images.alt_text: Mr Robin Khuda, founder of AirTrunk, announced that the bulk of the A$750 million will be spent expanding its current facilities in Sydney and Melbourne.

site_title: Brokers' take: KGI upgrades Japan Foods to 'outperform' with higher S$0.65 target price
summary: KGI Securities has upgraded its call on Japan Foods from "neutral" to "outperform" with a higher target price of S$0.65, citing the group's flexible business model and attractive dividend yield of 5% in FY2022. Analyst Joel Ng expects Japan Foods to grow and expand its market share, particularly with its halal-certified restaurants under the Tokyo Shokudo brand, which he believes will offer high growth potential.

images.alt_text: An impromptu memorial for singer Aretha Franklin, the "Queen of Soul" is shown outside New Bethel Baptist Church, the church where Aretha Franklin's late father Rev. C.L. Franklin was a minister and where she began her singing career, August 19, 2018 in Detroit, Michigan.

site_title: Lawrence Wong to deliver ministerial statement on support measures on July 5
summary: Finance Minister Lawrence Wong will deliver a ministerial statement on support measures for Phase 2 and Phase 3 (Heightened Alert) in Parliament on July 5, outlining funding approaches for the measures. This will be his first parliament speech since becoming Finance Minister in May.

site_title: China Huarong says cannot determine when it will publish 2020 earnings
summary: China Huarong Asset Management, the country's largest bad-debt manager, has delayed publishing its 2020 earnings and proposed postponing its annual shareholder meeting due to unfinished audit work and a proposed sale of stakes in a distressed asset exchange unit. The firm, whose shares have been suspended from trade since April 1, has assured auditors that operations are normal and that no material change has occurred in its business operations since then. The delay adds to the uncertainty surrounding the company, which has been struggling with failed investments, aggressive expansion, and a corruption case.

site_title: Singapore stocks advance at Wednesday's open; STI up 0.5%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.5% to 3,103.90 at open on Wednesday, tracking overnight gains on Wall Street. Gainers outnumbered losers 92 to 34, with Oceanus Group and Sembcorp Marine seeing brisk trading. Local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC also gained, while Thai Beverage (ThaiBev) rose half a cent. The US markets ended at records on Tuesday, with the Nasdaq Composite Index up 0.2% and the S&P 500 gaining less than 0.1%.

site_title: Japan's tax revenues likely reached record high in FY2020/21: sources
summary: Japan's tax revenues likely exceeded 60 trillion yen (S$726.4 billion) to a record high in FY2020/21, surpassing the government's initial estimate of 55.1 trillion yen. The boost was largely due to solid US and Chinese economic recoveries, which increased corporate profits. This news may encourage lawmakers to call for additional fiscal stimulus, potentially up to 10 trillion yen, ahead of the upcoming general election. Despite Japan's heavy public debt, the government has rolled out three stimulus packages totaling US$3 trillion to battle the pandemic.

site_title: Tokyo may extend coronavirus curbs into Olympics period
summary: Japan is considering extending its coronavirus prevention measures in Tokyo and other areas by two to four weeks, potentially overlapping with the July 23 start of the Tokyo Summer Olympics. The measures, currently set to be lifted on July 12, aim to address a recent uptick in cases and concerns about highly transmissible variants. The government is set to discuss the extension at a meeting later on Wednesday, with Chief Cabinet Secretary Katsunobu Kato stating that decisions will be made based on existing policies.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: MAS maintains its stance that the property market is not overheated, but will closely monitor rising prices. The central bank is conducting stress tests to assess the impact on banks' dividend caps. The global economy is expected to recover in H2, but virus mutations and inflation could pose risks. The STI rose 1.33% on Wednesday, posting its strongest half-year to June performance since 2017. The MAS managing director noted that a prolonged divergence between housing prices and income trends is unsustainable.

site_title: Chinese electric vehicle maker Xpeng to raise US$1.8b in Hong Kong listing: sources
summary: Xpeng Inc, a Chinese electric vehicle maker, plans to raise $1.8 billion in a Hong Kong dual primary listing, pricing its shares at HK$165 each. The company sold 85 million shares, equivalent to 5% of its shares, and has an over-allotment option for an additional $270 million. This follows the stock's recent decline, which has seen it drop from its November peak of $64.28. The dual primary listing allows qualified Chinese investors to invest in the company through the Stock Connect regime linking mainland Chinese and Hong Kong markets.

site_title: Stocks to watch: IReit, Oxley, Suntec Reit, UOB, Sembmarine
summary: IReit Global is issuing 11.4 million units at 61.55 Singapore cents per unit to raise S$126.7 million for a French retail property acquisition. Oxley is selling a piece of land overseas for S$100 million. Suntec Reit is divesting a portfolio of strata units and acquiring a London office building. UOB has lost a legal battle against developer Lippo Marina Collection and will appeal the decision. Sembmarine is partnering with SP Group to install solar energy across seven rooftops.

site_title: Trafigura completes first funding for committed prepayment portfolio fund worth US$155m
summary: Trafigura has completed the first funding for a US$155 million, closed-ended three-year committed prepayment portfolio fund. The fund was raised through private equity and senior debt from banks, including Lloyds Bank and Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corporation. The prepayment portfolio fund will be used to purchase insured prepayments from Trafigura, increasing its ability to agree further prepayments with producing counterparties. This fund introduces commodity-linked prepayments as a new asset class for investors, aiming to create a series of similar funds in a rapidly evolving commodity trading industry.

site_title: Australia: Shares track Wall Street higher, Telstra jumps on stake-sale plans
summary: Australian shares rose nearly 1% on Wednesday, tracking a strong finish on Wall Street, with Telstra scaling a 16-1/2-month high after plans to sell nearly half of its mobile tower business for A$2.8 billion. The S&P/ASX 200 index was up 0.9% at 7,366.4, while Japan's Nikkei gained 0.24%. The Australian miners sub-index was the top performer on the benchmark, with Rio Tinto shares rising 2% after declaring a force majeure on customer contracts.

site_title: Google-Microsoft truce crumbles amid feud over cloud, ad tech
summary: Microsoft and Google's truce over lobbying efforts has expired, with the companies resuming their public feud over cloud computing and ad tech. The two tech giants had agreed to cease using lobbying power against each other in 2016, but the deal lapsed in April. Microsoft claims Google's Search Ads 360 technology isn't interoperable with its Bing search engine, costing the software maker hundreds of millions in ad revenue. Google denies this, saying its product works with other search engines. The dispute escalates amid stepped-up regulation and antitrust activity against major tech companies, including Google, Apple, and Facebook.

site_title: GIC invests US$1b in plasma collection company Biomat
summary: Singapore's wealth fund GIC has invested around US$1 billion in Biomat, a US-based plasma collection company owned by Grifols. GIC will hold a minority stake in Biomat USA through the acquisition of newly issued non-voting shares, giving the company a strategic investor role. The investment will help Grifols reduce its debt of 6.2 billion euros. Grifols shares rose 1.5% following the announcement, valuing the company at 13.5 billion euros.

images.alt_text: Singapore's wealth fund GIC agreed to invest around US$1 billion dollars in Biomat, a US-based plasma collection company owned by Grifols, thus becoming a strategic investor in the Spanish pharmaceutical company, Grifols said on Wednesday.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares finish in negative territory
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed in negative territory on Wednesday, with the Hang Seng Index falling 0.57% to 28,827.95. The decline came as traders struggled to maintain early gains, following another Wall Street record. The Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.50% and the Shenzhen Composite Index climbed 1.02%. The losses come ahead of key US data releases this week, which may impact market sentiment.

site_title: China's factory activity growth slows slightly in June: PMI
summary: China's factory activity growth slowed to a four-month low in June, with the official manufacturing Purchasing Manager's Index (PMI) easing to 50.9 from 51.0 in May. Higher raw material costs, a global semiconductor shortage, and a resurgence of COVID-19 cases in Guangdong province contributed to the slowdown. Despite this, growth remained above the 50-point mark, and new orders picked up. Chinese authorities are taking steps to curb commodity price increases, with investigations launched into coal, iron ore, and fertilizer markets.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rise at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.39% at the open on Wednesday, driven by recovery optimism and a positive lead from Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index climbed to 29,107.90, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices remained flat. The rally came despite concerns over new virus spikes and US trade uncertainty.

site_title: MC Payment shareholders vote in new directors at EGM; most of current board resign
summary: MC Payment shareholders voted in favor of appointing five new directors, including Ching Chiat Kwong, to the company's board, with over 70% of votes in favor. Most of the current directors, including CEO Anthony Koh, resigned from the board after the vote. Ching Chiat Kwong's proposed additions include himself, his son Shawn Ching, and Harry Ng, who was previously lead independent director at Oxley Holdings. The move comes after Ching Chiat Kwong lost confidence in the current board, citing concerns over voting conduct and the authorization of a term sheet for a proposed acquisition.

site_title: 170 Pines members win suit against Exklusiv Resorts but awarded nominal S$1,500 each
summary: 170 members of The Pines won a class-action suit against Exklusiv Resorts for relocating the clubhouse at Stevens Road to a shared site in Tanah Merah. Justice Chua Lee Ming awarded them S$1,500 each, as the plaintiffs failed to prove the loss they incurred. The court allowed only the breach-of-contract claim, dismissing deceit, negligence, and negligent misrepresentation. Exklusiv Resorts had amended the rules to relocate the club at its sole discretion, but the judge ruled this was invalid. The High Court will decide on costs, with Exklusiv Resorts and the plaintiffs seeking reimbursement.

images.alt_text: John Bittleston, Founder & Chair, Terrific Mentors International Pte Ltd.

site_title: BT Explains: Life after Covid signals big change for commercial properties
summary: Singapore's commercial property market is expected to undergo significant changes post-Covid-19. The government's schemes, such as the Central Business District Incentive (CBDI) and Strategic Development Incentive (SDI) schemes, are driving redevelopment of older buildings into mixed-use developments. Cloud kitchens are also expected to grow, particularly in suburban malls and shophouses, while business parks are expected to see increased demand driven by Singapore's biomedical sector. The long-term reduction of office stock in the CBD is also anticipated, supporting the government's decentralisation strategy.

site_title: Gold set for biggest monthly drop since 2016
summary: Gold prices are on track for their worst monthly drop since 2016, falling 7.5% for the month as investors await US jobs data for clarity on the Federal Reserve's policy stance. The precious metal has touched its lowest since April 15 at $1,749.20. A Fed rate hike could increase the opportunity cost of holding gold, dulling its appeal. The US nonfarm payrolls data on Friday is expected to drive the market, with a rise in jobs potentially leading to the next floor in gold.

site_title: Seoul delays relaxation of social distancing as Covid-19 cases surge
summary: Seoul, South Korea has delayed the relaxation of social distancing rules by one week due to a surge in Covid-19 cases. The city had planned to lift restrictions, including private gatherings of up to six people, starting July 1, but the increase in cases, including Delta variants, led authorities to reconsider. The decision aims to prevent further transmission and confusion. Experts warn that the relaxation of restrictions may have sent the wrong signal to the public, and health authorities urge caution. South Korea has inoculated nearly 30% of its population with at least one dose of the Covid-19 vaccine.

site_title: Firmer global recovery on the cards in H2, but virus mutations, Fed moves could be drags: MAS
summary: MAS managing director Ravi Menon expects a stronger global recovery in the second half of 2021, driven by the US and China's strong rebounds. However, downside risks include the emergence of infectious virus mutations and a sharp pickup in US inflation, potentially leading to premature tightening of financial conditions. Singapore is forecasted to recover in the second half of 2021, with GDP growth exceeding 4-6%, and the MAS maintaining its official forecast range. The central bank also warned retail investors against investing in cryptocurrencies due to huge risks and volatility.

images.alt_text: A firmer global recovery is on the cards in the second half of 2021 with the world's two largest economies the US and China witnessing strong rebounds, but downside risks remain significant.

site_title: Oxley to sell overseas property for S$100m
summary: Oxley Holdings, a subsidiary of 5UX, has agreed to sell overseas property for approximately S$100 million. The sale, if completed by June 30, 2022, is expected to have a significant impact on the company's earnings per share. A deposit of 10% of the sale price has been paid, with the balance due upon completion, subject to regulatory approval. The sale is conditional on allowing greater development of the site within 12 months. This move is expected to contribute positively to the company's cash flow.

site_title: MAS doing more stress tests to assess lift on Singapore banks' dividend cap
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is conducting additional stress tests to assess the impact of lifting its dividend restrictions on local banks, which have strong capital levels and earnings. Analysts expect the MAS to ease the restrictions, citing healthy earnings and capital levels, but caution that ongoing economic uncertainty could weigh on the central bank's decision. The MAS has been monitoring the banks' capital-management plans and will advise them on its position "very shortly."

site_title: Three new Covid-19 cases linked to Changi General Hospital
summary: Three new Covid-19 cases in Singapore are linked to clusters at Changi General Hospital and Block 105 Henderson Crescent. The MOH reported a total of 16 cases from these clusters. A community case is also linked to a new cluster involving a 76-year-old retiree. The cases were announced on June 30, with the woman initially seeking medical treatment at Singapore General Hospital on June 25.

site_title: IReit Global launches equity fundraising to raise S$126.7m for France property acquisition
summary: IReit Global is issuing a non-underwritten placement of 11.4 million units at 61.55 Singapore cents per unit to raise around S$7 million. The placement is part of a S$126.7 million equity fundraising to acquire 27 retail properties in France for S$195.7 million. IReit will also launch an underwritten pro rata and non-renounceable preferential offering for eligible unitholders to raise S$119.7 million. Net proceeds will be used to finance the acquisition and repay debt.

site_title: Recipients of Sinovac Covid-19 vaccine not exempted from pre-event testing: MOH
summary: The Ministry of Health (MOH) in Singapore has stated that recipients of the Sinovac Covid-19 vaccine are not exempt from pre-event testing, despite the vaccine being approved by the government for use under the Special Access Route (SAR) framework. The Sinovac vaccine is not part of Singapore's national vaccination programme and lacks sufficient documentation of its effectiveness against the Delta variant. MOH advises individuals vaccinated with other vaccines to undergo pre-event testing before attending events.

site_title: Didi raises US$4b in US IPO: sources
summary: Chinese ride-hailing company Didi Global Inc raised US$4 billion in its US initial public offering (IPO), pricing 288 million shares at US$14 apiece, giving it a valuation of US$73 billion. The deal comes amid record IPO activity and follows a more conservative valuation than initially planned, suggesting investor concerns over China's potential anti-trust crackdown. Didi's shares are set to debut on the New York Stock Exchange on June 30, marking the largest US share sale by a Chinese company since Alibaba's 2014 IPO.

site_title: Japan's May factory output posts biggest monthly drop in a year
summary: Japan's factory output declined 5.9% in May, the largest monthly drop in a year, due to a sharp fall in car production. The decline was weaker than forecast, with a 19.4% drop in motor vehicle production mainly attributed to semiconductor chip supply issues. Despite this, the government expects the economy to rebound in June and July. The contraction follows a 2.9% gain in the previous month and raises concerns about the country's economic recovery, particularly ahead of the Tokyo Olympics.

images.alt_text: Aliqqa Noverry, 9, demonstrating her skateboarding skills at a public park ahead of the 2018 Asian Games in Jakarta. The pint-sized adrenaline junkie is the youngest competitor at this year's event.

site_title: MAS says property market not overheated, but it will watch rising prices closely
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has stated that the property market is not overheated, but remains vigilant to the risk of a sustained increase in housing prices relative to income trends. Despite a 1.6% rise in residential property prices in 2020, MAS managing director Ravi Menon noted that the market has been "remarkably resilient" and will continue to monitor the situation closely. MAS has a set of macroprudential policy tools to prevent over-inflation, and Menon emphasized the need for stability in the market.

site_title: Brokers' take: Lim & Tan positive on Tiong Woon amid construction sector recovery; initiates with 'buy'
summary: Lim & Tan Securities has initiated coverage on Tiong Woon Corporation with a "buy" call and a target price of S$0.84, citing the construction sector's recovery in Singapore. The company expects Tiong Woon to benefit from this recovery, as well as delayed contracts from last year. Singapore's Building and Construction Authority has awarded over S$23 billion worth of contracts, supporting the optimistic view.

site_title: Federal Reserve's Waller does not rule out 2022 rate hike
summary: Federal Reserve Governor Christopher Waller expressed optimism about the economy, stating he's "very optimistic" about the economic outlook. He declined to specify when interest rates might be raised, but hinted it could happen in 2022 if inflation remains high or unemployment drops substantially. Waller also suggested tapering the Fed's $40 billion mortgage-backed securities purchases, citing the strong housing market. He favors phasing out these purchases first, as the housing market "doesn't need any other unnecessary support."

site_title: Banks lost US$300m in 'fraudulent loans' to Hin Leong
summary: SINGAPORE: 16 banks lost nearly US$300 million in loans to Hin Leong Trading, a collapsed oil trader, due to "fraudulent" practices by founder Lim Oon Kuin. The losses stem from 130 forgery-related charges against Lim. The banks were allegedly deceived into extending US$2.77 billion loans to Hin Leong, with the actual losses totaling US$291.9 million. The case against Lim is ongoing, with prosecutors tendering charges related to the collapsed company.

site_title: Singapore bank lending up 0.2% in May: MAS data
summary: Singapore bank lending rose 0.2% in May, driven by a 0.2% increase in business loans, which rebounded from a flattish performance in April. Consumer loans continued their growth streak, up 0.3% for the 10th straight month. Total bank lending increased by 1.2% year on year, faster than the 0.4% rise in April. This marks the seventh consecutive month of growth in business loans, while consumer loans have been steadily increasing since January.

site_title: Pandemic gives Singapore biotechs a shot in the arm
summary: Singapore biotech startups have raised a record US$360 million in investments so far in 2021, exceeding the previous year's record of US$65.5 million by five times. The surge in funding is attributed to tailwinds from the pandemic, with larger rounds raised by companies like Engine Biosciences, Esco Lifesciences, and Hummingbird Biosciences. However, industry players caution that the small Singaporean market cannot sustain the sector's growth, making it essential for biotechs to diversify and explore global opportunities.

site_title: MOH to stop giving details of Covid-19 community cases
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Health (MOH) will stop providing detailed information on community Covid-19 cases, instead focusing on vaccination progress and severe disease cases. The decision aims to prevent the spread of the virus and promote a "new normal." As of June 30, about 3.28 million people have received at least one dose of the vaccine, with 57.5% of the population partially vaccinated and 36.8% fully vaccinated. The MOH will still report daily case numbers and severe disease cases, with a focus on key trends and vaccination rates.

site_title: Hong Kong security law is 'a human rights emergency': Amnesty
summary: Hong Kong's national security law has been used to target dissent, justify censorship, and violate human rights, according to Amnesty International. Implemented a year ago, the law sets punishment for subversion, secession, and terrorism with up to life in prison. Most high-profile democratic politicians and activists have been arrested or are in self-exile, with Amnesty describing the law as a "human rights emergency" that threatens to make Hong Kong a "human rights wasteland." Authorities claim rights remain protected, but the international human rights group cites evidence of widespread human rights violations.

site_title: US newspaper woes deepened in pandemic year: survey
summary: The US newspaper sector experienced significant job losses, with 4,000 reporters, editors, or photographers cut from newsrooms in 2020, totaling 12% of total employment. Print circulation declined 19% for weekdays and 14% for Sundays, but digital circulation and subscribers rose 38%. Despite a 6% overall circulation decline, digital revenue surpassed ad revenue for the first time, with estimated circulation revenue reaching $11.1 billion. The decline in print readers was slower than in recent years, according to a Pew Research Centre report.

site_title: South Korea factory output unexpectedly declines from April; grows at fastest annual rate in 11 years
summary: South Korea's factory output declined 0.7% seasonally in May, missing forecasts, but saw the fastest annual growth in 11 years, up 15.6% from 2020. This growth was driven by a sharp recovery from the pandemic's impact in 2020. Despite the monthly decline, the overall trend suggests a strong economic rebound.

images.alt_text: South Korea's factory output in May unexpectedly declined from April but logged the fastest expansion in near 11 years on a year-on-year basis compared to 2020's pandemic-impacted figures, government data showed on Wednesday.

site_title: Worth setting the alarm clock to savour the twists and turns of a captivating Euro 2020
summary: Football fans have been treated to captivating Euro 2020 matches, staying up late to watch thrilling games like Portugal's 2-2 draw with France, Germany's 4-2 win over Portugal, and the Netherlands' 3-2 victory over Ukraine. The time difference between Asia and Europe makes it difficult for fans to get a proper night's sleep, but the excitement of these matches makes it worth it.

site_title: Asia's new coal plant plans jeopardise climate targets: report
summary: Asian countries, particularly China, India, Indonesia, Japan, and Vietnam, plan to build over 600 new coal-fired power projects, with a combined capacity of over 300 gigawatts, contradicting international climate goals. According to Carbon Tracker, 92% of these projects would be uneconomical, wasting up to $150 billion. Existing coal plants would also be left stranded if Paris climate targets are reached, with $220 billion at risk. Renewable energy sources will become cheaper than coal by 2024, and by 2026, almost all global coal capacity will be more expensive to run than renewable power generation.

images.alt_text: China, India, Indonesia, Japan and Vietnam plan to build more than 600 new coal-fired power projects, with a combined capacity of more than 300 gigawatts.

site_title: Europe: Sharp rise in sentiment helps stocks higher
summary: European shares ended higher on Tuesday, driven by a sharp rise in economic sentiment, which reached a 21-year high in June. The Stoxx 600 index rose 0.3% to 456.37 points, with chemical stocks leading the gain. Adidas lifted the German index with a share buyback plan, while travel-related stocks fell 0.2% due to concerns over the Delta variant. Despite concerns over inflation, optimism around a steady economic recovery has put the European benchmark on course for its fifth straight month of gains.

site_title: The CCP at 100: Can it lead China to be the wave of the future?
summary: China's Communist Party (CCP) marks its 100th anniversary on July 1, amid a global environment of ambivalence towards its rise. As the world's largest trading nation, China is poised to overtake the US as the largest economy within the next decade. However, the US and China are locked in a geopolitical challenge, with both sides viewing the other's rise as a threat to their interests. The US sees China as undermining the status quo, while China views the US as preventing its peaceful rise. To avoid a catastrophic war, both countries must find convergence in their interests and prioritize trust and cooperation, rather than a zero-sum game.

site_title: Dozens dead as heat wave grips Canada, US: police
summary: At least 69 people have died in a record-breaking heat wave in western Canada and the US Pacific Northwest, mostly elderly or with underlying health conditions. The heat wave, caused by a high-pressure ridge trapping warm air, has broken temperature records, including Canada's all-time high of 47.9°C (118°F) in Lytton, BC. Environment Canada and the US National Weather Service have issued warnings, urging people to stay indoors and drink plenty of water. Climate change is exacerbating record-setting temperatures, with the decade of 2019 being the hottest on record.

images.alt_text: Globally, the decade to 2019 was the hottest recorded, and the five hottest years have all occurred within the last five years.

site_title: Biden touts historic infrastructure plan in blue-collar US
summary: US President Joe Biden touted his historic infrastructure plan in a blue-collar US town in Wisconsin, comparing it to the creation of the Interstate highway system. He emphasized the need for a generational investment to modernize America's infrastructure, competing with the rest of the world in the 21st century. Biden is pushing for two infrastructure bills, one focusing on traditional areas and another with "human infrastructure" investments. The total cost of the plans is estimated to be around $1 trillion and several trillion dollars.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden stood in an oily, machinery filled warehouse in Wisconsin to tout his multi-trillion dollar infrastructure plans Tuesday, arguing that America needs everything from better bridges to broadband to remain competitive.

site_title: Musk set to invest up to US$30b in Starlink
summary: Elon Musk plans to invest up to $30 billion in his Starlink satellite internet service, aiming to deploy thousands of low-orbit satellites to provide high-speed internet to isolated areas. Currently operating in about a dozen countries, Starlink expects to have a few hundred thousand users within 12 months. Musk hopes to reduce the cost of Starlink terminals from $1,000 to $220-$250, and has partnerships with major telcos and is in discussions with others. The service faces competition from rivals like OneWeb and Amazon's Kuiper.

site_title: Flexibility at a premium for monetary policy as central banks face delicate balancing act: BIS
summary: Central banks face a delicate balancing act as the global economy recovers from the pandemic. According to the Bank for International Settlements (BIS), they need to pursue "growth-friendly" policies to reduce massive debt burdens, particularly in developed and emerging economies. This growth should help alleviate debt and support economic stability, according to BIS General Manager Agustin Carstens.

site_title: Oil steadies as Opec fuels demand hopes amid new Covid-19 worries
summary: Oil prices steadied on Tuesday as hopes for a demand recovery persisted, fueled by Opec's secretary general comments. Brent crude futures rose 8 cents to $74.76 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose 7 cents to $72.98 a barrel. Opec Secretary General Mohammad Barkindo said the "Delta Variant" of the pandemic is a "wild card" factor, but expects gradual production ramp-ups to keep up with demand. Analysts expect vaccination programs to brighten the demand outlook, despite new outbreaks.

site_title: US to require crash reports for driver-assistance autos
summary: US safety regulators have ordered Tesla and other auto manufacturers with driver assistance systems to report serious crashes, including fatalities and hospital-treated injuries, within one day. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) aims to collect data to identify safety issues and instill public confidence in automated vehicles. The new policy requires reporting of incidents involving air bag deployments, vehicle tow-aways, and vulnerable road users, with data to be made publicly available. This move comes after a series of troubling incidents and calls for tighter regulation of driver-assistance systems.

site_title: Saudi crown prince launches strategy to make kingdom a logistics hub
summary: Saudi Arabia's Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman has launched a strategy to make the kingdom a global logistics hub, aiming to boost the sector's contribution to non-oil revenues to $16.14 billion by 2030. The plan includes launching a new national airline, increasing air cargo capacity, and developing ports and infrastructure. The strategy also seeks to increase the transport and logistics sector's contribution to GDP to 10% from 6%. The move is part of Prince Mohammed's efforts to diversify the economy and reduce reliance on oil revenues by 2030.

site_title: Financial sector faces heavier burden in EU climate plans, sources say
summary: The European Union is considering measures to bring its financial sector into line with climate plans, including combating greenwashing, setting climate change targets, and encouraging low-carbon blockchain projects. The EU aims to eliminate net emissions by 2050 and will assess how financial markets contribute to this goal. A strategy paper outlines several actions, including a consolidated report on EU financial markets' transition by the end of 2023, a digital sustainable finance roadmap, and initiatives to empower retail investors and small companies through green loans and mortgages.

site_title: Laguna note holders to raise funds for legal case against Peter Kwee, Laguna
summary: Laguna National Golf and Country Club debenture holders, who are owed money from their 30-year-old debentures, may mount a legal case against club owner Peter Kwee. The club's financials show losses of $1.5 million in 2020, with accumulated losses of $15.5 million as of 2000. Debenture holders claim their money was used to finance the club's construction and that Kwee has underestimated the number of individuals seeking full redemption of their notes. A pro-tem committee, led by Lim How Teck, is raising funds to bring a case against Kwee and the club.

images.alt_text: Financial statements from two decades ago show Laguna National has accumulated losses of S$15.5 million as at December 2000, seven years after its inauguration.

site_title: Bringing clinical trials to the home: a game changer for the sector
summary: Singapore's pharmaceutical and healthcare companies are redesigning clinical trials to run remotely due to the COVID-19 pandemic, leveraging technology such as apps, sensors, and wearables to track patient health indicators. This shift promises to shorten timelines for drug and vaccine development, but issues of interoperability and data privacy need to be urgently addressed. The industry must prioritize patient safety and transparency, and Singapore's government and industry must work together to facilitate the adoption of this new model, which has huge potential benefits for the sector.

site_title: Monetary sovereignty at risk in push for digital euro: French central banker
summary: France's central bank head warns that Europe's control over its money is at risk if it doesn't push ahead with a digital euro and European payments system. With 30+ banks setting up retail systems for instant transactions, time is running out, with only a year or two left. The European Central Bank's plans for a digital currency could drain money from high street bank accounts, potentially siphoning 8% of euro zone banks' customer deposits. However, the Bank of France says a CBDC could complement banks, making transactions easier and safer.

site_title: Euro 2020: England break Germany curse with 2-0 win, Ukraine await
summary: England defeated Germany 2-0 at Wembley to reach the Euro 2020 quarter-finals, ending their decades-long curse against the German national team. Raheem Sterling scored the opening goal with a quarter of an hour remaining, and Harry Kane sealed the win with a diving header in the 86th minute. The victory sets up a showdown with Ukraine, who defeated Sweden 2-1 in extra time. Germany's defeat marked the end of coach Joachim Loew's 15-year tenure, and the team's earliest exit from the European Championship since 2004.

site_title: Singapore inks advance purchase deal with GSK for Covid-19 drug sotrovimab
summary: Singapore has signed an advance purchase deal with GlaxoSmithKline (GSK) and Vir Biotechnology for the supply of sotrovimab, a Covid-19 treatment. The deal is for patients with mild to moderate Covid-19 and is currently undergoing regulatory review. Results from a Phase 3 trial showed an 85% reduction in hospitalization or death in those receiving sotrovimab. The treatment targets a conserved epitope of the Sars-CoV-2 spike protein and appears to retain activity against all circulating variants, including the Delta variant.

site_title: US: Stocks edge to records as consumer confidence rises
summary: US stocks rose to records on Tuesday, driven by a surge in consumer confidence to its highest point since the pandemic's start, with the Nasdaq Composite Index leading the market at 0.2% gain. The S&P 500 also reached a record, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average finished up slightly. Analysts attribute the improvement to low virus transmission, vaccinations, and expanded reopenings. However, concerns about the Delta strain of the virus remain, prompting fresh restrictions in other countries. United Airlines fell 0.7% after announcing a record plane order, while Morgan Stanley gained 3.3% following new dividend and share repurchase announcements.

site_title: 'Not perfect enough' - China has a growing problem of eating disorders
summary: China is experiencing a growing problem of eating disorders, with a 25-fold increase in cases reported in major cities since 2002. The issue is often linked to low self-esteem, social media pressure, and traditional beauty standards. Despite some hospitals reporting a rise in cases, recognition and treatment options are limited in China. Campaigners like Zhang Qinwen are working to raise awareness and challenge societal beauty ideals, with exhibitions and performances highlighting the struggles of those affected.

site_title: Positioning portfolios in the face of policy exits
summary: The US Federal Reserve has effectively begun the countdown to the final lift-off in its interest rates policy, with the median dot-plot predicting two rate hikes in 2023. This hawkish pivot is driven by strong inflation readings, but analysts note that inflation data is distorted by base effects and supply-side bottlenecks. The Fed's Flexible Average Interest Rate Targeting (FAIT) framework targets inflation over a longer historical window, allowing for short-term inflation overshoots. As fiscal policy tightens, markets are expected to be volatile, but UOB Private Bank recommends staying invested in cyclical sectors and quality growth stocks, with a focus on credit-oriented portfolios.

site_title: Singapore still in 'transition': Lawrence Wong
summary: Singapore remains in a transition phase before reaching the "new normal" of living with endemic Covid-19, according to Finance Minister Lawrence Wong. The country aims to safeguard its position as an international business hub while easing restrictions and opening borders to vaccinated travelers. Wong emphasized the need for a balance between reopening and protecting seniors, warning of potential high infection rates, hospitalizations, and fatalities if restrictions are lifted too quickly.

images.alt_text: Before Singapore reaches the "new normal" of living with endemic Covid-19, which will require high vaccination rates, the country remains in a transition phase, Finance Minister Lawrence Wong said at a dialogue organised by the Singapore Business Federation (SBF) on Tuesday.

site_title: UK house prices surge most in 17 years: Nationwide Building Society
summary: UK house prices surged 13.4% in June, the largest annual increase in 17 years, according to Nationwide Building Society. The growth is driven by buyers seeking more space outside urban areas and low borrowing costs. Prices rose to a new all-time high of £254,432, with the typical mortgage payment remaining low compared to take-home pay. The market is expected to remain buoyant despite a temporary tax break on purchases set to end on September 30.

site_title: Laguna's debenture holders had 'many options' to surrender notes: owner Peter Kwee
summary: Laguna National Golf and Country Club's owner, Peter Kwee, stated that pioneer members who took up debentures to finance the club's construction are unlikely to receive their money back. About 100 members are awaiting redemption of non-interest-bearing unsecured notes worth S$120,000 each, totaling S$12 million. Kwee acknowledged that he provided various options to members, including spending credits and membership extensions, to reduce their obligations. The club's financial position is currently unsustainable, with accumulated losses of S$15.5 million in 2000 and S$1.5 million in 2020.

site_title: 5 new locally transmitted Covid-19 cases in Singapore, all linked
summary: Singapore reported 5 locally transmitted COVID-19 cases on June 29, 2021, with all linked to existing clusters. The number of new cases in the community has fallen from 104 to 76 in the past week. 10 new cases, including 5 imported, brought Singapore's total to 62,563. 49,445 received their first COVID-19 vaccine dose, and 5,298 received their second dose, with 57.5% of the population partially vaccinated.

site_title: How to invest through high inflation
summary: Warren Buffett's 1981 Berkshire Hathaway shareholder letter outlined a blueprint for investors to cope with high inflation. Businesses that can easily increase prices and accommodate large dollar volume increases without significant additional capital investments are better equipped to handle inflation. Technology businesses that offer digital products or services, such as DocuSign and Facebook, possess these characteristics, as they have minimal marginal costs and no need for significant capital investments to increase sales volumes. These businesses can accommodate large increases in sales volume without tying up valuable working capital, making them more resilient to inflation.

images.alt_text: Technology businesses that offer digital products or services have one of Mr Buffett's required characteristics to cope well with inflation. An examples of such businesses is Etsy.

site_title: A new growth priority - venture building
summary: A growing number of global executives consider venture-building as a top three growth priority, with 55% in Asia citing it as a top-three priority, up from 20% pre-pandemic. Despite this momentum, only one in four new ventures launched by incumbents have become viable large-scale enterprises. Common pitfalls include a lack of adaptability, inadequate scaling strategies, and insufficient commitment from top management. Successful venture builders address these issues by creating learning buffers, testing products with customers, and leveraging the resources of their corporate parent. A long-term customer-backed strategy and effective leadership are also crucial for success.

images.alt_text: Venture building offers incumbents a unique opportunity: the chance to marry their resources and experience with a startup's agility and rapid growth potential.

site_title: Tricia Song, Linda Chern to join property consulting group CBRE
summary: CBRE has appointed Tricia Song as the head of research for South-east Asia and Linda Chern as head of residential services for Singapore, effective July 5 and July 1 respectively. Song, a 20-year veteran in research, will lead the firm's commercial real estate research, while Chern, a 20-year veteran in residential, will spearhead the marketing of ultra-luxurious and high-end residential properties. The appointments are seen as a strategic move to strengthen CBRE's market-leading real estate services.

site_title: Therapy dogs soothe amid trauma of Florida collapse
summary: Therapy dogs, including German Shepherds and Belgian Malinois, are being deployed in Surfside, Florida, to provide emotional comfort to those affected by the recent collapse of the Champlain Towers South apartment tower. The therapy dogs, brought by groups such as the United Cajun Navy, offer a unique form of healing and stress relief, with owners and volunteers reporting positive interactions. The dogs' presence is seen as a valuable addition to the ongoing rescue and aid efforts, providing a much-needed sense of comfort and companionship to those dealing with trauma and uncertainty.

site_title: Singapore's ageing population's care needs will shape everyday realities
summary: Singapore's ageing population is projected to shape the country's everyday realities, with the latest census revealing that over 7 in 10 residents aged 65 or older face difficulty with basic activities. The census data will inform policies on aged care, such as the need for care facilities and services. As the population continues to age, the demand for aged care is expected to grow, compounded by other long-term trends, including changes in living arrangements and a shrinking workforce. The increased need for caregivers may be mitigated by the potential for older, healthier residents to stay economically active past retirement age.

site_title: US federal judge throws out two antitrust cases against Facebook
summary: A US federal judge dismissed two antitrust cases against Facebook, throwing out allegations that the company holds a monopoly on social networking. The judge found prosecutors had failed to provide enough facts to support the claim and that the states waited too long to bring their case. The FTC can try again within 30 days, but the agency faces steep challenges. The decision is a setback for regulators' efforts to break up Facebook and has implications for the tech industry, with lawmakers calling for updates to century-old antitrust laws.

site_title: More clarity could help America's industrial policy
summary: The US Senate has passed the US Innovation and Competition Act (USICA) of 2021, which aims to boost American competitiveness and support strategic industries through subsidies, tariffs, and tax breaks. However, critics argue that the bill's focus on countering Chinese influence and supporting weaker research universities may not strengthen America's manufacturing and defense capabilities. Instead, they suggest that strengthening technical training and reforming immigration rules to admit more foreign STEM workers could yield greater returns for innovation and competitiveness. The bill's emphasis on basic research funding is seen as a more effective approach to promoting American innovation.

site_title: Singapore merger and acquisition activity hits record-high in H1 2021
summary: Singapore saw a record-high merger and acquisition (M&A) activity in the first half of 2021, with total deal values reaching US$80.9 billion, a 82.4% year-on-year increase. The largest deal was Grab Holdings' de-SPAC transaction with Altimeter Growth Corp, valued at US$31.1 billion. Inbound M&A activity surged 545.4% to US$37.6 billion, while outbound deals increased 75.7% to US$25.2 billion, with the US being the most active acquirer and target nation.

site_title: US dollar set for biggest rise as virus cases climb
summary: The US dollar is poised for its largest single-day gain in seven trading sessions, rising 0.2% against a basket of its rivals, driven by concerns over the spread of the highly infectious Delta variant of coronavirus, which threatens global economic recovery. The Australian and British pounds also fell, with the euro edging back toward a two-month low. Market sentiment is weakening, allowing the US dollar to benefit from risk aversion, with economists predicting potential downward revisions to second-half growth forecasts.

site_title: Chinese Communist Party needs new 'heroes' to meet future goals: President Xi
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping emphasized the need for new "heroes" to carry the Communist Party into its second century, as he celebrated 29 officials who contributed to its longevity. Xi, who has focused on rooting out corruption, urged officials to be "clean people" and devote themselves to public duties. The event marks the party's 100-year anniversary, with Xi expected to make a key speech on Thursday, solidifying his control over domestic politics ahead of a party congress next year.

site_title: From tattoos to tokens at Tokyo's first crypto art show
summary: Tokyo's first crypto art exhibition, "CrypTokyo," has opened, featuring 150 NFTs from various artists, including tattoo artist Ichi Hatano. The digital art exhibition showcases works that can be bought and sold as non-fungible tokens, using blockchain technology. Artists hope to monetize their digital creations and reach a wider audience. Despite some caution among Japanese buyers, the exhibition aims to demonstrate the potential of NFTs to spark broader creativity and provide new economic opportunities for artists.

site_title: Malaysia's rubber glove boom spotlights longtime labour standards issues
summary: Malaysia's rubber glove manufacturers, including Top Glove, Hartalega, and Kossan, face criticism over poor working and living conditions, with employees reporting cramped, unclean, and vermin-infested dormitories. Despite claims of adherence to government regulations, workers spoke of gruelling 12-hour workdays, lack of personal space, and inadequate facilities. The companies' financial success has attracted investor scrutiny, with the US Customs and Border Protection issuing a Withhold Release Order against Top Glove due to forced labor allegations. Industry critics warn of a lack of checks and balances, and labor rights activists call for improved labor standards and transparency.

site_title: Bali reopening to foreign tourists delayed as Covid-19 outbreak surges
summary: Indonesia's government has delayed reopening Bali to foreign tourists due to a surge in Covid-19 cases, with daily infections in Bali rising fourfold in the past month. The tourism minister, Sandiaga Uno, aims for daily infections to fall to 30-40 before reopening, citing low testing rates. Domestic travelers will be required to undergo a Polymerase Chain Reaction test before entering the island. The government is also considering a five-year visa for "digital nomads" and plans to achieve full vaccination for 70% of Bali's population by the end of July.

site_title: Tender for Jalan Anak Bukit site closes below expectations with just five bids
summary: A state tender for the 99-year leasehold Jalan Anak Bukit site in Singapore closed with just five bids, below expectations. The site, near Beauty World MRT, has a maximum gross floor area of 1.04 million sq ft and will be developed into a mixed-use integrated transport hub. Developers Far East Organization and Sino Group submitted three separate bids, while Allgreen Properties and Kerry Holdings teamed up for another bid. Analysts attribute the low response to the high land cost and construction sector headwinds due to the pandemic.

site_title: ecoWise reinstates deputy CEO; will comply with SGX RegCo's directives
summary: Ecowise Holdings has reinstated the duties of suspended staff, including deputy CEO Cao Shixuan, and will comply with Singapore Exchange Regulation Committee (SGX RegCo) directives. The company will appoint new independent directors, commission internal and external audits, and form a new auditing committee. Payments must now be reviewed and approved by the entire board, with additional safeguards to ensure ongoing operations. Trading in the group's securities remains suspended until all directives are completed.

site_title: Day of Seafarer marked by renewed commitments
summary: The International Maritime Organization (IMO) marked the Day of the Seafarer on June 25, 2021, with a focus on a Fair Future for Seafarers. Seafarers continue to face restrictions and challenges due to the Covid-19 pandemic, including access to repatriation, shore leave, and medical support. IMO Secretary-General Kitack Lim emphasized the need for a fair future, including a safe and secure environment, reasonable working conditions, and respect for seafarers' rights. A poll conducted by IMO received over 16,000 responses from seafarers, highlighting the importance of a shared responsibility for a fair future.

site_title: UOB loses suit against Lippo but plans to appeal
summary: UOB has lost a long-running lawsuit against Lippo Marina Collection (LMC) over inflated mortgages, with the Singapore High Court dismissing the bank's claims that Lippo had inflated mortgages to get higher housing loans. The court ruled that LMC was not liable for the inflated loans, but found UOB's allegations of misrepresentations against two property agents, Goh Buck Lim and Aurellia Ho, to be valid. UOB plans to appeal the decision, which could result in the bank recovering approximately S$181 million.

images.alt_text: The Marina Collection was launched for sale in late 2007, but sales were hampered after a series of cooling measures - with only 42 of its 124 units sold by March 10, 2011.

site_title: EHT unitholders file lawsuit against manager's board, claiming shortfalls in disclosure
summary: Two investors of Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT) are suing six directors for allegedly failing to disclose material information about late security deposit payments, which they claim would have affected investors' investment decisions. The lawsuit, filed by Ajeet Gobindram Vaswani and Viresh Ajeet Vaswani, seeks US$1.55 million and US$305,000 respectively. The trust collapsed in or around March 2020. The six defendants, including the manager's former and current directors, are accused of withholding relevant information.

site_title: Digital Covid certificate roll-out risks chaos, warn EU airlines, airports
summary: European airlines and airports have warned of potential chaos and long queues if the EU's digital Covid-19 certificate system is not coordinated properly. The system, set to be implemented on July 1, requires extra checks and equipment to read QR codes on vaccination certificates. To avoid huge delays, countries must process travellers before they arrive at airports, with checks only taking place in the country of departure. If not implemented correctly, the risk of queues and crowding at airports could increase to 5-8 hours, undermining passenger confidence.

images.alt_text: The digital Covid-19 certificates are designed to be used for travel throughout the EU from July 1, but would require extra checks and the right equipment to read the codes.

site_title: The Working Capitol, owing S$13.2m, applies for debt restructuring
summary: Singaporean co-working operator The Working Capitol has filed for debt restructuring amid S$13.2 million in debt owed to creditors, excluding related parties. The company's total debt, including loans from co-founders and related entities, is approximately S$26 million. The Working Capitol has been unable to reach an agreement with two landlords, Crocodile International and AIA Singapore, to renegotiate rental payments. The company plans to continue operations and aims to evolve its business model into an owner-operator one with aligned patient capital partners.

site_title: When investors are plentiful and allocations fall short
summary: Singapore-based investors are seeking investment-grade bonds and technology unicorn IPOs amid a low-interest-rate environment. However, when demand exceeds supply, allocation shortfalls occur, potentially triggering dissatisfaction among investors. To address this, the CFA Institute's Fair Dealing Standard emphasizes fair treatment of all clients, including transparent trade allocation procedures and differentiated services that do not disadvantage or negatively affect clients. Finance professionals must establish compliance procedures to ensure fair dealing, and disclose allocation methods to clients and prospective clients.

site_title: ESG investments performing better than traditional ones: study
summary: A global study by The Economist Intelligence Unit found that nearly three-quarters of institutional investors believe ESG (environmental, social, and corporate governance) investments outperform traditional ones. The study, which surveyed 450 investors worldwide, also found that the pandemic is expected to accelerate interest in ESG investments, with 74% of respondents anticipating increased capital inflows into sustainable investments over the next three to five years. The top drivers for ESG integration are expected to shift post-pandemic, with mitigation of recession impacts becoming a key factor.

site_title: Oil drops on worries about impact of virus surges
summary: Oil prices dropped 0.9% to $74.01 a barrel, with Brent crude futures falling 67 cents and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures falling 83 cents, on concerns about the Delta variant of coronavirus sparking new mobility restrictions. Despite this, analysts expect vaccine rollouts to improve demand outlook and Opec+ to step up supply in August, citing a tight market with a 2.2 million barrel per day supply shortfall in the fourth quarter. Opec's demand forecasts show room for producers to agree to add output.

site_title: Moderna's Covid-19 vaccine shows promise against Delta variant in lab study
summary: Moderna's Covid-19 vaccine demonstrated promise against the Delta variant in a lab study, with a modest decrease in antibody response compared to the original strain. The vaccine elicited neutralizing antibodies against the Delta variant, with a 3.2 to 2.1 fold reduction, and was more effective than against the Beta variant. The study's results support the vaccine's continued protection against newly detected variants, according to Moderna CEO Stéphane Bancel.

site_title: Covid-19 infections weigh on Asian markets, STI down 1.2%
summary: Singapore shares retreated 1.2% on Tuesday, following a rise in Covid-19 infections and fresh containment measures in the region. The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 37.39 points to 3,089.49. Only two STI constituents ended the day in the black, with Venture Corp being upgraded to "buy" by RHB. The region's performance lags behind Western counterparts amid uncertainty over virus controls.

site_title: New Boeing 777X needs more testing, US regulator says
summary: US air safety regulators, the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA), have notified Boeing that its new 777X widebody plane requires more than two years of additional testing and analysis before certification. The FAA has set a realistic certification timeline of mid to late 2023, citing issues such as an "uncommanded pitch" event and outstanding questions on the plane. Boeing has been working with the FAA to address these concerns, and the company remains committed to safety. The news comes amid scrutiny of Boeing and the FAA following the 737 MAX grounding.

site_title: Trustana seeking to help SMEs break barriers to trading globally
summary: Trustana, a TEMASEK-founded e-commerce platform, aims to democratize access to global markets for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). Founded in 2020, the platform facilitates wholesale transactions and cross-border payments, enabling SMEs to buy and sell food-and-beverage products without prohibitive costs. With a presence in Singapore, Malaysia, China, and plans to expand into Thailand, Trustana seeks to bridge the gap between buyers and suppliers across borders, supporting the growth of SMEs and contributing to their countries' gross domestic product.

site_title: Vietnam Q2 GDP growth quickens, but Covid-19 outbreak raises risks
summary: Vietnam's Q2 GDP growth accelerated to 6.61% from a year earlier, driven by robust exports and industrial production. However, the country is battling its most serious Covid-19 outbreak, posing a threat to its recovery. The outbreak has forced the government to take measures to control the virus, which may have an economic toll. Exports rose 28.4% and industrial production increased 9.3% in the first half of the year. The outbreak is spreading rapidly in Ho Chi Minh City and neighboring provinces, raising concerns about the country's economic outlook.

site_title: Three new Covid-19 cases linked to Changi General Hospital cluster
summary: Three new Covid-19 cases linked to the Changi General Hospital cluster were announced on June 29, bringing the total cluster cases to 13. The remaining cases were linked to other clusters or individuals, with a decrease in community cases and unlinked cases over the past week. Singapore's total cases rose to 62,563, with 34 active clusters and 49,445 people receiving their first Covid-19 vaccine dose.

site_title: UOB loses suit against Lippo over claims of inflated loans, plans to appeal
summary: Singapore's United Overseas Bank (UOB) has lost a long-running lawsuit against Lippo Marina Collection (LMC) over claims of inflated loans, with the High Court dismissing all claims against the developer. UOB had alleged that LMC conspired with property agents to inflate sale prices, leading to higher housing loans. However, the court found that the bank failed to prove conspiracy and that the property agents' actions did not cause harm to the bank. UOB plans to appeal the decision and is seeking to recover approximately S$181 million disbursed for 38 units at Marina Collection.

site_title: ESG factors are a 'must have' for all M&A transactions
summary: Businesses are now recognizing the importance of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors in mergers and acquisitions (M&A) transactions. Poor ESG practices can result in reputational damage, legal risks, and exposure to pre-, peri-, and post-transaction risks. Companies must assess, identify, and mitigate ESG risks across three dimensions: environmental, social, and governance. ESG due diligence is becoming increasingly critical, with parties to M&A transactions determining the extent of ESG risks and liabilities. Incorporating ESG considerations into valuation models can internalize externalities, but caution must be exercised to avoid double-counting risks.

site_title: Jalan Anak Bukit tender closes below expectations with five bids
summary: The 99-year leasehold commercial and residential site at Jalan Anak Bukit in Singapore closed with five bids, fewer than expected, due to developers' reluctance to take on the high land cost and construction risks. Far East Organization and Sino Group submitted three joint bids, while Allgreen Properties and Kerry Holdings, and Wing Tai Holdings and Mercatus Commercial Trust also participated. Experts attribute the low response to the high land cost and construction delays caused by the pandemic. The site, near Beauty World MRT, could serve as a catalyst to rejuvenate the precinct with a new mixed-use development.

site_title: Learning from past crises is key for investors
summary: Investors can navigate the lingering effects of the Covid-19 pandemic by following five guiding principles: focusing on long-term fundamentals, leveraging a collaborative culture, constantly rechecking investment theses, staying close to company management, and viewing dislocation and volatility as opportunities. By separating short-term noise from durable fundamentals and understanding the unique drivers of the current situation, investors can make informed decisions and achieve desirable results. These principles, learned from past crises, can help investors successfully navigate the crisis and identify long-term secular winners and losers.

site_title: Moderna's Covid-19 vaccine supplies to Asian region nearly maxed out for 2021
summary: Moderna's Covid-19 vaccine supplies for the Asian region are nearly fully booked for 2021, according to its supply partner Zuellig Pharma. Regional orders are almost exhausted, with some availability expected at the end of the year. Procurement efforts were hastened by recent coronavirus flare-ups in Indonesia, Malaysia, and the Philippines. Countries such as Singapore, the Philippines, Thailand, and Taiwan have sought or signed deals for Moderna vaccines, with some already receiving vaccine batches. Negotiations for 2022 booster shots are underway, with a "race to get the supply."

site_title: Stung by pandemic, G20 foreign ministers urge greater cooperation
summary: G20 foreign ministers met in Matera, Italy, calling for greater international cooperation to address global crises such as the Covid-19 pandemic and climate emergency. The meeting emphasized the need for multilateral responses to emergencies that transcend national boundaries. US Secretary of State Antony Blinken and German Foreign Minister Heiko Maas stressed the importance of delivering vaccines to poorer countries and addressing significant debt vulnerabilities. Despite some countries' absence, the meeting marked a step towards greater cooperation, with analysts noting that reaffirming multilateral commitment was a significant outcome.

site_title: The long game of sustainable investing
summary: Sustainable investments have gained importance in value-adding investment portfolios, but lack a clear definition and industry benchmark. DBS Private Bank's group head, Joseph Poon, notes that ESG ratings can differ based on the use case, and no single benchmark exists. To address this, DBS has developed an ESG portfolio-weighted rating methodology to assess and approach ESG as a curated collection of investments. The bank defines sustainable investments as those rated BBB and above, and aims to grow its sustainable investments to more than half of its private banking AUMs by 2023. A two-step approach is recommended for investors, assessing their current portfolio and considering ESG ratings when evaluating new investment opportunities.

images.alt_text: Sustainable investments may have made recent headlines in the last few years, but this trend was likely introduced in the 18th century.

site_title: Aung San Suu Kyi urges Myanmar to stay united
summary: Myanmar's ousted leader Aung San Suu Kyi urged the people to stay united in the face of military rule, as she reappeared in a junta court. The 76-year-old Nobel laureate, under house arrest since a February coup, could face more than a decade in prison if convicted on all charges. Suu Kyi's lawyers say she asked the people to stay united and be consistent, amid a backdrop of pro-democracy protests, clashes between the military and ethnic rebel armies, and an economy in freefall, with over 880 civilians killed.

site_title: Adidas launches new share buyback as demand booms
summary: Adidas is launching a new share buyback program worth up to 550 million euros, as part of its plans to return up to 9 billion euros to shareholders in the next five years. The company raised its 2021 sales forecast due to the expected resumption of big sporting events driving demand. This move comes as Adidas and rival Puma eye a revival in the running shoe market, despite tariff threats.

site_title: US consumer confidence soars on upbeat views about economy
summary: US consumer confidence surged to a pandemic high in June, reaching 127.3, exceeding forecasts. Optimism about the economy and job market drove the increase, with 54.4% of respondents saying jobs are plentiful, a 21-year high. Consumers also expected inflation to rise in the coming year, but this did not impact their confidence or purchasing intentions. The improvement in confidence is expected to support economic growth, with increased spending on services and a rise in vacation plans. Home-purchase plans also rose, despite a surge in prices.

site_title: Bridgepoint seeks US$2.8b valuation in rare buyout firm IPO
summary: Bridgepoint, a UK-based private equity firm, plans to raise about £300 million in its initial public offering (IPO), valuing the firm at around £2 billion. This is one of the largest listings of a UK private equity firm in decades. The funds will be used to expand into new strategies and increase its presence in the US. Bridgepoint has more than 27 billion euros of assets under management and has made significant investments in recent years, including a stake in Itsu and a deal to sell a business to Thoma Bravo.

site_title: Nasdaq and broker Marex team up to sell commodities data
summary: Nasdaq and broker Marex have partnered to distribute a wide range of commodities data, including speculative positioning estimates, through Quandl's platform. The deal comes as a sizzling rally in commodities attracts investment funds back to the sector. The Quandl platform will offer daily Marex reports on metals, agriculture, and other commodities markets, providing users with valuable insights into market trends and positioning. The partnership aims to expand access to commodities data, benefiting investors and market participants.

site_title: US: S&P 500 hits record high as bank stocks gain
summary: The S&P 500 index reached a record high of 4,299.26, gaining 8.65 points, or 0.20%, on Tuesday. This was driven by gains in US bank stocks. The Dow Jones Industrial Average also rose, while the Nasdaq Composite lost 5.31 points. The record high comes amidst rising inflation and a spike in Covid-19 cases in Asia, but investors remain optimistic.

site_title: Electric car sales surge as Europe's climate targets bite
summary: Europe saw a surge in electric car sales in 2020, with one in nine new cars sold being electric or plug-in hybrid vehicles. This led to a 12% drop in average CO2 emissions of new cars sold, reversing a three-year trend of increasing emissions. The uptick in electric car sales was driven by tougher CO2 targets for carmakers and subsidies in Covid-19 economic recovery packages. Campaigners say the data shows emissions targets are working, but urge Brussels to propose a ban on new petrol and diesel car sales by 2035 to meet the EU's net zero emissions target by 2050.

site_title: The 3 transformative trends powering manufacturing now
summary: Industry 4.0 is crucial for the manufacturing industry's growth, but many companies are lagging behind in adopting Fourth Industrial Revolution technologies. Over 70% of companies have not made significant progress, while only a small community of manufacturers have successfully implemented advanced manufacturing on a large scale. To catch up, manufacturers must exemplify leadership in embracing technologies that minimize operational costs, maximize profits, and develop manpower. This unified front is essential for the global manufacturing market to thrive and create new value and customer experiences within factories and supply chains.

site_title: Foley-backed SPAC reaches merger deal with System1 marketing firm
summary: Blank-cheque firm Trebia Acquisition, backed by Bill Foley, has agreed to merge with marketing firm System1, valuing the combined company at $1.4 billion including debt. The deal provides $175 million for growth and acquisitions and includes $600 million in financing from Foley's Cannae Holdings and debt. System1 co-founder Michael Blend will continue in his roles, while Foley and Trebia Chairman Frank Martire will join System1's board. The combined company will trade on the New York Stock Exchange under the "SST" ticker.

site_title: Top fashion brands found failing on gender equality in new index
summary: A new index by the World Benchmarking Alliance found that nearly two-thirds of top 35 apparel brands have not publicly backed gender equality and women's empowerment. Adidas, Gap, and VF Corp were the only three fashion industry giants to score over 50 points on the index, which gave an average score of 29 points. The garment industry employs 60 million workers globally, mostly women, and regularly faces criticism over labor exploitation and sexual harassment. The index revealed significant gaps between commitment and action on gender equality in fashion, with less than a third of companies providing violence and harassment training.

site_title: The Working Capitol, owing S$13.2m, applies for debt restructuring
summary: The Working Capitol, a six-year-old co-working startup, has filed for debt restructuring amid S$13.2 million in debts to creditors excluding related parties. The company's total debt, including loans from co-founders and related entities, is approximately S$26 million. The startup has failed to reach an agreement with landlords Crocodile International and AIA Singapore to renegotiate rental payments, totaling over S$610,000. The company plans to continue operations and evolve its business model into an owner-operator one with patient capital partners.

site_title: France to legalise IVF for lesbians after two-year debate
summary: France's Parliament is set to pass a bill allowing lesbian couples and single women to access IVF for the first time, marking a significant milestone in fertility treatment laws. The current law only permits heterosexual couples to undergo medically assisted procreation methods, forcing many women to travel abroad for IVF using donor sperm. The bill's passage is seen as a major step forward in promoting equality and reproductive rights in France.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 3.60 points to 1,548.31 on Tuesday, driven by a 510-432 gainers-to-losers ratio. The index closed at RM2.631 billion in volume.

site_title: Suntec Reit to divest office strata units, acquire London building
summary: Suntec Reit is divesting a portfolio of office strata units at Suntec City Office for S$197 million, generating a net gain of S$13.9 million. The Reit will acquire a Grade-A office building in London, the Minster Building, for S$667.2 million. The acquisition is expected to enhance the Reit's resilience, diversification, and income stability, with the London property having a committed occupancy of 96.7% and an income yield of 4.5%.

site_title: Steel sector may be saddled with up to US$70b stranded assets
summary: The global steel industry may face up to $70 billion in stranded assets due to the increasing adoption of electric arc furnaces and the phase-out of coal-based blast furnaces, a report by Global Energy Monitor found. The industry is developing 50 million tonnes of new steelmaking capacity using coal, which could become obsolete by 2030-2040, resulting in significant losses. To meet climate goals, the steel sector must reduce emissions by 50% by 2050, and companies are transitioning to electric arc furnaces and low-carbon technologies.

site_title: World passes three billion vaccine mark in race to contain Covid
summary: More than three billion Covid-19 vaccines have been administered globally, according to an AFP tally, as countries struggle to contain the highly infectious Delta variant. At least 3.9 million people have died from the virus, with some wealthy countries succeeding in reducing infections through strong vaccination drives, while others are struggling due to limited access to shots. The Delta variant has fueled outbreaks worldwide, prompting major sporting events like Euro 2020 and the Olympic Games to be put on hold.

site_title: Five new Covid-19 community cases in Singapore, all linked
summary: Singapore reported 10 new Covid-19 cases, bringing the total to 62,563. Five are locally-transmitted, linked to previous cases, and four were quarantined. The remaining case was detected through surveillance. All five imported cases are on stay-home notices or isolated. The country has had 36 deaths from Covid-19 complications and 15 who died of other causes.

site_title: Singapore still in 'transition phase', should not reopen prematurely: Lawrence Wong
summary: Singapore remains in a "transition phase" before reaching the "new normal" of endemic Covid-19, according to Finance Minister Lawrence Wong. The country should not reopen prematurely, as it risks high infection rates, hospitalizations, and fatalities. Restrictions will be eased as vaccination rates increase, with differentiated treatment for vaccinated persons and potential shorter quarantine periods. Singapore plans to reconnect with the world safely, allowing more travel and resuming worker flows, while firms must adapt to the post-Covid-19 economy and prioritize resilience and long-term growth plans.

site_title: HSBC loses four bond bankers as China spats hurt dealmaking
summary: HSBC Holdings Plc has lost about a third of its debt capital markets team covering Chinese state-owned enterprises, with four managing directors departing to join competing firms. The departures follow HSBC's struggles to win back favor in Beijing, stemming from its involvement in a U.S. probe of Huawei Technologies Co. and tensions between China and the UK over issues including Hong Kong's political freedoms. The bank's China investment-grade bond market share has fallen to 12th place from second in 2020, and it has been excluded from dollar issuance by several SOE clients this year.

site_title: Ministry of Law refines shareholding interest criteria for QC exemptions
summary: The Ministry of Law in Singapore has refined the shareholding interest criteria for exemptions from the Qualifying Certificate (QC) regime. Publicly listed housing developers that have shares held by Singapore shareholders through white-listed nominee companies or collectively by family members may now be counted towards fulfilling the requirements. The refinements aim to provide more clarity and flexibility for developers, with the changes taking effect immediately. The updates follow feedback received since the exemption framework was introduced in 2020.

site_title: ecoWise CEO welcomes SGX RegCo compliance notice and directives
summary: ecoWise Holdings CEO Lee Thiam Seng welcomes a compliance notice from SGX RegCo, directing the company to appoint new independent directors, audit its H1 2021 results, and conduct an internal audit of internal controls. Lee plans to convene an urgent meeting and implement weekly management meetings to ensure compliance. He also recommends reviewing existing approval matrices and replacing the company's legal advisers for a fresh perspective. ecoWise shares remain suspended following a trading halt on June 18.

site_title: Ren Ci chairman Chua Thian Poh retiring, to be succeeded by Seow Choke Meng
summary: Ren Ci Hospital chairman Chua Thian Poh is retiring, to be succeeded by Seow Choke Meng, a veteran of Singapore Press Holdings. Chua, who led the hospital for 21 years, oversaw expansion and growth, benefiting nearly 25,000 seniors. The transition takes effect July 1, 2021, and is part of Ren Ci's succession plan, with Seow expressing confidence in continuing the hospital's community care work.

images.alt_text: Chua Thian Poh (right) is retiring from the board of Ren Ci Hospital and will be succeeded as chairman by SPH veteran Seow Choke Meng (left), who is currently serving as vice-chairman on the board.

site_title: Diana's royal runaround sold to South American museum
summary: A Ford Escort once owned by Princess Diana was sold to a South American museum for £52,640, exceeding initial expectations of £30,000-£40,000. The silver 1981 model was given to Lady Diana as an engagement gift by Prince Charles and features its original registration plate and condition. The sale is a testament to the car's enduring popularity, with considerable interest from bidders globally. The vehicle will be shipped to its new home in South America.

site_title: China to pause squid fishing in Pacific, Atlantic breeding grounds
summary: China has announced a temporary ban on its fishing fleet from catching squid in parts of the Pacific and Atlantic Oceans, effective from Thursday until September 30 and September to November, respectively. The ban is aimed at protecting fragile marine ecosystems and preventing overfishing, which has pushed squid populations to the brink of collapse. The move follows international backlash and concerns over China's giant overseas fleet, which accounts for 70% of the global squid catch.

site_title: Norwegian Air showed poor judgement in making bonus payments: minister
summary: Norwegian Air's industry minister criticized the airline for paying top management bonuses of 30 million Norwegian crowns just weeks after completing a government-backed bankruptcy proceeding. The company had received 3 billion Norwegian crowns in loan guarantees and 1.5 billion crowns in a hybrid loan to avoid collapse.
