The minister deemed the payouts as poor judgment, stating the board and CEO must explain and rebuild the airline's reputation. Norwegian Air claimed the payouts were a retention bonus, with shareholders ultimately bearing the costs.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore-based Princeton Digital has invested US$1 billion to build a 97MW data centre campus in Japan. The campus, located in Saitama City, will consist of two facilities with a combined critical IT capacity of 48.5MW each. Meanwhile, MinLaw has refined its shareholding interest criteria for exemptions from the Qualifying Certificate (QC) regime. Temasek's Trustana has integrated its OneSME digital platform into a B2B marketplace, enabling SMEs in Singapore and Asean to access a larger pool of Chinese buyers.

images.alt_text: Located at Saitama City in the north of central Tokyo, Princeton Digital Group's data centre campus will consist of two facilities with a critical IT capacity of 48.5 MW each.

site_title: Thailand ready to tackle outbreak from reopening, minister says
summary: Thailand is taking steps to manage a potential outbreak of COVID-19 as it reopens to vaccinated foreign tourists. The country will limit tourist movement to smaller islands, such as Phuket, Samui, and Phi Phi, to quickly curb any community transmission. Despite concerns about fueling the outbreak, Thailand's Minister of Tourism and Sports, Phiphat Ratchakitprakarn, rules out closing borders. The tourism-dependent nation aims to revive its industry and expects around 100,000 tourists to visit Phuket over the next three months, with a higher price tag for travel due to the pandemic.

site_title: Japan minister says necessary to 'wake up' to protect Taiwan
summary: Japan's deputy defence minister, Yasuhide Nakayama, warned of a growing threat posed by Chinese and Russian collaboration, urging Japan to "wake up" to protect Taiwan as a democratic country. He questioned the long-term viability of the "one-China" policy, suggesting that future generations may judge policymakers on the issue. Nakayama's comments come as Beijing's pressure on Taiwan increases, raising concerns about the island's security and democratic status.

site_title: US$3.6b missing Bitcoins: lawyers for accused terminated
summary: Lawyers for the Cajee brothers, accused of vanishing with an estimated US$3.6 billion in Bitcoin from their Africrypt investment platform, have had their mandate terminated. The brothers, who claimed the platform was hacked, denied absconding with funds and promised to cooperate with future investigations. Their mobile phones remain unreachable, and the brothers have not been seen since April. Regulators suspect the investment scheme was a Ponzi scheme, offering unrealistically high returns. The public is urged to be cautious of such schemes.

site_title: Second Covid-19 jab can now be booked four weeks after first dose
summary: Singapore has allowed members of the public to book their second Covid-19 vaccine dose four weeks after the first dose, earlier than expected. This change comes as the country aims to meet its target of having the majority of the population vaccinated by the end of July. Health Minister Ong Ye Kung previously stated that the interval between doses would be reviewed and reduced to four weeks once the first dose target is met. Several individuals have already taken advantage of the change, moving their second jab appointments forward by weeks.

site_title: World Bank warns South Asia risks 'hidden debt' financial crises
summary: The World Bank has warned South Asia is at risk of financial crises due to unsustainable debt levels, largely concealed by state-led development and funding guarantees by state-owned banks and enterprises. Key countries, including India and Pakistan, face significant risks, with India particularly vulnerable due to its large public-private partnership projects and government guarantees for state-owned entity debt. The World Bank recommends policy reforms to ensure transparency, data collection, and responsible use of public capital to mitigate these risks and prevent financial crises.

site_title: AIA agrees to buy China Post Life stake for US$1.9b
summary: AIA Group has agreed to acquire a 24.99% stake in China Post Life Insurance for approximately US$1.9 billion, subject to regulatory approvals. The deal aims to bolster AIA's China expansion as the country eases restrictions on foreign insurers. China Post Life has a retail distribution network of around 40,000 financial outlets and more than 600 million retail customers, primarily targeting the mass-affluent market in China. The acquisition is AIA's second this year, following its purchase of the life insurance arm of Bank of East Asia in March.

images.alt_text: AIA Group has agreed to acquire a stake in China Post Life Insurance for about US$1.9 billion to bolster its China expansion.

site_title: Europe: Industrials, banks lift shares as reflation trade heats up
summary: Europe's shares rose 0.5% on Tuesday, driven by gains in industrial, banking, and mining stocks as investors bet on a steady economic recovery. France's Rexel shares jumped 3.4% after lifting its 2021 sales forecast. The Stoxx 600 has been on a five-straight month gain streak, but recently struggled to break above its all-time high due to concerns over the Delta variant. Travel-related stocks rebounded after a one-month low, while British house prices surged by the most in over 16 years in June.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end the day with losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.94% to 28,994.10, mirroring a sell-off across Asia due to concerns over global virus spikes and containment measures. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined 0.92% and 0.91%, respectively. The losses were in line with regional market trends, which have been impacted by government responses to the pandemic.

site_title: Soaring pump prices a threat to India recovery and inflation
summary: India is facing a fuel crisis due to record-high gasoline and diesel prices, which are twice as expensive as in New York. The soaring pump prices threaten the country's recovery and inflation, affecting the transport industry. The high fuel costs are attributed to government levies and rising benchmark Brent prices, which have recovered from the depths of the Covid-19 pandemic. The government's decision to increase taxes despite easing virus-related movement restrictions has exacerbated the issue.

site_title: Australia: Shares end slightly lower as virus curbs increase
summary: Australian shares closed 0.08% lower on Tuesday, with real estate, miners, and energy stocks experiencing a decline due to increasing Covid-19 curbs. The Delta variant outbreaks in five states and territories, with 80% of the population under restrictions, have dented market sentiment. Top percentage losers included property stocks Vicinity Centres and Stockland, while miners Rio Tinto and BHP Group also fell. Local tech stocks trimmed losses, with Afterpay jumping 2.4%.

site_title: Sembmarine to install additional 4MWp solar system at Tuas yard with SP Group
summary: Sembcorp Marine is partnering with SP Group to install an additional 4MWp solar system at its Tuas Boulevard Yard, increasing the facility's solar power capacity to 8.5MWp. The new system will supply nearly 60% of the yard's power during peak production periods. The installation is expected to reduce the yard's annual carbon emissions by over 4,200 tonnes and result in significant utilities savings. The project is part of Sembmarine's plans to reduce its annual carbon emissions by 15,000 tonnes by 2025.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end lower on Delta virus woes
summary: South Korean stocks ended lower on Tuesday, closing down 15.21 points or 0.46% at 3,286.68, amid worries about the Delta virus derailing economic recovery. Chip giants Samsung and SK Hynix dropped 1.10% and 0.79%, respectively, while internet giant Naver rose 0.86%. Foreigners were net sellers of 550.3 billion won worth of shares, citing concerns about the global recovery momentum.

site_title: Wind and the sun power Greek islands' green energy switch
summary: The Greek island of Tilos has become the first island in the Mediterranean to generate almost all its electricity from renewable sources, thanks to a pioneering project launched in 2018. The island of 800 inhabitants has a hybrid power station combining wind and solar energy, and is 100% energy independent for most of the year. The project, backed by EU and private funding, aims to reduce Greece's reliance on fossil fuels and serves as a model for other small islands.

images.alt_text: In the tranquil Greek island of Tilos, a wind turbine hums over a silvery sea while scorching sun rays hit a hill lined with solar panels.

site_title: China's Xi says party needs new 'heroes' to meet future goals
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping said the Communist Party needs new heroes to carry it into its second century, as he celebrated over two dozen officials for their contributions to the party's longevity. Xi emphasized the importance of rooting out corruption and maintaining the party's "clean nature." The celebration comes ahead of a party congress next year, expected to give Xi a third term, and marks the party's 100-year anniversary.

site_title: Tender for a Jalan Papan industrial site not awarded
summary: The tender for a Jalan Papan industrial site, launched by JTC on June 29, 2021, was not awarded. Two bids were received, but the highest qualified bid was rejected due to its price being below the reserve price. This is the last of three Confirmed List sites for the first half of the 2021 industrial government land sales programme, which will be released regardless of demand.

site_title: Myanmar jade industry becoming 'slush fund' for junta: report
summary: Myanmar's jade mines are at risk of becoming a "slush fund" for the military junta, with the industry financing both sides of a decades-long civil war. The multi-billion-dollar industry, driven by demand from China, has been mired in secrecy and exploitation, with thousands of illegal workers risking their lives to mine jade. Global Witness urges consumers to boycott jade and gemstones from Myanmar, calling for sanctions to ban imports and for companies and consumers to avoid purchasing jade sourced from the country.

images.alt_text: Myanmar's multi-billion-dollar jade mines risk becoming a "slush fund" for military repression, Global Witness said Tuesday, urging consumers to boycott purchasing any jade and gemstones from the coup-wracked nation.

site_title: Japan's SoftBank suspends production of chatty robot Pepper
summary: SoftBank has suspended production of its humanoid robot Pepper, a chatty robot used to greet people in stores and hotels, due to an inventory pile-up. The decision comes seven years after the robot's release in 2014, which was hailed as a symbol of SoftBank's determination to lead in artificial intelligence. The company has not disclosed the number of units sold or rented, and is negotiating potential job reductions with its European robotics unit. This move follows SoftBank's best-ever annual net profit for a Japanese company in May.

site_title: Pandemic boom drives UK house prices up by most since 2004
summary: UK house prices jumped 13.4% in June, the largest increase in over 16 years, driven by a tax break offered by finance minister Rishi Sunak during the pandemic. The 0.7% monthly rise was higher than expected by economists. Nationwide's chief economist Robert Gardner attributed the surge to "significant momentum" in the market, citing low borrowing costs and high demand. The tax break, which was initially set to expire, has been extended until the end of June, and a tax-free allowance will remain until the end of September.

site_title: Temasek's Trustana to integrate OneSME digital platform into B2B marketplace
summary: Trustana, a B2B marketplace founded by Temasek, has integrated OneSME's digital platform into its marketplace. The collaboration aims to facilitate trade opportunities between Singaporean and Chinese SMEs, enabling them to access a larger pool of buyers in China. The integrated platform will focus on the food and beverage sector, providing SMEs with value-added services and financing solutions. The partnership is expected to strengthen Trustana's presence in China and accelerate expansion to other trade corridors in Asean.

site_title: South Korean ex-lawman who hounded President Moon to seek top job
summary: South Korea's former top prosecutor Yoon Seok-youl has announced his candidacy for the country's presidency, vowing to end the policies of President Moon Jae-in's administration. Yoon, who was appointed prosecutor-general by Moon but later feuded with the administration and resigned, criticized Moon's policies as divisive and ignoring common sense. With no clear successor to Moon and no dominant party candidate, Yoon is seen as a top contender, leading in opinion polls. The election will focus on populist policies to address income inequality and housing affordability, with Yoon's ascension seen as a conservative bid to take back the Blue House.

site_title: Former South Korean mayor jailed for sexual harassment
summary: Former South Korean mayor Oh Keo Don was jailed for three years for sexually harassing two female staffers. The conviction comes amid a still patriarchal society where victims often face pressure to stay silent. The case is the latest in a series of high-profile convictions, following Seoul mayor Park Won Soon's apparent suicide after a woman accused him of sexual harassment. The convictions have given the conservative opposition fresh momentum ahead of next year's presidential poll.

site_title: Billionaire family plans IPO of luxury car interior designer
summary: Novem Group, a luxury car interior designer, plans to list on the Frankfurt stock exchange through an initial public offering (IPO). The company, which makes trim elements for high-end car manufacturers like Maserati and Porsche, aims to raise 50 million euros. Led by Gunter Brenner, Novem is tapping into the growing demand for luxury car interiors, driven by the shift towards self-driving cars and increased emphasis on high-end design. The IPO is part of a broader trend of European car companies listing on public markets, seeking to raise funds and capitalize on growth opportunities.

site_title: Australian oil industry up in arms over proposed decommissioning levy
summary: Australia's oil industry is opposing a proposed A$0.48 per barrel levy to cover the cost of decommissioning offshore oil fields, citing it as "extreme" and too costly. The levy, set to take effect on July 1, aims to cover the cost of removing facilities and rehabilitating the Laminaria-Corallina oil fields in the Timor Sea after the field's owner, Northern Oil & Gas Australia, collapsed in 2019. Industry representatives have called for the government to reconsider the levy and explore alternative cost-cutting measures.

site_title: Brazil asks China to clarify new soya standard, official says
summary: Brazil has asked China to clarify the new national soybean standard, which changes quality requirements, including how it will be implemented and assessed. The new standard, currently under discussion at the World Trade Organization, sets terms and definitions for soybeans, but Brazil is concerned about the maximum moist levels set at 13% under China's proposal, which is below Brazil's 14% threshold. Brazil has told China that this aspect should not be used to classify soybeans, and officials believe the Brazilian market will not be significantly affected by the new standard.

site_title: China Evergrande bond investors still wary as near-term risks ease
summary: China Evergrande Group has made arrangements to pay bondholders until March 2023, easing near-term debt concerns. However, investors remain wary due to the company's high debt levels and reliance on commercial bills to finance operations. Evergrande's dollar and yuan bonds are trading at discounts of over 30%, and Fitch Ratings has downgraded the company's long-term issuer default rating to "B" with a negative outlook. Despite the recent debt payment, investors fear the company's ability to de-lever and continue debt repayment in the coming years.

images.alt_text: China Evergrande Group may have cleared a near-term debt hurdle with arrangements for bond payments through next March, but investors are still giving the developer a wide berth as it struggles to downsize and reduce debt.

site_title: Indonesia to impose hard Covid-19 lockdown from June 30
summary: Indonesia plans to impose stricter COVID-19 restrictions starting June 30, called Pemberlakuan Pembatasan Kegiatan Masyarakat (PPKM) Darurat, amid a second wave of infections driven by the Delta variant. The new measures may require non-essential workers to work from home, ban dining in at restaurants, and limit domestic air travel to those who have been vaccinated and produce negative test results. The restrictions will likely apply nationwide, replacing the current localized lockdown.

site_title: India's vaccine shortage eases as inoculations outpace new registrations
summary: India's COVID-19 vaccine shortage is easing as the country has administered more doses in the last two weeks than new registrations. This improvement is attributed to increased production at the Serum Institute of India, which is on track to produce over 100 million AstraZeneca vaccine doses per month starting July. The surge in production has boosted vaccine availability, addressing the widespread shortages that occurred after the government opened vaccinations to all adults last month.

site_title: Brokers' take: UOBKH initiates on Q&M with 'buy' on growth potential in dental, Covid-19 testing businesses
summary: Q&M Dental Group is expected to post record core earnings in 2021 driven by its dental and Covid-19 testing businesses. UOB Kay Hian initiated coverage with a "buy" call and target price of S$0.94, citing robust growth potential. The dental group is expected to add 10 new outlets annually, boosting 18% on-year growth in core earnings, while the Covid-19 testing business is expected to remain a long-term growth engine due to the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: Greece recovers Picasso stolen in 2012
summary: Greece has recovered a stolen Picasso painting, "Head of a Woman," gifted to the country in 1949, and arrested a suspect in the 2012 theft from the National Gallery. The painting was found in the rural area of Keratea, along with another stolen work, "Stammer Windmill," by Piet Mondrian. The incident occurred in January 2012 and lasted only seven minutes, with security cameras and alarms being faulty at the time. The recovery comes after a state report found that the National Gallery's security had not been upgraded since 2000.

site_title: Google takes down maps targeting hundreds of Thais accused of opposing king
summary: Google removed two Google Maps documents listing hundreds of Thai activists accused of opposing the monarchy, following a complaint. The maps, created by a team of volunteers, included names and addresses of nearly 500 people, with some receiving over 350,000 views. The move was seen as a victory by human rights groups and critics of the establishment, who warned that the maps could put individuals at risk of violence. Google said it removed the maps due to violating its policies on user-generated content.

site_title: Mexican budget carrier Viva Aerobus plans US IPO
summary: Mexican budget airline Viva Aerobus plans to list on the US stock market through an initial public offering (IPO) this year, working with Barclays, Goldman Sachs, and JPMorgan Chase. The airline, now Mexico's third-largest carrier, has seen a 35% increase in passenger count to 1.34 million in the first five months of the year. Viva Aerobus surpassed Grupo Aeromexico, which is dealing with a Chapter 11 filing, in the domestic market. The airline's IPO comes as the global airline industry sees a resurgence in travel demand following the rollout of coronavirus vaccines.

site_title: Brisbane joins list of Australian cities under lockdown, 10 million Australians affected
summary: Brisbane, Australia's fourth major city, has implemented a three-day snap lockdown due to the spread of the highly contagious Delta variant, affecting around 10 million Australians. The lockdown comes after similar orders were imposed in Sydney, Perth, and Darwin. The decision was made after an unvaccinated hospital worker traveled extensively while infectious, and Queensland Premier Annastacia Palaszczuk attributed the spread to overseas arrivals.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Tuesday, with the Nikkei 225 index falling 0.81% and the Topix index dropping 0.82%. Concerns over the Delta coronavirus variant and the Tokyo Olympics led to sluggish trading. Investors took a wait-and-see attitude ahead of US unemployment figures due on Friday. Key stocks such as SoftBank Group, Nissan, and Toyota declined, while Dentsu rose after announcing plans to sell its headquarters building. Japan's jobless rate worsened to 3% in May, but did not prompt a strong market reaction.

site_title: Brokers' take: RHB upgrades Venture Corp to 'buy' on recent share price weakness
summary: RHB has upgraded its call on Venture Corp to "buy" from "neutral" with a target price of S$20.70, implying an 11% upside and 4% yield. Analyst Jarick Seet believes the recent share price weakness is unwarranted given the company's strong fundamentals and expected Q2 FY2021 financials. Seet sees Venture as a tech laggard at an attractive level, with growth prospects in areas such as life science and healthcare, and expects earnings per share growth of 11.8% in FY2021.

images.alt_text: RHB considers Venture Corp's recent share price weakness unwarranted, and believes the Mainboard-listed technology solutions provider is due to report stronger Q2 FY2021 financials.

site_title: Fed's Kashkari says banks can't expect government to bail them out of every crisis
summary: US Federal Reserve President Neel Kashkari stated in an op-ed that banks cannot expect government bailouts in every crisis and must increase equity funding to protect against future shocks. He noted that losses in the banking sector during the Covid-19 pandemic were smaller than expected due to aggressive fiscal support from governments. Kashkari's comments come as the banking sector faces uncertainty, with experts warning of potential economic downturns. The Fed's stance emphasizes the need for banks to build resilience and prepare for unexpected events.

images.alt_text: Banks cannot expect the government to bail them out of every crisis and must increase their equity funding to protect against the next "unexpected shock", Minneapolis Federal Reserve President Neel Kashkari wrote in an op-ed for the Financial Times.

site_title: Well-educated minorities in the UK are losing out at work
summary: Research by the Institute for Fiscal Studies reveals that second-generation ethnic minorities in the UK, despite having less advantaged backgrounds, excel in education but face lower employment rates. Second-generation Pakistani, Bangladeshi, and Black Caribbean individuals are more likely to be highly educated than their white counterparts, yet they experience lower employment rates and have not benefited equally from their qualifications. The findings highlight a complex picture, where neither less advantaged backgrounds nor discrimination alone explains job market inequalities.

site_title: Eyeing Asian market, Ecuador begins crude exports in larger vessels
summary: Ecuador has begun exporting crude oil to Asia in larger vessels, specifically Very Large Crude Carriers (VLCCs), for the first time. The shipment of 1.08 million barrels of Oriente crude aboard the Panama-flagged Gem No 2 vessel was made possible by the construction of a pipeline extension, allowing for direct loading of VLCCs. The move aims to boost exports to Asia, lower logistics costs, and make Ecuador's oil more competitive in international markets. This is part of President Guillermo Lasso's efforts to revive the country's struggling economy.

site_title: 'Not perfect enough': China's growing problem of eating disorders
summary: China is grappling with a growing problem of eating disorders, with cases increasing by hundreds in major cities over the past two decades. The issue is often linked to social media and traditional beauty standards, with pale skin and thin bodies being idealized. Despite some hospitals reporting steep increases in cases, recognition and treatment remain limited. Campaigners like Zhang Qinwen, who suffered from severe weight loss and mental torture, are now speaking out and organizing exhibitions to raise awareness and challenge societal norms.

site_title: Boeing prepares safety measures for 737 next generation jets
summary: Boeing is finalising safety enhancements for its 737 Next Generation models, following a US regulator's recommendation to prevent debris from escaping during engine failures. The Federal Aviation Administration plans to mandate the fixes, which include strengthening the engine's smooth curved surface, after a Southwest Airlines engine failure in 2018 killed a woman. The safety measures are aimed at addressing concerns after a chunk of metal flew off the engine, and Boeing is expected to issue service bulletins instructing operators on how to implement the changes.

images.alt_text: Boeing Co is finalising a set of three safety enhancements to the engines on its popular 737 Next Generation models to prevent debris from escaping during a failure, according to US regulators.

site_title: Disney delays test cruise over inconsistent Covid-19 results
summary: Disney has postponed its first test cruise since the pandemic due to inconsistent Covid-19 test results for five asymptomatic crew members. The crew members, who were vaccinated, tested positive initially but later tested negative after re-testing. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention treats the results as positive, prompting the cancellation of the test cruise. A new sailing schedule has not been announced. This delay follows the successful test cruise by Royal Caribbean's Celebrity Edge last weekend, which marked the first major cruise line to sail from a US port.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open with small gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened with small gains on Tuesday, following a record close on Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.08% to 29,291.89, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw gains. Traders remained cautious due to fresh virus flare-ups worldwide.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Tuesday, down 1.36 points (0.09%) to 1,543.35. Trading volume was 485.02 million lots worth RM168.08 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 189 to 182.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall on increasing coronavirus curbs
summary: Australia's shares fell 0.6% on Tuesday, led by energy stocks and banks, due to increasing COVID-19 restrictions to contain the Delta variant. Five states and territories have been hit by outbreaks, with around 80% of the population under restrictions. Energy stocks lost 1.4%, with Woodside Petroleum and Oil Search falling 1.5% and 2%, respectively. Heavyweight financials and miners also fell, while technology stocks were among the few gainers.

site_title: New Zealand to partially restart travel 'bubble' with Australia
summary: New Zealand partially resumes quarantine-free travel with Australia, starting July 5, for residents from South Australia, ACT, Tasmania, and Victoria. The country also lifts COVID-19 curbs in Wellington after a week without community cases. Restrictions will be eased from midnight on June 29, allowing for increased travel and economic activity.

site_title: Nomura loses 20 investment bankers in Asia after bonus payouts
summary: Nomura Holdings lost around 20 junior investment bankers in Asia following bonus payouts in May, adding to the firm's departures in the region. This follows a trend of talent shortages in China and Hong Kong, where junior banker attrition rates have roughly doubled. The departures highlight the competition among global banks for talent in Asia, where financial technology firms and investment companies offer faster promotion and higher earnings. Nomura has recently hired several new staff to boost its ranks, including from JPMorgan Chase & Co and Macquarie Group.

site_title: South Korean companies offer employees Covid-19 vaccines at work
summary: South Korean companies, including Samsung Group affiliates, have received permission to administer Covid-19 vaccines at in-house clinics to speed up employee inoculation. The move comes as the country aims to boost vaccinations, having inoculated 30% of its population with at least one dose. Eligible employees and suppliers will receive Moderna vaccines, with a total of several large companies participating, including SK Hynix and LG Display. This comes as South Korea reported 595 new infections, bringing its tally to 156,167 cases.

site_title: Taiwan to get vaccine boost with more Moderna shots on their way
summary: Taiwan is set to receive an additional 410,000 doses of the Moderna Covid-19 vaccine, boosting efforts to combat a local cluster of infections. This shipment brings the total doses received to 4.85 million, with the government under pressure to speed up deliveries. Only around 8% of Taiwan's population has received at least one dose, and the government is also awaiting 10 million doses from domestic companies and 4.76 million from the COVAX global sharing scheme. The new shipment is expected to arrive on Wednesday, further aiding Taiwan's fight against the virus.

site_title: Spike in restaurant job listings bodes well for Canada's recovery
summary: Canada's restaurant industry is experiencing a surge in job listings, with a 37% increase above pre-pandemic levels, as provinces relax Covid-19 restrictions. This growth suggests a strong recovery in the sector, which accounts for 64% of the 571,000 positions yet to be recovered since the pandemic. The industry's pick-up in demand is driven by the reopening of restaurants and bars, with interest in food-services remaining below pre-pandemic levels. However, businesses may struggle to find enough workers, with some workers leaving the industry due to closures and health concerns.

site_title: SoftBank shrinks robotics business, stops Pepper production: sources
summary: SoftBank is shrinking its robotics business, stopping Pepper robot production, and cutting about half of its 330 staff positions in France. The decision reflects the fading of CEO Masayoshi Son's plan to lead the robotics industry. Only 27,000 Pepper robots were produced, and the business struggled to find a global customer base. Staff have been laid off in the US and UK, with redeployed employees in Japan. SoftBank plans to continue investing in next-generation robots, despite the restructuring.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Yanlord, Ho Bee Land, CNMC, Sabana Reit, APAC Realty, Top Global
summary: Stocks to watch: Yanlord and Ho Bee Land have entered into an agreement to jointly develop a residential site in Tianjin, China. CNMC expects the Malaysian government's lockdown extension to negatively affect its financial performance. Sabana Reit rejected a request to hold an extraordinary general meeting, while APAC Realty's CEO is set to change roles. BHO's voluntary unconditional cash offer for Top Global closed with 95.9% valid acceptances.

site_title: Eye-popping returns lure hedge funds to Japanese startups
summary: Hedge funds and asset managers are investing in Japanese startups, attracted by past returns and government efforts to promote digitalisation and entrepreneurship. Asian hedge fund firms and global investment giants, such as T Rowe Price Group and Baillie Gifford, are providing late-stage growth capital to promising ventures. The investment is driven by surging share prices of startups that went public in recent years and the potential for valuations to be more compelling due to less intense competition. The goal is to help Japanese startups reach a scale that can draw money from global institutions, with at least eight companies planned to be backed over two years.

site_title: Singapore stocks open lower on Tuesday; STI down 0.4%
summary: Singapore stocks opened lower on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 0.4% to 3,113.80, as a mixed close on Wall Street influenced trading. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.4% to 34,283.27, while European shares ended lower due to concerns over travel restrictions. In Asia, Tokyo stocks also opened lower, with the Nikkei 225 index down 0.7% to 28,842.06.

site_title: Gold inches lower on firm dollar, Fed hawkish stance
summary: Gold prices fell 0.2% to $1,775.42 per ounce due to a firmer dollar and concerns about the US Federal Reserve's potential rate hike, which could increase the opportunity cost of holding bullion. The Fed has made progress towards its inflation goal, but some policymakers expressed caution, sparking worries about tighter monetary policy. Meanwhile, European Central Bank policymakers debated ending emergency bond purchases, and China's net gold imports halved in May amid coronavirus restrictions.

site_title: Goldman Sachs, Blankfein, Cohn must face shareholder lawsuit over 1MDB scandal
summary: A US judge ordered Goldman Sachs and two former executives, Lloyd Blankfein and Gary Cohn, to face a shareholder lawsuit over their involvement in the 1MDB scandal. The lawsuit claims the bank misled shareholders about its work for the Malaysian fund, which was involved in a corruption scandal. The judge found that several statements by Goldman, Blankfein, and Cohn about 1MDB were false and misleading, and shareholders are seeking damages after the bank's market value fell by billions of dollars. Goldman agreed to pay $2.9 billion in penalties and admitted criminal wrongdoing.

site_title: Vietnam Q2 GDP growth quickens to 6.61% y-o-y vs 4.65% expansion in Q1
summary: Vietnam's Q2 GDP growth accelerated to 6.61% year-over-year, surpassing the 4.65% expansion in Q1. This marks a faster-than-expected growth rate, with the first quarter revised up from 4.48%. The data suggests a strong economic rebound in Vietnam, although the article does not provide further details on the cause of the growth.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Tuesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Tuesday, down 0.71% or 205.96 points, following a mixed close on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index fell to 28,842.06 and the Topix index dropped 0.82% to 1,949.63. The lack of fresh clues on US trade policy from a Federal Reserve official's speech contributed to the subdued trade.

site_title: Wall Street banks hike shareholder payouts after Fed gives the green light
summary: Wall Street banks Morgan Stanley, JPMorgan, Bank of America, Goldman Sachs, and Wells Fargo announced plans to hike shareholder payouts after the US Federal Reserve gave them a clean bill of health following their annual "stress tests". Morgan Stanley doubled its dividend to 70 cents a share, while Bank of America and JPMorgan increased their dividends by 17% and 10%, respectively. Goldman Sachs and Wells Fargo also raised their dividend payouts. The banks plan to return a total of up to $130 billion in dividends and stock buybacks.

site_title: Firefighters tackle blaze in south London
summary: A fire at industrial units in south London sent thick smoke billowing across the city, disrupting transport. Six people were treated by medics, one hospitalized, after a blaze in three commercial units under railway arches at Elephant and Castle. Firefighters from across London responded to the incident, which was brought under control, but not the cause of the fire is known. The Metropolitan Police said it was not believed to be terror-related.

site_title: Oil falls 2% on rising Covid-19 cases, ahead of Opec+ talks
summary: Oil prices fell 2% on Monday, reaching a one-week low, due to rising Covid-19 cases in Asia and Europe, which may impact demand recovery over the summer. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec+) meeting this week may also influence oil prices. Analysts expect Opec+ to increase output by 500,000 barrels per day in August, but Abu Dhabi National Oil Co. is set to reduce crude supplies to Asian term buyers. The US and Iran are also expected to resume indirect talks on reviving a 2015 nuclear pact.

site_title: Japan's retail sales rise for third month, but overall trend still soft
summary: Japan's retail sales rose 8.2% in May, the third straight month of growth, beating expectations. However, the underlying trend remains soft due to Covid-19-linked pressures. The economic recovery is expected to take time, with analysts predicting a barely growth rate in the second quarter. Policymakers are under pressure to take supportive measures to boost demand, as major global economies rebound from the Covid-19 slump. Retail sales were largely driven by year-on-year gains in spending on items such as general merchandise and cars, but the trend for spending by Japanese consumers is losing steam.

site_title: Digital currency craze might be like bad fashion fad: Federal Reserve's Quarles
summary: Federal Reserve Vice Chair Randal Quarles warned that the current craze over digital currencies, including calls for official crypto currencies, may be similar to a bad fashion fad. He expressed skepticism about the need for a US Central Bank Digital Currency (CBDC), citing potential risks such as cyberattacks and money laundering. Quarles also noted that novelty and anonymity are the main attractions of bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies, but they will likely remain a speculative investment rather than a revolutionary means of payment.

site_title: US House Republicans oppose Democratic-led China bill
summary: US House Republicans oppose the Democratic-led "Ensuring American Global Leadership and Engagement Act" (Eagle Act), which aims to boost competitiveness with China and push Beijing on human rights. The bill, which will likely advance with only Democratic support, includes provisions to regulate technology exports and sensitive personal data. Republicans object to the bill's focus on messaging and lack of concrete action, citing concerns over funding for climate initiatives and missed opportunities for meaningful action. The Senate has passed a similar bill, the "US Innovation and Competition Act," with bipartisan support.

site_title: Singapore-based Princeton Digital invests US$1b to build 97MW data centre campus in Japan
summary: Singapore-based Princeton Digital Group (PDG) has invested $1 billion to build a 97 megawatt data centre campus in Saitama City, Japan. The campus, comprising two facilities with 48.5 MW of critical IT capacity each, will serve leading hyperscalers in Japan and is expected to be ready in 2022. This marks PDG's entry into the Japanese market, following its recent foray into India. The move is seen as part of the Asia-Pacific region's growing demand for data centres, with the Greater Tokyo market projected to reach $1.6 billion by 2025.

site_title: ecoWise reinstates deputy CEO; will comply with SGX RegCo's directives
summary: Ecowise Holdings has reinstated its deputy CEO Cao Shixuan after a dispute led to the company's CEO Lee Thiam Seng changing the locks on server rooms. The move is in line with SGX RegCo's directives to appoint new independent directors, commission an internal audit, and form a new auditing committee. The company will also implement additional safeguards to ensure continued operations and avoid breaching payment obligations. Trading in the group's securities remains suspended until clarity is achieved on matters under review.

site_title: Carousell explores US listing via SPAC
summary: Carousell, a Singapore-based online classifieds marketplace operator, is considering a US listing via a merger with a blank-cheque company, potentially valuing the company at up to $1.5 billion. The move, which could take place by the end of this year, follows a growing trend of South-east Asian companies listing in the US via SPAC mergers, including Carsome, Tiket.com, PropertyGuru, and Grab Holdings. The company has expanded to eight markets and counts prominent backers, including Telenor Group and Sequoia Capital India.

site_title: Euro 2020: France stunned by Switzerland, Spain through to last eight
summary: France was eliminated from Euro 2020 by Switzerland in a penalty shootout after a 3-3 draw in Bucharest. Kylian Mbappe missed the decisive penalty, allowing Switzerland to advance to the quarterfinals. The match followed a 5-3 extra-time win for Spain over Croatia in Copenhagen, setting up a quarterfinal tie between Switzerland and Spain. Switzerland, who never won a knockout tie at the European Championship before, celebrated their first-ever quarterfinal appearance.

site_title: United Airlines said to be near new Boeing, Airbus orders
summary: United Airlines is expected to announce orders for over 200 new Airbus and Boeing planes, according to aviation industry expert Michel Merluzeau. The announcement is scheduled for Tuesday, following two public events at Newark Airport and an investor event on the company's website. Analysts expect the order to include the Boeing 737 MAX and 787, and the Airbus A321neo, as the airline seeks to refresh its aging fleet. The move comes as the US airline industry begins to recover from the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Uber to let office staff work up to half their time from anywhere: source
summary: Uber plans to announce a flexible return-to-office strategy, allowing employees to work up to half their hours from anywhere. The policy doesn't require at least three days a week in the office, instead allowing workers to split their time between the office and remote work. Employees can work from anywhere, including at home or exotic destinations, and will be encouraged to try remote work for four weeks a year. The company also plans to allow more employees to work remotely full-time.

images.alt_text: Uber Technologies Inc will let employees work half their hours from wherever they want as part of its revamped return-to-office strategy, the transport app company plans to announce on Tuesday, according to a person familiar with the matter.

site_title: In a scarred Hong Kong, 'beautiful things are gone'
summary: Hong Kong's pro-democracy protests, which began in 2019, have led to the erasure of "beautiful things" such as the Lennon walls, where protesters displayed messages and artwork. The Chinese government has cracked down on dissent, introducing a national security law that has resulted in arrests, censorship, and restrictions on freedom of speech. Authorities have removed or reframed sensitive topics from school curricula, pulled democracy books from libraries, and cancelled screenings of protest-related works. The government claims the measures are necessary to defend national security and restore stability, but critics argue they aim to control the narrative and erase the memory of the protests.

site_title: US should consider alternative to economic sanctions against authoritarian regimes
summary: The US and other Western governments have applied economic sanctions to Myanmar's military regime, but past experience suggests they have been ineffective in changing authoritarian behavior. The policy has harmed American economic interests and alienated regional allies, strengthening China's influence. The Biden administration is urged to consider alternative approaches, such as encouraging "constructive engagement" through key allies in the region, to promote democracy and counter Chinese influence in Myanmar.

site_title: Wells Fargo announces US$18b buyback plan, doubles dividend
summary: Wells Fargo has announced a US$18 billion share buyback plan, doubling its common stock dividend to 20 cents per share for the third quarter of 2021. This move is part of the bank's efforts to return capital to shareholders. The plan is expected to be completed by the second quarter of 2022.

images.alt_text: Wells Fargo & Co said on Monday it planned to repurchase US$18 billion worth of shares for the period between the third quarter of 2021 and the second quarter of 2022.

site_title: Europe: Stocks deepen losses, airlines slump on UK travel ban woes
summary: European stocks ended 0.6% lower, with travel stocks plummeting 4.4% due to concerns over UK travel bans amid the Delta variant. Energy stocks fell 2.3% as crude prices dropped, while technology stocks rose 0.4%. The Stoxx 600 is now below record highs, and investors are awaiting June inflation readings and business activity data. Airlines such as Easyjet and Ryanair fell between 4% and 6% due to the travel ban woes.

site_title: Indonesia sets out tax plan with new income bracket, amnesty
summary: Indonesia's Finance Minister Sri Mulyani announced a tax overhaul proposal, aiming to increase the value-added tax (VAT) to 12% and impose a new income bracket with a 35% tax rate on individuals earning over $464,310. The proposal also includes a tax amnesty program for individuals and corporations with unreported income, and a carbon tax to earn 32 trillion rupiah in revenue. The changes are set to be implemented in January 2022 to refill the government's coffers and reduce the tax gap, which is around 8.5% more than the international benchmark.

site_title: US: Nasdaq ends at record on resurgence of tech shares; Dow falls
summary: US stocks ended Monday at records, with the Nasdaq and S&P 500 rising 1.0% and 0.2% respectively, driven by a resurgence of technology shares. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.4% to 34,283.27. The Nasdaq Composite Index closed at a record 14,500.51, while the S&P 500 reached its third consecutive all-time high at 4,290.61.

site_title: UBS to let two-thirds of employees adopt permanent hybrid work
summary: UBS Group will allow up to two-thirds of its employees to adopt a permanent hybrid work model, with flexibility based on roles and locations. The move is led by CEO Ralph Hamers, who aims to be more competitive in recruitment compared to US banks that have taken a harder approach. UBS's internal analysis shows that two-thirds of its workforce can work from home, while some roles will require in-office work. This sets a contrast with US rivals, including Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan Chase, which have stricter office attendance policies.

site_title: Myanmar violence escalates as 'self-defence' groups rise
summary: Violence in post-coup Myanmar has escalated as "self-defence" forces confront the military, warning of a high human cost if the regime uses its full power. Since the February coup, over 880 people have been killed in junta crackdowns, according to a local monitoring group. Anti-junta groups have risen in response, and the situation remains volatile, with the international community expressing concern. The escalation of violence raises fears of further instability and humanitarian crises in the country.

site_title: Hope amid pandemic for local tech and electronics distributor
summary: Ban Leong Technologies, a Singapore-based distributor of multimedia products, data storage devices, and IT accessories, has benefited from the pandemic. The company reported a 21.6% year-on-year revenue increase to S$182.7 million in the full year ended March 31, driven by strong demand for LCD monitors, notebooks, and gaming accessories. Net profit rose 2.6 times to S$7.2 million. Ban Leong's shares have rallied 55.1% year-to-date, and the company plans to expand its presence in the commercial space and e-commerce.

site_title: Hong Kong home prices rise for fifth straight month in May
summary: Hong Kong private home prices rose 0.6% in May for the fifth consecutive month, driven by a recovering economy and expectations of sustained Chinese buying. The index has climbed 3.6% this year and is off just 0.8% from its all-time high in 2019. Property consultants predict prices will break the record high in the third quarter and gain a further 5% in the second half. Developers are accelerating new launches, driving up transaction volume, with Cushman & Wakefield expecting the highest home transactions since 2012.

site_title: Facebook wins antitrust dismissal, surges to US$1t value
summary: A US judge dismissed the antitrust action against Facebook, allowing the company's value to surge above $1 trillion for the first time. The Federal Trade Commission and over 40 states had filed the lawsuit in December, seeking to roll back Facebook's acquisition of Instagram and WhatsApp, arguing that the company had acted to "entrench and maintain its monopoly." The judge ruled that the FTC's complaint failed to establish a necessary element of Facebook having monopoly power in the personal social networking market.

site_title: Possible failure point emerges in Miami building collapse
summary: A deadly building collapse in Miami has raised concerns about a possible failure point in the structure. Investigators are focusing on a spot near the underground parking garage, where an initial failure could have triggered a "progressive collapse." Experts believe the collapse started at or near the bottom of the 13-storey building, with evidence of major structural damage found three years prior to the disaster. The death toll has risen to nine, with over 150 people still unaccounted for, and a foundation-related matter is suspected as the cause.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Singapore's NTT DC Reit's public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times, while US stocks opened lower due to fresh tariffs on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss similar to H1. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10b upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC announced Tan Teck Long as its incoming CEO. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and PBOC to deepen cooperation in green finance. Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: ECB's emergency stimulus could end next March: Holzmann
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) may end its emergency stimulus scheme as early as next March, according to Austrian central bank chief Robert Holzmann. The scheme, which has been in place since the pandemic, is expected to end by the end of March, with the Asset Purchase Programme continuing to support the economy. Holzmann also suggested that the market's assessment of the timeline is correct, and that the ECB may use unconventional flexibility to keep borrowing costs low until inflation rises.

site_title: Saudi conglomerate buys Mumzworld as Middle East competition gains ground
summary: Saudi conglomerate Tamer Group has agreed to buy Mumzworld, the Middle East's largest online children-goods retailer, in a deal described as the region's first "woman-led e-commerce transaction". The acquisition aims to fuel Mumzworld's growth in the Middle East market, valued at over $10 billion, amid increasing competition from Indian rival FirstCry.com and regional players like Noon.com. Mumzworld's co-founder and CEO Mona Ataya sees the deal as a strategic fit, allowing the company to "supercharge our growth" with resources and networks.

site_title: Working together towards carbon-neutral societies
summary: Germany's Federal Government has set a goal of achieving greenhouse gas neutrality by 2045, with a target of 88% emissions reduction by 2040. The country aims to work with Singapore and other Indo-Pacific nations to promote sustainable development and environmentally friendly growth. Germany and Singapore will collaborate on initiatives such as plastic waste reduction and smart urban mobility, and the two countries have established a joint "Germany Singapore Business Forum Connect" to facilitate discussions on green technologies and sustainable development.

site_title: Who will win the Marina View white site?
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has launched a tender for a 99-year leasehold site in Marina View, Singapore, which can generate about 905 private homes, 540 hotel rooms, and 2,000 square meters of office space. IOI Properties Group, linked to Bursa Malaysia-listed IOI Properties, is tipped as the party that triggered the site release. The minimum bid price for IOI Properties is S$1,379 per square foot per plot ratio (psf ppr), which is seen as on the low side. The tender is expected to close on September 21, and IOI Properties may consider partnering with other developers, such as City Developments or Ho Bee, to boost its chances.

site_title: South-east Asian nations missing from push to protect 30% of planet
summary: South-east Asian nations are missing from a global push to protect 30% of the planet's land and oceans by 2030, despite the region being home to three of the world's 17 "megadiverse" countries. Environmentalists warn that the region's incredible biodiversity, including 35% of mangrove forests and 30% of coral reefs, is under threat from high deforestation rates and economic pressures. Cambodia is the only South-east Asian nation to have signed up to the goal, but Asean countries must join to meet the target, with indigenous groups and communities playing a vital role in conservation efforts.

site_title: Region can do much to create and sell carbon credits
summary: Singapore can expect a haze-free year, thanks to favorable weather and the Indonesian government's efforts to combat haze. The country's commitment to combating haze and strengthening sustainability is seen as a positive step, with the potential to create jobs and growth. Indonesia aims to achieve net-zero greenhouse gas emissions by 2045 and is working to generate carbon credits from conservation efforts, with the potential to become a "carbon credit superpower." However, challenges remain, including the need to balance environmental protection with economic growth and the potential for negative consequences from government-backed farms.

site_title: US dollar index steadies as focus shifts to jobs data
summary: The US dollar index remained steady, holding at 91.718, as markets awaited key US jobs data on Friday. The Australian dollar rose 0.1% due to a cautious mood, while the New Zealand dollar increased 0.2%. Speculators decreased their net short dollar positions, and a potential bipartisan US infrastructure agreement boosted risk appetite. Oil prices slipped after reaching their highest since October 2018.

site_title: Pandemic sees more firms drawn into political controversy
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has led to increased scrutiny of companies involved in vaccine development and supply, with AstraZeneca facing criticism from European politicians over its vaccine's efficacy and supply contracts. Despite its proven efficacy, the non-profit nature of the vaccine has allowed it to be rolled out at low cost in developing countries, prompting concerns about its availability in Europe. This is part of a broader trend of businesses becoming entangled in international political issues, with technology firms facing challenges in balancing user privacy and contact tracing efficacy.

images.alt_text: Despite the AstraZeneca vaccine's proven efficacy, the firm has been questioned by many politicians, especially in continental Europe.

site_title: Covid-19 relief measures for property sector extended for 6 months
summary: The Singapore government has extended temporary relief measures for property developers due to ongoing disruptions from the Covid-19 pandemic. The measures, which include a 6-month extension to construction timelines and the Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty regime, will benefit qualifying developers. The extensions are aimed at addressing manpower shortages and further disruptions to construction timelines caused by tightened border measures. The relief measures do not alter existing residential property market cooling measures.

site_title: US$27b pile of debt looms over India's new bad bank
summary: India's new bad bank, set to launch by the end of June, is expected to handle $36 billion in stressed debt, a quarter of the country's non-performing debt load. The institution aims to speed up decision-making and improve bargaining power, but investors say it's a long-term solution and fundamental problems with insolvency laws need to be addressed. Creditors' recovery rates have fallen, delays in closing cases have increased, and liquidations exceed resolutions in the insolvency courts, casting doubt on the bank's effectiveness.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust sold its remaining 9 non-auctioned Chapter 11 properties for US$324.7 million, bringing total proceeds from 14 properties to US$478.6 million. CNMC Goldmine Holdings expects the Malaysian government's extended nationwide lockdown to negatively affect its financial performance. Yanlord Land and Ho Bee Land will jointly develop a 53,200 sq m residential site in Tianjin, China.

site_title: North Korea highlights Kim's weight loss as food shortage builds
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong-un has made a dramatic appearance, showcasing his significantly thinner figure, sparking emotional reactions from citizens. The weight loss is believed to be due to food shortages, with the country struggling to recover from last year's typhoons and Covid-19 restrictions. Kim's health is a closely guarded secret, but his recent appearances suggest he is not visibly ill. The propaganda campaign aims to build support for his economic revival efforts and maintain his image as a selfless leader.

site_title: Simone Biles' Olympic cast members emerge from US trials
summary: Simone Biles has secured a spot on the US Olympic women's gymnastics team for the Tokyo Olympics, finishing first at the US trials. Her teammates, Sunisa Lee, Jordan Chiles, and Grace McCallum, will support her in the team event. Biles, 24, will defend her Olympic all-around title and aims to become the first woman to achieve this feat in over 50 years. Lee and Chiles also secured spots as individual competitors, with McCallum chosen for her strong performances in the team event.

images.alt_text: Left to right: Simone Biles, Sunisa Lee, Jordan Chiles, and Grace McCallum were named to the squad that will compete in Tokyo at the US Gymnastics Olympic Trials at America's Center on June 27, 2021 in St Louis, Missouri.

site_title: NZ central bank may cease QE bond purchases in coming months
summary: New Zealand's central bank, the Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ), may end its quantitative easing bond purchases in coming months as it prepares to raise interest rates. Financial markets are pricing a 56% chance of an OCR hike in November, prompting the RBNZ to keep QE purchases unchanged at NZ$200 million. The RBNZ forecasts rate hikes in the second half of 2022, driven by strong economic growth and inflation pressures. This could signal an end to QE purchases before the OCR hike.

site_title: Supreme Components grows global business with 'Speed of Thought'
summary: Supreme Components International Pte Ltd, a franchised distributor of electronic and LED components, has achieved a record seven Enterprise 50 Awards. Founded in 2005, the company has grown its annual turnover from S$495,000 to S$100 million, with 12 offices in 10 countries. The company's president, Vick Aggarwala, credits the "Speed of Thought" philosophy, which emphasizes speed and agility in delivering value to customers. SCI aims to become one of the top 50 distributors in the world, expanding its operations to China, Germany, and other markets, and implementing a digital e-commerce platform.

site_title: PUB engineer and television installer among four community cases
summary: Singapore reported four community cases on Monday, the lowest daily number since June 11. The cases involve a PUB engineer, a television installer, a 60-year-old man from Lam Chuan Import-Export, and an 81-year-old retiree. All community cases were under quarantine when detected. Meanwhile, five imported cases were reported, including two Singaporeans returning from Pakistan. The total number of new cases rose to 9, bringing Singapore's tally to 62,553. The number of unlinked community cases decreased from 16 to 15 over the past week.

site_title: Long-haul leisure market to Europe might recover faster than expected: Scoot
summary: Scoot, the budget carrier of Singapore Airlines, expects the long-haul leisure market to Europe to recover faster than initially anticipated due to increased vaccination rates and easing of travel restrictions. The airline has reinstated flights to Athens and is finalizing regulatory permissions for another long-haul route, with no specific destination disclosed. Scoot now operates at 17% of pre-pandemic capacity and aims to reach 23% by July. The International Air Transport Association forecasts global air travel to return to pre-pandemic levels by end-2023.

site_title: Malaysia extends lockdown, unveils RM150b package
summary: Malaysia has unveiled a RM150 billion stimulus package to help people through the nationwide lockdown, which has been extended for a second time due to elevated Covid-19 cases. The package includes a RM10 billion direct fiscal injection, RM10 billion in cash aid, and service tax breaks for hotel operators. The government has also announced automatic approval for six-month loan moratoriums and extended wage subsidies. The package comes as Malaysian stocks fell to a seven-month low amid a selloff in South-east Asia's equities markets.

site_title: S$1b nickel scam has 'limited' impact on fund-management industry: MAS
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has assessed investments by three licensed fund managers into an entity linked to a S$1 billion nickel scam and found the impact on the industry to be "limited". The fund managers, Envysion Wealth Management, Vickers Venture Partners, and Sun Hope Capital, invested less than S$100 million on behalf of fewer than 250 accredited investors. The accused, Ng Yu Zhi, faces 31 charges and has been out on bail of S$1.5 million. The MAS will conduct supervisory reviews of the fund managers to determine if there were governance or risk-management failures.

site_title: Boeing's 777X unlikely to gain key certification before mid-2023
summary: The US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has rejected Boeing's certification request for its 777X aircraft, citing unresolved issues such as a lack of data and a preliminary safety assessment. The FAA warns that the airplane is unlikely to be certified until mid- to late 2023, two years from now. This decision comes after fatal crashes of the 737 MAX prompted accusations of cozy relations between Boeing and the FAA. Boeing has confirmed that it remains committed to safety and is working to address the issues, but the certification delay is a setback for the company's development plans.

images.alt_text: The Boeing 777X (above) is to be the first major jet to be certified since software flaws in two Boeing 737 MAX planes caused fatal crashes in Indonesia and Ethiopia in 2018 and 2019, and prompted accusations of cosy relations between the company and FAA.

site_title: Emerging markets are losing the race for green finance
summary: Emerging markets are falling behind in green finance, with output expected to be 8% below pre-pandemic levels by 2024. While Western models have shown impressive strides in sustainable investing, grafting these ideas onto emerging markets may not be effective. The gap between developed and developing markets is growing, with Italy's green bond issuance surpassing emerging market sovereign green issuance in 2020. To address this, international financial institutions are exploring risk-sharing mechanisms and domestic capital markets in emerging economies need to build their own green finance ecosystems.

site_title: Thousands descend on Barcelona for reboot of MWC mobile tech show
summary: Thousands of visitors from 143 countries are attending the three-day Mobile World Congress in Barcelona, despite the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. Over 30,000 attendees are expected to pass through a testing area with 80 booths. The event, which was cancelled in 2020, is a significant step for the GSMA, which took a 40% staff cut after the pandemic. Major industry names such as Telefonica and Orange are in attendance, but Ericsson and Samsung are not. The event aims to provide a blueprint for future business gatherings and marks a return to in-person networking after a year of isolation.

site_title: Is there still a premium behind freehold property?
summary: In Singapore, freehold property commands a 10.4% premium over comparable leasehold properties, according to a study by the National University of Singapore's Institute of Real Estate and Urban Studies. Strong sales of 99-year land led to this premium, as buyers worry about land lease decay and the potential for reduced financing options. However, the government has a policy of allowing leases to expire without extension, and extensions are considered on a case-by-case basis. Freehold tenure may offer a sense of security, but it's not guaranteed, and foreign buyers may value it due to its rarity in China.

site_title: Korea's Kakao Bank seeks as much as US$2.3b in IPO
summary: Kakao Bank, an internet-only lender in South Korea, plans to raise up to $2.3 billion in its initial public offering. The bank is selling 65.45 million new shares at a range of 33,000-39,000 won apiece, which could make it the third most valuable lender in Korea.

site_title: China's electric car capital has lessons for the rest of world
summary: Liuzhou, China, has become the world's electric vehicle capital, with over 30% of its cars sold being electric, surpassing China's national average. The city's efforts to encourage EV adoption include incentives such as free parking, test drives, and cash rewards for drivers. Liuzhou's strategy has led to improved air and water quality, with the city's air quality rated excellent 97% of the time in 2020. The approach may serve as a blueprint for other cities to overcome concerns about EVs and meet ambitious emissions targets.

site_title: Dubai's luxury-home sales soar in post-pandemic rebound
summary: Dubai's luxury-home sales have surged in the post-pandemic era, with 22 properties worth over $10 million selling in the first five months of the year, the most since 2015. This rebound is part of a global trend, with London's wealthiest areas also seeing a surge in sales. The emirate's economic activity, tourism, and vaccination campaign have contributed to the growth, but other parts of the real-estate sector, such as developers struggling with debt and a property glut, may pose challenges.

site_title: Chinese flock to home-grown brands in golden opportunity for investors
summary: Chinese consumers are increasingly favoring home-grown brands, driving billions of dollars in investment. A surge in online shopping and infrastructure for local vendors have fueled demand for local products. Investors have poured funds into local consumer brands, with Chinese consumer firms raising 69.7 billion yuan (S$14.5 billion) from primary market investors in the first five months. Key brands, such as Maia Active and Weilong Delicious Global Holdings, have seen significant growth and valuations, with some reaching over $6 billion. Nationalism and a recent backlash against foreign brands have contributed to the trend, with JD.com reporting a 4% higher sales growth for Chinese brands compared to international brands.

site_title: China's worsening ties with the world will hurt its economy - and also the rest of the world's
summary: China's economic growth is at risk due to worsening ties with the rest of the world, particularly since the COVID-19 pandemic. Despite a strong desire to double household incomes by 2030, China's consumption-to-GDP ratio remains low, around 40%, hindering its goal of boosting domestic consumption. To achieve its target, China must increase productivity, particularly in manufacturing, while also promoting personal consumption and services. However, this poses a challenge, as manufacturing and services are not typically the most productive sectors. If China fails to address this dilemma, its economic growth and global influence will be negatively impacted, affecting not only China but also the rest of the world.

site_title: Ivan Glasenberg makes one last coal deal in final days at Glencore
summary: Glencore, under outgoing CEO Ivan Glasenberg, agreed to buy stakes owned by BHP Group and Anglo American in the Cerrejon thermal coal mine in Colombia for about $588 million. The deal expands Glencore's coal production, despite global efforts to reduce usage, and allows the company to maintain control for 30 more years. The purchase completes Anglo's retreat from thermal coal and extends BHP's efforts, as coal prices soar due to strong demand and output constraints.

site_title: Even gold-obsessed Indians are now pouring billions into crypto
summary: India's investments in cryptocurrency have grown from $923 million in April 2020 to nearly $6.6 billion in May 2021, a 612% increase, according to Chainalysis. This growth is driven by younger Indians, with 15 million buying and selling digital coins, surpassing the 2.3 million in the UK and 23 million in the US. Despite regulatory uncertainty and official hostility, many Indians are investing in crypto, with some even borrowing from family members to participate, citing its transparency and potential for short-term returns.

site_title: With cloud and AI, IBM broadens 5G deals with Verizon and Telefonica
summary: IBM has expanded its 5G deals with Verizon and Telefonica, offering cloud and AI services to help telecom operators build and sell 5G networks more efficiently. IBM's cloud platform will allow operators to run their networks faster and reduce costs, while a virtual assistant created by IBM and Telefonica will automate tasks and reduce wait times. This partnership broadens IBM's existing relationships with the two firms, marking an "existential moment" for telecom operators to rethink their networks as a digital world. No financial terms were disclosed for the tie-ups.

site_title: China starts Baihetan hydro project, biggest since Three Gorges
summary: China has begun generating electricity at the Baihetan hydro project, its largest hydroelectric dam since the Three Gorges Dam. The 1-gigawatt turbines will operate after a three-day trial, with the project's total capacity expected to be second only to the Three Gorges Dam once completed in July. The dam is part of a national scheme to generate electricity and strengthen control over water flows during the summer flood season, amid growing electricity shortages in eastern China.

site_title: MAS says impact on fund-management industry from investments into Envy entity is 'limited'
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has assessed investments by three licensed fund managers into Envy Global Trading, a S$1 billion fraud scheme, and found the impact on the fund management industry to be "limited". The investments were made by accredited investors, and the fund managers claimed they did not raise money from retail investors. MAS will conduct supervisory reviews to check for governance and risk-management failures and will take firm actions where necessary. The MAS reminded licensed fund managers of their responsibility to have robust risk-management policies in place.

site_title: Sabana Reit rejects EGM requisition to remove director
summary: Sabana Reit's manager has rejected a requisition from Quarz Capital and Black Crane Capital to hold an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) to vote on the appointment of independent non-executive director Chan Wai Kheong. The two firms, holding over 10% of Sabana Reit's units, objected to Chan's appointment citing potential conflicts of interest due to his substantial holdings in Aims Apac Reit, a competitor to Sabana Reit. Sabana Reit's manager argued that the regulations do not regard a director's non-independence solely based on their investment in another Reit, and that Chan will be subject to strict fiduciary duty to prioritize Sabana Reit's interests.

site_title: Working from home won't level the playing field for women
summary: Working from home (WFH) arrangements may not level the playing field for women, despite increased adoption of flexible work arrangements (FWAs). A survey found women prefer working from the office (WFO) for career progression, while men prefer WFH. Women cited blurred boundaries between work and family, interruptions, and shared physical space as challenges. Despite a higher demand for FWAs, women's workforce participation still depends on men's caregiving burden. Experts recommend a universal approach to FWAs to lift the unequal burden on working women and promote career progression.

site_title: Purported victims of Ng Yu Zhi's alleged scam include leading lawyers, venture capitalist
summary: Ng Yu Zhi, 34, is accused of swindling at least S$1 billion from investors through nickel deals that never took place. He is charged with 31 offences, including cheating and misappropriation of S$201.2 million. Ng, director of Envy Asset Management (EAT) and Envy Global Trading (EGT), allegedly deceived investors to purchase forward contracts for nickel sales that never occurred. He faces lawsuits from alleged victims, including prominent individuals and companies, and has links to 34 entities as a shareholder or director.

site_title: Australia steps up vaccine push to stem Covid-19 outbreak
summary: Australia's Prime Minister Scott Morrison announced measures to combat the country's Covid-19 outbreak, making vaccinations mandatory for high-risk aged-care workers and employees in quarantine hotels. The Delta variant has led to a surge in cases, with five states and territories experiencing outbreaks. The government aims to have all residential aged-care workers vaccinated by mid-September and all workers in quarantine facilities vaccinated or tested. Lockdowns and restrictions remain in place, with the goal of suppressing the outbreak until 2022.

site_title: K-pop activism becomes lifeline for Thailand's hard-hit tuk-tuk drivers
summary: Thailand's hard-hit tuk-tuk drivers are finding new sources of income thanks to young K-pop fans, who are putting up banners of their favorite idols on the vehicles. The initiative, which began during anti-government protests, has benefited hundreds of drivers by providing them with an additional 600 baht ($25.26) a month. The fans, who used to spend their ad money on public transport billboards, are now supporting grassroots businesses, including tuk-tuks and street food vendors, as the tourism industry remains devastated by the pandemic.

site_title: Industrial GLS for H2 2021 launched; 4 confirmed sites, 3 on reserve
summary: The Ministry of Trade and Industry launched the Industrial Government Land Sales programme for H2 2021, featuring 4 confirmed sites and 3 reserve sites with a total site area of 5.14 ha. This marks the second half of the year's industrial GLS sales.

site_title: PUB engineer, TV installer among four Covid-19 community cases, lowest since June 11
summary: Singapore reported four community cases of COVID-19, the lowest daily number since June 11, with all cases being under quarantine when detected. The cases include a PUB engineer, a television installer, a 60-year-old man linked to a cluster at Block 105 Henderson Crescent, and an 81-year-old retiree. Five imported cases were also reported, with two being Singaporeans who returned from Pakistan. The number of new cases in the community has fallen, with 135 patients in hospital, including three in critical condition.

site_title: CNMC expects its H1 to be hit by extended Malaysia lockdown
summary: CNMC Goldmine Holdings expects its first half of 2021 to be negatively affected by Malaysia's extended nationwide lockdown, which could delay exploration and production activities. The group has ceased on-site activities in Kelantan since June 1 and will only allow limited maintenance work at the Sokor project. Despite being in a net cash position, CNMC's outlook for the half-year remains challenging if the pandemic stalls its activities. Shares remained unchanged at 21.5 Singapore cents following the announcement.

site_title: UK government 'sorry' after top secret files left at bus stop
summary: The UK government apologized after top-secret documents assessing the movements of a Royal Navy warship in the Black Sea were found at a bus stop in Kent, England. The documents, marked "Secret: UK Eyes Only," were found by a member of the public and discussed a possible Russian response to the Royal Navy's HMS Defender. Junior Defence Minister Jeremy Quin blamed a senior ministry official for the lapse, which he said was a "mistake" and not a breach of national security. The individual's access to sensitive material was suspended pending an investigation.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed lower on Monday, following a broad Asian market decline, due to heavy storms that halted the morning session. The Hang Seng Index dropped 0.07% to 29,268.30, while the Shanghai Composite Index remained flat. The Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.88% to 2,463.66. The decline comes after a rally last week.

site_title: ECB hawks and doves spar as tapering debate fires up
summary: European Central Bank policymakers began debating the end of its emergency bond purchases, with hawkish governors Jens Weidmann and Robert Holzmann favoring a March 2022 end, while dovish member Fabio Panetta warned against withdrawing support too soon. The ECB has pledged to continue its Pandemic Emergency Purchase Programme until the coronavirus crisis phase is over, but disagreements over the timing and scope of tapering have emerged. The debate highlights faultlines between those advocating for tighter monetary policy and those supporting looser policy to stimulate economic activity.

site_title: Property sector gets 6-month extension to temporary relief measures
summary: Singapore's government has extended temporary relief measures for property developers, granting six-month extensions to construction timeline-related requirements. This is due to ongoing disruptions from the Covid-19 pandemic, including manpower shortages and border restrictions. The extensions apply to projects under the Project Completion Period, Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty, and Qualifying Certificate regimes. This move aims to support the sector, which continues to face challenges despite a gradual resumption of construction work since August 2020.

site_title: Maradona's doctor questioned in star's death
summary: Diego Maradona's doctor, Leopoldo Luque, was questioned by prosecutors in Buenos Aires as part of an investigation into claims that he and six medical personnel neglected the football icon in his final days, leading to his death in November 2021 at the age of 60. Luque has denied guilt, stating he did his best to assist Maradona, while prosecutors claim the team abandoned him for a "prolonged, agonising period."
