A judge will decide whether to order a trial, which could take years, with potential prison sentences ranging from 8 to 25 years.

site_title: EU hints at 'sausage war' deal with UK in 48 hours
summary: The European Union and the UK are close to resolving the "sausage war" over chilled meat products entering Northern Ireland, with a deal likely within 48 hours, according to EU Vice President Maros Sefcovic. The UK government had threatened to extend a grace period for checks, but the EU has indicated a compromise, with Sefcovic suggesting that 80% of hold-ups could be resolved if the UK signs up to a "Swiss-style" form of controls. The agreement would address both sides' needs and concerns, with a three-month extension to resolve the issue if no agreement is reached.

site_title: US Covid cases hit new plateau as Delta variant rises
summary: US Covid cases have plateaued at 11,500 new daily cases per 7-day average, as the Delta variant gains traction, accounting for 35.6% of sequenced cases. A divide has emerged across the country, with cases rising rapidly in under-vaccinated regions. Nationally, 54% of the population has received one or more doses, while 46.1% have had two doses. The Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine was 88% effective against symptomatic disease from Delta, but only 33% after one dose.

site_title: Scoot launches new Airbus A321neo aircraft on Singapore-Bangkok route
summary: Budget carrier Scoot has launched its first flights using the new Airbus A321neo aircraft on the Singapore-Bangkok route. The aircraft, which can accommodate 236 passengers, is 50 more than Scoot's previous planes and has a flight time of up to six hours. Scoot's CEO, Campbell Wilson, stated that the A321neo will expand the carrier's network and bring new routes to its network. The carrier is considering new routes, including those previously terminated due to economic considerations, and is confident that demand for air travel will recover, with the International Air Transport Association predicting international air travel will return to pre-Covid levels by 2023.

site_title: International Finance Corp unveils US$150m package for Vietnam's SMEs, green projects, trade finance
summary: The International Finance Corp (IFC) has unveiled a US$150 million package for Vietnam's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), green projects, and trade finance. The package includes a US$40 million loan to Vietnam-based SeABank, with US$100 million dedicated to SMEs, including at least US$20 million for women-led businesses. The goal is to triple women-led SME lending to 25% of the overall SME portfolio by 2024, helping bridge a US$4.9 billion financing gap. The package also aims to grow SeABank's climate-finance portfolio to US$60 million by 2024.

site_title: Kori Holdings unit wins two contracts worth S$52.3m
summary: Kori Holdings' subsidiary, Kori Construction, has secured two contracts worth S$52.3 million for the North-South Corridor project. The contracts involve supplying and installing temporary steel works for a tunnel between Novena Rise and Toa Payoh Rise, and steel struts and walers for another tunnel between Pemimpin Place and Sin Ming Avenue. This brings Kori's total contract value since September 2020 to S$133.5 million, affirming the company's long-standing track record and gaining customer trust.

site_title: US: Stocks mixed ahead of key economic reports
summary: US stocks are mixed ahead of key economic reports, with the Dow Jones down 0.4% and the S&P 500 shedding 0.1%. The Nasdaq Composite Index gained 0.5%. Recent signs of inflation are being taken in stride, according to Charles Schwab, with investors focusing on the timing of global monetary policy tightening. The markets are also awaiting updates on the US economic recovery from the coronavirus downturn.

site_title: Stretched global supply chain means shortages on summer menus
summary: Supply chain disruptions are causing shortages of key ingredients and products at restaurants and fast-food chains globally. The issue is not a scarcity of the product itself, but rather a strain on networks of cargo ships, trains, and trucks due to the pandemic. Shortages have affected restaurants in the US, South Korea, and the UK, with some locations running out of items such as french fries, chicken wings, and lettuce. Supply bottlenecks are expected to continue into 2022, according to St Louis Federal Reserve President James Bullard.

site_title: World's rich steer superyachts to Greece after Covid reopening
summary: Greece has seen a significant surge in superyachts, with at least 194 vessels parked off its shores as of June 25, according to Bloomberg. The Aegean nation has reopened to foreign tourists with no quarantine required, with celebrities such as Magic Johnson and James Packer spotted on yachts. Greece's tourism industry, which accounts for 25% of jobs and 20% of the economy, has been boosted by the reopening, but some countries, including Germany and France, have criticized Greece for accepting visitors with less effective vaccines.

site_title: Burberry CEO Marco Gobbetti to leave luxury brand by year-end
summary: Burberry CEO Marco Gobbetti will leave the luxury brand by the end of this year to take the top post at Salvatore Ferragamo. Gobbetti, who spent nearly five years at Burberry, will return to Italy after years working abroad. Burberry shares fell 7.5% after the announcement, while Ferragamo shares rose 2%. Ferragamo has struggled to attract younger luxury shoppers, and Gobbetti is expected to oversee a creative director change. Burberry's board will begin searching for a successor to Gobbetti, who oversaw a turnaround at the brand.

site_title: Yanlord, Ho Bee to jointly develop Tianjin residential site
summary: Yanlord Land Group and Ho Bee Land have entered an agreement to jointly develop a 53,200 sq m residential site in Tianjin, China, for approximately 1.5 billion yuan (S$312.3 million). The site will be transformed into a high-end residential development with ancillary community retail space and educational facilities. The joint venture will hold 51% and 49% effective interest, respectively, with Yanlord's chairman and CEO Zhong Sheng Jian expressing confidence in the project's success, citing the group's track record in building quality residences in Tianjin.

site_title: Sin Ghee Huat privatisation offer closes with 94.9% valid acceptances
summary: Sin Ghee Huat Corporation's voluntary unconditional privatisation offer by HHH Co has closed with 94.94% valid acceptances. The offer price was S$0.27 per share, and HHH Co will compulsorily acquire remaining shares at the same price. As a result, Sin Ghee Huat will be delisted from the Singapore Exchange, and trading of its shares will be suspended due to the lack of free float requirement.

site_title: Hong Kong bans passenger flights from UK to curb Covid-19
summary: Hong Kong has banned all passenger flights from the UK from Thursday to curb the spread of the Delta variant of Covid-19. The ban applies to individuals who have stayed in the UK for more than two hours, and it is the second time Hong Kong has barred arrivals from Britain. The move aims to prevent the spread of the highly contagious variant, which has been reported in the UK.

site_title: Frankfurt banker headcount to drop despite Brexit boost
summary: Frankfurt's banking jobs are expected to decline by 5% by 2023, dropping to around 62,200 people, despite a boost from Brexit, according to a Helaba study. This is due to cost-cutting measures. In contrast, Helaba predicts 1,500 new Brexit-related jobs for Frankfurt this year and next, on top of 2,000 already created in 2020 and earlier. The decline is attributed to a shift in demand for staff overseeing compliance and regulation at banks.

site_title: ERA Realty promotes COO Marcus Chu to CEO
summary: ERA Realty is promoting COO Marcus Chu to CEO, succeeding current CEO Jack Chua, effective July 1. The separation of chairman and CEO roles aims to enhance corporate governance. Chu will oversee ERA Singapore's business operations and growth plans. He has spearheaded ERA's digitisation initiatives and has been with the company for 25 years. Chu's promotion is seen as a confidence booster, with the current CEO expressing his confidence in Chu's ability to lead and advance the company's strategic growth plans.

site_title: Singapore shares buck regional trend, STI up 0.17%
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.17% on Monday, tracking gains on Wall Street, as concerns about the Federal Reserve easing eased. The Straits Times Index (STI) reached 3,126.88, with BN4 and C31 being top performers. However, the subdued Asian week is expected to continue until data releases accelerate, with the evolving virus situation across Asia-Pacific potentially weighing on gains.

site_title: Glencore snaps up BHP, Anglo stakes in Colombian coal mine
summary: Glencore is set to become the sole owner of the Cerrejon thermal coal mine in Colombia after buying out partners BHP and Anglo American for US $230 million. The deal, expected to complete in the first half of 2022, will boost Glencore's coal assets as demand for coal is expected to jump 4.5% in 2021, driven by increased coal-fired power generation in Asia. Glencore plans to maintain its climate commitments, aiming to become a net-zero emission company by 2050 and manage coal mine depletion by mid-2040s.

site_title: Swedish PM resigns following no confidence vote
summary: Sweden's Prime Minister Stefan Lofven resigned on Monday after losing a vote of no confidence, leaving the country without a government. Lofven, a Social Democrat, had seven days to consider his options after the confidence vote, but instead chose to resign, citing the difficult situation posed by the Covid-19 pandemic and the upcoming general election. The Speaker of Parliament will now begin the search for a new prime minister, with negotiations expected to start immediately.

site_title: EU countries approve deal to overhaul farming subsidies
summary: The European Union has approved a deal to overhaul its farming subsidy program, the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP), which will spend 387 billion euros on payments to farmers and rural development. The new rules, set to take effect in 2023, require countries to spend 20% of payments on "eco-schemes" to protect the environment. The deal aims to support sustainable agriculture and reduce the bloc's 10% greenhouse gas emissions from agriculture. However, campaigners have expressed concerns that key environmental protections are weak or voluntary, and Parliament will vote on the deal in the coming months.

site_title: Malaysia unveils US$36b package as lockdown is extended
summary: Malaysia has unveiled a US$36 billion package to aid the public during the extended nationwide lockdown due to COVID-19. The package includes a direct fiscal injection of RM10 billion and direct cash aid of RM10 billion. The lockdown, which began on June 1, is expected to further impact the economy, with the World Bank slashing its 2021 forecast to 4.5% growth. The government expects to transition to the second phase of its recovery plan once new daily cases drop below 4,000 and vaccination rates reach 10%.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed lower on Monday, down 14.97 points to 1,544.71. The market saw a significant decline in trading volume, with 4.731 billion lots worth RM 2.405 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 976 to 133.

site_title: Burberry says chief executive to step down
summary: British luxury fashion house Burberry announced that its chief executive Marco Gobbetti will step down at the end of the year to return to Italy after nearly 20 years abroad. Gobbetti will leave after nearly five years in the role, following a strong sales recovery for the company. The board and chairman Gerry Murphy expressed disappointment but respect for Gobbetti's decision, citing the company's path to strong growth as a factor. Burberry has not announced a replacement for Gobbetti yet.

site_title: Four new Covid-19 community cases in Singapore, all linked
summary: Singapore reported 4 new Covid-19 community cases linked to previous cases, bringing the total to 62,553 cases. 5 imported cases were also reported, with 2 being returning Singaporeans. No new cases were reported in migrant workers' dormitories. 148 patients remained hospitalized, with 4 in critical condition. The death toll remains at 36, with the latest fatality being an 84-year-old woman who died of Covid-19 complications, unvaccinated and with pre-existing health conditions.

site_title: Top Global privatisation offer closes with 95.9% valid acceptances
summary: Top Global's voluntary unconditional cash offer for the company has closed with 95.89% valid acceptances, surpassing the required 90% threshold. The offer price was S$0.39 per share, and the offeror intends to exercise its right to compulsory acquisition, applying to delist the company. As the free float falls below 10%, trading in Top Global shares will be suspended. The offeror closed the shares at S$0.385 on Monday, down 0.5 cents or 1.28%.

site_title: Indonesia finmin unveils plans for major tax overhaul
summary: Indonesia's finance minister, Sri Mulyani Indrawati, has unveiled a plan for a major tax overhaul, aiming to boost government revenues and build a fair tax system. The proposal includes increasing the VAT rate to 12%, introducing a carbon tax, and hiking excise taxes on plastic products. A new programme will allow people to report undisclosed assets, and an alternative minimum tax will be introduced for loss-making businesses. The bill is set to be debated in Parliament, with the government controlling over 70% of the seats.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: CapitaLand divests partial stakes in China projects to Ping An for 46.7 billion yuan. The Singaporean real estate company will retain 12.6-30% effective stake in six developments. Finian Tan, a top lawyer, and others are linked to a S$1 billion nickel scam. Singapore calls for retail CBDC solutions, partnering with IMF and World Bank. A 0.78-hectare site in Downtown may attract more interest at S$1.51 billion. CNMC expects H1 earnings hit by Malaysia lockdown, while the STI rose 0.17% today.

images.alt_text: CapitaLand has entered into conditional agreements with Ping An Life Insurance Company of China to divest partial stakes in a group of companies that own six of its Raffles City developments in China, the group said on Monday.

site_title: Saudi group buys Mumzworld in landmark Mid-East deal
summary: A Saudi conglomerate, Tamer Group, has acquired Dubai-based Mumzworld, the Middle East's largest online children-goods retailer, in a landmark deal. The transaction, described as the region's first "woman-led e-commerce transaction," will provide Mumzworld with resources and networks to fuel its growth. The deal underscores the growth of e-commerce in the Middle East amid increasing competition from Amazon and Noon.com. Mumzworld, valued at over $10 billion, estimates the online segment of the Middle East mother, baby, and children-goods market grows at 39% per year.

site_title: Europe: Inflation woes keep shares below record highs, travel stocks slump
summary: European shares held below record highs on Monday due to concerns over inflation and potential tapering of ultra-loose monetary policy. The pan-European Stoxx 600 fell 0.1% despite a 1.2% gain last week. Travel stocks declined, led by TUI, Ryanair, and IAG, after a spike in Covid-19 cases in Asia. The US Federal Reserve's hawkish stance also weighed on global markets. Meanwhile, Burberry Group shares plummeted 5.1% after CEO Marco Gobbetti's resignation, while Salvatore Ferragamo jumped 2.9% after naming Gobbetti as its new CEO.

site_title: With cloud and AI, IBM broadens 5G deals with Verizon and Telefonica
summary: IBM has expanded its partnerships with Verizon and Telefonica, offering cloud and AI services to the telecom operators. The services include a 5G cloud platform to help build networks faster and reduce costs, as well as a virtual assistant to automate frequently asked questions and tasks. This move aims to position telecom operators as destinations for services like augmented reality and machine learning. No financial terms were disclosed for the partnerships, which broaden IBM's existing deals with the two firms.

site_title: UBS CEO sees Archegos hit as one-off, plays down job cuts
summary: UBS CEO Ralph Hamers views the $774 million revenue hit from Archegos' default as a "unique event" and not a systemic failure. He emphasizes that the bank has learned from the incident and will prioritize transparency. Hamers also downplays reports of job cuts, stating that the bank will maintain its employee count by creating new jobs in certain areas.

site_title: South Korea's Kakao Bank seeks as much as US$2.3b in IPO
summary: Kakao Bank, South Korea's internet-only lender backed by Kakao Corp, plans to raise up to $2.3 billion in its initial public offering. The bank will sell 65.45 million new shares at a price range of 33,000 won to 39,000 won apiece. If successful, Kakao Bank would become the third most valuable lender in Korea, with a market capitalization of over $16 billion.

site_title: Malaysia's May exports rise 47.3% on-year, below forecast
summary: Malaysia's exports rose 47.3% in May, below the forecasted 56.8% growth, driven by strong demand for electrical and electronic shipments, rubber goods, and petroleum products. Imports grew 50.3% year-over-year, narrower than the expected 50.1% increase. The trade surplus narrowed to RM13.7 billion in May from RM20.5 billion in April, missing the forecasted surplus of RM21.7 billion.

site_title: Billionaire boss Ivan Glasenberg makes one last coal deal in final days at Glencore
summary: Glencore Plc, under outgoing CEO Ivan Glasenberg, agreed to buy stakes in Colombia's Cerrejon thermal coal mine from BHP Group and Anglo American Plc for about $588 million. The deal expands Glencore's coal production, despite global efforts to reduce usage, and allows it to maintain control of the mine for another 30 years. Glencore has committed to cutting its emissions by 50% by 2035, and the deal aligns with its goal to be carbon neutral by 2050.

site_title: Australia: Shares end flat as Sydney lockdown disrupts travel
summary: Australia's shares ended flat on Monday as the country's lockdowns and rising COVID-19 cases weighed on travel and tourism stocks. The S&P/ASX 200 index remained steady at 7,307.3 points, despite online retailers seeing a rally in "stay-at-home" stocks. Qantas Airways, Webjet, and Flight Centre Travel Group fell 5% each, while e-commerce names like Temple & Webster and Kogan.com rose above 10% each.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end flat as virus cases spike across Asia
summary: South Korean stocks ended flat on Monday amid concerns over a spike in coronavirus cases across Asia. Investors refrained from making fresh bets ahead of economic data later this week. The benchmark Kospi closed 0.03% higher at 3,301.89, following a record close on Friday. The won weakened, and the benchmark bond yield rose, while Australia's Sydney plunged into a lockdown.

site_title: US shale industry tempers output even as oil price jumps
summary: US shale oil producers are maintaining production levels despite a surge in oil prices to nearly $75 a barrel, defying expectations of a drilling boom. The industry is prioritizing shareholder returns over volume, with output remaining below the January 2020 peak. Despite a US average production outlook increase to 11.08 million barrels per day, US shale output remains 200,000 barrels per day below last year's average, with the Opec+ producers group confident that US shale will not return to explosive growth.

site_title: Strong indications of growth in Asia-Pacific's business events industry
summary: A white paper by the Singapore Tourism Board, PCMA, and UFI suggests the Asia-Pacific business events industry is showing signs of recovery, with in-person events planned for 2021 and 2022, and expected revenues 106% higher than 2020. A survey found 63% of planners and 77% of suppliers valued attending physical events despite precautions, and 64% of Asian attendees planned to attend in-person events after digitally attending. The industry is expected to pivot to digital and hybrid events, with digital solutions cited as opportunities for growth.

site_title: South Korea raises growth forecast to 4.2% on record exports
summary: South Korea raised its economic forecast to 4.2% for 2021, driven by record exports and a rebound in consumption as vaccination levels rise. The country's GDP growth is expected to surpass its pre-pandemic size earlier this year, with shipments projected to jump 18.5% to an annual record of $607.5 billion. The government aims to use an extra budget to facilitate a consumption recovery, creating over 150,000 jobs and extending employment benefits. Inflation is expected to reach 1.8%, and growth and inflation are forecast to slow to 3% and 1.4% in 2022.

images.alt_text: South Korea raised its economic forecast for this year by a wide margin on expectations for record exports and a rebound in consumption as vaccination levels rise.

site_title: EH-Reit books US$324.7m in net proceeds from sale of non-auctioned assets
summary: EAGLE Hospitality Reit (EH-Reit) has sold its remaining nine non-auctioned Chapter 11 properties, generating US$324.7 million in net proceeds. This sale, part of a total of 14 properties, brings the aggregate net proceeds to US$478.6 million. The funds will be used to repay outstanding expenses and creditors, prioritizing post-petition and pre-petition creditors. The sale follows an earlier transaction in June that yielded US$153.9 million.

site_title: Singapore calls for retail CBDC solutions, partners IMF and World Bank
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has launched a Global CBDC Challenge, inviting fintech companies and financial institutions worldwide to propose innovative retail central bank digital currencies (CBDCs) solutions. The challenge focuses on improving digital payments, mitigating risks, and providing low-cost infrastructure for cross-border transactions. The MAS aims to encourage innovators to develop solutions that maximize the potential of CBDCs to deliver efficiencies in payment services and improve financial inclusion. Interested participants have until July 23 to submit their proposals, with winners set to be announced in November.

site_title: Quarz, Black Crane object to Sabana Reit manager's appointment of Chan Wai Kheong as independent non-exec director
summary: Quarz Capital and Black Crane Capital have objected to Sabana Reit manager's appointment of Chan Wai Kheong as an independent non-executive director, citing potential conflicts of interest due to his substantial holdings in Aims Apac Reit, a competitor of Sabana Reit. The two firms have proposed their own chief investment officers as alternatives. Sabana Reit's manager rejected their request for an extraordinary general meeting, stating that the reasons for the objection lacked grounds. The appointment is still subject to the endorsement of Sabana Reit's independent unitholders at the annual general meeting.

site_title: Lessons from a Singapore medtech leader
summary: Singapore's medtech sector has experienced significant growth, with medtech manufacturing output rising from S$2.4 billion to over S$15 billion in 15 years, and the number of employees soaring to over 16,000. CEO Abel Ang of Advanced MedTech credits his company's turnaround to taking risks, cutting distractions, and continuously learning and improving products to stay ahead of disruption. Ang emphasizes the importance of focus, decision-making, and adapting to change, saying "only the paranoid survive" in the rapidly evolving medtech industry.

site_title: Hong Kong home prices rise for fifth straight month in May
summary: Hong Kong's private home prices rose 0.6% in May for a fifth consecutive month, driven by a recovering economy and expectations of continued Chinese buying. The index has climbed 3.6% this year, close to its all-time high in May 2019. Property consultants predict home prices will break the record high in the third quarter and gain 5% in the second half. Developers are accelerating new launches, driving up transaction volume, with a recent project receiving 30,600 registrations of intent.

site_title: Thai economy seen back at pre-pandemic level in Q1, 2023
summary: Thailand's economy is expected to return to pre-pandemic levels in the first quarter of 2023, according to the central bank, amid a slow recovery in tourism due to a surge in coronavirus infections. The country is due to reopen Phuket to vaccinated foreign visitors in a pilot project, with forecasted 700,000 foreign tourists in 2021 and 10 million in 2022. The tourism sector is expected to normalize over the next two years, with the industry group predicting 25 million foreign visitors and $47 billion in revenue for 2022.

images.alt_text: Thailand's economy is expected to return to pre-pandemic levels in the first quarter of 2023, the central bank said on Monday, amid a slow recovery in tourism due to a surge in coronavirus infections.

site_title: All washed up: furloughed Londoner finds fortune in the Thames
summary: A 34-year-old Londoner, Flora Blathwayt, turned a hobby into a successful business after collecting plastic waste from the River Thames during the pandemic lockdowns. She created and sells thousands of greeting cards decorated with the retrieved plastic, which she found colorful and had no formal art training. Blathwayt sees her success as part of a wider movement towards creating businesses that minimize environmental impact, inspiring others to "reuse, upcycle, or make something from waste."

site_title: Gold hits one-week low on dollar bounce, mixed signals from Fed officials
summary: Gold prices fell to a one-week low on Monday, dropping 0.2% to $1,777.03 per ounce, due to a dollar bounce and mixed signals from the US Federal Reserve on monetary policy tightening. Despite tame inflation data, Fed officials' comments on the Fed's timeline for tapering monetary policy sent mixed signals, weighing on gold prices. The market is trading in a range, with gold expected to remain sideways until it breaks above $1,800 or below $1,760, according to analyst Kyle Rodda.

site_title: China state planner launches investigation into fertiliser market
summary: China's National Development and Reform Commission (NDRC) has launched an investigation into the urea market amid record prices. The probe aims to address price gains, hoarding, and fabricating information, with prices rising 9% in June to a record 2,674 yuan per tonne. The NDRC has previously launched market probes into coal and iron ore, following China's highest producer inflation in over 12 years. The investigation will strengthen market supervision and maintain stable prices for fertilisers and agricultural materials.

site_title: North Koreans 'heartbroken' over thinner Kim, state TV reports
summary: North Korean state TV reported that citizens were "heartbroken" upon seeing Kim Jong Un, who appeared dramatically thinner, after his recent return to public view. The 37-year-old leader has been the subject of health speculation due to his weight and smoking habits. His longest absence from the public eye was six weeks in 2014, and his health has been a topic of concern, particularly given his family's history of heart disease. The rare comments provide insight into the public's reaction to Kim's health, which is closely monitored by overseas agencies.

site_title: Thai May manufacturing output jumps 25.84% y-o-y, beating forecast
summary: Thailand's manufacturing production index (MPI) rose 25.84% in May, beating the forecast of a 19.55% increase. This marks the third consecutive month of growth, driven by higher production of automobiles, air conditioners, and electronics. The reading surpassed April's revised 17.97% increase.

site_title: Federal Reserve's Rosengren says US can't afford housing market 'boom and bust': FT
summary: US Federal Reserve Bank President Eric Rosengren stated that the US cannot afford a "boom and bust cycle" in the housing market, which could threaten financial stability. He emphasized the need for sustainable inflation targeting, citing the importance of avoiding a boom and bust cycle in real estate. Rosengren's comments come as the US housing market continues to experience fluctuations, with rising mortgage rates and record-breaking rent increases in cities like Manhattan.

site_title: China's automaker Great Wall aims to sell 4 million cars in 2025
summary: Great Wall Motor Co Ltd, China's top pickup truck maker, aims to sell 4 million vehicles in 2025, with 80% of annual sales expected to be new energy vehicles. The company targets 2.8 million car sales in 2023, expanding its production lineup to over 60 models. Great Wall plans to be carbon-neutral by 2045, earlier than China's target of 2060, and is building a car plant in China with BMW for electric vehicles. The company also plans to manufacture cars in Russia and Thailand.

site_title: European firms betting big on Vietnam, Malaysia and Thailand for growth: report
summary: European firms are betting big on Vietnam, Malaysia, and Thailand for growth, with 88% of polled companies expecting business to increase in the next 12 months. The top markets for expansion are Vietnam (60%), Malaysia (53%), and Thailand (48%). Key sectors expected to drive growth include pharmaceuticals production, European fast-moving consumer goods, automotive production and export, construction and engineering, renewable energy, and e-commerce. However, respondents cited regional regulations, payments, and infrastructure as significant medium-term barriers to growth.

site_title: SoftBank group plans dollar/euro bonds amid continued debt push
summary: SoftBank Group Corp plans to issue dollar/euro bonds, hiring banks for a potential sale of notes with tenors from three years to 12 years. This move comes after the company posted Japan's biggest-ever quarterly profit, driven by gains from investments. SoftBank has been the largest issuer in Japan's corporate bond market, raising over $72 billion. The company's decision to issue new bonds indicates it's continuing its debt push despite previously pricing Japan's largest corporate note sale of the year.

site_title: Australia will only open borders if it is safe: Treasurer
summary: Australian Treasurer Josh Frydenberg stated that the country will only open its international borders if it is safe to do so and based on medical advice. This decision comes after Australia shut its borders in March 2020 to contain the Covid-19 pandemic. Frydenberg made this announcement during the launch of the 2021 'Intergenerational Report', which projects an outlook for the economy and the Australian government's budget over the next 40 years.

images.alt_text: Australia shut its borders in March 2020 to help contain the Covid-19 pandemic, only allowing citizens to return with a 14-day mandatory hotel quarantine.

site_title: Brokers' take: KGI upgrades Hyphens Pharma to 'outperform' after Q1 comeback
summary: KGI Securities has upgraded its call on Catalist-listed Hyphens Pharma to 'outperform' with a higher target price of S$0.43, citing its strong Q1 FY2021 results and growing portfolio of high-margin proprietary brands. The analysts expect the group's segments, including medical hypermart, digital business, and e-commerce, to contribute to topline growth. However, they caution that H2 FY2021 may not replicate H1 FY2021 due to COVID-19 cases and operational difficulties.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed at opening after last week's gains
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Monday, following a record close on Wall Street, as investors took a breather after last week's rally. Despite upbeat sentiment on the global economy and a bipartisan US infrastructure deal, concerns about Federal Reserve monetary policy easing and inflation drove some losses. Shanghai, Singapore, and Taipei rose, while Tokyo, Seoul, and Manila experienced minor losses. Investors remain cautious, warning that inflation remains a worry, and the Fed may adjust interest rates in the coming months.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks to resume trading after morning storm halt
summary: Hong Kong stocks will resume trading on Monday afternoon after a rainstorm warning prompted a morning halt. The Hong Kong Observatory lowered the rainstorm warning to red, allowing trading to resume at 1:30pm. The cancellation of morning trading was the first since October 2020 due to tropical storm Nangka. Market analysts expect a stable trading session, with plenty of time to digest weekend news and A-share movements.

site_title: Mask-free and 'low risk', Italy welcomes milestone
summary: Italy has become the first European country to lift all coronavirus restrictions, making it a mask-free, "low-risk" zone. The country's health ministry classified each of its 20 regions as "white" under the country's colour-coded classification system, allowing facemasks to be removed in outdoor areas. This milestone marks a significant step forward in Italy's recovery from the pandemic, coinciding with an ongoing heatwave expected to push temperatures past 40 degrees Celsius.

site_title: Philippines' Voyager raises US$167m from KKR, Tencent, World Bank unit
summary: Philippines' Voyager Innovations, a digital and financial services firm, has raised US$167 million in funding from KKR, Tencent, and a unit of the World Bank's International Finance Corp. The company aims to expand its services, including digital banking, and serves 38 million Filipinos through its consumer platforms. Voyager's largest shareholder, PLDT, participated in the funding round.

site_title: Thin home supply in Downtown area may stir more interest for Marina View site, triggered at S$1.51b
summary: The 0.78-hectare Marina View site, with a 99-year leasehold tenure, is being sold by public tender for S$1.51 billion. Due to limited supply in the Core Central Region, the site is expected to attract "no more than five bidders" of consortiums, with developers setting up joint ventures to parcel out the risk. The site can generate up to 905 private homes, 540 hotel rooms, and 21,528 sq ft of commercial space. The expected bidding price could be S$1,550 - S$1,700 psf, with a selling price of S$2,500 - S$2,800 psf.

site_title: Hong Kong Exchanges delays open on Monday morning due to black rainstorm
summary: Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing delayed morning trading sessions on Monday due to a black rainstorm warning. If the warning is cancelled by midday, trading in securities and derivatives markets, including Stock Connect, will resume in the afternoon.

site_title: Euro 2020: Three key battles in England's clash with Germany
summary: England is set to face Germany in the Euro 2020 knockout stage, with the winner likely to reach the final. Key battles include Harry Kane's head-to-head with Antonio Ruediger, where Kane's scoreless streak at Euro 2020 continues to be a concern. England's John Stones will face Kai Havertz, who has been a threat to England's defense. Meanwhile, Jordan Pickford will face Manuel Neuer, with Pickford's recent form being a crucial factor in England's success in the tournament.

site_title: Australia: Tech, banks drag shares lower as states enter lockdown
summary: Australian shares fell 0.3% on Monday, weighed down by banking and technology stocks, amid tighter lockdown curbs following a record-high number of locally acquired coronavirus cases. The S&P/ASX 200 index dropped to 7,286 points, with technology stocks declining 2% and financial stocks falling 0.6%. Movement restrictions in Sydney and Darwin prompted declines in travel and tourism stocks, while energy stocks rose 0.6% on higher oil prices.

site_title: Japan's Suga says government on high alert as Tokyo cases rise
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga has warned that the government must be on high alert as Tokyo cases rise, about three weeks before the Olympics. The seven-day moving average of new virus infections in Tokyo has increased to 477, prompting concerns of a potential reintroduction of a state of emergency. Suga has expressed his willingness to adjust policies to address the situation. Meanwhile, Tokyo Governor Yuriko Koike's absence from public duties has sparked controversy over the Olympics, with a recent survey showing 58% of respondents opposing the games.

images.alt_text: Japanese Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga said the government must be on high alert as virus cases begin to rise in the capital, about three weeks before Tokyo hosts the Olympics.

site_title: Shanghai: Stocks open with gains
summary: China's mainland stocks rose at the start of Monday's trading, with the Shanghai Composite Index increasing 0.17% to 3,613.57, and the Shenzhen Composite Index rising 0.23% to 2,447.66. This follows a record close on Wall Street and growing optimism about the global recovery. Hong Kong's morning session was cancelled due to heavy storms.

site_title: Australia races to stem Delta variant as cases emerge nationwide
summary: Australia is racing to contain outbreaks of the highly contagious delta strain, with Sydney and Darwin under lockdown. The delta strain has forced 130 cases in Sydney, with 18 new infections reported, and has led to restrictions in other major cities. The country's "Covid-zero" strategy, relying on closed borders and testing, is being tested. Economists warn the slow vaccine rollout and localized outbreaks will keep the economy vulnerable, and tourism operators are feeling the impact. The government is under pressure to ramp up vaccine delivery, with a program hindered by community concerns over blood clots from the AstraZeneca shot.

site_title: UBS to let two-thirds of employees adopt permanent hybrid
summary: UBS Group will allow two-thirds of its employees to adopt a permanent hybrid work model, combining remote and office work, in an effort to be more competitive in recruitment. This move is led by CEO Ralph Hamers and will apply to roles suitable for hybrid working, while some positions, such as traders and branch staff, will require in-office work. The decision contrasts with US banks that have taken a more hardline approach, and UBS has no set date for returning to the office. This shift aims to provide staff flexibility and improve recruitment competitiveness.

site_title: How Singapore and Asia's tech sector can lead in renewable energy adoption
summary: Singapore's launch of the Singapore Green Plan 2030 aims to scale its net-zero ambitions, focusing on the tech sector's green transition. The government has imposed a moratorium on new data center construction, prompting ICT companies to adopt sustainable alternatives. ICT companies, with a significant presence in Asia, have the potential to accelerate renewable energy development in the region. With Asia accounting for 52% of global tech revenue growth, ICT companies can help drive the transition to clean energy. To achieve 100% renewable energy, ICT companies must develop flexible strategies, tap into innovative solutions, and advocate for change, such as importing renewable energy from other countries.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 12.53 points, or 0.8%, to 1,547.15 on Monday, with losers outnumbering gainers 507 to 76. The country's shares opened lower, with a total trading volume of 645.88 million lots worth RM266.52 million.

site_title: South Korean consortium to produce Russia's Sputnik Light vaccine
summary: A South Korean consortium, Huons Global, plans to start producing Russia's Sputnik Light Covid-19 vaccine in September. The move follows a request by the Russian Direct Investment Fund, which markets the vaccine. The company aims to boost production capacity and produce 30 million doses by the end of this year, in addition to 100 million doses of Sputnik V vaccine per month. This partnership is part of Russia's efforts to increase global vaccine production to meet rising demand.

site_title: Japfa to acquire two dairy farms to strengthen foothold in China
summary: Industrial agri-food company Japfa has agreed to acquire two dairy farms in Shandong, China, through its subsidiary AustAsia Investment Holdings for approximately US$123.4 million. The acquisition is expected to boost AustAsia's capacity and accelerate Japfa's expansion in China, taking advantage of the favourable raw milk price environment due to a supply shortage in the Chinese market. The transaction is expected to close on or about June 30, 2021, and will enable Japfa to become the leading independent raw milk supplier in China.

site_title: Ancient aromas aim to lure new crop of tourists to Cyprus
summary: Cyprus is cultivating ancient aromas such as lavender, basil, and roses to attract new tourists and regain its botanical status dating back to Roman times. In the village of Agros, family members Andria, Elena, and Maria tend to their rose bushes, gathering Damask roses for which Agros is famed. The initiative aims to broaden Cyprus' appeal and showcase its rich history and natural beauty.

site_title: iX Biopharma to commence supply of Xativa to Brazil
summary: iX Biopharma has obtained export listing status for its Xativa brand of medicinal cannabis wafers, allowing it to supply the product to Brazil and other international markets. The company, which currently supplies Xativa to Australian patients, believes the global market value for medicinal cannabis will surge from US$41.5 million in 2021 to US$103.5 million by 2024. This move follows iX Biopharma's expansion of wafer production capacity and comes as attitudes towards cannabis continue to shift globally, with several countries having legalized the drug in recent years.

site_title: BOJ was confident in June meeting of recovery as vaccination proceeds
summary: Bank of Japan policymakers expressed confidence in Japan's economic recovery due to accelerating vaccinations and a decline in new coronavirus cases. They saw no significant inflationary pressures, citing subdued demand and cellphone fee cuts. The BOJ kept monetary policy steady and announced a plan to boost funding for climate change by the end of the year. Policymakers expect a robust recovery driven by exports and domestic demand, without needing additional support.

site_title: Tesla dealt big blow as almost all cars in China need safety fix
summary: Tesla faces a major setback in China after the government ordered a recall of almost 285,000 vehicles due to a safety issue with the autopilot system. The recall affects locally produced Model 3 and Model Y vehicles, as well as imported Model Ys. The problem allows vehicles to accelerate suddenly, potentially leading to crashes. Tesla will upgrade the software for free and the fix can be made remotely. The recall adds to Tesla's struggles in China, where public opinion has soured after a viral protest and a spate of crashes.

site_title: Police checks and patriotic flowers: Beijing leaves nothing to chance ahead of Party centenary
summary: Beijing is intensifying security measures ahead of the 100th anniversary of China's Communist Party on July 1, with roadblocks, police checks, and patriotic flower arrangements. The city has also ramped up surveillance and restrictions, including banning the shipment of flammable products and censoring online commentary. The secretive rehearsals are part of a yearlong planning effort to glorify Party history and cement domestic loyalty. Local institutions will hold special events marking the anniversary, including political-education sessions and party history exhibitions, with the goal of promoting the Party's legitimacy and advancing its cause.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise at Monday's open; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.3% at Monday's open, tracking Wall Street gains, as monetary policy uncertainty eased. The Straits Times Index (STI) reached 3,130.45, with 108 gainers and 36 losers, in a 100.2 million securities trade worth S$52.6 million.

site_title: Living with Covid endemic in Singapore
summary: Singapore has shifted towards an endemic norm for COVID-19, allowing infected individuals to recover at home with mild symptoms, reducing the risk of transmission. With vaccination, massive contact tracing and quarantining will be minimized. The focus will be on monitoring severe cases, and safe management rules will be eased, allowing large gatherings and travel to countries with controlled outbreaks, with recognition of vaccination certificates.

site_title: Britain bans Binance's UK ops in latest cryptocurrency crackdown
summary: Britain's Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) has banned Binance's UK operations, citing that the cryptocurrency exchange's regulated entity, Binance Markets, cannot conduct any regulated activities without prior written consent. The FCA issued a warning to consumers, stating that Binance Markets must display a notice stating it is not permitted to undertake regulated activity in the UK. The move comes as the FCA steps up oversight of cryptocurrency trading, which has grown in popularity in Britain.

site_title: Queensland tightens Covid-19 curbs amid Australian outbreak
summary: Queensland, Australia reintroduced mandatory masks and limited home gatherings amid a growing Covid-19 outbreak, with more than 10 million Aussies under lockdown or restrictions. The highly contagious Delta variant has prompted the national security committee to hold an emergency meeting. Sydney and Darwin were placed under lockdown, and Western Australia also reintroduced masks and limited gatherings. Australia has seen just over 30,000 cases and 910 deaths, but the fast-moving Delta variant has alarmed health authorities. The country's swift contact tracing and lockdowns have helped suppress prior outbreaks.

site_title: Israel foreign minister tells Blinken of 'serious reservations' on Iran
summary: Israel's new Foreign Minister Yair Lapid expressed "serious reservations" about the Iran nuclear deal being discussed in Vienna, urging direct and professional conversations to address disagreements. Lapid also acknowledged past mistakes made by former Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's alliance with the US Republican Party, promising to correct them with US Secretary of State Antony Blinken. Lapid pledged a more cooperative approach with the US, seeking to improve relations and work together to address concerns.

site_title: Wild ride for top manager shows challenges in China stock bets
summary: Joy Young, a top-performing Chinese stock fund manager, has seen her portfolio experience significant volatility in 2021, with gains of up to 84% in April before halving and worsening to 31% by June 18. The challenges in China's stock market, driven by regulatory crackdowns and a slowdown in growth, have made it difficult for professional investors to achieve consistent returns. Young has shifted her focus to cyclical sectors and individual stocks, betting on rising demand from a potential global infrastructure boom, but faces ongoing risks and uncertainties.

site_title: CapitaLand to divest partial stakes in China projects to Ping An for 46.7b yuan; deal to yield net proceeds of over S$2b
summary: CapitaLand is divesting partial stakes in six Chinese Raffles City developments to Ping An Life Insurance for 46.7 billion yuan (S$9.6 billion), generating over S$2 billion in net proceeds. The deal allows CapitaLand to retain a 12.6-30% stake in each development, with plans to use the funds to support new-economy assets. Analysts see the deal as a positive move for CapitaLand, aligning with its strategy to rebalance its portfolio and increase return on equity.

images.alt_text: CapitaLand has entered into conditional agreements with Ping An Life Insurance Company of China to divest partial stakes in a group of companies that own six of its Raffles City developments in China, the group said on Monday.

site_title: Boeing 777X 'realistically' will not win certification approval before mid-2023: US FAA
summary: The US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has told Boeing that its 777X plane is not yet ready for certification and "realistically" will not be certified until mid- to late 2023. The FAA cited numerous concerns, including lack of data and a preliminary safety assessment, as reasons for the delay. Boeing has been developing the 777X since 2013 and had initially expected to release it for airline use in 2020. The FAA's warning comes after fatal crashes involving the 737 MAX led to accusations of cozy relations between Boeing and the FAA.

images.alt_text: The US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has told Boeing Co that its planned 777X is not yet ready for a significant certification step and warned it "realistically" will not certify the airplane until mid- to late 2023.

site_title: Death toll in Florida condo collapse climbs to 9, with 150 still missing
summary: A 12-story condominium complex in Surfside, Florida, partially collapsed on June 24, killing 9 people and leaving over 150 missing. The cause of the collapse is still unknown, but a 2018 engineer's report found major structural deterioration in the parking garage beneath the building. Rescue efforts continue with the aid of cranes, backhoes, and experts from Israel and Mexico. The Miami-Dade County plans to audit all buildings over 40 years old within the next 30 days to ensure their safety.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CapitaLand, iX Biopharma, Japfa, Sarine Tech, Ascott Residence Trust, OUELH, Keppel, SIA
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Several Singapore-listed companies saw new developments that may affect trading on Monday. CapitaLand entered into agreements to divest stakes in Chinese Raffles City developments for S$9.67 billion. iX Biopharma obtained export listing status for its medicinal cannabis wafer, Xativa, and plans to supply it to Brazil. Japfa agreed to buy two Chinese dairy farms. Sarine's dual listing application on the Tel Aviv Stock Exchange was approved. Keppel sold its 20.05% stake in a Thai company for S$2.6 million. Singapore Airlines launched a voluntary carbon offset program.

site_title: Friction emerges in North America one year into trade deal
summary: The US-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) has failed to eliminate trading friction between North American allies one year after its implementation. Disputes have arisen, with the US objecting to Mexican and Canadian practices, and Canada seeking its own dispute settlement panel over US tariffs on solar panels. Despite these challenges, experts credit the deal with removing uncertainty and creating a better atmosphere for trade and investment. The US and Canada have ongoing disputes, including those related to dairy and softwood lumber industries, while Mexico hopes to see labor legislation improvements in the future.

site_title: Thailand announces new Covid-19 restrictions in Bangkok, other provinces
summary: Thailand has announced new COVID-19 restrictions in Bangkok and five surrounding provinces, effective for 30 days. The measures include banning restaurant dine-ins, closing shopping malls by 9pm, and shutting down construction sites to contain clusters. Authorities will set up checkpoints to limit travel and relocation of construction workers. The restrictions aim to tackle Thailand's worst coronavirus outbreak, following the emergence of more clusters in construction camps in the capital. Prime Minister Prayut Chan-o-cha emphasized targeting specific businesses and activities to contain the virus.

site_title: US Republicans Senate negotiators ready to move forward on infrastructure deal
summary: US Senate negotiators on an infrastructure deal are optimistic after President Joe Biden withdrew his threat to veto the measure unless a separate Democratic spending plan passes Congress. Republican Senator Rob Portman said Biden's comments were "blindsided" and clarified his remarks, allowing the bipartisan bill to move forward. At least 16 Republicans, including 11 who initially endorsed the deal, are expected to support the $1.2 trillion bipartisan bill. The White House adviser, Cedric Richmond, stated that Democrats expect to get both bills to the president's desk without conditions.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Monday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Monday, with the Nikkei 225 index up 0.18% at 29,118.06 and the Topix index advancing 0.32% to 1,968.91. The gains followed a mixed close on Wall Street, as investors await fresh market-moving events.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Monday in cautious trade following a mixed close on Wall Street, with investors awaiting fresh market-moving events.

site_title: Hong Kong police arrest former Apple Daily journalist at airport
summary: Hong Kong police arrested Fung Wai-kong, a 57-year-old former Apple Daily journalist, at the international airport on a suspected national security charge. He is the seventh staffer from the pro-democracy Apple Daily newspaper to be arrested on national security grounds in recent weeks. Fung was accused of conspiring to collude with foreign countries or forces to endanger national security. The arrest marks the latest crackdown on media freedom in Hong Kong.

site_title: Dawn of 'Roaring Twenties' as Dubai's luxury home sales soar
summary: Dubai's luxury home sales have surged, with 22 homes worth over $10 million sold in the first five months of the year, the most since 2015. This rebound is attributed to the emirate's post-pandemic economic recovery, particularly in the tourism sector. The "Roaring Twenties" trend is being echoed globally, with Dubai's super-prime market mirroring a wider trend. However, the city's real estate sector still faces challenges, including a property glut and ongoing debt restructuring issues.

site_title: Shadow lenders pile into US energy debt after bank retreat
summary: Shadow lenders, including major funds like Oaktree Capital Management and Elliott Investment Management, are rushing into the US energy debt market, filling the gap left by banks that have retreated from lending due to mounting losses and pressure to address environmental concerns. The trend began with Callon Petroleum's $300 million secured debt deal last autumn, which was backed by an alternative lender. Alternative lenders are offering flexible terms, including second-lien capital at interest rates of 9-12%, to capitalize on the sector's perceived mispricing.

site_title: Unissued gold coin sold for record US$18.87m
summary: A 1933 US Double Eagle gold coin, the last coin intended for circulation, sold for a record $18.87 million at a Sotheby's auction in New York. Designed by Augustus Saint-Gaudens, it features Lady Liberty and an American eagle. The coin was originally intended for circulation but was never issued after Franklin Roosevelt removed the US from the gold standard. It had been the subject of a Secret Service investigation and several legal battles over ownership, with the current sale being the first allowed under a 2002 court decision.

site_title: Girding up for adaptive living
summary: Cities must adapt to future shocks by combining new technologies, citizen-centric solutions, and data-driven governance. Leveraging cutting-edge technologies and fostering collaboration across private and public sectors is crucial for building resilient, responsive, and responsible cities. Experts emphasize the need for cities to prioritize sustainability, biodiversity, and climate change resilience, while also enhancing agility, adaptability, and digital readiness. Cities should focus on creating multimodal hubs, self-sustaining in food, product production, and local leisure, and adopt flexible, innovative approaches to urban design and planning.

site_title: Euro 2020: Belgium knock out Ronaldo and Portugal, Czechs end Dutch dreams
summary: Belgium knocked out Portugal 1-0 in the Euro 2020 tournament, with Thorgan Hazard scoring the only goal before half-time. The Czech Republic then ended the Netherlands' dreams with a 10-man side, also securing a 1-0 victory. The highly anticipated match between Portugal, the reigning champions, and Belgium's top-ranked team did not live up to expectations, with Portugal unable to recover from Hazard's goal. Belgium holds on for a 1-0 victory, advancing in the tournament.

site_title: Shut off from the world, Australia fosters red-hot growth at home
summary: Australia's economy is experiencing a "triple boom" in mining, housing, and corporate profitability, driven by a swift recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic. The country's unemployment rate has dropped to 5.1%, and consumer and business confidence are high, with exports booming due to soaring iron ore prices and new markets in Asia and the Middle East. The economy has grown larger than its pre-pandemic level, with record-high home building approvals and consumer spending. However, the country's border restrictions are limiting skilled migration and labor supply, leading to shortages in key sectors.

images.alt_text: A year after the coronavirus pandemic pummelled Australia's economy, IT contractor Ashok Ravindran has a nice problem: deciding which of three job offers to accept.

site_title: China investors shifting from blue-chip bets to 'small giants' in hunt for big returns
summary: China investors are shifting from blue-chip stocks to small-cap growth shares in pursuit of higher returns. The tech-heavy ChiNext Index has gained 6.6% and the Star Board 50 Index has risen 15%, while the MSCI gauge of small-cap growth stocks has increased 6%. This shift contrasts with the economically sensitive value share equivalent, which is down 5%. The trend suggests investors are looking for growth opportunities in smaller companies.

site_title: Delfi adapts its chocolates to modern tastes
summary: Delfi Ltd, a chocolate confectionery manufacturer, is adapting its products to cater to modern tastes in South-east Asia. The company is focusing on healthier chocolates, novelty products, and sustainable business practices. Delfi is leveraging its Van Houten brand to market new, healthier products and has introduced novelty products such as chocolates coupled with collectible items. The company is also exploring ways to reduce plastic packaging and has managed to reduce its palm oil use. Delfi's share price has risen 36.4% this year, driven by the company's efforts to adapt to changing consumer behavior.

images.alt_text: Mr Chuang says healthier chocolates, novelty products and more sustainable business practices are just a few of the areas Delfi is working on to cater to the modern consumer.

site_title: Macron rolls out red carpet to JPMorgan, global CEOs in post-Brexit push
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron is hosting a "Choose France" summit, where he aims to attract international CEOs, including JPMorgan's Jamie Dimon, to relocate from post-Brexit Britain. The US bank's new trading hub in Paris will create jobs and boost the French economy. Macron hopes to showcase France as a major financial destination, following the UK's exit from the EU. The summit and hub inauguration are seen as a post-Brexit push to revive France's global financial standing.

images.alt_text: President Emmanuel Macron will declare that Paris is back on the map of global finance on Tuesday when he inaugurates JPMorgan's new trading hub in the French capital which he hopes will attract more bankers leaving post-Brexit Britain.

site_title: At Ming Hing, robots whip up fried rice at a press of a button
summary: Ming Hing Food, a Singaporean F&B company, has successfully integrated robots into its operations, reducing the need for skilled chefs and alleviating labor shortages in the industry. The company uses "robot rice cookers" programmed with smart cards to serve a variety of fried rice dishes, with a focus on quality consistency. By automating cooking tasks, Ming Hing has achieved cost savings and created job opportunities for senior citizens, with most staff members aged 58-64. The company's use of technology has helped it overcome the labor crunch and continue to grow despite the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Good occupancy for industrial, data centre S-Reits
summary: Singapore's Reit sector saw a slight dip in average occupancy rates, from 96% in 2020 to 95% in 2021, mainly due to pandemic-hit segments like retail and office Reits. However, industrial and data centre Reits experienced year-on-year growth, with occupancy rates increasing by 1.4% and 3.1% respectively. Reits like AIMS Apac Reit, Keppel DC Reit, and Mapletree Industrial Trust saw significant improvements in occupancy rates, driven by structural trends like work-from-home and e-commerce.

site_title: From a great height: Tokyo sky decks offer fresh perspective
summary: Tokyo's sky-high observation decks, such as the Tokyo Skytree, offer a unique perspective on the city's sprawling landscape. The two decks at Tokyo Skytree attracted an average of 4.5 million visitors annually before the pandemic. These elevated views provide a fresh perspective on the city's seemingly endless sprawl, making them a popular tourist attraction in Japan.

site_title: BT launches new vertical, Global Enterprise
summary: The Business Times (BT) has launched a new portal called Global Enterprise, catering to Singapore-based businesses seeking to expand overseas. The portal offers current news, expert insights, and analysis on key topics such as the Asia-Pacific region, travel bubbles, office space, and global minimum corporate tax. BT aims to support businesses navigating the post-pandemic landscape, with full access to Global Enterprise available to subscribers. The portal will provide in-depth coverage of global issues and their impact on businesses, playing a key role in their expansion journey.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Myanmar violence escalates with rise of 'self-defence' groups: report
summary: Violence in post-coup Myanmar has escalated with the rise of "self-defence" groups, a report warned. Since the February coup, over 880 people have been killed in a junta crackdown on dissent. Locals, often armed with homemade or hunting rifles, have formed "defence forces" to fight back. The report predicts an "enormous" human cost if the regime uses its full power in subsequent crackdowns, amid ongoing turmoil in the country.

images.alt_text: Myanmar has been in turmoil since the February coup that ousted Aung San Suu Kyi's government, with more than 880 killed in a junta crackdown on dissent, according to a local monitoring group.

site_title: CGH cluster grows to 10 cases, including NUH porter
summary: A Covid-19 community cluster at Changi General Hospital (CGH) has grown to 10 cases, including a National University Hospital (NUH) porter. Five of the cases linked to the cluster are community cases, with the remaining five being healthcare workers at CGH. The cases are believed to have originated from a single source, but the exact cause remains under investigation. The Singapore government is taking measures to contain the outbreak, but no specific actions have been mentioned in the article.

site_title: Travel agency Nam Ho explores new businesses
summary: Nam Ho Travel, a Singapore-based travel agency, has diversified its business to reduce cash burn during the COVID-19 pandemic. The company has launched logistics and warehousing, e-commerce, hawker food delivery, and school bus transport ventures, which now cover 60-70% of business costs. These new ventures have generated significant revenue, with the e-commerce site "Buy Beyond Borders" earning almost S$400,000 in sales since its launch. The company aims to break even by the end of this year or early next year, thanks to its diversified business strategy.

site_title: 'Heat dome' in western US, Canada brings scorching temperatures
summary: A "heat dome" over western Canada and the US Pacific northwest brought scorching temperatures, triggering heat warnings. Temperatures soared to new highs, with over 40 new records in British Columbia and expected to continue breaking records throughout the week. Environment Canada issued alerts for several provinces, warning of a "prolonged, dangerous, and historic heat wave" with temperatures 10-15°C hotter than normal. Wildfire risks are elevated, and cities opened emergency cooling centers. The highest temperature ever recorded in Canada could be broken in the coming days.

images.alt_text: A "heat dome" over western Canada and the US Pacific northwest sent temperatures soaring to new highs, triggering heat warnings from Oregon to Canada's Arctic territories on Sunday.

site_title: Big Tech wants drivers' eyes on screens instead of on the road
summary: Big Tech companies like Apple and Google are pushing to have drivers' eyes on screens while driving, despite the risks. They aim to defend their valuable turf in the self-driving market, projected to reach $2 trillion by 2030. The tech industry has a higher operating margin of 34% compared to the automotive industry's 5.2% in 2020. By keeping drivers focused on screens, these companies can potentially increase their market share and revenue. However, this approach raises concerns about driver safety and attention.

site_title: Strong opening for Fast & Furious suggests movie crowd is back
summary: The box office is showing signs of recovery, with Universal Pictures' "F9: The Fast Saga" and Paramount's "A Quiet Place 2" performing well after reopening theatres. "F9" is expected to earn $68 million on 4,179 screens, within the range of previous iterations of the franchise. Internationally, the film has already earned over $300 million, with most ticket sales coming from China. The success of these movies vindicates Universal Pictures' decision to delay their releases during the pandemic, with chair Donna Langley stating it was a "really great decision."

site_title: Sydney put into two-week hard lockdown: state premier
summary: Sydney, Australia's largest city, has entered a two-week hard lockdown due to a fast-spreading outbreak of the highly infectious Delta coronavirus variant. The lockdown affects over a million people in downtown Sydney and surrounding regions, including the Blue Mountains, Central Coast, and Wollongong. This is the latest in a series of short but hard lockdowns imposed in Australian cities to combat the coronavirus. The lockdown is aimed at containing the outbreak and will last for two weeks, with further updates to be provided by authorities.

site_title: Medtecs CEO ups stake; Venture continues buybacks
summary: Medtecs CEO William Yang Weiyuan acquired 500,000 shares of Medtecs International Corporation for S$420,272, increasing his deemed interest to 0.46%. In other news, institutions were net sellers of S$332 million, led by OCBC's S$127 million outflow. Share buybacks totaled S$4,553,547, with Venture Corporation buying 90,200 shares at S$18.43 per share. Director and substantial shareholder transactions also occurred, including Pan Asian Holdings' sale of 56 million shares to Sylvester Lim Wei Zhi and Uni-Asia Group's Ham Yong Kwan increasing his direct interest to 8.36%.

site_title: US investors chasing housing returns target massive pools of Airbnb rentals
summary: US investors are seeking to acquire massive pools of short-term rentals on Airbnb, driven by a post-pandemic travel boom and the desire for better returns than from hotels or apartment buildings. Firms like ReAlpha plan to spend up to $1.5 billion to buy 5,000 homes, with the goal of offering a consumer experience similar to a hotel stay. This shift comes amid record-low home inventory, which is pushing prices higher for average buyers and investors alike.

site_title: Dollar steady after US inflation data misses estimates
summary: The US dollar remained steady on Friday after producer price inflation data missed estimates, with the core PCE price index increasing 3.4% in the 12 months through May, the largest gain since April 1992. Consumer spending held steady, and economists believe the Federal Reserve may hold off on acting to curb inflation. The dollar index ended unchanged at 91.838, while the British pound fell 0.33% to US$1.3875, and the Japanese yen remained steady at 110.83.

site_title: Berlin may have to buy out landlords amid tenant ire
summary: Berlin's local government may be forced to buy out large landlords like Vonovia after activists collected over 343,000 signatures for a referendum, exceeding the required 175,000 threshold. The movement aims to expropriate housing corporations with over 3,000 apartments, citing a shortage of affordable housing in the city. Vonovia, Berlin's largest landlord, has offered to sell 20,000 apartments and build 13,000 new units, but activists argue this won't solve the shortage. A referendum, if certified, would be held on September 26.

site_title: Cathay Pacific sees lower H2 monthly cash burn
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways expects to reduce its monthly cash burn to less than HK$1 billion (S$173 million) in the second half of the year due to easing crew quarantine restrictions and rising capacity. The airline had been burning up to HK$1.9 billion of cash per month in the first half. By August, Cathay aims to increase capacity to 20% of pre-Covid levels, and by the fourth quarter, to 30%, driven by Chinese students returning to the US and Britain for studies.

site_title: Private-car hire drivers surge by over 10,000 as pandemic pushes gig, contract workers to 228,000
summary: The number of private-car hire drivers in Singapore surged by over 10,000 in 2020, reaching 34,400, with 70% of them being non-tertiary educated and 57% aged 50 and over. This represents a 10,700 increase from 2019. The rise in gig workers, including own-account workers, is attributed to the Covid-19 pandemic, with nearly half of Singapore respondents in a survey expressing interest in contract work. Analysts believe the trend may be here to stay, driven by demand for flexibility and freedom.

site_title: Peak support from central banks marks new phase for global recovery
summary: Multiple central banks, including the US Federal Reserve, UK, Canada, and others, are planning to withdraw emergency stimulus, marking a new phase in the global recovery. The move is expected to be slow due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, but economists predict a gradual rise in interest rates, averaging 1.28% by the end of the year. The shift in policy could test the global recovery and markets, with too-fast or too-slow moves risking investor confidence and inflation.

site_title: Singapore, UK launch negotiations on digital economy agreement
summary: Singapore and the UK have launched negotiations on a bilateral digital economy agreement (UKSDEA) to facilitate digital trade and business between the two countries. The agreement aims to establish forward-looking rules for trusted cross-border data flows, prohibit data localisation, and ensure high standards in data protection. The UKSDEA will also promote interoperable digital systems, connect innovation ecosystems, and explore emerging technologies like artificial intelligence. The agreement is seen as a key step in enhancing region-to-region digital connectivity and unlocking new opportunities for businesses.

site_title: MC Payment refutes claims in third statement from controlling shareholder
summary: MC Payment, a Singaporean company, has released its third statement refuting claims made by controlling shareholder Ching Chiat Kwong. Mr. Ching alleged that the company's board and nominating committee made untrue statements about him and others. MC Payment denies these claims, stating that the nominating committee's report was focused on the lack of full disclosure about Pindan Group's financial difficulties, not disclosure requirements. The company also defended its decision to redact paragraphs from Mr. Ching's statements. MC Payment's shares have fallen 7.8% in the past two days.

site_title: Seoul Garden Group goes full steam ahead to digitalise
summary: Seoul Garden Group, a Korean restaurant chain, accelerated its five-year digital transformation roadmap to be completed in just two years amid the pandemic. The company set up an e-commerce business in seven days and has since focused on online sales. This shift is part of the broader trend of digitalization in the business world, where companies are turning to online channels to reduce operating costs and increase sales.

site_title: Copper retracement or reversal?
summary: Copper prices have retreated 17% from their all-time high, driven by the Chinese government's plan to sell strategic reserves and curb inflation. The commodity's price surge, 148% from March 2020, has raised concerns about unintended inflationary effects on economies worldwide. The US is scrambling to adjust monetary policies to balance economic recovery with inflation control, while technical indicators suggest further downside potential for copper prices, with support levels at $3.8490/pound and $2.8345/pound.

site_title: Digitalisation seen as key to Great Eastern's growth
summary: Great Eastern (GE) has invested over S$100m in digital initiatives since 2018, strengthening online engagement, data analytics, and cybersecurity. The company has seen significant growth, with total weighted new sales rising 28% to S$383m in the first quarter of this year and profit attributable to shareholders reaching S$437.6m. GE has also recruited 1,200 advisers, boosting its sales force to 5,100. The company aims to continue investing in digital capabilities and transform itself "inside-out" to prioritize customer needs, while also focusing on sustainability and retraining staff to meet growing business needs.

images.alt_text: Group chief executive Khor Hock Seng is seeking to transform GE "inside-out'' so that even as digital "touchpoints'' increase, the customer remains at the centre of its proposition.

site_title: Living room practice table is Thai's last stop on long road to Tokyo
summary: Thai table tennis star Orawan Paranang, 24, is preparing for the Tokyo Olympics after securing her spot in the games with a victory in the South-east Asia regional qualifiers in Qatar. Orawan, who was once told she was too short to play, has come a long way from her poverty-stricken rural upbringing in north-east Thailand. With a world ranking of 88, she faces stiff competition from China, but aims to reach the final rounds and give a good account of herself.

site_title: Malaysia to extend lockdown, boost Covid aid: Muhyiddin
summary: Malaysia's nationwide lockdown will be extended due to high new Covid-19 infections, with daily cases above 4,000. The lockdown will remain in place until the daily caseload falls below 4,000. The government will also announce additional aid programs and relax one lockdown measure, allowing eateries to operate longer hours starting Monday. The extended lockdown will further impact Malaysia's economy, which is expected to bounce back only in the last three months of the year, with the World Bank slashing its growth forecast to 4.5% from 6%.

site_title: Global IPO market never hotter than it is right now
summary: The global IPO market has reached an all-time high, with $349.8 billion raised in the first six months of 2021, surpassing the previous peak of $282 billion in 2020. Companies such as renewable-energy firms and online retailers are entering the market, while tech companies continue to dominate. The boom has been fueled by central banks' cash injections and individual investors' appetite for growth. However, investors are becoming more selective, and some high-profile stocks have stumbled in their trading debuts, leading to concerns about market saturation and regulatory scrutiny.

site_title: Keeping the nightlife lights on at ABV Riverside
summary: Singaporean pub owner Yvonne Yeo adapted to the COVID-19 pandemic by pivoting to a food delivery firm, OTD, in 2020. Despite not having a kitchen, Yeo's pub, now called ABV Riverside, is generating enough income to pay off its rental. Yeo expects the nightlife industry to return, with more pubs revamping as bistros, offering a variety of food and drinks. She believes the industry will come back stronger, with operators taking on new experiences and ideas. Yeo's resilience is a testament to the adaptability of small businesses in the face of adversity.

images.alt_text: ABV Riverside, a former pub, now bistro. Owner Yvonne Yeo closed four of her five pubs last year and set up a logistics company called OTD to pay her bills and retain the remaining nightlife business - her first outlet when she started out nine years ago.

site_title: Robot tech lures new clients, staff, day-drinkers to Ratio Inc
summary: Singaporean robotics and automation startup ROSS Digital has leased out all its available robot arms to clients, including Kaffe & Toast and Singapura Club, amidst the manpower crunch in the food and beverage sector. Ratio Inc, a cafe and lounge outlet under ROSS Digital, has seen sales trend upwards since its opening in November 2020, with a focus on human-robot collaboration. The company plans to open six more outlets in the next six months, with a goal of providing customers with a good experience through human interaction and automation.

site_title: Rescuers search around the clock for survivors of Florida building collapse
summary: A 12-story oceanfront apartment building in Surfside, Florida, partially collapsed on Friday, leaving four confirmed dead and 159 unaccounted for. Rescue teams are searching the rubble around the clock, guided by sound, and are working to confirm the identities of the victims. The cause of the collapse remains unclear, with officials citing a study showing signs of land subsidence in the mid-1990s. Experts say it will take time to determine the cause and simulate scenarios to pinpoint how the collapse occurred, with the state's governor calling for a full investigation.

site_title: Booster may be needed for J&J shot as Delta variant spreads, some experts already taking them
summary: US infectious disease experts are weighing the need for booster shots of the Pfizer/BioNTech or Moderna mRNA-based vaccines for Americans who received Johnson & Johnson's one-dose vaccine due to the spreading Delta coronavirus variant. Some experts, including former senior pandemic advisor Andy Slavitt and Stanford professor Dr. Michael Lin, argue that the J&J shot is less protective against the variant and suggest boosters to prevent severe outcomes. The CDC is not recommending boosters, but experts advise Americans to discuss the possibility with their doctors.

site_title: US FDA adds warning about rare heart inflammation to Pfizer, Moderna Covid-19 vaccines
summary: The US FDA has added a warning to Pfizer and Moderna Covid-19 vaccine fact sheets about a rare risk of heart inflammation, specifically myocarditis and pericarditis, particularly after the second dose. Over 1,200 cases have been reported, mostly in males under 30, with 309 hospitalizations. This update follows an FDA review and CDC's Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices meeting.
