summary: Singapore Pools, a company established in 1968, has a corporate culture of giving and doing good through its iShine Community Programme. The initiative, formed in 2003, fosters volunteerism among staff, with each employee given two days of leave for volunteering. In FY2020/21, the company's staff volunteerism rate reached a record high of 70%, with over 10,900 volunteering hours logged. The iShine Programme has led to collaborations with various organizations, including government agencies and non-profit groups, resulting in over S$1 million disbursed to the community.

site_title: Euro 2020: Germany relish facing England in last 16
summary: Germany, eliminated from Group F in Euro 2020, advanced to the last 16 after a 2-2 draw with Hungary, with Leon Goretzka scoring the equalizing goal in the 86th minute. The team will face England at Wembley Stadium next Tuesday, where they will look to avenge their 1996 Euro semi-final defeat. Germany goalkeeper Manuel Neuer expressed confidence in the team, stating they want to go further and that Wembley suits them, while coach Joachim Loew vowed to improve against England.

site_title: Kamala Harris: Her thankless job, and can she succeed Biden?
summary: Kamala Harris, the first African American, Indian American, and third woman to be chosen as a vice-presidential nominee for a major party ticket, faces numerous challenges in her role as Vice President under President Biden. Despite being tasked with handling the growing humanitarian crisis at the US-Mexico border, Harris' comments during her first foreign trip to Guatemala drew criticism from left-leaning lawmakers and critics alike. Harris' supporters had hoped she would play an activist role, but her duties as a tie-breaker in the Senate and her limited visibility on key issues have raised concerns about her effectiveness.

site_title: Oil climbs to highest in over two years as US supplies tighten
summary: Oil prices surged to their highest in over two years, with Brent climbing above $76 a barrel, after US crude inventories declined by 7.6 million barrels to 459.1 million barrels. Travel and petrol demand increased, driving upward pressure on prices. Analysts attribute the rise to easing coronavirus restrictions and supply cuts by Opec+. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec+) is expected to discuss production further at its meeting next week, potentially leading to prices reaching $100 a barrel for the first time since 2014.

site_title: Unliveable Sydney homes going for millions in Australia housing boom
summary: In Australia's A$8.3 trillion housing market, homes in dire condition are selling for millions of dollars. A derelict brick cottage in Sydney's northwest sold for A$1.6 million, and an abandoned house in Sydney's southeast sold for A$4.7 million. Buyers are willing to pay a premium for uninhabitable homes to tear down and rebuild. The market's surge is driven by record low borrowing rates, tax incentives, and solid employment growth, with property agents expecting more sales of distressed properties.

site_title: Calvin Klein owner to sell Van Heusen, Arrow brand trademarks
summary: PVH Corp will sell its Izod, Van Heusen, Arrow, and Geoffrey Beene trademarks to Authentic Brands Group for approximately $220 million. The deal includes the sale of intellectual property and other assets from PVH's heritage brands segment. PVH will retain ownership of intimates and underwear businesses, as well as dress shirts and neckwear segments. The company cut its annual sales forecast, now expecting 22-24% growth, despite the sale.

site_title: Hong Kong pro-democracy tabloid Apple Daily to print final edition on Thursday
summary: Hong Kong's pro-democracy tabloid Apple Daily will print its final edition on Thursday, following a year of raids by police and arrests under the national security law. The closure has raised alarm over media freedom and rights in the Chinese-ruled city, with critics denouncing the action as attempts to silence a champion of democracy. The tabloid's owner, Jimmy Lai, has been in jail since December on charges related to pro-democracy protests, and the paper's closure has been condemned by rights groups, media organizations, and Western governments.

site_title: Buffett exits as Gates Foundation trustee, sidestepping rift
summary: Warren Buffett, 90, has resigned as a trustee at the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation amid the charity's upheaval following the divorce of its namesake founders. Buffett, who contributed nearly $33 billion to the charity, cited his "100% in sync" goals with the foundation and a desire to give away his Berkshire Hathaway shares. The move comes as Buffett faces criticism over low tax rates among ultra-wealthy individuals, including himself. His resignation marks a shift in the partnership with Bill Gates, who will now serve as a tie-breaker in the divorce.

site_title: Group led by Daniel Teo buys Mount Rosie bungalow for S$43.8m
summary: A group led by Daniel Teo of Hong How Group is purchasing a Mount Rosie bungalow in Singapore for S$43.8 million to redevelop into landed homes. The property, located near Barker Road, is being sold by the sons of Pacific International Lines' founding chairman, YC Chang. The transaction marks a significant investment in the Singapore property market.

site_title: Tech giants risk fresh tumult as Congress hefts antitrust hammer
summary: US Congress is set to consider legislation aimed at reining in the power of tech giants Apple, Facebook, Google, and Amazon, with six bills targeting their dominance over markets. The bills, the result of a 16-month investigation, seek to address the companies' market control. This bipartisan push is the first significant attempt to limit the power of internet platforms. The Judiciary Committee will take up the bills, but it's unclear if they will become law. The measures aim to address the tech giants' influence over markets and consumer data.

site_title: Europe: Inflation fears keep stocks below record highs
summary: Europe's stock market fell 0.7% on Wednesday, despite data showing a 15-year high in euro zone business growth in June, due to inflation concerns. Luxury goods makers Kering and Hermes tumbled after a ratings downgrade from HSBC, while retail index fell 1.3%. Economists say the strong economic rebound is coming alongside price pressures, overshadowing the data.

images.alt_text: European stocks remained below record highs on Wednesday as inflation worries overshadowed data showing a rise in June business activity, while shares in French luxury goods makers tumbled on the back of a ratings downgrade from HSBC.

site_title: HSBC apology shows financial fears are mounting in Hong Kong
summary: HSBC apologized to Hong Kong customers after an update to its online and mobile banking terms sparked fears over overseas access to its services. The update, set to take effect in July, stated that customers may not be able to use online or mobile banking outside of Hong Kong. The bank reassured customers that there were no changes and that services would remain accessible. The incident highlights growing concerns in Hong Kong over China's tightening grip and the city's increasingly fraught political environment, with thousands of residents leaving for the UK and other countries.

site_title: Much ado about Modern Monetary Theory
summary: Singapore is exploring opportunities in sustainable aviation, with a new centre set up to advance the sector in the Asia-Pacific region. The country is also poised to become a global hub for advanced chip packaging, according to a study. In other news, the government is promoting Modern Monetary Theory (MMT) and is providing support for businesses affected by tariffs, with a new grant of up to S$100,000. The government is also urging graduates to plan for their future careers, with early data showing better employment rates.

site_title: Software firm Sprinklr raises US$266m in downsized IPO
summary: Sprinklr, a customer experience software firm, raised $266 million in its downsized initial public offering (IPO), pricing 16.6 million shares at $16 each. The company's market value is approximately $4 billion, down from its last valuation of $2.7 billion. Sprinklr's revenue grew to $387 million, while it incurred a net loss of $41 million. The offering was led by Morgan Stanley, JPMorgan Chase & Co, Barclays Plc, and Wells Fargo & Co, with the shares expected to begin trading on the New York Stock Exchange on Wednesday.

site_title: Central banks will act if inflation accelerates: analysts
summary: Central bankers are warning of potential interest rate hikes to curb inflation, which has accelerated globally due to supply shortages and shipping delays. Despite this, US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell believes inflation is temporary, while Harvard professor Larry Summers and others argue it could take off due to excessive monetary policy and government spending. Economists disagree on the severity of the inflation threat, with some predicting a minor surge and others warning of a more significant crisis. Central bankers' warnings have caused a minor US dollar rally and a slump in commodity prices, but financial markets remain optimistic about the short-term outlook.

site_title: Genting's new Vegas resort is a US$4.3b bet on city's comeback
summary: Genting Group has opened its new US$4.3 billion Resorts World Las Vegas resort on the Las Vegas Strip, marking a significant comeback for the city's gaming industry after a three-month coronavirus closure. The 3,500-room property features a 5,000-seat theatre with Celine Dion's residency, a 100,000-square-foot LED screen, and various luxury amenities. Genting aims to attract Asian gamblers with a broader theme, and the resort's marketing slogan "Stay Fabulous" reflects its focus on luxury. A successful launch could inspire other operators to build new resorts on the Strip, with Genting potentially selling shares in a US subsidiary if it achieves critical mass.

site_title: MC Payment's board must do better at explaining disagreements with Ching
summary: MC Payment's board has fallen out with controlling shareholder Ching Chiat Kwong, who has expressed "completely lost confidence" in the current board. Ching has made two requisitions, including nominating new directors and removing existing directors, including CEO Anthony Koh. The board has responded that it wishes to remain "above the fray" and not engage in private disputes. Shareholders may be interested in knowing why the board is reluctant to address Ching's concerns, particularly regarding a proposed acquisition of NGSC, an investment holding company with subsidiaries in China and Indonesia.

site_title: Malaysia's fight against the pandemic is at the crossroads
summary: Malaysia is at a critical juncture in its fight against COVID-19, with the country's unpredictable political climate posing a challenge to effective management. Despite efforts to ramp up vaccination rates, with over 200,000 jabs administered daily, the pandemic remains stubbornly high, with over 700,000 cases and a high test positivity rate. The government's four-phase recovery plan, which aims to ease curbs based on vaccination rates and other metrics, could be the most clear plan yet, but its success depends on execution and follow-through.

site_title: Digital services taxes - consensus approach from all nations needed
summary: A global consensus on digital services taxes (DSTs) is needed to address the challenges posed by digitalisation, but a G-7 agreement may not be sufficient. The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) has proposed two pillars to tackle tax challenges, but a G-7 deal on digital services tax calculation and administration is still pending. Experts warn that unilateral DSTs, such as those imposed by France, Australia, and the UK, may result in double taxation and hinder innovation. A global consensus is crucial to ensure a level playing field and prevent uneven outcomes, with the G-20 meeting in July expected to set the tone for further discussions.

site_title: Big Oil CEOs join traders in seeing possibility of oil hitting US$100
summary: Big Oil CEOs predict oil prices could reach US$100 a barrel due to low investment and supply constraints. CEOs from Royal Dutch Shell, TotalEnergies, and Exxon Mobil forecast higher prices in the short term, with some traders and banks also predicting a potential surge to US$100. The increase in oil prices is attributed to growing demand and reduced supply, with economies recovering from the pandemic. However, the energy transition may eventually lead to declining oil consumption and prices.

site_title: Boardroom intrigue at MC Payment
summary: MC Payment's controlling shareholder Ching Chiat Kwong has issued public statements questioning the board's actions, leading to two extraordinary general meetings (EGMs) to consider new director appointments and removing current directors. Two directors were previously voted out at the annual general meeting (AGM) on April 28, 2021. The company's boardroom tussle raises concerns about the need for further changes to take the company forward.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Investors in Singapore can now access SPDR Gold Shares in local currency starting June 30. The exchange-traded fund, backed by physical gold, first listed in 2006 and was the most traded ETF in 2020. Ley Choon Group Holdings has received approval to extend its annual general meeting and lodge its annual return. Mapletree Logistics Trust has had its sale and purchase agreement lapse, but remains keen on acquiring a property in Malaysia.

site_title: Central banks to lead way for digital currencies: BIS
summary: Central banks are set to lead the way in regulating digital currencies, according to the Bank for International Settlements (BIS). The BIS stresses that digital payments should be secure and regulated by central banks, which will provide protection for the public. Central bank digital currencies (CBDCs) aim to offer a safe and regulated monetary system, settlement, liquidity, and integrity. The BIS warns about the risks of large tech firms offering digital currencies, citing concerns about data silos and anti-competitive practices.

site_title: Tales of wanderlust
summary: Singaporean authors have turned their travel experiences into bestsellers, such as Koh Buck Song's "Around the World in 68 Days" and Clara Chow's books on New Orleans and Ipoh caves. Meanwhile, local designers have incorporated historic shophouses into condominium projects, offering a mix of past and present. Restaurants like Basque Kitchen by Aitor have also revamped their spaces, providing a new dining experience. These stories showcase the creative ways Singaporeans are compensating for their wanderlust and embracing their local culture.

site_title: Blackstone bets US$6b on shifting path to suburban homes
summary: Blackstone Group has agreed to buy Home Partners of America, a rental company with over 17,000 houses, for $6 billion. The deal is a bet on the US housing market shifting towards suburban homes as Americans seek new ways to purchase a house due to tight housing markets and rising prices. Home Partners' unique business model allows tenants to buy their rental home at a predetermined price, making it a pathway to home ownership. The acquisition comes as single-family rentals have been a popular investment strategy over the past year, with Blackstone's shares increasing 25% since exiting its stake in Invitation Homes in 2019.

site_title: WeRide deepens ties with Nissan, raises US$310m
summary: China-based autonomous driving startup WeRide raised US$310 million at a US$3.3 billion valuation, deepening ties with Nissan Motor on autonomous driving technology for the China market. WeRide is pursuing a level 4 autonomous standard, testing vehicles in California, Guangzhou, and Zhengzhou. The funding round includes investors Renault-Nissan-Mitsubishi alliance and China Structural Reform Fund. Nissan's Ashwani Gupta said the partnership aims to bring innovative technologies and services to enrich people's lives in China, as the company eyes the future of mobility.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close with healthy gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed with healthy gains on Wednesday, snapping a two-day losing streak, as Federal Reserve officials reassured investors that they won't tighten monetary policy soon. The Hang Seng Index rose 1.79% to 28,817.07, while the Shanghai Composite Index added 0.25%. The gains were driven by a global rally, with the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Why 50% of businesses won't survive the sustainability push
summary: Businesses face significant challenges in surviving the growing sustainability push, with 50% predicted to fail. Investors, governments, and companies are increasingly prioritizing environmental, social, and governance (ESG) policies, with climate change now a fact of life. To adapt, businesses must set targets, measure performance, and track data in real-time, and update records regularly to show progress. The failure to do so can lead to dire consequences, including extinction.

site_title: EU begins legal action against Hungary over anti-LGBTQ law
summary: The European Commission is launching legal action against Hungary over its anti-LGBTQ law, which prohibits content deemed to "promote homosexuality" for children. The law, approved by Hungary's Parliament, is part of a broader effort to restrict LGBTQ rights, including banning same-sex adoption and enshrining marriage as only between a man and a woman. EU governments have condemned the law as a form of discrimination, and the Commission will use all available powers to protect EU citizens' rights.

site_title: EV Maker Xpeng gets nod for US$2b Hong Kong listing
summary: Xpeng, a New York-traded electric vehicle maker, has received approval from the Hong Kong stock exchange to list in the city with a potential fundraising of up to $2 billion. The company's dual primary listing will give it a foothold in Hong Kong and allow it to broaden its investor base. This move comes as rival Chinese EV companies Nio and Li Auto also plan listings in Hong Kong, amid intense competition in the Chinese electric-vehicle market.

site_title: SP Group donates S$1m to Community Chest
summary: SP Group donated S$1 million to Community Chest to support children from low-income families through the SP Kids at Heart initiative. The program aims to benefit approximately 2,000 KidSTART children with educational tools, books, and toys for a year. The initiative complements SP's existing programs for seniors through the SP Heartware Fund, and will also provide additional resources such as electronic devices and financial assistance. This donation is seen as a way for corporates to play a part in building a society of opportunities, with Minister Masagos Zulkifli praising SP's efforts.

site_title: NCID nurse among three unlinked Covid-19 cases; four new clusters declared
summary: A nurse at the National Centre for Infectious Diseases in Singapore tested positive for Covid-19 after interacting with patients, becoming one of three unlinked cases announced. The nurse, who received two doses of the vaccine, developed symptoms on Monday and underwent testing, with her results confirmed on Tuesday. The Ministry of Health also announced 10 linked cases and 9 imported cases, bringing Singapore's total to 62,470 cases. Four new clusters were declared, and three closed, with 39 active clusters of infection.

images.alt_text: A nurse at the National Centre for Infectious Diseases (NCID) who interacted with Covid-19 patients tested positive for the coronavirus on Tuesday, said the Ministry of Health (MOH) on Wednesday night.

site_title: Reimagining the workspace of tomorrow
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has disrupted traditional office space use, with firms diversifying operational risks by distributing work close to employees' homes. This shift has led to increased adoption of cloud-based office systems and virtual platforms, reducing the need for in-person interactions. As a result, the demand for traditional physical office space may decrease, but it is unlikely to be completely replaced. Instead, the future of office space is likely to center on flexibility, with hybrid spaces and on-demand office space emerging to support a more collaborative and less structured working environment.

site_title: NCID nurse among three unlinked Covid-19 cases; four new clusters declared
summary: A nurse at the National Centre for Infectious Diseases (NCID) in Singapore tested positive for Covid-19, becoming one of three unlinked cases announced. The nurse, who wears full personal protective equipment, had previously received two doses of the Covid-19 vaccine. Four new clusters of infection were declared, bringing the total to 39 active clusters. There were also 22 new cases, including nine imported cases, bringing Singapore's total to 62,470.

site_title: Cyclical currencies lead after dust settles on Fed
summary: The US dollar fell against other currencies, including the Kiwi dollar and Norway's crown, after the Federal Reserve signaled a less likely path for earlier rate hikes. The dollar dropped to its lowest level in nearly a week, while the euro rose for a third consecutive day. Other currencies, such as the Japanese yen and Bitcoin, also moved in response to the Fed's dovish stance. The greenback's decline was attributed to relative growth differentials and neutral positioning on the currency, rather than a sudden change in monetary policy.

site_title: AstraZeneca, Pfizer vaccines effective against Delta Covid-19 variants: study
summary: A study by Oxford University researchers found that AstraZeneca and Pfizer-BioNTech Covid-19 vaccines remain effective against Delta and Kappa variants, but neutralizing antibodies in the blood may be reduced, leading to potential breakthrough infections. The study suggests the current vaccines will provide protection against the B1617 lineage, but previous infection with the Alpha variant may offer "reasonable" cross-protection against other variants. The findings support continued vaccination efforts and may inform the development of next-generation vaccines.

site_title: Family offices driving a few car park deals; Chinatown offers latest million-dollar lot
summary: A multi-storey car park at People's Park Complex in Singapore's Chinatown has been put up for public tender with a guide price of S$42 million. The property spans four floors, comprising 648 car parking spaces and a restaurant unit. The car park sector is considered an "appealing alternative" to traditional real estate classes, with limited supply and steady cash inflow. The sale is expected to attract family offices and other investors, following recent sales of car parks by local and foreign buyers, including a S$16.2 million deal concluded by Brilliance Capital earlier this year.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 9.26 points lower on Wednesday at 1,564.76, with a trading volume of 5.218 billion lots worth RM2.784 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 716 to 297.

site_title: S&P agreement for proposed acquisition in Malaysia lapsed amid pandemic situation: Mapletree Logistics Trust
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust's sale and purchase agreement for a Malaysian property lapsed due to the pandemic situation, with the Reit's manager remaining keen on the acquisition. The asset, Mapletree Logistics Hub - Tanjung Pelepas in Johor, was valued at RM402.5 million (S$130.22 million). The vendor is working to obtain necessary approvals from the Johor Port Authority and Pelabuhan Tanjung Pelepas, which has taken longer than expected. The Reit's manager will continue to work towards the acquisition.

site_title: Stay-home notice cut to 14 days for travellers from high-risk areas, but they must take additional Covid-19 rapid tests
summary: Singapore has reduced its stay-home notice (SHN) period for travellers from high-risk areas from 21 days to 14 days, effective June 28. New arrivals must take additional Covid-19 rapid tests on the 3rd, 7th, and 11th day of their stay. This change applies to travellers from countries or regions except Australia, Brunei, Hong Kong, Macau, China, and New Zealand. The Ministry of Health (MOH) found no evidence of longer incubation periods with new variants of concern, and the reduced SHN period is based on incubation periods within the 14-day window.

site_title: South-east Asian marketers spend US$244m to acquire users as demand for fintech apps rise in 2020
summary: South-east Asian marketers spent US$244 million to acquire users in 2020, accounting for 8% of the global total of US$3 billion. The majority of their marketing budgets (65%) focused on non-organic installs, with investment apps making up over 65.5% of these. The pandemic led to increased demand for loan apps, which accounted for 58.3% of non-organic installs, while financial services trailed behind. Despite lockdowns and reduced spending, the region's overall demand for fintech apps grew, with Indonesia, the Philippines, Thailand, and Vietnam seeing higher demand in Q1 2021.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise on Wednesday in line with region; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.3% on Wednesday, following gains in the region, led by the Straits Times Index (STI) closing at 3,118.62. The gains were influenced by US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's testimony, which reassured investors that inflationary pressures are transitory and the Fed will be patient in lifting borrowing costs. The local bourse saw 18 out of 30 STI constituents gain, with Yangzijiang Shipbuilding emerging as the top performer.

site_title: Del Monte swings back into the black for Q4, declares final dividend of 1.2 US cent per share
summary: Del Monte Pacific reported a net profit of US$14.5 million for the fourth fiscal quarter, reversing a net loss of US$12.4 million in the same period last year. The company's full-year net profit rose to US$63.3 million, up from a net loss of US$81.4 million in FY 2020. Del Monte's board approved a final dividend of 1.2 US cents per share, representing 37% of the group's net profit for FY 2021. The company attributed its improvement to reduced sales of low-margin segments and lower trade promotions.

site_title: Singapore's GIC to invest US$180m in Sunway's healthcare unit
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC will invest US$180 million in Sunway Berhad's healthcare business, acquiring a 16% stake valued at RM4.69 billion (S$1.5 billion). The investment will be disbursed over three years, with GIC entitled to 3% annual dividend. The deal validates Sunway's confidence in its healthcare division and the long-term potential of Malaysia's healthcare industry. The investment will support Sunway's expansion plans, which include building up to six more hospitals and increasing capacity to approximately 3,000 beds.

site_title: Spike in Singapore inflation not yet cause for alarm; MAS unlikely to normalise currency settings before next year: analysts
summary: Singapore's inflation rate rose to its highest point since 2013 in May, with all-items inflation at 3.3%. However, core inflation remains at manageable levels. Analysts believe the spike is not yet a cause for alarm and the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is unlikely to normalize currency settings before next year. Experts consider the current inflationary pressures manageable and manageable, citing the need for workers to future-proof their careers.

site_title: US: Nasdaq hits record high ahead of business activity data
summary: The Nasdaq Composite hit a record high, rising 10.1 points or 0.07% to 14,263.381, ahead of business activity data. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 also rose, with the Dow up 3.0 points or 0.01% and the S&P 500 up 2.8 points or 0.07%. Investors are awaiting data on business activity, following concerns about a potential tapering of monetary stimulus by the Federal Reserve.

site_title: Europe: Technology stocks gain ahead of business activity data
summary: European technology stocks rose 0.6% ahead of business activity data, while the Stoxx 600 hovered below record highs. The pan-European index was up 0.2% as investors awaited euro zone data. Technology stocks led sectoral gains, while mining and healthcare also contributed to the market's momentum. The rally comes despite US-EU trade talks and tariff uncertainty.

site_title: COE prices slide across all categories
summary: COE prices in Singapore slid across all categories in the latest tender, with cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp finishing at S$47,821, down from S$48,510 two weeks ago. Commercial vehicle COE closed at S$37,000, while motorcycle premium ended at S$8,501. Market watchers attribute the drop to the absence of aggressive sales promotions and new buyers being deterred by recent premium increases.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's government ICT spending is set to increase to S$3.8 billion in FY2021, with 83% of opportunities available to small and medium-sized enterprises. Consumer prices rose 2.4% in May, the highest in seven years, due to the ongoing Phase 3 situation. The SPDR Gold Shares fund will start trading in Singapore dollars on June 30. DBS completed Singapore's first USD SOFR-linked export financing transaction worth US$25 million. Private exchange HGX graduated from the MAS FinTech Regulatory Sandbox and obtained an RMO licence, supporting digital and non-digital capital market products.

images.alt_text: ICT contracts will be made available to SMEs through streamlined procurement efforts, which will improve SMEs' access to government ICT procurement opportunities, the agency said in a press statement.

site_title: Central bank digital currencies get full BIS backing
summary: The Bank for International Settlements (BIS) has given full backing to the development of central bank digital currencies (CBDCs), citing their need to modernize finance and prevent "Big Tech" control of money. At least 56 central banks and monetary authorities are exploring digital currencies, representing around a fifth of the world's population. The BIS has set out recommendations for the development of a CBDC, such as a digital dollar or euro, and is coordinating discussions among central banks on digital currencies. This move aims to ensure a secure and inclusive financial system.

site_title: Honda goes all in on electric in stark contrast to Toyota
summary: Honda has set a goal to phase out sales of petrol-powered cars by 2040, making it the first Japanese automaker to do so. The company aims to achieve carbon neutrality by 2050, aligning with Japan's Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga's pledge. Honda has already begun integrating electric technologies, including a partnership with General Motors and plans to unveil three new electric motorcycles by 2024. The move is seen as a bold move to capture market share and differentiate itself from rival Toyota, which prioritizes hybrid vehicles.

site_title: Taiwan Buddhist group enters fray for BioNTech Covid vaccines
summary: A major Taiwanese Buddhist group, the Tzu Chi Foundation, has submitted an application to buy 5 million doses of BioNTech's Covid-19 vaccine, joining Foxconn and TSMC in efforts to secure vaccines for Taiwan. Despite global supply shortages, Japan and the US have donated 3.74 million doses, and the Taiwanese government has millions on order. The government has allowed Terry Gou and TSMC to negotiate on behalf of the government, but BioNTech has stated it will only sell to governments.

site_title: Government ICT spending to increase to S$3.8b in FY2021; 83% of contracts open to SMEs
summary: Singapore's government ICT spending is set to increase to S$3.8 billion in FY2021, with 83% of contracts open to small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). The Government Technology Agency (GovTech) aims to improve SMEs' access to government ICT procurement opportunities through streamlined procurement efforts. The majority of the spending, S$2.7 billion, will go towards re-engineering digital government infrastructure and transforming government digital services, including cloud developments and artificial intelligence (AI) adoption.

site_title: SHN cut to 14 days for travellers from high-risk areas, but rapid tests required
summary: Singapore has reduced the mandatory 21-day stay-home notice (SHN) for new arrivals from high-risk countries to 14 days, effective Monday. However, travellers must undergo antigen rapid tests on the third, seventh, and eleventh day of their arrival, in addition to PCR tests on arrival and day 14. The change applies to travellers from countries or regions except Australia, Brunei, Hong Kong, Macau, China, and New Zealand. Affected travellers will have their notice reviewed and arrangements for check-out will be communicated separately.

site_title: 13 new Covid-19 cases in community, including three unlinked
summary: Singapore reported 22 new Covid-19 cases, bringing the total to 62,470, with 13 in the community, including three unlinked cases. Nine cases were imported, with four returning Singaporeans placed on stay-home notices. Hospitalized cases remain at 142, with 173 recuperating in community facilities. There have been 35 Covid-19-related deaths in Singapore.

site_title: 3,000 sensors at Temasek Poly can soon alert on frigid indoor sweater weather, energy waste
summary: Temasek Polytechnic will deploy a digital integrated facilities management platform with over 3,000 sensors to monitor energy use and reduce costs. The platform, developed by Surbana Jurong, will provide real-time data on temperature, humidity, and occupancy levels, enabling the institution to optimize energy consumption and prevent waste. The system will also provide hands-on learning experience for students in the institution's facility management course, as they work with real data to make informed decisions. The move is part of the polytechnic's digitalisation plans to improve operational efficiencies.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end higher as Powell calms markets; Naver, Kakao lead gains
summary: South Korean stocks rose 0.38% to close at 3,276.19, driven by gains from tech giants Naver and Kakao, which surged 8.31% and 6.60% respectively. The Federal Reserve's pledge to not raise interest rates too soon eased market fears and calmed investors. Foreigners sold 8.1 billion won worth of shares, while the won weakened 0.51% against the dollar.

site_title: HSBC apology shows financial fears are mounting in Hong Kong
summary: HSBC Holdings apologized to customers in Hong Kong after a Twitter post revealed updated online and mobile banking terms that raised concerns over overseas access to its services. The bank clarified that there were no changes and that customers could continue to access services outside of Hong Kong. The incident underscores growing concerns in the city over China's tightening grip, with thousands of Hong Kongers leaving for the UK and other places due to restricted freedoms.

site_title: US, China discuss possible meeting of secretary of state, Chinese foreign minister
summary: The US and China are discussing a possible meeting between US Secretary of State Antony Blinken and Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi at the G-20 meet in Italy next week. The White House has also considered sending Deputy Secretary of State Wendy Sherman to China, potentially paving the way for a bilateral summit between US President Joe Biden and Chinese President Xi Jinping at the G-20 leaders meeting in Rome in October. These discussions aim to improve diplomatic relations between the two nations.

site_title: EV maker Xpeng said to get nod for US$2b HK listing: sources
summary: Xpeng, a Chinese electric vehicle maker, has received approval from the Hong Kong stock exchange to list in the city, potentially raising up to $2 billion. This move allows the company to diversify its investor base and hedge against potential risks of being kicked off US exchanges. Xpeng's dual primary listing is the largest since BeiGene's $903 million raise in 2020, and comes as the EV industry faces increased competition and declining shares. The company aims to break even by late 2023 or 2024 and has seen its deliveries grow 483% in May.

site_title: Eurozone business growth at 15-year high as demand unleashed
summary: The Eurozone experienced its fastest business growth in 15 years, driven by the easing of lockdown measures and pent-up demand in the services industry. The IHS Markit Flash Composite Purchasing Managers' Index rose to 59.2, its highest reading since June 2006, beating expectations. Manufacturing activity also accelerated, with the June flash PMI estimate matching May's record pace. However, supply chain disruptions and high demand led to sellers' markets for raw materials, fueling inflationary pressures.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares give up gains, end down
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index ended lower Wednesday, giving up earlier gains, after a second straight day of US Wall Street gains and easing fears over US rate policies. The benchmark index closed 0.03% down at 28,874.89, while the Topix index lost 0.53%. Gains in US shares and the yen's retreat initially lifted the Nikkei, but profit-taking ensued as it approached 29,000 yen.

site_title: US comics legend Chris Ware wins top Angouleme prize
summary: US comic legend Chris Ware has won the prestigious Grand Prix of Angouleme award, considered the industry's top prize, for his work documenting suburban American life. Ware, known for his meticulous attention to detail, joins a trio of past US winners, including Art Spiegelman and Bill Watterson, in the honor. The award comes after Ware's book "Rusty Brown" tipped the balance for voters in 2020, and he will accept the award from the United States due to the festival's postponement.

site_title: Apple Daily to print final edition on Thursday
summary: Hong Kong's pro-democracy tabloid Apple Daily will print its final edition on Thursday, following a year of raids by police and arrests under a national security law. The paper, known for its mix of pro-democracy discourse and celebrity gossip, has been a thorn in Beijing's side since its founder Jimmy Lai was arrested in December. Rights groups and Western governments have criticized the action, with Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam saying criticism amounts to attempts to "beautify" acts endangering national security. Apple Daily's end has raised alarm over media freedom in the Chinese-ruled city.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong's pro-democracy tabloid Apple Daily will stop operating no later than Saturday, its publisher, Next Digital, said on Wednesday after national security police arrested another employee of the besieged newspaper.

site_title: SoftBank CEO Son says share buybacks remain an option for firm
summary: SoftBank Group Corp CEO Masayoshi Son said share buybacks remain an option for the conglomerate, despite a decline in its shares. The company's shares have fallen 50% from their value, prompting Son to consider alternative uses of its capital. Son stated that buybacks would increase his own shareholding and make a management buyout easier to achieve. He emphasized the need for a long-term view on the company, drawing parallels to the role of financiers in industrial revolutions.

site_title: Tesla opens first charging station in China with energy storage facilities
summary: Tesla has opened its first charging station in China, located in Lhasa city, with integrated solar and energy storage facilities. The charging station utilizes Tesla's solar services, including Solar Roof and Powerwall, to generate and store power for electric vehicles. This marks Tesla's expansion into the Chinese energy market, following its move into the solar business in 2016. The company aims to develop its energy business, particularly in China, where it has been hiring solar and energy storage project managers.

site_title: UK to go easy on firms with unpaid taxes during pandemic
summary: The UK government will take a "cautious approach" to collecting unpaid taxes from companies during the pandemic. Business Secretary Kwasi Kwarteng announced a "flexible approach" to firms that engage with HM Revenue and Customs, promising not to pursue insolvency action unless a customer does not respond or engage. This move comes as the Chancellor of the Exchequer, Rishi Sunak, faces pressure to extend support to businesses amid ongoing Covid-19 restrictions. The government will consider alternative routes to recovery of debts accrued during the pandemic.

site_title: Australia: Shares buck global rally as virus concerns deepen
summary: Australian shares fell 0.6% on Wednesday, led by a drop in banks due to concerns over a Covid-19 outbreak in New South Wales, prompting border closures and curbs on gatherings. The outbreak, with 37 cases in Sydney, overshadowed improved global sentiment after US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell vowed not to raise interest rates quickly. Benchmark heavyweight financials dropped 1.1%, while tech-led gains from Afterpay and Appen helped offset losses, with miners also advancing due to higher iron ore prices.

site_title: Two new accreditation schemes for managing agents recognised by BCA
summary: The Building and Construction Authority (BCA) has recognised two new accreditation schemes for managing agents in Singapore. The schemes, introduced by the Association of Property and Facility Managers (APFM) and the Association of Strata Managers (ASM), aim to raise professionalism and improve competencies of managing agents who handle over 3,500 management corporations. This move is part of the BCA's efforts to support industry bodies and enhance standards in the industry.

site_title: Temasek-backed software startup Sprinklr raises US$266m in downsized US IPO
summary: Sprinklr, a customer experience software company backed by Temasek, raised US$266 million in a downsized US IPO after pricing its shares at US$16 each. The company, which works with clients like Microsoft and McDonald's, had revenue of US$387 million for the year ended January 31, but reported a net loss of US$41 million. Sprinklr's top investors, including Hellman & Friedman and Battery Ventures, will control more than half of the shareholder voting power after the IPO. The shares began trading on the New York Stock Exchange under the symbol CXM.

site_title: Sydney residents banned from leaving city as coronavirus cluster grows
summary: Sydney residents are largely banned from leaving the city due to a growing outbreak of the Delta Covid-19 variant. Over 30 people have been diagnosed with Covid-19 in the city's Bondi Beach area since the cluster emerged last week. New South Wales Premier Gladys Berejiklian announced new restrictions, including a ban on non-essential travel and limits on social gatherings, for the next week. Authorities urge residents to follow the new rules as they try to contain the outbreak, with vaccination rates still low in the population.

site_title: New British £50 note with WWII codebreaker Turing enters circulation
summary: The Bank of England has introduced a new £50 banknote featuring Alan Turing, a British mathematician and computer scientist who contributed to WWII codebreaking. The note is part of the UK's transition to polymer banknotes and enters circulation three months after its design was unveiled. Turing's contributions to computer science and his role in decrypting coded messages during WWII are being recognized. The new note also acknowledges Turing's experiences as a gay man during a time when homosexuality was illegal in Britain.

site_title: China's Covid-hit Shenzhen suspends direct flights to Beijing
summary: China's Shenzhen suspends direct flights to Beijing until July 1 due to a Covid-19 outbreak, with 170 confirmed local cases in Guangdong province. Eight cases were reported in Shenzhen, while 146 were in Guangzhou. Flights to other mainland destinations remain operational. The suspension follows China's efforts to contain the outbreak ahead of the Chinese Communist Party's founding celebrations in Beijing.

site_title: Bank of Thailand holds rate, lowers outlook on tourism slump
summary: Thailand's central bank, the Bank of Thailand, held its benchmark interest rate at a record low of 0.5% for the ninth consecutive meeting, as expected. The decision aims to preserve policy space amid the country's largest wave of COVID-19 cases and a weakening tourism economy. The bank is prepared to use limited policy space to target loans and debt restructuring for businesses and households, rather than lowering interest rates.

images.alt_text: Thailand's central bank held its benchmark rate unchanged Wednesday, signalling a need to preserve policy space as the country grapples with its biggest wave of Covid cases and a weakening outlook for the tourism-reliant economy.

site_title: Alibaba alum becomes billionaire with US IPO for China trucking startup
summary: Zhang Hui, a 42-year-old former Alibaba employee, has become a billionaire after his US IPO for China's trucking startup, Full Truck Alliance, reached a market value of $2.2 billion. Zhang owns 9.2% of the company, which operates a truck-sharing app, and saw his stake rise 16% above the IPO price. SoftBank's Vision Fund has a 20% stake in the company, valued at $4.8 billion, and Full Truck Alliance raised $1.6 billion in the IPO, making it one of the biggest by a Chinese company this year.

site_title: Singapore consumer prices post 2.4% rise in May, a seven-year high
summary: Singapore's consumer prices rose 2.4% in May, the highest level in seven years, driven by increased prices in services, private transport, and accommodation. Core inflation, excluding private transport and accommodation costs, stood at 0.8%, higher than economists' median estimate of 0.7%. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and Ministry of Trade and Industry attributed the rise to a low base from the pandemic-related downturn and a boost from strong price increases in services.

site_title: South Korea's finance minister expects this year's second extra budget to be above 30t won
summary: South Korea's Finance Minister Hong Nam Ki expects the country's second extra budget this year to be worth more than 30 trillion won (S$35.6 billion), aiming to safeguard jobs and boost aid for businesses hit by the coronavirus pandemic. The budget plan is set to be submitted to parliament by early July.

site_title: Unliveable Sydney homes going for millions in Australian housing boom
summary: In Australia's housing market, homes with severe damage and uninhabitable conditions are selling for millions of dollars, driven by record low borrowing rates and high demand. A derelict brick cottage in Sydney's northwest sold for A$1.6 million, and another abandoned house in Sydney's south-east sold for A$4.7 million. Experts say buyers are willing to pay a premium for the land, rather than renovating the property, and this trend is expected to continue, fueling a building boom. However, regulators are warning of increased risk-taking in mortgage lending, and a potential slowdown in the market.

site_title: Malaysia aims to inoculate 60% of population by end-September
summary: Malaysia aims to vaccinate 60% of its population by the end of September, with 4.08 million individuals already receiving at least one dose of the Covid vaccine. The country plans to administer 11 million doses in July, 13 million by the end of August, and a further eight million by the end of September. This goal is part of Malaysia's efforts to ramp up inoculations following recent weeks.

site_title: Private exchange HGX graduates from MAS FinTech Regulatory Sandbox, attains RMO licence
summary: HG Exchange, a private securities exchange, has graduated from the Monetary Authority of Singapore's FinTech Regulatory Sandbox with a Recognised Market Operator (RMO) licence. The RMO licence enables HGX to support the issuance and trading of both digital and non-digital capital market products. The company has also promoted Willie Chang to CEO and appointed Eric Neo as president, citing the demand for alternative investments and the potential for HGX to democratize private fundraising and investments.

site_title: Trump's tariffs led to billions of losses, Fed research shows
summary: Federal Reserve research shows that US tariffs on China led to billions of dollars in losses, primarily due to misreporting by both exporters in China and importers in the US. The tariffs caused a reversal of the normal trade pattern, with China selling more goods to the US than reported. The distortions in trade data also suggest that the US-China trade deficit contracted by $88 billion in 2020, with $55 billion due to evasion of US tariffs and $12 billion due to misreporting for higher VAT rebates.

site_title: New Zealand mulls lockdown after Covid-19 case in capital city
summary: New Zealand is considering a lockdown in Wellington after an Australian tourist tested positive for Covid-19 after visiting the city over the weekend. The tourist had visited multiple locations, raising concerns of an outbreak. This comes after New Zealand was declared Covid-19 free with the last positive case due to community transmission reported on Feb 28. The decision to lock down Wellington would be a significant move, given the country's efforts to contain the spread of Covid-19 and return to normalcy.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.92 points, or 0.12%, to 1,572.10. The index saw 247.79 million lots traded worth RM126.55 million, with 169 gainers and 100 losers.

site_title: Bitcoin rallies after dropping below US$30,000 on China crackdown
summary: Bitcoin rallied 3.7% to $32,802 after dropping below $30,000 due to China's crackdown on cryptocurrencies. The world's largest cryptocurrency fell to $28,600, its lowest since early January, and remains 13% higher this year. Analysts say the outlook remains tilted to the downside, with smaller coins like ether also affected. China's central bank urged banks and payment firms to crack down harder on cryptocurrency trading, exacerbating the sell-off.

site_title: Twitter stars to dabble with getting fans to pay
summary: Twitter is testing a feature allowing fans to pay for special access to online content, including live audio events and exclusive interactions with popular users. Ticketed Spaces will allow creators to set prices between $1 and $999 for live audio events, while Super Follows will offer exclusive content at monthly subscription rates of $3, $5, or $10. Twitter will take a 3% commission on earnings up to $50,000, increasing to 20% thereafter. The feature is being tested with a small group of users to gather feedback before a broader launch in the coming months.

site_title: SPDR Gold Shares to start trading in Singapore dollars on June 30
summary: SPDR Gold Shares, an exchange-traded fund backed by physical gold, will start trading in Singapore dollars on June 30 under the stock code GSD. This move aims to provide local investors with more flexibility to access gold amid market volatility. The ETF, which tracks gold prices, has an expense ratio of 0.4% and allows investors to diversify their portfolios. The move follows the ETF's previous listing in US dollars in 2006, and is seen as a cost-efficient way for investors to access the gold market.

images.alt_text: The ETF, which is backed by physical gold and tracks the price of the yellow metal, first listed in Singapore in 2006 in US dollars.

site_title: Asia: Stocks extend gains as traders eye loose policies, upbeat outlook
summary: Asian markets continued their rally on Wednesday, driven by the Federal Reserve's reassurances on monetary policy, which eased concerns about an interest rate hike. The Fed chief, Jerome Powell, stated that a substantial part of the inflation surge is linked to the re-opening of the economy, and the central bank will wait for evidence of inflation before raising interest rates. The news lifted Wall Street and Asian markets, with Tokyo, Hong Kong, and Shanghai rising, while Sydney and Jakarta edged lower.

images.alt_text: Asian markets rose on Wednesday to extend a global rally, as fresh pledges on monetary policy by the Federal Reserve reassured investors who had been rattled last week by the bank's forecasts of an earlier-than-flagged hike in interest rates.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares open higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.56% in the first few minutes of trading, tracking a record close on Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index reached 28,468.24, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw slight gains. This follows two days of losses, as fears over Federal Reserve monetary policy ease for now appear to have subsided.

site_title: Mega-Sales Days encourage brand-switching behaviour: study
summary: A study by Facebook and Bain & Company found that 91% of South-East Asian consumers are more likely to try new brands during Mega-Sales Days, a two-fold increase in consumer openness. Consumers are also more savvy in planning purchases, with 75% using social media to discover new products. The study suggests that Mega-Sales Days are a key point of entry for new e-commerce customers, with over half of shoppers in Thailand and Vietnam being first-time e-commerce consumers.

site_title: Australia: Shares ease after best day in four months, energy stocks top losers
summary: Australian shares slipped 0.5% to 7,303.20, retreating after a 1.5% gain on Tuesday, as energy stocks fell 1.5% due to a discussion by Opec+ countries to raise production. Gold stocks slid 0.5% as crude oil prices fell. Sector heavyweights Santos and Woodside petroleum were the biggest drags on the sub-index. Tech stocks advanced 0.8%, led by a gain in Afterpay.

site_title: Crushing climate impacts to hit sooner than feared: draft UN report
summary: A draft UN report warns that climate change will drastically reshape life on Earth in the coming decades, even if greenhouse gas emissions are curbed. The report states that devastating impacts, such as species extinction, widespread disease, and unlivable heat, are accelerating and will become painfully obvious before a child born today turns 30. The world must prepare for the onslaught, with tens of millions more people facing chronic hunger and extreme poverty by 2050. The report highlights the need for transformational change to avoid worst-case scenarios and emphasizes the importance of conservation, restoration, and sustainable behaviors.

site_title: Fossil fuel firms face new challenge over 'greenwashing' ads
summary: Environmental groups Global Witness, Greenpeace, and Earthworks have filed a false advertising complaint against Chevron Corp with the Federal Trade Commission (FTC), alleging the company's "greenwashing" ads are misleading. The groups claim Chevron spent only 0.2% of its annual budget on renewable energy, despite advertising its investment in clean energy. The FTC can issue warnings or penalties if it finds the ads unfair or deceptive. The move aims to set a precedent for further action against "greenwashing" by fossil fuel firms, which are increasingly touting their green credentials.

site_title: 'Common language' and risk data critical to mobilise private capital, close sustainable infrastructure financing gap: Indranee
summary: Singapore's Second Minister for Finance and National Development Indranee Rajah emphasized the need for a common language on green finance and better data on climate risk to mobilize private capital for Asia's sustainable infrastructure needs. The region faces a significant financing gap, with green and sustainability-linked bonds making up less than 5% of the global market. Indranee called for regional bodies to develop taxonomies and databases to inform investors on climate risks and opportunities. She also introduced the Asia Sustainable Infrastructure Panel to advise on trends and best practices in sustainable infrastructure development.

images.alt_text: There remains a "significant financing gap" for Asia's sustainable development needs, Second Minister for Finance and National Development Indranee Rajah said at the Asia Infrastructure Forum on Wednesday.

site_title: Google gives workers tool for remote work planning
summary: Google has introduced a new tool, the Work Location Tool, to help employees plan and calculate pay and benefits for remote work based on their location. The platform considers local job markets and costs of living, allowing workers to plan for potential changes in compensation. The hybrid workplace model, expected to see 60% of employees in offices 2-3 days a week, 20% in new office locations, and 20% working from home, aims to provide flexibility regarding remote work and location changes.

site_title: US dollar in retreat as Powell says Federal Reserve won't raise rates on 'fear' of inflation
summary: The US dollar experienced a two-day drop against major peers, with the dollar index at 91.775, after US Federal Reserve officials, including Chair Jerome Powell, reaffirmed that tighter monetary policy is not imminent due to concerns over inflation. Powell stated that the Fed will not raise interest rates "pre-emptively" due to the risk of inflation, and instead will wait for evidence of actual inflation or imbalances. This led to a market correction, with the euro and Aussie dollar largely unchanged, and benchmark 10-year Treasury yields edging lower.

images.alt_text: The US dollar remained on the back foot against major peers on Wednesday after a two-day drop as US Federal Reserve officials including Chair Jerome Powell reaffirmed that tighter monetary policy was still some way off.

site_title: GIC-backed South Korean fintech eyes 12-fold growth, IPO by 2025
summary: South Korean fintech startup Toss, backed by GIC, has raised over $400 million at a $7.4 billion valuation, aiming for 12-fold sales growth by 2025. The company, which operates the largest fintech startup in South Korea, plans to launch an online lender and expand its securities platform, doubling monthly users to 20 million. Toss is poised to become a $100 billion company, with founder Lee Seung-gun's estimated stake exceeding $1 billion. The startup's success marks a significant shift in the transition from traditional finance to online finance in South Korea.

site_title: SingEx-Sphere Holdings renamed Constellar Holdings
summary: SingEx-Sphere Holdings, a merged entity of Temasek's MICE portfolio and Singapore Press Holdings' (SPH) Sphere Exhibits, has been renamed Constellar Holdings. The company aims to leverage opportunities from the Covid-19 pandemic to create a new agile path for growth through reinvention and collaboration. With a focus on hybrid business models and digitally-enabled intellectual property, Constellar plans to expand its portfolio through organic curation and inorganic investments, aiming to become a global leader in the MICE experience space. The company has also announced a new CEO, Jean-Francois Quentin, effective August 1.

site_title: Gold ticks up after Powell pledges not to raise rates quickly
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell pledged not to raise interest rates too quickly, citing only inflation concerns, boosting gold prices. Spot gold rose 0.1% to $1,780.06 per ounce, while US gold futures remained steady. Powell's comments, which also reaffirmed the Fed's intent to encourage a broad job market recovery, led to lower 10-year Treasury yields. The dollar index rose, making gold more expensive for holders of other currencies, despite a decline in silver and palladium prices.

site_title: Nanofilm chief executive resigns due to health reasons
summary: Nanofilm's CEO Lee Liang Huang has resigned due to health reasons, effective August 21. Executive Chairman Shi Xu will assume the interim CEO role until a successor is appointed. The company's share price remained largely unaffected, closing at S$5.36 with a 0.74% decline. Lee, who founded Nanofilm in 1999, had been the CEO since 2017, overseeing the company's daily management and operations. The board expressed appreciation for his contributions during his tenure.

site_title: US Federal Reserve bank stress tests pave way for stock buyback, dividend bonanza
summary: The US Federal Reserve is set to release its annual stress test results on Thursday, which are expected to clear the way for US banks to issue up to $130 billion in dividends and stock buybacks. The test assesses banks' ability to withstand an extreme economic downturn, following last year's pandemic-induced economic crash. The results will determine the banks' capital requirements, and a clean bill of health will allow them to distribute more funds to shareholders. The test results are expected to be announced next month, paving the way for a dividend and stock buyback bonanza.

site_title: Singapore stocks open slightly higher on Wednesday; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.2% on Wednesday, tracking a second straight day of gains on Wall Street. The Straits Times Index (STI) reached 3,116.20, driven by gains in Sembcorp Marine, Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust, and ThaiBev. Meanwhile, US stocks reached fresh records, with the Nasdaq Composite Index rising 0.8% and the S&P 500 advancing 0.5%. European stocks also ended higher, with mining stocks benefiting from stable commodity prices.

site_title: Pandemic has increased trust in media: report
summary: The pandemic has boosted confidence in news reporting, with 44% of respondents trusting news sources, up 6 points since the start of the crisis. Trust remains highest in Finland (65%) and lowest in the US (29%). The shift to digital has accelerated, with increased consumption of mainstream news in countries with independent public service media. However, only 17% of respondents pay for news online, with higher rates in wealthier countries. Trust in news shared on social media remains low at 24%, and younger generations are more likely to get news from social media and aggregators.

site_title: Morgan Stanley tells staff they'll need to be vaccinated to enter office
summary: Morgan Stanley announced that employees will need to be vaccinated against Covid-19 to enter its New York offices, following a growing trend among Wall Street firms. The policy takes effect on July 12 and applies to staff, clients, and visitors. The move is seen as a measure to prioritize the return of vaccinated staff, with CEO James Gorman estimating that over 90% of employees in offices are already vaccinated. The bank's decision comes after similar policies were implemented by other firms, including Goldman Sachs and BlackRock.

site_title: Indonesia, home to giant gold mine, wants its own bullion bank
summary: Indonesia plans to establish its own bullion bank to spur domestic gold trading, following the country's largest gold mine, the Grasberg mine in Papua, which holds one of the world's largest gold reserves. The bank, expected to start operating in 2024, aims to cut reliance on transit countries like Singapore and Australia for gold trading. The move is part of Indonesia's broader effort to climb the commodities value chain and profit from higher-value products rather than just raw materials exports. This will help develop the local industry and provide financing opportunities.

site_title: Bank of Japan board saw prospects of faster-than-expected recovery: April meeting minutes
summary: The Bank of Japan's April policy-setting meeting minutes revealed that board members believe massive stimulus measures by advanced nations may speed up Japan's and global economies' recovery. However, policymakers also expressed concerns about uncertainty in coronavirus vaccinations affecting Japan's economic activity. The BOJ maintained its monetary settings and projected inflation to miss its 2% target beyond 2023.

site_title: US House Speaker Pelosi to create special panel to probe Jan 6 attack: source
summary: US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi plans to create a special committee to investigate the January 6 attack on the Capitol, following Senate Republicans' rejection of a bipartisan commission. This move comes after Pelosi informed high-level House Democrats of the decision.

site_title: Genting's new Vegas resort is a US$4.3b bet on city's comeback
summary: Genting Group has opened its newest resort, Resorts World Las Vegas, a $4.3 billion investment in the city's comeback after a three-month coronavirus closure. The 3,500-room resort features a 5,000-seat theatre, a 100,000-square-foot LED screen, and a pop-up store selling Kardashian family merchandise. Genting aims to attract Asian gamblers with a broader theme, but analysts note that themed properties are less popular in Las Vegas. The resort's marketing slogan "Stay Fabulous" emphasizes luxury and excess, with a cashless casino and partnerships with Hilton Worldwide. Genting hopes the resort will help the company achieve its goal of becoming a global gaming company.

images.alt_text: Genting Group opens its newest resort on Thursday, a US$4.3 billion extravaganza in Las Vegas and the biggest new property on the city's famous Strip in over a decade.

site_title: Europe: Shares propped up by commodities, Powell speech in focus
summary: European shares rose 0.3% on Tuesday, driven by stable commodity prices and gains in mining and chemical stocks. Irish stocks surged 1.6% after the new leader of the Democratic Unionist Party was named, while economically sensitive sectors like banks and industrials rose amid signals of possible interest rate hikes. The focus shifts to US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's speech, which may impact risk-linked assets.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Nanofilm, CLCT, Keppel, Silkroad Nickel, DBS, Cromwell E-Reit, Hatten Land
summary:
Key developments in the Singapore stock market include: 
- Nanofilm CEO Lee Liang Huang resigns due to health reasons, with Shi Xu taking over temporarily.
- CLCT priced S$150 million worth of notes at 2.4% to fund corporate and working capital purposes.
- Keppel is exploring floating cities in Singapore and has launched a digital fixed income execution platform.
- Silkroad Nickel entered into a subscription agreement for US$15 million in exchangeable bonds.
- DBS launched a digital fixed income execution platform and appointed Keppel as the sole arranger and dealer.
- Cromwell E-Reit agreed to sell its Parc de Popey asset for S$9.3 million.
- Hatten Land entered into a memorandum of understanding to manage three malls in Malaysia.
- DBS shares dropped 0.8% after announcing the digital fixed income execution platform.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei index opens slightly higher on Wednesday
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index opened 0.08% higher on Wednesday, following Wall Street's second straight day of gains as US rate policy worries eased. The broader Topix index was down 0.13%. US stocks reached fresh records despite tariff uncertainty, while traders brushed off new Trump threats to extend the rally.

site_title: Google likely to soon face antitrust claims over Play store from US states: sources
summary: A group of US state attorneys general, led by Utah, Tennessee, North Carolina, and New York, are set to file a lawsuit against Google as early as next week, accusing the company of violating antitrust law in managing its Play Store for Android devices. The lawsuit follows complaints from app developers and is expected to focus on Google's requirement that some apps use the company's payment tools to sell subscriptions and content. This comes as Google faces similar lawsuits from Epic Games and Apple, and amid a broader debate over federal antitrust enforcement.

site_title: Japan government to consider tighter rules on foreign owners of domestic firms: Yomiuri
summary: Japan's government is considering stricter regulations on foreign investment in domestic firms with significant technology, such as nuclear and defense, to prevent foreign funds and companies from compromising Japanese companies' competitive edge or leaking technological expertise. The new rules aim to protect Japan's critical technology and prevent potential national security threats.

site_title: Goldman Sachs begins trading on JPMorgan repurchase blockchain network
summary: Goldman Sachs has begun trading on JPMorgan's blockchain-based repurchase agreement network, marking a pivotal moment in the digitization of transactional activity. The firm swapped a tokenized US Treasury bond for JPMCoin, a digital representation of the US dollar, in a trade that took place on June 17. This move is seen as a significant step forward in the adoption of blockchain technology in financial markets.

site_title: Singapore firms helping to fuel Indonesia's tech sector's growth
summary: Singaporean firms are driving Indonesia's tech sector growth, with companies like Memiontec Holdings securing major projects in the country. The Singapore Exchange-listed firm has established full-fledged Indonesian operations and is providing clean drinking water to millions of Indonesians. With cutting-edge technology and strong operational strengths, Memiontec is leading a surge in Singapore investments into Indonesia, with the country topping the list of approved foreign direct investments in the first quarter of 2021. Singapore's position as a global financial hub also facilitates cross-border cooperation, with venture capital firms and international investors raising funds for Indonesian startups and tech companies.

site_title: DBS completes Singapore's first USD SOFR-linked export financing transaction
summary: DBS has completed Singapore's first USD Secured Overnight Financing Rate (SOFR)-linked export financing transaction worth US$25 million with food and agri-business Bunge. The transaction marks a significant milestone as the industry transitions away from the Interbank Offered Rate (Ibor). DBS aims to help clients transition to alternative Risk-Free Benchmark Rates (RFRs) ahead of the December 2021 cessation of USD Libor. This transaction is part of DBS's efforts to shift institutional clients to RFRs for the Singapore dollar cash and derivatives market, with a third of new SME loans now Sora-pegged.

images.alt_text: DBS has completed Singapore's first export financing transaction referencing the US dollar Secured Overnight Financing Rate (SOFR) with food and agri-business, Bunge.

site_title: Britney Spears to address court in guardianship battle with father
summary: US pop singer Britney Spears is set to address a Los Angeles court via an internet link, addressing the terms of her guardianship and her father's controlling role. The 39-year-old singer has been under a guardianship since 2008, with her father Jamie Spears managing her finances and personal life. Spears has filed to remove her father as conservator and give sole power to a financial institution, citing the guardianship as "oppressive and controlling." Spears has expressed her desire to be free from her father's control, stating she is "sick of being taken advantage of."

images.alt_text: Under a controversial legal guardianship since 2008, US pop singer Britney Spears is scheduled to address a Los Angeles court on Wednesday in the battle over her father's control of her affairs.

site_title: Singapore has what China tech giants need
summary: Chinese tech giants, including Alibaba, Tencent, and Meituan, are seeking 'neutral' managers who can navigate the US, China, and other international markets. After facing antitrust fines and regulatory crackdowns, these companies need to grow abroad. Singapore is emerging as a stepping stone due to its cultural similarity with mainland China, neutrality, and access to international markets. The country's ability to facilitate the growth of Chinese tech companies will be crucial in helping them overcome the challenges of operating globally.

site_title: US seizes Iranian state news websites
summary: The US government seized the websites of Iranian state-controlled news groups Press TV, Al-Alam, and Al-Masirah TV, citing US sanctions laws. The move also froze domains tied to Iran-backed groups in Iraq and Hezbollah. Iran's Islamic Republic of Iran Broadcasting accused the US of repressing freedom of expression and blocking pro-resistance media outlets. The seizure comes amid US efforts to restore the 2015 Iran nuclear deal, with talks between the US and Iran ongoing.

site_title: The best time to invest was when you drew your first pay cheque. The next best is now
summary: A growing trend among young adults in Singapore, dubbed "kiasu-ism," involves prioritizing retirement planning over other financial goals. This attitude is encouraged by financial professionals, as starting early can significantly impact retirement savings. The CFA Institute Mercer study warns that reduced contributions, investment returns, and government support may lead to reduced retirement benefits. To ensure retirement adequacy, millennials and Gen Z are advised to save more, start early, and consider investing consistently, even with small amounts. The power of compounding can help accumulate wealth over time, providing financial freedom and beating inflation.

site_title: Alset soars 19.4% after Tesla partnership announcement
summary: Alset International's shares rose 19.4% after announcing a partnership with Tesla to deliver its first 20 eco-friendly homes in the Houston area of Texas. The stock reached an intraday high of 7.4 cents, ending the day at 6.6 cents, with 26.61 million shares traded. This follows a sustainability boom, with the company's shares surging in a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Sterling strikes as England beat Czechs to top Euro 2020 group
summary: England secured top spot in Euro 2020 Group D with a 1-0 win over the Czech Republic at Wembley Stadium. Raheem Sterling scored the decisive goal in the 12th minute, his second of the tournament. England boss Gareth Southgate made several changes to his lineup, including giving Jack Grealish and Bukayo Saka their first starts. The win gives England a seven-point lead in the group, with Croatia second and the Czech Republic third, who will also advance to the last 16.

site_title: Carmaker pledges to halt combustion engines
summary: Audi, a subsidiary of Volkswagen, has pledged to launch only fully electric vehicles from 2026 and halt manufacturing of internal combustion engines by 2033. This move follows similar commitments from other automobile manufacturers. The decision aims to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and comply with environmental regulations. Audi's plan is part of a broader effort to transition the automotive industry towards electric vehicles, with many companies setting targets to phase out internal combustion engines in the next decade.

site_title: US has 'wrong' expectation for North Korea dialogue: Kim's sister
summary: North Korea's Kim Yo Jong stated that the US has "wrong" expectations for dialogue, warning that Washington's approach would "plunge them into a greater disappointment". This comes after the US promised a "practical, calibrated approach" to persuade North Korea to give up its nuclear and missile program. The US diplomat, Sung Kim, said Washington is ready to meet with Pyongyang "anywhere, anytime, without preconditions", but Kim Yo Jong dismissed prospects for an early resumption of negotiations, saying the US is seeking "comfort for itself".

site_title: Thailand gives go-ahead to pilot quarantine-free travel to Phuket
summary: Thailand has given the green light to a pilot model for quarantine-free travel to Phuket, a popular beach destination, starting July 1. The "Phuket sandbox" scheme allows vaccinated tourists to enter the country without a two-week quarantine. To ensure the scheme's success, Thailand will monitor infection rates, with Phuket's weekly cases limited to 90. The move aims to boost the country's pandemic-battered economy, which has been hit hard by tourism losses.

site_title: Container dangers can be reduced
summary: A container ship, the X-Press Pearl, sank off the coast of Sri Lanka after catching fire, resulting in an environmental disaster. The ship's crew was rescued safely, but the ship's master was arrested under anti-pollution legislation. Investigations are underway to determine the cause of the fire and the incident's impact on the environment. The maritime industry is being called to action to improve safety measures, particularly in securing large above deck stows and handling hazardous cargo. Experts emphasize the need for transparency, trust, and best practices in the industry to prevent similar incidents.

site_title: Oil settles slightly lower as Opec+ discusses raising production
summary: Crude oil prices settled slightly lower on Tuesday after Brent rose above $75 a barrel for the first time in over two years. Opec+ discussed raising oil production, but no decision has been made. Brent crude futures settled at $74.81 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude fell to $73.06 a barrel. Oil prices have risen for the past four weeks due to the global rollout of Covid-19 vaccinations and expected summer travel. Forecasts predict oil could briefly reach $100 a barrel in 2022 due to tight supply and recovering demand.

images.alt_text: Crude oil prices settled slightly lower on Tuesday after Brent rose above US$75 a barrel for the first time in over two years, as Opec+ discussed raising oil production.

site_title: China crypto clampdown sends Bitcoin closer to key US$30,000 level
summary: China's intensifying cryptocurrency crackdown has pushed Bitcoin closer to the key US$30,000 level. Bitcoin fell 4.3% on Tuesday to US$31,171, with some analysts viewing a breach of US$30,000 as a potential trigger for a steep sell-off. The price level is seen as a significant short-term benchmark for the largest virtual currency.

images.alt_text: Bitcoin has roughly halved from a record of US$65,000 in mid-April, but it's still up over 200 per cent over the past year. The Bloomberg Galaxy Crypto Index has more than quadrupled over 12 months.

site_title: Biden sees work needed to address problems created by big tech firms: White House
summary: US President Joe Biden believes steps are needed to address problems created by big technology platforms, including safeguarding privacy and promoting innovation. The White House supports bipartisan work in Congress to tackle these issues, particularly with the House Judiciary Committee voting on a package of antitrust bills targeting large tech firms. The legislation aims to protect users, small businesses, and tech startups, while also allowing for the emergence of new great tech companies in the US.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden believes steps are needed to safeguard privacy, bolster innovation and deal with other problems created by big technology platforms, the White House said on Tuesday, signaling his support for legislation concerning Big Tech.

site_title: EU meets with a new 'spring in its step'
summary: The European Union (EU) is experiencing a renewed sense of optimism and unity among its leaders, driven by improved economic and political conditions.
