Oil prices are expected to rise further, with Bank of America predicting Brent crude could average $68 a barrel this year and reach $100 next year.

site_title: Brazil Congress green-lights Eletrobras privatisation
summary: Brazil's Congress passed a bill paving the way to privatize state-controlled company Eletrobras, the largest electric utility in Latin America, with a vote of 258-136. The bill, which sets up a share issue to dilute the government's stake from 51.82% to 45%, is a victory for President Jair Bolsonaro's privatisation agenda. The government will retain a "golden share" in the company, allowing it to make strategic decisions, and estimates the share issue will raise 25 billion reais (S$6.71 billion).

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Singapore stock market saw significant activity with several key events. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times, while Creative Technology warned of potential revenue and operating loss shortfalls. London's Heathrow airport plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. Singapore stocks rallied for the fifth consecutive day ahead of GDP data, with MAS and PBOC announcing deeper cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: Olam posts 13.1% drop in Q1 PATMI; launches S$601.7m rights issue
summary: Olam International reported a 13.1% drop in profit after tax and minority interests (PATMI) to S$155.6 million for the first quarter, mainly due to the absence of net exceptional gains. The company launched a S$601.7 million rights issue at S$1.25 per share, representing a 26.9% discount to its last traded price. This move aims to repay debt used to fund its US$950 million acquisition of Olde Thompson. Revenue grew 14.5% to S$8.8 billion, and the group has S$18.2 billion of total available liquidity.

images.alt_text: Olam International on Tuesday posted a 13.1 per cent drop in profit after tax and minority interests (PATMI) to S$155.6 million for the first quarter ended March 31, from S$179.1 million the year before.

site_title: World's biggest pork plant in US unable to ship to Mexico: USDA website
summary: The US Department of Agriculture announced that a Smithfield Foods Inc facility in North Carolina, the world's largest pork plant, is no longer eligible to export to Mexico due to a change in US regulations. This move affects Mexico, which was previously the largest export market for US pork by volume, with purchases worth $1.3 billion in 2019.

site_title: HSBC, StanChart eye 3b yuan fee windfall on new China link
summary: Global banks HSBC and Standard Chartered are ramping up hiring to tap into China's latest market opening, a new investment link with Hong Kong, which could yield 3 billion yuan (S$623.2 million) in annual fees. The "Wealth Connect" plan, set to launch in the second half of the year, will allow bank customers in nine southern Chinese cities to invest across the border in Hong Kong and vice versa. The plan is expected to start slowly, targeting the mass affluent rather than the super rich, and will operate with a closed-loop currency conversion regime.

images.alt_text: Global banks including HSBC Holdings and Standard Chartered are ramping up hiring to tap into China's latest market opening - a new investment link with Hong Kong that could yield 3 billion yuan (S$623.2 million) a year in fees.

site_title: Paving the way for transformation in the landscaping industry
summary: Mao Sheng Quanji Construction, a Singapore-based landscaping company, is thriving in the city's ambitious greening endeavour. Founded by Choo Kim Chuan in 1983, the company has grown to over 500 employees and maintains a family-like culture, prioritizing relationships and employee development. Despite the challenges of the Covid-19 pandemic, Mao Sheng adopted a positive approach, embracing technological transformation through digital platforms and e-learning. The company's visionary leader, Choo Jun Wei, is confident in Mao Sheng's future expansion, both domestically and internationally.

site_title: Hong Kong to shorten quarantine for most arrivals to seven days
summary: Hong Kong's government announced it will shorten quarantine for most vaccinated arrivals to seven days, starting June 30, provided travellers show sufficient antibodies against the coronavirus. This change is aimed at incentivizing more residents to get vaccinated, with only around 17% fully vaccinated since the scheme started in February. The quarantine period remains unchanged for arrivals from countries deemed "very high risk". Social distancing measures will also be eased from June 24 for vaccinated residents.

site_title: US: Stocks bounce back from rout, Dow Jones up 1.8%
summary: US stocks rebounded on Monday, with the Dow Jones up 1.8% to 33,876.97, after a week of decline due to concerns over the Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes. The market correction was attributed to financial, industrial, and energy shares. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also gained, with the S&P 500 up 1.4% to 4,224.79 and the Nasdaq up 0.8% to 14,141.48. Fed Chair Jerome Powell is set to appear before a congressional panel on Tuesday, amid ongoing discussions on a bipartisan infrastructure package.

site_title: ExxonMobil prepares to cull US white-collar ranks by up to 10%
summary: ExxonMobil is planning to reduce its US headcount by 5-10% annually for 3-5 years by identifying low performers through its performance-evaluation system. This will not be considered layoffs, but rather targeted firings of underperforming employees, many of whom will be put on a performance improvement plan and expected to leave on their own. The cuts are part of a broader effort to optimize the company's workforce.

site_title: Aerospace industry looks for boost with major Dubai Airshow set for Nov
summary: The Dubai Airshow, set for November 14-18, will be held under capacity restrictions due to the pandemic, but is seen as a boost for the aerospace industry to reset after the health crisis. The five-day show will attract tens of thousands of visitors, including planemakers, airlines, and military officials, and will feature Israeli companies. Exhibition stands will have limits on attendance, and wearing of masks is expected to be compulsory. Despite few deals expected, the show aims to gauge regional conflicts and tensions, particularly between the US and Iran.

site_title: China's first Reits make solid debut in Shanghai, Shenzhen
summary: China's first batch of real estate investment trusts (Reits) made their stock market debut on June 21, 2021, with solid initial gains. The nine Reits drew interest from Chinese retail investors, with the Bosera CMSK Industrial Park fund and AVIC Shougang Biomass fund rising as much as 20%. The IPOs were "significantly oversubscribed" by institutional and retail investors, raising over $1.21 billion. China is launching a public Reits market to channel private money into infrastructure projects, but analysts predict high volatility in the market before sentiment calms down.

site_title: Singapore market a top pick for H2; upside seen in reopening, cyclical plays
summary: Analysts are optimistic about the Singapore market's prospects in the second half of the year, citing the country's speedy vaccination program and gradual economic reopening. The Straits Times Index has outperformed regional peers, with many analysts revising their targets upwards, including Morgan Stanley and DBS. Reopening plays, such as ComfortDelGro and Reits, are expected to benefit from increased economic activity, while healthcare and cyclical sectors, like banks and construction, are also expected to see growth. Despite risks, the Singapore market is seen as a top pick for investors due to its strong control on the pandemic and better-than-expected economic growth.

site_title: Hitman's Wife's Bodyguard shoots to top of US box office
summary: The Hitman's Wife's Bodyguard has taken the top spot at the US box office, earning an estimated $11.7 million over the weekend. The action comedy, a sequel to the 2017 hit, features Ryan Reynolds, Samuel L. Jackson, and Salma Hayek. Despite total box office takes remaining below pre-pandemic levels, the progressive reopening of theaters and lifting of capacity limits offer a glimmer of hope for Hollywood. The film's production cost was $70 million, and it will need to continue performing well to recoup its investment.

site_title: Taiwan pulls out officials from HK after 'one China' row
summary: Taiwan has pulled out officials from its representative office in Hong Kong after Hong Kong's government demanded that Taiwan officials sign a document supporting China's "one China" claim to Taiwan. The move comes amid an escalating row over China's sovereignty claims over Taiwan. Taiwan's Mainland Affairs Council head Chiu Tai-san said the decision was made in response to Hong Kong's "unreasonable" request, and Taiwan will maintain operations but take "necessary measures" if its presence is further jeopardized. The move is seen as a protest against China's increasing influence in Hong Kong.

site_title: It's been three long years ayondo, what are you still waiting for?
summary: Ayondo, a Catalist-listed fintech company, has been listed on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) for three years, yet investors remain unpaid. The company's affairs have raised numerous questions, including ballooning losses and a cash-flow pickle. Ayondo's stock has lost three-fourths of its value since its IPO in 2018, and its trading life on SGX ranks it high on the list of IPO failures. The company has proposed a reverse takeover, but the process has been delayed, and regulators have questioned two directors over a possible offence under the Securities and Futures Act.

site_title: Learn from and build on response to disruptions: DPM
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat of Singapore emphasized the need for cities to learn from disruptions, including the Covid-19 pandemic, to recover and build a more resilient future. He highlighted the importance of treating each disruption as a unique crisis, rather than relying on past experiences. Heng proposed three "I"s for building cities of the future: innovation, investment, and integration. He encouraged cities to explore new possibilities in planning and running, invest in infrastructure, and collaborate globally to share strengths and enhance connectivity.

site_title: Nova Systems' Asia business divested in management buyout, renamed Heron Technology
summary: The Asia business of Australian-based Nova Systems has been divested in a management buyout, rebranded as Heron Technology. The Singaporean-led team will focus on cybersecurity and digital aviation capabilities under the new name. The management buyout was the result of Nova Group's decision to divest its cyber security and UAS Asia business, which was set up in 2017. The deal amount is confidential, but the existing team will transition to their new appointments at Heron Technology, with the core management team remaining unchanged.

site_title: Australia's central bank and largest lender divided on wages, inflation outlook
summary: Australia's central bank, the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA), and its largest lender, Commonwealth Bank of Australia (CBA), have differing views on wages and inflation. The RBA believes higher wages are "some way off" due to a potential untapped workforce, while CBA economist Gareth Aird sees a tight labor market with workers seeking pay hikes, leading to higher wages and prices. The disagreement highlights a divide between the central bank and the country's largest bank on the outlook for the economy.

site_title: Is B3W another tool in the broad Western pushback against China?
summary: The G-7's Build Back Better World (B3W) plan, aimed at rivaling China's Belt and Road Initiative (BRI), has been met with skepticism. The plan promises high-standard and transparent infrastructure projects, but critics argue it lacks concrete details and may not be sufficient to compete with China's ultra-low pricing. The US and its allies may be attempting to counter China's influence in the developing world, but the B3W plan's effectiveness remains uncertain.

site_title: Uber to buy remaining stake in online grocer Cornershop
summary: Uber has agreed to buy the remaining 47% stake in Chile's online grocer Cornershop for about $1.4 billion in shares, valuing the transaction at that price. Uber first took a majority stake in Cornershop in 2019 to expand its geographic reach and bolster profits by bundling food delivery with rides. The all-stock deal involves exchanging 29 million shares, including shares for outstanding stock options.

site_title: Have Singapore office rents bottomed?
summary: Singapore's Grade A CBD office rentals posted a 1.2% quarter-on-quarter increase to S$9.90 psf in the second quarter, marking the first uptick after five consecutive drops since the Covid-19 outbreak. JLL expects rents to continue to firm up in the second half, potentially culminating in a 2-3% full-year gain. Strong demand from growth sectors, including tech and healthcare, and the successful containment of the virus, have driven the market sentiment and occupier confidence, leading to the rental uptrend.

site_title: Covid-19 eases but US won't join EU in opening borders
summary: The US has not lifted its travel restrictions despite Europe easing its own border openings, as the country continues to navigate the COVID-19 pandemic. President Joe Biden has set a goal of reaching 70% vaccination rates by July 4, and health authorities have eased mask recommendations, but travel restrictions remain in place. The State Department has expressed a desire to resume transatlantic travel once the science permits.

images.alt_text: The United States during the pandemic has also banned travel on most visitors coming from the European Union as well as Britain, along with Brazil, China, India, Iran and South Africa.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: NUTRYFARM International's subsidiary Global Agricapital (Thailand) Co has secured a sales order for 300 containers of durians worth S$40.59 million. Prime US Reit has established a distribution reinvestment plan (DRP) to allow unitholders to receive new units without brokerage fees. Singapore Myanmar Investco has entered into a subscription agreement with China-based The9 to raise up to S$1.33 million.

site_title: Bank of England set to stay split on QE after inflation jump
summary: The Bank of England (BOE) is expected to maintain its stance on quantitative easing (QE) despite inflation exceeding its 2% target for the first time in nearly two years, reaching 2.1%. Most economists still predict the BOE will raise interest rates in 2023, with some predicting a first rate hike in May 2022. The BOE's chief economist, Andy Haldane, has been a vocal advocate for halting QE, citing pressure as "transient" and warning of potential wage-price spirals.

site_title: India protest 'unfair' Olympics rules for Covid-hit nations
summary: India's Olympic body has criticized the Japanese government's strict COVID-19 protocols for athletes from Covid-hit nations, including India, ahead of the Tokyo Games. The rules require daily testing and a 3-day quarantine upon arrival, which Indian athletes claim will cause them to lose crucial training time. The Indian Olympic Association (IOA) sees this as "unfair" and discriminatory, affecting athletes who have worked hard for five years.

site_title: China trucking startup said to have raised US$1.6b in US IPO
summary: Hong Kong-based trucking startup Full Truck Alliance has raised approximately US$1.6 billion in its US initial public offering, pricing 82.5 million shares at US$19 each. The company, backed by investors including SoftBank Group and Tencent Holdings, is expected to be one of the biggest US IPOs by a Chinese company this year. The funds will be used for infrastructure development, technology innovation, and general corporate purposes.

site_title: Realpolitik's name of the game for US, Russia
summary: US President Joe Biden met with Russian President Vladimir Putin to discuss disputes and forge a working relationship, eschewing the confrontational approach of previous administrations. Biden acknowledged Russia's nuclear capabilities but emphasized the importance of self-interest and verification in their relationship. The two leaders agreed to return ambassadors, resume talks on reducing conflict risks, and hold expert consultations on cybersecurity. Biden's pragmatic approach prioritizes US interests and avoids ideological crusades, setting the tone for a more practical and collaborative relationship with Russia.

images.alt_text: Russia's President Putin, left, and US President Biden, right, at the start of the US-Russia summit at Villa La Grange in Geneva, Switzerland, on June 16.

site_title: US dollar loses some steam after Fed boost
summary: The US dollar lost some steam against major currencies, dipping 0.2% to 92.074, after the Fed signaled a sooner-than-expected end to its ultra-easy monetary policy. The dollar index had surged 1.9% last week, its largest gain since March 2020. Sterling and the euro gained ground, while the yen rose 0.2%. Analysts attribute the dollar's decline to the Fed's hawkish shift, which may lead to more rate hikes and lift US short rates.

site_title: Goldman Sachs expands transaction bank to UK
summary: Goldman Sachs has expanded its transaction bank to the UK, offering cash management services such as payment processing and payroll to companies in Britain. This move follows the launch of its transaction banking business in the US last year, which has attracted over 250 clients and processed trillions of dollars. The bank aims to compete with rivals like Citigroup and JPMorgan by offering a digital cash management platform. Goldman's expansion in the UK is part of its strategy to diversify revenue streams beyond its investment bank.

site_title: Axiata, Telenor seal US$15b deal to form Malaysia's biggest mobile operator
summary: Axiata Group and Norway's Telenor have agreed to merge their mobile operations in Malaysia in a $15 billion deal, forming the country's largest mobile operator. The combined entity, Celcom Digi Bhd, will have an estimated annual revenue of $3 billion and core profitability of $1.4 billion from 19 million subscribers. The deal is expected to be completed by the second quarter of 2022 and will result in cost cuts and savings of approximately $2 billion.

site_title: Chinese regulators launch probe into spot iron ore trading
summary: Chinese regulators have launched a probe into the spot iron ore trading market, with the National Development and Reform Commission (NDRC) and the market regulator jointly investigating hoarding and speculation. The move follows an investigation into coal prices and aims to stabilize iron ore prices, which have risen significantly and put pressure on production and operation at mid- and downstream companies. The regulators will closely monitor spot trading prices and strictly punish irregularities, such as price manipulation and hoarding.

site_title: Banks chart cautious crypto policy with regulators taking aim
summary: Banks are charting a cautious approach to cryptocurrencies, with regulators warning of significant risks to financial stability. The Basel Committee on Banking Supervision plans to assign Bitcoin to the toughest capital requirements for banks holding it. Despite increasing client interest, most banks have steered clear of other crypto services, with some, like JPMorgan and Goldman Sachs, offering only crypto futures. The banks are exploring partnerships with exchanges and focusing on the underlying blockchain technology, but there is no consensus on how to offer exposure to crypto assets.

site_title: Macron and Le Pen both disappoint in French regional vote
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron and far-right leader Marine Le Pen both underperformed in the first round of the French regional election, with the traditional right party, the Republicans, emerging as the main winner. Macron's party averaged 11% of the vote, while Le Pen's National Rally took around 19%. The left scored better than expected, with 34% of the total national vote. The outcome may have implications for the presidential election in April, with Macron's party struggling to build a strong local base and Le Pen seeking to win her first regional power base.

site_title: Oil prices climb as Iran talks drag, summer demand picks up
summary: Oil prices rose Monday, driven by strong summer demand and a pause in Iran nuclear deal talks, which could delay OPEC supplies. Brent crude gained 23 US cents to $73.74 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose 30 cents to $71.94 a barrel. Market concerns about further sharp drawdowns on inventories and limited US output growth forecast also supported prices. The pause in talks, which could last around 10 days, is seen as a potential delay in Iran's resumption of OPEC supplies, potentially impacting global supply.

site_title: Asia's cities don't have to break the bank to plan for a green recovery post-pandemic
summary: Asia's cities face significant challenges in addressing climate change and Covid-19, with many relying heavily on central governments for funding. To overcome these challenges, municipal leaders are turning to the private sector for partnerships and financing. A study found that investing in green projects could create 144 million new jobs and $7 trillion in investment opportunities by 2030. Reforms are needed to improve fiscal decentralization and financial autonomy for cities, and central governments must create an enabling environment for private sector engagement. By working together, cities can create green, resilient, and inclusive cities without breaking the bank.

site_title: Call for creation of national unit for infrastructure sector
summary: Singapore is considering the creation of a national infrastructure development unit to drive the sector's growth at home and abroad. The unit would aim to create national champions, design policy guidelines, and develop a support package for local firms. The report also recommends improving career pathways, forming alliances with overseas agencies, and strengthening industry-institute links. Singaporean firms face challenges in participating in big infrastructure projects due to systemic bias and limited financial muscle, which could worsen during the pandemic. The goal is to create a more vibrant infrastructure sector and strengthen the competitiveness of Singapore companies.

site_title: Surbana Jurong pushing boundaries to attract talent, promote sustainability
summary: Surbana Jurong, a global urban and infrastructure consulting firm, is pushing boundaries to attract talent and promote sustainability. The company, formed in 2015, has expanded its footprint globally and is involved in various technically challenging projects, including the Atal Tunnel in India and Mexico's interoceanic corridor. Sustainability underpins Surbana Jurong's projects, with the company delivering sustainable solutions across the built environment life cycle. Notably, Surbana Jurong has priced a S$250 million public sustainability-linked bond and is focusing on climate change and impact investing. The company aims to develop the next generation of built environment leaders and has acquired several firms to bolster its capabilities.

site_title: Steven Spielberg's production company reaches film deal with Netflix
summary: Steven Spielberg's production company Amblin Partners has reached a multi-year deal with Netflix to supply multiple movies per year. The agreement allows Amblin to continue producing films for Comcast's Universal Pictures, with Spielberg continuing to direct movies under a separate deal. The partnership marks a significant expansion of Amblin's content offerings for the streaming giant.

site_title: Apple Daily to suspend paper if Hong Kong accounts stay frozen
summary: Apple Daily, a pro-democracy newspaper in Hong Kong, plans to suspend its print and digital operations if authorities don't allow access to its frozen bank accounts. The company, which has around $90 million in cash, has been under increasing pressure since China imposed a national security law on the city last year. Hong Kong's national security officials have blocked the newspaper's bank accounts, and the company's top adviser has warned that the government's moves against Apple Daily tarnish the image of Hong Kong as an international financial centre. The situation has alarmed foreign governments and human rights groups, which say China and the Beijing-backed local administration are undermining constitutionally guaranteed freedoms.

site_title: Battered reflation trade in bonds faces more pain in Fed's wake
summary: The US Treasury market's reflation trade, which had driven long-term yields higher, is unraveling as the Federal Reserve signals a hawkish stance on inflation. The Fed's pivot to rate hikes and tapering its bond-buying program has led to a surge in short-maturity rates and a sharp decline in the 5- to 30-year yield spread. Traders expect the Fed to announce tapering in August, with some predicting a bigger retrenchment in yields. The reflation trade's collapse may not be over, with some traders bringing forward bets on when the central bank will lift rates to late 2022.

site_title: Post-pandemic, will heartland malls stay resilient?
summary: Singapore's heartland malls, such as Tampines Mall and Junction 8, have demonstrated resilience in the post-pandemic economy, with asset values growing 145% and 164% respectively over 18.6 years. While disrupted by online shopping, malls have adapted by increasing contributions from food and beverage and education services. However, the shift towards digitalization poses a challenge, with some habits changing, such as reduced visits to cinemas and salons, and increased online shopping. Despite this, heartland malls remain a key asset class, with investors' faith unshaken, and landlords exploring strategies to partner retailers and leverage digital ecosystems.

images.alt_text: Values of Tampines Mall (above) and Junction 8, which are now part of CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust, are up 145 per cent and 164 per cent respectively or a simple annual average of 7.8 per cent and 8.8 per cent respectively over 18.6 years.

Values of Tampines Mall and Junction 8, which are now part of CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust, are up 145 per cent and 164 per cent respectively or a simple annual average of 7.8 per cent and 8.8 per cent respectively over 18.6 years.

site_title: 44-year-old man dies from Covid-19 complications; 16 new cases, 3 unlinked
summary: A 44-year-old Singaporean man has died from Covid-19 complications, bringing the country's total deaths to 35. There were also 16 new cases reported, including three unlinked cases and three imported cases. The total number of cases in Singapore has reached 62,430. Five new cases were added to the Bukit Merah View Food Centre cluster, and special testing operations will be conducted at a nearby FairPrice supermarket to disrupt community transmission.

site_title: A look at investing styles: How to pick stocks for growth, value and yield
summary: Investing styles vary, with growth, value, and yield being key objectives. To choose stocks, identify investment goals and consider returns from dividends, capital appreciation, and income. Common characteristics include dividend payments, low volatility, and strong financials. Real-world examples include companies with stable cash flows and those with growth potential. Productivity gains and asset diversification, such as dollar asset diversification, can drive wealth creation and market growth. Understanding investment styles and strategies is crucial for selecting suitable stocks and achieving long-term financial success.

site_title: Climate on agenda as Biden prepares to meet with top financial regulators
summary: President Joe Biden is set to meet with top US financial regulators, discussing climate change risks and increasing access to credit. The meeting, scheduled for Monday, will include Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen and Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell, among others. The discussion aims to cover regulatory priorities, including climate-related financial risk and promoting financial inclusion. This marks Biden's first face-to-face encounter with many of the leading federal regulators, who were appointed by former President Donald Trump. The meeting comes as the US economy recovers from the coronavirus-triggered recession.

site_title: Intel to work with India's Reliance Jio on 5G network technology
summary: Intel will collaborate with Reliance Jio, an Indian telecommunications company, to develop 5G networking technology. Intel's venture capital unit previously invested $250 million in Reliance Jio, and the two companies will work on "co-innovations" for 5G radio-access networks and other technologies. Reliance Jio is using a non-legacy approach to build 5G networks, shifting towards software and standard computing equipment. This partnership aims to benefit Intel's growing networking chip business, which saw a 20% increase in 2020.

site_title: Singapore Myanmar Investco to raise up to S$1.33 million through placement
summary: Singapore Myanmar Investco is raising up to S$1.33 million through a placement deal with China-based The9, with 11.08 million new shares at S$0.03 each. The deal represents 3.45% of the company's existing equity and includes an option for an additional 33.25 million shares. Half of the proceeds will be used for business investments, while the other half will cover working capital requirements.

site_title: Thailand's pro-democracy protesters plan return to streets on June 24
summary: Thailand's pro-democracy protesters plan to return to the streets on June 24, reviving a movement that has been dormant since the COVID-19 outbreaks. At least four groups will gather to demand the resignation of Prime Minister Prayut Chan-o-cha and commemorate the 1932 Siamese Revolution. The Metropolitan Police Bureau has warned against demonstrations, citing risks of infections and spreading the virus. Protests could disrupt the government's plan to reopen the country for tourism and worsen the outbreak situation, with dozens already facing charges including sedition and insulting the monarchy.

images.alt_text: Thai activist Panupong Jadnok (left) and human rights lawyer Anon Numpa speaking to protesters earlier this month. Thai police have cautioned activists against staging demonstrations.

site_title: Kimly set to benefit as more work from home: CGS-CIMB
summary: Kimly is expected to benefit from Singapore's shift towards a hybrid work-from-home model, which should boost footfall at its heartland outlets and food delivery services. Research firm CGS-CIMB has initiated coverage on the company with an "add" call and a target price of S$0.46, making Kimly its top pick among listed food and beverage companies.

site_title: Ray Dalio still sees risk US overheats after Fed shift
summary: Billionaire investor Ray Dalio and former Treasury Secretary Lawrence Summers warn the US is heading for a period of overheating and inflation, potentially threatening the economic recovery. The Federal Reserve signaled its intention to step in before this happens, with officials raising inflation expectations and discussing interest rate increases. Dalio is more concerned about rising financial asset prices, which he believes are building a bubble. Summers acknowledges the Fed's growing awareness of inflation threats, but notes that forecasters were too optimistic in February.

site_title: Suez ship case adjourned as canal operator assesses new offer
summary: An Egyptian court adjourned a case over the Suez Canal blockage by the Ever Given due to the operator's time to assess a new offer of financial compensation. The ship's owners and insurers submitted a proposal, which the operator claims satisfies all requirements. The SCA initially demanded over $900 million in damages, but the amount was reduced to around $550 million. The sides have been negotiating out of court, with Japan's Shoei Kisen Kaisha Ltd. offering to pay $150 million. The next hearing is scheduled for July 4.

site_title: Opportunity for corporate restructuring amid pandemic
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has presented opportunities for companies on shaky financial ground to restructure and emerge stronger. Successful restructurings can preserve value and enable businesses to take advantage of booming industries. However, companies often delay restructuring, leading to a vicious downward spiral of short-term solutions that ultimately result in court filings and asset sales. In contrast, early intervention and swift action can lead to successful restructurings, as seen in Pacific International Lines' recent US$3.3 billion restructuring. The new Simplified Debt Restructuring framework in Singapore provides a simpler and faster process for eligible micro and small businesses to restructure their debts, making it a better time than ever to restructure.

site_title: Swedish PM Lofven ousted by Parliament in no-confidence vote
summary: Swedish Prime Minister Stefan Lofven was ousted in a no-confidence vote by Parliament on Monday, leaving him to decide whether to call a snap election or resign. Lofven's Social Democratic party lost the support of the Left Party over a plan to ease rent controls, and the nationalist Sweden Democrats called the vote. With Parliament deadlocked, economists expect the economic uncertainty to be short-lived due to Sweden's strict fiscal rules. Lofven has a week to decide his next move, and a snap election is possible but may not bring clarity, with opinion polls showing an evenly balanced centre-right and centre-left bloc.

site_title: NutryFarm unit wins 195 million yuan sales order for Thai durians
summary: NutryFarm International's subsidiary, Global Agricapital (Thailand) Co (GAT), has secured two significant sales orders for durians worth 195 million yuan (S$40.59 million) and 115.2 million yuan. GAT, a newly incorporated Thai company, will operate and manage the group's durian trading business in Thailand. The deals are part of NutryFarm's expansion efforts in the Thai market.

site_title: LegalZoom eyes over US$5b valuation in second attempt at US IPO
summary: LegalZoom is attempting to raise over US$516 million in its second US IPO, aiming for a valuation of more than US$5 billion. The company, co-founded by Robert Shapiro, plans to sell 19 million shares priced between US$24 and US$27 each. LegalZoom previously filed for an IPO in 2012 but postponed and withdrew it. The company has received funding from investors including Francisco Partners, GPI Capital, and Neuberger Berman Investment Advisers, valuing it at US$2 billion in 2018.

site_title: A real estate mogul has US$100m plan to save the Internet
summary: Billionaire Frank McCourt is investing $100 million in Project Liberty, a social media initiative that aims to create a publicly accessible database of people's social connections, allowing users to move records of their relationships between social media services. The project, led by Braxton Woodham, uses blockchain technology to construct a new internet infrastructure called the Decentralized Social Networking Protocol (DSNP), which could reduce the power of dominant social media companies like Facebook. The goal is to create an "open, inclusive data economy" where individuals own and control their personal information.

site_title: Amazon Prime Day deals expected to disappoint as costs surge
summary: Amazon Prime Day deals are expected to be stingier this year due to rising shipping costs, higher advertising rates, and scarce inventory. Merchants are being selective with deals and are worried about shipping delays persisting through the Christmas holiday season. Amazon is still offering more deals than last year, but the discounts are expected to be smaller. The two-day event is expected to generate $12.2 billion in online spending in the US, with Amazon capturing 60% of that.

site_title: It's Novak Djokovic's Wimbledon. Don't roll your eyes.
summary: Novak Djokovic is poised to win his 20th major title and tie with Rafael Nadal and Roger Federer at Wimbledon, starting Monday. Djokovic, fresh from his recent Roland Garros victory, is taking dead aim at the record books, aiming to win four majors in a single year. Despite criticism for his pared-down approach, Djokovic's game has its beauty, with his flexibility, balance, and defensive skills making him a formidable opponent. His openness and willingness to reveal his flaws make him more interesting than his peers, and recent history suggests he may emerge victorious, rebuking those who refuse to accept him as one of the greatest tennis players of all time.

site_title: US Commerce Department rescinds TikTok, WeChat prohibited transactions list
summary: The US Commerce Department has rescinded a list of prohibited transactions with TikTok and WeChat, reversing a Trump-era order issued in September. The move comes after President Joe Biden withdrew a series of Trump-era executive orders aimed at banning new downloads of the Chinese-owned apps. The Commerce Department will now monitor software applications like TikTok for security concerns and make recommendations within 120 days to protect US data. The decision reverses a Trump-era order targeting WeChat and other Chinese apps, and a separate national security review of TikTok remains active.

site_title: Russia and Myanmar junta leader commit to boosting ties at Moscow meeting
summary: Russia's Secretary of Security Council Nikolai Patrushev and Myanmar's junta leader Senior General Min Aung Hlaing met in Moscow to strengthen ties, focusing on security cooperation and military relations. Despite criticism from rights activists, Russia has maintained a relationship with Myanmar's military regime, providing training and arms sales. The two leaders agreed to maintain a good relationship between their militaries, with discussions on security measures and Myanmar's current affairs. This meeting comes amid concerns over human rights abuses in Myanmar.

site_title: China urges banks, Alipay to crack down harder on cryptocurrencies
summary: China's central bank summoned banks and payment firms, including Alipay, to crack down harder on cryptocurrency trading, following the State Council's tightening of restrictions on bitcoin trading and mining. The PBOC urged institutions to identify and cut off clients' payment channels involved in cryptocurrency transactions, citing risks of criminal activities and economic instability. Bitcoin prices plummeted 8.3% after the announcement, with China's expanding crackdown on bitcoin mining cited as a major factor.

site_title: The EU and Asean are natural partners with a visionary agenda
summary: The European Union reaffirmed its commitment to the Indo-Pacific region, particularly through its partnership with ASEAN. The EU is the top investor and development assistance provider for the region, with 40% of its foreign trade passing through the South China Sea. ASEAN considers the EU its No. 1 development partner and third trade partner. The EU's exports to ASEAN countries grew from €54 billion in 2010 to €85 billion in 2019, while imports increased to €125 billion. A broad common agenda for cooperation is desired, covering pandemic recovery, connectivity, trade, green agenda, and security.

site_title: Indonesia loans app Kredivo gets US$100m to tap Asia shopping boom
summary: Indonesian digital lender Kredivo secured US$100 million in debt financing from Victory Park Capital Advisors to accelerate consumer loans during the Asia shopping boom. The deal brings the total loan facility to US$200 million, allowing Kredivo to expand in Indonesia and enter new markets in South-east Asia. The startup, which has 5 million customers and has given credit scores to 15 million Indonesians, plans to partner with consumer finance businesses to launch "buy now, pay later" options in Vietnam and Thailand by the end of this year.

site_title: Goldman Sachs starts to offer transaction bank services in UK
summary: Goldman Sachs has started offering transaction bank services in the UK, expanding its new transaction-banking arm. The bank plans to offer a range of services, including payments in over 125 currencies, deposit accounts, and payroll. This move aims to generate stable revenue streams to complement its volatile trading and investment banking units. Since launching its US transaction banking business last year, Goldman has attracted over 250 clients and processed trillions of dollars. The expansion follows a partnership with Visa to enable corporate clients to send high-value payments overseas.

site_title: BT Money Hacks: How multi-currency wallets can save businesses money (Ep 97)
summary: A new episode of BT Money Hacks discusses how traditional payment rails can hurt businesses when dealing in multiple currencies. HSBC's Winnie Yap explains that cross-border payments through these rails result in high fees, which can quickly multiply and harm the bottom line. To address this, Winnie introduces the concept of multi-currency wallets, such as the HSBC Global Wallet, which can save time and money by streamlining transactions and reducing foreign exchange rate risks.

site_title: Asean should pursue digital economy, green economy as part of recovery: DPM Heng
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat of Singapore emphasized the need for ASEAN to pursue digital and green economies as part of its recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic. He encouraged businesses and chambers within the region to collaborate with global partners, particularly in new growth areas. Heng also highlighted the importance of green financing and human capital development in the region's transition to a green economy, noting that ASEAN lags behind in green finance with only 3% of global green finance.

site_title: UK financial sector urges caution over any 'work from home' law
summary: UK financial sector officials urge caution on potential 'work from home' law, citing the need for flexibility and natural evolution. Senior executives from Lloyd's of London, Fidelity International, and the Confederation of British Industry say legislation would be inappropriate, allowing firms to adapt to remote work on their own. They emphasize the importance of balancing work from home and office time to maintain a competitive advantage and treat those working from home with respect, suggesting a more organic approach will find its own natural equilibrium.

site_title: Olympics: Up to 10,000 fans allowed at Tokyo 2020 venues, despite warnings
summary: Tokyo 2020 Olympics organisers announced that up to 10,000 domestic spectators will be allowed at venues, despite warnings from medical experts. The decision, made after months of speculation, sets the limit at 50% of venue capacity, with a maximum of 10,000 people. Spectators will be required to wear masks, travel directly to venues, and return home immediately. The move comes as the Games face public opposition and concerns about a resurgence in infections, with only 65% of the public wanting the event to proceed as planned.

site_title: Indonesia hits 2m coronavirus cases, tightens curbs
summary: Indonesia surpassed 2 million coronavirus cases, with 14,536 new infections reported on June 21, 2021. Authorities tightened restrictions in 29 "red zones" nationwide, including suspending religious activities and limiting restaurant and mall capacities to 25%. The measures aim to contain the spread of the virus, which has surged due to travel during the Muslim Eid al-Fitr holiday and the delta variant. The country reported 294 new deaths, taking total fatalities to 54,956.

images.alt_text: Indonesia passed the two million mark in coronavirus cases after a record in new infections on Monday, as authorities announced a tightening of restrictions to contain the spread in the world's fourth most populous country.

site_title: 70% of Asia-Pacific corporations willing to pay more rent for green buildings: JLL
summary: Seventy percent of Asia-Pacific corporations are willing to pay higher rents for sustainability-certified buildings, with the majority currently paying 7-10% more rent. Despite this, the supply of green buildings is insufficient to meet net-zero targets, forcing landlords to refurbish and retrofit existing buildings. Investors prioritize green-certified assets to ensure adequate supply. Corporate occupiers view real estate as closely tied to their sustainability agenda, driving demand for green spaces. This shift emphasizes the importance of sustainable real estate solutions in addressing climate risk.

site_title: WeWork posts best sales since dropping IPO plans in 2019
summary: WeWork reported its best net desk sales since September 2019, selling enough desks in April and May to match its best sales since the company's IPO attempt in 2019. The global co-working company has maintained its occupancy rate at 53% at the end of May, up from 47% in late 2021, as vaccination rates rise and workers return to offices. WeWork has also trimmed its locations, leaving 17 buildings and renegotiating leases for 51 more to cut expenses. The company's memberships, which dropped to 490,000 in 2020, are climbing again, reaching 505,000 at the end of May.

site_title: Wealth management app Hugo raises US$2m from 1982 Ventures and others
summary: Wealth management app Hugo has raised US$2 million from 1982 Ventures, family offices, and angel investors. The Singapore-based startup aims to help users develop saving and investing habits through features like the Gold Vault, automatic savings and investment, and setting financial goals. Hugo also issues a Hugo-branded Visa debit card. The funding will support the app's growth and expansion in the fintech industry.

site_title: Sweden PM loses no-confidence vote, toppling government
summary: Sweden's Prime Minister Stefan Lofven lost a no-confidence vote, toppling the government, after a motion filed by the far-right Sweden Democrats and supported by the Moderate Party and Christian Democrats secured a majority of 181 MPs. The vote was triggered by a proposal to reform rent controls, seen as a threat to the Swedish social model. Lofven has one week to decide whether to trigger a snap election or resign, allowing parliament to negotiate a new candidate for the office. This marks the first time a Swedish prime minister has lost a no-confidence vote.

site_title: Kerry Group to buy preservatives maker Niacet for US$1b
summary: Kerry Group, an Irish ingredients giant, agreed to acquire US-based preservatives maker Niacet Corp for $1.35 billion. The deal is part of Kerry's strategy to invest in its core business following the sale of its consumer foods operations. Niacet creates preservation technologies for bakery, meat, and pharmaceuticals, and low-sodium preservatives for meat and plant-based food. The acquisition is expected to enhance Kerry's leadership position in the food protection and preservation market, driven by growing demand for longer-lasting food and plant-based meat alternatives.

site_title: US: Wall Street rebounds after Fed-induced pullback
summary: US stocks rebounded on Monday after a pullback triggered by hawkish comments from the Federal Reserve. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.07%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite gained 0.17% and 0.12%, respectively, marking the blue-chip Dow's biggest weekly fall in months. The rebound was driven by financials and energy stocks.

site_title: Covid-19 presents once-in-a-generation opportunity to reimagine cities of tomorrow: DPM Heng
summary: Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat said the COVID-19 pandemic presents a once-in-a-generation opportunity to reimagine cities for greater resilience, sustainability, and liveability. Heng emphasized the need for cities to be part of a global network and efficient supply chains, while also being resilient and efficient. He proposed three key strategies: innovation, investment, and global cooperation, citing examples such as Singapore's polycentric city plan and the Global Innovation Alliance. Heng urged cities to work together to build a more sustainable and liveable future.

site_title: CCCS seeks feedback on proposed SIA-ANA joint venture
summary: Singapore's Competition and Consumer Commission (CCCS) is seeking public feedback on a proposed joint venture (JV) framework agreement between Singapore Airlines (SIA) and Japan's All Nippon Airways (ANA). The JV, which would cover areas such as scheduling, pricing, and sales, aims to improve connectivity between the two countries, offer more competitive air fares, and benefit frequent flyer programme members. The CCCS accepted the joint application and will accept feedback until July 12. The proposed JV is unlikely to adversely affect competition, according to the airlines.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore explores adaptable city planning, considering larger homes and co-working spaces in public libraries to maintain a liveable environment. DBS has started trading on the London Metal Exchange, marking a new step in the bank's expansion. The Covid-19 pandemic presents an opportunity to reimagine cities with greater resilience, sustainability, and liveability. Many law firms in Singapore are establishing practices focused on environmental, social, and governance matters. Asian stocks fell on Monday due to concerns over a US interest rate hike, with the STI down 0.8%.

site_title: Taiwan denounces Hong Kong after officials expelled in 'one China' row
summary: Taiwan denounced Hong Kong after Hong Kong's government demanded that Taiwan officials sign a document supporting Beijing's "one China" claim to Taiwan. Taiwanese staff working at the island's representative office in Hong Kong began leaving the city on Sunday. The move was seen as an escalation in the row over China's sovereignty claims over Taiwan. The Mainland Affairs Council head stated that the move aimed to diminish national dignity and force staff to bow to Beijing authorities.

site_title: Asian stocks start the week lower amid US rate hike concerns; STI down 0.8%
summary: Asian stocks fell on Monday, tracking US rate hike concerns, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 0.8% to 3,117.87. Japan's Nikkei 225 and Australia's ASX 200 also declined 3.3% and 1.8%, respectively. US Federal Reserve comments on potential rate hikes as early as next year sparked the losses. The global reflation and cyclical recovery trade was also hit, with analysts suggesting the dip is corrective and may continue unless the Fed announces dovish views.

site_title: Volvo joins forces with Northvolt on European EV battery factory
summary: Volvo and Northvolt AB are jointly building an electric vehicle battery factory in Sweden, with a capacity of 50 gigawatt hours per year. The factory will supply around 500,000 vehicles, complementing Volvo's goal to sell only battery-powered cars by 2030. The companies will also establish a joint research-and-development center in Sweden, operational next year, and the plant is scheduled to begin production in 2026. This move aims to secure a sustainable battery supply for Volvo's electric cars and supports Northvolt's efforts to build a domestic European battery supply chain.

site_title: MinLaw extends third-party funding framework to include domestic arbitration
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Law will extend the third-party funding framework to cover domestic arbitration proceedings, connected court and mediation proceedings, and Singapore International Commercial Court (SICC) proceedings starting June 28. The move aims to provide litigants with access to funding options, allowing them to pursue meritorious claims despite financial constraints. This expansion is seen as a risk management tool to mitigate high legal costs and a step forward for Singapore's arbitration centre.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall most in over one month on CBA plunge, hawkish Fed
summary: Australian shares plummeted 1.8% on Monday, the largest decline in over a month, due to a 5% drop in Commonwealth Bank and a hawkish shift by the US Federal Reserve. The ASX 200 index fell to 7,235.3, moving away from a record high. Riskier assets, including miners and retailers, also suffered losses. The Fed's warning of potential interest rate hikes earlier than expected spooked investors.

site_title: UN official seeks Xinjiang visit this year, says HK trials key test
summary: UN human rights chief Michelle Bachelet hopes to visit China's Xinjiang region this year to investigate reports of human rights violations against Muslim Uyghurs. The visit would be the first since 2018, amid pressure from Western states for unfettered access to the region. Bachelet also expressed concerns over the national security law in Hong Kong, which has led to the arrest of 107 people, including 57 formally charged. The visit and her comments come amid reports from Amnesty International and Human Rights Watch documenting human rights abuses in Xinjiang and Hong Kong.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Monday, down 16.81 points to 1,572.24 on the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index. Volume was 6.041 billion lots worth RM2.798 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 784 to 309.

site_title: New US envoy for North Korea says looks forward to 'positive response' on dialogue
summary: US special representative for North Korea Sung Kim expressed optimism for a "positive response soon" on dialogue from North Korea during a five-day visit to Seoul. Kim's visit comes amid an impasse in denuclearisation talks with Pyongyang, with no word of any planned efforts to contact the North. Kim's appointment was made after a review of North Korea policy concluded the US would seek practical ways to induce Pyongyang to give up its nuclear weapons.

site_title: Netherlands asset manager NN Investment Partners to set up responsible investing hub in Singapore
summary: NN Investment Partners, a Netherlands-based asset manager, plans to establish a responsible investing hub in Singapore, its first outside the Netherlands. The hub will focus on developing ESG-integrated solutions in Asia, in response to growing demand from Asian investors and companies. Three specialists will lead the hub's stewardship and engagement activities, and dedicated ESG research analysts will engage with Asian corporates. The hub aims to further NN Investment Partners' focus on responsible investing in Asia, with plans to develop additional ESG-integrated Asian credit strategies.

images.alt_text: Adrie Heinsbroek, chief sustainability officer, NN Investment Partners

site_title: Taiwan's daily domestic Covid-19 cases drop below 100
summary: Taiwan's daily domestic Covid-19 cases dropped below 100 for the first time in over a month, with 75 new infections reported. Officials have extended curbs on private gatherings and entertainment venues, which may need to be lifted beyond June 28. The government is working to speed up its vaccination program, with 2.5 million doses arriving from the US, bringing the total to over 6% of the population vaccinated. The pandemic has resulted in 14,080 infections and 569 deaths in Taiwan.

site_title: China's State Grid launches Sichuan-Jiangxi UHV power line
summary: China's State Grid has launched a 24.4 billion yuan ultra-high voltage (UHV) power line connecting Sichuan and Jiangxi provinces, spanning 1,696 km. The line aims to transport hydropower from western regions to central China, addressing power supply pressure in the region. The construction is expected to help Jiangxi meet power consumption growth and ensure power security, with the province's power load projected to reach 43 GW by 2025. This is the 26th UHV power line constructed by State Grid, with plans to build at least seven new lines in the next five years.

site_title: Bitcoin pressured by post-Fed dip in sentiment, China crackdown
summary: Bitcoin fell 9% to US$32,605 on Monday amid a global risk-off sentiment and China's intensifying cryptocurrency crackdown. The move came after China's Ya'an city promised to root out Bitcoin and Ether mining operations within a year. The selloff also followed a broader retreat in assets like stocks and commodities following the Federal Reserve's hawkish policy pivot. The decline in Bitcoin's price is attributed to waning hashrate in China and a tumble in DeFi tokens, with the total market value of over 8,000 coins down from a peak of US$2.6 trillion.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks tumble on hawkish Fed; won hits three-month low
summary: South Korean stocks plummeted 0.83% on Monday, tracking global declines, after the US Federal Reserve's surprise hawkish stance. The benchmark Kospi fell 27.14 points to 3,240.79, with chip giants Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix down 0.75% and 2.01%, respectively. The won hit a three-month low, and foreign investors sold 892.1 billion won worth of shares. Despite upbeat 20-day exports data, the market volatility increased, pulling down the Kospi.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end lower after Fed's surprise turn
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 1.08% on Monday, following the US Federal Reserve's surprise hawkish shift, with the Hang Seng index closing at 28,489.00. The region's MSCI Asia ex-Japan stock index was weaker by 1.07%, while Japan's Nikkei index closed down 3.29%. China's benchmark lending rate remained unchanged, despite a 0.22% weakening of the yuan against the US dollar. The top gainer was AAC Technologies Holdings, while Haidilao International Holding was the biggest loser.

site_title: UN warns of worst 'cascade of human rights setbacks in our lifetimes'
summary: The United Nations (UN) has warned of the worst "cascade of human rights setbacks in our lifetimes," with UN rights chief Michelle Bachelet calling for "concerted action" to recover from the deteriorating global human rights situation. Bachelet highlighted rising extreme poverty, inequalities, and injustices, as well as the erosion of democratic and civic space. She urged a "life-changing vision" to address these issues, warning that they are being exacerbated by global challenges.

site_title: Hong Kong to shorten quarantine for most arrivals to seven days
summary: Hong Kong's government announced a reduction in quarantine period for most vaccinated arrivals to seven days, provided they show sufficient antibodies. The rule change, effective from the end of June, aims to incentivize vaccination among its 7.5 million population, currently at 17%. Unvaccinated arrivals from high-risk countries will still face 21-day quarantine. The move follows efforts by the government to encourage vaccination, with some businesses offering incentives for jabbed employees. The city has largely controlled the virus, with 11,800 infections and 210 deaths.

site_title: China's first Reits make solid debut in Shanghai and Shenzhen
summary: China's first real estate investment trusts (Reits) made their stock market debut, with nine Reits drawing interest from Chinese retail investors. The Reits, five in Shanghai and four in Shenzhen, opened higher, with some gaining as much as 20% due to bets on land price gains in industrial park projects. The IPOs raised over 5.8 billion yuan, significantly oversubscribed by institutional and retail investors. Analysts predict high volatility in the Reits market, but a broader market could reach over $3 trillion, surpassing the US as the world's largest.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares follow Wall Street's retreat on Fed's official comments
summary: Japanese shares dropped 3.29% on Monday, the largest decline in four months, following Wall Street's sell-off due to the Federal Reserve's comments on potential earlier interest rate hikes. The Nikkei and Topix indexes also fell, with tech and chip-related shares leading the decline. Analysts say Japan needs a consistent reason for a market rebound, as companies accelerate vaccine rollouts ahead of the Olympic Games.

site_title: Gold prices firm as US Treasury yields slide
summary: Gold prices rose 0.7% to $1,775.96 per ounce, driven by a decline in US Treasury yields, which reduced the opportunity cost of holding bullion. The real yields fell to their lowest since late February, bolstering gold's appeal amid rising inflationary pressure. Silver and palladium also gained, while platinum fell 0.3%. Investors are watching closely for comments from Fed officials, including Chair Jerome Powell, who testifies before Congress on Tuesday.

site_title: Axiata, Telenor sign US$15b deal to merge Malaysian telecoms units
summary: Malaysian telecoms firm Axiata Group and Norway's Telenor have signed a US$15 billion deal to merge their mobile operations in Malaysia, forming a new market leader in the competitive South-east Asian nation. The combined company will have annual revenue of US$3 billion and core profitability of US$1.4 billion, with a subscriber base of about 19 million. The transaction is expected to be completed by the second quarter of 2022, with cost cuts and savings on capital expenditure totaling US$2 billion.

site_title: WongPartnership launches new sustainability practice
summary: WongPartnership, a Singapore law firm, has launched a new practice dedicated to sustainability and responsible business, focusing on sustainable finance, responsible investment, and responsible business and governance. The practice, jointly headed by partners Quak Fi Ling and Tiong Teck Wee, aims to help organizations navigate the increasing importance of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) issues. The firm highlights its involvement in ESG-centred matters, including UOB's sustainability bond offering and a joint investment in a clean energy solutions provider.

site_title: Bigger homes, co-working spaces in public libraries among ideas for new urban normal
summary: The Centre for Liveable Cities (CLC) in Singapore suggests that homes and their surroundings should be designed to accommodate new roles, including refuge and work, in the post-pandemic era. Ideas include larger units, co-working spaces in public libraries, and flexible solutions such as pay-per-use work booths. CLC also proposes improving connectivity in towns and neighbourhoods, particularly for the ageing population, and incorporating more mixed-use planning to promote polycentric development.

site_title: Legendary sprinter Usain Bolt has twin boys: Thunder and Saint Leo
summary: Usain Bolt, the legendary sprinter, has announced the birth of twin boys, Thunder Bolt and Saint Leo Bolt, with partner Kasi Bennett. The twins' birth was revealed on Father's Day via Instagram. Bolt, 34, retired from sports in 2019 and won eight gold medals at the 2008, 2012, and 2016 Olympics. He is now focusing on being a father and does not plan to compete at the Tokyo Olympics. Bolt and Bennett also have a daughter, Olympia Lightning Bolt, born in May 2020.

site_title: 44-year-old man dies of Covid-19; special testing operations for 166 Bukit Merah Central
summary: A 44-year-old Singaporean man has died from Covid-19 complications, bringing the country's death toll to 35. The man, who had not been vaccinated, was admitted to hospital on May 25 and confirmed with Covid-19 the next day. Special testing operations will be conducted at a FairPrice supermarket and the Bukit Merah View Food Centre cluster, where 78 cases have been reported, including 5 new cases confirmed on Monday.

site_title: Chinese regulators launch probe into spot iron ore trading
summary: China's National Development and Reform Commission (NDRC) has launched a probe into the spot iron ore trading market, aiming to crack down on hoarding and speculation. The move follows a similar investigation into coal prices and is part of China's efforts to stabilize commodity prices. Benchmark iron ore futures plummeted 9% to 1,119 yuan per tonne, with gains narrowed to 30% in 2021. The regulators vow to strictly punish irregularities and maintain good market order, monitoring spot trading prices and investigating malicious speculation in a timely manner.

site_title: UK travel chiefs set to challenge warning of fourth lockdown
summary: UK travel chiefs are set to challenge government restrictions on travel, citing 195,000 jobs at risk due to quarantine rules. Health authorities warn of a fourth national lockdown, with Calum Semple stating a "pretty miserable" winter ahead. The government is sticking to current rules until end of July, despite pressure to ease restrictions. Industry officials, including the British Airline Pilots Association, and some Labour opposition figures are calling for a balance between containing the virus and allowing international travel. The UK's aviation industry has seen a 73% decline in flights from 2019 levels.

site_title: Singapore needs land that can be easily converted to other uses: Desmond Lee
summary: Singapore needs adaptable city planning to maintain a liveable and connected environment, Minister for National Development Desmond Lee said. The government will engage the public in July on the country's long-term development plans, including reviewing land use and city planning. Lee emphasized the importance of having "white space" that can be quickly adapted for emergencies, citing examples of former schools and hotels being converted into quarantine facilities. The government will also review its approach to office space, home design, and digital connectivity as remote-working gains pace.

images.alt_text: In the longer run, the country will need to review its broader approach to land-use and city planning, Mr Lee said.
Next month, Singapore will kick-start public engagement for the Long-Term Plan Review exercise, in which the authorities review plans for long-term land use every 10 years.

site_title: South African mystery gemstones are quartz, not diamonds
summary: Thousands of people in South Africa's KwaZulu-Natal province flocked to a hillside after discovering mysterious stones, sparking a diamond rush. However, preliminary findings revealed that the stones are actually quartz crystals, not diamonds. The discovery was made after a cattle herder unearthed the stones, and geoscientists and mining experts were sent to collect samples for testing. The results showed that the site is not a diamond-bearing area, and the stones' value is expected to be "very low" compared to diamonds, highlighting socio-economic challenges in the region.

images.alt_text: Gemstones that sparked a diamond rush to eastern South Africa last week have turned out to be just quartz, according to preliminary findings presented Sunday.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei drops 3% on US rate hike fear
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index dropped 3.01% or 870.79 points to 28,093.29 after the US Federal Reserve signaled more restrictive monetary policy, sparking investor fears. The broader Topix index also fell 2.44% or 47.51 points to 1,899.05. The losses followed a 3% decline on Wall Street.

site_title: Dongguan becomes latest city in China's Guangdong to be hit by Covid-19
summary: Dongguan, a major manufacturing hub in China's Guangdong province, has launched mass testing and cordoned off communities after detecting its first Covid-19 infections, marking the first time the Delta variant has hit the country. The citywide testing program follows two reported cases, with residents advised not to leave except for essential reasons and to show negative test results upon departure. The province has reported 168 confirmed infections since May 21, with nearly 90% in its capital, Guangzhou. Experts warn of the Delta variant's highly transmissible nature.

site_title: Adviser to jailed HK tycoon Jimmy Lai says Apple Daily to shut within day
summary: Hong Kong pro-democracy newspaper Apple Daily will likely shut down in the next few days after authorities froze its assets under a national security law. The move comes after chief editor Ryan Law and chief executive Cheung Kim-hung were denied bail on charges of collusion with a foreign country. The freezing of assets has made it impossible for the newspaper to conduct banking operations, forcing it to consider closure. Apple Daily's owner, Jimmy Lai, is currently in jail, adding to the pressure.

site_title: Australia: Shares drop as Fed official's hawkish view spooks investors
summary: Australian shares dropped 1.6% on Monday, their largest fall in nearly five weeks, amid comments from a Federal Reserve official suggesting sooner-than-expected rate hikes to curb inflation. Financials declined the most, with Commonwealth Bank of Australia falling 4.4%. Gold stocks and miners also fell, while Boral Ltd rose 2.4% after divesting its North American business.

site_title: Law firms in Singapore ride the ESG wave
summary: Law firms in Singapore are expanding their environmental, social, and governance (ESG) practices, with at least two Big Four firms launching dedicated ESG practices in the last six months. This growth is driven by increasing demand for sustainability advice, particularly in corporate advisory and mergers and acquisitions. Lawyers expect larger and more contentious ESG-related matters in the future, including disputes and net-zero pledges. The Big Four firms are investing in ESG expertise, with some planning to streamline resources across practice areas and others focusing on key areas such as sustainable finance and responsible business practices.

site_title: Europe: Shares slide as Fed's hawkish tone hits miners, bank stocks
summary: European shares fell 0.6% on Monday, reaching a two-week low, amid a surprise shift in the US Federal Reserve's stance on monetary policy. Mining stocks dropped 1.7% due to a slump in metals prices, while banking shares lost 1.3% as investors booked profits. The European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde is set to speak later in the day, and investors will focus on US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Ikea, Rockefeller foundations to pledge US$1b in clean energy push
summary: Ikea and the Rockefeller Foundation plan to launch a US$1-billion fund to support renewable energy programs in developing nations, aiming to reduce 1 billion tons of greenhouse gas emissions and empower 1 billion people with distributed renewable energy. Each foundation will provide US$500 million of risk capital, with the potential to attract additional funds from international development agencies and institutional investors. This initiative supports Ikea's goal of being climate positive by 2030 and aligns with the Rockefeller Foundation's efforts to expand renewables investment in countries like India, Nigeria, and Ethiopia.

site_title: Brokers' take: CGS-CIMB positive on Kimly's presence in heartlands, initiates with 'add'
summary: CGS-CIMB initiated coverage on Kimly with a "add" rating and set a target price of S$0.46, citing the company's resilience in mass-market demand and potential boost from Singapore's hybrid work-from-home model. The research team believes higher footfall at heartland outlets and increased food delivery services will drive higher same-store sales for Kimly.

site_title: In good sign for global economy, South Korea exports post early double-digit gains
summary: South Korea's exports rose 29.5% in the first 20 days of June compared to the same period last year, with adjusted daily shipments increasing 33.7%. This marks a slower pace from recent months, indicating the end of outsize gains. The global economy's recovery, driven by vaccinations and easing lockdowns, is boosting demand for consumer goods. While exports to China may moderate, the outlook remains positive, with economists expecting the Bank of Korea to shift its focus to financial stability and potentially raise interest rates earlier than peers.

site_title: Australia's CBA sells general insurance unit to South Africa's Hollard Group
summary: Commonwealth Bank of Australia sold its Australian general insurance unit, CommInsure General Insurance, to Hollard Group of South Africa for A$625 million upfront and deferred payments. This marks the completion of the bank's multi-year divestment strategy following scandals that increased regulatory scrutiny on the sector. The sale is part of the country's Big Four banks' efforts to re-focus on local core operations.

site_title: American Airlines to cut 1% of July flights as travel rebound strains operations
summary: American Airlines announced plans to cancel around 1% of its July flights due to a surge in travel demand amid the COVID-19 vaccination rate increase and lifted travel restrictions. The airline aims to minimize surprises at the airport and ensure good care for customers and team members. The move comes as the company struggles with bad weather and labor shortages at its hubs. American Airlines plans to adjust flights in markets with multiple re-accommodation options to impact the smallest number of customers.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Monday, down 17.8 points (1.1%) to 1,571.2. Losers outnumbered gainers 285 to 127, with 177.3 million lots traded worth RM57.2 million.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall at Monday's open; STI slips 0.8%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.8% at Monday's open, with the Straits Times Index (STI) reaching 3,119.27. The losses followed Wall Street's sharp decline after the Federal Reserve hinted at raising interest rates sooner than expected. Asian markets also dropped, with Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index tumbling 3% and European stocks falling 1.6%. Local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB were among the losers.

site_title: Winds of change lift Indonesian renewables
summary: Indonesia's power sector is poised for a robust economic recovery, driven by a shift towards renewable energy. Despite being dominated by fossil fuels, the country has vast potential for solar, wind, and geothermal energy, with estimates suggesting these resources could provide three to four times the current power generation capacity. However, regulatory and technical headwinds, as well as the country's large coal reserves, pose significant challenges to the sector's goal of becoming carbon neutral by 2050. The government has introduced policies to promote rooftop solar and geothermal development, and Fitch Solutions predicts Indonesia will claim the number one spot for installed geothermal power capacity by the decade.

site_title: Closed-door Games? Tokyo 2020 to decide on allowing fans
summary: Tokyo Olympics organisers are set to decide on Monday whether to allow fans at the pandemic-postponed Games, with reports suggesting up to 10,000 fans may be allowed, swelling to 20,000 at the opening ceremony. Senior medical experts recommend holding the Games behind closed doors to prevent a surge in infections, but organisers are leaning towards allowing foreign dignitaries and sponsors to attend. The decision comes amid a slow vaccine rollout and a sceptical public, with 86% of respondents expressing concern over a rebound in virus infections if the Games proceed.

site_title: Macau beefs up casino rules, more than doubles number of gaming investigators
summary: Macau is strengthening its casino regulator by more than doubling the number of gaming inspectors to 459, from 192, in an effort to curb illicit capital flows and tighten scrutiny of casinos. The move comes ahead of the expiry of multi-billion-dollar casino licenses that require operators to rebid for new gaming concessions. The changes, announced by the executive council, also include restructuring several departments and the creation of a new director-level post. The regulations will take effect within a few weeks.

site_title: Barclays appoints Ee-Ching Tay as head of South-east Asia banking
summary: Barclays has appointed Ee-Ching Tay as its new head of South-east Asia banking, succeeding Sandeep Pahwa since November 2010. With over 20 years of experience in investment banking, Tay will focus on driving mergers & acquisitions (M&A) advisory and financing, as well as leading senior client relationships. Her extensive transactional expertise and deep local knowledge are expected to bring substantial value to Barclays' clients in the region.

site_title: Wall Street banks struggle to cash in on China hiring binge
summary: Wall Street banks continue to struggle to generate significant profits in China, despite investing billions and hiring hundreds of staff. Despite rising revenue, firms like JPMorgan Chase & Co. and Goldman Sachs posted losses, with UBS being the only one to reverse losses. The challenging market is attributed to entrenched local competition, rising costs, and changing regulations, with some experts predicting that Wall Street banks will need more time and talent to post meaningful earnings in China.

site_title: Australia May retail sales edge up, lag expectations
summary: Australian retail sales rose 0.1% in May, lagging expectations of a 0.5% increase. The increase was largely due to a rebound in consumer spending, despite a snap coronavirus lockdown in Victoria. Food retailing led the gains, while household goods and clothing sales declined. The data suggests that the Australian economy is still performing well, driven by low borrowing costs and government support, but the Reserve Bank of Australia may keep interest rates low for a long time due to undershooting inflation targets.

site_title: DBS starts trading on London Metal Exchange
summary: DBS, the first Asian bank to receive a LME membership outside London, has started trading on the London Metal Exchange. The bank's corporate clients in Singapore, China, India, Indonesia, Korea, and Hong Kong can now access hedging and financial solutions, as well as LME's storage facilities worldwide. DBS received a Category 4 membership, which allows it to trade client contracts in the telephone market and on LMEselect. The move aims to provide clients with access to sustainably-produced metals and materials used in electric vehicles and decarbonisation.

site_title: UK house prices show biggest seasonal rise since 2015: Rightmove
summary: UK house prices saw a 0.8% increase in asking prices between mid-May and early June, the largest seasonal rise since 2015, according to Rightmove. This brings asking prices 7.5% above their level in early March 2020. Despite a strong buyer demand, the low number of available properties and high new stock prices indicate a slowing pace. The full stamp duty tax break ends in June, and prices rose 8.9% in the year to April.

site_title: US extends travel restrictions at Canada, Mexico land borders through July 21
summary: The US has extended its travel restrictions at Canada and Mexico land borders until July 21, citing positive developments and cooperation with Canada and Mexico. The 30-day extension follows Canada's announcement to extend its own travel restrictions, which were set to expire on June 21. The US Homeland Security Department will continue to work with its agencies and Canada/Mexico to identify conditions for easing restrictions safely and sustainably.

site_title: UK launches plan to capitalise on science and technology breakthroughs
