summary: Singapore's government has clarified dining rules for F&B outlets, allowing groups of two or more to dine together if they are household members, starting June 21. Indoor mask-off fitness activities may resume in groups of two or classes of 30. The Ministry of Health (MOH) has also announced fast and easy COVID-19 testing every 14 days for workers in 'higher-risk' settings. The country's reopening roadmap is expected to be unveiled 'in due course'. Meanwhile, DBS has apologized for duplicate debits and deposits on customer accounts, promising refunds by June 20.

images.alt_text: The expectation had previously been for dining in groups of up to five persons, but this will be delayed to mid-July.

site_title: Singapore Airlines' S$6.2b MCB rights issue undersubscribed
summary: Singapore Airlines' S$6.2 billion mandatory convertible bonds (MCBs) rights issue received valid acceptances and excess applications for S$3.76 billion, representing 60.6% of the available amount. This includes S$3.43 billion taken up by controlling shareholder Temasek and its subsidiary Napier Investments, making up slightly more than half of the total principal amount. The rights issue was undersubscribed, failing to meet its target.

site_title: Fast and easy testing can help assure customers, but firms worry about mounting costs
summary: Singapore firms support fast and easy Covid-19 testing every 14 days for workers in 'higher-risk' settings, such as dine-in eateries, gyms, and personal care services, to increase consumer confidence. However, industry players express concern over mounting costs, which could add up to hundreds and thousands of dollars a month. The testing requirement will be rolled out progressively from next week and become mandatory from mid-July. Industry leaders see it as a necessary step to fight the virus, but worry about the financial impact on small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs).

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Friday with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 18.19 points to 1,589.05, driven by a gainers-to-losers ratio of 563 to 456. The trading volume was 6.295 billion lots worth RM4.765 billion.

site_title: Bukit Merah View now largest active cluster with 65 cases
summary: The Bukit Merah View Market and Food Centre cluster has reached 65 confirmed cases, surpassing the Jem and Westgate cluster as the largest active cluster in Singapore. A 64-year-old male Singaporean, employed as a school bus driver, was added to the cluster, bringing the total to 65 cases. The Ministry of Health (MOH) reported 10 linked cases, including five already quarantined and five detected through surveillance, with four unlinked cases and two imported cases confirmed.

site_title: Singapore stocks end week in the black, STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index rose 0.2% to 3,144.16, ending the week in the black, driven by easing of COVID-19 restrictions and a boost from Jardine Matheson Holdings and MC Payment. The Jobs Support Scheme was also extended for three weeks, and food and beverage establishments will reopen on June 21 with limited capacity. Markets in the region were mixed, with the Hang Seng Index up 0.9% and the KLCI adding 1.2%.

site_title: Singapore civil servants to receive 0.3-month mid-year bonus
summary: Singapore's government will pay a mid-year bonus of 0.3 month to all civil servants, with an additional one-time payment of S$350 or S$700 for junior grades. The move comes as the government seeks to recognize civil servants' efforts while considering the economic situation. The decision was made in consultation with public-sector unions and follows a one-time payment of S$1,200 to lower-wage civil servants in 2020. The government also plans to monitor the economic situation closely and consider guidelines from the National Wages Council for year-end AVC payments.

site_title: LifeBrandz raises S$5m from rights, warrants issue
summary: LifeBrandz, a food and beverage group, announced its renounceable non-underwritten issue of rights with warrants was about 103% subscribed. The company received 1.06 billion valid acceptances and excess applications for rights shares with warrants. Institutional investors, Concept Global Growth Fund and Liw Chai Yuk, subscribed for 33.8% and 1.2% of the available shares, respectively. The subscription results will be used to raise S$5m for the company.

site_title: Chinese apps could face subpoenas or bans under Biden order: sources
summary: US President Joe Biden's executive order may force Chinese apps to take tougher data protection measures to remain in the US market. The order aims to safeguard Americans' sensitive data from foreign adversaries like China and Russia. The US Department of Commerce may issue subpoenas or ban apps, with WeChat and TikTok potentially facing review. The order applies to business and consumer apps, including those in banking and telecommunications, and may capture more apps than the Trump administration's previous bans due to a stronger legal framework.

site_title: Europe: Stocks nudge lower at open
summary: European stocks began the day with a slight decline, with the FTSE 100, DAX 30, and CAC 40 indices all falling 0.1% due to concerns over US monetary policy. In contrast, Asian markets rose as investors became more optimistic about interest rate hikes, easing fears of runaway inflation.

site_title: Brokers' take: UOB Kay Hian positive on Netlink's ability to generate sustainable dividend yield
summary: UOB Kay Hian has upgraded Netlink NBN Trust, citing its potential to generate a sustainable 5.3% dividend yield from FY2022 to FY2024. The trust aims to increase fibre take-up in Singapore and invest in South-east Asia, driven by the government's Smart Nation initiatives and 5G network roll-out. The research house expects connections to grow, particularly non-building access points, and maintains a "buy" rating with a target price of S$1.08.

images.alt_text: UOB Kay Hian expects Netlink NBN Trust to be a "high yielding, safe haven stock" as it looks to take advantage of the increase in fibre take-up locally as well as investment opportunities in South-east Asia.

site_title: Fast and easy Covid-19 testing every 14 days for workers in 'higher-risk' settings: MOH
summary: Singapore is set to implement a 14-day fast and easy testing regime for workers in "higher-risk" settings, including dine-in eateries, gyms, and personal care services, starting from next week. The testing will use antigen rapid tests and can be done through self-swabs supervised by employers. The government will also set up quick test centres for small businesses and provide DIY test kits for individuals who may have been exposed to the virus. The aim is to strengthen ringfencing around cases and reduce the risk of infection.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Friday, down 2.8 points or 0.2% to 1,568.0. Volume was 122.3 million lots worth RM56.5 million. Gainers outpaced losers 133 to 113.

site_title: Health experts warn of Olympic Covid-19 threat, prefer no spectators
summary: Japan's top medical experts warn that holding the Olympics during the Covid-19 pandemic could increase infections, recommending a ban on all spectators as the least risky option. The experts, led by Shigeru Omi, cited the event's scale and social interest, as well as the risk of infections spreading during the Games. Tokyo 2020 organizers, however, want to allow up to 10,000 spectators, sparking a possible collision with the health advisers.

site_title: Malaysia's Carsome weighs US listing with SPAC as option
summary: Carsome, a Southeast Asian online used car platform, is considering a US listing, potentially making it Malaysia's first unicorn. The startup is working with advisers to seek a US$2 billion valuation through a merger with a special purpose acquisition company or conventional IPO. A pre-IPO funding round aims to raise US$150 million, and a deal could be finalized by the end of the year.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks end lower
summary: Japanese stocks closed lower on Friday, with the Topix index falling 0. per cent to 1,946.56, as financial stocks and Toyota's retreat from a record high weighed on the market. The unclear direction of US interest rates and concerns over the potential for COVID-19 infections at the upcoming Olympics, which may allow up to 10,000 spectators, contributed to market uncertainty. This has made it difficult for investors to allocate money, according to Credit Suisse's chief investment officer.

site_title: Indonesia gets US$800m loan from World Bank for policy reform
summary: Indonesia received a US$800 million loan from the World Bank to accelerate policy reforms in trade and investment. The loan aims to open more sectors to private investment, particularly in renewable energy, and improve access to basic food and manufacturing. This is part of the government's efforts to deepen financial markets and strengthen disaster response programs. The loan is the latest in the World Bank's support for Indonesia, following at least US$900 million in loans provided this year.

site_title: Supreme Court backs Nestle, Cargill on child slavery suit
summary: The US Supreme Court ruled in favor of Nestle and Cargill, rejecting a lawsuit alleging the companies were complicit in child slavery on Ivory Coast cocoa farms. The court held that the allegations lacked a sufficient US connection to proceed under the 1789 Alien Tort Statute. The decision limits claims of human rights abuses committed abroad, making it more difficult for victims to seek justice. The ruling reverses a lower court's decision and is the latest in a series of decisions to limit the ATS, which has been used in US courts to pursue claims for alleged rights abuses committed abroad.

site_title: Two can dine together at F&B outlets from June 21; 5-person cap targeted for mid-July
summary: Food and beverage establishments in Singapore will reopen to diners on June 21, but with a 2-person cap due to concerns about large clusters. The initial plan of a 5-person cap was delayed to mid-July. This cautious approach aims to minimize the risk of COVID-19 spikes.

site_title: Pacific undersea cable project sinks after US warns against Chinese participation
summary: The World Bank-led Pacific undersea cable project has been stalled after Pacific island governments declined to award a contract to a Chinese company due to US security concerns. The US had warned against Chinese participation, citing the company's ties to Beijing's intelligence and security services. The project aimed to improve communications in island nations, but the US concerns led to a stalemate, with the World Bank stating that all three bids were deemed non-compliant. The project's connection to a sensitive cable in Guam also heightened security concerns.

site_title: Indoor mask-off fitness activities may resume in groups of 2 or classes of 30
summary: Singapore has given the green light for indoor mask-off fitness activities to resume in groups of 2 or classes of 30, including the instructor, starting June 21. This follows the suspension of indoor mask-off activities. Meanwhile, indoor mask-on activities and outdoor mask-off activities are allowed in groups of 5 and 30, respectively, with the same restrictions. The multi-ministry taskforce made the announcement in an update on June 18, 2021.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei index opens higher
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index opened 0.3% higher on Friday, driven by US high-tech shares. The benchmark index rose 75.82 points to 29,094.15. In contrast, the Topix index slipped 0.2% to 1,959.80. The focus shifted to the Bank of Japan's policy decision later in the day.

site_title: Privacy chief sounds alarm over live facial recognition
summary: UK's Information Commissioner Elizabeth Denham warns of risks from live facial recognition technology, urging organizations to prioritize people's privacy. She expresses concerns over the technology's potential for misuse, including discrimination and targeted advertising. The EU has proposed new rules requiring facial recognition systems to undergo audits before deployment to prevent discrimination. Denham calls for a more cautious approach, stating people should be free to move without their biometric data being collected and analyzed.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares kick off on front foot on Friday
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened with slight gains on Friday, extending the previous day's advances. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.1% to 28,586.04, while the Shanghai Composite Index dipped 0.1% and the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.1%. The gains come as traders await the Federal Reserve's decision on tapering monetary policy and interest rates.

site_title: ecoWise requests suspension as directors disagree on response to SGX RegCo queries
summary: ecoWise Holdings, a CATALIST-listed environmental solutions provider, has requested a trading suspension due to disagreements among its directors regarding responses to queries from Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) on June 14. The company needs more time to gather information and update shareholders, citing recent developments in its operations. This is not an indication of wrongdoing, and the suspension is intended to ensure orderly trading. Shares last traded at 7.8 Singapore cents on June 14.

site_title: KGI positive on IReit's Decathlon acquisition in France, initiates with 'outperform'
summary: KGI Securities has initiated an "outperform" rating on IReit Global with a target price of S$0.69, citing the potential benefits of its proposed Decathlon acquisition in France. The acquisition is expected to reduce tenant and geographical concentration risk, while potentially increasing distribution per unit and yield accretion. KGI expects the French economy and sporting goods industry to rebound strongly, driven by forecasted 13% turnover growth in 2021. The brokerage also notes that IReit's vacancy rate and headline rents remain stable, and that stabilizing foreign office markets will compress yield premiums.

site_title: North Korea's Kim opens door for dialogue with Biden
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un has opened the door for dialogue with US President Joe Biden, stating he is ready for "both dialogue and confrontation." This comes as Biden's special representative for North Korea, Sung Kim, is set to hold talks with counterparts from Seoul and Tokyo. Kim's comments are seen as a possible response to Biden's criticism of North Korea's arms buildup, and may offer encouragement to South Korean President Moon Jae-in to resume stalled nuclear negotiations. However, it remains unclear if North Korea is genuinely interested in resuming talks or is simply seeking to improve relations.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall at Friday's open; STI slips 0.3%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.3% at the open on Friday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) dipping to 3,128.71. This comes amid a mixed performance on Wall Street overnight, where investors shifted to buying technology giants and shunning energy equities. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.6% and the S&P 500 dipped less than 0.1%. Local stocks such as Advanced Systems and MC Payment were among the top performers, while OCBC fell 1.2% after announcing the appointment of its new group COO.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end higher, post fifth straight weekly gain
summary: South Korean stocks closed higher, posting a fifth straight weekly gain, with the Kospi index rising 2.97 points to 3,267.93. Despite hawkish signals from the US Federal Reserve, the benchmark index rebounded from a decline on Thursday. For the week, it rose 0.57% and for the year, it's up 13.73%. Foreigners sold $725.38 million worth of shares, while technology giants Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix fell 0.49% and 1.58%, respectively.

site_title: Dollar surges to 2-month high on Fed rate-hike projection
summary: The US dollar surged to a two-month high against a basket of currencies on Thursday, following the Federal Reserve's projection of interest rate hikes and an end to emergency bond-buying sooner than expected. The dollar index rose 0.5% to 91.892, its highest since mid-April. Analysts predict the dollar's strength will be temporary, citing a broader global economic recovery and the currency's high valuation.

site_title: DBS says all duplicated card transactions refunded on June 19, day after incident
summary: DBS, Singapore's largest bank, has resolved a payment processing glitch that caused duplicate card transactions, resulting in double charges for some customers. The issue was reported on Friday and resolved on Saturday, with automatic refunds expected to be completed by the weekend. DBS has apologized for any inconvenience caused and waived any fees or charges. The Monetary Authority of Singapore has instructed DBS to conduct a thorough investigation and will take supervisory actions if the bank falls short of expectations.

site_title: Stocks to watch: OCBC, Prime US Reit, SGX, MC Payment, Advanced Systems
summary: OCBC appointed Lim Khiang Tong as group chief operating officer, driving transformation. Prime US Reit is in talks with WeWork to restructure a lease, but expects no impact on distribution per unit. SGX plans to add asset classes to its product suite. TVV received a letter of intent from Indonesia-based payments company Dompet Harapan Bangsa to take a strategic stake in MC Payment. Advanced Systems is consolidating shares and proposing a bonus issue. These developments may affect trading of these companies' securities.

site_title: Share of households in condos, apartments up almost 5 percentage points as proportion in HDB flats slips 3.7 points: census
summary: Singapore's household income rose 3.3% per annum to S$7,744 in 2020, with median monthly household income per member increasing 4.2% to S$2,463. Households earning S$20,000 or more now account for 13.9%, more than doubling from 6.6%. The proportion of households in condominiums and apartments rose to 16%, while those in Housing Board flats fell to 78.7%. The data will inform policy reviews and urban planning, particularly to enable more people to work close to home.

site_title: MC Payment receives letter of intent from Indonesia's OY! for equity stake
summary: MC Payment, an Indonesia-based digital payments company, received a letter of intent from OY! to explore a strategic equity stake. The letter, dated June 14, does not constitute legally binding obligations. OY! aims to work with MC Payment's associate in Indonesia and leverage its regional network for expansion. MC Payment, listed on the Catalist, closed at S$0.33 on Thursday, down 2.9%. The deal is subject to a formal term sheet or memorandum of understanding agreement at a later stage.

site_title: Malaysia's biggest IPO in 2021 draws Aberdeen, AIA
summary: Malaysia's CTOS Digital Bhd, a credit reporting agency, is in talks to sign Aberdeen Standard Investments and AIA Group as cornerstone investors for its planned IPO, which could be the country's biggest listing this year. The company aims to sell shares for up to RM1.10 each, raising RM1.2 billion. CTOS plans to file a prospectus before the end of the month, when it will confirm the investors and pricing. This follows a slow IPO market in Malaysia, with only US$84.3 million raised in 2021 through first-time share sales.

site_title: Asia has wary welcome for G-7's answer to Belt and Road Initiative
summary: The Group of Seven (G-7) nations have proposed the Build Back Better World (B3W) initiative to counter China's Belt and Road Initiative (BRI), a challenge to China's growing influence in developing economies. Asian countries, including Indonesia and the Philippines, welcome the initiative but have doubts about Western commitment to emerging market projects. A challenge for B3W will be matching China's speed in engaging developing economies, and the initiative's multilateral nature may make it slower-moving than BRI.

site_title: Debt-funded acquisitions could give S-Reit's DPUs a shot in the arm: report
summary: A report by Maybank Kim Eng suggests that debt-funded acquisitions could boost distribution per unit (DPU) of Singapore real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) by up to 15% due to low interest rates. The report also expects developers and Reits to incorporate green features to gain access to funding and interest rate savings. Additionally, office assets are expected to see robust investment activity, despite some occupiers trimming space in the central business district (CBD) to curb costs.

site_title: China's new home price growth stabilises in May amid raft of cooling measures
summary: China's new home prices grew 0.6% in May, unchanged from April, according to official data. This marks a slowdown in price growth, with 62 cities reporting monthly gains. Despite this, prices remain elevated, with a 4.9% year-on-year increase. The government's cooling measures, including stricter rules and higher mortgage rates, are expected to continue to temper gains, with forecasts predicting a 5% growth rate for the year.

site_title: SGX's multi-asset strategy could evolve to include more asset classes: CEO
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) CEO Loh Boon Chye suggests the bourse's multi-asset strategy could evolve to include more asset classes, such as tokenized real estate, private equity, and decentralized finance, over the next five years. SGX has already expanded its offerings through acquisitions and partnerships, and plans to continue this growth through disciplined acquisitions and partnerships. The bourse expects medium-term revenue to rise to the "high single-digit" and is investing in technology to enhance efficiency and minimize costs. Analysts are optimistic about SGX's growth prospects, with several raising their target prices.

site_title: Richard Li-backed insurer FWD files for US$2b IPO in US
summary: FWD, a Hong Kong-based insurer backed by billionaire Richard Li, has filed a confidential draft registration with the US Securities and Exchange Commission for a potential US$2 billion initial public offering (IPO). The planned listing could value the insurer at around US$13 billion. FWD has reported a net loss of US$243 million in 2020, but its new business value reached US$617 million, a 24% increase from the previous year. The insurer has considered various options, including a US listing through a merger with a special purpose acquisition company.

site_title: US dollar at highest level in more than two months
summary: The US dollar reached its highest level in over two months, rising 0.5% to 91.825 on the US dollar index, after the Federal Reserve signaled it would raise interest rates and end emergency bond-buying sooner than expected. This move led to a decline in equities and a rise in US Treasury yields. The euro fell to a two-month low against the US dollar, while the pound and Canadian dollar lost ground against the US dollar.

site_title: Nuevocor raises US$24m in oversubscribed Series A round to target genetic heart disease
summary: Nuevocor, a biotech startup, has raised $24 million in an oversubscribed Series A round to develop gene therapies for genetic heart disease, specifically dilated cardiomyopathy caused by mutations in the lamin A gene. The company's therapy aims to modulate the activity of another gene to suppress the bad effects of the mutated gene, rather than replacing the faulty gene with a normal one. The funding will be used to advance its research and move closer to clinical trials.

site_title: Cathay Pacific working with Airbus on single-pilot programme
summary: Cathay Pacific is working with Airbus on a single-pilot programme for long-haul flights, aiming to certify its A350 jet for solo operations by 2025. The programme, known as Project Connect, promises savings for airlines amid post-pandemic uncertainty but faces hurdles, including resistance from pilots and safety concerns. Regulatory approval, pilot training, and extensive testing are required before commercial implementation, which will need backing from the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) and countries whose airspace they cross.

site_title: The US averted one housing crisis, but another is in the wings
summary: The US housing market has largely avoided the dire predictions of the pandemic, with no eviction wave materializing despite predictions of widespread evictions. However, a new report by Harvard's Joint Center for Housing Studies reveals that a growing housing crisis is on the horizon, with millions of households struggling to make housing payments, particularly lower-income households and people of color. The federal eviction moratorium is set to expire, leaving tenants vulnerable to eviction, with some advocates pushing for a one- to two-month extension. The crisis highlights the need for increased housing assistance and support for low-income households to recover from the pandemic.

site_title: Strong external outlook likely to benefit Singapore's exports
summary: Singapore's exports remained resilient in May, with non-oil domestic exports (NODX) rising 8.8% year-on-year, according to Enterprise Singapore. Economists are optimistic about export growth in the coming quarters, driven by a strong global trade recovery. This positive outlook is expected to benefit the country's economy despite some uncertainty ahead, with many experts fairly optimistic about the export growth prospects.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: WeWork has approached Prime US Reit to restructure its lease at a California property, occupying 56,977 square feet. Ascendas Reit priced 300 million euros of unsecured notes due 2028 with a 0.75% interest rate. Epicentre Holdings agreed to issue new shares and convertible bonds to Transworld Electronic Technology for S$5.4 million, transferring controlling interest. Advanced Systems Automation proposed a 375-to-1 share consolidation and bonus warrants. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed, while Creative Technology warned of below-target revenue and operating loss.

site_title: The message in a reusable wine bottle: Combat climate change
summary: A company called Gotham Project is testing reusable wine bottles that can be returned, sanitized, and reused 10 times or more. The bottles, made of sturdy glass, are sealed with corks and emblazoned with "Return & Reuse." Gotham Project aims to reduce packaging waste and carbon footprint by selling wine in reusable stainless steel kegs. The company is working with a small group of retailers and restaurants in three states to test the reusable bottles, which are a natural evolution of traditional wine packaging methods. The goal is to minimize waste and promote sustainability in the wine industry.

site_title: Supercycle price surges . . . will inflation ease?
summary: Supercycle prices surge, with food prices rising at their fastest in many parts of the world, amid economic adjustments post-pandemic. Economists weigh in on the drivers of these movements and whether they signal a long-term inflation trend.

site_title: Poaching frenzy in cybersecurity: Curbs on foreign hiring triggers scramble
summary: Cybersecurity professionals in Singapore are facing a talent shortage, with poaching being a stopgap measure due to border closures and tighter hiring rules for foreigners. The industry is struggling to build manpower, with the Ministry of Manpower naming cybersecurity professionals as one of the top 10 emerging workforce roles. Recruitment firms report high demand for skilled staff, with average pay bumps of 8-12% for tech talent and up to 30% for niche talent. Training programs, such as the Cyber Security Associates and Technologies programme, are being implemented to address the shortage, but experts warn that poaching is an unhealthy habit that will not be sustainable in the long run.

site_title: US FCC proposes ban on Chinese surveillance cameras, other products
summary: The US Federal Communications Commission (FCC) has proposed a ban on products from five Chinese electronics companies, including Huawei Technologies and Hangzhou Hikvision Digital Technology, citing national security risks. The ban targets surveillance cameras used in US schools and local government facilities, which are linked to alleged human rights abuses in China. The FCC's order, adopted in a 4-0 vote, begins a period of review before a final vote. The move is seen as a step to exclude untrusted equipment and vendors from US communications networks, following years of warnings about Huawei's security risks.

site_title: Nielsen now knows when you are streaming
summary: Nielsen has introduced a new metric, "The Gauge," to measure streaming TV viewership, allowing for more accurate comparisons between traditional TV and streaming services. According to Nielsen, 64% of American viewers spent time watching network and cable TV in May 2021, while 26% watched streaming services, with Netflix and YouTube leading the way. Streaming shares have increased rapidly, from 14% in 2019 to 33% by the end of the year, with Nielsen anticipating this growth. The Gauge is seen as a significant step forward for Nielsen, which has faced criticism for undercounting TV ratings during the pandemic.

site_title: Father time
summary: Father's Day is a perfect occasion to gift Dad a watch, symbolizing permanence and a timeless message. A Lange & Sohne's Lane 1 Perpetual Calendar ($157,780) and Panerai's Officine Submersible Blue Notte ($15,500) are notable options, featuring innovative designs and precise timekeeping. Other watches, such as Franck Muller's Skafander ($23,800) and Zenith's Chronomaster Revival Safari ($13,100), offer unique features and styles.

site_title: IOI Properties said to have triggered Marina View plot
summary: IOI Properties Group has triggered the release of a 0.78-hectare site in Marina View from the government's reserve list for the 2021 Government Land Sales Programme. The site, with a 99-year leasehold tenure, can be developed into 905 private homes, 540 hotel rooms, and 21,528 sq ft of commercial space. The site will be released for sale by public tender on June 28, with a minimum bid price of S$1.508 billion or S$1,379 per square foot per plot ratio.

site_title: Wise plans to pioneer direct London listing
summary: Wise, a British fintech firm, plans to list directly on the London Stock Exchange without raising funds, in a move that boosts the UK government's efforts to attract tech firms to its capital markets. The listing, expected to value Wise at $6-7 billion, will be finalized on July 5 and will have a minimum free float of 25%. Wise has been profitable since 2017 and has seen 54% annual revenue growth. The direct listing is a cheaper and more transparent way for Wise to broaden its ownership, aligning with its mission.

site_title: Luxury meets thrift for Dubai startup raising funds to go abroad
summary: Dubai-based startup The Luxury Closet has raised $14 million in equity funding to expand internationally, marrying luxury with thrift. The platform, which lists 60,000 luxury items, aims to capitalize on the growing global resale market, valued at $40 billion. With the funds, the company plans to enter new markets, following its success in the US, where it is the second-largest market after the Gulf. The Luxury Closet's CEO, Kunal Kapoor, expects one in six transactions to be pre-owned by the end of the decade.

site_title: Critical interviews for critical jobs
summary: A critical interview is not just about the interviewee, but also about the interviewer. To succeed, it's essential to establish a sense of belonging and connection. The key to a successful interview is to prepare, focus on the interviewer, and read people well. The three rules to follow are: allow space to prepare yourself, it's not about you, and pay close attention to the interviewer. By applying these principles, you can create a meaningful purpose for your interview and increase your chances of success.

site_title: Insurers tighten cyber cover terms, raise premiums amid cyber attacks
summary: Insurers are tightening cyber insurance terms and raising premiums due to the surge in cyber attacks amid the pandemic. Firms with inadequate risk management protocols may see their coverage reduced or withdrawn, particularly for ransomware risk. This shift is a response to the growing threat of cyber attacks, which have intensified as offices transition to remote work.

site_title: Phuket set to welcome vaccinated tourists from July 1
summary: Thailand's Phuket island is set to reopen to fully vaccinated tourists from countries with low or medium Covid-19 transmission risk on July 1, under the Phuket Sandbox plan. This reopening marks a step towards recovery for Thailand's devastated tourism industry, which accounts for up to 20% of the country's GDP. Vaccinated visitors will not need to undergo quarantine, but must comply with conditions such as staying at government-designated hotels and taking Covid-19 tests. The reopening is seen as a bellwether for the industry, with other tourist destinations hoping to follow suit if the Phuket model proves successful.

site_title: NY grapples with growing presence of homeless in midtown Manhattan
summary: New York City is grappling with a growing homeless presence in midtown Manhattan, largely due to an emergency move by the city to ease crowding in shelters during the pandemic. Many homeless individuals have settled in nearby hotel rooms, while others with mental health and drug issues have become a visible presence in Hell's Kitchen and Times Square. Advocates are calling for more mental health services and single-occupancy rooms for safe shelter, as well as increased housing production for extremely low-income and homeless households. Some city officials have proposed converting hotels into housing for the homeless, with several Democratic mayoral candidates supporting the idea.

site_title: Private equity raising dividend-linked debt like it's 2007
summary: Europe's private equity firms are aggressively borrowing debt to support dividend payouts, with nearly $20.8 billion in leveraged loan deals linked to dividend recapitalizations by early June, the highest in 14 years. This move could jeopardize these firms' prospects as economies reopen and policymakers consider tapering stimulus. Many experts warn that increased debt could lead to financial bankruptcies if another downturn occurs, citing concerns over the fragility of companies with high leverage.

site_title: US jobless claims break streak of declines with surprise increase
summary: US jobless claims increased last week for the first time in seven weeks, breaking a streak of declines. Jobless claims rose to 412,000, seasonally adjusted, in the week ended June 12. This rise was attributed to the reopening of businesses and rehiring of workers. However, the four-week moving average of claims fell to 395,000, the lowest since March 2020. The total number of people receiving aid under all programmes decreased to 14.8 million, down from 30.1 million in the same week last year.

site_title: Europe: Shares snap 9-day winning streak on Fed jitters
summary: European shares ended a 9-day winning streak, closing 0.1% lower, amid hawkish signals from the US Federal Reserve that raised concerns over early policy tightening. Mining stocks fell 2.5% as commodity prices tumbled, while bank stocks rose 0.4% on bond yield increases. The Eurozone inflation rate rose as expected, driven by energy price spikes and more expensive services.

site_title: Artists at Art Basel reflect the times
summary: Art Basel's first curator-led virtual fair, Art Basel Online Viewing Rooms (OVR) Portals, features 94 top galleries from around the world, including David Zwirner and Victoria Miro. The fair showcases artworks that reflect the times, such as American artist Vanessa German's sculpture "HEAVY," which encapsulates the artist's feelings on the pandemic and Black Lives Matter. The virtual exhibition invites viewers to investigate beyond the appearance of the artworks, highlighting the fair's focus on exploring the zeitgeist. The fair runs until June 19.

site_title: Biden-Putin summit surprises, but ties still frozen
summary: US President Joe Biden held a summit with Russian President Vladimir Putin, describing the talks as "positive" and "constructive", but little substantive progress was made on pressing issues like climate change and Ukraine. Despite the diplomatic language, US concerns about Russia's behavior are growing, including recent cyber hacks and military escalation at the Ukraine border. The two sides agreed to return ambassadors, but their relationship appears frozen, with Putin expressing no great hopes for improved ties. Biden stressed a desire for a "stable and predictable relationship", but the outlook for Washington's relations with Moscow appears poor in the immediate term.

site_title: Indonesia takes taper talk in stride, holds rates at record low
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, maintained its benchmark interest rate at a record low of 3.5% for the fourth consecutive month, supporting a pandemic-hit economy and shielding the rupiah from volatility sparked by the US Federal Reserve's hawkish message. Governor Perry Warjiyo stated that the decision is consistent with low inflation projections and aims to strengthen the national economic recovery by keeping policy accommodative to boost lending to businesses. The move is expected to help shield the rupiah from further decline amid taper talk and global financial volatility.

site_title: More millennials want to work outside their home, here's why
summary: More Singaporeans are moving out of family homes and into co-living properties and serviced residences due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The shift is attributed to the need for soundproof and spacious work areas, as well as the desire for a sense of community and social interaction. Occupancy rates for co-living and serviced residences have increased, with some operators seeing a 90% occupancy rate. Reasons for the increase include the delay in home renovations, the need for temporary housing solutions, and the appeal of shorter leases. Operators are adapting their offerings to meet the changing needs of tenants, including upgrading features such as desks, wifi systems, and luxury furnishings. As remote work becomes the new normal, co-living companies are expected to remain popular with Singaporeans even when international travel resumes.

site_title: Pricey lumber, scarce materials hit US homebuilding
summary: US homebuilding rebounded less than expected in May, with permits for future construction falling to a 7-month low and housing completions declining. Very expensive lumber and material shortages continued to constrain builders, driving up prices and contributing to higher inflation. Housing starts rose 3.6% to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.572 million units, but demand remains strong, and inventories are expected to remain tight. The housing market boom is driven by demand for bigger and more expensive accommodations amid the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: South Korea's largest mobile carrier plans US$5 billion splurge to become next SoftBank
summary: SK Telecom, South Korea's largest mobile carrier, plans to spend $5 billion over three years to invest in tech startups, aiming to become the next SoftBank Group. The company's senior executive, Huh Seok-joon, stated that the goal is to boost the company's share price and increase shareholder value. SK Telecom will split its business into two companies, one focusing on steady cash flows and dividends, and the other on investment and IPOs. The company also plans to introduce a quarterly dividend and cancel treasury shares, and aims to boost its net asset value by 30% annually to $89 billion by 2025.

site_title: Dude food for Dad's Day
summary: For Father's Day, food delivery remains the default option, offering a range of "dude food" options. Carne, a burger eatery, stands out with its use of hormone-free, grass-fed beef and locally grown greens, while Larry & the Birds offers zany, crunchiest fried chicken. Salted & Hung offers a porchetta set, and Decker Barbecue serves up authentic Texas-style barbecue. Artichoke has created a takeaway menu themed around poultry, priced at S$160 for a Middle Eastern-influenced meal for four. Combo packs and combo meals are also available at these restaurants.

site_title: Xi taps top lieutenant to lead China's chip battle against US
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping has appointed Liu He, his economic czar, to lead the development of third-generation chips and provide financial and policy support to domestic chipmakers. This move aims to help China overcome US sanctions that have hindered its chipmaking industry. Liu He will oversee a trillion-dollar government funding initiative, which includes financial support for chip projects, research programs, and strategic electronics materials. The effort is seen as a crucial step for China to achieve technology self-sufficiency and counter the US's efforts to dominate the chip industry.

site_title: China-made Tesla Model Y sales jump as bigger cars gain traction
summary: Tesla sales of China-made Model Y cars more than doubled in May, reaching 12,785 registrations, up from 5,520 in April. Registrations of the Model 3 sedan also increased, with 9,324 units sold. Despite concerns over a protest and security risks, demand appears to be rebounding. Data from China's Passenger Car Association shows Tesla's China shipments rebounded in May, with 33,463 locally made vehicles sold. The company is expected to see increased interest in larger, roomier cars, particularly in the seven-seater category.

site_title: Bank, airline sites go dark in Internet outage
summary: A global internet outage affected financial institutions, governments, and airlines, including Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing and Australia's central bank, on June 17, 2021. The outage was linked to a failure at Akamai Technologies, a web services provider. Many websites recovered within an hour, with companies including Commonwealth Bank of Australia and Southwest Airlines investigating the incident. This marks the second global internet outage in as many weeks, highlighting the vulnerability of major websites to disruptions and cyber attacks.

site_title: Saudi Aramco raises US$6b in debut Islamic bond sale
summary: Saudi Aramco successfully raised $6 billion from its first dollar-denominated Islamic bond sale, following two previous non-compliant offerings. The three-tranche sukuk bonds, due in 3, 5, and 10 years, were sold to institutional investors. The funds will help pay an annual $75 billion dividend, a key revenue source for the Saudi government. The sale comes as the company seeks capital to fund its dividend payments and amid Riyadh's efforts to diversify its oil-reliant economy.

site_title: The games must go on: How digital transformation can safely rekindle the spirit of sport
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated the adoption of digital transformation in the sporting world, enabling the safe rekindling of sports. Bio-bubbles and technology have been used to prevent the spread of the virus, with success stories including the Tokyo Olympics and the US Open. Smart sport technology, including IoT and AI, has improved athlete safety, while digital solutions such as cashless ticketing and AI-powered fan tracking have enhanced the fan experience. As sports return to normalcy, these innovations are likely to change the nature of sports for good, prioritizing safety and technology.

site_title: Fed ripples hit Asian markets hardest as rates outlook shifts
summary: The Federal Reserve's interest rate outlook shift has had a significant impact on Asian markets, with the US dollar and Treasury yields surging and local currencies declining. Emerging economies such as India and Indonesia may face constraints on policy flexibility due to the Fed's decision, while central banks in developed markets like New Zealand and Australia may consider rate hikes. The Fed's move has also affected the Bank of Japan, which may benefit from a weaker yen, and the People's Bank of China, which may welcome a shift in expectations for yuan strength.

site_title: US jobless claims break streak of declines with surprise increase
summary: US jobless claims increased for the first time in seven weeks, rising to 412,000 seasonally adjusted in the week ended June 12, breaking a streak of declines. This surge is attributed to the reopening of businesses and rehire efforts, despite COVID-19 vaccines. The increase in claims, particularly under the Pandemic Unemployment Assistance program, marks a reversal of the declining trend in regular claims.

site_title: Vita Coco owner plans IPO at over US$2b value
summary: The owner of coconut water company Vita Coco, All Market Inc, is planning to go public in the US with an estimated valuation of over $2 billion. The company, which also owns Runa energy drinks and Ever & Ever water, aims to list its shares in the third quarter. This move comes after investors flocked to back Oatly Inc's initial public offering, which has seen its shares jump 60% since its May debut, valuing the company at $16 billion. The global wellness market is expected to grow by 5-10% annually, with Vita Coco counting prominent investors such as Madonna and Verlinvest.

site_title: Gold slides below US$1,800 after Fed's hawkish tilt
summary: Gold prices dropped below $1,800 due to the Federal Reserve's hawkish stance, signaling interest rate increases earlier than expected. The Fed's statement also indicated a potential taper of asset purchases and downgraded the risk of the coronavirus pandemic. Despite this, some analysts believe gold may rise if the economic recovery leads to further price increases. Gold futures fell 3.3% to $1,799.80 per ounce, while silver and other precious metals also declined.

site_title: 23andMe DNA-testing firm goes public following Branson deal
summary: 23andMe, a DNA-testing firm, went public after a deal with billionaire Richard Branson's special-purpose acquisition company (SPAC) VG Acquisition. The company's stock rose 7.2% to $11.78 after the merger valued it at $3.5 billion. CEO Anne Wojcicki invested $25 million, and current shareholders own 81% of the combined company. The deal allows 23andMe to bypass an initial public offering, citing increased consumer interest in genomics and novel healthcare modes. The company plans to expand its therapeutics business and uses its data trove for more than 40 drug development programs.

site_title: Rafael Nadal pulls out of Wimbledon and Olympics
summary: Tennis star Rafael Nadal has withdrawn from Wimbledon and the Tokyo Olympics, citing a desire to prolong his career. The 35-year-old, who won titles in 2010 and 2008, made the decision after listening to his body and consulting with his team. Nadal, a two-time Wimbledon champion, will not participate in this year's Wimbledon and Olympic Games, citing it as the right decision for his career.

site_title: US: Nasdaq rallies, Dow falls in post-Fed rotation
summary: US stocks shifted patterns Thursday, buying technology giants and selling financial and energy equities as long-term bond yields retreated. The Nasdaq Composite Index rose 0.9% to 14,161.35, driven by gains from Apple, Facebook, and Amazon. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.6%, while the S&P 500 slipped less than 0.1%. The Federal Reserve signaled an earlier interest rate hike timeline, prompting investors to rotate out of financial and energy shares and into growth stocks.

site_title: Dr. Martens reports 22% rise in earnings
summary: Dr. Martens reported a 22% rise in annual core earnings to £224.2 million, driven by online sales. Revenue rose 15% to £773 million, in line with guidance. The group maintains a target of "high teens" percentage revenue growth in 2021-22 and expects "mid-teens" growth from 2022-23. Dr. Martens targets e-commerce to reach 40% of sales mix, with direct-to-consumer channels making up 60%. The company also expects to begin paying a dividend in the 2021-22 year and maintains a 30% Ebitda margin target.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower as Fed's taper talks drag down tech shares
summary: US stocks fell at the open on Thursday, with the Dow Jones down 0.06% and the S&P 500 down 0.08%, as the Federal Reserve signaled it could start tapering its stimulus earlier than expected, affecting tech shares. The Nasdaq Composite dropped 0.29%. The weakness in tech shares was attributed to the sector's vulnerability to higher interest rates.

site_title: US Open to welcome back tennis fans at 100% capacity
summary: The US Open tennis tournament will welcome back spectators at 100% capacity for its Aug 30-Sept 12 event, marking a return to full capacity after last year's COVID-19 pandemic. Tickets will go on sale to the public on July 15. The US Tennis Association (USTA) aims to provide an unforgettable experience, citing the sport's ability to unite and thrive during challenging times. The event will adhere to CDC guidelines to ensure a safe environment for fans and players.

site_title: Lufthansa to allow check-in with digital vaccine pass
summary: Lufthansa allows passengers to use digital Covid-19 vaccination certificates for check-in, either on phones or printed, starting June 17. The move reduces the risk of misuse of fake certificates. The airline recommends carrying original printed certificates until further notice. This follows Germany's issuance of QR codes for fully vaccinated individuals and EU countries' easing of travel restrictions for fully vaccinated tourists.

site_title: Park Hotel Management's creditor files winding-up application
summary: A creditor, represented by Allen & Gledhill, has filed a winding-up application against Park Hotel Management, a Singapore-based hospitality company. The application, to be heard on July 2, is related to alleged unpaid rent and outstanding debts, specifically at the Grand Park Orchard hotel. Park Hotel Management's sole shareholder and CEO, Allen Law Ching Hung, is also involved in the matter, with his wife serving as an executive director of Park Hotel Group. The outcome of the application is uncertain, but it may lead to the liquidation of Park Hotel Management.

site_title: Blackstone to buy out office developer SOHO China in HK$23.7b deal
summary: Blackstone Group Inc is set to acquire SOHO China Ltd in a HK$23.7 billion deal, maintaining the developer's stock market listing. The US private equity firm will acquire 100% of the company, while the founders will retain a 9% stake. The deal is conditional on Chinese competition authorities granting clearance. This marks Blackstone's largest real estate deal in China, with SOHO China's shares jumping 25.8% after the announcement. The acquisition aims to expand Blackstone's presence in China's office market, which the company is confident about due to the country's long-term economic prospects.

site_title: Hong Kong jobless rate falls third straight month to one-year low
summary: Hong Kong's unemployment rate fell to 6% in May, the lowest level in a year, marking the third consecutive month of decline. The rate is below the consensus forecast of 6.2%. The number of unemployed individuals dropped to 233,300, while total employment increased to 3.63 million. Authorities have reported no new coronavirus cases, and are shortening hotel quarantine for fully vaccinated travelers to seven days. Economists attribute the recovery to rising vaccinations and contained virus risks.

site_title: After EU, Britain and US reach truce in aircraft trade dispute
summary: Britain and the US have reached a truce in their long-standing trade dispute over Airbus and Boeing, agreeing to resolve the issue and turn their attention to tackling Chinese subsidies. The deal, which is similar to a recent EU-US agreement, will lift uncertainty over a key source of transatlantic trade tensions and set aside tariffs for five years. The agreement also commits governments to providing funding on market terms, a move that could benefit industries such as Scotch whisky and aerospace.

site_title: Five luxurious gifts for Dad
summary: Five luxurious gifts for Dad include a Gillette Heated Razor ($299), Bosch Vero Barista 600 coffee machine ($2,099), Gentle Monster-Huawei Smart Glasses ($590), Louis Vuitton LV Volt Cufflinks ($11,000), and Versace Trigreca Sneakers ($1,440), offering unique and high-end presents for the special occasion of Father's Day.

site_title: China flags new rules for commodity price indices from August
summary: China has announced new rules for managing commodity price indices, effective from August 1, aiming to standardize and improve transparency in price data compilation. The National Development and Reform Commission (NDRC) will review compliance and take disciplinary measures for non-compliance. The measures are part of the government's efforts to contain inflation, which has hit its highest in over 12 years due to surging commodity costs. The new rules will require price index providers to be independent and disclose information about their methods.

site_title: Advanced Systems proposes 375-to-1 share consolidation, bonus warrants issue
summary: Advanced Systems Automation (ASA) proposes a 375-to-1 share consolidation and bonus warrants issue, aiming to reduce share price volatility and increase market interest. The consolidation affects approximately 1,901 shareholders holding fewer than 375 shares, who are advised to buy additional shares to remain shareholders. The bonus warrants, worth up to 19.8 million, will be issued to eligible shareholders, potentially increasing the company's capital base and financial flexibility. The proposal is subject to shareholder and listing approvals.

site_title: Britain, pressed by airlines, may ease rules for vaccinated travellers
summary: Britain is considering easing travel rules for double vaccinated people, potentially relaxing quarantine requirements and COVID-19 testing for fully vaccinated tourists. The move aims to placate airlines, which are threatening legal action against the government's current curbs on international travel. The UK has over 50% of its adult population vaccinated, and the decision is seen as a step towards allowing vaccinated travelers to avoid quarantine and tests. Airlines, including Ryanair, have called for the relaxation of rules, and the government has indicated that it is open to reviewing its travel policy.

site_title: Singapore millennials more stressed than global average: survey
summary: Singapore millennials and Gen Zs report higher levels of anxiety and stress compared to the global average, with 45% of millennials and 40% of Gen Zs in Singapore feeling anxious or stressed all or most of the time. Fewer in Singapore have spoken openly to their employers about their feelings, with 65% of millennials and 40% of Gen Zs saying they have not discussed their mental health concerns. The survey also found that 69% of millennials and 66% of Gen Zs believe wealth and income are distributed unequally, with many advocating for government intervention to drive change.

site_title: Putin lavishes post-summit praise on Biden, says media have US leader wrong
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin praised US President Joe Biden, saying media portrayals of him as unfocused and vague were incorrect. At a summit on Wednesday, Biden and Putin agreed to launch arms control and cybersecurity talks, with Putin describing Biden as a "professional" who doesn't miss anything. The Kremlin called the summit "positive" and highlighted a joint statement on avoiding nuclear war. Putin attributed Biden's jet lag to his long trip across the ocean, saying he looked cheerful and composed during their face-to-face meeting.

site_title: Hong Kong approves plan to ease city's strict travel quarantine: sources
summary: Hong Kong is set to shorten its hotel quarantine for fully vaccinated travelers from most places to seven days, as long as they pass an antibody test, in an effort to ease the city's strict travel quarantine policy. The policy change, recommended by a government advisory panel earlier this month, will apply to travelers coming from "low-risk" countries like Australia and New Zealand. However, those from "high-risk" locations, such as the UK and US, will still face the current 21-day quarantine. The policy change aims to boost vaccination rates in the city, where only 24.2% of the population has received a first dose of the vaccine.

site_title: China's Didi adds banks to work on mega US IPO: sources
summary: China's Didi Chuxing, the country's largest ride-hailing company, has appointed five additional investment banks to work as book runners on its US initial public offering (IPO) worth up to $10 billion. The banks, including Bank of America, Barclays, and Citigroup, will work alongside Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley, and JPMorgan. The IPO could be the largest by a Chinese firm in the US in seven years, valuing the company at up to $100 billion. The move comes as China's market regulator begins an antitrust probe into Didi.

site_title: Singapore loses top spot in global competitiveness ranking on unfavourable geography
summary: Singapore has lost its top spot in the global competitiveness ranking, falling to fifth place, according to the Institute for Management Development (IMD) World Competitiveness Ranking 2021. The country's geography, particularly its physical limitations, is cited as a major factor contributing to its decline. Despite this, Singapore remains the most competitive economy in Asia, while China has jumped to 16th place, with estimates suggesting it could soon emerge in the top five globally.

site_title: OTS Holdings ends first day trading 6 Singapore cents above IPO price
summary: OTS Holdings, a food manufacturer, ended its first day of trading 6 Singapore cents above its IPO price of S$0.23, closing at S$0.29. The shares traded within a range of S$0.28 to S$0.31, with 25.7 million shares changing hands. The stock opened at S$0.30, reached an intraday high of S$0.31, and ended at S$0.29. This represents a 30.4% increase from its IPO price.

site_title: Prime US Reit in talks with WeWork on proposed lease restructuring
summary: US coworking space operator WeWork has proposed a lease restructuring with Prime US Reit, a US real estate investment trust, at its California office property. WeWork occupies 56,977 sq ft of the 222,606 sq ft building, contributing less than 2.5% of Prime US Reit's cash rental income. Discussions are ongoing, and the lease terms are currently under evaluation. The proposed restructuring is not expected to impact Prime US Reit's distribution per unit or the value of its portfolio.

site_title: Singapore stocks end Thursday flat, traders remain wary after Federal Reserve meeting
summary: Singapore stocks ended flat on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index rising 0.04% to 3,138.31, after Federal Reserve officials signaled a possible scaling back of policy support and hinted at two interest rate hikes by the end of 2023. Markets across the region also declined, with the Nikkei 225 and Kospi falling 0.9% and 0.4% respectively. Local stocks such as Jardine Matheson Holdings and C07 rose, while banks declined due to concerns over higher interest rates.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's non-oil exports grew 8.8% year on year in May, extending April's gains. This growth fell short of economists' expectations. The May growth rate is the first time the non-oil exports have surpassed the 8% mark since 2018.

site_title: Hong Kong tycoon Richard Li's FWD files for US listing
summary: Hong Kong tycoon Richard Li's insurer FWD has filed for a US initial public offering (IPO) valued at $13 billion to $15 billion, raising $2 billion to $3 billion. The company aims to list on a US exchange, with no disclosed details on the size of the IPO.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong tycoon Richard Li's insurer FWD said it has lodged an application to regulators for an initial public offering (IPO) in the United States.

site_title: Chinese astronauts board space station module in historic mission
summary: China has successfully completed its first crewed mission to its space station, with three astronauts, Nie Haisheng, Liu Boming, and Tang Hongbo, boarding the Tianhe module. This mission marks China's expansion in near-Earth space and challenges US leadership in orbital space. The crew will live on the station for three months, the longest stay by any Chinese national, and will test out technologies including life-support systems. China's space station, expected to be completed by end-2022, will be the only alternative to the International Space Station, potentially giving China greater power in shaping future norms and regulations for near-Earth space.

images.alt_text: The astronauts rode to Tianhe - the module that will be the living quarters of China's completed space station - on Shenzhou-12, or "Divine Vessel".

site_title: A*Star, Arcstone launch joint lab for smart manufacturing solutions
summary: A*Star and Arcstone have launched a joint lab to develop smart manufacturing solutions, investing S$18 million over three years. The lab aims to create next-generation manufacturing execution systems (MES) with integrated technologies like artificial intelligence and the Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT). The collaboration is expected to halve research and development time and create 30 engineering jobs. The joint lab will focus on improving production processes, control, and sustainability, with the goal of boosting digital transformation in the industry.

site_title: Taiwan central bank upgrades economic growth forecast, stands pat on rates
summary: Taiwan's central bank upgraded its economic growth forecast to 5.08% for 2021, citing strong exports and a resilient economy despite local Covid-19 cases. The bank maintained interest rates at a record low of 1.125%, marking the fifth time in a year-and-a-quarter it has kept rates unchanged. GDP growth in the first quarter of 2021 was 8.92%, the strongest quarterly growth in over a decade, and the bank attributed this to global demand for tech products during the pandemic.

site_title: Shell and JTC plan for large solar farm on Semakau Island
summary: Shell and JTC Corporation plan to build Singapore's largest solar farm on Semakau Island, covering an area of 112 football fields and generating 72 megawatt-peak (MWp) of electricity. The project aims to power 17,500 households and reduce carbon dioxide emissions by 37,000 tonnes annually. The project's location near Shell's Pulau Bukom energy and chemicals park will facilitate integration with the company's operations, supporting its goal of becoming a net-zero emissions energy business by 2050.

site_title: OCBC appoints its head of group operations and technology as new COO
summary: OCBC appoints Lim Khiang Tong, head of group operations and technology, as its new group chief operating officer (COO) effective June 21, 2021. The appointment aims to drive transformation and accelerate change. Lim will report to group CEO Helen Wong and oversee the bank's capabilities in technology, data science, and analytics. He will continue to lead the operations and technology functions, focusing on building the bank's capabilities to meet changing customer needs. This appointment is part of OCBC's strategy to establish itself as a leading digitally-empowered financial services group.

site_title: Football: Denmark's Eriksen to get heart starter implant after collapse on pitch
summary: Denmark's Christian Eriksen, who collapsed due to a cardiac arrest during his team's Euro 2020 opener, will receive an Implantable Cardioverter Defibrillator (ICD) after his heart was restarted with a defibrillator on the pitch. Eriksen's life was saved through CPR and hospital treatment, and he is recovering. The ICD, a small electronic device, can prevent fatal cardiac arrests by restoring a regular heart rhythm. Eriksen's heart collapse occurred during the match against Germany on June 12, 2021.

site_title: Indian tycoon Adani loses US$9b in three days in worst wealth rout
summary: Indian billionaire Gautam Adani's fortune plummeted by $9 billion in three days, dropping to $67.6 billion, after a media report raised questions about offshore investors holding $6 billion in Adani Group stocks. The report led investors to rush for the exit, despite Adani Group's claims that the report was "blatantly erroneous." The conglomerate's six listed stocks fell sharply, with flagship Adani Enterprises dropping 15% and Adani Green Energy slipping 7.7%. The incident highlights the risks of opaque ownership and the speculative nature of Adani's stock prices.

images.alt_text: Indian billionaire Gautam Adani's dream run up the global wealth rankings is faltering after a media report raising questions about some offshore investors triggered a rout in his conglomerate's six listed stocks.

site_title: Singapore exports likely to benefit from strong external outlook: economists
summary: Singapore's exports remained resilient in May despite tightened Covid-19 restrictions, with non-oil domestic exports (NODX) rising 8.8% year-on-year. This is a positive sign, particularly since it showed resilience against tightened restrictions. Electronic exports rose 11% and non-electronic exports expanded 8.1%. Exports to China and Hong Kong saw significant gains, while those to the US, Japan, and EU declined. Economists remain optimistic about Singapore's export growth in the coming quarters, citing a strengthening global trade recovery and the reopening in the US and Europe.

images.alt_text: Non-oil domestic exports in May rose 8.8 per cent year on year, extending the previous month's 6 per cent rally, according to Enterprise Singapore on Thursday.

site_title: Medtech startup Aevice Health raises S$2.8m, secures commercialisation partnership
summary: Medtech startup Aevice Health has secured a S$2.8 million pre-Series A funding round and partnered with Tokyo-listed Toho Holdings to develop and commercialize its wearable device AeviceMD. The device, a smart stethoscope, monitors patients with respiratory conditions remotely and detects cardiopulmonary abnormalities. The partnership aims to address the challenges faced by patients in rural Japan, where access to regular care is limited. The collaboration will also expand AeviceMD's reach to the Middle East, North Africa, and South Asia regions through its partnership with THB Global.

site_title: Brokers' take: CGS-CIMB says SPH could see new substantial shareholder, unlock assets
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) may see a new substantial shareholder and unlock value from its assets after transferring its media business to a company limited by guarantee (CLG), analysts from CGS-CIMB said. The brokerage increased its target price on SPH shares to S$2.19 and reiterated an "add" call, citing the group's quality portfolio and stable income. Potential buyers include real estate funds, strategic investors, and companies with similar exposure to SPH's asset management business, such as Keppel Corp. CGS-CIMB estimates that SPH's non-core assets could be worth around S$1.23 billion, potentially ripe for capital recycling.

site_title: Yinson invests in EV battery startup Oyika; analysts positive on its green-tech investments
summary: Malaysia's Yinson Holdings has invested in Oyika, a Singapore startup that offers a battery-swap subscription service for electric vehicles. The investment is in line with Yinson's net-zero carbon ambition and aims to accelerate the adoption of EVs in South-east Asia. Analysts are positive on Yinson's green technology investments, citing potential for growth and first-mover advantage. Oyika aims to reach operational breakeven soon and plans to boost its rider base to 1.2 million by 2025, with an order backlog of 30,000 units.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks snap five-day winning streak on Fed outcome; won drops
summary: South Korean stocks closed lower on Thursday, snapping a five-day rally, after the US Federal Reserve signalled it might raise interest rates earlier than expected. The benchmark Kospi fell 0.42% to 3,264.96, with the won losing nearly 4% to 1,130.4 per dollar. The Fed moved its projected rate increases from 2024 to 2023, and discussed bond purchases. Foreigners were net sellers of 348 billion won worth of shares.

site_title: Singapore among key drivers of surge in demand for life sciences real estate: CBRE
summary: Singapore is a key driver of a surge in demand for life sciences real estate in the Asia-Pacific region, according to CBRE Research. The country's competitive life sciences sector, skilled talent pool, and government funding make it an attractive location for companies in the pharmaceutical, biotechnology, and medical equipment sectors. Other key markets in the region include Shanghai, Tokyo, Beijing, and Melbourne, driven by their advanced manufacturing and R&D capabilities. Demand for life sciences real estate is expected to rise, with CBRE recommending that companies optimize their portfolios and leverage government incentives to stay competitive.

site_title: Australia: Shares close lower after Fed signals policy tightening
summary: Australian shares closed 0.4% lower on Thursday, with mining and energy stocks declining, following the US Federal Reserve's signal of potential policy tightening. The Reserve Bank of Australia Governor Philip Lowe acknowledged the economy's faster-than-expected recovery, but noted it still needed continued stimulus. Despite this, financials rose, and broadcaster Seven West Media jumped 26% after forecasting a 97% earnings jump.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 7.46 points to 1,570.86 on Thursday, closing lower. The market saw a significant loss, with 611 losers outweighing 361 gainers. Volume reached 4.260 billion lots worth RM2.745 billion.

site_title: Bukit Merah View cluster grows to 56; special testing operations for Eng Hoon Street
summary: The Ministry of Health in Singapore announced special testing operations for staff and tenants at affected premises in Redhill and Tiong Bahru. The operations aim to detect and curb community transmission of COVID-19. The Bukit Merah View cluster has grown to 56 cases, the largest open cluster since the MINDSville@Napiri cluster. 27 new cases were reported, including 19 linked to the cluster and 7 imported cases. The total number of cases in Singapore has risen to 62,366.

site_title: Fintech Wise plans to pioneer direct London listing
summary: British fintech firm Wise plans to list on the London Stock Exchange through a direct listing, valued at $6-7 billion, without raising funds. The move is seen as a boost to the British government's efforts to attract technology firms to its capital markets. Wise has been profitable since 2017 and has 54% annual revenue growth, with a freefloat of at least 25% expected. The listing is set to finalize on July 5, following a dual-class share structure that allows the company's founders to retain voting control.

site_title: Australian economy still in recovery phase, needs stimulus: RBA
summary: Australia's economy is still in a recovery phase from a pandemic recession and will need continued policy stimulus, according to Reserve Bank of Australia Governor Philip Lowe. Lowe emphasized that wages growth and inflation are subdued, and that wage increases will need to be higher than recent levels to meet the 2-3% inflation target. The RBA has signaled no cash rate increase until 2024, and will review its bond buying program to support the ongoing recovery.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower on profit-taking
summary: Tokyo stocks closed down 0.9% on Thursday, with the Nikkei 225 index falling to 29,018.33, due to profit-taking after the Federal Reserve hinted at interest rate hikes. A cheaper yen against the dollar offered some support, while Japanese shares were also impacted by concerns over a potential rebound of infections. Key movers included Sony and SoftBank Group, which fell, while Toyota rose. The government announced plans to lift Tokyo's virus emergency on June 20, a month before the Olympics.

site_title: Hong Kong: Fed's recovery optimism lifts stocks higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended higher on Thursday, driven by the Federal Reserve's optimistic view of the US recovery, with the Hang Seng index rising 121.75 points or 0.43%. China's tech shares climbed on reports of policy support from Beijing, and the yuan weakened 0.5% against the US dollar. The top gainer was BYD, while Haidilao International Holding fell 3.68%. The Fed's policy statement marked a strong vote of confidence in the US recovery, with officials projecting an accelerated timetable for interest rate increases and ending crisis-era bond-buying.

site_title: Bank, airline sites go dark briefly in broad Internet outage
summary: A global internet outage briefly affected websites operated by financial institutions, governments, and airlines, including the Reserve Bank of Australia, Commonwealth Bank of Australia, and Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing. The outage, linked to Akamai Technologies, a web services management provider, was the second such incident in as many weeks. Most affected websites recovered within an hour, with companies like Southwest Airlines and Hong Kong's exchange investigating the incident. The outage highlighted the vulnerability of the world's biggest websites to disruptions, including simple human error and coordinated cyberattacks.

site_title: Brokers' take: Analysts positive on Suntec Reit's sale of Penang Road asset
summary: Suntec Reit has sold its 30% stake in 9 Penang Road to its joint venture partner, Haiyi Holdings, for S$2,468 per square foot, a 5.7% premium to its latest valuation. Analysts from RHB, Jefferies, and Citi Research are positive on the move, citing improved gearing levels and enhanced unitholder value. The divestment is expected to have minimal impact on the Reit's distribution per unit and office portfolio, with analysts anticipating a favorable market reaction.

site_title: Asia's private capital industry to hit US$6.1t by 2025, but structural challenges remain: Preqin
summary: Asia's private capital industry is expected to reach $6.1 trillion by 2025, driven by growing institutional investors and a large middle class. Despite this growth, structural challenges persist, including business owners' reluctance to cede control and limited financing options. Alternative assets data provider Preqin attributes the industry's slow growth to these challenges, which have made it difficult for investors to deploy capital. The region's emerging markets, particularly Southeast Asia, are seen as key drivers of growth, with Asean projected to become the fourth-largest economy by 2050.

site_title: Epicentre to issue new shares and bonds, cede controlling interest to Transworld
summary: Epicentre Holdings has agreed to issue new shares and convertible bonds to Transworld Electronic Technology for S$5.4 million, resulting in the transfer of its controlling interest to Transworld. The investment aims to provide recovery to creditors and working capital for the company. The shares will be issued at 0.1 Singapore cent per share, and the convertible bonds will bear a 5% per annum interest rate, maturing in 36 months. The deal is part of Epicentre's efforts to address its financial issues following the suspension of its shares from trading in 2019.

site_title: Europe: Shares slip from record highs on hawkish Fed
summary: European shares slipped from record highs on Thursday, following overnight declines on Wall Street after the Federal Reserve hinted at potentially starting to taper its stimulus sooner than expected. The Stoxx 600 index fell 0.4% to snap a nine-day winning streak, with mining, utility, and technology stocks leading declines. The news also led to a 0.3% decline in S&P 500 futures, as the Fed's interest rate hike timeline was revised to 2023, a year earlier than initially expected.

site_title: Japan to issue vaccine passport for travel abroad
summary: Japan plans to issue a paper-based vaccine passport for Japanese travelers starting next month, allowing them to visit foreign countries. The certificate will be issued by local governments and feature vaccination information. This move comes as governments worldwide experiment with vaccine travel documents to relaunch tourism and business trips. Japan's vaccine rollout has picked up pace, with just over 6% of the population fully vaccinated. The country's borders remain closed to almost all foreign arrivals, except for the upcoming Olympic Games in Tokyo.

site_title: TikTok owner ByteDance's revenue up 111% to US$34.3b in 2020: source
summary: ByteDance, the owner of TikTok, reported a 111% increase in revenue to US$34.3 billion in 2020, with gross profit reaching US$19 billion and operating loss totaling US$2 billion. The company also reported a net loss of US$45 billion. These figures represent significant growth for the company.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 4.58 points, or 0.29%, to 1,573.74. The market saw 252 losers compared to 140 gainers, with a total trading volume of 275.38 million lots worth RM105.01 million.

site_title: Ant inching closer to IPO as valuation drops 60%, Bernstein says
summary: Ant Group, a Chinese fintech giant, may list its shares by the end of this year despite a 60% drop in valuation. The company's estimated worth could be around $120 billion due to slower revenue growth. Ant Group must inject $6.24 billion to $40 billion into its new consumer finance unit to support credit growth. The company has made progress in overhauling its business and becoming compliant with regulatory requirements, paving the way for its planned IPO.

site_title: Asia: Prospect of earlier Federal Reserve rate hike sends markets lower
summary: Asian markets fell on Thursday as the Federal Reserve brought forward its interest rate hike forecasts, citing concerns of overheating in the US economy. The Fed's "dot plot" showed 11 policymakers now expect at least two rate hikes in 2023, up from seven in March. The dollar surged against major currencies, while Asian stocks were mostly down, with Hong Kong flat and Shanghai slightly up. The Fed's decision was seen as a sign that it may be moving away from ultra-easy monetary policy and towards a more gradual approach.

images.alt_text: Asian markets mostly fell on Thursday and the dollar held strong gains after the Federal Reserve brought forward its forecasts for hiking interest rates as it looks to prevent overheating in the US economy, which is enjoying a blockbuster recovery.

site_title: Microsoft names Nadella chair, Thompson remains on board
summary: Microsoft has named CEO Satya Nadella as board chairman, strengthening his influence at the company after seven years as top executive. Nadella, 53, succeeds John Thompson, who will return to lead independent director, a role he held before becoming chairman in 2014.
