This change is a vote of confidence in Nadella, who has led Microsoft's rebirth around cloud computing, mobile applications, and artificial intelligence, resulting in a sevenfold increase in shares and a market value approaching $2 trillion.

site_title: Re-entry rate of retrenched workers up, job vacancies grew in first quarter
summary: Singapore's labour market is showing signs of recovery, with total employment growing by 12,200 in the first quarter, exceeding initial estimates. The re-entry rate for retrenched residents has improved, with 66.2% finding work within six months. Job vacancies also rose to 68,400, nearing parity with the unemployed population. However, the government warns that the recovery path will be uneven, with sectors such as construction facing a labour crunch due to entry restrictions on foreign workers.

site_title: China state planner to issue new rules on commodity price indexes
summary: China's National Development and Reform Commission plans to issue new rules on commodity price indexes, effective August 1. The rules standardize the compilation process and improve transparency, requiring price index providers to be independent and disclose information about their methods. Authorities will review compliance and take disciplinary measures for non-compliance, aiming to enhance the credibility of China's commodity markets. The move follows the government's increased scrutiny of the country's commodity markets.

site_title: MAS further extends US$60b swap facility with US Fed through December
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has extended its US$60 billion swap facility with the US Federal Reserve through December 31, 2021. This arrangement provides up to US$60 billion of backstop funding to support US dollar lending to businesses in Singapore and the region. The facility, initially established in March 2020, has already provided about US$25 billion to banks since its launch. The extension aims to promote stability in USD funding conditions and supports the economic recovery in Singapore and the region.

site_title: Malaysia's biggest IPO in 2021 draws Aberdeen, AIA
summary: Malaysia's CTOS Digital, a credit reporting agency, is set to file a prospectus for its initial public offering (IPO) with a valuation of approximately US$585 million. Cornerstone investors include Aberdeen Standard Investments and AIA Group, with discussions ongoing with Eastspring Investments Bhd, Fidelity International, and local asset managers. The IPO aims to raise around RM1.2 billion (S$388.4 million) at a share price of RM1.10 each, potentially making it Malaysia's biggest listing this year. The company plans to confirm cornerstone investors before the end of the month.

site_title: New Zealand economy back to pre-pandemic levels
summary: New Zealand's economy has returned to pre-pandemic levels, growing 1.6% in the first quarter of 2021, exceeding forecasts. This growth reverses a 1.0% contraction in the previous quarter, driven by spending on hospitality and retail goods. The economy has largely contained the coronavirus, allowing minimal restrictions, and a booming housing market has fueled construction. Analysts predict the central bank may ease monetary policy by May next year, indicating a strong economic recovery.

site_title: Most Singaporeans unsatisfied with generic financing solutions from banks: survey
summary: A recent survey by FICO found that 76% of Singaporeans are dissatisfied with generic credit offers from banks, with many seeking preferential pricing solutions and faster access to funds. To build loyalty, banks can offer personalized offers in exchange for more financial information. The survey also revealed that Singaporeans expect quick access to loaned funds, with 56% expecting access within a week. FICO suggests that banks can deepen relationships with customers and move past single-product pricing to engage in improved cross-selling and product penetration.

site_title: DBS to be anchor investor in a special situations debt fund by Muzinich Asia Pacific
summary: DBS, South-east Asia's largest bank, has announced it will be the anchor investor in a special situations private debt fund by Muzinich Asia Pacific, injecting up to US$200 million. The investment aims to support companies affected by the Covid-19 pandemic, with DBS seeking growth exposure to recovery opportunities in the Asia-Pacific region. The fund, which has US$39.3 billion in assets under management, will focus on private debt solutions for lower middle-market companies and incorporates an Environmental, Social and Governance (ESG) conscious approach.

site_title: Australia's May employment surges 115,200, jobless drops to 5.1%
summary: Australia's employment surged 115,200 in May, exceeding forecasts, with unemployment dropping to 5.1%, the lowest since the pandemic began. This marks a significant recovery from a high of 7.5% in July 2020. Full-time jobs increased by 97,500 and hours worked rose strongly. The data suggests the economy is resilient to temporary lockdowns, providing a boost to the government's economic outlook.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Thursday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Thursday, with the Nikkei 225 index down 0.57% and the Topix index down 0.22%, weighed down by negative sentiment from Wall Street and a strong yen against the dollar.

site_title: Malaysia's biggest IPO in 2021 draws Aberdeen, AIA
summary: Malaysia's largest IPO in 2021, CTOS Digital Bhd, is set to raise up to RM1.2 billion through a Kuala Lumpur IPO. Cornerstone investors Aberdeen Standard Investments and AIA Group are in talks to participate, along with Eastspring Investments Bhd and several local asset managers. The company plans to sell shares for RM1.10 each, with a draft prospectus expected to be filed before the end of the month. The IPO could be Malaysia's biggest listing this year, following a slow recovery from the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Singapore non-oil exports grow 8.8% y-o-y in May, extending April's gains: ESG
summary: Singapore's non-oil exports grew 8.8% year-over-year in May, extending April's 6% gains, according to Enterprise Singapore. This was below economists' expectations of a 16% year-on-year expansion. Despite the disappointing showing, exports have expanded for six straight months.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares begin Thursday's session with losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks began Thursday's session with losses, following the Federal Reserve's policy meeting, which led investors to expect US interest rates to rise earlier than previously thought. The Hang Seng Index slipped 0.69%, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.28%. This move is attributed to investors' concerns over rising interest rates and their impact on global markets.

site_title: Eerily empty for months, Phuket set to welcome vaccinated tourists from July 1
summary: Thailand's Phuket island is set to welcome vaccinated tourists from July 1 as part of the "Phuket Sandbox" reopening plan. Fully vaccinated visitors from countries with low or medium Covid-19 transmission risk will be allowed to enter without quarantine. The plan aims to revive the devastated tourism industry, which accounts for up to 20% of the country's GDP. However, the move comes as Thailand faces its third and deadliest wave of Covid-19, with over 202,000 cases and 1,485 deaths.

site_title: OTS Holdings debuts on SGX Catalist board at 30.4% above IPO price
summary: OTS Holdings, a food manufacturing and brand builder, debuted on the Singapore Exchange's Catalist board at S$0.30 per share, 30.4% above its initial public offering (IPO) price of S$0.23. The company's IPO raised approximately S$7.9 million, with net proceeds to be used for expanding its regional footprint, manufacturing capabilities, research and development, and general working purposes. As of the debut, the counter was trading 28.3% higher than its IPO price.

site_title: Japan seeks 'quasi-emergency' measures for seven prefectures until July 11: minister
summary: Japan's Economy Minister Yasutoshi Nishimura announced plans to implement "quasi-emergency" measures in seven prefectures from June 20 to July 11, maintaining some restrictions to prevent a rebound in coronavirus infections. The measures will ensure continued public health efforts, despite lifting a state of emergency in the prefectures.

site_title: Rainmaking teams up with ESG to launch supply-chain focused accelerator
summary: Rainmaking, a corporate innovation firm, has teamed up with Enterprise Singapore to launch the Supply Chain Resilience Accelerator, focusing on startups specializing in supply-chain solutions. The accelerator will back at least 20 Singapore-based startups, aiming to strengthen local and global supply chains through end-to-end visibility, automation, analytics, and sustainability. Successful solutions could be adopted globally by participating corporations, including agriculture giant Cargill. The programme will provide access to investment opportunities and foster valuable startup-corporate engagements to drive scalable pilots.

site_title: Tycoon Richard Li's insurer FWD files for US$3b US IPO
summary: FWD, an Asian insurer backed by billionaire Richard Li, has filed confidentially for a US$3 billion initial public offering (IPO). The holding company has submitted a draft registration with the US Securities and Exchange Commission, paving the way for a potential listing. FWD's business spans South-east Asia, Japan, and Hong Kong, and the IPO could value the insurer at over US$15 billion. The insurer has considered various options, including a US listing through a merger with a special purpose acquisition company, and plans to raise funds in the third quarter.

site_title: IPO-bound Didi probed for antitrust violations: sources
summary: China's market regulator has launched an antitrust probe into Didi Chuxing, the ride-hailing giant, amid its planned US IPO. The probe, part of a broader crackdown on "platform" companies, examines whether Didi used competitive practices to squeeze out smaller rivals and whether its pricing mechanism is transparent enough. Didi has completed a self-inspection and submitted compliance commitments, but regulatory bodies may still impose penalties. The impact on the IPO, expected to be the largest Chinese IPO in New York since Alibaba's 2014 float, remains unclear.

site_title: Toshiba chairman says he may leave once problems fixed: WSJ
summary: Toshiba chairman Osamu Nagayama says he may leave once the corporate governance scandal is resolved. Nagayama has been facing calls to resign amid allegations that Toshiba management colluded with Japan's trade ministry to block foreign investors from gaining board influence. To address these concerns, Nagayama plans to revamp the board and appoint a new CEO, stating it will be an "appropriate time" to consider his resignation.

site_title: Australia: Shares slip as Federal Reserve signals rate hikes at faster pace
summary: Australian shares fell 0.5% to 7,351.50 points, as weaker commodity prices and a negative mood from US interest rate hike projections weighed on the market. The Federal Reserve signaled faster rate hikes than expected, causing a sell-off in gold stocks and miners. US equities also dipped overnight, with Wall Street's main indexes closing lower.

site_title: New Zealand central bank finalises bank capital rules
summary: The Reserve Bank of New Zealand finalized bank capital rules, increasing the amount of capital banks must have. The changes will make the country's banking system safer and will be phased in over a seven-year period starting from July 2022. Deputy Governor Geoff Bascand stated that the new framework is more up-to-date, logical, and transparent, allowing banks to better understand and comply with the requirements.

site_title: Hong Kong police raid pro-democracy newspaper Apple Daily, arrest five
summary: Hong Kong police raided Apple Daily, a pro-democracy newspaper, and arrested five executives, including chief editor Ryan Law, under the city's national security law. The arrests follow a previous raid in August and come after billionaire owner Jimmy Lai was charged with collusion. The police alleged the five executives were involved in collusion with a foreign country to endanger national security. Apple Daily has been a vocal supporter of the pro-democracy movement in Hong Kong.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Ascendas Reit, Suntec Reit, OTS, Soilbuild Construction, Hong Lai Huat, Rex
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Several Singapore-listed companies saw notable developments that may impact their trading on Thursday. Ascendas Reit priced 300 million euros in notes, while Suntec Reit sold its 30% interest in a property to Haiyi Holdings. OTS received strong interest in its initial public offering, and Soilbuild Construction's subsidiary received a writ of summons related to a warranty breach. Hong Lai Huat expects a new revenue source from a mixed-use agricultural hub in Cambodia, and Rex acquired a stake in a Norwegian oil field. Meanwhile, Singapore Reinsurance will be delisted due to Fairfax Asia's compulsory acquisition.

site_title: Singapore shares fall at Thursday's open tracking US retreat: STI down 0.4%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.4% to 3,126.51 at Thursday's open, tracking the US retreat after the Federal Reserve signaled potential monetary policy tightening. Key exports in May grew 8.8% year-over-year, but saw a sequential fall. Banking stocks were mixed, with DBS up 0.03%, UOB down 0.7%, and OCBC declined 1.1%. The US stock market also fell, with the Dow down 0.8% and the S&P 500 losing 0.5%.

images.alt_text: Losers outnumbered gainers 102 to 57 after 141.5 million securities worth S$129.6 million changed hands.

site_title: UK health minister brushes off PM's 'hopeless' remark
summary: UK Health Secretary Matt Hancock has rejected criticism after private WhatsApp exchanges emerged showing Prime Minister Boris Johnson describing him as "hopeless" due to his handling of the Covid pandemic. The exchanges, posted by former chief aide Dominic Cummings, also showed Johnson blaming Hancock for difficulties in obtaining ventilators. Hancock denied being hopeless and Johnson's spokesman said the prime minister has full confidence in the health secretary. The UK has been one of the countries worst hit by the pandemic, but a successful vaccination drive has helped bring deaths down sharply.

site_title: Putin and Biden won't be friends but see path together
summary: US President Joe Biden met with Russian President Vladimir Putin in Geneva, marking the first summit between the two leaders. Despite earlier remarks calling Putin "a killer," Biden described him as "a worthy adversary" and expressed a desire to find common interests. The two leaders agreed to return ambassadors to each other's capitals and work on prisoner releases, but no significant breakthroughs were expected. The meeting was seen as a step towards a more predictable, if still tense, relationship between the two nations, with Biden signaling that Russia's actions will have consequences.

images.alt_text: Instead, Mr Putin's first summit with the fifth US president of his tenure, Joe Biden, was about mutual respect - and the meeting in Geneva could, both of them said, lead to a more predictable, if still tense, relationship.

site_title: Mobile health apps plagued by privacy issues: study
summary: A study published in the British Medical Journal found that over 20,000 health and fitness apps can access and share personal data without proper privacy disclosures, posing concerns for users. The analysis of over 15,000 free health apps in the Google Play store revealed that 28% didn't offer any privacy policy text, and at least a quarter of user-data transmissions breached those policies. The study also found that 88% of the apps could access and potentially share personal information. This raises heightened privacy risks for users, particularly for sensitive health information.

site_title: Slower population growth, ageing need not be alarming: economists
summary: Singapore's population growth slowed to 1.1% per year over the last decade, down from 2.5% previously, according to the latest Census of Population. The population aged, with the median age rising to 41.5 and 15.2% of residents aged 65 and older. Economists say the economic implications of this trend are not alarming, but pivoting away from non-resident labor might be challenging. The government must carefully calibrate immigration to support the economy and ensure the required skillsets.

site_title: Japan manufacturers remain optimistic in June: Reuters Tankan
summary: Japan's business confidence levels remained little changed in June, with manufacturers showing optimism thanks to strong overseas demand. The Reuters Tankan sentiment index for manufacturers edged up to 22, while the service sector index remained flat. The poll suggests a fragile and uneven state of the country's coronavirus recovery. The Bank of Japan may extend pandemic-relief programs at its upcoming policy meeting to support the economy's recovery.

site_title: US: Stocks dip, dollar rallies as Federal Reserve edges towards policy shift
summary: US stocks fell 0.5% to 4,223.79, while the dollar rose after the Federal Reserve signaled it may tighten monetary policy, citing higher inflation and growth forecasts. Fed Chair Jay Powell emphasized that recent price hikes are temporary and the committee will give notice before making changes. The dollar may continue to gain ground, and the S&P 500 recovered somewhat during Powell's press conference.

site_title: Pandemic sparks surge in Hong Kong's cash druggings
summary: A surge in opportunistic crimes, including "Devil's Breath" attacks, has plagued Hong Kong's entertainment district Wanchai, targeting tourists and locals alike. Scammers use spiked drinks to incapacitate victims, stealing their PIN numbers and emptying their bank accounts. The pandemic has exacerbated the issue, with police struggling to keep up with the rise in cases. Experts attribute the surge to desperation and economic hardship during Hong Kong's worst recession in decades. Victims report significant psychological damage, and authorities are working to educate officers on how to treat victims and improve response times.

images.alt_text: A spiked drink, a puff of dust, missing memories, and an empty bank account.

site_title: Bezos-backed fusion startup picks UK to build first plant
summary: General Fusion, a nuclear fusion startup backed by billionaire Jeff Bezos, has announced plans to build its first pilot power plant in the UK, potentially accelerating clean energy production. The $400 million facility, expected to begin construction next year, aims to produce 115 megawatts of power, a fraction of the energy generated by larger fusion reactors. The project follows a call by the US National Academies of Science for a pilot fusion reactor capable of generating electricity by 2035 and UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson's offer of $17 billion in support for green industries, including nuclear power.

site_title: Federal Reserve signals higher rates in 2023, bond-buying taper talks as virus fades
summary: The US Federal Reserve signaled higher interest rates in 2023, moving its projected rate increases from 2024 to 2023, with 11 policymakers foreseeing two quarter-percentage-point rate increases. The Fed also discussed ending its crisis-era bond-buying program, with discussions to be completed in coming months. The economy is expected to grow 7% this year, and inflation is projected to exceed the 2% target by 3.5%. Fed Chair Jerome Powell expressed confidence in the economic recovery, but noted that the pandemic's influence is diminishing.

site_title: Earlier Federal Reserve rate hikes will not jack up low projected borrowing costs: White House
summary: The White House says earlier Federal Reserve rate hikes won't significantly impact its forecasts for long-term borrowing costs. Fed officials project a 7% US economy growth and accelerated interest rate increases starting in 2023. The Biden administration expects real debt service rates to remain negative to slightly positive over the next decade, keeping its budget plans fiscally prudent. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen also stated that government borrowing costs will stay "well below" historical levels.

site_title: Facebook AI software able to dig up origins of deepfake images
summary: Facebook scientists have developed AI software to identify and trace the origins of deepfake images. The software, created in collaboration with Michigan State University, analyzes images for imperfections left during the manufacturing process, allowing it to detect and track deepfakes. This technology aims to facilitate deepfake detection and tracing in real-world settings, helping researchers and practitioners investigate incidents of coordinated disinformation. The software's ability to identify the generative model used to create the deepfake image opens up new directions for future research in deepfake detection.

site_title: Europe: Shares mark record-high close
summary: European shares closed at a record high on Wednesday, reaching 459.86 points, marking its longest gaining streak in three-and-a-half years. The Stoxx 600 rose 0.2% despite caution ahead of a potential US Federal Reserve stimulus unwinding plan. Travel, leisure, utilities, and chemical stocks performed well, driven by investor bets on consumer demand and industrial production.

site_title: Designing density better for cities and nature
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a reevaluation of the relationship between urban population density and disease transmission, with evidence suggesting that high density alone does not predict high infection rates. Instead, factors such as healthcare access, work-from-home arrangements, and grassroots collective action play a crucial role in mitigating the spread of the virus. To design density better, urban planners, policymakers, and businesses must collaborate to intensify efforts to widen and maximize the benefits of urban density, reduce inequities in healthcare, and consider the benefits of urban density for surrounding natural ecosystems.

site_title: Chinese trucking startup seeks US$1.6 billion in US IPO
summary: Chinese trucking startup Full Truck Alliance is seeking a US$1.57 billion initial public offering (IPO) in the US, valuing the company at up to US$20.6 billion. The IPO, led by Morgan Stanley, China International Capital, and Goldman Sachs Group, would make it one of the largest US listings by a Chinese company this year. The company plans to use the funds for infrastructure development, technology innovation, and expansion. This follows successful IPOs by other Chinese companies, including Kanzhun, which raised US$912 million in May.

site_title: Ascendas Reit trustee prices 300m euros of 0.75% notes due 2028
summary: Ascendas Reit, a Singapore-based real estate investment trust, priced 300 million euros (S$480.8 million) in 0.75% notes due 2028. The notes will be used for financing general working capital purposes, including acquisitions. The Reit recently acquired 11 European data centres and is set to buy a 75% stake in Galaxis for S$534.4 million. The issuance is expected to have a minimal impact on the Reit's net asset value and distribution per unit for the current financial year. The notes were priced by joint lead managers BNP Paribas, HSBC, MUFG, and Natixis.

site_title: Thailand targets reopening within 120 days as economy flounders
summary: Thailand plans to reopen to visitors within 120 days, aiming to revive its troubled economy. The country has secured 105.5 million doses of coronavirus vaccine and plans to administer 10 million shots per month. Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha announced the reopening, citing the need to reduce suffering and stimulate the economy. The country will start with a pilot reopening on Phuket island in July, with strict entry requirements and quarantine measures in place. Thailand lost US$50 billion in tourism revenue last year due to the pandemic.

site_title: China economic data disappoints as consumer spending lags
summary: China's economic data in May disappointed, with industrial output rising 8.8% and retail sales increasing 12.4% below forecasts. The recovery is stabilizing, but consumer spending remains weak, with tourism spending 25% lower than pre-pandemic levels. Economists expect the economy to gradually moderate this year, with growth projected to slow to 6.2% in the third quarter and 5% by the end of the year. The People's Bank of China is expected to inject liquidity into the interbank market to ease upward pressure on interest rates.

site_title: Malaysia's king calls for early resumption of Parliament
summary: Malaysia's King Al-Sultan Abdullah urged the early resumption of Parliament to debate emergency ordinances and a coronavirus recovery plan. The king's call comes after Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin stated parliament could reopen by September if daily infections fall below 2,000. The king emphasized the need for a stable government to effectively handle the epidemic and restore the economy. Parliament was suspended in January amid a national emergency, with the opposition accusing the premier of attempting to shore up his position amid a leadership challenge. Vaccination is seen as the sole "exit strategy" from the epidemic.

site_title: Slim hopes as Putin-Biden summit begins with a wide gulf between them
summary: US President Joe Biden and Russian President Vladimir Putin met in Geneva for their first summit since Biden took office, with deep disagreements expected and low hopes for progress. The two leaders discussed arms control, cyber-hacking, election interference, and Ukraine, but aides downplayed expectations for significant agreements. Relations have deteriorated since Russia's 2014 annexation of Crimea and US charges of meddling in the 2016 election. The summit is seen as an effort to maintain stability and predictability in relations, with the goal of avoiding a military collision.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Broadway Industrial Group plans to discuss next steps with potential buyer of its HDD business, potentially extending the June 30 long-stop date, amid Singapore Exchange regulatory review. Innopac Holdings will be delisted from the Singapore bourse on June 30 without an exit offer. GHY Culture & Media aims to acquire 51% stake in Clover Films Group's entities to expand its geographical footprint. F&N issued S$100 million 2% notes due 2026, while Rex International acquired a 33.8% interest in the Brage field in Norway for US$42.6 million.

site_title: Now worth US$1 billion, Beautycounter aims to take a big leap
summary: Beautycounter, a decade-old company advocating for safer cosmetic ingredients, has reached a valuation of $1 billion after Carlyle Group's majority stake acquisition in April. Despite the beauty industry's downturn during the pandemic, Beautycounter's sales rose 17% in 2020, driven by its "clean beauty" approach and independent sellers. Founder Gregg Renfrew plans to invest in digital capabilities and brand awareness, aiming to expand the company's influence in the industry and push for more regulations on toxic chemicals.

site_title: Marco Polo Marine a play on renewable energy: RHB
summary: RHB has initiated coverage on Marco Polo Marine with a "buy" call, citing growth potential in the offshore windfarm space and diversification into renewable energy. The brokerage expects an earnings rebound and a turnaround to strong profitability within the next two to three years. Marco Polo Marine's shipyard division has seen a 34.5% year-on-year increase in shipbuilding and repair revenue, and the company plans to expand its Dry Dock 1 to cope with demand. The stock rose 3.5% following the report, reaching a market capitalization of S$102.3 million.

site_title: Apple warns EU law 'risks destroying iPhone security'
summary: Apple CEO Tim Cook warned that the EU's proposed new rules could "risk destroying iPhone security." The EU's draft rules aim to rein in tech giants, including Apple, by limiting their control over online "gatekeepers" such as app installation on Apple devices. Cook expressed concerns that the rules could undermine the security of the iPhone, which relies on Apple's control over app installation to protect users. The EU is set to vote on the rules later this year.

images.alt_text: The EU's proposed new rules to rein in tech giants risk undermining the security of the iPhone, Apple chief Tim Cook warned on Wednesday.

site_title: Constituents of the iEdge S-Reit Index
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times, while Creative Technology warned of below-target H2 revenue and operating loss similar to H1. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10b upgrade, and Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. Meanwhile, OCBC named Tan Teck Long as its incoming CEO, replacing Helen Wong, and Singapore stocks rallied for a 5-day run ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Half of China-backed overseas coal projects shelved
summary: Half of China-backed overseas coal-fired power plant projects have been shelved or cancelled since 2014, with only one project remaining operational. Research by the International Institute of Green Finance found that financing costs and risks related to coal projects have increased, while clean energy like solar power has become cheaper. This shift can accelerate a sustained green energy transition in countries involved in China's Belt and Road Initiative.

site_title: China set to launch first crew to new space station
summary: China is set to launch its first crew to the new space station, Tiangong, with a trio of astronauts blasting off on a Long March-2F rocket. The crew, led by Commander Nie Haisheng, will spend three months on the space station, conducting tests, maintenance, and scientific experiments. This mission marks a significant step in China's space ambitions, with 11 more missions planned to complete the station's construction. The launch comes as China prepares to celebrate the 100th anniversary of the ruling Communist Party with a massive propaganda campaign.

images.alt_text: The first astronauts for China's new space station are set to blast off Thursday for the country's longest crewed mission to date, a landmark step in establishing Beijing as a major space power.

site_title: How to have a roaring 2020s without wild inflation
summary: The US economy is experiencing a potential boom, driven by rapid job growth and pent-up demand, but policymakers risk overreacting by slamming on the brakes. Unlike the post-World War II era, where demand was met by increased supply, modern economists fear inflation and joblessness. However, a boom can create a virtuous cycle, with higher wages, labor market tightness, and increased productivity. To manage the boom, policymakers should focus on sustaining growth, updating tools to address supply chain issues, and implementing policies to boost capacity in areas with rising prices.

site_title: The Fed cannot control its easy-money monster
summary: The Federal Reserve's quantitative easing (QE) policy, which has kept long-term interest rates low since the 2008 financial crisis, is being questioned by economists and investors. The Fed's balance sheet has grown to nearly $9 trillion, sparking concerns about inflation and asset bubbles. Despite rising consumer price index (CPI) rates, the Fed has shown no willingness to end QE, leaving investors with limited options for returns and fueling speculation in assets like stocks and cryptocurrencies. Experts warn that the prolonged low-interest rate environment may lead to a financial crisis, highlighting the need for the Fed to reassess its policy.

site_title: When working from home-away-from-home ...
summary: Working from home has led to a shift in living arrangements for younger Singaporeans, with more opting for co-living spaces and serviced residences. This trend is boosting the property sector, which has been struggling due to the absence of short-stay foreigners. The co-living space market is becoming increasingly popular among locals, providing a more flexible and affordable living solution.

site_title: Blackstone closing in on Soho China acquisition worth US$3b
summary: Blackstone is nearing a deal to acquire Hong Kong-based office developer Soho China for approximately US$3 billion, a move that would be its largest real estate investment in Asia. The private equity firm's acquisition comes after Soho China's stock price surged 48% last week, and the company's shares were halted from trading pending an announcement. This deal would mark a significant move for Blackstone in Asia, and would follow its recent acquisition of a US$1.1 billion stake in a Chinese logistics park.

site_title: Instilling healthy eating habits, one recipe at a time
summary: Prudential Singapore has extended its nutrition programme, Healthy with KidSTART, to benefit 1,300 families, including those with greater food security concerns. The programme, in collaboration with KidSTART Singapore, provides fresh produce, recipe cards, and guidance on preparing healthy meals. Beneficiaries will also receive a Healthy Plate, a modelled guide for well-balanced meals. The initiative aims to instill healthy eating habits in children, supporting their growth and development.

site_title: F&B outlets may rethink real estate footprint as online sales grow
summary: Singapore's online food and beverage sales are expected to slow down due to increasing competition and consumer fatigue, but prime mall space may still fall out of favor as cloud kitchens become more popular. F&B retailers may need to rethink their operations and real estate footprint, with some opting to relocate to cheaper locations and use rental savings for digital marketing. Cloud kitchens, which allow operators to rent space for delivery, are expected to gain pace, while businesses may open fewer full-service eateries.

site_title: Oil settles near US$75, at multi-year highs
summary: Oil prices rose for a fifth day, closing near US$75 a barrel, driven by US refiners drawing more crude inventories to meet recovering demand. Crude inventories fell 7.4 million barrels, with refining utilisation at 92.6%, the highest since January 2020. Brent crude reached $74.39 a barrel, its highest since April 2019, while US crude rose to $72.15, the highest since October 2018. Analysts expect prices to remain above $70 and demand to return to pre-pandemic levels in the second half of 2022.

site_title: UK inflation vaults past Bank of England target, hitting 2.1% in May
summary: UK inflation jumped to 2.1% in May, exceeding the Bank of England's 2% target and surpassing forecasts. The acceleration in consumer prices, largely driven by weak inflation in May 2020, marks the first time the target has been breached in almost two years. Fuel prices rose 18% and clothing costs increased by 2.1% as people emerged from lockdown. The central bank is expected to leave policy unchanged on June 24, but some economists predict a rate rise may be necessary to combat sustained price growth.

site_title: Business and adminstration the top course of study
summary: Business and administration remains the most popular field of study in Singapore, with 31.2% of male and 39% of female university graduates choosing this path, up from 2010. Engineering sciences and humanities and social sciences also remain popular, but with a decline in their share of graduates. Experts attribute this shift to the expansion of university places and the growing demand for less technical roles, with well-paid jobs in business services and management being a key factor.

site_title: It's a bright outlook for the oil trade this summer
summary: Crude oil prices surged to multi-year highs, reaching $74.61 and $72.67 per barrel, driven by robust energy demand as travel and economic activity recover. OPEC+ supply cuts have kept oil inventories manageable, while vaccination rates and a stronger economic outlook for Europe and the US fuel optimism. Analysts predict prices may spike higher, with some expecting $80 per barrel, but others caution that a nuclear deal with Iran could lead to increased supply and dull the rally.

site_title: Would a listing of Mapletree Investments be good for the Singapore market?
summary: Singapore's biggest corporations are struggling, with several posting losses in their latest financial results, including Singapore Airlines, CapitaLand, and Keppel Corporation. State investor Temasek Holdings' backed companies are also facing challenges. In contrast, NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times. The market is expected to continue its 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, despite the economic concerns.

site_title: Rolex New Guard to the fore
summary: The Rolex New Guard, comprising young golfers Cameron Champ, Joaquin Niemann, and Matthew Wolff, is set to shine in the golf world. Born in the 1990s, these talented golfers have already recorded notable wins, including PGA Tour victories. With a strong amateur background, they are tipped to follow in the footsteps of golf greats like Arnold Palmer and Jack Nicklaus. The trio, along with Frenchman Victor Perez, will compete in the U.S. Open, showcasing their skills and potential to become golf's next stars.

site_title: Inflation and its effects
summary: Singapore sets up a centre to advance sustainable aviation in Asia-Pacific. The country aims to capitalize on this opportunity, potentially becoming a global hub for advanced chip packaging. The government also plans to support businesses hit by tariffs with a new grant of up to S$100,000. Additionally, Deputy Prime Minister Gan has scheduled trade talks in the US. Meanwhile, a study suggests that Singapore's graduates are experiencing better employment rates, advising them to "stay calm" and prepare for future-proof careers.

site_title: Tsao family's shipping business turns to venture capital in search of fresh ideas
summary: Singapore-based shipping group IMC Group has launched a corporate venture capital arm, IMC Ventures, to invest in startups focused on environmental sustainability and social impact. The $15 million fund will support pre-Series A and Series B startups, with half allocated to Singapore-based companies, 20% to Southeast Asia, and 30% to US and European startups. IMC Ventures aims to catalyze the pace of tech development in the maritime sector, seeking to reduce fuel costs and improve efficiency through innovations in data analytics, green shipping, and vessel performance.

images.alt_text: James Ong says IMC wants to catalyse the pace of tech development in the maritime sectorThe group is also hoping that its embrace of technology will give it a competitive edge.

site_title: Singapore evaluating timing, scope of next stage of reopening
summary: Singapore's multi-ministry task force is reviewing the timing and scope of the second stage of the economy's reopening due to the emergence of a major Covid-19 cluster in Bukit Merah and new cases. Finance Minister Lawrence Wong announced the review amid the first stage of reopening, which began on June 14, allowing dine-ins at eateries. The review will consider the situation with public health experts, and further updates will be provided soon. The cluster has linked 25 cases, and the closure of Bukit Merah View Market and Food Centre was extended to June 26.

site_title: US dollar holds steady before Fed meeting
summary: The US dollar remained steady ahead of the Federal Reserve meeting, with markets awaiting signs of response to rising inflation. Retail sales dropped in May, but April sales were revised up, and wholesale price inflation accelerated to 6.6%. The Fed is expected to discuss potential tapering of monetary policy, which could impact currency markets. Risk-related currencies rose, while the euro remained near 1.21 against the dollar.

site_title: Corporate culture and Covid-19: How leaders respond is crucial
summary: Corporate culture plays a crucial role in fostering good governance, particularly during the Covid-19 pandemic. Companies that effectively manage their culture can respond to challenges such as job losses, reduced pay, and supply chain disruptions. A strong corporate culture drives a company to compete ethically and efficiently, generating value not just for shareholders but also employees and the community. Leaders' responses to these challenges are critical in defining a company's culture, and companies that prioritize culture are better equipped to navigate uncertain times and maintain their success.

site_title: Targeting groups can boost retail sales in Singapore
summary: Singapore's retail industry is expected to see a surge in group visits as the country relaxes its Phase 2 curbs. Targeted advertising and promotions for groups can boost sales, according to research. Businesses can use advanced data analytics to identify close-knit groups and offer personalized promotions. However, concerns over data privacy and ethics must be addressed to ensure the targeting system is used ethically and safely. Retailers must also be transparent about their data collection and targeting practices to build trust with customers.

site_title: With impressive PGA victory, Phil Mickelson eyes Grand Slam in homecoming
summary: Phil Mickelson won the PGA Championship, his 45th PGA Tour victory, by two shots at the age of 50. He broke Julius Boros' 48-year-old record, eclipsing it with his victory at Kiawah Island. Mickelson is now primed to win the U.S. Open, which would complete his Grand Slam, having also won the Masters, British Open, and PGA Championship. He will tee off at Torrey Pines, a course he has won three times, and is confident in his abilities, saying he thinks he's "25 years old again."

site_title: US to buy 200m more doses of Moderna Covid vaccine
summary: The US government has agreed to purchase 200 million more doses of the Moderna Covid-19 vaccine, bringing the total order to 500 million doses, at a price of $16.50 per dose. The new doses will be delivered in two tranches, with 110 million doses expected in the fourth quarter of 2021 and the rest in the first quarter of 2022. The deal gives the US flexibility to choose between different vaccine types, including pediatric vaccines and booster shots, at the same price as the original order.

site_title: TrickleStar has new products planned outside US market
summary: TrickleStar, a Singapore-based energy-saving device maker, has shown confidence in its future by paying out a dividend for FY2020 despite a 11% revenue decline. The company's flagship product, an advanced power strip, has 75% market share in the US. TrickleStar plans to introduce eight new products this year, including a USB-powered computing product that will allow it to expand outside the US. The company's cash position has improved, with US$3.7 million in cash and cash equivalents as of December 2020. Despite a global components shortage risk, TrickleStar is optimistic about its recovery and growth prospects.

site_title: Expat flows may stabilise later this year
summary: Singapore's expatriate inflows are expected to stabilize later this year, despite the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on skilled foreign talent flows. One year after the pandemic started, expatriates are choosing to leave Singapore due to job losses and uncertainty, while relocation companies are adapting to the volatile situation with faster turnaround times. Businesses are also prioritizing flexible work arrangements, including virtual assignments, amid the rise of remote work. Experts believe Singapore's vaccination regime and status as an international hub will continue to attract professionals, but it may take time for mobility patterns to shift towards a completely remote workforce.

site_title: Alphabet's Waymo raises US$2.5b after departures
summary: Waymo, Alphabet's self-driving car unit, raised US$2.5 billion in funding to advance its technology and replace a management team that lost six key executives since February. Despite criticism over its strategy and competitive strength, Waymo cited its "tens of millions of miles driven" and "tens of billions of miles driven in simulation" as evidence of a "massive opportunity ahead." The funding round includes investors such as Alphabet, Andreessen Horowitz, and Fidelity Management & Research Co. Waymo is also expanding its delivery business unit, Waymo Via, with a growing fleet of Class 8 trucks.

site_title: Billionaire who helped Evergrande hit by bond, stock sell-off
summary: Billionaire Zhang Jindong's 30-year empire, Suning Appliance Group, is facing a critical test due to concerns over its financial health and links to China Evergrande Group. Evidence of liquidity issues has increased, with creditors agreeing to extend a 2.89 billion yuan bond by two years and a Beijing court freezing 3 billion yuan worth of shares held by Zhang. The move may complicate his ability to raise cash and potentially derail a state-backed rescue. Zhang's shares are pledged as collateral, and his fortune has declined by $2 billion this year.

site_title: US keeps tariff threat alive for discriminatory taxes, watching inflation: Yellen
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen stated that the US will keep tariffs as an option to address discriminatory digital services taxes, but is open to suspending or rolling back tariffs if countries comply. She engaged in constructive bilateral conversations with the Irish finance minister and believes the EU will support a global minimum tax of at least 15%. The US is also proposing changes to prevent foreign companies from shifting profits offshore. Yellen emphasized the administration's seriousness about monitoring inflation and taking steps to address supply chain bottlenecks.

site_title: Indonesia's Bukalapak aims to raise US$800m in IPO: sources
summary: Indonesian e-commerce firm Bukalapak plans to raise up to $800 million in an initial public offering (IPO) in August, aiming to sell 10-15% of the company and value it between $4-5 billion. This could be Indonesia's biggest IPO in 10 years and its largest ever by a startup. Proceeds from the offering could range from $500 million to $800 million, depending on investor demand and market conditions.

site_title: Hong Kong landlord shifts upscale office to co-working space
summary: Hong Kong Land, the largest landlord in Hong Kong's Central business district, has converted two floors in Edinburgh Tower to a 320-desk flexible office space, catering to financial companies and professional services with leasing terms ranging from three months to three years. This move aims to capitalize on tenants' changing needs for smaller offices and shorter leases, as the company joins Swire Properties to operate flexible office spaces. The co-working space is part of Hong Kong Land's efforts to adapt to the evolving office market, following a 1.2% drop in gross revenue from its office portfolio in 2020.

site_title: Far from Paris, the Pompidou plans an outpost in Jersey City
summary: The Pompidou Centre, a renowned Parisian art museum, plans to establish its first North American satellite in Jersey City, New Jersey. The century-old industrial building in Journal Square will be renovated at a cost of $10-30 million, with the city assuming the financial burden. The satellite, called Centre Pompidou x Jersey City, will open in early 2024 and offer access to the Pompidou's 120,000 works and experts, as well as host exhibitions and events. This move aims to strengthen the Pompidou's global presence during its four-year renovation period in Paris.

site_title: Lawrence Wong downbeat about the return of air travel anytime soon
summary: Finance Minister Lawrence Wong expressed a downbeat outlook for air travel due to ongoing Covid-19 waves and low vaccination rates in the region. He stated that air travel is unlikely to recover anytime soon, with possible exceptions for travel between countries with low and stable infections. Singapore will reassess its reopening plans when half the population is fully vaccinated by August, and the country will adjust its tax systems to align with a global minimum corporate tax rate. Wong also touched on emerging areas, including cryptocurrency, which Singapore is studying for wholesale use in cross-border payments.

site_title: Matsuyama leads Asian hopes
summary: Hideki Matsuyama, a Japanese golfer, finished tied-23rd at the PGA Championship, seven shots behind winner Phil Mickelson. Despite this, Matsuyama's fans believe he can raise his game for the U.S. Open, citing his all-round ability and mental toughness. As the second Asian to win a golf Major, Matsuyama aims to break the U.S. Open's Asian drought, with no Asian having won the tournament before. Matsuyama will compete at the U.S. Open starting June 17 at Torrey Pines.

site_title: Chasen bags S$12.4m of specialist relocation, third-party logistics projects
summary: CHASEN Holdings secured S$12.4m worth of new projects in specialist relocation and third-party logistics. Two projects were signed by its China-based subsidiary, involving move-in services for TFT LCD manufacturers in Fujian and Guangdong provinces. A Malaysia-based 3PL subsidiary secured another contract for cross-border trucking services. The new orders are expected to contribute to the group's business recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic, with the goal of growing market share and customer base.

site_title: OTS Holdings' public offer 233.6 times subscribed
summary: OTS Holdings' initial public offering (IPO) received 233.6 times the number of shares subscribed, with 3,809 valid applications for a total of 1 million shares, amounting to S$53.7 million. The company also received indications of interest for 110.1 million placement shares, valued at S$25.3 million, making the overall invitation approximately 8.4 times subscribed. The IPO will deliver S$7.9 million in net proceeds, primarily used for expanding the group's regional footprint and investing in manufacturing capabilities.

site_title: Blackstone offers HK$23.7b for majority of Soho China
summary: Blackstone Group has offered to acquire a majority stake in Soho China for HK$23.7 billion (S$4.05 billion), a 31.6% premium to Soho's last closing price. The New York-based private equity firm plans to keep Soho listed on the Hong Kong stock exchange and intends to double down on Asia, seeking at least US$5 billion for a regional fund. Soho chairman Pan Shiyi and CEO Zhang Xin, who own a majority stake, have agreed to sell most of their shares to Blackstone, with plans to retain a 9% stake.

site_title: Singapore Reinsurance to delist after Fairfax compulsorily acquires remaining shares
summary: Singapore Reinsurance Corp will delist from the mainboard after Fairfax Asia compulsorily acquires the remaining shares of dissenting shareholders. Fairfax received 90.02% valid acceptances for its cash offer of 35.35 Singapore cents per share, which is 20.6% higher than the volume weighted average price. The offer will close on June 17, allowing shareholders who haven't accepted the offer to realise their shares at the offer price. Singapore Reinsurance will lose its free float, suspending trading of its shares.

site_title: 24 private clinics to offer Sinovac's Covid-19 vaccine for S$10 to S$25
summary: Twenty-four private healthcare institutions in Singapore have been licensed to provide Sinovac's Covid-19 vaccine, with the vaccine available at no cost to the providers. The vaccine will be administered at a cost of $10 to $25 per dose, with consultation charges and 7% GST included. The providers were selected based on their safety, efficiency, and experience in vaccine administration. The vaccine is being provided under the Pandemic Special Access Route and will not be covered under the national vaccination program. Individuals can contact the providers directly for more information on receiving the vaccine.

site_title: De Beers unit's gigantic diamond could be third-biggest ever
summary: De Beers unit Debswana has discovered a 1,098 carat diamond, the largest since the company's operations began five decades ago, surpassing the world's third-largest gem-quality diamond, the Lesedi la Rona. The stone's valuation is pending, and it's unclear whether it will be sold by De Beers or the state-owned Okavango Diamond. Debswana is a 50/50 partnership between Botswana and De Beers, with the discovery highlighting the country's significant diamond exports, which account for 90% of its exports.

site_title: Malaysia's king calls for early resumption of Parliament
summary: Malaysia's King Al-Sultan Abdullah has urged the early resumption of Parliament to debate emergency ordinances and a coronavirus recovery plan. The king's remarks come as Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin suggested parliament could reopen by September, provided daily coronavirus infections fall below 2,000. The king emphasized the need for a stable government administration to effectively handle the epidemic and restore the economy, citing the importance of easing bureaucracy and speeding up vaccinations to reach herd immunity.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's King Al-Sultan Abdullah said on Wednesday the country's Parliament should reconvene as soon as possible, to allow emergency ordinances and a coronavirus recovery plan to be debated by lawmakers.

site_title: US: Pre-Fed jitters keep S&P 500, Nasdaq below record highs
summary: US stocks, including the S&P 500 and Nasdaq, drifted below record highs on Wednesday due to pre-Fed jitters about potential hints on tapering monetary stimulus. The jump in producer prices has raised inflation concerns, prompting investors to expect the Federal Reserve to begin debating tightening its policy. Interest rate-sensitive bank stocks fell, while technology, utilities, and healthcare stocks rose. The central bank's policy statement is expected to be released with fresh economic projections later in the day.

site_title: Millions of dollars in notes held by pioneer members of Peter Kwee's Laguna still unpaid
summary: Hundreds of Laguna National's pioneer members who invested tens of millions of dollars in debentures to finance the golf club's construction are uncertain if they will receive their money back. The club's current owner, Peter Kwee, wrote a letter stating that the club cannot fulfill the redemption due to its current financial position. The club's financial statements from 2019 indicate that a director will provide financial support to allow the club to continue operating as a going concern. The future of the debenture holders remains uncertain.

images.alt_text: In 2001, entrepreneur Peter Kwee bought Laguna National from NatSteel, after which he revamped the golf course and built a 200-room hotel, the Dusit Thani Laguna.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 3.05 points lower to 1,578.32 on Wednesday, with 668 losers outnumbering 349 gainers. The index saw a volume of 4.686 billion lots worth RM3.136 billion.

site_title: Wimbledon cuts 2021 prize purse by 5%, tickets go on sale on Thursday
summary: Wimbledon has reduced its 2021 prize purse by 5.2% to £35 million, a decrease from £36.9 million in 2019. The singles champions will receive £1.7 million, down from £2.35 million in 2019. In contrast, players in the qualifiers will see a 17.5% increase in overall prize money allocation, while wheelchair and quad wheelchair events will also receive a 17% boost. The tournament will return with full crowds of 15,000 on Centre Court for the men's and women's singles finals.

site_title: Japan to lift virus emergency in Tokyo on June 20: NHK
summary: Japan's government has decided to lift the coronavirus state of emergency for Tokyo and other areas, excluding Okinawa prefecture, on June 20. Strong virus measures will remain in place, including banning alcohol sales in bars and restaurants until 7pm, and urging individuals to avoid unnecessary travel.

images.alt_text: Japan's government has decided to lift the coronavirus state of emergency for Tokyo and other areas, excluding Okinawa prefecture, when it expires June 20, public broadcaster NHK reported.

site_title: Portugal to allow tourists from countries including US, Singapore
summary: Portugal has lifted travel restrictions on tourists from the US, Japan, Australia, South Korea, China, Israel, New Zealand, Rwanda, Singapore, and Thailand, with requirements of a negative Covid-19 test taken 72 hours prior to arrival. The US is one of the countries allowed to visit Portugal, along with EU countries and Britain, following the easing of restrictions. However, Nepal, where a new Covid-19 variant has been detected, is now on a "red" list, requiring 14-day quarantine upon arrival.

site_title: Rex International unit to buy 33.8% of Norway oil field for US$42.6m
summary: REX International's 90%-owned subsidiary, Lime Petroleum, will acquire Repsol Norge's 33.8% interest in Norway's Brage oil field for US$42.6 million. The deal aims to establish recurring cash flow and drive value in Lime Petroleum's portfolio. Production in the field has been ongoing since 1993, with ongoing efforts to increase recovery. The acquisition aligns with Rex's strategies to increase production and minimize production risk, particularly with oil prices surpassing US$70 per barrel.

site_title: Centuries-old shipwrecks found off Singapore
summary: Singapore's National Heritage Board and ISEAS-Yusof Ishak Institute announced the discovery of two centuries-old shipwrecks off Pedra Branca, east of the city-state. The wrecks, dating back to the 14th and 18th centuries, contain ceramics, glass, and other artefacts, shedding light on Singapore's maritime heritage. The first wreck, discovered in 2015, was carrying Chinese ceramics possibly from the 14th century, while the second, likely the Shah Munchah, was a merchant vessel from India that sank in 1796. The wrecks' discovery highlights Singapore's role as a trading hub before British colonization in 1819.

site_title: Soilbuild Construction unit receives writ of summons from condo developer
summary: Soilbuild Construction's subsidiary, Precast Concrete Builders, has received a writ of summons and statement of claim from luxury condominium developer TG Development over alleged breaches of a warranty. The claims, valued over S$1.4 million, relate to defects in a proprietary wall system. Soilbuild Construction's board believes the claims will not affect its financial position, and has engaged legal counsel to represent itself and/or PCB in the case.

site_title: Heineken wants to link executive pay to green targets
summary: Heineken, the world's second-largest brewer, plans to link executive pay to its green targets, aiming to meet a 2040 net-zero emissions goal. CEO Dolf van den Brink says the company is investigating linking salaries and bonuses to climate action. This move is seen as a key step to incentivize corporate management to meet climate goals. Heineken has set a 35% emissions reduction target by 2030, and may cut ties with suppliers who fail to decarbonize their operations quickly enough. The company's efforts come as climate action becomes increasingly important to stakeholders.

site_title: Israel 'startup nation' era may be ending: new figures
summary: Israel's high-tech sector, known as the "startup nation," may be nearing its end, according to a report by the Israel Innovation Authority. The number of new startups declined from 1,400 in 2014 to 520 in 2020, and seed investment in new companies dropped. This decline raises concerns about the future of the sector and the wider economy. Prime Minister Naftali Bennett aims to increase the sector's share of the workforce to 15% by 2026, but the report warns that the decline in new startups could critically affect employment, tax revenue, and the stability of the Israeli economy.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore is evaluating the timing and scope of its economy's reopening amid a recent Covid-19 outbreak. The multi-ministry task force is reviewing the plan, which comes after a major cluster emerged in Bukit Merah. The city-state's population growth slowed to 1.1% per year, less than half of the previous decade. Air travel recovery is expected to be slow, despite bilateral arrangements for vaccinated travelers. Meanwhile, a digital currency sandbox has been launched to test central bank digital currency apps, and UOB has priced a record-low perpetual bond at 2.55%.

site_title: Wide disagreements, low expectations as Biden, Putin meet
summary: US President Joe Biden and Russian President Vladimir Putin met in Geneva on Wednesday for their first meeting since Biden took office, amidst deep disagreements over arms control, cyber-hacking, and Ukraine. Expectations for breakthroughs are low, with both sides focusing on areas where they can advance their national interests and make the world safer. The meeting comes after years of deteriorating relations, including Russia's annexation of Crimea and US charges of election interference. A tense atmosphere surrounds the summit, with no meals and separate news conferences planned.

site_title: Fermenting Philip Glass: René Redzepi on music and cooking
summary: Chef and Noma owner René Redzepi discussed the intersection of music and cooking with Tan Dun and Einojuhani Rautavaara, choosing pieces that evoke a sense of adventure in using unconventional ingredients. Redzepi paired his chosen music, Philip Glass' "Floe from Glassworks," with a conversation about fermentation and foraged ingredients. The discussion aimed to engage all senses, highlighting Redzepi's innovative approach to using local, seasonal, and unexplored ingredients in his culinary creations.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end with losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended the day with losses, slipping 0.70% to 28,436.84, following a forecast-beating jump in US inflation. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index also dropped 1.07% to 3,518.33. Investors are closely watching the Federal Reserve's latest policy meeting, which concludes later in the day.

site_title: Innopac to delist on June 30, no exit offer received
summary: Innopac Holdings will be delisted from the Singapore bourse on June 30 due to its inability to exit the financial watch list within the 36-month cure period. The company had requested restructuring and was seeking advice on operational procedures. No exit offer from interested parties was received, and the Singapore Exchange's regulatory arm clarified that the delisting notice is irreversible. Innopac's shares have been suspended from trading since June 2018.

site_title: NUS, NTU and industry partners launch S$23m research programme for green data centre solutions
summary: NUS and NTU, in partnership with industry stakeholders, have launched a S$23 million research programme to develop sustainable cooling solutions for data centres in tropical locations. The Sustainable Tropical Data Centre Testbed (STDCT) will be operational by October, serving as an innovation hub for academia and industry to co-create and demonstrate advanced cooling technologies. The programme aims to reduce energy consumption and greenhouse gas emissions by up to 25% and potentially lower energy usage by 40% if adopted industry-wide.

site_title: Citi warns of bigger-than-expected trading drop
summary: Citi warns of a 30% drop in trading revenue for the second quarter, exceeding analyst expectations. The bank's CFO, Mark Mason, attributed the decline to a weaker performance in the fixed income unit, despite strength in equities trading. This prediction follows JPMorgan's CEO Jamie Dimon's similar forecast of a trading revenue decline. Citi's shares fell 1.8% on the news, while the bank expects expenses to range between $11.2 billion and $11.6 billion for the quarter.

site_title: Singapore evaluating timing, scope of next stage of reopening amid latest outbreak
summary: Singapore is reviewing the timing and scope of its next stage of reopening amid a major Covid-19 cluster in Bukit Merah and new cases. Finance Minister Lawrence Wong stated that the multi-ministry task force is evaluating the situation with public health experts, and will provide updates soon. The country had planned to ease restrictions in two stages, but the emergence of new cases has prompted a reevaluation. Further relaxation of rules, including dine-ins at eateries, was initially set for June 21, but this may be delayed due to the outbreak.

site_title: China's May property investment growth slows as curbs bite
summary: China's real estate investment growth slowed to 9.8% in May, the weakest clip this year, due to policy tightening on developers' financing and mortgages. Despite this, growth remained resilient. For the first five months, property investment grew 18.3%, slower than the 21.6% increase in January to April. Authorities continue to clamp down on speculative activity and prevent an asset bubble with measures such as debt ratio caps and mortgage rate hikes.

site_title: Boardroom tussle: MC Payment disputes Ching's account of financial performance
summary: MC Payment, a financial technology company, is at odds with its controlling shareholder Ching Chiat Kwong over financial performance. Ching has proposed adding five new directors to the board, including himself, and removing all existing directors except one. MC Payment disputes Ching's claims, citing the company's successful reverse takeover of Artivision Technologies, which has benefited Ching. The company's management has limited time to run the business since the last annual general meeting, where Ching's son was not re-elected. A vote on Ching's proposals will be held at an extraordinary general meeting on June 30.

site_title: Suntec Reit sells 30% stake in new 9 Penang Road building
summary: Suntec Reit sold its 30% stake in 9 Penang Road, a 10-storey Grade-A commercial building, to Haiyi Holdings for approximately S$89.9 million. The sale, based on the adjusted net asset value of the joint venture, will provide financial flexibility and potentially redeploy funds to acquire higher-yield assets. The purchase price represents a 30.3% premium over the total development cost of S$756 million. The sale is part of Suntec Reit's proactive portfolio management strategy to enhance unitholders' value.

site_title: Bankers may face delay in plans for quarantine-free business travel to Hong Kong
summary: Bankers may face a delay in their plans for quarantine-free business travel to Hong Kong due to the Hong Kong government's ongoing evaluation of the policy, which includes how detailed the applicant's itinerary should be. Currently, fully vaccinated senior executives at financial institutions can apply to travel without a 21-day hotel quarantine, but no applications have been approved yet. The delay may dash hopes of banks with significant operations in Hong Kong, but some are taking a wait-and-see approach, prioritizing caution.

site_title: STI falls 1.1% as Covid-19 case count threatens to impede next phase of reopening
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index fell 1.1% on Wednesday due to concerns over the reopening of the economy amid a major Covid-19 cluster and new cases. The Finance Minister Lawrence Wong announced a review of the second stage of reopening, citing these factors. The review follows a 5-day rally in the market, with the STI closing at 3,139.57. The broader market saw more decliners than advancers, with 2.06 billion securities changing hands.

site_title: Air travel recovery to be slow despite bilateral arrangements, leeway for vaccinated travellers: Lawrence Wong
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Lawrence Wong expressed skepticism about the air travel recovery, stating that it will take time to recover despite bilateral arrangements and leeway for vaccinated travelers. The region is still grappling with COVID-19 waves and low vaccination rates, making open and free travel unlikely in the near future. Wong also discussed the planned loosening of COVID-19 curbs on June 21 and Singapore's reopening schedule, as well as the need for multilateral cooperation on taxation systems and the potential role of cryptocurrency in the country's future.

site_title: Israel conducts air strikes in Gaza as new violence flares
summary: Israel conducted air strikes in Gaza on June 16, 2021, targeting sites belonging to Hamas, following the launch of incendiary balloons that set multiple fires in southern Israel. The violence marred a fragile truce that ended the 11-day conflict in May and poses a test to Prime Minister Naftali Bennett. The clashes were sparked by sovereignty disputes over Jerusalem, with Palestinians objecting to a march by Jewish nationalists through Palestinian neighborhoods. The conflict killed over 250 Palestinians and 13 people in Israel in May, and tensions could escalate in the coming months due to Gaza's water and electricity shortages.

site_title: Hong Lai Huat to develop mega agricultural hub in Cambodia
summary: Hong Lai Huat Group, a mainboard-listed property developer, plans to develop a 10,000-hectare mixed-use agricultural hub in Cambodia, with the first phase starting in Q4 2021. The hub will include zones for food-processing factories, logistics, livestock farms, and renewable energy, aiming to create jobs and attract foreign direct investments. The development is expected to add new revenue sources for the group and fuel its long-term growth, with three companies already showing interest in investing up to US$225 million.

images.alt_text: An artist's impression of the commercial zone in the Cambodia-Singapore Agriculture Hub. The development will add new revenue sources for the group, Hong Lai Huat said.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks close at record high; Fed outcome in focus
summary: South Korean shares closed at a record high on Wednesday, with the Kospi index rising 0.62% to 3,278.68. Investors await the US Federal Reserve's policy statement, amid rising inflation and a tension between its two main goals. Foreigners were net buyers of 233.3 billion won, while the won ended flat at 1,117.2 per dollar. Technology giants Samsung and SK Hynix rose, while LG Chem fell, as the benchmark bond yield held steady at 1.284%. The Kospi is up 14.10% for the year so far.

site_title: Europe: Oil gains lift shares, Stoxx index holds just off record high
summary: European shares rose 0.3% on Wednesday, driven by gains in energy stocks following a jump in oil prices. The Stoxx 600 index is on track for its longest gaining streak in three-and-a-half years, if gains hold until the end of the day. A recent surge in inflation has sparked concerns about a sooner-than-expected tightening in global monetary policy, but investors remain optimistic about economic growth.

site_title: UK inflation hits 2.1%, jumping over Bank of England target
summary: The UK's inflation rate jumped to 2.1% in May, exceeding the Bank of England's 2% target for the first time in almost two years. This increase was largely driven by fuel price rises and clothing costs, as the economy reopened from lockdown. Investors are assessing the risks of sustained inflation, particularly in the US, where annual inflation hit 5% in May. The Bank of England is expected to keep interest rates unchanged at its next meeting on June 24, but some economists warn that inflationary pressures may be more significant than previously thought.

site_title: Bukit Merah View food centre cluster grows to 39 cases
summary: Singapore reported 39 cases in the Bukit Merah View food centre cluster, with 14 new cases added on Wednesday, bringing the total to 39. The cluster includes a 12-year-old student and her family members, as well as food stall workers and household contacts. The Ministry of Health has closed the affected food centres for deep cleaning and disinfection. Singapore's total cases have risen to 62,339, with 146 patients hospitalized and 44 active clusters of infection.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei index closes lower ahead of Fed meeting
summary: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei index closed 0.51% lower on June 16, 2021, ahead of the US Federal Reserve's meeting. Investors locked in profits, with the Nikkei 225 index ending at 29,291.01. The broader Topix index was flat. Market heavyweights Fast Retailing and Sony fell 2.72% and 2.85%, respectively, amid concerns over the Fed's potential to taper its easy-money policy. The dollar fetched 110.07 yen in Asian trade.

site_title: Indonesian e-commerce firm Bukalapak seeking up to US$800m in IPO: sources
summary: Bukalapak, Indonesia's No. 4 e-commerce firm, plans to raise up to US$800 million in an initial public offering (IPO) in August, aiming to sell 10-15% of the company and value it between US$4-5 billion. This would be Indonesia's largest IPO in 10 years. Proceeds could range from US$500-800 million, depending on investor demand and market conditions. Bukalapak, which has a 7% market share in Indonesia's e-commerce sector worth over US$40 billion, is tapping into Southeast Asia's rapidly expanding technology sector.

site_title: China economic data disappoints as consumer spending lags
summary: China's economic data for May missed estimates, with industrial output rising 8.8% and retail sales increasing 12.4% versus forecasts of 9.2% and 14% respectively. Fixed-asset investment increased 15.4% in the first five months of the year. Consumer spending remains the weak link in the recovery, with the latest holiday spending figures showing a 25% decline in tourism spending compared to pre-pandemic levels. Economists expect the economy to moderate this year, with growth forecast to reach 8.5% for the full year, slightly above the government's target of "above 6%".

site_title: China's bid to curb commodity prices and risks goes into overdrive
summary: China has intensified its efforts to curb commodity prices and speculation, ordering state-owned enterprises to limit their exposure to overseas commodities markets and releasing state stockpiles of metals such as copper, aluminum, and zinc. This move aims to ease the threat to its pandemic rebound from soaring raw material costs. Metals prices in London and Shanghai have fallen, and shares of metals companies in China and Hong Kong have declined, while Australia's metals and mining sub-index has posted its biggest loss in almost a month. The government's actions are part of a broader effort to curb inflationary pressures and speculation in the commodities market.

site_title: Brokers' take: RHB initiates 'buy' on Marco Polo Marine on forecast renewable energy turnaround
summary: RHB has initiated coverage on Marco Polo Marine with a "buy" call and a target price of 4.1 Singapore cents, citing an expected turnaround in the renewable energy sector. Analysts expect an earnings rebound and a return to strong profitability in the next two to three years, driven by diversification into renewable energy services.

site_title: MAS-backed entity launches sandbox to test central bank digital currency apps
summary: The Asean Financial Innovation Network (AFIN) has launched a digital currency sandbox in partnership with the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and R3, allowing banks and fintechs to test central bank digital currency (CBDC) applications. The sandbox, running on the Corda blockchain platform, will provide a platform for collaboration, evaluation, and testing of CBDC use cases. This initiative aims to drive global adoption of CBDCs, following growing interest in the technology, including Singapore's own Project Ubin and China's launch of digital yuan.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened lower on Wednesday, following a soft US market lead. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.1% to 28,609.37, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index were barely moved. Investors await the conclusion of the Federal Reserve's policy meeting, amid concerns over US factory gate inflation.

site_title: Central Bank-backed digital currencies altering the face of cash
summary: Central banks are exploring the development of Central Bank Digital Currencies (CBDCs), with 86% of central banks researching and developing digital cash. The Bank of England, European Central Bank, and US Federal Reserve are among those considering digital versions of their currencies. CBDCs have the potential to improve financial inclusion, increase efficiency in digital payments, and simplify cross-border transactions. However, there are concerns about the risks of anti-money laundering and counter-terrorism financing, as well as the potential impact on traditional banking systems. The development of CBDCs is seen as a step towards a more inclusive and digital world of finance.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 1.7 points, or 0.1%, to 1,583.0 on Wednesday, driven by a higher volume of 154.4 million lots worth RM50.9 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 164 to 93. This follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks, which is expected to be influenced by upcoming GDP data.

site_title: Hyundai Motor Group chases local chipmakers to cut exposure to shortage
summary: Hyundai Motor Group is in talks with South Korean chip companies to reduce its reliance on foreign supplies amid a global semiconductor shortage. The company is exploring long-term strategies to diversify its supply chain by shifting some auto chip orders to local designers, but technology lags behind industry leaders. Hyundai officials have met with local "fabless" firms to discuss potential partnerships, aiming to cut exposure to the shortage that has halted assembly lines worldwide.

images.alt_text: Hyundai Motor Group is in talks with South Korean chip companies to help it reduce reliance on foreign supplies amid a global shortage that has halted assembly lines at automakers around the world, four people familiar with the matter told Reuters.

site_title: GHY Culture & Media to acquire 51% shareholding interest in Clover Films
summary: GHY Culture & Media Holding has entered into a non-binding memorandum of understanding with Clover Films Group to acquire a 51% shareholding interest in the company. Existing shareholders Lim Teck and Paulyn Chua Nga-Lim will retain 49%. The acquisition is part of GHY's growth strategy to enhance its geographical footprint in Singapore and South-east Asia, with plans to increase Clover Films' production and distribution capacity. GHY aims to expand its movie distributor's reach and increase its local production capabilities.

site_title: Australia: Shares scale new high above 7,400 level, Fed decision awaited
summary: Australian shares reached an all-time high of 7,406.2 on Wednesday, surpassing the 7,400 level. Energy stocks surged 1.5% as oil prices rose, while financials also gained. The Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to follow the US Federal Reserve's tapering of economic support, with the RBA potentially adjusting its bond-buying program. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed 0.09% higher at 7,386.2.

site_title: Malaysia's phased reopening on right track: Citi
