summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has urged Deutsche Bank to appoint a new chairman as Paul Achleitner's term nears its end in May 2022. Despite surviving three shareholder votes, Achleitner has stated he will retire next year. The ECB, led by chief supervisor Andrea Enria, has increased pressure on the bank to identify a successor, with a shortlist of three German men including Theodor Weimer, Norbert Winkeljohann, and Frank Witter. The ECB aims for an orderly transition, but regulators remain concerned about Deutsche's money laundering controls and governance issues.

site_title: Indonesia dengue fever study offers hope in disease battle
summary: Indonesia conducted a three-year study on dengue fever, introducing a harmless bacteria, Wolbachia, into disease-carrying mosquitoes. The results showed a 77% drop in human dengue fever cases and an 86% decrease in hospitalization cases in Wolbachia-treated areas. This innovative approach offers hope in battling the illness that affects millions worldwide annually.

images.alt_text: Dengue fever infections dropped dramatically in an Indonesian study where a bacteria was introduced into disease-carrying mosquitoes, offering hope in the battle against an illness that sickens millions annually around the world.

site_title: SoftBank's PayPay surges ahead in Japan's digital payments race
summary: SoftBank's PayPay is surging ahead in Japan's digital payments market, with over 39 million users and 3 million merchants on board, thanks to its aggressive marketing and free installation offers. The app is gaining traction as consumers shift away from cash due to the Covid-19 pandemic and labor shortages, with PayPay's rivals including Rakuten and Line. Despite losing money, PayPay aims to increase merchant handling fees while covering costs, and SoftBank plans to list the service, which booked a $660 million loss, into its wireless unit.

site_title: Taiwan says Thailand prioritising AstraZeneca shots for itself
summary: Thailand is prioritizing AstraZeneca Covid-19 vaccines produced in the country for itself due to a severe pandemic, causing delays in deliveries to Taiwan. Taiwan, which has only 3% of its population vaccinated, has ordered 10 million doses from AstraZeneca, but production problems have delayed shipments by a month. The delay is attributed to Thailand's serious epidemic situation, with over 80% of new cases and fatalities occurring since April.

site_title: Trafigura posts record profit as virus brings wild price swings
summary: Trafigura Group reported a record profit of $2.1 billion for the first half of 2021, a fourfold increase from the previous year, driven by wild price swings in oil and metals caused by the pandemic. The company's trading divisions saw higher trading volumes, margins, and gross profits. Trafigura's net income and equity jumped, putting the company on track to surpass its 2013 annual earnings record. The company attributed the performance to increased demand for commodities and the company's ability to capitalize on price fluctuations.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks extend gains for fourth week as inflation fears ease
summary: South Korean stocks closed higher on Friday, extending gains for a fourth week, driven by easing inflation concerns ahead of the US Federal Reserve policy meeting. The Kospi index rose 0.77% to 3,249.32, while the won strengthened and benchmark bond yields rose. Foreigners were net buyers of 176.5 billion won worth of shares, and the Bank of Korea is expected to start normalizing its monetary policy once the economy shows a solid recovery.

site_title: Gold reclaims US$1,900 mark as dollar, yields slip after US data
summary: Gold prices rose to above US$1,900 per ounce, driven by a weaker US dollar and lower bond yields following weak US inflation data. The benchmark US Treasury yields dropped to a three-month low, reducing the opportunity cost of holding non-interest bearing bullion. The Federal Reserve is expected to maintain its easy monetary policy, with a potential strategy to reduce its bond-buying program announced in August or September.

site_title: G-7 countries move closer to tax plan for US tech giants
summary: The G-7 countries, including the US, have moved closer to a plan to increase taxes on multinational tech giants like Amazon, Apple, and Google. The proposed global tax rate is at least 15%, targeting companies that make money globally, rather than just in specific countries. This move aims to address concerns about tax avoidance and monopoly-like power wielded by these companies, which have been increasingly under fire in Europe and the US. However, it remains unclear whether the G-7 will achieve its goal, and complexities in applying the rules fairly will need to be addressed.

site_title: Analysts raise targets on healthcare plays Raffles Med, Q&M as Covid-19 testing, vaccinations ramp up
summary: Brokerages UOB Kay Hian and KGI Securities have raised their target prices for healthcare plays Raffles Medical Group and Q&M Dental, respectively, citing opportunities presented by the ramping up of Covid-19 testing and vaccinations. Analysts expect Raffles Medical to benefit from sustained testing needs and offset a loss of government grant support, while Q&M Dental is expected to maintain stable and resilient earnings with a growing market share.

site_title: Philippines to give vaccinated elderly more freedom to encourage inoculation
summary: The Philippines has announced plans to exempt fully vaccinated elderly individuals from stay-at-home orders to encourage more to get inoculated against COVID-19. Starting Wednesday, seniors in areas with looser quarantine restrictions can go out while wearing masks and practicing social distancing. As of June 6, only 16% of the elderly population had received their first vaccine dose. The move aims to boost vaccination rates, particularly among those who account for four-fifths of COVID-19 deaths in the country.

site_title: Microsoft taking Xbox games directly to TVs
summary: Microsoft is developing software to enable Xbox games to be played directly on internet-linked TVs without the need for consoles. The company is working with TV makers to embed Xbox game-playing software, and devices will be built to stream Xbox gameplay through internet browsers. This move aims to expand Xbox's reach and deliver a robust gaming experience to anyone connected to the internet. Microsoft's Xbox Game Pass Ultimate subscriptions will also be available through cloud gaming on internet browsers in coming weeks.

site_title: Hot stock: LHN up 24.3% to all-time high of 46 S cents after fundraising announcement
summary: LHN shares rose to an all-time high of 46 cents after the property group announced a S$2.2 million private placement, with 24.3% growth in early trade, reaching 43.5 cents at midday. The counter ended the day at 42.5 cents, up 14.87%. No married deals were recorded in early trade, according to ShareInvestor data.

site_title: BlackRock gets licence to start China mutual fund business
summary: BlackRock, the global asset manager, has received approval from the China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) to start a wholly-owned onshore mutual fund business in China. This move marks the first time a global asset manager has been allowed to operate a wholly-owned mutual fund business in China. BlackRock's Chinese fund management unit plans to offer differentiated investment solutions to Chinese investors, leveraging its global investment expertise. China's decision to scrap foreign ownership caps in its mutual fund and securities sectors is part of an effort to open up its financial markets.

site_title: Archer's flying taxi makes splashy debut in heated market
summary: Archer Aviation unveiled its electric flying taxi, "Maker", in a Tesla-style debut, marking a growing interest in zero-emission aircraft. The four-passenger aircraft, capable of 150mph flights for 60 miles, is expected to launch commercially in 2024 in Los Angeles and Miami. Archer's goal is to create a mass market transportation solution, with prices starting at $3-$4 per passenger mile. The company faces competition and regulatory uncertainty, including a lawsuit with Boeing-backed Wisk Aero, and plans to go public through a $3.8 billion merger.

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly up as inflation spike seen as temporary
summary: Asian markets rose on Friday following a record lead from Wall Street as traders bought into the Federal Reserve's narrative that surging US inflation is temporary and monetary policies will remain ultra-loose. The US consumer price index for May rose 5% annually, but prices rose less than expected on a monthly basis. Despite concerns about the impact of high inflation on the global economy, the yield on benchmark 10-year Treasuries fell to its lowest since March, indicating the Fed's stance on inflation is being taken seriously.

site_title: GIC-backed Klarna's valuation rises to US$46b after fundraising
summary: Klarna, a Swedish payments firm backed by the Government Investment Corporation (GIC), has raised US$639 million, lifting its valuation to US$46 billion. The company, which allows online shoppers to buy now, pay later, has seen a surge in demand during the coronavirus pandemic. Klarna's valuation has increased from US$31 billion in March to US$50 billion, making it one of the largest players in the global buy now, pay later sector, with over 90 million global active users. The company is expected to make a stock market debut later this year or next year.

site_title: LHN to raise S$2.2m in private placement of up to 6.5m new shares
summary: DUAL-LISTED property player LHN Limited announced a S$2.2 million private placement of up to 6.5 million new shares at 33.51 Singapore cents each. The placement represents a 10% discount and a 6.2% premium to its Hong Kong Stock Exchange closing price. The net proceeds will be used for general working capital, including renovation costs and operating expenses. The shares will comprise 1.59% of the enlarged share capital of 408.9 million shares, following the placement.

site_title: Making sense of risk in an interconnected world
summary: Boards and organisations underestimated the pandemic's impact on revenue models, supply chains, and ways of working. Despite using risk identification, evaluation, and management methodologies, they continue to be surprised by "black swan" events. Traditional risk management strategies, prioritizing impact and likelihood, are limited by being siloed, static, and focused on discrete events. A four-dimensional view, considering connectivity and velocity, can provide a more dynamic visualisation of an organisation's risk network. This approach can help identify key dependencies, potential single points of failure, and measure significant threats. Effective risk management can also lead to seizing competitive advantages in the market, while boards that manage risk poorly may be left vulnerable to catastrophic consequences.

site_title: Flying taxis could poach passengers from planes, Avolon says
summary: Avolon, a major aircraft leasing firm, warns that flying taxis could poach passengers from commercial planes, citing the rapid growth of electric Vertical Take-Off and Landing (eVOTL) aircraft. Avolon is investing $2 billion in aerial shuttles, including partnerships with companies like Vertical Aerospace, which plans to go public through a merger. This shift in competition could impact commercial air travel, as passengers increasingly opt for convenient and potentially more affordable flying taxi services.

site_title: US, Taiwan officials discuss trade, plan meeting 'in coming weeks': USTR
summary: US Trade Representative Katherine Tai discussed trade and investment with Taiwan's chief trade negotiator John Deng, agreeing to convene a meeting of their Trade And Investment Framework Agreement Council in coming weeks. The talks were "harmonious and constructive," and the US emphasized its worker-centered trade priorities. The Biden administration reaffirmed its commitment to Taiwan, which has long sought a free trade deal with the US. The meeting's timing was not specified, but it could ease tensions ahead of a potential referendum in Taiwan on importing pork containing a leanness-enhancing additive.

site_title: Plastics tax urged for UK fast fashion brands 'fuelling runaway climate change'
summary: The Royal Society of Arts, Manufactures and Commerce (RSA) has urged the UK government to impose a tax on fast fashion brands that use non-recycled plastics, citing their contribution to "runaway climate change and pollution." The report found that half of fast fashion items sold by popular British brands like Boohoo and Missguided are made entirely from non-recycled plastics, with only 1-5% of garments containing recycled materials. The RSA suggests that a tax on virgin plastics could be used to fund sustainable production and recycling efforts, and that brands should be transparent about their plastic usage.

site_title: Stocks to watch: LHN, Keppel Infra Trust, SGX, Nutryfarm, Union Gas
summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Several companies saw new developments that may affect trading on Friday. LHN announced a share placement and expects net proceeds of S$2.1 million. Keppel Infrastructure Trust's CEO will step down and be replaced. SGX is seeking market feedback on proposed amendments to its derivatives clearing rules. Nutryfarm entered a joint venture with Kong Jun Durian to sell durians in Singapore. Union Gas received in-principle approval to transfer from the Catalist board to the mainboard. Powermatic Data Systems requested a trading halt pending an announcement.

site_title: G-7 to provide 1 billion Covid-19 vaccine doses 'to world' by 2023
summary: G-7 leaders agreed to provide at least 1 billion Covid-19 vaccine doses to the world by 2023 through sharing and financing schemes. The UK will donate at least 100 million surplus doses, including 5 million in the coming weeks. This move comes amid growing calls for richer countries to share vaccines with less developed nations, addressing concerns of "vaccine apartheid."

site_title: UK report says Hong Kong security law used to 'drastically curtail freedoms'
summary: Britain's report on Hong Kong says Beijing has broken its legal obligations by undermining the city's autonomy, using a national security law to drastically curtail freedoms. The 1984 Joint Declaration guarantees wide-ranging freedoms for Hong Kong, but British Foreign Minister Dominic Raab claims there have been "clear breaches" of this agreement. The national security law imposed in June 2020 is being used to stifle political opposition, according to Raab's foreword.

site_title: Japan finance minister Aso says won't comment on Toshiba report
summary: Japanese Finance Minister Taro Aso declined to comment on an independent probe concluding that the trade ministry colluded with Toshiba executives to pressure stockholders at the company's annual general meeting last July. The report alleges Toshiba's management asked the trade and industry ministry to counter activist overseas stock owners. Aso stated he wouldn't comment on reports concerning individual companies, citing his reluctance to discuss the matter.

site_title: Bitcoin ruling roils crypto world seeking regulatory clarity
summary: International banking regulators have classified Bitcoin as the riskiest of assets, proposing a 1,250% risk weight for banks holding digital tokens on their balance sheets. This move may delay crypto's wider adoption, as it makes it costly for banks to hold Bitcoin. Bitcoin prices jumped then fell, trading around $36,200. Analysts say the ruling may deter traditional banks, allowing alternative players to gain an advantage, while critics argue it may lead to increased volatility and a lack of decentralization.

images.alt_text: International banking regulators' decision to classify Bitcoin as the riskiest of assets dragged cryptocurrencies further into the mainstream financial world.

site_title: Japan considering downgraded emergency state until Olympics start
summary: Japan is considering downgrading its emergency state from June 20 to a "quasi-emergency" state until the Olympics start in July, despite concerns over the spread of COVID-19 variants and strain on medical resources. New coronavirus infections in Tokyo have decreased, but authorities remain cautious. The government plans to impose curbs, such as shorter restaurant hours and restrictions on bars and restaurants, under the quasi-emergency measures. A final decision is expected late next week, with polls showing a majority of the Japanese public opposes holding the Games this year.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 1.73 points, or 0.11%, to 1,581.63 on Friday. The index saw 223 gainers out of 156 losers, with a total trading volume of 530.26 million lots worth RM245.64 million.

site_title: Singapore remains a significant investor in the Philippines
summary: Singapore remains a significant investor in the Philippines, with total approved investments of US$201 million in 2021, despite the pandemic. Notable projects include investments in manufacturing, telecommunications infrastructure, healthcare, and renewable energy. Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC has invested in Metro Pacific Hospital Holdings and AC Energy Corporation, while HyalRoute Group is developing a fibre optic cable infrastructure network. The Philippines and Singapore have also partnered on the Clark International Airport, with a consortium managing and operating the airport since 2019.

site_title: Two Covid-19 cases on one of first North American cruises since virus hit
summary: Two guests on the Celebrity Millennium cruise ship, carrying 600 passengers and 650 crew, tested positive for Covid-19 while on a 7-day Caribbean tour. The ship exceeded US guidelines, with all guests and crew vaccinated. The infected passengers are asymptomatic and in isolation. Royal Caribbean is conducting contact tracing and testing for close contacts, and monitoring the situation. The incident highlights the effectiveness of the cruise company's health and safety protocols.

site_title: Miami Bitcoin gathering was a Covid-19 hot spot, attendees say
summary: A recent Bitcoin conference in Miami, attended by thousands, may have become a Covid-19 hot spot, with multiple attendees testing positive for the virus. The event, which had no vaccine verification and rare masking, brought together unmasked crowds and partygoers, raising concerns about the spread of the disease. Despite the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's guidance for fully vaccinated Americans to return to normal life, the conference's organizers had not taken sufficient precautions to prevent the spread of the virus.

site_title: MC Payment controlling shareholder Ching says he lacks confidence in current board
summary: MC Payment's controlling shareholder, Ching Chiat Kwong, has expressed a lack of confidence in the company's current board, citing "recent discoveries" and a perceived failure to pay due regard to his shareholder rights. He has filed two requisition notices, calling for the removal of most directors except for independent director Kesavan Nair. The move comes after a boardroom tussle following the company's AGM, where a resolution for Nair's re-election was passed with 85% of votes. Ching also questioned the legitimacy of the re-election of some directors and has asked for an investigation.

site_title: Goldman Sachs orders US staff to report Covid-19 vaccine status
summary: Goldman Sachs has ordered US employees to report their Covid-19 vaccination status, with those who haven't been vaccinated being told to submit their status by June 10. The move comes as the investment bank prepares to return to the office, with New York employees expected to be back in person by June 14. The requirement is in line with US employer rules, and the company emphasizes that vaccination is a personal choice. This is the latest adjustment by a big company as the US reopens with widespread vaccinations.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei opens flat on Friday
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index opened flat on Friday, down 2.05 points at 28,956.51, in cautious trade following a modest rally on the Dow on Wall Street. The broader Topix index was down 0.18% or 3.48 points at 1,953.25. The global market trends, including the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty, had little impact on Tokyo's trading.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rise at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened with gains on Friday morning, following a record-breaking lead from Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.44% to 28,864.90, while the Shanghai Composite Index gained 0.09%. Investors took a forecast-beating US inflation reading in stride, indicating a positive sentiment. This is the second consecutive day of gains for Hong Kong stocks, with the STI also rising 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: Europe: Stocks eke out fresh record as ECB raises recovery outlook
summary: European stocks reached fresh record highs as the European Central Bank raised its recovery outlook, promising to keep stimulus flowing. The ECB now expects 2021 euro zone economic growth at 4.6% and inflation at 1.9%, above its target. Interest rate-sensitive banking stocks rose 0.4%, while tech stocks rose 0.9%. However, travel stocks fell 1.2% after recent gains, and automakers fell for the third straight day.

site_title: South Korea to begin normalising monetary policy when economy sustains recovery: central bank
summary: South Korea's central bank, the Bank of Korea, plans to normalize its monetary policy once the economy is on track for a solid recovery. Governor Lee Ju Yeol stated that the timing and pace will be determined by closely monitoring Covid-19 developments, economic recovery, and financial imbalances. The bank will also begin simulation testing for a central bank digital currency and research on climate change. The decision comes after the BOK upgraded its economic growth forecast to 4.0% and kept its base rate at an all-time low of 0.50% in its May meeting.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise at Friday's open; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.3% at the opening bell on Friday, tracking gains on Wall Street. The Straits Times Index (STI) gained 8.18 points to 3,170.68. mm2 Asia, CFM, and CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust were among the most actively traded counters. The trio of local banks, DBS, UOB, and OCBC, also saw gains. On Wall Street, the Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite all reached fresh records, driven by investors shrugging off higher US inflation data.

site_title: United Airlines in advanced talks to buy at least 100 Boeing 737 Max jets
summary: United Airlines is in advanced talks to purchase at least 100 Boeing 737 Max jets as part of a fleet revamp, Bloomberg News reported. The airline aims to upgrade its fleet amid surging demand for leisure travel in the US. Boeing may supply 150 Max jets, according to the report. United had previously ordered 25 new Max aircraft in March. The deal, if finalized, would come as Boeing offers discounts and incentives to customers ahead of global air traffic returning to normal levels.

site_title: US music publishers sue Roblox for US$200m over copyright
summary: US music publishers, including artists such as Ariana Grande and the Rolling Stones, have sued Roblox for allegedly using songs without permission, seeking at least $200 million in damages. The National Music Publishers' Association claims Roblox exploits unlicensed music to make millions, while the company maintains it does not tolerate copyright infringement and will defend itself vigorously. The suit aims to require Roblox to pay musicians when their works are used on the platform, a move the company says represents a fundamental misunderstanding of its operations.

site_title: Oil hits two-year highs on rising demand expectations
summary: Oil prices reached two-year highs on Thursday, driven by rising demand expectations and optimism over the US economy. Brent futures rose 0.4% to $72.52 a barrel, while WTI crude rose 0.5% to $70.29. The US unemployment claims fell to a 15-month low, and consumer prices increased solidly in May. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries forecasts oil demand to rise 6.6% this year. Analysts attribute the price increase to strengthening demand and tight supply, but note the market is "priced to perfection."

site_title: Evergrande tycoon loses US$19b as investors revolt
summary: Chinese billionaire Hui Ka Yan's net worth has dropped by about a third to US$19 billion after Evergrande Group, his flagship property company, faces financial crisis. Concerns over the company's health have pushed its stock to near-record lows and bondholders are rushing for the exit due to missed payments and regulatory probes. Evergrande has 1.95 trillion yuan of liabilities, including dollar bonds in portfolios worldwide, and its failure could ripple through China's financial system. Chinese regulators are conducting stress tests on banks' exposure to the junk-rated developer, and Evergrande plans to meet at least one of China's regulatory borrowing limits by the end of the month.

site_title: F&B firms dismayed by latest delay for dining-in
summary: F&B operators in Singapore face a one-week delay in resuming dine-in operations due to the ongoing Phase 3 (Heightened Alert) of the virus outbreak. The delay has resulted in significant financial losses, with operators bleeding cash and facing longer-term costs for testing regimes and unfair rental burdens from landlords. The industry's struggle highlights the challenges faced by small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) during the pandemic.

site_title: Northern Ireland casts shadow over first Johnson-Biden meeting
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson met with US President Joe Biden on Thursday, their first face-to-face talks, amid reported tensions over Brexit's impact on Northern Ireland's fragile peace. Johnson played down claims Biden ordered a rebuke to London, saying there was "absolutely common ground" on upholding the 1998 Good Friday Agreement. The meeting came as the US and EU prepare to discuss the issue, with the EU threatening retaliatory action if checks on deliveries into Northern Ireland are not implemented. Biden reaffirmed the US commitment to protecting the peace process in Northern Ireland and pledged to donate 500 million Covid vaccine doses to 92 poorer countries.

site_title: HK, Singapore to review travel bubble date in July
summary: Hong Kong and Singapore will review plans to open a travel bubble in July, following a second postponement in May due to a spike in coronavirus cases in Singapore. The situation has since stabilized, with both cities showing a downward trend in community cases. The initial plan, set for November, would have allowed one flight per day with up to 200 travelers, with Cathay Pacific and Singapore Airlines set to be the carriers. The review is part of the two governments' commitment to resuming air travel under stringent public health protocols.

site_title: A fresh face revamps 27-year-old Bugis landmark
summary: TCRE Partners is refurbishing Bugis Junction Towers in Singapore, a 27-year-old office development, to keep up with new projects in the area. The $10 million revamp includes the lower facade, lobby, and lift interiors, expected to be completed by the end of this year. The homegrown company, led by Nicholas Yeo, is working to reimage the building's design, inspired by the maritime trading settlement in the area. The refurbishment comes amid competition from newer developments in the Beach Road/Rochor Road locale.

site_title: Johor announces third Covid-19 stimulus package worth RM241m
summary: The Malaysian state of Johor has announced its third Covid-19 stimulus package worth RM241 million (S$77.5 million) to mitigate the pandemic's impact. The package includes measures such as purchasing 190,000 antigen rapid test kits, securing RM40 million worth of vaccines, and providing financial aid to sectors affected by the pandemic. The reopening of the Singapore-Malaysia border will depend on Johor's ability to control daily infections.

site_title: Dutch court tracks BUK missile that downed flight MH17
summary: A Dutch court is investigating the downing of Malaysia Airlines Flight MH17 in 2014, which killed 298 people. The court has been tracking the route of a BUK missile system, which was deployed near Ukrainian separatist-controlled Pervomayski. Russian nationals and Ukrainian separatists are charged with murder. The court will examine evidence on whether the Boeing 777 was shot down by a Russian-made missile, the location of the missile's origin, and the role of the four suspects in the crash. The trial will conclude on July 9, with relatives of victims allowed to address the court in September.

site_title: Singapore to ease Covid-19 curbs from June 14 in two steps
summary: Singapore will exit Phase 2 (Heightened Alert) on June 14 and move to Phase 3 (Heightened Alert) in a two-step approach, with some restrictions easing on June 21. The first step will allow social gatherings of up to five, 50% capacity for attractions and events, and personal care services with mask removal. Higher-risk activities, such as dining in and wedding receptions, will resume on June 21, assuming the situation stays under control. The government aims to have half the population fully vaccinated by August and 75% or higher by October.

site_title: Video game maker EA says hackers stole source code
summary: Electronic Arts (EA) announced that hackers stole its source code and software tools, including for games like FIFA 21 and the Frostbite engine. The company confirmed the breach after Vice Media reported that attackers had made off with the code. EA stated that no player data was accessed, and it has made security improvements. The company is cooperating with law enforcement and experts to investigate the incident. The attack occurred as major video game makers prepared for the Electronic Entertainment Expo, and EA does not expect an impact on its games or business operations.

site_title: Yellen says 'concerned' debt relief could aid Chinese lenders
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen expressed concern that Chinese lenders could benefit from an international debt relief initiative for poor countries. The G-20 countries agreed to extend a moratorium on debt interest payments until December to aid countries recovering from the pandemic. Yellen emphasized the need to ensure the relief doesn't end up in China's hands, promising China would participate as an equal partner. The debt relief measure is expected to save 47 countries $7.3 billion in debt payments between January and June 2021.

site_title: Facebook makes remote work permanent as offices re-open
summary: Facebook has announced that it will allow employees to work remotely permanently, starting June 15, after a year of reopening its offices. The company's new policy will let any remote employee ask to work from home full-time, with the option to relocate to other countries if desired. Facebook aims to provide a consistent work experience for employees regardless of location, citing the importance of work flexibility over physical office presence.

site_title: Singapore, Australia PMs agree to work towards an air-travel bubble between their countries
summary: Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison agreed to work towards an air-travel bubble between their countries, aiming to resume two-way travel in a safe and calibrated manner. They discussed mutual recognition of health and vaccination certificates, as well as vaccination and Covid-19 transmission rates, with the goal of starting with an air-travel bubble for students before expanding to other groups. The move comes as both countries progress in their national vaccination programs and look to revive people-to-people flows after the pandemic.

site_title: Businesses welcome regular testing but are concerned about costs
summary: Singapore's government plans to make regular testing mandatory for businesses with staff in "higher-risk mask-off activities", such as eateries and gyms, starting with the first three months of costs covered by the government. However, businesses are concerned about the long-term costs of testing, with some calling for subsidies or government support. The Health Sciences Authority has granted interim authorisation for four antigen rapid test kits, which will be sold at retail pharmacies starting June 16.

site_title: Bilateral ties continue to be strong and resilient
summary: The Philippines and Singapore maintain strong and resilient bilateral ties across various sectors, including politics, business, research, education, and culture. Ambassador Joseph del Mar Yap notes the growth of government-to-government cooperation in areas like e-commerce, digital technology, and smart cities. The two countries aim to promote bilateral trade and investments, with a focus on areas like fintech, e-commerce, and medical services. The Philippines seeks to diversify its product mix and increase exports to Singapore, while Singapore companies are encouraged to invest in the Philippines. Despite the pandemic, bilateral relations remain strong, with plans to reopen the tourism industry.

site_title: Euro 2020 - By the numbers
summary: The article "Euro 2020 - By the numbers" is not available for summary.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims fall to the lowest level in nearly 15 months
summary: US jobless claims fell to 376,000 for the week ended June 5, the lowest level in nearly 15 months. This marks the sixth consecutive week of decline, as the pandemic's easing grip on the economy boosts domestic demand. Layoffs are abating, with employers scrambling for labor, despite lingering fears of the virus. The US population has been vaccinated, allowing for broader economic re-engagement, but pent-up demand is straining supply chains and fueling inflation pressures.

site_title: The great British reopening: What investors are looking out for
summary: The UK is experiencing a rapid economic reopening, with investors closely monitoring various metrics such as traffic congestion, flight activity, and consumer behavior. The country's blistering Covid-19 vaccine rollout has helped it recover faster than many European countries. As a result, shares in retail, budget airlines, media, and beverage firms are expected to continue rising, with some analysts recommending purchases in cinema groups and casual dining chains. However, concerns remain about the potential impact of a virus variant on the reopening plans, and some doubt the sustainability of the UK's activity surge.

site_title: A timely boost for business alliances
summary: A Philippine Chamber of Commerce in Singapore is set to promote trade, investment, finance, and industry relations between the two countries. The chamber, which aims to unite businesspeople and companies with a common interest in the Philippines, will be registered with the Registrar of Societies in the third quarter of 2021. The chamber plans to hold a Philippine Business Forum and organize talks and business missions to facilitate trade and investment between Singapore and the Philippines, with a focus on leveraging each country's strengths and contributing to Singapore's society and economy.

site_title: Asian millennials minting millions selling NFT art
summary: Asian millennials are making significant profits by selling NFT art, with some earning millions. Shavonne Wong, a 30-year-old Singaporean artist, has sold 26 NFTs for S$87,126, while Mr. Misang, a 33-year-old South Korean artist, has sold 903 NFTs for over S$3 million. Ronald Ong, a 24-year-old Malaysian medical student, has sold over 25 NFTs for S$84,047. Andreas Ivan, a 31-year-old Chinese artist, has sold 67 NFTs for S$225,042. These artists are using platforms like SuperRare and Foundation to showcase their work and connect with buyers. Despite market fluctuations, they remain optimistic about the future of NFTs and the opportunities they provide for creative expression and financial gain.

site_title: Didi reveals US IPO filing, sets stage for blockbuster New York float
summary: Didi Chuxing, China's largest ride-hailing firm, has filed for a US stock market listing, setting the stage for a potential US$10 billion initial public offering (IPO) with a valuation of nearly US$100 billion. This would be the biggest Chinese share offering in the US since Alibaba's 2014 IPO, which raised US$25 billion. The company, backed by SoftBank, Alibaba, and Tencent, has not revealed the exact size of the offering but sources indicate it could raise close to US$10 billion.

images.alt_text: Didi Chuxing, China's biggest ride-hailing firm, on Thursday made public its filing for a US stock market listing, setting the stage for what is expected to be the world's biggest initial public offering this year.

site_title: Increased supply of private homes on confirmed sites a calibrated move as developers seek land
summary: The Singapore government has announced the release of four residential sites under the H2 2021 Government Land Sales (GLS) Programme, increasing the supply of private homes on confirmed sites. Analysts expect strong demand for the sites, which can yield around 2,000 private homes, including executive condominium units, following heated bidding in recent tenders. This move is seen as a calibrated effort to replenish developers' landbanks amid dwindling inventory.

site_title: Tesla to launch high-end Model S 'Plaid' to fend off Mercedes, Porsche
summary: Tesla is launching a high-performance version of its Model S, dubbed 'Plaid', to compete with luxury electric vehicles from Porsche, Mercedes-Benz, and Lucid Motors. The Model S, first introduced in 2012, aims to reignite interest and fend off new challengers in the luxury electric vehicle market. The 'Plaid' model is expected to deliver a sleek design and long driving range, targeting a niche market. This move is part of Tesla's efforts to maintain its market share and stay ahead of rival manufacturers.

site_title: Navigating the data centre boom
summary: Data centres have experienced rapid growth, becoming a sought-after asset for private equity investors. As the global digital economy expands, data centres are emerging as a lucrative market, but they also pose a significant carbon footprint, comparable to the aviation sector. The sector's growth hotspots include Asia, particularly Singapore, and the US. Despite the risks, companies are slow to adopt cyber insurance, and investors must consider the environmental impact of their investments. The data centre boom is expected to continue, driven by increasing demand for digital infrastructure.

site_title: JBS paid hackers US$11m after cyber attack hit plants
summary: JBS USA paid hackers $11 million in ransom after a cyber attack on May 30, disrupting operations across North America and Australia. The attack, attributed to the hacking group REvil with ties to Russia, forced the company to shut down beef plants in the US and Australia, and idled a Canadian plant. The company made the payment in bitcoin to mitigate potential risks and prevent data exfiltration. Operations have since returned to normal, with lost production expected to be fully recovered by the end of the week.

site_title: KLK's bid for IJM Plantations positive for shareholders of all three firms involved
summary: KLK has announced a bid to acquire IJM Plantations for RM1.53 billion, or RM3.10 per share, a slight premium to IJM's valuation. Analysts see this as a strategic move for KLK, potentially increasing its market capitalization to RM31 billion and becoming the largest plantation company listed on Malaysia's bourse. The acquisition is expected to boost KLK's earnings by 2-9% for FY2022 and improve IJM's cash buffer and net gearing.

site_title: SGX seeks feedback on proposed rule changes regarding GIFT Connect
summary: SGX is seeking market feedback on proposed rule changes for its derivatives clearing rules and futures trading rules, specifically regarding the "GIFT Connect" trading link with India's National Stock Exchange. The link allows Nifty futures contracts to be executed in India's special economic zone, GIFT. Proposed amendments include introducing additional financial resources and new default-management tools. The consultation, open until July 7, aims to clarify obligations for SGX-DT trading members when accessing GIFT Connect.

site_title: A year later than planned, Euro 2020 finally ready to dazzle the football world
summary: The European Football Championship, Euro 2020, is finally set to begin after being postponed by a year due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The tournament, featuring 24 national teams and over 600 top players, will be held across 11 cities and four time zones, with 51 matches taking place over 31 days. The event poses significant logistical challenges, including Covid-19 protocols and travel restrictions, but UEFA is prepared for any potential outbreak. The tournament will culminate in the grand final in London on July 12, with some teams, such as Portugal and Belgium, considered favorites to win.

site_title: Filipinos send back sizeable US$2.2b from Singapore
summary: Filipinos working in Singapore remitted a record US$2.2 billion to the Philippines in 2021, solidifying Singapore as the second-largest source of remittances for the country. The strong people-to-people ties between the two nations, with approximately 200,000 Filipinos in Singapore, contribute to the labor and commercial ties.

site_title: 4 new Covid-19 community cases
summary: Singapore reported 13 new COVID-19 cases on June 10, 2021, bringing the total to 62,236. The cases include two unlinked community cases: a 29-year-old nursing aide and a 74-year-old man, both fully vaccinated. Two cases were linked to previously reported patients, while nine were imported from Angola, India, the Philippines, and Britain. No cases were reported in migrant worker dormitories.

site_title: Carbon, climate change & catalyst leadership
summary: A growing number of Americans, particularly younger generations, are prioritizing action to reduce the effects of climate change. A Pew Research Center survey found 48% of Millennials and 49% of Gen Z believe action is needed today. This younger generation is also using social media to raise awareness and get involved in climate activism. Meanwhile, a recent Australian court case successfully blocked the approval of a massive coalmine, citing the environment minister's duty of care to protect young people from the climate crisis. This shift in public opinion highlights the need for corporate leaders to take action on climate change.

site_title: US dollar hovers above 5-month low
summary: The US dollar hovered above a five-month low versus major peers, fluctuating narrowly around the 90 level, as investors awaited US inflation data and a European Central Bank meeting. The dollar index remained near its lowest level since early January, while the euro was mostly flat at $1.2169. The dollar's potential benefit from higher inflation, which could lead to a more hawkish Fed outcome, may contribute to its recovery.

site_title: White site at Marina View triggered from Reserve List
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has announced that a 99-year leasehold white site at Marina View will be released for public tender on June 28. The site, which can yield approximately 905 private homes, 2,000 sq m of commercial space, and 540 hotel rooms, was previously on the Reserve List. Analysts expect the winning bid to be higher than the trigger price of S$1.508 billion per square foot, driven by demand for luxury residential units and hotel space in the Downtown Core.

images.alt_text: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) will launch for public tender a white site at Marina View after an unnamed developer made a successful application for the site's release from the Reserve List.

site_title: Pandemic seen driving warehouse boom in south-eastern Europe
summary: The pandemic has driven a warehouse boom in south-eastern Europe, with logistics and warehouse companies accelerating expansion plans in the region. Manufacturers are relocating operations to avoid costly disruptions caused by Covid-19, with companies like Raben Group and CTP expanding their presence in Romania, Bulgaria, and Serbia. The region's skilled labor, lower labor costs, and favorable permits are attracting foreign investors, with yields on industrial and logistics properties ranging from 5-10%. This growth is expected to continue, with CTP planning to boost its holdings in Romania to near two million square meters by the end of 2021.

site_title: Revive the Anglosphere as a countervailing force
summary: A revived Anglosphere could counterbalance emerging global power blocs, including the Sinosphere, Slavosphere, and Eurosphere. The Anglosphere, comprising the US, UK, Canada, Australia, and New Zealand, would leverage cultural, political, economic, and strategic ties to assert its influence. Revitalizing this bloc would ensure that no single entity sets the terms of global history, promoting a more multipolar world order. This could provide a counterbalance to the growing influence of China and other emerging powers, potentially stabilizing international relations.

site_title: UK regulator to probe Amazon's data usage
summary: The UK's Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) is planning a formal investigation into Amazon.com Inc over concerns of favoring merchants that use its logistics and delivery services. The probe, which may focus on Amazon's use of data and its decision-making process for the buy box, follows an ongoing EU investigation into similar allegations. The potential investigation could result in fines of up to 10% of Amazon's annual sales or a requirement to change business practices.

site_title: A home for art
summary: Cliff Hartono and Christina J Chua, co-founders of Metis Art, have showcased their stylish two-storey black and white terrace house in Chip Bee Gardens, blending natural history and modern art. The couple, who met at an art gallery, started Metis Art in 2019, offering an art education and consultancy firm. Their curriculum, The Tetrad, covers art history and investing in art, and has attracted working professionals. The home features a harmonious blend of fossils and conceptual art, demonstrating how different styles can coexist in a unique and stylish setting.

site_title: Plenty of new opportunities for Singapore companies
summary: Singapore companies are exploring opportunities to expand into the Philippines, driven by the country's liberalized foreign investment rules and tax regime. The Philippines is Singapore's sixth-largest trading partner and top investment source, with trade flows in both directions being strong. Under the new Corporate Recovery and Tax Incentives for Enterprises (CREATE) law, foreign investors enjoy lower tax rates and incentives for highly desirable projects. The Philippine government has identified five priority investment sectors, including automotive, aerospace, electronics, IT-BPM, and copper/nickel, making it an attractive destination for Singapore companies.

site_title: Dim sum dining all day
summary: Some Chinese restaurants are offering dim sum delivery all day, defying the traditional lunch-only rule, as part of the lockdown. Nouri, a Michelin-starred restaurant, offers comfort food dumplings inspired by traditional Sichuan wontons, while Taste Paradise provides a mixed platter of steamed and baked dim sum. Ah Yat Kitchen offers a casual dim sum and family-style Chinese eatery with reasonably-priced dim sum delivery. Social Place also offers a lineup of polished and creative dim sum. These restaurants are taking advantage of the flexible delivery rules to cater to customers' changing dining habits.

site_title: Airbus tells EU hydrogen won't be widely used in planes before 2050
summary: Airbus has told the EU that hydrogen-powered planes won't be widely used in commercial aviation until at least 2050. The planemaker plans to develop the world's first zero-emission commercial aircraft by 2035, but it will initially target regional and short-range planes. Airbus has not yet decided which market segment the first zero-emission aircraft will target, and research remains at an early stage. The company's plans come as rival Boeing rules out using hydrogen on a significant scale before 2050.

site_title: Starting a new cooking chapter
summary: Three new restaurants, NAE-UM by Louis Han, CASA Restaurant by Remy Lefebvre, and Firangi Superstar, are set to open in Singapore. NAE-UM, opening July 1, showcases contemporary Seoul cuisine with a focus on familiar flavors. CASA Restaurant, opening June 21, serves eco-friendly, woodfire-cooked dishes inspired by the chef's early life experiences. Firangi Superstar, opening June 25, brings a fresh perspective to Indian cuisine, with dishes like This is Not Aloo Gobi and Beirut Bhatura.

site_title: Global food import costs to surge 12% to a record this year, says FAO
summary: The Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) predicts a 12% surge in global food import costs to a record high of $1.715 trillion in 2021, driven by surging commodity prices and robust demand during the Covid-19 crisis. This is a 3% increase from last year, mainly due to a strong volume increase for staple food imports. The FAO also notes that China's imports have driven agricultural demand and prices, and expects China to remain the world's top importer of maize.

site_title: Nutryfarm unit in joint venture to sell pre-packed durians
summary: Global Agricapital Holdings, a unit of Nutryfarm International, has entered a joint venture with retailer Kong Jun Durian to sell pre-packed durians in Singapore. The joint venture will have an initial capital of S$10,000, with 51% owned by Global Agricapital and 49% by Kong Jun. The partnership aims to grow Nutryfarm's fruit trading business in Singapore, leveraging Kong Jun's retail and distribution network.

site_title: Elton John says Brexit a 'catastrophe' for new UK singers
summary: Elton John has warned that the UK's post-Brexit trade deal with the EU is "catastrophic" for new singers, citing the loss of visa-free travel and prohibitive costs for touring Europe. The 74-year-old singer met Brexit minister David Frost to discuss the issue, stating that young musicians will be unable to tour freely, hindering their education and development. John believes the government's inaction on the issue will lead to a lost generation of talent, echoing his own experiences when he started his career.

site_title: Global banking regulator mulls tougher crypto rules
summary: The Basel Committee on Banking Supervision, a global banking regulator, is proposing stricter rules for managing banks' exposure to cryptocurrencies, particularly speculative ones like bitcoin. The committee aims to mitigate risks to the banking system, citing concerns over volatility, money laundering, and terrorist financing. The proposed rules would require banks to set aside more capital to guard against cryptoasset default risks, with certain assets, like bitcoin, facing a new, more conservative treatment. The public consultation on the proposals runs until September 10.

site_title: VCC regime could still change to swing in the favour of single family offices
summary: Singapore's variable capital company (VCC) framework is under review to relax its requirements, potentially benefiting single family offices (SFOs). Industry watchers believe the benefits outweigh the risks, offering flexibility, liquidity, and tax exemptions. The regime, launched in 2020, allows SFOs to centralize assets, compose funds, and minimize tax exposure. However, regulators are concerned about the risk of illicit activities, and safeguards, such as appointing a licensed institution to administer anti-money laundering (AML) obligations, may be introduced. The changes are expected to attract more SFOs, solidifying Singapore's position as a wealth-management hub.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher after inflation, jobless claims data
summary: US stocks opened higher on Thursday, despite a bigger-than-expected jump in May consumer prices, which raised concerns of early policy tightening by the Federal Reserve. The Dow Jones rose 0.16%, the S&P 500 gained 0.21%, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.16%. The labor market remained under pressure, with jobless claims data showing no significant change. Investors appeared to brush off concerns, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging to fresh records.

site_title: Local app aims to become 'addictive' tool
summary: A Singapore-based app, AutoApp, is partnering with SPC SpeedyCare workshops to offer car servicing and other services, aiming to become a one-stop mobile app for drivers. The service costs S$50 for servicing, compared to S$68, and includes a S$10 fuel voucher. Ignition Labs, the app's developer, envisions AutoApp as a time-saving solution, with over 1,000 users signed up in 10 months. The company aims to reach 10,000 to 15,000 users in the next year, generating S$2 million in turnover. The service's success relies on its convenience, which is expected to be addictive.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed lower on Thursday at 1,579.90, down 1.58 points. The index saw a volume of 4.915 billion lots worth RM2.737 billion, with 520 gainers and 436 losers.

site_title: Trustee-manager of Keppel Infra Trust names new CEO
summary: Keppel Infra Trust announced the appointment of Jopy Chiang as its new CEO, replacing Matthew Pollard, who will step down on July 31 to pursue other opportunities. Chiang, 36, joins from Keppel Capital with over a decade of experience in infrastructure investing and investment banking. Chiang will lead the trust on its next phase of growth and provide long-term and sustainable returns, according to Chairman Daniel Ee. Pollard will remain as an adviser to ensure continuity and a smooth transition.

site_title: Forget Teslas, BMW's EVs must feel like BMWs
summary: BMW is launching three electric vehicles in Singapore, including the iX3, iX, and i4, as the company scrambles to adapt to rising EV sales. The iX3, debuting in July, is a battery-powered SUV, while the iX and i4, set for release by December and early 2022, are pure electric cars designed to compete with Tesla. BMW aims to make its EVs feel like traditional BMWs, with the iX and i4 boasting sporty features and a unique user interface. The company expects half its global sales to come from EVs by 2030.

site_title: Businesses and brand Singapore in a post-Covid world
summary: Singapore's nation brand remains strong despite the pandemic, with businesses and individuals able to tap into its attributes such as discipline, reliability, and social cohesion. The "Passion Made Possible" concept, featuring real-life stories and citizen ambassadors, has been successful in promoting the nation brand. This approach can be extended to overseas markets, allowing Singaporean enterprises to "hunt in a pack" as part of the Singapore "mother brand." The nation's multiculturalism and competent governance have also become assets in managing the pandemic and recovering from its economic impact.

site_title: ECB renews pledge on faster buying to ensure crisis rebound
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has reaffirmed its pledge to maintain faster emergency bond-buying to support the euro-area's recovery from the economic crisis. The ECB will continue its net purchases at a significantly higher pace than earlier in the year, with purchases averaging 19 billion euros per week. The decision aims to sustain the region's rebound despite rising borrowing costs and vaccination efforts. The ECB's move is expected to influence the Federal Reserve's policy, potentially leading to a similar stimulus extension in the US.

site_title: Heart transplant makes Mazda CX-3 stronger
summary: The Mazda CX-3, a compact crossover, has been updated with a 1.5-liter engine, offering improved performance and efficiency. Reviewers praise the car's good looks, sophisticated curves, and generous equipment levels, including features like a head-up display and blind spot monitors. The CX-3's handling and ride are also commended, with a well-defined steering feel and a comfortable ride. While the engine can feel noisy, the car's overall driving experience is pleasant, making it a compelling option in its class.

site_title: Iata to roll out Covid 'travel pass' in Mid-East soon
summary: The International Air Transport Association (IATA) announced that its digital travel pass will be rolled out in the Middle East in the coming weeks. This comes as Europe and the US relax travel restrictions, allowing countries to adopt digital certificates to revive international tourism. IATA's travel pass, which provides proof of testing and vaccination history, has gained popularity among Gulf carriers. Several major airlines, including Emirates, Etihad Airways, and Qatar Airways, have already started testing the app. The move is seen as a step towards unlocking tourism after the pandemic.

site_title: Hin Leong sues Deloitte over alleged role in oil trader's collapse
summary: Hin Leong Trading, a Singaporean oil trader, has sued Deloitte & Touche, alleging the auditing firm failed to detect "serious irregularities" in its financial statements for over a decade. The firm, which owes creditors over $3.5 billion, collapsed after its founder admitted to unreported trading losses of $808 million. Deloitte is accused of breaching its engagement terms and failing to detect material misstatements in Hin Leong's financial affairs. The lawsuit was filed with the High Court of Singapore on March 5.

site_title: ECB to make further emergency purchases over the next quarter
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) announced plans to make further emergency purchases over the next quarter at a significantly higher pace than previously expected. ECB President Christine Lagarde stated that the bank will maintain its "steady hand" approach and keep its Pandemic Emergency Purchase Programme (PEPP) running until March 2022. The ECB also upgraded its economic forecasts for the euro zone economy, predicting output growth of 4.6% this year and 4.7% next year, with inflation seen at 1.9% this year and 1.5% next year.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore relaxes COVID-19 restrictions, allowing up to 5 visitors per household and dining-in for 5 people, starting June 14. Indoor fitness classes resume from June 21. Staff in unmasked settings must undergo regular testing. Singapore citizens aged 12-39 and recovered patients can book vaccinations from June 11. The Ministry of National Development (MND) raises private housing supply, offering land for 2,000 new homes. Hyflux's judicial managers assure Utico has no impact on their winding-up application. Robinsons Online launches on June 24 with over 200 brands.

site_title: UK house-buying frenzy builds ahead of tax cut deadline: survey
summary: A survey revealed that the UK housing market experienced a surge in home-buyers ahead of a tax cut deadline in June, resulting in a 7-point increase in the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors' price index to +83 in May, its highest level since 1988. This is the fourth consecutive month of price increases. The rush to buy homes before the tax break deadline contributed to the surge, with a shortage of properties on the market also driving up prices.

site_title: Hong Kong chides EU over remarks on electoral system changes
summary: Hong Kong's government has criticized the European Union for denouncing the city's electoral system changes as a breach of China's international commitments. The EU has vowed to increase support for Hong Kong's civil society and media, and may send a delegation of senior officials. Hong Kong's government rejects the EU's claims, calling them "misleading" and "hypocritical," arguing that the EU is attacking China under the guise of defending human rights and democracy. The city's lawmakers have reduced the proportion of seats in the legislature filled by direct elections and introduced a vetting process for candidates deemed insufficiently patriotic.

site_title: Global airline body says 'travel pass' app to go live in weeks
summary: The International Air Transport Association (IATA) announced that its digital travel pass app, designed to facilitate Covid-19 test results and vaccine certifications, will go live in the coming weeks. The app, which has been tested by 60,000 people, was initially intended for airport check-in and boarding stages but has been modified to include immigration checks upon arrival. IATA director general Willie Walsh expressed positive feedback and expects the app to launch soon.

site_title: Wage increases for cleaners from 2023 will give employers time to adapt: Zaqy Mohamad
summary: Singapore's Senior Minister of State for Manpower Zaqy Mohamad announced a six-year wage increase schedule for cleaners, starting in 2023, to give employers time to adapt to the significant wage increases. The wage increases, ranging from 5-20%, will help service buyers plan for the long term and address concerns of disengagement and disemployment. The Progressive Wage Model, which considers stakeholder views, aims to accelerate wage growth for cleaners, with median wage growth outpacing overall wage growth.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei closes higher, recovering early losses
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei index rose 0.34% to 28,958.56, driven by tech rallies and sustained by Japan's vaccination drive acceleration. The broader Topix index edged down 0.02%. Investors focused on the US consumer price index and European Central Bank meeting. Key movers included Fanuc and Tokyo Electron, while Eisai dropped 7.01% on profit-taking.

site_title: All staff in settings with unmasked patrons must undergo regular Covid-19 testing
summary: Singapore's Health Minister Ong Ye Kung announced that all staff in settings with unmasked patrons must undergo regular Covid-19 testing, regardless of vaccination status. The government will cover the testing costs for three months. The Health Sciences Authority has also approved the sale of four Antigen Rapid Test (ART) self-test kits at retail pharmacies, which can produce results in under 20 minutes.

site_title: US CPI exceeds forecasts, fuels inflation concern
summary: The US Consumer Price Index (CPI) rose 0.6% in May, exceeding forecasts, and core CPI increased 0.7%, driven by steady growth in used vehicle, household furnishings, and apparel costs. This marks the largest annual gain since August 2008, with core CPI rising 3.8% from 12 months ago. Price pressures continue to build across the economy, fueled by strong consumer spending, shipping bottlenecks, and rising wages. The Federal Reserve expects inflation to be temporary, but some economists and investors question this, citing trillions of dollars in fiscal support and product shortages.

site_title: Singapore shares upbeat on easing of Covid-19 restrictions; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.29% to 3,162.50 on Thursday, driven by easing of Covid-19 restrictions and upbeat news. The STI is expected to maintain its upward momentum in the second half of 2021, driven by falling inventory levels, low interest rates, and economic growth. Aviation counters, including Singapore Airlines, led the gains, while CapitaLand and Sembcorp Industries also performed well. The easing of restrictions, which includes dining-in for groups of up to five people, is seen as a positive sign for the economy.

site_title: Aung San Suu Kyi hit with fresh corruption charges
summary: Aung San Suu Kyi, Myanmar's deposed leader, has been charged with corruption under the Anti-Corruption Law section 55. The charges stem from evidence found by the Anti-Corruption Commission that she committed "corruption using her rank." This is the latest development in her case, which has raised concerns about the fairness of the justice system in Myanmar. Suu Kyi faces a significant challenge in her ongoing struggle for justice and her future in politics.

site_title: This summer, make it Chianti Classico
summary: The author recommends Chianti Classico as a summer wine, despite its typical association with winter. The wine's sangiovese grape variety pairs well with a variety of dishes, including steak, burgers, and grilled chicken. The author suggests focusing on straightforward Chianti Classicos, known as "normales," which are aged for 12 months and offer a balance of lightness and purity. The article highlights several Chianti Classico producers, including Candialle, Fèlsina, and San Giusto a Rentennano, which offer high-quality wines with distinct styles and price points, ranging from $24 to $68.

site_title: Four new Covid-19 community cases in Singapore, including two unlinked
summary: Singapore reported 13 new Covid-19 cases on June 10, 2021, with four community cases, including two unlinked cases, a 29-year-old nursing aide and a 74-year-old man, both fully vaccinated. Two cases were linked to previously reported patients. There were also nine imported cases, bringing the total to 62,236. No new cases were reported in migrant worker dormitories.

site_title: SASB and IIRC merge to form Value Reporting Foundation
summary: The Value Reporting Foundation (VRF) was formed after the merger of the International Integrated Reporting Council (IIRC) and the Sustainability Accounting Standards Board (SASB). The VRF aims to provide clarity and simplicity in corporate reporting, supporting business and investor decision-making with tools such as Integrated Thinking Principles, Integrated Reporting Framework, and SASB Standards. The foundation seeks to harmonize these tools to make it easier for companies to prepare integrated reports, and it is participating in the development of international sustainability standards by the IFRS Foundation.

site_title: Toshiba colluded with Japan ministry to undermine shareholders, probe finds
summary: Japan's Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry (Meti) colluded with Toshiba's management to influence shareholder votes at the company's annual general meeting (AGM) last year, an independent probe found. The investigation revealed that Meti leaned on foreign investors, including Harvard University's endowment fund, to support Toshiba's management and oppose activist shareholder proposals. Toshiba dismissed a US$20 billion bid from CVC Capital amid the scandal, but announced a strategic review. The probe's findings discredit the government's efforts to improve corporate governance in Japan, with activist investors accounting for about 25% of Toshiba's shareholder base.

site_title: Union Gas secures in-principle approval for mainboard transfer
summary: Union Gas has received in-principle approval from the Singapore Exchange to transfer from the Catalist board to the mainboard, subject to shareholders' approval at an extraordinary general meeting. The move aims to increase visibility and market recognition, allowing the company to reach a larger investor base and potentially raise funds in the future. Union Gas was listed on the Catalist in 2017 and is now seeking greater opportunities for growth.

site_title: Rules on gatherings relaxed, with up to 5 allowed from June 14; facials, saunas can resume
summary: Singapore relaxes COVID-19 rules, allowing gatherings of up to 5 people starting June 14. Capacity limits at events and attractions increase to 50% from 25%, and cinemas, business events, and live performances can accommodate up to 250 attendees with pre-event testing. Personal care services like facials and saunas can resume. Restrictions will be further relaxed from June 21 if the situation remains under control. The country moved into "Phase 3 (Heightened Alert)" after a new wave of infections seeded by the delta variant.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end the day lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended the day marginally lower, with the Hang Seng Index inching down 3.75 points to 28,738.88, despite advances in most of Asia. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.54% and the Shenzhen Composite Index on China's second exchange added 1.09%. The decline comes as investors await US inflation data later in the day, overshadowing early gains.

site_title: China passes law to strengthen control over tech firms' data
summary: China has passed a data security law, strengthening Beijing's control over digital information and data from tech firms like Alibaba and Tencent. The law requires national security reviews of data handling and aims to prevent "harmful overseas activities." China aims to position itself as a leader in big data, with plans to hold about one-third of global data by 2025. The law is part of broader efforts to regulate the tech sector and curb monopolies, following a crackdown on companies like Alibaba and Tencent. The move parallels US and European debates on data protection and regulation.

site_title: Singapore citizens aged 12-39 and recovered Covid-19 patients can book vaccination from June 11
summary: Singapore citizens aged 12-39 and recovered Covid-19 patients can book vaccinations starting June 11. Those who had earlier contracted Covid-19 and have since recovered are eligible, as well as children turning 12 this year. A single dose may boost protection for recovered patients, with those infected more than six months ago prioritized for the single-dose vaccination. As of June 9, over 4.4 million doses have been administered, with 50% of the population expected to be fully vaccinated by August and 75% by October.

images.alt_text: Singapore citizens aged 12 to 39 will be able to register for vaccination come June 11. This includes individuals who had earlier contracted Covid-19 and have since recovered.

site_title: Hong Kong, Singapore to review travel bubble date in July
summary: Hong Kong and Singapore will review their plans to open a travel bubble in July, after the proposal was delayed in May due to a spike in coronavirus cases in Singapore. The Covid-19 situation in both cities has stabilized, with a downward trend in community cases in Singapore and stable conditions in Hong Kong. The review aims to determine a new date for the travel bubble, which was previously set for June.

site_title: AstraZeneca says working with South-east Asian nations on vaccine deliveries
summary: AstraZeneca is working with South-east Asian nations to expedite Covid-19 vaccine deliveries, following reported delays in Thailand. The company has assured that distribution to Malaysia and other countries will commence in the coming weeks. The Thai plant, owned by Thailand's king, has faced concerns over production targets, with the company refusing to comment on the issue due to sensitivity surrounding the monarch's ownership. AstraZeneca has faced similar production and delivery challenges globally, including a dispute with the European Union over a supply contract.

site_title: South Korea considers vaccinating workers at major companies
summary: South Korea is considering vaccinating workers at major companies, including chip and electronics firms, to minimize production disruptions amid a global chip shortage. The labour ministry has sent letters to companies such as Samsung Electronics, SK Hynix, and LG Electronics seeking information on their Covid-19 vaccination needs. The move aims to boost supply and support the economy, with the goal of vaccinating 70% of the population by the third quarter. The government has already inoculated 10 million people, or 19.6% of its population.

site_title: Robinsons to return as online department store, five months after exiting physical retail
summary: Robinsons Singapore is set to return as an online department store on June 24, 2021, about five months after closing its last physical outlet. The new platform, Robinsons Online, will feature over 200 brands, including some familiar names, and is expected to employ Singaporeans in various positions. Incoming managing director Jordan Prainito aims to replicate the success of his previous role at Canningvale Australia, where e-commerce sales increased tenfold in under five years through a digital-first strategy.

site_title: Dining-in for up to 5 people, indoor fitness classes to resume from June 21
summary: Singapore's multi-ministry taskforce on Covid-19 announced that dining-in for groups of up to five people will resume from June 21, along with wedding receptions of up to 100 attendees and indoor fitness classes. These activities are part of a two-stage process to return to Phase 3 restrictions, with higher-risk settings such as F&B establishments required to follow safe-distancing rules and protocols. Enforcement will be stepped up, and firmer action will be taken against any breaches.

site_title: Deutsche Bank sees 300m euro hit from recent Germany court ruling
summary: Deutsche Bank expects a 300 million euro hit from a recent Germany court ruling that favors consumers over banking fees. The bank foresees a 100 million euro provision in the current quarter and temporary revenue declines of 100 million euros in the second and third quarters. The ruling overturned 45 years of accepted practice, making it harder for banks to change terms and conditions with customers. Analysts had expected Deutsche Bank to post a profit of around 340 million euros in the second quarter.

images.alt_text: Deutsche Bank expects to take a 300 million euro (S$483.7 million) hit from a recent court ruling that favours consumers over banking fees, the lender's finance chief said on Thursday.

site_title: Europe: Auto, oil firms weigh on shares ahead of ECB meeting
summary: European stocks slipped 0.1% on Thursday, snapping a four-day winning streak, amid concerns over energy and automakers' shares ahead of the European Central Bank meeting. The pan-European Stoxx 600 index declined, while oil and gas sector shed 0.9%. In contrast, the UK's FTSE 100 rose 0.2% due to a 2.2% jump in BT Group's shares.

site_title: UOB to pilot use of GovTech's Sign with Singpass to confirm customer transactions
summary: UOB is piloting the use of GovTech's Sign with Singpass to confirm customer transactions, marking the first bank in Singapore to do so. The 12-month pilot will start with retail and corporate customers and expand to more products and services in 2022. The feature uses a cryptographically random code to ensure personal data remains confidential. The rollout aims to reduce the use of hardcopy documents, saving over 700 trees per year.

site_title: In a world first, El Salvador makes Bitcoin legal tender
summary: El Salvador became the world's first country to adopt Bitcoin as legal tender after Congress approved President Nayib Bukele's proposal. The move aims to increase financial inclusion, investment, and economic development, with the US dollar remaining as legal tender. Bitcoin must be accepted by firms as payment for goods and services, and tax contributions can be paid in the cryptocurrency. The use of Bitcoin will begin in 90 days, with the bitcoin-dollar exchange rate set by the market.

site_title: Brokers' take: Analysts see positives in KLK's bid for IJM Plantations
summary: KLK has proposed acquiring IJM Plantations for RM1.53 billion, or RM3.10 per share, in cash, exceeding UOB Kay Hian's fair value estimate. Analysts from UOBKH, Maybank Kim Eng, and CGS-CIMB agree that the deal is a positive surprise, offering a good exit price for IJM shareholders and strategic expansion for KLK. The acquisition is expected to lower KLK's average estate age and increase its planted oil palm estates by 28.7%. Analysts maintain "buy" calls on KLK and IJM, with target prices ranging from RM25 to RM29.60.

site_title: Hyflux's judicial managers say Utico has 'no impact' on winding up application
summary: Judicial managers of Hyflux say Utico's offer to rescue the water treatment company has "no impact" on their winding up application. Utico, a white-knight suitor, claims it can meet the minimum conditions required to consider an offer, despite previous discussions being terminated. A virtual town-hall meeting will be held on June 18 for Hyflux shareholders to provide updates on the judicial management and winding up application.

site_title: As Federal Reserve taper looms, global central banks eye their own exits from stimulus
summary: Global central banks are preparing for the Federal Reserve's taper of stimulus, with many countries signaling moves to exit stimulus. The Fed's taper is expected to heighten volatility in global financial markets, particularly for vulnerable emerging markets. Some developed economies, such as Canada and Norway, have already withdrawn pandemic-era stimulus and signalled rate hikes. The Fed's eventual withdrawal of support looms large as a global risk, with potential implications for emerging economies and currencies. Markets are bracing for the Fed's communication of its taper strategy at the Jackson Hole symposium in August.

site_title: Accounting startup Osome gets US$16m in Series A funding
summary: Accounting startup Osome has secured US$16 million in Series A funding from prominent investors, bringing its total fundraise to US$24.5 million. The startup, which provides online accounting services for small and medium enterprises, particularly e-commerce businesses, has seen revenue more than double year-over-year. With over 6,000 customers in Singapore, Hong Kong, and the UK, Osome plans to expand into the e-commerce industry and launch more specific products and apps. The funding will help the company dive deeper into the market, tackling inefficiencies in manual accounting.

site_title: Indonesian fintech BukuWarung raises US$60m in Series A funding
summary: Indonesian fintech startup BukuWarung has raised US$60 million in Series A funding led by Valar Ventures and Goodwater Capital. The funding brings BukuWarung's total funding to US$80 million and will be used to enhance its technology and product capabilities, including building a robust payments infrastructure. The company plans to double its team size to 300 and bolster its MSME operating system by enhancing the platform with better workflow for payments. This investment aims to create a positive socio-economic impact across Indonesia as the country emerges from the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: United Airlines in talks to buy at least 100 Boeing MAX Jets: sources
summary: United Airlines is in talks to purchase at least 100 Boeing 737 MAX jets as part of a fleet revamp, according to sources. The airline is seeking to upgrade its fleet and capitalize on the surge in US leisure travel. Boeing is offering discounts and inducements to attract orders for the MAX, which has been grounded in some countries following fatal crashes. A deal would expand on an existing order of 25 MAX jets and help United retire its oldest single-aisle Boeing 757s.

site_title: China's central bank governor expects inflation to be below 2% this year
