summary: China's central bank governor Yi Gang expects annual average inflation to be below 2% this year, citing structural changes and monetary policy to support the economy's green transformation. The country will maintain normal monetary policy, focusing on price impact from structural changes. Yi also mentioned using structural monetary policy tools to support green transformation.

site_title: Keppel Infra Trust to make extra S$23.8m arbitration provision for Basslink
summary: Keppel Infra Trust will make an additional arbitration provision of S$23.8 million for its Australian subsidiary Basslink, on top of the existing S$76.2 million provisions. The provision covers costs for three arbitrations to resolve disputes over a cable failure in 2015. Basslink will pay a total of A$26 million in costs to Australian state enterprises, which can be settled as part of its refinancing of existing debt. The provision is expected to have no financial impact on the trust's distribution per unit.

site_title: Biden to donate 500m Pfizer doses, urge others to join in
summary: US President Joe Biden plans to donate 500 million Pfizer coronavirus vaccine doses to over 90 countries, with the US also distributing 200 million doses in 2021 and 300 million doses in 2022. The shots will be provided at a not-for-profit price, with the goal of saving lives and ending the pandemic. The donation is part of the US's total commitment of $4 billion to Covax, a global vaccination program. Biden's announcement comes ahead of a meeting with Group of Seven leaders and amid mounting pressure for the US to boost donations to countries in need.

site_title: Brokers' take: UOBKH downgrades Top Glove to 'hold' after Q3 earnings miss
summary: UOB Kay Hian downgraded its call on Top Glove to "hold" from "buy" after the glove maker missed Q3 earnings expectations, citing rationalized earnings and lower severe Covid-19 cases. Analyst Philip Wong attributed the earnings miss to US Customs requirements weighing on volume sales and average selling prices. Wong cut his FY2021-2023 earnings estimates by 20-30% due to lower ASP assumptions. Despite the downgrade, Top Glove's valuations are supported by its generous dividend yields.

images.alt_text: UOBKH has downgraded its call on Top Glove to "hold" from "buy" with a lower RM5.15 target price from RM6.30 previously, against the backdrop of rationalised earnings and lower severe Covid-19 cases in the glove maker's key markets.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end higher on foreign buying; US inflation in focus
summary: South Korean stocks ended higher on Thursday due to strong foreign buying, bouncing back from a near 1% fall on Wednesday. The benchmark Kospi rose 0.26% to 3,224.64, while the won traded flat and the benchmark bond yield fell. Investors awaited clearer signals on inflation ahead of US data later in the day.

site_title: Two Australian states on Covid-19 alert after infected woman's interstate travel
summary: Two Australian states, New South Wales and Queensland, are on Covid-19 alert after an infected couple traveled from Victoria, a state in lockdown, through the states and visited dozens of sites. The couple, who tested positive for Covid-19 in Queensland, may face criminal charges for breaching border restrictions. Authorities are tracing close contacts and locating virus hotspots, with no other cases reported from Queensland. The incident raises concerns about the country's Covid-19 containment efforts, which have largely been successful since the pandemic began.

site_title: Indonesian palm plantations urged to tighten Covid-19 curbs as infections climb
summary: Indonesia's palm oil industry is urging plantations in the top-producing province of Riau to tighten COVID-19 protocols amid a surge in infections. The province has reported an average of 522 cases per day since May 16, and plantations have been criticized for having loose protocols. Industry officials are urging plantations to adopt standardized health measures, such as COVID-19 testing and restricting worker movement, to avoid disruptions in production. This comes as Indonesia struggles with its worst coronavirus outbreak in South-east Asia, with 1.87 million infections and 51,992 deaths reported.

site_title: Renewables giant jumps in debut after biggest 2021 China IPO
summary: China Three Gorges Renewables Group surged 44% in its trading debut on the Shanghai stock exchange, reaching a high of 3.82 yuan, after raising 22.7 billion yuan in its IPO. The company's renewables unit has total assets valued at over 140 billion yuan. The listing reflects investor appetite for renewable energy stocks amid China's push for cleaner energy and its goal to reach peak carbon emissions by 2030.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise on tech, banking stocks as focus shifts to US inflation
summary: Australian shares rose 0.4% on Thursday, driven by technology and banking stocks. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 7,302.5, with tech stocks jumping 2% to a one-month high. Banking stocks also rose 0.4%, while energy stocks fell 1.1%. Investors await US inflation data for clues on when the Federal Reserve will start tapering stimulus. Despite concerns, some analysts remain positive, citing strong tech performance and a possible buy signal for Afterpay.

site_title: GIC-backed analytics startup Amplitude valued at US$4b in latest funding round
summary: Data analytics startup Amplitude has reached a valuation of $4 billion in a new funding round led by Sequoia Capital, with existing investors including GIC, Battery Ventures, and IVP. The $150 million investment quadruples Amplitude's previous valuation of $1 billion. The company, which works with major brands like Ford and Burger King, has seen significant growth during the pandemic and now intends to go public through a direct listing, citing its effective product and ease of use.

site_title: Facebook remote work made permanent as offices reopen
summary: Facebook has made remote work permanent for its employees, allowing them to work from anywhere and even relocate to other countries if desired. The company's policy change, effective June 15, is part of its shift towards a more flexible work arrangement. Facebook's decision follows similar moves by other tech firms such as Google and Microsoft, and comes as the company reopens its offices after a year-long pandemic shutdown.

images.alt_text: Facebook on Wednesday said it will give employees the option of sticking with remote work for the long term, even offering to help some interested in moving to other countries.

site_title: Advanced Systems proposes to buy video game company for S$120m in RTO
summary: Advanced Systems Automation has agreed to acquire video game company Excelgames Interactive Asia Holdings for S$120 million in a reverse takeover (RTO). The deal is part of the company's plan to enhance profitability, following significant disruptions caused by Covid-19 that led to net losses and limited opportunities for fundraising. Excelgames is viewed by Advanced Systems' board as a profitable company with good growth potential in the gaming industry, and its vendors will hold 100% of the company after the restructuring exercise.

site_title: Hotel Covid-19 quarantines to be lifted for most vaccinated travellers to Canada
summary: Canada's mandatory hotel COVID-19 quarantines for incoming travelers are set to be lifted for fully vaccinated individuals in early July. The stays, initially ordered in February to slow the introduction of variants, will be phased out as COVID-19 cases trend downward. Fully vaccinated travelers must be 14 days or more past their last vaccine dose to enter Canada without hotel stays. Canadian citizens, permanent residents, and essential workers will still need to provide proof of a negative PCR test and undergo COVID-19 testing and isolation upon arrival.

site_title: Australia: Shares inch higher on tech gains; US inflation data eyed
summary: Australian shares rose 0.2% to 7,284.8 on Thursday, driven by gains in technology and healthcare stocks. The easing of inflation expectations boosted technology stocks, with Altium and Afterpay gaining 2.7% and 0.5%, respectively. Healthcare stocks also led the gains, with CSL advancing 1.6%. Energy stocks, however, slipped 0.8%, with Woodside Petroleum and Santos falling 0.6% and 1.4%, respectively.

site_title: MND raises private housing supply for Confirmed List under H2 2021 GLS Programme
summary: The Ministry of National Development (MND) has increased the supply of private housing for the Confirmed List under the H2 2021 Government Land Sales (GLS) Programme by nearly 25% to 2,000 units, citing declining inventory of unsold private homes. This is one of the steepest increases in dwelling units since 2016. Four sites, including one executive condominium (EC) site, will yield approximately 2,000 private homes.

images.alt_text: The government also accepted an application from a developer to put up a white site at Marina View for sale by public tender.
The government has increased the supply of private housing for the Confirmed List under the H2 2021 Government Land Sales Programme by nearly 25 per cent to 2,000 units.

site_title: Gold subdued with focus on US data, ECB meeting
summary: Gold prices fell 0.1% to $1,886.66 per ounce, influenced by a stronger US dollar and investors' cautious outlook ahead of US inflation data and the European Central Bank meeting. The dollar index edged up to near 90.183, making gold more expensive for other currency holders. A higher-than-expected US consumer price index would reignite concerns over sooner-than-expected tapering of stimulus measures, negatively impacting gold prices. The ECB is expected to maintain a generous flow of stimulus when policymakers meet.

images.alt_text: Gold prices were on the back foot on Thursday as the dollar ticked higher but traded in a narrow range as investors turned cautious ahead of the European Central Bank (ECB) meeting and US inflation data later in the day.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 2.24 points, or 0.14%, to 1,583.72 on Thursday, driven by a higher volume of 150.34 million lots worth RM57.84 million. Gainers outpaced losers 172 to 97.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Straits Trading, Top Glove, Goodland, Chip Eng Seng, LHN, MC Payment
summary: The Straits Trading Company's subsidiary, Malaysia Smelting Corporation, has temporarily suspended its tin mining and smelting operations due to Malaysia's Movement Control Order 3.0. Top Glove reported a net profit of RM2.04 billion for the third quarter, with its US glove ban delaying its Hong Kong share sale plan. Goodland and Chip Eng Seng announced acquisition deals, while LHN and MC Payment made updates on their operations. The Straits Trading Company rose 0.4% to S$2.86, while Top Glove closed at S$1.60, and shares of Goodland and Chip Eng Seng were down 1.4% and flat, respectively.

site_title: China, US commerce chiefs to cooperate on handling differences, Beijing says
summary: US and Chinese commerce chiefs agreed to promote healthy trade and cooperate on differences, according to a Chinese commerce ministry statement. The high-level exchange comes amid disagreements between the two countries, including the US Senate's approval of a bill targeting Chinese technology. US Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo spoke with Chinese Commerce Minister Wang Wentao, and the two sides agreed to maintain open communication lines. This move follows previous exchanges between US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen and US Trade Representative Katherine Tai.

site_title: Japan's Suga to compile big stimulus package around summer: Nikkei
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga's administration plans to compile a large-scale economic stimulus package, possibly totaling around 30 trillion yen ($362.6 billion), ahead of a snap election in September, despite opposition parties' calls for a similar package. This move aims to appeal to voters and alleviate public finances strained by previous Covid-19 pandemic measures.

site_title: Singapore stocks open slightly higher on Thursday; STI inch up 0.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.1% to 3,155.42 on Thursday, driven by gains from Advanced Systems and Abundance International. The STI has now recorded a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. Meanwhile, global markets were mixed, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 0.4% and European stocks near record highs. Asian markets, including Tokyo stocks, also opened lower due to cautious trading ahead of US inflation data and the ECB meeting.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares kick off day with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened slightly higher, with the Hang Seng Index adding 0.17% to 28,792.02, following a weak lead from Wall Street. The move comes as traders monitor China-US ties after US President Joe Biden revoked an executive order to ban TikTok and WeChat apps. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index dipped 0.11% to 3,587.53, while Singapore's STI rose 0.4% as investors remained positive despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Meatpacker JBS paid equivalent of US$11m in ransomware attack: CEO
summary: JBS USA, a US subsidiary of Brazilian firm JBS SA, paid approximately $11 million in ransom to end a cyberattack that disrupted its North American and Australian operations. The attack halted cattle slaughtering at US plants for a day, threatening to disrupt food supply chains and further increase food prices. The incident follows a similar cyberattack on Colonial Pipeline, the largest fuel pipeline in the US, which disrupted fuel delivery in the Southeast.

site_title: Eleven dead, including eight children, in Mumbai building collapse
summary: At least 11 people, including eight children, died in a residential building collapse in a Mumbai suburb on Wednesday. The incident occurred late at night during heavy rains, which have become more common in the city. Eight people were injured and taken to nearby hospitals. This is the first reported collapse in the city during the monsoon season, highlighting the risk of such incidents in Mumbai.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower ahead of key US data, ECB
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on June 10, 2021, ahead of US inflation data and the European Central Bank's policy meeting. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.13% to 28,823.29, while the Topix index dropped 0.21% to 1,953.00. This cautious trade follows recent rallies in Singapore and Asia, where traders have been resilient despite new US threats and tariff uncertainty.

site_title: UK house-buying frenzy builds ahead of tax cut deadline: RICS
summary: The UK house-buying market is experiencing a frenzy ahead of a tax cut deadline, pushing house prices to their highest level since 1988 in May. The Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors' price index rose to +83, driven by demand for housing and a shortage of properties on the market. Experts warn of a mismatch between buyer and seller inquiries, and a potential surge in inflation. The UK government's stamp duty holiday is set to expire in June, with a new £250,000 tax-free allowance until September.

site_title: Abu Dhabi wealth fund, GIC joins Medline buyout group: sources
summary: Abu Dhabi's sovereign wealth fund, ADIA, is investing around $1 billion in a consortium acquiring medical supply company Medline Industries, alongside Blackstone Group, Carlyle Group, and Hellman & Friedman. The deal values Medline at over $30 billion, with Singapore's GIC also investing. ADIA, the world's third-largest wealth fund, joins the $30 billion leveraged buyout, backed by Abu Dhabi's rainy-day fund with $700 billion in assets.

site_title: France eye Euro 2020 glory as kick-off looms
summary: Euro 2020 is set to begin, with France seeking a rare double after a year-long delay due to the COVID-19 pandemic. France's strong forward line makes them favourites to win a third European crown, while top-ranked Belgium and a youthful England side pose a significant threat. The tournament is taking place in 11 European cities, marking a change from previous events. The competition will be held despite the lingering impact of the pandemic, with Cristiano Ronaldo's Portugal defending their title.

images.alt_text: "All the other countries envy us," said a recent front page of French sports daily L'Equipe underneath pictures of Kylian Mbappe, Karim Benzema and Antoine Griezmann.

site_title: Malaysia Smelting appeals to resume operations at 60% workforce capacity amid MCO 3.0
summary: Malaysia Smelting Corporation (MSC), a subsidiary of Straits Trading, has suspended its tin mining and smelting operations in Malaysia from June 4 to 14 due to Movement Control Order 3.0. MSC has appealed to resume operations at 60% workforce capacity, citing its importance to the global tin supply chain. The company has also issued a notice of force majeure to customers, expecting a slowdown in delivery of tin metal. Contractual obligations have been suspended with immediate effect.

site_title: Oil steadies amid weak summer kick-off for US fuel demand
summary: Oil prices remained steady on Wednesday following weak US fuel demand after the US Memorial Day weekend. Brent crude futures settled at US$72.22 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude closed 9 cents lower at US$69.96 a barrel. The data showed a surge in petrol inventories, contradicting expectations of higher demand during the peak summer driving season.

site_title: UK, US to sign new 'Atlantic Charter' to boost ties, pandemic recovery
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson and US President Joe Biden are set to sign a new 'Atlantic Charter' aimed at boosting ties and leading the world's pandemic recovery. The agreement, modeled on the 1941 accord, promotes democracy, free trade, and opportunity, covering global defense, security, and rebuilding from coronavirus and climate change. The leaders will discuss joint pandemic recovery work, travel, trade, and post-Brexit issues, with a focus on reducing barriers for British tech firms in the US.

site_title: GameStop taps Amazon Australia chief as CEO, may sell shares
summary: GameStop has appointed Matt Furlong, the head of Amazon's Australian business, as its new CEO, succeeding George Sherman. The company may sell up to 5 million new shares, worth $1.4 billion, and has surged 1,300% in 2021. Despite this, GameStop's core business is shrinking due to declining sales of physical game discs. The company's shares fell 7% after the announcement, disappointing some individual investors who had driven the stock's recent surge. Furlong will join on June 21, while a new CFO, Mike Recupero, will start on July 12.

images.alt_text: GameStop on Wednesday named the head of Amazon's Australian business as its CEO and said the struggling videogame retailer may sell new shares, sending its volatile stock down 7 per cent in extended trade and disappointing some of its ardent fan base of individual investors.

site_title: Founder of Dubai's DAMAC offers to take property firm private
summary: UAE property tycoon Hussain Sajwani is offering to buy out minority shareholders in DAMAC Properties, a company he has run for nearly two decades, amid a slump in Dubai's property market. Sajwani, who directly and indirectly owns 72.215% of DAMAC, is making an all-cash offer of 2.185 billion dirhams (S$788.3 million) per share, valuing the deal at US$2.1 billion. The deal would make DAMAC private and delist the company from Dubai.

site_title: Canadian company TC Energy drops Keystone pipeline project
summary: Canadian company TC Energy has terminated the Keystone XL Pipeline project, citing environmental and regulatory commitments. The decision comes after US President Joe Biden formally rescinded a permit for the pipeline by executive order in January, opposing the project due to environmental concerns. The 1,947km pipeline aimed to transport oil from Alberta to Nebraska and refineries in Texas. Environmentalists celebrate the demise of the project, warning that it's a sign of more challenges to come in the fight against fossil fuels.

site_title: US state sues to have Google declared public utility
summary: Ohio's attorney-general has filed a lawsuit to declare Google a public utility, accusing the company of favoring its own products and services in search results, putting competitors at a disadvantage. The lawsuit claims Google's actions amount to a monopoly, and the state seeks government regulation. Google denies the claims, stating the lawsuit has no basis in fact and will defend itself in court. This move follows similar actions by other US states and a recent fine from France's competition regulator.

site_title: Crypto is 'wild West' needing consumer protection, Warren says
summary: US Senator Elizabeth Warren calls the cryptocurrency market the "wild West," calling for stronger oversight and consumer protection. She criticized digital currencies for being an environmental disaster and not a good investment. Warren also expressed concerns about the energy needed to power the Bitcoin network, which she says threatens the environment. She plans to hold additional hearings to explore the issue, but did not specify new regulations. Warren compared the lack of consumer protections in cryptocurrencies to existing financial systems, citing examples such as credit-card fraud protections.

site_title: Facebook working on smartwatch
summary: Facebook is working on a smartwatch that will integrate with its augmented reality glasses, according to a tweet by Andrew "Boz" Bosworth, unit head of Facebook Reality Labs. The smartwatch will feature cameras and connect to Facebook apps like Instagram. Bosworth stated that research and development will continue, and the company will consult with third-party experts to ensure the product is "truly useful." This project is part of Facebook's larger effort to create futuristic eyewear that combines real-world views with internet data or graphics.

site_title: Britain's airlines say extra support needed if travel stays shut
summary: Britain's airlines urge the government to provide industry-specific support to help them survive if travel markets remain shut due to COVID-19. Companies including British Airways, easyJet, and Ryanair are facing a deepening crisis after the government's plans to restart travel fell short of their expectations. The industry lobby, Airlines UK, has requested the extension of furlough for aviation workers, longer repayment periods for COVID-19 government loans, and a "restart grant" scheme to help airlines pay for idle planes. The summer season may be lost, risking airline viability and jobs if meaningful reopening is not possible.

site_title: Young voter anger over housing, jobs threatens Moon's legacy in South Korea
summary: Young voters in South Korea, aged 15-29, are increasingly angry about the government's handling of housing and job opportunities, threatening President Moon Jae In's legacy. Despite being the most educated generation in the country's history, nearly one in four young Koreans are effectively jobless, and housing prices have soared 60% since Moon took office in 2017. This has eroded his approval rating, with many young voters shifting their support to the conservative opposition, who promise to address their concerns through policies such as rent subsidies and support for tech start-ups.

site_title: French PM isolates after wife tests positive for Covid-19
summary: French Prime Minister Jean Castex has isolated himself for seven days after his wife tested positive for Covid-19. Castex received his first AstraZeneca vaccine and had a negative test before the positive result. This is his third isolation in under a year, following contact with a Tour de France official and President Emmanuel Macron. The move comes as France relaxes Covid-19 restrictions and nears its target of 30 million vaccinated individuals by June 15.

site_title: US remains far ahead of global pack in finance, says study
summary: The US remains the world's dominant financial centre, ranking 84 out of 100, surpassing Britain's score of 35. China ranks third with 29 points, driven by its large domestic financial sector. The US leads in international financial activity, particularly in sub-sectors such as hedge funds and FX trading. Brexit has raised concerns for Britain, but the EU is bolstering its financial autonomy by relocating euro trading and clearing activities. The rankings highlight the US's significant lead over other global financial centres.

site_title: US: Stocks end down after another lackluster session
summary: US stocks ended down, with the Dow Jones falling 0.4% to 34,447.14, the S&P 500 shedding 0.2% to 4,219.55, and the Nasdaq Composite Index losing 0.1% to 13,911.75. Investors await key consumer inflation data, while individual companies like Campbell Soup and meme stocks like AMC Entertainment and Clover Health reported declines. The market remains in a trading range pattern, with few major earnings reports or economic data.

site_title: Europe: Shares hold near peaks; travel stocks shine on recovery prospects
summary: European stocks held near record highs on Wednesday, with the pan-European Stoxx 600 index closing 0.1% higher. Travel stocks, such as Air France KLM, Lufthansa, and British Airways owner IAG, rose about 3% after the US CDC eased travel recommendations for 110 countries and territories. The market awaits the European Central Bank's policy decision and a US inflation reading later this week, with investors cautious ahead of these events.

site_title: Huarong, Evergrande bond slump tests too-big-to-fail belief
summary: China's two largest debt issuers, Evergrande and Huarong, are experiencing a bond slump amid concerns over contagion risks in the country's $862 billion dollar bond market. Evergrande's shares fell 7.6% and its bonds are trading below par, while Huarong's longer-dated dollar bonds are trading at 75.4 cents and 70.4 cents, sparking worries about the government's willingness to bail out investors. The government has offered little public support for Huarong, and regulators are conducting stress tests on Evergrande's major creditors, raising concerns about the potential for a debt restructuring.

site_title: Cost of pre-event testing a concern: live event organisers
summary: Singapore's live event organizers are concerned about the cost of pre-event testing for large-scale events, which could lead to higher ticket prices for consumers. Despite the government's plan to introduce extensive testing, which may allow for the resumption of larger-scale events, organizers are worried about the financial impact. Base Entertainment Asia's CEO, Chantal Prudhomme, stated that factors such as testing costs and availability of alternative options like breathalysers will affect ticket prices. The industry is working towards developing a viable reopening plan, with the Singapore Sports Hub calling for closer discussions between the government and industry.

site_title: Greenback hovers at lower end of recent gains
summary: The US dollar hovered at the lower end of recent gains, awaiting US inflation data and a European Central Bank meeting to gauge the pace of global recovery. Investors are concerned about the potential end of monetary stimulus and interest rate rises, which could end a 15-month dollar downtrend. The euro ticked higher, while the US dollar index remained steady, as traders anticipate a wait-and-see stance ahead of key events.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: LHN, a Catalist-listed property company, is aggressively acquiring co-living properties to expand its Coliwoo co-living residential portfolio. The company contributed S$499,999 to a joint venture, which will partly fund the purchase of a S$27 million property. This move comes as the co-living business faces upheaval, with other prominent operators like Hmlet and Cove exiting or taking control of properties. LHN's shares closed at S$0.38, down 2.56%, following the announcement.

site_title: Malaysia, Taiwan say deliveries of Thai-made AstraZeneca vaccines delayed
summary: Malaysia and Taiwan are expecting delays in deliveries of AstraZeneca Covid-19 vaccines manufactured in Thailand due to production problems. The Thai plant, owned by King Maha Vajiralongkorn, is facing concerns over meeting production targets. AstraZeneca has promised deliveries to Southeast Asian countries would begin in July, but the Philippines' delivery was postponed and Taiwan's orders are delayed by a month. Malaysia is expecting delays with its 610,000 doses this month and 1.6 million more later this year.

site_title: US stocks regulator to 'freshen' rules to ensure orderly markets
summary: US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) Chair Gary Gensler announced plans to update trading rules to ensure orderly markets, amid concerns over the impact of disruptors like Robinhood on transparency and investor protection. The review aims to modernize rules, address issues such as "gamification" and data collection, and promote efficient markets. Gensler also disputed Robinhood's claim of cost-free trades, stating that someone pays for order flows and that the data collected is valuable. The goal is to make markets as efficient as possible, while protecting investors and facilitating capital formation.

site_title: Private equity vows to help the world but lenders want proof
summary: Private equity firms have driven a surge in sustainability-linked loan issuance, reaching $87 billion in the first quarter, but lenders are now demanding independent verification of borrowers' environmental, social, and governance (ESG) targets. Industry associations have revised their sustainability-linked loan principles to require external verification, driven by investors and lenders. This shift aims to address concerns about the reliability of borrowers' self-reported ESG performance. As a result, borrowers may face increased scrutiny, and the trend may evolve towards independent verification becoming the norm in the public bond markets.

site_title: Buying frenzy drives price surge in hidden world of diamonds
summary: A buying frenzy is driving up prices in the diamond market, with prices increasing by 10% in a matter of hours. The surge is attributed to strong demand from retailers in the US and China, combined with limited rough diamond supply from De Beers and Alrosa. This has led to a shortage of polished diamonds, with manufacturers competing fiercely for stones. Industry experts warn that the market could be running too hot, with some buyers betting on continued price appreciation. Demand shows no signs of letting up, with Russia also considering selling more rough diamonds from state stockpiles.

images.alt_text: Diamonds have been a big winner from lockdowns around the globe as access to rival luxury offerings, such as experiences and travel, was limited.

site_title: Hyundai overstated just how clean one of its fuel cell cars is
summary: Hyundai Motor Co's UK unit has been ordered by the Advertising Standards Authority to stop claiming its hydrogen fuel cell car "purifies the air as it goes" due to the claim being deemed misleading. The ruling highlights that even the cleanest cars, like the Nexo, still release particulates from brake and tire wear. This emphasizes that electric and hydrogen fuel cell vehicles won't completely eliminate transportation emissions, which account for over half of road transport pollution. The ruling comes as the UK prepares to phase out gasoline and diesel cars by 2030.

site_title: Peugeot to be prosecuted in France over 'dieselgate'
summary: Peugeot faces prosecution in France over "dieselgate" emissions cheating scandal, with its parent company Stellantis announcing two subsidiaries, Automobiles Citroen and FCA Italy, have been summoned to appear before the Judicial Court of Paris. Peugeot is under investigation for consumer fraud related to the sale of Euro 5 diesel vehicles in France between 2009 and 2015. This follows similar charges against Renault and Volkswagen.

site_title: Suppliers expect DIY Covid test kits to take off amid heightened demand for mass testing
summary: Suppliers of Covid-19 test kits in Singapore are expected to enter the DIY market amid heightened demand for mass testing ahead of the country's economic activities resumption. DIY kits, already in use in other countries, are quick and simple to use, but less accurate than PCR tests. Suppliers like Arista Biotech and SPD Scientific are targeting businesses in high-density industries, while some are also planning to target individuals. The DIY kits are seen as a way to differentiate themselves in the crowded market and provide a cheaper and swifter alternative for companies.

site_title: Southwest Airlines takes 34 more Boeing 737s as leisure travel returns
summary: Southwest Airlines plans to take 34 more Boeing 737 Max 7 jets, bringing its total order to 660, as leisure travel resumes. The deal is seen as a strategic move to counter budget airlines and startups targeting secondary markets. The airline's fleet revamp is expected to cost around $1.5 billion, with the Max 7 jets complementing its 175-seat Max 8 model. Southwest's shares rose slightly following the announcement, as the airline expects to operate at 97% of 2019 levels in July and sees modest improvements in business travel.

site_title: Trump's presence is thwarting rejuvenation of the Republican Party
summary: Former US President Donald Trump is reportedly considering running for a seat in the US House of Representatives in 2022, with the goal of becoming Speaker of the House. This move would allow him to launch impeachment proceedings against President Joe Biden and potentially reinstate himself as President. Trump's supporters believe he could win a seat and use his position to advance his agenda, despite significant obstacles, including the need for Vice-President Kamala Harris to be removed from office. This scenario is seen as a long shot, but it highlights Trump's continued influence over the Republican Party and his ability to shape the party's direction.

site_title: US 'to buy 500 million doses for world' as curbs ease in Europe
summary: The US plans to donate 500 million Pfizer-BioNTech Covid-19 vaccine doses to countries worldwide, amid a global shortage. As Europe eases restrictions, allowing restaurants and cafes to serve indoors, rich countries face pressure to share vaccines. The global death toll exceeds 3.7 million, with many nations still struggling to contain outbreaks. Meanwhile, Europe's vaccination campaign has accelerated, with almost half of EU adults receiving at least one shot, and hopes of a return to normality are tempered by the ongoing pandemic in poor countries.

images.alt_text: The Washington Post and New York Times, citing people familiar with the matter, said President Joe Biden was due to formally announce the huge donation of Pfizer-BioNTech doses at a G-7 meeting in Britain this week.

site_title: China's producer inflation rise is highest in over 12 years
summary: China's producer price index (PPI) rose 9.0% in May, the highest annual pace in over 12 years, driven by surging commodity prices. This surge in global inflation pressures is raising concerns among investors and policymakers, who are worried about the potential for central banks to tighten policy. Consumer inflation, however, remained below expectations, and experts expect it to remain under control, with some signs of factories passing on higher raw material costs to overseas clients.

site_title: New retailers sprouting in Singapore, but more shop spaces stand empty
summary: New retailers are setting up in Singapore, but many shop spaces remain unoccupied due to the shift towards online operations during the pandemic. Despite a net increase in retail entities, data from the Institute of Real Estate and Urban Studies shows slow take-up of retail units. This trend is expected to continue, with more retailers opting to work from home and start online ventures instead of occupying physical spaces.

site_title: Routine testing for workplaces could temporarily nudge up WFH adoption
summary: Singapore is considering making frequent Covid-19 testing mandatory in workplaces to ensure safety, potentially nudging more employees towards work-from-home (WFH) arrangements. However, experts warn that this may be short-lived as regular testing and vaccinations become the norm. Employers may adopt flexible work arrangements to protect employees' health, and some companies already offer on-site testing or support for staff to get tested. A survey suggests that the shift to WFH is likely to stay for a while, with employers prioritizing employees' physical, emotional, and social well-being.

site_title: ESG factors don't necessarily lead to outperformance, says Scientific Beta study
summary: A recent study by Scientific Beta found that environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors do not necessarily lead to outperformance in investments. The study analyzed market performance from 2007 to 2020 and found that ESG strategies had attractive returns, but once adjusted for factors such as value, size, and profitability, the outperformance diminished. The study suggests that the quality of the stock and the attention cast on ESG in recent years are more important drivers of outperformance.

site_title: Day traders in duel with short-sellers over Korea meme stock
summary: Retail investors in South Korea, known as "ants," are rallying behind Doosan Heavy Industries & Construction, a power-plant builder, after it surged 160% from mid-May. The stock's rapid gains have led to a duel with short-sellers, who are being targeted by online forums. Doosan Heavy has been the most-bought stock by retail investors on the Kospi so far in June and is among the most shorted stocks since the lifting of a ban on short-selling in May. The company is trying to transition to renewable energy, but its parent Doosan Group is undergoing financial restructuring.

site_title: Las Vegas Sands faces US$12b claim in Macau court
summary: Las Vegas Sands is facing a US$12 billion lawsuit in a Macau court from a former partner, Asian American Entertainment Corporation, over a casino licence awarded in 2004. The lawsuit alleges Sands breached its contract, seeking damages of around 70% of Sands' Macau profits from 2004 to 2022. The case comes as Sands faces declining revenues and the expiration of its Macau casino licence, which it must re-bid for in 2022.

site_title: Chinese grocery app Dingdong Maicai targets US$500m in US IPO: sources
summary: Chinese grocery app Dingdong Maicai plans to raise around US$500 million in its US IPO, targeting a valuation of at least US$6 billion. The company, backed by Sequoia Capital and Tiger Global Management, aims to compete in a crowded sector fueled by the Covid-19 pandemic's demand for fresh produce. Dingdong plans to list its shares on the New York Stock Exchange under the symbol "DDL" and has already raised over US$1 billion in funding, valuing the company at US$5.1 billion in its latest funding round.

site_title: Clarity of purpose leads transformation in the business of healthcare
summary: IHH Healthcare's CEO Kelvin Loh attributes the company's transformation during the pandemic to clarity of purpose and vision. The group has prioritized transparency, convenience, and digital healthcare, with initiatives such as fixed price packages, AI-powered cost estimation, and telemedicine. IHH has also expanded its hospital capacity and partnered with governments to provide bed capacity and vaccination drives. As the pandemic continues, Loh emphasizes the importance of public-private partnerships and the role of the private sector in healthcare. The company aims to grow its hospital services through geographical clusters, leveraging its global platform to improve healthcare delivery and reduce costs.

site_title: Crypto art gets lucrative
summary: Crypto art has become a lucrative market, with young Asian artists earning five to seven figure amounts for their digital creations. The non-fungible token (NFT) market is hot, and millennial artists in Singapore, South Korea, Malaysia, and China are capitalizing on the trend. Meanwhile, restaurants in Singapore prepare to reopen, and diners can still enjoy dim sum delivery before it returns to its traditional lunch slot.

site_title: Impact of the great lockdown on global trade
summary: Global trade is recovering robustly, with the World Trade Organization expecting an 8% increase in 2021. The pandemic's impact on trade and investment differs from its effect on goods transportation, allowing global supply chains to prove less vulnerable than feared. Governments have largely avoided protectionist measures, with some countries, like Singapore, signing free-trade agreements to support the recovery. The EU has also concluded key agreements with China and Mercosur, indicating a continued commitment to global trade and investment.

site_title: Unconcerned landlords find plenty of takers for office space that banks vacate
summary: Singapore's banking sector is set to cut office space by 30% over the next few years, but this trend is being offset by tech and corporate tenants filling the vacated spaces. Firms such as tech giants ByteDance, Alibaba, and US companies are expressing strong interest in prominent locations like the Marina Bay Financial Centre (MBFC) and Ocean Financial Centre. Real estate investment trusts (Reits) are also confident of backfilling the vacancies, with some expecting rents to increase due to the limited supply of office space.

site_title: RedDoorz launches Sunerra Hotels
summary: RedDoorz, a Singapore-based hotel management and booking platform, has launched its new chain of hotels, Sunerra Hotels, in the midscale segment with three-star properties and above. The first hotel in Jakarta, Indonesia, features 142 rooms, a swimming pool, spa, and international cuisine. Rooms start at S$35 per night, with an average size of 24 square meters. The company aims to cater to different consumer needs, offering a balance of comfort, local flavors, and value.

site_title: Data deluge: more does not mean better for businesses
summary: A growing amount of data is being created, with 64.2ZB of data generated in 2020, but having more data is not always better, as it can lead to a "data deluge" that impedes understanding and poses risks of data protection and compliance. To mitigate this, businesses need to adopt proper data governance, classification tools, and policies to protect and manage their data. This includes deploying tools to understand what data they have, where it's located, and how to safeguard it against cyber threats and ensure compliance with regulations.

site_title: Goodland, Chip Eng Seng units to acquire properties
summary: Goodland Group and Chip Eng Seng Corporation announced property acquisition deals. Goodland's unit PEG East acquired four freehold shophouses on Serangoon Road for S$16 million to redevelop the land. Chip Eng Seng's unit CES Grosvenor acquired a two-storey commercial building in Adelaide, Australia, for A$2.6 million, expanding its frontage along Hindley Street. Both deals are expected to be completed without material impact on earnings.

site_title: Ignore this ESG revolution at your peril
summary: A shift in corporate priorities is underway in the Asia-Pacific, driven by the growing importance of ESG (Environmental, Social, and Governance) considerations. Companies are seeking leaders who can navigate the intersection of stakeholder expectations and shareholder value. This trend is gaining momentum, with every brief from clients since December calling for experts in corporate affairs and communications. As a result, CEOs and directors who fail to adapt risk their careers and company reputations. This societal phenomenon is a global phenomenon, with smart corporations addressing it rapidly.

site_title: Singapore's sole unlinked case is repairman who had first vaccine dose
summary: Singapore reported four new COVID-19 cases, the lowest daily number since February 2021. The cases include a 29-year-old repairman, a 21-year-old kitchen assistant, and two imported cases from India and Iraq. The cases are linked to a cluster at NTUC Foodfare and a bakery outlet in Ion Orchard. All staff at the Ion Orchard outlet have been quarantined, and the outlet has been closed temporarily.

images.alt_text: His infection is linked to the cluster at NTUC Foodfare in Anchorvale Road.

site_title: Grab delays merger completion to fourth quarter
summary: Grab Holdings postponed the completion of its merger with a US blank-cheque company to the fourth quarter, citing a financial audit of the past three years. The delay is attributed to the company's work with the SEC on accounting policies and financial disclosures. Grab's business has been affected by the coronavirus outbreak, but its consolidated gross merchandise value rose 5.2% to $3.6 billion in the first quarter. The merger is expected to be completed in the fourth quarter, with the combined entity's market value projected to be around $40 billion.

site_title: US$1.8b in official foreign reserves to go towards climate-linked investments
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) plans to deploy US$1.8 billion from its official foreign reserves to five asset managers for climate-related investments. The funds will be used to set up Asia-Pacific sustainability hubs in Singapore and launch new environmental, social and governance thematic funds. The move is part of the MAS' US$2 billion Green Investment Programme, which aims to enhance the climate resilience of the official foreign reserves and attract sustainability-focused asset managers to Singapore.

images.alt_text: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) will deploy US$1.8 billion of the official foreign reserves (OFR) to five asset managers for climate-related investments, MAS managing director Ravi Menon has said.

site_title: Plan for retirement early, but not wise to spurn CPF for higher returns
summary: A recent survey found that while the Covid-19 pandemic has prompted many Singaporeans to start retirement planning early, a significant proportion are willing to give up guaranteed CPF savings for higher investment returns. Only 45% of those aged 21-30 and 35% of those aged 31-40 said CPF savings would be a source of retirement income. This is concerning, as CPF guarantees a minimum 4% compound interest per annum and provides a national longevity insurance annuity scheme. Experts warn that relying solely on investments without safer avenues may leave individuals with no retirement safety net.

site_title: Malaysia's KLK offers RM1.53b for majority stake in IJM Plantations
summary: Malaysia's KLK offers RM1.53 billion to acquire IJM Plantations' majority stake in a cash deal. IJM Corp has agreed to finalise terms with KLK, subject to shareholder approval, lender consent, and authority clearance. The acquisition values IJM Plantations at RM2.73 billion, a 26% premium to its last traded share price. The deal could expand KLK's planted area by 27% and raise palm oil production.

site_title: LHN on aggressive hunt for more properties for its co-living business
summary: LHN Limited, a Catalist-listed company, is aggressively seeking properties to acquire for its co-living business, Coliwoo. The company has contributed S$499,999 to a joint venture to purchase a S$27 million property at 40 and 42 Amber Road. This acquisition follows the high occupancy of existing Coliwoo properties, aligning with the company's business roadmap.

site_title: US eases travel recommendations on 110 countries, territories
summary: The US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has eased travel recommendations for over 110 countries and territories, including Japan, ahead of the Olympic Games. The CDC lowered ratings for 61 countries to "Level 2" or "Level 1", recommending travel for fully vaccinated individuals. Countries now ranked lowest for Covid-19 risks include Singapore, Israel, and South Korea. The CDC also revised its criteria for travel health notices, with some countries being lowered to "Level 3" despite high infection rates, prompting concerns about inconsistent travel restrictions.

site_title: Australia PM Scott Morrison in Singapore for leaders' meeting
summary: Australia Prime Minister Scott Morrison is visiting Singapore for a leaders' meeting with Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, marking the first in-person visit since the Covid-19 pandemic. The two leaders will discuss bilateral cooperation, regional developments, and a potential travel bubble between the two countries. However, a travel bubble remains unlikely due to Australia's slow vaccination rate and Singapore's current Phase 2 (Heightened Alert) measures. Morrison will also attend the G-7 summit in the UK, where he will meet with US President Joe Biden.

site_title: As hiring prospect improves, so does outlook for HRnetGroup shares: CGS-CIMB
summary: Analysts at CGS-CIMB have reiterated their "add" call on HRnetGroup, citing an improving hiring landscape in Singapore as a positive factor for the stock. The brokerage has increased its price target to 82.1 Singapore cents, up from 69.8 cents previously. A labor market report due next week could also serve as a catalyst for the stock. This positive outlook suggests a potential boost to HRnetGroup's shares.

site_title: Malaysia's King summons political leaders as public anger grows over Covid
summary: Malaysia's King Sultan Abdullah Sultan Ahmad is convening a meeting with political leaders on June 16 to discuss the country's handling of the Covid-19 pandemic and the ongoing emergency. The meeting comes amid growing public anger over the government's response to the outbreak. The Conference of Rulers will focus on efforts to combat the pandemic and the measures taken during the emergency. The meeting aims to address concerns and find solutions to the crisis.

site_title: Credit Suisse offers bankers bonuses to stay as defections mount
summary: Credit Suisse is offering selective retention bonuses to senior bankers amid growing defections, following scandals such as the Archegos Capital Management collapse. The discreet payments are aimed at managing divisions within the business. Two senior employees, Andrew Conway and Charles Hadid, have recently left for Bank of America and Morgan Stanley, respectively. The move is seen as an attempt to retain key talent and mitigate the impact of stock-based rewards being lost due to scandals.

site_title: British Airways, Ryanair face UK probe over denied refunds
summary: The UK's Competition and Markets Authority has launched investigations into British Airways and Ryanair Holdings Plc over denied refunds to customers for flights they couldn't take during the Covid-19 pandemic. The probe follows concerns that airlines steered passengers toward rebooking or accepting credits instead of issuing refunds. The regulator is seeking to determine whether the airlines broke UK consumer rules and unfairly left customers out of pocket. The airline companies have responded, with British Airways claiming it issued over 3 million refunds and Ryanair stating it approached refund requests on a case-by-case basis.

site_title: Volkswagen to get US$351m in dieselgate settlement with former execs
summary: Volkswagen has agreed to a US$351 million settlement with former executives, including Martin Winterkorn, over the dieselgate scandal. The settlement includes payments from directors' and officers' liability insurance and settlements with former Audi boss Rupert Stadler, Stefan Knirsch, and Wolfgang Hatz. Winterkorn was charged by Berlin prosecutors for giving false testimony to the German Parliament, and the company's annual general meeting must approve the deal on July 22. The scandal has cost Volkswagen over 32 billion euros in vehicle refits, fines, and legal costs, and has spurred the company to invest in electric cars.

site_title: Nasdaq's green equity plan gives new ESG product key endorsement
summary: Nasdaq is launching a green equity label program in the Nordic region, which will provide a new ESG product trading platform. The framework, if successful, may be adopted in the US, according to Nasdaq's head of European listings. The goal is to connect the dots and create a global framework for green investing, with Adam Kostyal stating that if it works, it can be adopted elsewhere. This move aims to promote sustainable investing and align with growing investor demand for environmentally friendly investments.

site_title: Tesla, gold bars added to Hong Kong's vaccine incentive prizes
summary: Hong Kong authorities are offering incentives, including a Tesla or gold bars, to encourage Covid-19 vaccination. Local businesses, such as Li Ka-shing's CK Group and New World Development, are giving away shopping vouchers and subsidies to vaccinated residents. The move aims to boost the city's sluggish inoculation rate, currently at 15.1% of the population. The campaign follows concerns about rare side effects, faltering trust in the government, and a lack of urgency due to low case numbers. The government has set a goal to accelerate vaccination by September.

site_title: SingPost's next CEO has to deliver on the bottom line
summary: SingPost's current CEO, Paul Coutts, is stepping down, marking the start of a leadership transition at the national postal service provider. Coutts' four-year tenure has seen the company grow its e-commerce market share in Singapore from 20% to 50%, but its margins remain challenging due to increasing volume-related expenses. Coutts' successor faces a daunting task to improve margins and drive growth in a competitive e-commerce landscape, with the company's share price having more than halved since 2015. The board is seeking a candidate with a clear strategy and timeframe for achieving SingPost's transformation goals.

site_title: Grab delays merger completion to Q4
summary: Grab Holdings postponed its merger with a US blank-cheque company, initially expected to be completed in the third quarter, to the fourth quarter of this year. The delay is due to a financial audit of the past three years. Grab's consolidated gross merchandise value rose 5.2% to $3.6 billion in the first quarter, driven by 49% growth in food delivery. The company is still expected to have a market value of $40 billion after the merger, with its stock set to trade on the Nasdaq.

site_title: Fintech MatchMove gets US$100m shot in the arm
summary: Fintech company MatchMove has received a US$100 million strategic investment from US-headquartered IT services group Nityo Infotech Corp at a post-money valuation of US$600 million. The investment, made through Nityo's corporate venture arm Karma Free Capital (KFC) Ventures, will give Nityo the startup's largest shareholder. The deal is expected to provide MatchMove with access to Nityo's staffing resources, clients, and markets as it develops its banking-as-a-service product. MatchMove, founded in 2009, has a presence in several countries and is authorized to operate in multiple jurisdictions, including Singapore, India, and Indonesia.

images.alt_text: MatchMove's Mr Naik (left) says the company will gain access to more resources, clients and markets. Nityo's Mr Kumar says the deal is its "largest investment by far".

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: MAS to deploy $1.8 billion to five asset managers for climate-related investments, part of its $2 billion Green Investment Programme. Climate-linked financial disclosures to become legally binding and align to one global standard. HDB rents rose 0.7% and condominium rents 0.3% in May. Budget hotel brand RedDoorz launches upscale segment with Sunerra Hotels. Goodland unit acquires four shophouses in Serangoon Road for $16m. Top Glove Q3 profit soars to RM2.04b, Singapore stocks extend losses with STI falling 0.4%.

site_title: EU Parliament set to sue European Commission over rule-of-law inaction
summary: The European Parliament is set to vote on a resolution to sue the European Commission over its inaction on enforcing the rule of law, which could impact billions of euros in EU aid. The Commission has been accused of dragging its feet on applying a new regulation that makes EU access to funds conditional on respect for the rule of law and democratic norms. Hungary and Poland, under EU investigation, stand to lose billions in EU funds. The vote is expected on Wednesday evening, with lawmakers warning that inaction could boost Viktor Orban's re-election chances.

site_title: Can Johnson and Biden bolster UK-US 'special relationship'?
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson is set to meet US President Joe Biden on his first foreign trip, aiming to strengthen the UK-US 'special relationship'. The two leaders will discuss global challenges, including China and Russia, as well as bilateral issues like a trade deal and transatlantic travel restrictions. Johnson hopes to build on the traditional ties between the two nations, despite Biden's opposition to Brexit and concerns about the implications for the Good Friday peace process. A trade deal is seen as a key potential victory for Johnson's "global Britain" agenda, but challenges remain, including financial regulations and agricultural differences.

site_title: Google to build new undersea cable to connect Latin America and the US
summary: Google is building an undersea cable called Firmina to connect the US, Brazil, Uruguay, and Argentina, with a total length of approximately 14,000 miles. The cable will carry traffic quickly and securely between North and South America, providing fast, low-latency access to Google services such as Search, Gmail, and YouTube. The project aims to improve internet connection capacity in the region and respond to increased demand for online services during the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 6.48 points to 1581.48. The market saw a significant number of losers (640) compared to gainers (367) and a total volume of 6 billion lots worth RM3.198 billion.

site_title: EU threatens UK with tariffs as Northern Ireland spat escalates
summary: The European Union threatened to impose tariffs and quotas on the UK as a Brexit dispute over trade with Northern Ireland escalates. European Commission Vice President Maros Sefcovic warned that if the UK makes unilateral changes to the legally binding agreement, the EU could retaliate with suspending cooperation in certain sectors and imposing tariffs. The UK has sought to delay implementing parts of the accord, prompting the EU to threaten retaliation. Relations between the EU and UK have deteriorated, with tensions set to grow in coming days.

site_title: Japan's Suga regrets having to take all the heat for hosting Olympics in pandemic
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga expressed regret over taking all the blame for hosting the Summer Olympics during the pandemic, amid strong public and medical opposition. The Games, already postponed by a year, face challenges in Tokyo, where a fourth wave of infections has raised concerns. The government, however, is determined to hold the Games, with domestic spectators allowed and foreign spectators prohibited. Suga's comments came amid criticism of the government's surveillance measures, with some experts warning of restrictions on freedom and human rights.

site_title: UK government 'unlawfully' gave contract to PM adviser's friends
summary: A UK High Court judge ruled that the government unlawfully awarded a $800,000 communications contract to friends of Prime Minister Boris Johnson's adviser, Michael Gove, in June 2020. The contract, valued at $800,000, was awarded to Public First, an agency with ties to Gove and Johnson's former adviser Dominic Cummings, who described their directors as "friends". The judge found apparent bias, but no actual bias, in the awarding of the contract. The ruling comes amid accusations of cronyism and lack of transparency in government contracting during the pandemic.

site_title: Chip Eng Seng unit to acquire Australian commercial property for A$2.5 million
summary: Chip Eng Seng's unit, CES Grosvenor (SA), has agreed to acquire a two-storey commercial building in Adelaide, Australia for A$2.5 million (S$2.56 million). The property is fully tenanted and located on a freehold site with a land size of 287 square meters. The deal is expected to be completed on July 1, allowing the company to increase its frontage along Hindley Street, which will enable better tenant management. The acquisition is part of the company's redevelopment plans for the area, but no specific redevelopment timeline has been disclosed.

site_title: Singapore stocks extend losses; STI falls 0.4%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.4% on Wednesday, extending losses for the second day, with the Straits Times Index (STI) closing at 3,153.47. Asian markets also declined, with the Nikkei 225 and Kospi indices falling 0.35% and 0.97%, respectively. Decliners outnumbered advancers 247 to 238 on the local bourse. Industrial Reits, such as Ascendas Reit and Keppel DC Reit, made gains, with analysts predicting the sector to outperform in the near term.

site_title: MC Payment to defer Ching Chiat Kwong's board-removal resolution to another EGM
summary: MC Payment will not move the resolution to remove most of its directors, as proposed by controlling shareholder Ching Chiat Kwong, to its upcoming EGM on June 30. Instead, the company will hold another EGM by August 1 to vote on the overhaul. On June 30, shareholders will vote on Ching's initial proposal to add new directors to the board. MC Payment's board has decided not to accede to Ching's request, citing a need for reasonable time for directors to make representations and for shareholders to consider the proposals.

site_title: EU, US to end trade tariffs, call for new study into Covid-19 origins
summary: European Union and US leaders agree to lift steel tariffs by December 1, 2021, and end a dispute over aircraft subsidies by July 11. They also pledge cooperation on addressing China's economic rise and call for a new study on the origins of the Covid-19 pandemic. The move aims to avoid further transatlantic trade disputes and strengthen bilateral relations.

site_title: Goodland unit to acquire four Serangoon Road shophouses for S$16m
summary: Goodland Group's unit PEG East has agreed to acquire four Serangoon Road shophouses for S$16 million. The properties are located at 1375, 1377, 1379, and 1381 Serangoon Road and are described as "conveniently located" at the city fringe. The acquisition is intended to be redeveloped, subject to approval, and is funded through internal resources and/or bank borrowings. This deal is not expected to have a material impact on earnings per share for the current financial year ending September.

site_title: Thailand targets 3 million foreign tourists this year under phased reopening
summary: Thailand aims to attract 3 million foreign tourists this year under a phased reopening, with vaccinated visitors allowed to visit Phuket without quarantine in July. The target is lower than initial projections due to the ongoing coronavirus outbreak. The country expects most arrivals in the final quarter, with estimated spending of $7.7-$9.6 billion. Thailand's tourism authority projects 20 million foreign arrivals for 2022, a significant increase from 40 million in 2019. The phased reopening will eventually reopen nine provinces in October.

site_title: Top Glove delays HK listing by few months after US ban on products
summary: Top Glove, the world's largest rubber glove maker, has delayed its Hong Kong listing by a few months due to a US ban on its Malaysian-made gloves. The ban, which is temporary, was imposed after the US Customs and Border Protection ordered personnel to seize the company's gloves. Top Glove has resolved all issues of forced labor and is working to resolve the withhold order. The company has reduced its share sale target to RM4.22 billion, down from RM7.77 billion. The Hong Kong listing is for the long term and will not be affected by the US ban.

site_title: UK composer vows to defy government if coronavirus restrictions not lifted
summary: UK composer Andrew Lloyd Webber vows to defy government if coronavirus restrictions are not lifted on June 21, despite rising infection rates. He warns that further postponement would be another blow to the hard-hit entertainment industry. Lloyd Webber, known for hits in London's West End and Broadway, is prepared to be arrested if restrictions are not lifted. His comments come as the government considers delaying the easing of measures.

site_title: Shell to deepen emission cuts following court ruling, CEO says
summary: Royal Dutch Shell will accelerate its energy transition strategy and deepen carbon emission cuts following a Dutch court ruling that ordered the company to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 45% by 2030. The ruling, which applies immediately, contradicts Shell's current plan, but CEO Ben van Beurden sees it as an opportunity to reduce emissions further. The company aims to cut carbon intensity by 100% by 2050 and plans to increase spending on renewables to 25% of its budget by 2025.

images.alt_text: Royal Dutch Shell will seek ways to accelerate its energy transition strategy and deepen carbon emission cuts following a landmark Dutch court ruling last month.

site_title: Europe: Shares linger near record levels, airlines rise
summary: European stocks remained near record levels, holding steady despite a policy decision from the European Central Bank and US inflation reading later this week. Airlines rose over 1% after the US CDC eased travel recommendations, while Spanish retail giant Inditex increased 1.3% after beating analyst expectations. French food group Danone slipped 1.5% after a downgrade.

site_title: Singapore's Pavilion Energy signs 10-year LNG deal with BP
summary: Singapore's Pavilion Energy has signed a 10-year deal with BP to buy approximately 800,000 tonnes of liquefied natural gas (LNG) annually starting in 2024, as the city-state seeks to diversify its gas supply sources. This is the third long-term deal Pavilion has signed since November, following agreements with Chevron Corp and Qatar Petroleum Trading. The deal also aims to jointly develop a greenhouse gas quantification and reporting methodology to cover emissions from wellhead-to-discharge terminal, in line with Pavilion's goal to eventually make its purchases carbon neutral.

site_title: Dubai tycoon makes US$599m offer to take Damac private
summary: Dubai-based billionaire Hussain Sajwani made a US$599 million offer to take Damac Properties private, a 45% discount from its 2015 local listing. Sajwani's investment vehicle, Maple Invest, is seeking to buy out minority shareholders. The move comes amid sluggish trading and a desire to escape investor scrutiny in Dubai's property market, which has been improving. Analysts say the suggested premium appears low given recent developments in the market, and the trend may deprive investors of exposure to the crucial sector.

site_title: Indonesia reports highest rise in Covid-19 cases in over three months
summary: Indonesia reported 7,725 new Covid-19 cases, the highest daily number in over three months, with a total of 1.87 million cases and 52,162 deaths. This marks a significant rise in cases since February 26.

images.alt_text: Indonesia on Wednesday reported 7,725 new coronavirus infections, the highest daily number since Feb 26, bringing the total number of cases to 1.87 million, data from the country's Covid-19 taskforce showed.

site_title: Malaysia says delivery of Thai-made AstraZeneca vaccines delayed
summary: Malaysia's science minister, Khairy Jamaluddin, announced that deliveries of Thai-made AstraZeneca Covid-19 vaccines are expected to be delayed. This comes amid concerns over AstraZeneca's vaccine distribution plan in Southeast Asia, which relies on 200 million doses from Siam Bioscience, a company owned by Thailand's king. The exact delay duration and number of affected shipments have not been specified.

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly down as investors jostle before inflation, ECB
summary: Asian markets were mostly down on Wednesday as investors awaited US inflation data and the European Central Bank's policy decision, amid concerns about a potential spike in prices forcing central banks to taper ultra-loose monetary policies. The key CPI figures, due Thursday, are crucial, with a reading above 4.7% expected to prompt earlier policy tightening. Oil prices extended their rally, with WTI breaking above $70 for the first time since 2018, as US stockpiles likely fell last week.

site_title: Malaysia's KLK offers US$372m for majority stake in IJM Plantations
summary: Malaysia's KLK has proposed acquiring IJM Corporation's entire stake in IJM Plantations for RM1.53 billion (S$491.4 million) in cash, a 26% premium to the company's last traded share price. The deal, if approved, would expand KLK's planted area by 27% and raise its palm oil production. IJM Corp has agreed to finalize terms with KLK and will also extend a mandatory general offer to acquire remaining shares. The acquisition is subject to shareholder approval, lender consent, and regulatory approval.

site_title: Australian PM calls for WTO reform as tensions with China mount
summary: Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison called for WTO reform to address growing "economic coercion" by China, citing the imposition of tariffs on Australian commodities. China's retaliatory measures, described as "economic coercion," have effectively halted a billion-dollar trade. Morrison urged G-7 nations to endorse reform of the WTO's binding dispute settlement system, stating that without consequences, coercive behavior will persist. The move comes amid strained relations between Australia and China, which have cooled further since Australia's independent investigation into the coronavirus pandemic's origins.

images.alt_text: The World Trade Organization (WTO) must have a binding dispute settlement system to address the growing use of "economic coercion", Australia's Prime Minister Scott Morrison said on Wednesday, as Canberra moves to win the support of G-7 nations in its dispute with China.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end nearly 1% lower on tech slump; US inflation eyed
summary: South Korean stocks ended nearly 1% lower on Wednesday, driven by a tech slump and foreign selling, amid concerns over US inflation data and European Central Bank policy. The benchmark Kospi fell 31.65 points to 3,216.18, with tech giants Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix leading the decline. Foreign investors sold 329.5 billion won worth of shares, further weakening the won.

site_title: COE premiums end mostly higher at latest tender
summary: Singapore's COE premiums ended mostly higher after a three-week break, with cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp closing at S$48,510, up from S$41,801. Cars above 1,600cc or 130bhp finished at S$60,109, up from S$58,089. The higher premiums follow a prolonged period of low demand, with the last tender taking place on May 19. The increases are expected to impact car buyers and contribute to the overall impact of rising fuel costs on the local automotive market.

site_title: Top Glove Q3 profit soars to RM2.04b
summary: Top Glove, a Malaysian glove maker, reported a net profit of RM2.04 billion (S$654.7 million) for the third quarter of 2021, nearly six times the net profit of the previous year. The company attributed the robust performance to technological advancements and research and development. Sales revenue rose to RM4.16 billion, and earnings per share increased to 25.44 sen. However, the company delayed its Hong Kong IPO due to a US ban on its gloves over forced labor issues, and expects to benefit from a downtrend in raw material prices going forward.

site_title: UK launches action against Ryanair, British Airways over refunds
summary: The UK's Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) has launched enforcement action against Ryanair and British Airways over their failure to offer refunds to passengers barred from flights due to lockdown rules. The airlines had instead offered vouchers or rebooking options. The CMA believes the airlines may have breached consumer law, and enforcement cases have been opened. The regulator is seeking a resolution that could include refunds or other forms of redress for affected customers. The move comes as the airline industry faces financial strain due to 15 months of Covid-19 restrictions.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares end lower on caution ahead of US inflation data; Eisai jumps
summary: Japanese equities closed lower on Wednesday due to profit-booking in shippers and semiconductor stocks, awaiting US inflation data's impact on the Federal Reserve's stimulus program. The Nikkei share average fell 0.35% to 28,860.80, while the Topix declined 0.28%. Eisai surged 16.26% after its Alzheimer's drug received US approval. Investors are cautiously waiting for the US CPI number, which could influence market sentiment.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end the day lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended the day 0.13% lower, following a trend in most Asian markets. Investors remained cautious ahead of US inflation figures, which are set to be released later in the week. The Hang Seng Index closed at 28,742.63, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.32%.

site_title: Chinese grocery app Dingdong Maicai targets US$500m in US IPO: sources
summary: Chinese grocery app Dingdong Maicai plans to raise around $500 million in its US IPO, targeting a valuation of at least $6 billion. Backed by investors including Sequoia Capital and Tiger Global Management, Dingdong aims to compete in the crowded US grocery app market. The company has filed for the IPO, but details on the issue size and valuation remain confidential.

site_title: High Court caps OK Lim's spending at S$10,000 a week
summary: Singapore's High Court capped the weekly expenses of the founding family of collapsed oil trader Hin Leong Trading at S$10,000 per person. The order also freezes up to US$3.5 billion of their assets globally and limits their ability to dispose of assets, including properties and insurance policies. Lim Oon Kuin, 79, has been charged with forgery and related offenses, and his family must report all spending to their lawyers. This order may aid debt recovery for over 20 bank creditors, including HSBC Holdings and DBS Group Holdings.

site_title: Ferrari hires little-known tech leader Vigna to be new CEO
summary: Ferrari appoints Benedetto Vigna, a tech leader from chipmaker STMicroelectronics, as its new CEO, replacing John Elkann. Vigna, who helped pioneer screen-sensor technology in iPhones, will focus on transforming the Italian supercar maker into an electric driving and digital gadgetry company. The move reflects the industry's shifts and Ferrari's slow transition to electric cars, which is complicated by tightening regulations on emissions. Vigna's appointment signals Ferrari's shift towards the tech industry, with a capital markets day planned in 2022 to share details about its future.

site_title: UK urges EU 'flexibility' for post-Brexit Northen Ireland trade
summary: Britain urges the European Union to show "flexibility" in post-Brexit trade arrangements for Northern Ireland, citing the protocol's impact on the region and sparking violence. The EU has warned against further unilateral UK actions and threatened retaliation with tariffs if the UK extends a grace period on checks on chilled meats. Brexit minister David Frost and EU vice-president Maros Sefcovic are set to meet to discuss solutions, with Frost emphasizing the need for pragmatism and common sense to resolve the issues.

site_title: Sole unlinked Covid-19 case is Myanmar repairman who got first dose of vaccine
summary: Singapore reported its lowest daily number of Covid-19 cases in six months, with four new cases on June 9. The cases include a lone unlinked case, a 29-year-old Myanmar repairman who received his first vaccine dose on May 31, and three imported cases. The unlinked case is linked to a cluster at NTUC Foodfare in Anchorvale Road. With the new cases, Singapore's total tally stands at 62,223.

site_title: Asia's consumption patterns driven by sustainability and diversity: McKinsey
summary: Asian consumers are expected to drive half the world's growth in consumption, reaching $10 trillion by 2030, according to a McKinsey report. However, businesses will face challenges in adapting to shifting preferences, demographics, and diversity. Gaps in income levels and comfort with online consumption will require stratification of online and physical presence. Sustainability and environmental concerns will also influence consumer behavior, with consumers willing to pay a premium for responsible consumption. Companies must adapt to these changes to succeed in the region.

site_title: MAS to deploy US$1.8 billion to five asset managers for climate-related investments
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) plans to deploy $1.8 billion from its official foreign reserves to five asset managers for climate-related investments, part of its $2 billion Green Investment Programme. The programme aims to enhance the climate resilience of the reserves and attract sustainability-focused asset managers to Singapore. MAS will also exclude companies at risk from the economy's transition to lower carbon intensity and integrate ESG considerations into its investment process. The central bank plans to report its progress annually and set targets for emissions reduction in 2025 and 2030.

site_title: China to reform bank deposit rates pricing regime, set new ceilings: sources
summary: China plans to reform its bank deposit rates pricing regime, allowing banks to set upper limits on deposit rates by adding basis points to the benchmark rate. New ceilings of up to 75 basis points above the benchmark rate will be set for some lenders, with 20 basis points for demand deposits and 75 basis points for time deposits. The move aims to promote interest rate liberalization and lower banks' funding costs. The changes are expected to remain unchanged for one-year fixed deposit rates, but will lower ceilings for fixed deposit rates over one year.

images.alt_text: China plans to reform the way banks calculate deposit rates, setting new ceilings of up to 75 basis points above the benchmark rate for some lenders, sources said.

site_title: US eases travel recommendations on 110 countries, territories including Singapore
summary: The US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has eased travel recommendations for over 110 countries and territories, including Japan ahead of the Olympics. Countries such as Singapore, Israel, and South Korea have been lowered to "Level 1" or "Level 2", while others like France, Ecuador, and South Africa remain at "Level 3". The CDC revised its criteria for travel health notices, and the US State Department is in the process of revising its travel advisory to reflect the changes.

site_title: Budget hotel brand RedDoorz enters more upscale segment with launch of Sunerra Hotels
