summary: RedDoorz, a budget hotel brand, has launched Sunerra Hotels, entering the upscale segment with three-star and above properties. The first hotel opened in Jakarta, Indonesia, with rooms starting at S$35 per night. Each property will have over 100 rooms, averaging 24 square meters, with multiple room categories. This move expands RedDoorz's offerings, targeting the midscale hotel segment.

site_title: Australia: Shares end lower as banks, Woolworths drag
summary: Australian shares ended lower on Wednesday, weighed down by declines in financial stocks and supermarket giant Woolworths. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 0.3% to 7,270.2, reversing early gains. The heavyweight financial sector fell 0.5% and Woolworths shed 1.9% after an independent review found failings in its liquor store plan. Despite this, Australia's major miners rose, with Fortescue Metals Group increasing 1%. Reserve Bank of Australia's assistant governor said policy measures will continue to deliver stimulatory monetary conditions until inflation and employment targets are met.

site_title: HDB rents up 0.7% in May, condominium rents rise 0.3%: SRX
summary: Singapore's condominium rents rose 0.3% in May, while HDB rents increased 0.7%, marking the fifth and eleventh consecutive month of rising condo and HDB rents respectively. Despite fewer foreigners entering the country, the market remained robust due to tenants renewing leases. Condominium rents are up 7.3% year-on-year, while HDB rents are up 7.9%.

site_title: Lazada updates offerings for SMEs under E-Commerce Booster Package programme
summary: Lazada has launched revamped solution packages under its E-Commerce Booster Package programme, offering subsidies of 80% or up to S$8,000 to help SMEs set up online sales channels. The programme provides packages with different value propositions, including content creation, product photography, and dedicated account management. Qualifying retailers can pay S$2,000 after subsidies for a bundle valued at S$28,890. This move aims to reduce barriers to entry for SMEs affected by safe-management measures, building on its success from last year, which brought over 300 businesses onto its platform.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares flat at open
summary: Hong Kong shares opened flat on Wednesday, with the Hang Seng Index down 10.24 points to 28,771.14. Investors remained cautious ahead of US inflation data, while global markets continued to rise, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging to fresh records. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks rallied for the fifth consecutive day, and US-EU trade talks were in focus.

site_title: Climate-linked financial disclosures to be legally binding, align to one global standard: MAS chief
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority (MAS) plans to make climate-linked financial disclosures legally binding and aligned to a single global standard. MAS' managing director Ravi Menon emphasized the importance of reliable and comparable climate-related disclosures for better risk management and capital allocation. The move aims to enhance the quality and consistency of climate-related disclosures, ultimately improving the pricing of climate-related risks and promoting green and transition activities.

site_title: OCBC executes sustainability-linked interest rate swap with Far East H-Reit
summary: OCBC has executed a 2.5-year, S$85 million sustainability-linked interest rate swap with Far East H-Reit to hedge against interest rate risk related to a sustainability-linked loan facility. The swap features a step-down mechanism, where Far East H-Reit can fix its interest rate if it meets its sustainability targets, resulting in lower interest costs. This is a departure from traditional sustainability-linked interest rate swaps, which impose heavier rates on companies that fail to meet their sustainability goals. OCBC expects its sustainability-linked derivatives to grow as it targets S$25 billion in sustainable finance by 2025.

site_title: Tesla, gold bars added to Hong Kong's US$15m vaccine incentive prizes
summary: Hong Kong is offering incentives, including a Tesla or gold bars, to encourage people to get vaccinated against Covid-19. Li Ka-shing's CK Group and New World Development are among the companies participating in the program, which aims to boost the city's sluggish inoculation rate. About 34,600 people reserved vaccine slots in 24 hours, a significant increase. The move is part of the government's efforts to reach herd immunity and alleviate economic concerns. Only 15.1% of Hong Kong's population is fully vaccinated, behind other finance centers.

site_title: Australia inflation unlikely within RBA target range until 2024: central bank official
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) expects inflation to remain below its target range of 2-3% until 2024, according to Assistant Governor Chris Kent. Despite a sharp economic rebound, price pressures remain subdued, and policy measures will remain stimulatory until the economy returns to full employment. Inflation expectations have returned to pre-pandemic levels, indicating that inflation is unlikely to exceed the target in a sustainable way. The RBA's forecast suggests that interest rates will remain at record lows, supporting economic growth.

site_title: Saudi Aramco launches first dollar sukuk bond: term sheet
summary: Saudi Aramco has launched its first US dollar-denominated sukuk bond with three, five, and ten-year tranches, following high demand for Islamic bonds in the Gulf market. The deal's pricing guidance ranges from US Treasuries plus 105 basis points for the three-year tranche to plus 160 basis points for the ten-year tranche. The final terms and size of the transaction are expected to be set on Wednesday, with 29 active and passive bookrunners involved. This marks Aramco's first dollar sukuk bond and follows its previous bond deals in 2019 and 2021.

site_title: Australia's Melbourne to exit Covid-19 lockdown but some restrictions remain
summary: Melbourne, Australia's second-largest city, will exit its Covid-19 lockdown on Thursday, but with some restrictions remaining. Residents will be allowed to step outside except for essential business, but must stay within 25km of their homes and follow mask mandates. Travel and gatherings are banned, and house gatherings are prohibited. Acting Premier James Merlino warned that the lockdown is not over yet and restrictions may ease within a week if case numbers decrease. Melbourne has endured four lockdowns since the pandemic began, with over 800 deaths in Victoria.

site_title: China tells banks to stress test their Evergrande exposure
summary: China's Financial Stability and Development Committee has instructed major creditors of Evergrande Group to conduct a fresh round of stress tests on their exposure to the company, amid concerns over its financial health. The move comes after recent negative news, including late payments on short-term debt and media reports that regulators are scrutinizing Evergrande's dealings with a bank it owns a stake in. The stress tests will assess the potential hit to lenders' capital and liquidity if Evergrande runs into trouble, although it's unclear whether the results will lead to any official action.

site_title: Singapore-based waste management startup Blue Planet buys UK biogas energy company
summary: Singapore-based waste management startup Blue Planet Environmental Solutions has acquired UK biogas energy company Qube Renewables, its third acquisition this year and third in the biogas or anaerobic digestion sector. The deal strengthens Blue Planet's capability to deploy climate-friendly energy solutions into new markets and enhance its anaerobic waste digestion and biogas production plants. The acquisition marks Blue Planet's third UK acquisition and expands its portfolio of AD technologies, enabling the company to provide customized organic waste management solutions worldwide.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index up 1.29 points, or 0.08%, to 1,589.25. Volume reached 289.94 million lots worth RM118.49 million. Gainers beat losers 221 to 150.

site_title: Bitcoin proves double-edged sword for criminals
summary: Regulators have found that Bitcoin's transparent transactions can be a double-edged sword for criminals. While it's easy for hackers like Darkside to extract ransom in Bitcoin, US authorities have clawed back $2.3 million of the funds by tracing transactions. The blockchain's public nature allows for complex tracking, enabling authorities to access private keys and identify perpetrators. This technology has been used to dismantle child pornography rings and has become an industry in itself. Despite its appeal to criminals, the pseudonymous nature of Bitcoin is also working against them, with some transactions being identified and linked to illicit activities.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Wednesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Wednesday, with the Nikkei 225 index down 0.28% and the Topix index down 0.12%. Investors sought fresh market-moving events, following subdued US trade.

site_title: Brokers' take: CGS-CIMB raises HRnetGroup target on upbeat hiring outlook
summary: CGS-CIMB has raised its target price for HRnetGroup to 82.1 Singapore cents, citing an upbeat hiring outlook and improving economic fundamentals. The research house expects higher permanent placement volumes and positive hiring sentiment across Singapore and North Asia. Analysts believe the company's labour markets could be "turning the corner" despite the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic, and a positive labour market report due out on June 14-18 could serve as a tailwind for the stock.

site_title: Gold holds steady as spotlight shifts to US data, ECB meeting
summary: Gold prices remained steady, influenced by the US data and ECB meeting, with investors awaiting the US consumer price index report and ECB policy meeting. US Treasury yields hovered near a month low, and the dollar index remained steady. Gold futures rose 0.1% to US$1,896.60 per ounce. Analysts expect the Fed to discuss tapering monetary stimulus, which could positively impact gold prices, amidst rising inflation and a weak US dollar.

site_title: Malaysia's king summons political leaders amid public anger
summary: Malaysia's king will meet with opposition leaders, including Democratic Action Party head Anthony Loke and former Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad, amid public anger over the government's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic. The meetings come as the government faces widespread dissatisfaction and rising public anger, which could affect unity and lead to protests if elections aren't held in the coming months. The king has the power to lift the state of emergency, which has allowed the government to suspend Parliament and enact temporary laws without legislative approval, but it has failed to contain the outbreak.

site_title: China's factory prices soar in May but consumers avoid cost surge
summary: China's factory gate inflation surged 9.0% in May, the highest rate in over a decade, due to a surge in commodity prices. However, factories are absorbing the costs, not passing them on to consumers, as domestic demand recovers from COVID-19 lockdowns. Consumer prices rose 1.3% in May, less than expected, with pork prices stabilizing after an African swine fever outbreak. The producer price index (PPI) has not been this high since September 2008, but consumer prices remain stable.

site_title: Japan weighs holding Olympics with spectators
summary: The Japanese government and Tokyo Olympics organisers are considering holding the 2020 Tokyo Olympics with domestic spectators as COVID-19 vaccines are rolled out. This is a shift from their previous stance, which was to hold the Games without spectators. Tokyo 2020 President Seiko Hashimoto announced that the plans for spectators will be announced by the end of the month after consultation with the Japanese government. Foreign spectators are already prohibited, and organisers aim to minimize contagion risk with a "sanitised" event.

site_title: US: Stocks end near flat as trade deficit declines
summary: US stocks ended near flat on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.1% and the S&P 500 flat, following data showing a lower US trade deficit of $68.9 billion in April. Retail investors lifted Clover Health Investments by over 85% on the Reddit platform. This comes as equities have been volatile due to concerns over inflation and supply chain issues. Upcoming consumer price data on Thursday may further impact inflation worries.

site_title: China bond selloff fears grow as liquidity starts to tighten
summary: China's sovereign bonds are experiencing growing concerns over a potential selloff, driven by tightening liquidity and increased local government debt sales. The overnight interbank interest rate rose to its highest level since February, while benchmark 10-year bonds are creeping higher in yields. The market is sensitive to capital needs, and municipal governments are expected to double debt issuance this week, which could divert funds away from bonds. Experts warn that investors should be cautious, with the possibility of a one-trillion yuan increase in monthly net government bond financing in the pipeline.

site_title: Facebook to ease creation of Instagram shops for influencers
summary: Facebook is making it easier for content creators to set up digital shops on Instagram, allowing them to add shops to their personal profile pages and link with merchandise companies. The social network is also testing a new affiliate tool to enable creators to earn commissions for product promotions. Brands will set their own commission rates. This move aims to lure creators with new monetization tools as they compete with social media rivals like Snapchat and TikTok, and to attract small businesses to Facebook's e-commerce offerings.

images.alt_text: Facebook chief executive officer Mark Zuckerberg said the social network is making it easier for content creators to set up their own digital shops on photo-sharing app Instagram.

site_title: Thai developer bets on Phuket reopening for return of investors
summary: Thai developer WHA Corp plans to use Phuket's limited reopening to attract foreign investors and boost land sales. The company expects land sales to rebound in the second half, targeting 124 hectares in Thailand and 41 hectares in Vietnam this year. Thailand will reopen Phuket to vaccinated foreign visitors without quarantine starting July 1, allowing tourists to travel across the country. If the reopening is successful, WHA aims to increase land sales to over 160 hectares per year in 2022, driven by pent-up demand created during the pandemic.

site_title: Britain takes step to classifying 'green' investments
summary: Britain has established a Green Technical Advisory Group (GTAG) to classify climate-friendly investments and prevent "greenwashing." The group will develop a taxonomy, or common framework, for environmentally sustainable investments. The move aims to provide better data on the environmental impact of firms, supporting investors and consumers in making green financial decisions. This follows the European Union's lead in publishing its own taxonomy, with Britain set to provide advice on hydrogen, carbon capture, and nuclear power. The GTAG will meet for at least two years, with initial recommendations due in September.

site_title: Australian consumer sentiment slugged by Victoria coronavirus shutdown
summary: Australian consumer sentiment fell 5.2% in June, marking a second consecutive month of decline, due to a coronavirus lockdown in Victoria. The Westpac-Melbourne Institute index of consumer sentiment rose 14.5% from June last year. Despite the decline, optimists still outnumbered pessimists, but the margin narrowed. Economists attribute the drop to concerns over the lockdown, which is expected to be relaxed soon. The outlook for the economy over the next 12 months dropped 10.3%, and intentions to buy a major household item fell 4.1%.

site_title: Hyundai overstated just how clean one of its fuel cell cars is
summary: Hyundai Motor's UK unit has been ordered to stop claiming that its hydrogen fuel cell car "purifies the air as it goes" due to misleading advertising by the Advertising Standards Authority. The claim suggested the car had negligible environmental impact and removed impurities from the air. However, the car still releases particulates from brake and tire wear, contributing to air pollution. This ruling highlights that even electric and hydrogen fuel cell cars won't completely eliminate transportation emissions, and the UK continues to struggle with air quality issues.

images.alt_text: Even the cleanest cars on the road aren't immune from accusations of greenwashing.

site_title: Champion of key Federal Reserve inflation gauge says policy shift is needed
summary: The five-year, five-year forward breakeven inflation rate, a key Federal Reserve gauge, has reached a seven-year high of 2.55%, exceeding the central bank's 2% inflation goal. This level suggests the Fed may need to adjust its massive bond-buying program. Economist Brian Sack, a former Fed official, says the rate indicates inflation expectations are already consistent with the Fed's mandate, and further increases could make it harder to meet its objectives of stable prices and maximum employment. The Fed may begin to trim its bond purchases, a move that could signal a shift in policy.

images.alt_text: The economist who helped change the way the Federal Reserve assesses long-run inflation expectations says their current level means the central bank needs to start laying the groundwork for shrinking its massive bond-buying programme.

site_title: US Senate passes sweeping bill to address China tech threat
summary: The US Senate has passed a bipartisan bill worth $190 billion to boost the country's technology and research capabilities against China's tech threat. The measure authorizes spending on strengthening US technology, increasing semiconductor and telecommunications research, and would need to pass the House of Representatives before being signed into law by President Joe Biden. The bill aims to enhance US competitiveness in the face of growing Chinese influence in the tech industry.

site_title: South Korea's May unemployment rate edges up; more jobs added
summary: South Korea's unemployment rate edged up to 3.8% in May, after falling to an eight-month low in April. Despite the increase, the number of employed individuals rose by 619,000, with jobs added in healthcare, construction, and transportation. The decline in retail jobs continued, with 136,000 positions lost. The government is considering a second supplementary budget to safeguard jobs and boost aid for businesses hit by the pandemic.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall at Wednesday's open; STI down 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.2% at the open on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) losing 4.62 points to 3,162.52. Gainers outnumbered losers 86 to 49, with P5 Capital's shares up 11.1% after announcing a proposed acquisition. Other actively traded stocks included Hong Lai Huat and Singtel, which announced a joint venture with Cambodia Hei Shi Mineral Co. to explore and mine mineral resources.

site_title: Former Grab and Tokopedia executives raise US$5.6m for new fintech venture wagely
summary: Wagely, a fintech startup, has raised US$5.6 million in funding to expand its reach in Indonesia, allowing workers to access their earned wages in real-time. The funding round was led by Integra Partners and includes investors from the Asian Development Bank, T Triputra Investindo Arya, and Global Founders Capital. Wagely aims to bring over 250,000 Indonesians onto its platform by the end of the year, with more than 50 large enterprises already using its platform, including Bentoel Group and Kencana Energy.

site_title: Biden's Asia chief 'relatively confident' on billion vaccine timing despite India crisis
summary: US Indo-Pacific policy chief Kurt Campbell expressed confidence in meeting a target of producing a billion vaccine doses for the region by the end of 2022, despite the COVID-19 crisis in India, where the vaccines are to be made. Campbell stated that the US has been in close consultation with India and other involved parties, and acknowledged the difficulties faced by India during this time.

site_title: Bitcoin sinks and approaches US$30,000
summary: Bitcoin's price fell 8.6% to $31,501, approaching a 6-month low of $30,000. Ethereum also dropped 11.2% to $2,361. The cause of the drop is unclear, but some analysts point to the seizure of $2.3 million worth of bitcoin by US authorities and moves to regulate the crypto space. The price has fallen by over 50% since its peak in mid-April, causing concern among investors.

site_title: How China is tightening its grip on Hong Kong's media scene
summary: China's tightening grip on Hong Kong's media scene is causing concern, with the city's vibrant media landscape under threat. The national security law imposed last year has led to the arrest of democracy activists and the overhaul of the election system, while authorities are eroding freedom of speech and the press. Hong Kong ranked 80th in Reporters Without Borders's latest press freedom index, down from No. 54 a decade ago. The government has denied pressure on the media, but critics argue that the media is being pushed towards a system on the mainland, where the government controls the narrative.

site_title: Sheng Siong signs lease agreement for third store in Kunming, China
summary: Sheng Siong Group has signed a lease agreement for its third store in Kunming, China. The new 37,800 sq ft store is expected to be operational by the end of the third quarter of this year. This brings the group's store count to 63 in Singapore and three in China, with revenue from the China market accounting for 2% of the group's total revenue. The new store is not expected to have a significant impact on the group's financial performance for the year ending Dec 31, 2021.

site_title: South Korea's Q1 GDP up 1.7% q-o-q, ticks up from earlier estimate
summary: South Korea's economy expanded 1.7% in the first quarter, revised from an earlier estimate of 1.6%. Private consumption and facilities investment grew 1.2% and 6.1% quarter-over-quarter, respectively. Construction investment rose 1.3% and exports jumped 2.0%. The revised year-over-year growth rate was 1.9%, better than the previously reported 1.8%. This positive economic performance may have implications for the country's economic outlook.

site_title: Pandemic propels Auckland to top of EIU's most liveable cities ranking
summary: Auckland has taken the top spot in the Economist Intelligence Unit's most liveable cities ranking, replacing Vienna, due to New Zealand's effective Covid-19 elimination measures. The city's geographic isolation and lockdown measures contributed to its high ranking. Auckland's rise to the top comes as the Austrian capital, Vienna, dropped out of the top 10.

site_title: Oil rises as Iranian supply not seen returning soon
summary: US oil prices rose to a two-year high on Tuesday, settling at $72.22 a barrel for Brent crude and $70.05 a barrel for US West Texas Intermediate. The increase is attributed to the US Secretary of State Antony Blinken's statement that even a nuclear deal with Iran would not lead to a significant increase in Iranian oil supply due to hundreds of US sanctions remaining in place. Despite rising demand expectations, supply restraint by OPEC and allies, and declining US crude production, prices remain supported by strong fuel demand recovery in the US and Europe.

site_title: Boeing seeks renegotiation of Air Force One contract
summary: Boeing has requested a price renegotiation for two new Air Force One planes, citing a 12-month delivery delay due to a subcontractor's bankruptcy and production disruptions caused by the coronavirus pandemic. The initial contract price was $3.9 billion, set to be completed by the end of 2024. Boeing has proposed selling two 747-8s to the Air Force instead of the original Russian airline Transaero to offset the cost. The US government is currently assessing whether to adjust the contract calendar.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SATS, Sembmarine, UOB, QAF, New Silkroutes, Clearbridge Health
summary: Stocks to watch: SATS, Sembmarine, UOB, QAF, New Silkroutes, Clearbridge Health. SATS agreed to buy a food-manufacturing facility for S$21 million, Sembmarine explores alternative skilled labor sources, UOB commences consent solicitation for floating rate bonds, QAF plans to reward shareholders with a special dividend, and New Silkroutes received a letter of demand for US$10.7 million.

site_title: Robinhood Markets is said to now target July for IPO
summary: Robinhood Markets is reportedly targeting a July IPO, after initially planning for a listing in late June. The decision was made to coincide with the July 4 holiday travel period, when users are less likely to be actively trading. A final decision has not been made, and the listing plans could change again. The popular trading app, which confidentially filed for an IPO in March, is also rolling out technology to enable customers to buy into IPOs, including its own listing.

site_title: UK pushes for City of London exemption from global tax deal
summary: UK Chancellor Rishi Sunak is pushing for the City of London to be exempt from a global tax deal, which aims to make multinationals pay a minimum corporate tax rate of 15%. The deal, set to be discussed at the G-20 next month, would exempt financial services, including global banks with London headquarters, from the tax. Sunak argues that financial services are a key component of the UK's economy and exempting them from the tax would be necessary to maintain London's position as a global financial hub.

site_title: Europe: FTSE 100 lifted by miners, travel stocks; earnings shine
summary: Europe's FTSE 100 index rose 0.3% on Tuesday, driven by gains in miners and travel stocks. Intermediate Capital Group and British American Tobacco also boosted sentiment with upbeat earnings. Travel stocks, including Flutter Entertainment and InterContinental Hotels Group, climbed 2%. However, a report suggests the June 21 lockdown lift in Britain may be delayed due to rising Covid-19 cases. Despite this, investors remain optimistic about a faster economic recovery, with miners and export-heavy stocks continuing to post gains.

site_title: Musk, Bezos, other billionaires avoid US income taxes: report
summary: Billionaires like Jeff Bezos, Elon Musk, Michael Bloomberg, and George Soros paid zero income tax in some years, according to an investigative report by ProPublica. The report found that these individuals used tax-avoidance strategies and benefited from the US tax code's definition of taxable income, which only considers proceeds from sales, not the growing value of assets. The findings come as the US weighs new proposals to address tax avoidance by the wealthy, including a global minimum corporate tax rate of at least 15%.

site_title: US eases travel warning to countries including Olympics host Japan
summary: The US has eased its travel warning to countries including Olympics host Japan, Canada, Mexico, France, Germany, Greece, and South Africa, following reassessment of Covid concerns. The State Department upgraded its advisory from "do not travel" to "reconsider travel" after the CDC recommended full vaccination for US travelers and non-vaccinated individuals to avoid trips. The easing of travel restrictions comes as the US looks to ease restrictions for European nations, with National Security Advisor Jake Sullivan stating that any easing would be guided by science and evidence.

site_title: Taxing times ahead for shipping?
summary: A global minimum corporate tax rate proposed by the G7 countries could have significant implications for the shipping industry. According to Richard Stephens, a tax expert, the introduction of such a rate could undermine the tax policies applied to shipping, as shipping companies are exempt from corporate taxation in their ports of call. Stephens argues that shipping companies already use tax incentives to compete with low-tax jurisdictions, and that a global minimum tax rate would create a predictable and consistent tax expense, but would also limit the ability of countries to attract investment and develop their maritime industries.

site_title: Contactless payments usurp cash to become new king
summary: Contactless payments have surged globally, driven by the COVID-19 pandemic, innovation, and youth. The Mastercard New Payments Index found a 1 billion increase in contactless transactions in Q1 2021 compared to the same period in 2020. 71% of people expect to use less cash, and 93% are open to new payment methods. The pandemic highlighted hygiene concerns, while improved digital payment technology has increased convenience and reduced costs. Millennials are driving the shift, preferring digital payments over cash, and experts predict contactless payments will become the norm, making cash obsolete in the near future.

site_title: BOJ's absence from stock market in May lauded
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) has withdrawn from the stock market for the entire month of May, marking the first time since Governor Haruhiko Kuroda's easing campaign in 2013. Market watchers praise the move, citing the BOJ's outsized presence as a hindrance to better corporate governance and price discovery. The BOJ's reduced ETF purchases are seen as a step towards curbing its ownership of local stocks and addressing investor concerns about the sustainability of its easing program.

site_title: Ready to travel abroad again? Watch out for superbugs: study
summary: A study published in Genome Medicine found that nearly a third of travelers returning from South-east Asia carried drug-resistant "superbugs" in their gut, posing a risk to global health. Researchers analyzed the feces of 190 Dutch travelers before and after travel to Africa and Asia, revealing a significant amount of antimicrobial resistant genes that don't respond to commonly used antibiotics. The study warns that the overuse of antibiotics by humans is accelerating the development of superbugs, threatening 70 years of progress in treating infectious diseases.

images.alt_text: Newly vaccinated travellers enjoying a return to trips abroad may find a drug-resistant "superbug" hitching a ride in their gut, a study in Genome Medicine says.

site_title: US gold coin sells for record US$18.87m at Sotheby's auction
summary: A 1933 US gold Double Eagle coin, one of the last US gold coins intended for circulation, sold for a record $18.87 million at a Sotheby's auction in New York. The coin, designed by Augustus Saint-Gaudens, was never legally issued due to President Roosevelt's removal of the US from the gold standard during the Great Depression. The sale broke the previous record for the most expensive coin in the world, set by a 1794 Flowing Hair silver dollar. The coin was previously owned by King Farouk of Egypt and had been the subject of a Secret Service investigation.

site_title: Global crackdown on organised crime after high-tech US-Australia sting
summary: US and Australian agencies conducted a high-tech sting operation, hacking into an encrypted messaging app used by organised crime figures, resulting in hundreds of arrests across 18 countries, including Australia, Asia, and the Middle East. The operation, Operation Trojan Shield, targeted the global narcotics trade and involved the use of An0m messaging app, which was taken control of by US authorities in 2018. Australian authorities arrested 224 people, including members of outlawed motorcycle gangs, while New Zealand detained 35 people, with more charges expected.

site_title: Lordstown Motors warns it needs more capital to keep going
summary: Lordstown Motors, an electric truck startup, has warned that it lacks sufficient capital to begin commercial production and may struggle to continue operating. The company has $587 million in cash, which is deemed insufficient for commercial-scale production and vehicle sales. This warning raises substantial doubt about the company's ability to continue as a going concern, causing its share price to plummet 16.3% to $11.22. The company's flagship vehicle, the Endurance pickup, has faced criticism and competition from other electric vehicle manufacturers, further exacerbating the situation.

site_title: Websites worldwide rumble back to life after Fastly-linked outage
summary: A widespread outage affecting various websites worldwide, including Reddit, Amazon, CNN, and The New York Times, was linked to US-based cloud company Fastly Inc. on Tuesday. The outage, which caused issues for citizens booking Covid-19 vaccinations and reporting test results, was resolved after Fastly identified and fixed the issue. The company's website stated that most of its coverage areas experienced "degraded performance," and there was no evidence of a malicious cyber attack. Fastly may offer refunds or credit to affected customers depending on their service level agreement.

site_title: Prospects of US infrastructure deal fade as Biden ends GOP talks
summary: US President Joe Biden ended talks with Senate Republicans on a massive infrastructure package, failing to reach agreement on a bill to fund a national upgrade to roads, public transport, and other elements. The White House proposed reducing the cost to $1.7 trillion, while Republicans countered with a $928 billion proposal. The talks ended with the White House shifting strategy to engage a new bipartisan Senate group, with Biden urging them to develop a compromise proposal addressing the country's pressing infrastructure needs.

site_title: Yen left behind as worst performer in global reflation trade
summary: Japan's currency, the yen, has slumped 6% against the US dollar this year, the worst performance among Group-of-10 currencies, amid a global economic recovery. As interest rates are expected to rise globally, the yen's decline continues. The article does not provide a conclusion but highlights the yen's poor performance in the reflation trade, while Japan's economy appears to be standing still.

site_title: Goldman inks Visa deal for corporate payments push
summary: Goldman Sachs has partnered with Visa to expand its corporate payments capabilities, allowing clients to easily send and track high-value payments overseas. The deal follows discussions with over 100 clients and marks Goldman's growth of its newly formed transaction-banking arm. The partnership aims to facilitate international transactions and increase efficiency for corporate clients.

site_title: Pianist Andras Schiff changes his tune about period instruments
summary: Pianist Andras Schiff, 67, has transformed from disdaining historical instruments to embracing them, including a new Brahms recording with the Orchestra of the Age of Enlightenment. Schiff plays a 1859 Julius Blüthner piano, and also serves as conductor, leading an ensemble of 50 players. His new recording recovers the sound of Brahms' music when it was written, conveying elegance and intimacy. Schiff attributes his change in attitude to playing Mozart's piano in Salzburg, Austria, and notes that historical instruments allow for greater detail and clarity in performances.

site_title: Airline chiefs call for end to UK-US travel restrictions
summary: Airline chiefs from the US and UK are calling for an end to travel restrictions between the two countries, citing high vaccination rates and safe travel conditions. The restrictions, put in place since March 2020, have been in place for over a year and are affecting millions of people. The CEOs of major airlines, including American Airlines and British Airways, urged the US and UK governments to lift restrictions, which are expected to be lifted around July 4, coinciding with the G-7 meeting between President Biden and Prime Minister Johnson.

site_title: A Midsummer Night's Dream onstage, a nightmare off it
summary: Shakespeare's Globe Theater in London recently rehearsed a scene from A Midsummer Night's Dream with a twist, as the cast sang a lullaby to quiet the audience after a chaotic take. The theater, which survived the Elizabethan plagues, has also navigated the coronavirus pandemic. However, the company's director, Sean Holmes, expressed concerns about the tough times ahead, suggesting that the theater may face challenges in the future. Despite this, the cast's performance demonstrated the theater's resilience and ability to adapt to difficult situations.

site_title: 86-year-old woman linked to TTSH cluster dies of Covid-19 complications at KTPH
summary: An 86-year-old Singaporean woman, linked to the TTSH Covid-19 cluster, died on Monday due to complications from the virus. This brings Singapore's death toll to 34. The woman, case number 62680, had not been vaccinated and had pre-existing medical conditions. Three new community cases were reported, including one linked to the cluster and two unlinked. The total number of cases in Singapore has risen to 62,219, with nine new cases confirmed on Tuesday, the lowest daily number since March 17.

site_title: Is white-knight offer Hyflux's last, best hope?
summary: Utico CEO Richard Menezes has made a surprise rescue bid for crisis-hit water treatment company Hyflux, offering unsecured senior creditors five cents on the dollar and retail investors four cents. The proposal, which includes S$50 million of personal shares and S$50 million in cash, comes just days after Hyflux's judicial managers announced an application to wind up the company. However, the proposal's details are unclear, and it's uncertain if Menezes's offer is too late, with judicial managers possibly having already exhausted all options.

images.alt_text: The winding up application of the beleaguered water treatment company and its unit Hydrochem will be heard on July 12

site_title: Six mega-trends hedge fund investors in Asia should take note of
summary: Hedge fund investors in Asia should note six mega-trends that will prevail over the next several years, offering unique opportunities. These trends include Asia's role in dollar asset diversification, the growth of retail investors in ETFs, and the emergence of structural alpha opportunities. Additionally, productivity gains and de-dollarisation are expected to drive wealth creation. As the global economy reopens, accommodative monetary policy, and fiscal stimulus lead to inflation concerns, investors must adjust portfolios to position for a new economic cycle. These trends are expected to shape the market landscape in the coming years.

site_title: Revamping underperforming state-owned enterprises is his job
summary: Indonesian Deputy Minister of State-Owned Enterprises (SOEs) Pahala Mansury aims to revamp underperforming SOEs, introducing professionalism, corporate governance, and a performance-oriented culture. With assets totaling 9.27 trillion rupiah (S$800 billion), Mansury's goal is to unlock value through restructuring and consolidation. He plans to create 20 holding companies to monitor and manage 107 SOEs, with 14 to go public this year. Mansury's top priority is revamping the healthcare sector, with a focus on corporatizing Indonesian Healthcare Corporation and bringing in global investors.

site_title: Why all the fury at Apple?
summary: Apple's annual conference for app-makers has sparked controversy, with developers accusing the tech giant of imposing unfair costs and complexities on them and iPhone users. Apple takes a commission of up to 30 cents per dollar of each sale in iPhone apps, which some developers believe is too high. The issue has gained attention from influential app-makers, including Spotify, Match Group, and Epic Games, which has led to a dispute over Apple's control of the app store. The debate raises questions about the impact of Apple's grip on the iPhone on app prices and innovation.

site_title: Flipkart in talks to raise US$3b from investors including GIC, SoftBank: sources
summary: Flipkart, the Indian e-commerce giant controlled by Walmart, is in talks to raise at least $3 billion from investors including SoftBank Group and sovereign wealth funds. The startup aims for a valuation of $40 billion and is targeting a fundraising ahead of an initial public offering (IPO) planned for next year. SoftBank could invest $300-500 million through its Vision Fund II, while Singapore's GIC, Canada Pension Plan Investment Board, and Abu Dhabi Investment Authority are also involved. This move comes as the e-commerce market in India has boomed over the past 18 months, driven by the pandemic.

site_title: Bitcoin's fizzling 2021 returns start to lag mainstream assets
summary: Bitcoin's value tumbled 7% on Tuesday, falling to around $33,100, as it struggles to regain ground lost in May. Despite being up 14% this year, Bitcoin trails traditional assets and commodities. The decline is attributed to a US recovery of a Bitcoin ransom, which may have undermined the token's libertarian case. Strategists predict a potential test of support around $29,000, with some warning of another capitulation if prices break below $30,000. Bitcoin has plunged from its peak of $65,000 in mid-April, casting a pall over the cryptocurrency sector.

site_title: Real estate ETFs emerging as a bet on global supply-chain mess
summary: Real estate exchange-traded funds (ETFs) are attracting significant investment due to the global supply-chain mess and low interest rates. The US$6.2 billion iShares US Real Estate ETF (IYR) and US$41.4 billion Vanguard Real Estate ETF (VNQ) saw record inflows, with IYR posting US$1.3 billion and VNQ US$338 million. Investors are betting on a "return to normal" environment, with a focus on data storage and supply-chain concerns. Reits with exposure to these sectors, such as American Tower and Equinix, are outperforming hotels, suggesting a shift in investor sentiment.

site_title: It's the end of the road for Singtel's HungryGoWhere
summary: Singtel's HungryGoWhere, a food reviews and reservations portal, will shut down on July 11 after 15 years. The company cited a crowded and fragmented restaurant reviews space as the reason for its closure. In a statement, HungryGoWhere expressed gratitude to its users and thanked them for their support. This move follows Singtel's review of its digital businesses.

site_title: Japan upgrades Q1 GDP on smaller hit to domestic demand
summary: Japan's economy contracted at a slower-than-expected pace in the first quarter, shrinking 3.9% annually, but a smaller hit to domestic demand was reported. Capital spending and private consumption remained weak, but growth in bank lending and real wages showed signs of a gradual recovery from the pandemic. The economy's vaccination rate needs to reach around 50% to boost economic recovery prospects, according to economists.

site_title: US consumers sour on housing market's buying conditions
summary: US consumers have become increasingly pessimistic about the housing market, with a record-low 35% believing it's a good time to buy a home, down from 47% in May. Worries about high prices and low supply outweigh improved job and income sentiment. This marks the second consecutive monthly decline, with 56% of consumers now saying it's a bad time to buy. The Home Purchase Sentiment Index (HPSI) increased to 80, up 12.5 points from last year, but remains at its lowest level since Fannie Mae began the survey about a decade ago.

site_title: Crypto buyers now looking to purchase a physical home
summary: Cryptocurrency developers are targeting younger, affluent investors aged 25-35 to purchase luxury properties, such as One.Six's 30-storey condo in Bangkok, using alternative payment methods like cryptocurrencies. Platforms like Bithome and Zipmex facilitate crypto-friendly property transactions, and some developers are embracing blockchain technology to offer novel approaches to property investment, including fractional ownership of real estate assets. This trend is expected to continue, with One.Six CEO Tanyatip Chearavanont stating that cryptocurrency is "here to stay" in the real estate market.

site_title: Taking a holistic view of resilience will go a long way to ensure success
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic highlighted the need for resilience in businesses, with many private equity investors reviewing their exposure to risks and investing in portfolio companies to build long-term resilience. A holistic view of resilience, considering external events and multiple channels, is crucial for effective risk management. General partners are willing to invest up to 5% of a portfolio company's short-term profit to build resilience, with successful leadership teams taking a strategic, financial, operational, technological, and organisational approach. Companies that have strengthened their resilience, such as Indonesia's PT BFI Finance, have seen improved loan collection and reduced nonperforming loans.

site_title: Asia reflation momentum puts some stocks on top
summary: Asia's reflation momentum has lifted shipping equities and commodity stocks, outperforming broader stock gauges. Companies such as Cosco Shipping Holdings, Philex Mining Corp, and Hoa Phat Group have seen significant gains, with marine transportation being the top industry for benchmark indexes in Japan and Taiwan. Analysts attribute the surge to pent-up demand as major economies reopen with successful vaccine roll-outs. However, risks remain, including China's campaign to control prices and the US Federal Reserve's stimulus tapering.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 9.51 points to 1,587.96 on Tuesday, driven by gains. Volume was 6.711 billion lots worth RM4.111 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 580 to 567.

site_title: Women falling behind in India's Covid-19 vaccination drive
summary: India's Covid-19 vaccination drive has shown a significant gender disparity, with men receiving nearly 17% more vaccines than women. The disparity is most pronounced in rural areas, where women are often unable to travel to vaccination centers due to domestic chores and limited access to information. Health officials attribute the disparity to rumors about vaccines disrupting menstruation and fertility, as well as the lack of awareness among rural women. The government has rejected these concerns and plans to ramp up awareness programs to ensure women prioritize vaccination.

site_title: Renewable energy boom unleashes a war over talent for green jobs
summary: Renewable energy companies are experiencing a global talent shortage, with companies like EDP Renovaveis and NextEra Energy struggling to find workers with the necessary skills for green jobs. Engineering and chemistry graduates with expertise in renewables are in high demand, with some universities launching specialized master's programs to address the shortage. The industry is expected to continue growing, with solar generation capacity tripling and wind capacity doubling by the end of the decade, but the lack of skilled workers could become a bottleneck in the post-pandemic economic recovery.

site_title: Liquidity key to success of Singapore's carbon exchange
summary: Singapore's Climate Impact X (CIX), a joint venture by several financial institutions, aims to launch a global carbon exchange at the end of the year. The platform's success hinges on achieving high liquidity, a challenge faced by existing carbon exchanges. CIX will focus on scaling the voluntary carbon market to help companies address the climate crisis, and experts say it has drawn significant interest from buyers, suppliers, and intermediaries. The launch is timely, with countries like China, Australia, and the US looking to build on their existing infrastructure to meet the growing demand for globally tradable carbon credits.

site_title: FX volatility falls to pre-Covid lows as traders wait it out
summary: Currency market volatility has fallen to pre-Covid lows, with the Deutsche Bank Currency Volatility Index hitting its lowest since February last year. Investors are waiting for clearer signals on inflation and central bank responses, leading to a range-bound market. The US dollar rose 0.1% against the euro, while the euro fell marginally due to weaker-than-expected German industrial production numbers. Implied volatilities on both currencies have dropped to their lowest levels since early 2020, with the Japanese yen also falling against the US dollar.

site_title: Investor beware when it comes to SPACs
summary: SPACs, or Special Purpose Acquisition Companies, have grown in popularity, with US$76 billion in IPO capital in 2020, driven by successful mergers like Virgin Galactic and DraftKings. However, the average retail investor may overlook the inherent risks in the SPAC process. This article warns investors to be cautious when investing in SPACs, highlighting the need for thorough research and understanding of the risks involved.

site_title: Fear of heights not justified
summary: The S&P 500 and Shanghai indices continue their uptrend, with no cause for concern about reaching new highs. Investors should watch for signals of slowing momentum and behavior patterns that precede trend changes. The charts show two parallel trend lines, with the lower line anchored on October 2020 and March 2021 lows. A move below the lower trend line or the development of a rounding-top or head-and-shoulders pattern could signal a trend change. Meanwhile, the Shanghai index has offered short-term investment opportunities, with a current breakout and upside target near previous highs.

site_title: Hyflux's liquidation a sad day for corporate Singapore
summary: Hyflux, a Singaporean water treatment company, has been granted permission to be liquidated by its judicial managers. The decision marks the end of a three-year-long restructuring process, during which the company received several court-ordered debt moratorium extensions. The liquidation affects 50,000 retail investors, including 34,000 preference and perpetual holders who invested in the company's ill-fated billion-dollar Tuaspring project. The case highlights concerns over the company's governance and risk management, with some investors losing their entire investment. The liquidation is seen as a warning to directors who fail to observe their responsibilities.

site_title: Thailand's The Strand accepts crypto as payment but others see limited prospect in property deals
summary: Singapore-based digital exchange Zipmex has partnered with Thai luxury developer One.Six Development to facilitate crypto payments for a 188-unit condo in Bangkok. The platform allows buyers to close part of their property transactions, such as the deposit, with crypto and the remainder with fiat money. However, the initiative is at a "very early stage" due to regulatory issues in Singapore, where Zipmex is not licensed to provide digital payment token services. Industry observers note that the volatility of crypto conversion rates and complex property tax schedules are potential issues, and major property developers in Singapore have declined to comment on accepting crypto payments.

site_title: Anticimex IPO off for now, EQT to sell Swedish pest control firm to its longer-hold strategy
summary: EQT, a Swedish private equity firm, has decided to retain its ownership of Anticimex, a global pest control specialist, instead of exiting the investment through an initial public offering (IPO). The decision comes after six months of deliberation, citing the company's growth prospects and long-term fundamentals. EQT will hold on to its interests in Anticimex, which has an estimated enterprise value of 60 billion kronor (S$10 billion), and is expected to close the transaction in the fourth quarter of 2021.

site_title: Knight Frank's Tan Boon Leong and Ng Ee Kiat join JLL
summary: JLL is welcoming Tan Boon Leong and Ng Ee Kiat from Knight Frank to its logistics and industrial team in Singapore. Tan Boon Leong joins as executive director of logistics and industrial, while Ng Ee Kiat becomes senior director. The pair will leverage their 29 years of experience to provide comprehensive advice to clients on logistics strategy. The move aims to support clients in future-proofing their logistics strategy, with Tan and Ng reporting to Tom Woolhouse, head of logistics and industrial for the Asia-Pacific.

site_title: How carbon credits work
summary: Singapore aims to sign a carbon credits transfer agreement with its first ASEAN country by the end of 2025. The move is part of the country's efforts to reduce its carbon footprint. Temasek, a Singaporean investment firm, has committed to $46 billion in sustainability-aligned investments by FY2025. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is evolving its climate investing approach, and Singapore is considering introducing carbon offsetting legislation for airlines. Meanwhile, companies like BYD, which makes electric vehicle batteries, face increased pressure to cut emissions. This is part of Singapore's growing focus on environmental finance.

site_title: US job openings jump to fresh record high of 9.3 million
summary: US job openings surged to a record high of 9.3 million in April, with 4 million people voluntarily leaving their jobs, indicating workers' growing confidence in finding employment. The number of vacancies exceeded hires by 3.2 million, highlighting hiring challenges. The economy's recovery is being hindered by factors such as childcare obligations, health concerns, and skills mismatches, with the labor market still 7.6 million jobs short of pre-pandemic levels.

site_title: G-7 tax deal - not quite the perfect storm for Singapore just yet
summary: Singapore's tax sovereignty is being constrained by the G-7's proposed global minimum tax rate of at least 15%. The deal commits "market countries" to awarding taxing rights on at least 20% of profit exceeding a 10% margin for multinational enterprises, potentially affecting Singapore's corporate income tax revenues. However, Singapore can still maintain its reputation as a trusted investment hub by emphasizing simplicity and certainty in its tax response measures, and exploring opportunities to broaden its tax base, such as introducing a capital gains tax.

site_title: US trade deficit narrows in April as imports fall
summary: The US trade deficit narrowed in April to $68.9 billion, a 8.2% decrease from the previous month, as imports fell 1.4% to $273.9 billion. The decline was led by a drop in consumer goods imports, while exports rose 1.1% to a record $205.0 billion. The services surplus was the smallest since August 2012, but economists expect exports to continue rising as global economic growth gains momentum.

site_title: No bigger short-term challenge than Covid to keep G-7 focused and united
summary: The G-7 summit, set to take place in Cornwall, is a timely response to the ongoing international crisis from the Covid-19 pandemic and its aftermath. The group, founded in 1975, has a proven record of delivering when needed, as seen in its role in coordinating Western strategy towards the Soviet Union in the 1970s and 1980s. Despite recent divisions under former US President Trump, the G-7 is expected to put aside personal animosity and come together to address the pandemic's challenges. This unity is crucial for the group to remain relevant and engage on international issues, countering the argument that it lacks legitimacy compared to the UN or G-20.

site_title: Add 'climate hazards' to your homebuyer's checklist
summary: Homebuyers are increasingly considering climate hazards when purchasing properties, alongside traditional factors like location and price. As global temperatures rise and sea levels increase, home shoppers are looking at the long-term impact of natural disasters on a property's value. Commercial real-estate investors are also using climate analytics to inform their investment decisions, with companies like Four Twenty Seven and Jupiter Intelligence providing projections on weather-related hazards. This trend is expected to continue, with homebuyers prioritizing resilience and adaptability in the face of climate-related risks.

images.alt_text: Maps and other data are now available to help buyers analyse the risks of fires, floods and other disasters when searching for a new house.

site_title: Can unconstrained bond funds help investors mitigate interest rate risk?
summary: Investors may benefit from unconstrained bond funds in the current interest rate environment, which exposes traditional fixed-income portfolios to interest rate risk. These funds offer flexible duration profiles, allowing managers to adjust their strategies based on market conditions. They can invest across various fixed-income assets, including Treasuries and high-yields, and are not limited by geography. Unconstrained bond funds have generally performed well amid inflation and tapering scares, but investors must consider managerial risk and expense ratios when selecting a fund. Two options to consider are the Allianz Global Opportunistic Bond Fund and the BlackRock Fixed Income Global Opportunities Fund.

site_title: TPG-backed PropertyGuru eyes US$2b Thiel SPAC deal
summary: Bridgetown 2 Holdings, a blank-cheque company backed by Richard Li and Peter Thiel, is in advanced talks to merge with Singapore's online real estate firm PropertyGuru, valued at up to US$2 billion. The deal could be announced as soon as next month, pending discussions and potential delays. PropertyGuru, backed by KKR & Co and TPG Capital, has held preliminary talks about a US listing through a merger with a SPAC. The combined firm would be a major player in the Southeast Asian real estate market, with operations in countries including Vietnam, Indonesia, and Malaysia.

site_title: US: Stocks mixed as trade deficit ebbs
summary: US stocks were mixed on Tuesday as a lower-than-expected trade deficit in April helped stabilize markets ahead of a key inflation report. The trade deficit dropped to $68.9 billion, with exports rising and imports falling. The Dow Jones fell 0.2%, while the S&P 500 remained flat, while the Nasdaq Composite Index gained 0.5%. Investors are watching consumer price data later in the week, which could impact inflation worries and the reopening economy.

site_title: New Silkroutes receives US$10.7m letter of demand
summary: New Silkroutes Group has received a US$10.7 million letter of demand from Iolani Shipping, allegedly for a lease-financing arrangement. The company is reviewing the letter with its legal advisors and is currently under regulatory scrutiny, following recent queries from the Singapore Exchange. Shares of New Silkroutes closed 10.19% lower on the day.

site_title: 86-year-old woman linked to TTSH cluster dies of Covid-19 complications at KTPH
summary: An 86-year-old Singaporean woman, a contact of a patient at a large coronavirus cluster at Tan Tock Seng Hospital, died of Covid-19 complications at Khoo Teck Puat Hospital. She had not been vaccinated and had underlying health conditions. The Ministry of Health reported three new community cases, including one linked and two unlinked, bringing Singapore's total cases to 62,219. This marks the lowest daily number of Covid-19 cases in Singapore since March 17.

site_title: Singapore sequencing reveals Delta variant crowds out others
summary: Singapore's Covid-19 sequencing data reveals the Delta variant as the country's major local strain, accounting for 428 of 449 cases as of May 31. The variant is more transmissible, with concerns it may extend the pandemic globally. Singapore's aggressive response to the variant includes limiting gatherings and extending quarantines, but the country still faces challenges in eradicating the recent outbreak.

site_title: UN says 100,000 flee fighting in Myanmar border state
summary: The United Nations reports that an estimated 100,000 people in Myanmar's Kayah state have fled due to fighting between the military and ethnic minority militias. The UN urges all parties to protect civilians and civilian infrastructure. The fighting, which includes "indiscriminate attacks by security forces," has led to a significant displacement of people, with many seeking safety across international borders. The military's plan for restoring democracy has been met with skepticism, and Asean foreign ministers expressed disappointment at the junta's slow progress in implementing a five-point plan.

site_title: Japan to keep fiscal target deadline, reassess later this year
summary: Japan's government will maintain its goal of achieving a primary balance surplus by fiscal year 2025, but will reassess the timeframe later this year due to the economic damage caused by the Covid-19 pandemic. The government's draft fiscal blueprint, set to be submitted on June 18, aims to bring the primary balance into a surplus by 2025 while lowering the country's debt-to-GDP ratio. However, some ruling party lawmakers want to drop the timeframe for a second year, citing the ongoing pandemic's impact on the economy.

site_title: More than 30,000 people with history of severe allergies to get invite to register for Covid-19 jab
summary: Singapore's Health Minister Ong Ye Kung announced that over 30,000 people with severe allergy histories will be invited to register for the Covid-19 vaccine, lifting restrictions that previously barred them. This comes as 75% of seniors and 90% of graduating student cohorts have already signed up for or received the vaccine. The country has seen a recent surge in Covid-19 cases, prompting the government to emphasize the importance of vaccination and unity during challenging times.

site_title: EHT unit surrenders Queen Mary floating hotel property to California city
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT) has surrendered the Queen Mary floating hotel property to the City of Long Beach, California, as part of its Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings. EHT filed a motion to reject lease and operational agreements for the property, which is currently closed, citing a lack of viable prospects for selling the interest and substantial cure costs. The property's expenses include $45,000 monthly rent, $300,000 monthly caretaker costs, and $1.3 million insurance premium. The hearing on the motion is scheduled for July 7.

site_title: Social media, news websites hit by major internet outage
summary: A widespread internet outage affected major websites, including social media platforms Reddit, Amazon, CNN, and news outlets The New York Times and Al Jazeera, on Tuesday. The outage, linked to US-based cloud company Fastly Inc., caused issues for citizens booking Covid-19 vaccinations and reporting test results. Fastly attributed the issue to "degraded performance" and applied a fix, with most services returning within a few minutes to an hour. The company denied any malicious cyber attack, and affected customers may receive refunds or credits.

site_title: Latest innovation strategy: venture building
summary: Established firms are adopting a new innovation strategy called venture building, where they create a separate venture from scratch to target untapped opportunity spaces outside of their existing business. This approach has shown promising results, with companies outperforming those that didn't diversify by 54% in shareholder returns. Corporate venture building offers a way for companies to circumvent "innovation theatre" and avoid complex integration issues, allowing for faster returns on investment and more radical growth. To succeed, companies need to define their strategy, create a safe and open environment for experimentation, and prioritize customer validation.

site_title: STI dips 0.27% with Asian markets mixed on pandemic concerns and US weak trading
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.27% to 3,167.14 points on Tuesday, as Asian markets experienced a mixed trading session. Investors were caught between pandemic concerns and US equity strength. Japan's Nikkei 225 Index and Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index declined, while South Korea's Kospi Index dropped 0.54%. However, Australia's S&P/ASX 200 Index rose 0.15% and Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite climbed 0.60%.

site_title: SATS unit enters deal to buy majority of Thai food company for S$21m
summary: SATS (Thailand) Co, an indirect subsidiary of in-flight caterer SATS, has entered an agreement to buy 85% of Thailand-listed Bangkok Ranch's food-manufacturing facility owner, Food City, for S$21 million. The facility, set up in 2016, will focus on producing 90,000 ready-to-eat meals per day. This acquisition will increase SATS' interests in meal-production facilities in 10 markets, and is not expected to impact earnings per share for the financial year ending March 2022.

site_title: Lawsuit against two Clearbridge units dismissed over jurisdiction issue
summary: A lawsuit filed by Tirta Medika Nusantara (TMN) against Clearbridge Medical Asia and its indirect subsidiary Tirta Medika Jaya (TMJ) has been dismissed by an Indonesian court due to jurisdiction issues. TMN sought damages of 1.06 trillion rupiah (S$102 million) related to a notarial deed. The North Jakarta District Court ruled in favor of Clearbridge, stating it lacked jurisdiction to hear the suit. TMN is directed to pay court administrative fees and may submit an appeal within 14 days.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai

site_title: QAF to pay out 2 S-cent special dividend with sale of Australian pork business
summary: BREAD specialist QAF is set to reward shareholders with a special dividend of two Singapore cents per share after completing the sale of its Australian pork business, estimated to fetch A$148.1 million. The sale of Rivalea Holdings and Oxdale Dairy Enterprise to Industry Park, part of Brazilian giant JBS, will result in estimated proceeds of S$151.8 million. The company proposes to set aside S$11.5 million for the special dividend, with the sale expected to allow QAF to focus on its core bakery and distribution segments.

site_title: Europe: Stocks steady at open, awaiting key events
summary: European stock markets remained steady at the open on Tuesday, awaiting key events including US inflation data and the European Central Bank meeting. The FTSE 100 index rose 0.1%, while the DAX 30 and CAC 40 indices remained unchanged. Investors are concerned about the impact of strong inflation on interest rates and economic recovery.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's G-7 tax deal may not impact the city-state's business environment, with Lawrence Wong stating the new rules won't weaken investment incentives. Phoon Huat is set to hit $100 million in revenue this year, while condo resale volumes fell 11.4% in May. OTS Holdings priced its IPO shares at $0.23 each, and Singapore-based suppliers may lose $146.6 billion in annual revenue if they fail to cut emissions. Bukit Sembawang Estates may offer Reit-like dividends, and Innopac signed an MOU to acquire a cable manufacturer. Keppel will recognize an impairment of $318 million in H1 due to KrisEnergy exposure.

site_title: New dinosaur species discovered in Australia, one of world's biggest
summary: Scientists have confirmed the discovery of a new dinosaur species in Australia, named "Australotitan cooperensis", a plant-eating sauropod that lived between 92-96 million years ago. Measuring 25-30 meters in length and 5-6.5 meters in height, it is one of the largest dinosaurs found in Australia and the fifth-largest in the world. The discovery was made after a 17-year journey to analyze the bones of the animal, using new digital technology for 3D scanning.

site_title: World Bank sees strongest rebound in 80 years despite divergence
summary: The World Bank predicts the strongest post-recession global growth in 80 years, with global GDP expanding 5.6% this year, driven by a 6.8% expansion in the US and 8.5% in China. However, emerging and developing nations will struggle with the pandemic's aftermath, with 2/3 projected to remain below pre-pandemic per-capita income levels. The recovery is uncertain, with potential risks including policy support withdrawal, pent-up demand, and inflation pressures, which could slow global growth to 2.7% in 2022 and 2.1% in 2023.

site_title: Biden administration sets up 'strike force' to go after China on trade
summary: The US has established a "strike force" to combat unfair trade practices with China, targeting specific violations that contribute to the "hollowing out" of supply chains. The strike force, led by the US trade representative, will focus on addressing issues with critical products such as semiconductors and electric-vehicle batteries. The Biden administration also considers initiating a Section 232 investigation into neodymium magnet imports used in motors and other industrial applications. The goal is to increase domestic manufacturing capabilities and address supply chain vulnerabilities, with a focus on more diverse suppliers from like-minded allies and partners.

images.alt_text: The United States will target China with a new "strike force" to combat unfair trade practices, the Biden administration said on Tuesday, as it rolled out findings of a review of US access to critical products, from semiconductors to electric-vehicle batteries.

site_title: Singapore's ING Labs spin-out Stemly raises US$2.5m in seed funding
summary: Singapore-based startup Stemly, a platform for supply chain and finance optimization, has raised US$2.5 million in seed funding. The funding round includes ING Ventures, Elev8, and EDB New Ventures. Stemly aims to automate forecasting and optimization of supply chains and finance processes, helping companies respond to market changes faster and reduce costs. With the investment, Stemly plans to grow and expand its client base, including leading multinational corporations, and help businesses save 10-40% of their inventory and working capital costs.

site_title: OTS, company behind Golden Bridge luncheon meat, prices IPO shares at S$0.23 each
summary: OTS Holdings, the manufacturer of Golden Bridge luncheon meat, launched its initial public offering (IPO) on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) at S$0.23 per share, offering around 41 million shares. The IPO aims to raise S$7.9 million, with funds allocated to expanding the group's regional footprint, investing in manufacturing capabilities, and research and development. The company, founded by Ong Tuan Seng in 1993, has a portfolio of brands including Golden Bridge, Kelly's, and Orchid, and has targeted the growing halal food market.

site_title: Foxconn subsidiary hit as Taiwan virus cluster grows
summary: A Foxconn subsidiary, Foxsemicon Integrated Technology, has temporarily suspended operations after six foreign workers tested positive for Covid-19 in a growing cluster within Taiwan's tech industry. The company's operations in northern Miaoli county will be suspended until Wednesday for nearly 430 workers. The outbreak is the fourth tech company in Miaoli to report infections among employees, and it comes as Taiwan battles a surge in virus cases. The suspension is expected to impact Foxsemicon's output and revenue, and raises concerns about the global chip shortage.

site_title: Nine new Covid-19 cases, including three in the community
summary: Nine new COVID-19 cases were reported in Singapore, including three in the community, bringing the total tally to 62,219. The community cases include two unlinked and one linked to previous cases. Five imported cases were also reported, with two being Singaporeans or permanent residents. The cases are under quarantine or stay-home notice.

site_title: Innopac signs MOU to acquire cable manufacturer in struggle for survival
summary: Innopac Holdings, a struggling company, has signed a non-binding MOU to acquire FEC Power, a cable manufacturer, in an effort to ensure its viability and ability to operate as a going-concern. The proposed acquisition, valued at RM20 million per annum, is contingent on Innopac's continued operations as a going-concern status. Innopac has been operating without funds and staff since August 2019, and its shares were suspended from trading in June 2019 due to financial watch-list criteria issues. The acquisition is seen as a last-ditch attempt to stabilize the company.

site_title: Singtel's HungryGoWhere takes its last meal
summary: Singtel's HungryGoWhere, a food and restaurant reviews portal, will shut down on July 11 after 15 years. The decision comes as Singtel undergoes a strategic review of its digital units and announces a strategic reset. HungryGoWhere was acquired by Singtel in 2012 for S$12 million, but the company's co-founder notes that the market has become more crowded and decentralized, with people consuming digital content in different ways. Users can still make or edit reservations until July 11, and HungryRewards will be discontinued on June 30.

site_title: Yinson, SMRT Ventures co-invest in autonomous vehicle tech startup MooVita
summary: Yinson Holdings and SMRT Ventures co-invest a multi-million dollar amount in MooVita, an autonomous vehicle tech startup, as part of its Series A funding. The co-investment marks Yinson's first foray into mobility. MooVita aims to advance its driverless technologies and deploy driverless public transport solutions starting from Singapore and Malaysia. The company's software solution transforms various vehicle types into autonomous vehicles for various driving conditions and applications, addressing issues like road accidents, carbon emissions, and traffic congestion.

site_title: Foodtech startup Float Foods raises S$2.2m in seed funding
summary: Float Foods, a Singapore-based plant-based food startup, has raised US$2.2 million in seed funding to boost research and development and accelerate commercialization of its flagship product OnlyEg, a plant-based whole egg substitute. The funding, led by Insignia Ventures Partners and DSG Consumer Partners, brings the startup's post-money valuation to S$7.5 million. With the new capital, Float Foods aims to optimize OnlyEg with nutritional enhancements and commercialize it in Singapore by 2022, aligning with Singapore's 30 x 30 goals.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close with losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed marginally lower on Tuesday, with the Hang Seng Index falling 5.90 points to 28,781.38. Investors await US inflation data later in the week. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.54% and the Shenzhen Composite Index slipped 0.86%.

site_title: Heavy sleepers: elephants on epic trek take nap
summary: A herd of 15 wild elephants in southwestern China has taken a 500-kilometer trek, causing over $1 million in damage, before resting in a forest near the provincial capital Kunming. The elephants, closely monitored by authorities, have been followed by drones and convoys of trucks to keep them away from densely populated areas. Experts are unsure why the group migrated away from their original habitat. The Chinese government has distributed feed and evacuated residents in the elephants' path, and a 24-hour live feed of the herd has been launched on state television.

site_title: Thousands of UK police poised for G-7 protests
summary: Thousands of UK police are deployed in southwestern England to secure the G-7 summit in Carbis Bay, with 5,000 extra officers added to the existing 6,500. The event, focusing on the Covid-19 pandemic and climate change, is expected to be disrupted by protests, with some groups planning to cause major disruption. Police have allocated four protest sites, but groups such as Extinction Rebellion and the Kill The Bill group have vowed to boycott these. Police have indicated they will take a tough line on sustained disruption.

site_title: Singapore-based suppliers that fail to cut emissions may lose US$146.6b in annual revenue: survey
summary: A Standard Chartered survey found that 91% of multinational corporations (MNCs) in Singapore have set emission reduction targets for their suppliers, aiming for a 30% reduction by 2025. MNCs expect to exclude 35% of suppliers due to carbon concerns, and 67% consider tackling supply chain emissions as the first step in their net-zero transition. Suppliers that fail to cut emissions may lose $146.6 billion in annual revenue.

site_title: Renault-Nissan's India unit wants state govt to set social distancing rules
summary: Renault-Nissan India, the local unit of the automaker, is seeking the Tamil Nadu state government to set social distancing rules to ensure worker safety amid a dispute with its workers union. The union claims hundreds of workers have fallen ill with Covid-19 and dozens have died, leading to a strike. The company cites the practices of other automakers such as Maruti, Hyundai, Kia, Ford, and BMW, stating it's impossible to increase distances to over two to three feet at some workstations. The union plans to file a counter petition.

site_title: Bank Syariah Indonesia aims to double assets by targeting religious millennials
summary: Bank Syariah Indonesia, Indonesia's largest Islamic lender, aims to double its assets to $22.3 billion within three to four years by targeting religious millennials with a better online banking experience and Islamic features. The bank plans to become the No. 5 lender in Indonesia and achieve the highest return on equity among local banks by 2025. BSI aims to strengthen its wholesale banking and consider opening a branch in Dubai to serve Indonesian companies.

site_title: Apple in talks with CATL, BYD over battery supplies for its electric car: sources
summary: Apple is in early-stage talks with China's CATL and BYD about battery supplies for its planned electric vehicle, according to four people with knowledge of the matter. Discussions are subject to change and it's unclear if agreements will be reached. Apple has made US manufacturing a condition for potential suppliers, while CATL is reluctant due to political tensions and cost concerns. The US firm is reportedly in favor of using lithium iron phosphate batteries.

site_title: China's Guangdong steps up Covid-19 testing as infections mount
summary: China's Guangdong province, a manufacturing hub, has stepped up Covid-19 testing after a rise in novel coronavirus infections since May. Over 110 confirmed cases have been reported, with nearly 28 million nucleic acid samples taken in Guangzhou. Mass testing has been launched in multiple cities, including those without reported cases, as a precautionary measure. China reported 33 new cases on June 7, with 19 local transmissions from Guangdong, and 16 new asymptomatic infections. The country's death toll remains unchanged at 4,636.

site_title: Bukit Sembawang may offer Reit-like dividends as 'land bank king'
summary: DBS Research predicts Bukit Sembawang Estates can maintain dividends in the range of 18-33 cents per share, offering "Reit-like" yields of 4-7%. The developer has a land bank valued at "extremely low" historical cost, allowing for potential long-term investors to receive 70% of their capital from holding on to the company for the next decade. The brokerage maintains a "buy" call with a target price of S$5.92, citing the company's strong earnings growth and potential for recurring income.
