site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei closes lower
summary: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei index closed lower on Tuesday, falling 0.19% to 28,963.56, weighed by uncertainties from Japan's domestic Covid-19 situation and the Tokyo Olympics. Investors are concerned about a potential rebound in cases if emergency restrictions are lifted on June 20. The broader Topix index edged up 0.09%. The Nikkei's decline was attributed to uncertain factors, including the Olympics and the country's economy, which contracted 1.0% during the three months to March.

site_title: Fashion retailer About You, shareholders seek US$1.46b in IPO
summary: About You AG, a German e-commerce fashion retailer, is seeking up to €941 million (approximately $1.46 billion) in its Frankfurt initial public offering (IPO). The company plans to sell 28.6 million shares, with shares being marketed at €21-€26 apiece, starting June 16. About You aims to capitalize on the growing demand for party outfits as night life resumes in Europe, following a decline in sales during the pandemic. The IPO comes after a similar model was seen in THG Plc's London listing, and is backed by Otto Group and Michael Otto's e-commerce behemoth.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end lower, investors look to US inflation data
summary: South Korean stocks closed 0.13% lower at 3,247.83, driven by technology stocks and anticipation of US inflation data due this week. Foreign investors sold $185.24 million worth of shares, with Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix experiencing losses. Analysts remain cautious ahead of the US Federal Reserve policy meeting, citing investor uncertainty.

site_title: Australia: Shares end the day higher
summary: Australian shares rose 0.5% on Tuesday, driven by gains in technology and healthcare stocks, despite a retreat from a record peak. The S&P/ASX 200 closed at 7,292.6, influenced by overnight US market movements. Investors are awaiting US economic data this week, which may gauge inflationary pressure. Healthcare sector heavyweight CSL added 0.9%, while technology stocks, including Afterpay and EML Payments, rose 1.5%.

site_title: BT Explains: Why office landlords aren't fretting over banks cutting space
summary: Singapore's banking sector is expected to cut office space by 30% over the next few years, but landlords are unfazed as tech and corporate tenants are quickly filling the vacated spaces. Large corporates are leveraging the pullback in rents to move to higher-quality offices, fuelling a recovery in the Grade A market. Investors, developers, and Reits are optimistic about the new mix of tenants, with demand driven by an influx of global tech companies setting up regional headquarters in the city-state.

images.alt_text: Large corporates will probably leverage the pullback in rents to move to higher-quality and better-located offices, fuelling a recovery in the Grade A market, CBRE said.

site_title: Phoon Huat to open more stores this year; on the lookout for deals
summary: Phoon Huat, a Singapore-based baking supplies retailer, is set to open three new stores this year, taking its total to 22, as it crosses the US$100 million revenue milestone. The company, which acquired a majority stake in French goods retailer Le Petit Depot, plans to expand overseas, including talks with potential partners about entering South-east Asian countries. Phoon Huat remains committed to being a speciality retailer, focusing on baking products.

site_title: Renewable energy boom unleashes a war over talent for green jobs
summary: Renewable energy companies are facing a global talent shortage, with skilled workers in demand for roles such as energy assessment, project management, and clean energy technologies. Companies like EDP Renovaveis SA and green supermajors are struggling to find qualified candidates, leading to a "war over talent" globally. The sector is expected to grow rapidly, with solar and wind generation capacities tripling and doubling by the end of the decade, respectively. Policymakers are banking on the sector to create new jobs for post-pandemic economic recovery, but the shortage of skilled workers could become a bottleneck in the industry.

site_title: Free vaccines, food to cost India an additional S$14b
summary: India will spend an additional 800 billion rupees (S$14.5 billion) to provide free vaccines and food to millions of people devastated by the coronavirus wave. The government will allocate 700 billion rupees for food until November and 100 billion rupees for free vaccinations. Prime Minister Narendra Modi has agreed to provide free inoculations for all Indians above 18, reversing a previous policy that led to severe shortages. The government may not need to tap the bond market for funds, citing a recent dividend and expected asset sales.

site_title: UK hospitality industry warns 500,000 jobs are at risk
summary: The UK hospitality industry is warning that 500,000 jobs may be at risk if the government fails to drop all lockdown rules as planned on June 21, due to unsustainable back taxes and labor shortages. Industry leaders cite a shortage of migrant workers, including those from the EU, and concerns over post-Brexit visa rules. An emergency coronavirus recovery visa has been suggested to attract workers back to Britain, while commercial landlords remain wary of renting to hospitality firms due to the risk of lockdown rules tightening.

site_title: Top Japanese virologist warns of risks of Tokyo Games during pandemic
summary: A top Japanese virologist, Hiroshi Oshitani, has warned that the Tokyo Olympics pose a risk of spreading Covid-19 infections, despite the event being held with a scaled-down format and no foreign spectators. Japan has not suffered a large outbreak but has recorded nearly 760,000 cases and over 13,500 deaths. A former Olympian and public health expert, Tara Kirk Sell, believes the Games can be held with an acceptable level of risk, citing testing regimes and movement restrictions. The government's top medical adviser has planned a statement on the Games by June 20.

site_title: Hot Stock: Enviro-Hub gains 26.7% after associate gets nod to market medical-grade gloves in US
summary: Enviro-Hub Holdings shares surged 26.7% after its associate company Pastel Gloves received 510(k) regulatory clearance from the US FDA to market nitrile medical-grade examination gloves. The clearance enables Pastel Gloves to export the gloves in the US, where they typically command a higher price due to limited supply. Enviro-Hub had previously announced a proposed acquisition of Pastel Gloves, which will become its wholly-owned subsidiary. The company estimates high demand for the gloves, with only 20% of the market holding FDA certification.

site_title: Nvidia asks Chinese regulators to approve US$40b Arm deal: FT
summary: Nvidia has submitted an application to Chinese regulators to review its $40 billion takeover of UK chip designer Arm, amid a period of scrutiny that could take up to 18 months. The move follows a US Federal Trade Commission probe into Nvidia's agreement to buy Arm, announced in February. Nvidia expects to close the acquisition by March 2022, having struck a deal with SoftBank Group in September 2020.

site_title: Biogen's Japanese partner has a second Alzheimer's drug coming
summary: Biogen's Japanese partner, Eisai, is developing a second Alzheimer's drug, BAN2401, following the FDA's approval of Biogen's Aduhelm, the first drug to slow Alzheimer's progression. The two drugs target beta amyloid protein, a hallmark of the disease. Eisai's shares are unaffected due to a trading imbalance, while Biogen's stock rose 38.3%. The FDA's approval may boost BAN2401's chances, and regulatory approvals are expected in Europe and Japan later this year. Eisai and Biogen will split profits 50-50, with Biogen taking a greater share in the US and Europe.

site_title: Cathay Pacific given extension to draw down HK$7.8b government loan
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways has received a one-year extension to draw down a HK$7.8 billion (S$1.34 billion) government loan facility, set to expire in June 2021, to June 2022. The airline has not yet drawn down on the loan, instead adopting cost-saving measures. The extension gives Cathay more flexibility to manage its liquidity position amid a significant decline in passenger numbers. Cathay has also raised additional funds through convertible bond issues and a recent bond sale.

site_title: China's Wuxi exchange plans to launch lithium contract as soon as July: sources
summary: China's Wuxi Stainless Steel Exchange plans to launch a lithium contract as soon as July, according to sources and a draft document. The yuan-denominated contract will trade battery-grade lithium carbonate, targeting strong market demand for electric vehicle batteries. This move would make Wuxi the first exchange-traded lithium contract in China, allowing lithium producers and consumers to manage price exposure. The launch follows requests from numerous traders and takes into account production and trading needs of relevant enterprises.

site_title: Tesla veteran and trucking chief leaves company
summary: Jerome Guillen, a long-time Tesla executive, has left the company after being president of the Tesla Heavy Trucking unit for three months. Guillen, who joined Tesla in 2010, oversaw the company's entire vehicles business before his departure. His exit is seen as negative, as he was crucial in stabilizing the auto business after the Model 3 launch in 2017. Tesla's battery-powered Semi electric commercial truck, which was expected to launch this year, may now be delayed to 2022 due to battery cell supply constraints.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Tuesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Tuesday, with the Nikkei 225 index down 0.15% and the Topix index down 0.17%. This follows recent Wall Street losses after recent rallies.

site_title: Gold prices dip on strong dollar ahead of US inflation data
summary: Gold prices dropped 0.2% to $1,895.59 per ounce due to a stronger US dollar, which made gold more expensive for other currency holders. Investors await US inflation data later this week to gauge inflationary pressure and the Federal Reserve's monetary policy. The dollar index rose 0.1% against its rivals, contributing to the decline in gold prices.

site_title: Canada prepares to ease quarantine rules for vaccinated travellers
summary: Canada is set to ease quarantine rules for fully vaccinated travellers, with plans to shorten the 14-day isolation period to a shorter quarantine period after testing, according to reports. The announcement is expected within days, with vaccinated travellers still required to undergo testing and possibly shorter quarantine. The move aims to facilitate travel while maintaining public health measures.

site_title: China markets sold mink, civets, stoking natural origins theory
summary: China's Huanan seafood and fresh produce market, linked to early Covid-19 cases, sold various wildlife, including mink, civets, and raccoon dogs, from 2017 to 2019. This supports the World Health Organization's conclusion that SARS-CoV-2 likely originated from animals, possibly a bat or another mammal sold at the market. The findings contradict some theories suggesting a lab origin. Researchers found 38 animal species sold live at the market during the study period, fueling the debate over the pandemic's natural origins.

site_title: EU chief defends China deal ahead of US summit
summary: European Union President Charles Michel has defended the EU's efforts to reach an investment agreement with China ahead of US President Joe Biden's summit meetings. Michel stressed that the EU will not compromise on its fundamental values and human rights in dealings with China, despite criticism from the US. The EU is seeking to rebalance its economic relationship with China and has been working on a "Comprehensive Agreement on Investment" (CAI) with Beijing. However, the agreement has been delayed due to rows over human rights sanctions.

site_title: Japan service sector sentiment dips in May
summary: Japan's service sector sentiment index fell to 38.1 in May, down for a second consecutive month, due to pandemic-related curbs on restaurants and retailers. The index, based on a survey of workers in the economy, decreased from 39.1 in April. This decline is attributed to the ongoing pandemic restrictions, which have impacted consumer and retail trends. The result is the second consecutive drop in sentiment.

site_title: Man suspected of killing a Canadian Muslim family by truck was motivated by hate: police
summary: A 20-year-old man, Nathaniel Veltman, has been charged with four counts of first-degree murder and one count of attempted murder for killing four members of a Canadian Muslim family in a targeted attack motivated by hate. The victims, including a father, mother, and two children, were struck by Veltman's truck in London, Ontario, and were all Muslim. Veltman, who has no prior record, was arrested after a high-speed chase and is due back in court on Thursday. Police believe the attack was premeditated and motivated by hate, and may file terrorism charges.

site_title: European companies plan to invest more in China after pandemic
summary: European companies plan to increase investment in China, with nearly 60% of respondents expanding operations in 2021, up from 51% last year. The quick recovery from the pandemic made China a key growth driver, with 73% of respondents reporting a profit last year and 68% optimistic about the business outlook over the next two years. Companies are also onshoring supply chains to avoid disruptions due to geopolitical tensions, with a quarter moving production lines into China or switching to local suppliers.

site_title: Asia: Markets struggle ahead of US inflation report
summary: Asian markets struggled on Tuesday ahead of the US inflation report, which is expected to show a 4.7% increase in consumer prices, the highest since 2008. Investors are concerned that a strong reading will lead the Federal Reserve to reconsider its ultra-loose monetary policy, potentially leading to higher interest rates. Despite record highs, global tax and inflation concerns are intensifying, with investors seeking safe-havens like gold. The G-7 finance ministers have endorsed a global minimum corporate tax rate of at least 15%, but a deal at the G-20 or OECD levels remains uncertain.

site_title: Too early to tell what G-7's historic tax deal would mean for Singapore: Lawrence Wong
summary: Singapore Finance Minister Lawrence Wong says it's too early to determine the impact of the G-7's historic tax deal on the country, as jurisdictions need to adjust their tax systems. The deal aims to reduce incentives for multinational companies to shift to low-tax havens by imposing a 15% minimum corporate tax rate. Wong warned that weak tax systems could lead to a "shrinking revenue pie" for countries, affecting businesses' incentives to invest and innovate.

site_title: Philippines approves Sinopharm vaccine as it ramps up Covid jabs
summary: The Philippines has approved Sinopharm's coronavirus vaccine for emergency use, allowing the government to receive donated doses. The country has already vaccinated about 6 million people, with 1.5 million receiving their second dose. The nation expects 11 million doses to arrive this month, including 4.5 million from Sinovac, and plans to vaccinate 35 million workers. The economy, which contracted in 2020, is counting on vaccines to aid its rebound, with President Duterte urging Filipinos to take the second dose after data showed a low completion rate.

site_title: Faux-chicken maker Simulate is valued at more than US$250m
summary: Simulate, a plant-based food startup, raised $50 million in funding, valuing the company at over $250 million. The fresh capital will be used to accelerate product development, triple the employee base, and expand internationally, starting in Canada. Simulate, known for its faux-chicken nuggets, aims to simulate other animal products and develop a beef alternative. The company plans to capitalize on changing consumer habits and the growing faux-meat industry.

site_title: Russia weighs selling more diamond stocks to tap global demand
summary: Russia is considering selling more rough diamonds from its state stockpiles, known as Gokhran, to tap into the recovering global demand following the Covid-19-induced slump. The government plans to increase sales via public auctions, with Russia's largest diamond miner, Alrosa, likely to bid to replenish its inventories. The move aims to replenish depleted inventories, with Alrosa's diamond stocks at a record low of 10 million carats. This sale comes after top producers De Beers raised prices for some rough diamonds by about 10% in recent sales.

site_title: Pandemic pushes poor US students into working odd jobs
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has forced many poor US students, mostly Black and Hispanic, to take on odd jobs to support their families. Despite attending virtual school, students are often exhausted and struggle to balance work and education. Many students, including those from families with undocumented parents, are being pressured to work due to financial needs, with some working up to 35 hours a week. Educators warn that this could lead to a significant number of students dropping out of school, with some already having dropped out during the pandemic.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel, Sembcorp Marine, Enviro-Hub, Suntec Reit
summary: Keppel and Sembcorp Marine faced new developments. Keppel will recognize a loss of S$318 million due to its exposure to KrisEnergy's winding-up petition. Sembcorp Marine explored alternative sources of skilled labor due to labor shortages. Meanwhile, the Singapore Stock Exchange (STI) rallied 0.4% on Thursday, driven by positive investor sentiment despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Hong Kong's poor families doubled amid pandemic, protests
summary: Hong Kong's low-income households nearly doubled to 302,000, with 61% of economically active individuals in these households either unemployed or underemployed. The proportion of people in full-time employment fell compared to the previous year. This reflects the deterioration in Hong Kong's labor market during the pandemic and protests.

site_title: Australian police arrest over 200 after cracking underworld messaging app
summary: Australian police arrested over 200 individuals involved in organised crime after infiltrating the encrypted messaging app ANOM, which revealed "industrial scale" drug imports and murder plots. The joint operation with the US FBI began in 2018 and targeted criminals in Australia, Asia, South America, and the Middle East. Authorities seized 104 firearms, nearly A$45 million in cash, and laid 525 charges, with more expected in the coming weeks. The operation is considered a "watershed moment" in Australian law enforcement history, striking a heavy blow against organised crime globally.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 1.22 points to 1,579.67, a 0.08% gain. Trading volume was 455.41 million lots worth RM239.49 million. Gainers outpaced losers 282 to 166.

site_title: Airline chiefs urge end to UK-US travel restrictions
summary: Airline chiefs from the US and UK, including American Airlines, British Airways, Delta Air Lines, and JetBlue, are urging both countries to lift trans-Atlantic travel restrictions due to high vaccination rates. The restrictions, imposed in March 2020, have limited travel between the two countries for over a year. The CEOs stated that lifting restrictions is essential for trade, tourism, and business, with some airlines predicting they could add capacity within four weeks if restrictions are lifted. The push comes ahead of meetings between US President Joe Biden and British Prime Minister Boris Johnson at the G-7 meeting.

site_title: Japan upgrades Q1 GDP on smaller hit to domestic demand
summary: Japan's economy contracted at a slower-than-expected pace in the first quarter, with an annualized 3.9% decline, beating economists' forecasts of a 4.8% drop. The contraction was mainly due to smaller-than-expected cuts to public and capital spending, offsetting a slightly larger fall in private consumption. Despite this, real wages posted their largest monthly jump in over a decade, and bank lending growth slowed, with economists warning that Japan's recovery will lag major economies that have rolled out Covid-19 vaccines quicker.

site_title: Singapore IoT service provider opens Tokyo office
summary: Singapore-based IoT service provider UnaBiz has opened its Tokyo office to support its growing strategic alliance and explore new collaborations in Japan. Pascal Gerbert-Gaillard, a trade adviser to the French government and board member in the French Chamber of Commerce and Industry Japan, has been appointed managing director of UnaBiz Japan. The move aims to increase global competitiveness and accelerate the buildout of stronger IoT infrastructure.

site_title: Australia: Shares inch higher as gold stocks shine; New Zealand rises
summary: Australian shares rose 0.3% to 7,302.3, driven by gains in gold miners, including Newcrest Mining and Northern Star Resources. Gold prices hovered near $1,900 an ounce, boosted by a weaker dollar and bond yields. Meanwhile, tech stocks and individual stocks like Afterpay and Nearmap also saw gains. In contrast, miners fell up to 0.6% due to softer iron ore prices, and big miners Rio Tinto, BHP Group, and Fortescue Metals dropped more than 1%. New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.3%.

site_title: Top copper nation calls for debate on how to best tap the boom
summary: Chile's government is calling for a debate on how to tap the country's copper boom, rather than rushing to vote on a proposed new tax system. The proposed royalty bill, which would significantly increase company taxes, is being held up in the senate due to concerns over its constitutionality. Mining Minister Juan Carlos Jobet said the country should set goals for the sector, such as sustainability and community relations, before discussing tax levels. Jobet expressed confidence that a reasonable agreement will be reached, preventing the bill from being sent to the senate in its current form.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares rise at start
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.39% at the start of Tuesday, following a day of losses, as investors await US inflation data later in the week. The Hang Seng Index reached 28,900.52, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices remained flat. The rally comes as investors brush off new Trump threats to extend the stocks rally.

site_title: If Singapore insists on keeping dual-class share regime, let's have more stringent regulations
summary: Singapore's dual-class share (DCS) regime has failed to attract significant listings, with only one DCS listing, AMTD International, listed on the New York Stock Exchange since its introduction in 2018. Despite introducing safeguards, the structure remains a concern for corporate governance, as it conveys unequal economic rights and benefits. The Asian Corporate Governance Association (ACGA) and experts argue that Singapore lacks a comprehensive whistleblowing law and effective ex post mechanisms, which are crucial for protecting minority shareholders and investors. The government may consider revising its approach to DCS, focusing on strengthening regulatory frameworks and enforcement mechanisms.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise at Tuesday's open; STI edge up 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.1% at Tuesday's open, with the Straits Times Index (STI) gaining 2.87 points to 3,178.68. Gainers outnumbered losers 89 to 49, driven by gains from Enviro-Hub and Metal Component. Pastel Gloves received US FDA clearance for its medical gloves, while Keppel Corp announced a loss of S$318 million due to exposure to KrisEnergy. Local banks were mixed, with DBS down 0.3%, UOB up 0.2%, and OCBC gaining 0.3%.

site_title: Evergrande rises after developer announces HK$336m share buyback
summary: China Evergrande Group, the country's most indebted developer, rose 4.2% in Hong Kong trading after announcing a HK$336 million (S$57.3 million) share buyback. The company will pay HK$11.08 to HK$11.84 per share for the buyback, about 0.2% of its issued capital. The move comes as the property firm faces regulatory scrutiny and refinancing concerns due to its failure to meet stricter Chinese borrowing limits.

site_title: Enviro-Hub associate company Pastel Gloves cleared to market gloves in the US
summary: Enviro-Hub associate company Pastel Gloves has received 510(k) regulatory clearance from the US FDA for its nitrile medical-grade examination gloves. The certification allows Enviro-Hub to export the gloves for sale in the US, where they command a higher price due to limited supply. Only 20% of gloves in the market have obtained this certification, and demand is expected to remain high. This comes after Enviro-Hub obtained a manufacturing license from Malaysia's Ministry of International Trade and Industry. Enviro-Hub's shares rose 20.9% following the announcement.

site_title: Sembmarine seeking alternative labour sources; likely to incur extra costs
summary: SembCorp Marine, a marine and offshore engineering group, is exploring alternative labor sources due to a shortage caused by Phase 2 (Heightened Alert) restrictions. This move is expected to incur increased manpower costs. The company has revised delivery dates for two ultra-deepwater drill ships for Transocean Offshore Deepwater Holdings, rescheduling them to December 2021 and May 2022. This delay is expected to have an adverse impact on Sembmarine's cash flows, with a potential five to six-year time frame for payment, delaying a return to free cash flow-positive territory.

site_title: UOB starts consent solicitation exercise to facilitate transition to Sonia from Libor
summary: UOB has initiated a consent solicitation process to modify the terms and conditions of its £350 million floating rate covered bonds due 2023, aiming to transition from Sterling Libor to Sterling Overnight Index Average (Sonia). A videoconference meeting for eligible bondholders will be held on June 30 to seek approval via an extraordinary resolution. Credit Suisse Securities (Europe) and HSBC have been appointed as solicitation agents.

site_title: Keppel to recognise S$318m impairment in H1 due to KrisEnergy exposure
summary: Keppel Corporation will recognize a S$318 million loss in its H1 2021 financial results due to its exposure to KrisEnergy, which has submitted a winding-up petition. The loss is non-core and will be offset by S$597 million from the divestment of Keppel Bay Tower and S$309 million in divestment and restructuring gains. Keppel has implemented a recovery plan to preserve assets and maximize recoveries, with a comprehensive security package over KrisEnergy's assets. The group's shares closed 1.12% down on the news.

site_title: Metal Component to diversify into healthcare with proposed S$4.3m Gainhealth acquisition
summary: Metal Component Engg (MCE) has agreed to acquire about 85.1% of shares in loss-making healthcare firm Gainhealth Pte Ltd for S$4.3 million. The acquisition, which includes a cash payment of S$3.8 million and the issuance of up to 13 million new shares, represents a 44.8% discount to the volume-weighted average price of 6.7 cents per share. The deal aims to diversify MCE's business and find sustainable revenue streams, with the company citing the Covid-19 pandemic's adverse impact on its operations.

site_title: Flipkart in talks to raise US$3b from investors including GIC, SoftBank: sources
summary: Flipkart, the Indian e-commerce giant controlled by Walmart, is in talks to raise at least $3 billion from investors including SoftBank Group and sovereign wealth funds. The startup aims for a valuation of $40 billion and plans to use the funds for investments in its supply chain, technology, and possible acquisitions ahead of its planned initial public offering (IPO) in 2022. SoftBank could invest $300 million to $500 million through its Vision Fund II, while Flipkart's annual revenues reached $15 billion in 2020.

images.alt_text: Flipkart, the Indian e-commerce giant controlled by Walmart, is in talks to raise at least US$3 billion from investors including SoftBank Group and several sovereign wealth funds, according to people familiar with the matter.

site_title: Gangrene, hearing loss point to Delta variant being more severe
summary: The Delta coronavirus variant, linked to India's devastating epidemic, has been found to be more infectious and potentially more severe, with symptoms including hearing loss, gangrene, and stomach issues. Doctors in India and England are reporting higher hospitalization rates and unusual presentations, including blood clots and joint pain. The variant is 50% more contagious than the Alpha strain and may be evading vaccine-induced antibodies, prompting calls for new vaccines or updated shots. The UK government is reconsidering its plans to reopen later this month due to the surge in cases.

site_title: Biden agenda under threat - from within his party
summary: US President Joe Biden's ambitious agenda is under threat from within his own party, with Democratic Senator Joe Manchin's refusal to support the voting rights bill and his opposition to weakening or eliminating the filibuster. The 50-50 Senate and Vice President Kamala Harris's tie-breaking vote mean there's zero margin for defection, putting the trillion-dollar infrastructure improvement and other key bills at risk. Manchin's stance has earned criticism from some Democrats, who see the filibuster as an obstacle to enacting meaningful policy changes.

site_title: US recovers most of ransom paid to hackers by Colonial Pipeline: Justice Deparment
summary: The US Justice Department announced it recovered most of the $4.4 million paid by Colonial Pipeline to Russia-based ransomware extortionists Darkside, who forced a major US fuel network shutdown. Deputy Attorney General Lisa Monaco said the department targeted the entire ransomware ecosystem, including digital currency. This marks a significant victory in the fight against digital extortion attacks.

site_title: UK consumers splashed out the cash as lockdown rules eased
summary: UK consumers boosted sales by 10% in May compared to 2019, with clothing, beauty products, and food sales driving growth. The strong consumer confidence was fueled by vaccination programs and retailers' safety measures. However, international travel remains restricted, and plans to remove remaining COVID-19 restrictions are under threat due to the Indian variant. This marks the strongest growth during the pandemic and puts the economy on course for its fastest recovery in decades.

site_title: New York plans huge August concert to celebrate post-Covid 'rebirth'
summary: New York Mayor Bill de Blasio announced plans to host a major concert in Central Park in August to celebrate the city's "rebirth" after the Covid-19 pandemic. Veteran music producer Clive Davis will organize the event, which is expected to feature eight "iconic" stars, with many free tickets available. The concert will be the culmination of a "Homecoming Week" of events to celebrate New York's emergence from the pandemic, with vaccination efforts and lifted restrictions contributing to the city's recovery. An August 21 date is tentatively planned.

site_title: Australia's business activity climbs to fresh highs in May: survey
summary: Australia's business activity surged to fresh highs in May, according to a National Australia Bank survey, with sales, profits, and employment all increasing strongly. The index of business conditions rose 5 points to +37, while confidence eased 3 points to +20. Trading conditions, profitability, and employment all improved, with capacity utilisation remaining high at 85.1%. The survey suggests the economy is entering a period of growth after a rapid rebound, with forward indicators pointing to ongoing strength.

images.alt_text: A measure of Australian business conditions extended its blistering run to reach all-time highs in May with sales, profits and employment all up strongly, a sign the economy has the momentum to cope with a coronavirus lockdown in Victoria.

site_title: Amazon to be covered by global tax deal despite thin margins
summary: Global policy makers are crafting an international tax plan that will include Amazon, despite the company's thin profit margin of 7.1% this year. The plan aims to reallocate a portion of profits above a 10% margin to be taxed in other countries. Negotiators are working on a mechanism that could target Amazon's more-profitable cloud computing or advertising businesses, rather than the whole company. The deal, expected to be finalized by the end of the year, will also set a worldwide minimum corporate tax rate of at least 15%.

images.alt_text: Global policy makers are crafting their international tax plan to make sure Amazon.com Inc. is included, even though the US company's profit margin is below the 10 per cent proposed threshold that would give other countries rights to collect revenue.

site_title: Russell 2000 swells 84%, investors await update on AMC, GameStop
summary: The US Russell 2000 small-cap stock index has surged 84% over the past year, with its total market capitalization reaching US$3.5 trillion. This growth is attributed to the popularity of meme stocks and significant increases in the overall size of US-listed companies.

site_title: China could use digital yuan to promote capital convertibility
summary: China is considering using the digital yuan to test capital account convertibility between Shenzhen and Hong Kong through a "regulatory sandbox" program. According to a senior central bank official, the digital yuan can help accelerate the promotion of yuan internationalization, with risks controlled through smart contracts and real-time transaction data monitoring. The program, if implemented, would help deepen cooperation between the PBOC and Hong Kong Monetary Authority, and potentially expand the digital yuan's use in international finance.

site_title: SGeBiz offers free food procurement solution to 1,000 SMEs for 1 year
summary: Singapore E-Business (SGeBiz) is offering its free food procurement solution, EzyProcure, to 1,000 small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) for a year to support F&B businesses affected by Covid-19 measures. The solution automates ordering, invoice reconciliation, and payment processes, and can be linked to accounting systems for real-time inventory management. The move aims to help F&B operators and suppliers sustain their businesses amidst declining sales volumes.

site_title: Oil dips on profit-taking after logging two-year high on Opec+ curbs
summary: Oil prices dropped after reaching two-year highs on Monday, as Chinese data showed a year-low in crude oil imports in May, reducing demand optimism. Opec producers maintained supply curbs, causing analysts to cite "pressure" on the market. Prices retreated from session highs, with Phil Flynn citing the Chinese data as a factor in the decline. The retreat follows recent price gains driven by improved demand expectations and Opec's supply curbs.

site_title: North Korea's Kim meets senior officials to address economy: KCNA
summary: North Korea's leader Kim Jong Un convened a meeting of senior officials to address the country's struggling economy, which has been battered by international sanctions and strict border closures. The meeting aimed to improve the economy in the second half of the year and implement a plan to bring about "a tangible change" in stabilizing state economic work and people's living. The meeting is a precursor to a ruling party plenary meeting later in June, where Kim will seek a greater role in government to address the economic crisis.

site_title: When the power grid runs low, your EV's battery could help
summary: A trial launched in 2019 by Ovo Energy Ltd in the UK allows Nissan Leaf owners to charge their vehicles and supply electricity back to the grid, helping to balance peak power demand. The program, which began with 330 participants, has shown that EV batteries can be used to stabilize the grid and even generate revenue for owners. With 10% of total power use expected to come from cars by 2040, vehicle-to-grid technology could help meet peak power demand by the end of the decade.

site_title: US: Wall Street loses steam with S&P 500 short of record
summary: US stocks experienced a brief setback on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropping 0.4% to 34,630.24 and the S&P 500 falling short of its record high, losing 0.1% to 4,226.52. Despite this, the Nasdaq Composite Index rose 0.5% to 13,881.72. The tech-rich Nasdaq was boosted by the ongoing buying frenzy of "meme stocks" such as AMC Entertainment and GameStop, which rose 14.8% and 12.7%, respectively. Analysts attribute the market's cautious optimism to expectations of a strong economic recovery this year, despite inflation concerns.

site_title: G-7 group out to show its unity through crises
summary: The Group of Seven (G-7) leaders are meeting in Carbis Bay, England, to discuss major crises such as Covid-19, climate change, and the impact of Russia and China. US President Joe Biden aims to showcase Western unity and cooperation, while leaders also pledge to donate hundreds of millions of Covid-19 vaccines to poor countries and slow climate change. The summit also addresses the rise of China and Russia, with leaders seeking to ensure free trade and protect democratic institutions.

site_title: Local plant fertiliser brand flourishes amid pandemic
summary: Plantonic, a local plant fertiliser brand, has seen a nearly 12-fold increase in sales since the COVID-19 pandemic, growing from 400 bottles per month to 4,800. Founded in 2019, the all-natural, non-toxic fertiliser has become a global phenomenon, driven by the growing interest in home gardening. Despite not being trained in chemistry or science, founder Eric Tan's approach to creating the product, combining plant-based ingredients with medicinal benefits, has proven successful. Plantonic plans to expand its product range and regional presence, including Malaysia, Hong Kong, and the UK.

site_title: Investors call for ethical approach to facial recognition technology
summary: A group of 50 investors managing $4.5 trillion in assets has called on companies using facial recognition technology to do so ethically, citing concerns over privacy and potential human rights implications. The initiative, led by Candriam, will engage with 34 companies, including Amazon, Facebook, Alibaba, and Huawei, over a two-year period. The investors urge companies to assess and mitigate human rights risks related to their facial recognition products and services, amid concerns of inaccurate matching leading to unjust arrests and government surveillance.

images.alt_text: A group of 50 investors managing more than US$4.5 trillion in assets is calling on companies involved in the development and use of facial recognition technology, such as Amazon and Facebook, to do so in an ethical way.

site_title: Horror film Conjuring spooks its way to US box office lead
summary: Horror film "The Conjuring: The Devil Made Me Do It" topped the US box office with an estimated $24 million, beating "A Quiet Place: Part II" which took in $19.5 million. The film's success is seen as a positive sign for Warner Bros, as it is available on HBO Max at no extra cost. The film's director, Michael Chaves, is set to make the quickest film to cross the $100 million mark in North America since the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Carousell picks former Razer executive Edwin Chan as CFO
summary: Carousell, a Singapore-based classifieds startup, has appointed Edwin Chan, former Razer executive, as its new Chief Financial Officer (CFO). Chan will oversee the company's capital strategy, including fundraising and mergers and acquisitions, and will report to CEO Quek Siu Rui. Carousell is valued at US$874 million and is expected to pursue a listing or trade sale in the near to mid-term, with CEO Quek stating the company is "well-capitalised for the next couple of years".

site_title: One Championship cites IPO plans after Temasek-linked directors resign
summary: Singapore-based MMA promotion One Championship has announced plans for a public listing, following the resignation of two Temasek-linked directors from its board. The company's president, Teh Hua Fung, cited the need for a governance structure suitable for various jurisdictions, including the US. Despite a recent US$70 million fundraise, One Championship's revenue prospects and financial performance have raised concerns among investors, with some questioning the company's ability to generate sufficient revenue to justify a public listing.

site_title: Apple doubles down on privacy in new iPhone software
summary: Apple has announced plans to expand its focus on privacy in the new iPhone operating software, iOS 15, set to be released later this year. The update includes features such as overviews of app access to smartphone cameras and microphones, as well as data like location or contacts. The move comes as Apple faces challenges over its control of the App Store, with Epic Games accusing the company of having monopoly power and the European Union accusing it of unfairly squeezing out music streaming rivals. Apple's CEO Tim Cook said the company is committed to making its products more powerful and capable without compromising privacy.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times. US stocks opened lower following Trump's fresh tariff salvo on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potential H2 revenue below target and operating loss similar to H1. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC announced Tan Teck Long as its incoming CEO, replacing a DBS veteran. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and PBOC agreed to deepen green and transition finance cooperation.

site_title: New, more positive climate narrative
summary: A new climate narrative, focusing on a "win-win" story of economic growth and technological innovation, is gaining traction, making rapid progress towards a deep green transformation more feasible. This optimistic approach emphasizes the benefits of green technologies and policies, which are now being driven by technological advancements and policy incentives. The shift away from a somber narrative of costs and burdens could lead to widespread adoption of green technologies, with many countries committing to carbon-neutrality by mid-century. However, challenges remain, including compensating losers, addressing digital divides, and the need for long-term development finance.

site_title: Europe: Shares stay at record highs; commodity stocks fall
summary: European stocks hit record highs on Monday, with the European automobiles and parts index rising 0.9% to its highest since March 2015. The Stoxx 600 index added 0.2% as investors await a European Central Bank meeting later this week. Commodity stocks fell, with miners dropping 1.6% due to weaker-than-expected Chinese export data and oil and gas stocks declining 0.3% ahead of talks on a potential nuclear deal.

images.alt_text: European stocks hit record highs on Monday as another run of gains in automakers more than offset early declines in commodity-linked shares sparked by downbeat China export data.

site_title: HK buyers making steady investments in Singapore property
summary: Hong Kong investors have maintained steady interest in Singapore property, with a record 93 property investments in the 2019-2021 period. However, the number of transactions has held steady since the Covid-19 pandemic, with analysts attributing this to the government's cooling measures, such as the 20% additional buyer's stamp duty. Some analysts suggest that interest may be shifting towards the UK, particularly with the new British National Overseas system allowing Hong Kong residents to apply for British citizenship.

site_title: Surging inflation, economic rebound to test ECB's commitment to stimulus measures
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is set to meet on Thursday, with policymakers likely holding interest rates at historic lows and maintaining its massive bond-buying scheme. The ECB's 1.85 trillion euro pandemic emergency bond-purchasing programme will run until March 2022, as inflation surges to 2% in May, exceeding the ECB's target. ECB president Christine Lagarde will balance striking an upbeat tone on the eurozone's recovery while stressing the need for ongoing support.

site_title: Phoon Huat buys majority stake in French foods retailer
summary: Phoon Huat, a Singaporean baking supplies retailer, has acquired a majority stake in Le Petit Depot, a Singapore-based online retailer specializing in French food products. Phoon Huat now holds 91.5% interest, with the remaining shares held by Le Petit Depot's founders and a holding firm. The deal aims to leverage strengths, reduce supply chain costs, and double sales volumes in three years. Phoon Huat will retain Le Petit Depot's management and founders will remain "meaningful shareholders."

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Cromwell E-Reit acquired a Czech Republic logistics asset for $16.4 million. Hutchison Port Holdings Trust's CEO Lam Hing Man will step down on June 25 due to health reasons, replaced by Ivor Chow. Eagle Hospitality Trust sold four Chapter 11 properties for $117.2 million to repay debt. Sembcorp Marine revised delivery dates for two ultra-deepwater drillships due to Covid-19 disruptions, rescheduling them for December 2021 and May 2022.

site_title: UK house prices rise by most since 2014: Halifax
summary: UK house prices rose 9.5% in May, the largest annual increase since 2014, driven by a government tax break and surge in demand for spacious properties. The Halifax report also showed a 1.3% monthly increase and 10.2% annual rise in house prices, based on transactions in March. Economists had forecast a 1.2% monthly increase and 10% annual rise. The current strength in house prices suggests a long-lasting change in buyer preferences, with demand for larger properties warranting higher spending on housing.

site_title: China's cautious consumers offer clues for post-pandemic world
summary: China's cautious consumers are offering insights into the post-pandemic world, with 49% of respondents increasing savings in Q1, up from 46% in Q4 2019. Despite the economy reopening, consumers remain cautious, indicating pent-up demand may not be as strong as expected globally. The country's aggressive control over the virus allowed for 13.7% real household income growth in the first quarter.

site_title: Sri Trang Gloves sees chance to expand fast by investing in automation
summary: Sri Trang Gloves, a Thai company, plans to expand its capacity and increase productivity by 24% annually from 2017 to 2026. With a 44 billion baht (S$1.87 billion) capital expenditure program, the company aims to reach 102 billion pieces of gloves per year. Despite a global glove shortage, the company expects average selling prices to drop due to increased supply. To maintain efficiency, Sri Trang Gloves is investing in automation and reducing its workforce. The company also has a presence in non-medical sectors, where demand could remain firm after the pandemic.

site_title: Gehry's quiet interventions reshape the Philadelphia Museum
summary: Frank Gehry's renovation of the Philadelphia Museum of Art's Beaux-Arts home has resulted in a discreet, $233 million expansion. The Core Project has cleared out and reshaped the underground space to produce 20,000 additional square feet of galleries, a refreshed entrance, and an atrium. The new galleries feature a satisfyingly understated design, while Gehry's only concession to showiness is a Piranesian switchback staircase. The American galleries, dedicated to colonial period to Civil War art, display the museum's deep collection but lack interpretive depth, instead focusing on individual biographies. The renovation aims to create a substantial museum with a circulation comparable to the Musée du Louvre.

site_title: Digital divide can be tackled with technology and the right policies
summary: Singapore ranks fourth globally in digital government services satisfaction, despite a high digital divide between the rich and poor. Only 42% of low-income households use online government services, compared to 70% of top-income households. The country's digital literacy is also a concern, with 11% of households without a computer at home. However, the government's efforts, such as the NEU PC Plus Programme, and the widespread use of smartphones and digital contact tracing apps, have helped to mitigate the issue. To close the digital divide, industry, academia, and civil society must work together to develop digital solutions for all segments of society.

site_title: Corporate governance ranking improves for Singapore
summary: Singapore's corporate governance ranking has improved, ranking joint second with Hong Kong, behind Australia, according to the Asian Corporate Governance Association's 2020 report. The absolute score increased from 59 in 2018 to 63.2, reflecting a 4.8-point improvement. However, Singapore's ranking is still 10 points lower than Australia's, and the ACGA suggests that incorporating director duties into listing rules and law could enable regulators to act against breaches of director duties, preventing complacency.

site_title: Nato summit seeking to bring back solidarity across the alliance
summary: US President Joe Biden is set to host a Nato summit in Brussels, aiming to restore the alliance's solidarity after the strain caused by Donald Trump's presidency. Trump nearly announced US withdrawal from Nato, leading to cancellations and a chill in relations with allies. His erratic behavior, including a cordial meeting with Vladimir Putin, alarmed Canada and Western Europe. The summit seeks to re-establish trust and unity among Nato members, a year after Trump's presidency.

site_title: US dollar stabilises as markets wait for inflation data
summary: The US dollar stabilized on Monday after a drop on Friday due to lower-than-expected US jobs data. Investors await key inflation data and the European Central Bank meeting, which may influence monetary policy. The dollar index remained flat at 90.141, while the euro was down 0.1% against the US dollar. Speculators reduced their net short US dollar positions, and a global corporate tax rate of at least 15% could positively impact the US dollar in the long term.

site_title: Enterprise Singapore advises firms to test employees regularly for Covid-19
summary: Enterprise Singapore advises companies to test employees regularly for Covid-19, especially those in high-risk settings, using alternative tests like antigen rapid tests. Companies are also encouraged to manage potential contacts, encourage vaccination, and enforce mask-wearing and social distancing. If multiple cases are linked, all high-risk employees should be tested before operations resume.

site_title: US consulting allies on 'shared approach' to China 2022 Olympics
summary: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken announced on Monday that the US is consulting with allies and other countries on a "shared approach" to the 2022 Winter Olympics in Beijing amid criticism of China's human rights record. The move comes as some members of Congress have called for a boycott or relocation of the games. Blinken stated that more information on the US approach will be provided in the coming weeks. This move is in response to the US State Department's classification of China's treatment of Muslim Uyghurs and other ethnic minorities as a genocide.

site_title: Suntec Reit's S$150m perps priced at 4.25%
summary: Suntec Reit has priced S$150 million of subordinated perpetual securities at 4.25% per annum for five years. The net proceeds will be used for refinancing existing borrowings, acquisitions, or asset enhancements. Distributions will be made semi-annually, starting from December 15, 2021. HSBC and United Overseas Bank have been appointed as joint lead managers for the issue, which is under the Reit's US$2 billion Euro Medium Term Securities Programme. The announcement led to a 1.36% increase in Suntec Reit's units to S$1.49.

site_title: Economist who said inflation was dead now thinks it's alive
summary: Economist Roger Bootle has reversed his stance on inflation, now believing it's alive after a quarter-century. Signs of price growth are emerging in areas such as used cars and lumber as the world recovers from the pandemic. This has led to multi-year high borrowing costs in major economies, prompting some economists to sound the alarm. Despite central bankers' contentment with the transitory nature of the gains, Bootle's shift highlights the evolving inflation landscape.

site_title: China blocks several crypto-related social media accounts amid crackdown
summary: China has blocked several crypto-related social media accounts amid a crackdown on Bitcoin trading and mining. Analysts predict more actions, including linking illegal crypto activities to China's criminal law. This move is part of a broader effort to curb the country's growing cryptocurrency market, which has been criticized for its lack of regulation.

images.alt_text: Last month, China's State Council vowed to crack down on Bitcoin mining and trading, escalating a campaign against crypto currencies days after three industry bodies banned crypto-related financial and payment services.

site_title: National Australia Bank reveals anti-money laundering investigation
summary: National Australia Bank (NAB) is under investigation by the Australian Transaction Reports and Analysis Centre (Austrac) for suspected serious and ongoing breaches of anti-money laundering and counter-terrorism laws. The investigation concerns potential serious and ongoing non-compliance with customer identification procedures and customer due diligence. NAB has cooperated with the regulator and acknowledged the need to improve its performance in these matters. Austrac is handling the investigation, and a decision on further enforcement action has not been made, but the regulator may consider civil penalty proceedings.

site_title: South-east Asian startups explore early stock option cash-out to retain talent
summary: South-east Asian startups are exploring ways to allow employees to partially cash out stock options earlier, even before a listing or trade sale, to retain talent. This trend is driven by the growing pool of "soonicorns" and the maturing startup ecosystem. Buybacks and secondary sales of Employee Stock Option Plans (ESOP) are expected to gain traction, providing liquidity options for employees and creating a virtuous cycle of capital flow. Companies are offering ESOP buybacks to attract and retain top talent, particularly those nearing life milestones. As the ecosystem matures, ESOP design will become more sophisticated, with non-standard designs like KPI-based ESOP plans emerging.

images.alt_text: Kelvin Lee (left) of Fundnel says company-sponsored liquidity schemes are a secret weapon for talent attraction and retention. Ravi Ravulaparthi of Qapita says offering liquidity to employees can also become a signal of performance to the broader market.

site_title: Asean ministers urge Myanmar to halt violence after slow progress
summary: Southeast Asian foreign ministers urged Myanmar to halt violence, free prisoners, and start its agreed dialogue during a meeting in China. The group expressed disappointment at the "very, very slow progress" made by Myanmar, which has been in chaos since a February coup. At least 849 people have been killed by security forces, and over 4,500 people are detained, including Aung San Suu Kyi, who goes on trial next week. The ministers called for the immediate and transparent implementation of a five-point consensus agreed by Asean in April.

site_title: Qantas seeks details on 'disturbing' criminal gang report
summary: Qantas Airways Ltd has requested details on an intelligence report suggesting 150 employees may be linked to organized crime, including a mid-level manager affiliated with a motorcycle gang. The report, titled Project Brunello, allegedly found individuals with ties to organized crime within the airline. Qantas' chief security officer stated the claims are "disturbing" and that the company follows government vetting procedures. The airline will investigate and take action if concerns are raised about employees. This revelation has caused Qantas shares to fall 1.9% in the past week.

site_title: IndiGo expects domestic travel recovery by Q3
summary: IndiGo, India's largest airline, expects domestic air travel to recover by the October-December quarter, with passenger numbers expected to return to February 2021 levels. CEO Ronojoy Dutta attributed the recovery to a reduction in Covid-19 cases and increased vaccination rates. The airline plans to raise up to $1.03 billion to strengthen its balance sheet, despite reporting a fifth straight quarterly loss. International travel recovery is expected to be pushed to the fiscal fourth quarter of 2022.

site_title: Useful lessons from China's digital currency lead
summary: China has successfully adopted digital payments, with nearly all consumers carrying no cash and knowing little about ATMs. The country's digital currency roadmap began in 2014, with tech giants like Ant Group and Tencent contributing to its development. China leads 86% of central banks in experimenting with central bank digital currency (CBDC), leveraging its tech companies to increase convenience and retain customers. This has put China in a strong position to launch a digital currency, with the country now overtaking more advanced economies in digital payments adoption.

site_title: US approves first new Alzheimer's drug in almost two decades
summary: The US FDA has approved Aduhelm, a monoclonal antibody, as the first new Alzheimer's treatment in almost two decades. The decision was made under the Accelerated Approval pathway due to potential benefits over existing treatments despite some uncertainty. Aduhelm showed a reduction in beta-amyloid build-up in Alzheimer's patients and a reduction in cognitive decline in one of two Phase 3 trials. However, the FDA acknowledges differing perspectives from the expert community regarding the treatment's effectiveness. Aduhelm targets the underlying cause of Alzheimer's disease, addressing cognitive decline linked to the condition.

site_title: Pakistani train smashes into derailed carriages, 36 killed
summary: A train in Pakistan smashed into derailed carriages, killing at least 36 people and injuring over 70. The accident occurred in the southern province of Sindh, where several carriages were strewn across the tracks. Railway officials said the track has issues and old coaches, with some dating back 40 years. Prime Minister Imran Khan has ordered a comprehensive investigation into the safety of the railway system. The accident highlights the deteriorating state of Pakistan's 19th-century railway system, with successive governments struggling to secure funds for upgrades.

site_title: Pandemic heightens Singapore workers' anxiety about future: survey
summary: Singapore workers have a bleak view of their future, with half believing their jobs will be obsolete within five years, and 63% thinking traditional employment will not exist in the future. Many feel discriminated against and lack access to upskilling opportunities, with 62% experiencing workplace discrimination. Despite this, Singapore workers are more enthusiastic about embracing challenges and opportunities, with 51% believing their digital skills have improved during the pandemic. The survey attributed these findings to the pandemic's acceleration of workforce trends, including digitalization, and emphasized the need for equal opportunities and collaboration between government and business leaders.

site_title: Temasek-backed Nium to acquire travel payments company Ixaris for potentially £15m
summary: Nium, backed by Temasek, has agreed to acquire London-based travel payments company Ixaris for £15 million (S$28 million). The acquisition is expected to close in Q3 2021. Ixaris provides funding and payment methods to airlines and online travel agents to reduce surcharges, earn rebates, and streamline reconciliation. The deal aims to enhance Nium's cross-border payment capabilities and expand its presence in the travel industry.

site_title: G-7 corporate tax plan could net Singapore more revenue in short run
summary: Singapore may collect more corporate tax revenues in the short term if a global minimum corporate tax rate of 15% is implemented, according to tax experts. The G-7 has agreed to a minimum tax rate, which could lead to companies paying "top-up" taxes to foreign tax jurisdictions. This could result in additional revenues for Singapore, but in the longer run, the city-state needs to find new ways to attract foreign investors. Singapore's tax incentives and attractive business environment may need to be revised to maintain competitiveness.

site_title: Road to IPO: GoTo appoints former OneConnect executive as CFO
summary: GoTo Group, an Indonesian tech company, has appointed Jacky Lo, a former executive of OneConnect Financial Technology, as its new chief financial officer (CFO). Lo, who previously led OneConnect's 2019 New York listing, will lead the company's finance function and teams across various areas. The appointment comes as GoTo prepares for a public listing, with CEO Andre Soelistyo stating that Lo's expertise will support the company's long-term growth plans.

site_title: Amazon's billionaire founder Jeff Bezos to fly to space next month
summary: Amazon billionaire Jeff Bezos plans to fly to space on July 20th aboard Blue Origin's New Shepard spacecraft, along with his brother Mark, marking the first crewed space flight from the company. The flight will take passengers over 62 miles above Earth, offering a few minutes of weightlessness and a view of the planet's curvature. Bezos, stepping down as Amazon's CEO on July 5th, won the auction for a seat in the second round of bidding, which currently stands at $2.8 million.

site_title: Concerns over US inflation ease, lifting Singapore shares; STI up 0.79% to 3,175.81
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.79% to 3,175.81 points on Monday, driven by eased US inflation fears after below-expectations non-farm payroll data. Metal Component Engineering posted over 140% gains to S$0.09, while Aspen (Group) Holdings shares slid 8.29%. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed at a record high, with gains outweighing losses 212 to 282. Markets in Asia also showed mixed performance, with South Korea's Kospi Index rising 0.37% and Japan's Nikkei 225 Index up 0.27%.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore to see higher wages for cleaners in 2023, with increments ranging 5-20%. Two Temasek-linked directors of One Championship have resigned. OCBC predicts full-year growth to exceed official forecast of 4-6%. DBS has obtained a license for its majority-owned securities JV in China, with operations set to begin. The High Court is set to deliver its verdict on a long-running dispute between UOB and Lippo Marina Collection. A report highlights the digital divide in Singapore, with only 42% of low-income households meeting their online government service needs.

images.alt_text: From 2023 onwards for a period of six years, workers in the cleaning industry will enjoy higher wages under Tripartite Cluster for Cleaners' (TCC) latest review of the Cleaning Progressive Wage Model (PWM) on Monday.

site_title: GIC joins global investors to push large Asian utilities to cut emissions
summary: GIC joins a group of 12 institutional investors to push Asian utilities to cut emissions. The investors, managing $8.8 trillion in assets, focus on five utilities companies: China Resources Power Holdings, CLP Holdings, Chubu Electric Power Co, Electric Power Development Co, and Tenaga Nasional Berhad. These companies are targeted due to their significant greenhouse gas emissions, large coal-fired power capacity, or strategic role in driving the net-zero emissions transition. The Asia Investor Group on Climate Change (AIGCC) will monitor progress and encourage these companies to reduce their carbon footprint.

site_title: Taiwan to extend Covid-19 curbs, schools to stay shut
summary: Taiwan is extending its COVID-19 restrictions for two weeks until June 28, with schools remaining shut until summer vacation. The country is at its second-highest alert level, with gatherings restricted and entertainment venues closed. The government says the pandemic has not yet stabilized, despite a decrease in new cases. Taiwan is also distributing vaccines, with 1.24 million doses from Japan and 150,000 doses from the US set to be administered. The country has reported 11,491 cases and 286 deaths since the pandemic began.

site_title: Hong Kong's departing residents withdrew US$248.9m in pension funds in Q1
summary: Hong Kong residents withdrew a total of US$248.92 million from their Mandatory Provident Fund (MPF) accounts in Q1 2021, a 49.1% increase from the same period in 2020. A total of 7,700 claims were made, with 30,200 claims made for the whole of 2020. The reason for the withdrawals remains unclear, but it comes amid anti-government unrest and China's imposition of a national security law in Hong Kong.

site_title: US: Stocks start week flat, S&P nears record
summary: US stocks began the week flat, with the S&P 500 near a record high. Despite a solid gain last week, trading on Monday was muted, with the Dow Jones and S&P 500 dipping slightly. The tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index also fell 0.1%. The S&P 500 is close to setting a new record, but market participants are cautious due to uncertainty about the Federal Reserve's monetary policies. Individual stocks, such as AMC Entertainment, saw gains, while Amazon fell after its founder, Jeff Bezos, announced his plans to go into space.

site_title: UOB vs Lippo on inflated mortgages - excessive furniture rebates or poor internal controls?
summary: Singapore's High Court is set to deliver a verdict on a long-running lawsuit between UOB and Lippo Marina Collection (LMC) over inflated home loans. UOB alleges that LMC conspired with property agents to offer excessive furniture rebates, inflating the stated sale prices of luxury condo units at Sentosa Cove. The bank claims it was misled into granting housing loans based on inflated prices, resulting in S$181 million disbursed to 38 units. LMC denies the conspiracy, claiming UOB was manipulated by its poor internal controls. The verdict is expected this month.

site_title: Daimler's China venture aims to raise capacity 45% at Mercedes-Benz plants: document
summary: Daimler's main China joint venture, Beijing Benz Automotive Co (BBAC), plans to increase capacity at two Mercedes-Benz plants in Beijing by 45% through adding a shift and working days. The upgrade aims to boost nominal capacity to 760,000 vehicles per year, addressing surging demand for luxury vehicles in China's largest car market. The joint venture, 49% owned by Daimler, will increase working days to 312 per year and add a 7.5-hour shift per day at one plant, with no specified investment details.

site_title: Five new community cases, the lowest number of such infections since May 10
summary: Singapore reported 14 new COVID-19 cases, the lowest number since May 10, with five community cases linked to previously reported clusters. Two asymptomatic, fully vaccinated patients were added to the MINDSville cluster, bringing the total to 32. Another two community cases were linked to the Atatcutz Bedok barber shop cluster. There were also nine imported cases on stay-home notice. The expert committee on COVID-19 vaccination endorsed the effectiveness of mRNA-based Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccines, stating they are safe and highly effective against variants of concern.

images.alt_text: Two more Covid-19 patients have been linked to the cluster at the MINDSville @ Napiri Adult Disability Home, bringing the total number of patients in that cluster to 32.

site_title: Sembcorp Marine unit revises delivery dates for two drill ships due to Covid-19
summary: Sembcorp Marine's Jurong Shipyard unit has revised delivery dates for two ultra-deepwater drill ships due to Covid-19 disruptions. The first vessel, Deepwater Atlas, will now be delivered in December 2021, while the second vessel, Deepwater Titan, will be delivered in May 2022. The revisions are due to work disruptions caused by the pandemic, and Transocean will make partial payments upon delivery, followed by deferred instalment payments. The agreements were made after Transocean has already paid 35% of the contract price for both vessels.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed lower on Monday, with the Hang Seng Index falling 0.45% to 28,787.28, amid concerns over higher interest rates following US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen's comments. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.21% and the Shenzhen Composite Index added 0.26%.

site_title: Whatsapp message that Covid-19 treatment protocols changed after patient autopsy is false: MOH
summary: The Singapore Ministry of Health (MOH) has denied a false claim circulating on WhatsApp that Covid-19 treatment protocols were changed following a patient autopsy, stating that the claim is untrue. The message falsely claimed that Covid-19 is a bacterium that causes human death by coagulation in the blood, and that MOH immediately changed treatment protocols to give patients aspirin. The MOH has assured the public that the treatment protocols remain unchanged.

site_title: DBS gets licence for its majority-owned securities JV in China; operations to start
summary: DBS Group received the official green light for its majority-owned securities joint venture in China, attaining a securities business licence from the China Securities Regulatory Commission. The JV, DBS Securities (China), will operate various financial services, including brokerage, consulting, and underwriting, with DBS holding a 51% stake. This marks a significant milestone for DBS, further solidifying its commitment to China's financial sector, which has been pushing to open up its markets.

site_title: Over-investment into semiconductors amid shortage may lead to overcapacity, warns Natixis
summary: Natixis warns that over-investment in semiconductors to address a global shortage may lead to overcapacity, triggering a drastic fall in semiconductor prices. The report suggests that countries should instead focus on higher-value-added types of semiconductors and invest in extreme ultraviolet (EUV) and lithography equipment to maintain a self-sufficient supply chain. A fully self-sufficient supply chain is deemed too complex, and countries will need to rely on a global supply chain to fulfill global demand. Over-investment may also lead to a bottleneck in high-end chip production.

site_title: Two MINDSville @ Napiri residents, part-time barber among five new Covid-19 community cases
summary: Two new Covid-19 cases in Singapore have been linked to the MINDSville @ Napiri Adult Disability Home cluster, bringing the total to 32. The cases were asymptomatic and fully vaccinated. Five new community cases were reported, including a part-time barber, with all linked to previously reported cases. The cases were already quarantined when they tested positive. Singapore's total cases now stand at 62,210, with 14 new cases confirmed on Monday.

site_title: Toyota apologises in settlement over harassment suicide
summary: Toyota has apologized and settled with the family of a 28-year-old engineer who killed himself in 2017 after being repeatedly abused by his boss, including being told "it would be better if you died." The company vows to tackle workplace harassment, expanding its counseling system and imposing strict punishment for harassment. Toyota president Akio Toyoda visited the family to apologize directly, but details of the settlement were not disclosed. The move comes as Japan remains notorious for poor working conditions, with an increasing number of complaints about workplace harassment.

site_title: Hong Kong may be 'restrained' by new global tax rules, Chan says
summary: Hong Kong's Financial Secretary Paul Chan expressed concerns that the proposed global minimum corporate tax rate of at least 15% may restrict the city's ability to offer tax concessions to industries. Chan stated that Hong Kong may need to adopt alternative methods to maintain competitiveness, as the reform talks led by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development will change the global tax landscape. The city aims to maintain a simple tax regime to remain competitive.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end at record high on strong US jobs data
summary: South Korean stocks closed at a record high on Monday, driven by strong US jobs data, but gains were tempered by caution ahead of US inflation data. The Kospi index rose 0.37% to 3,252.12, with tech giant Samsung Electronics and internet giant Naver among the top gainers. Foreign investors sold US$165.90 million worth of shares, and investors await US inflation data, which could influence monetary policy.

site_title: Europe: Stocks steady at open
summary: European stock markets opened steadily on Monday, following a similar trend in Asia, as traders reacted to the prospect of higher interest rates amid gathering inflation. London's FTSE 100 index rose 0.1% to 7,075.30 points, while the eurozone's DAX 30 index and Paris CAC 40 index fell 0.2% each.

site_title: Google overhauls global ad model after French antitrust fine
summary: Google has agreed to pay 220 million euros and alter its global ad model after a French antitrust probe found the company distorted the market to its advantage by using its dominance over ad sales and purchasing. Google's vertical integration skewed the process, hurting publishers like News Corp. The company has entered a pledge to remedy the situation by ensuring its Google Ad Manager services work more smoothly for third parties.

site_title: Hospital patient dies after security guard performs surgery
summary: A 80-year-old woman, Shameema Begum, died at Lahore's Mayo Hospital in Pakistan after a security guard, Muhammad Waheed Butt, posed as a doctor and performed surgery on her. Butt attempted to treat her back wound two weeks prior to the surgery, which ultimately led to her death. Hospital officials acknowledged that keeping track of doctors and staff is challenging, citing the hospital's size. The incident highlights concerns about medical supervision and the risks of unqualified individuals posing as medical professionals.

site_title: Australia: Shares ease off record high as NAB, casino operators fall
summary: Australian shares closed 0.2% lower on Monday, retreating from a record high, as National Australian Bank (NAB) and major casino operators fell due to concerns over regulatory probes. NAB was under investigation for suspected breaches of anti-money laundering laws, while Star Entertainment, Crown Resorts, and SkyCity Entertainment were also investigated. Technology stocks, including Altium, rose, and gold stocks gained, tracking a jump in bullion prices.

site_title: Aboriginal group disappointed by Rio Tinto board hire
summary: An Aboriginal group in Western Australia expressed disappointment over Rio Tinto's appointment of former state minister Ben Wyatt as its first Indigenous board member. The group cited Wyatt's past approvals that led to the destruction of cultural heritage sites, including the Juukan Gorge rock shelters. Chairman Glen Camile stated that the group's engagement with Wyatt has been negative and does not believe he can restore Rio's reputation with indigenous stakeholders.

site_title: Brokers' take: CGS-CIMB maintains 'add' on UOL on 'solid execution', raises target price
summary: CGS-CIMB analyst Lock Mun Yee raised the target price for UOL to S$8, maintaining its "add" call due to the group's diversified business model and solid execution. UOL successfully bid for a residential site and plans a new launch in the third quarter, with ongoing projects seeing brisk sales. Despite challenges from the Singapore dining ban, the analyst expects the group to reposition its tenant mix and drive medium-term asset productivity through planned enhancements.

site_title: Singapore's growth to stabilise in H2, full-year growth may beat official forecast: OCBC
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to stabilize in the second half of 2021, with full-year growth projected to beat the official forecast of 4-6% at 6% year-on-year, according to OCBC. The bank attributes this to the electronics cluster's strong manufacturing momentum and retail sales rebounding 10.5% year-on-year. However, some sectors, such as F&B services and hospitality, may remain below pre-Covid levels due to the pandemic. Monetary policy is expected to remain accommodative, with policymakers unlikely to recalculate policy settings until the next meeting in October.

site_title: Tonik becomes the Philippines' first neobank to secure digital bank licence
summary: Tonik, the Philippines' first neobank, has secured a digital bank license from the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas, marking a significant milestone for the digital-only bank. Following its successful public launch in March, Tonik secured over $27.8 million in retail deposits and raised $17 million in Pre-Series B funding. The bank's cloud-based solution is powered by global financial technology leaders, and its deposits are insured by the Philippine Deposit Insurance Corporation. This license will help Tonik further expand its lending and payment products, strengthening its presence in the neobanking space.

site_title: Surging inflation, economic rebound test ECB's mettle
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is set to meet to assess its economic policies amid surging inflation and an economic rebound. Policymakers are expected to maintain historic low interest rates and unchanged bond-purchasing schemes, but will provide clues on when to start tapering stimulus measures. The brighter outlook on the eurozone horizon, driven by vaccination efforts and business reopenings, will be closely watched. The ECB's decisions will impact the eurozone economy and global financial markets.

site_title: Brokers' take: CGS-CIMB raises TP for Elite Commercial Reit to 83 pence
summary: CGS-CIMB has raised its target price for Elite Commercial Reit to 83 pence (S$1.55) from 79 pence, citing the potential reduction of income tax and elimination of capital gains tax from the proposed listing of its UK subsidiary on The International Stock Exchange. The Reit maintains a strong balance sheet and a 100% occupancy rate, with a healthy debt maturity profile. Analysts expect the listing to enhance cash flows and increase distributable income.

site_title: Swiss vote to become first European nation to ban synthetic pesticides
