summary: Switzerland is set to become the first European country to ban synthetic pesticides in a June 13 referendum. The ban aims to reduce health problems and biodiversity loss, with supporters citing risks from agro-chemical giants like Syngenta and Bayer. Manufacturers argue their products are rigorously tested and safe for use. The move could trigger similar prohibitions elsewhere, following Bhutan's complete ban on synthetic pesticides.

site_title: Thailand starts long awaited Covid-19 vaccination drive
summary: Thailand launched its COVID-19 vaccination drive on June 7, aiming to administer 6 million doses by the end of the month. The government plans to vaccinate 70% of its 66 million population by year-end, with 2.8 million people already receiving a first dose. Officials reported 2,419 new cases and 33 deaths, bringing the total to 179,886 and 1,269 fatalities. Thailand expects to receive additional doses of AstraZeneca and Pfizer/BioNTech vaccines, but has faced criticism over supply shortages and production capacity concerns.

site_title: New director says Rosneft has exploration cost advantage
summary: Karin Kneissl, a former Austrian foreign minister, has joined Rosneft's board, stating that the Russian energy major has a cost advantage in exploration due to low costs of around $2.6 per barrel. This gives Rosneft an edge over rivals, according to Kneissl.

site_title: BMW to increase China charging poles to 360,000
summary: BMW plans to increase public electric-vehicle charging poles in China to 360,000 by the end of 2021, as the company steps up efforts to capture a larger share of the country's EV market. BMW's Chinese plants aim to be carbon-neutral by year-end, reducing emissions in the production chain by 80% by 2030. The company also plans to launch 12 all-electric models in China by 2023 and increase its presence in the country through a joint-venture with Great Wall Motor Co.

site_title: Making the case for Lean Six Sigma in the healthcare sector
summary: Lean Six Sigma has transformed healthcare processes worldwide, improving efficiency, effectiveness, and patient satisfaction. Mayo Clinic and the National Health Service in the UK have achieved significant results, while Fortis hospital in India reduced costs by 20%. However, Lean implementation in healthcare has drawbacks, including a lack of data-driven approach and incorrect project selection. Lean Six Sigma combines Lean's rapidness with Six Sigma's robustness, addressing these issues. Research and practice have endorsed Lean Six Sigma's effectiveness in various healthcare contexts, including out-patient departments, mobile hospitals, and diagnostic labs. It has improved patient satisfaction, reduced turnaround times, and increased cost savings, making it a worthy direction for healthcare professionals to learn and apply.

images.alt_text: There is an increasing interest in Lean Six Sigma by healthcare practitioners. While it offers both process and data lenses to examine problems towards a resolution roadmap, practitioners endorse it to be easy to learn and effective when applied.

site_title: No 'Biden bounce' to US image in France, Germany: poll
summary: A poll by the German Marshall Fund and the Bertelsmann Foundation found that the US image has not improved in France and Germany due to its handling of the Covid-19 pandemic. The US reputation as a leading global power has suffered, with China's reputation rising slightly. Only 51% of Germans trust the US, while 60% in France and 76% in Poland do. The survey, conducted in 11 countries, also found that most Americans think the EU is a reliable partner, but views on US involvement in European defense are divided.

site_title: China faces nationalist anger over US military plane in Taiwan
summary: China's muted reaction to a US military plane's three-hour stopover in Taiwan, carrying a bipartisan congressional delegation, has sparked nationalist anger online, putting pressure on President Xi Jinping to enforce Beijing's view that Taiwan is part of its territory. The US Air Force C-17 cargo plane made a stopover in Taipei, where Taiwanese President Tsai Ing-wen met with the senators and announced plans to donate 750,000 Covid-19 vaccine doses. China's response was relatively measured, with State media not reporting on the trip, but nationalist voices demanded a stronger reaction to prevent the US from expanding ties with Taipei.

images.alt_text: China's muted reaction over a US military flight to Taiwan prompted criticism from nationalists online, underscoring the pressures on President Xi Jinping to follow through on heated "red line" rhetoric.

site_title: Philippines says rice importers may shift to cheaper Indian grains
summary: The Philippines, a top rice importer, may shift its market sources to cheaper Indian grains as the country diversifies suppliers to keep prices affordable amid food inflation. Finance Secretary Carlos Dominguez cited India, the world's top rice exporter, as a possible source of cheaper grain. The country has lowered tariffs for rice imports from 40% to 35% to contain inflation and has seen a 12.7% drop in average rice import costs to 19,312 pesos per tonne in May.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares end with gains
summary: Tokyo stocks closed with gains, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.3% to 29,019.24, and the Topix index increasing 0.1% to 1,960.85, following strong US shares and cues from Asian markets.

site_title: Despite Covid-19 resurgence, South-east Asia still set for strong 2021 rebound: ICAEW
summary: South-east Asia is forecast to experience a 4.8% economic rebound in 2021 despite a Covid-19 resurgence, according to a report by Oxford Economics commissioned by the ICAEW. The region's growth will be driven by improved global trade, accommodative macropolicies, and government fiscal support. Countries like Singapore and Vietnam are expected to lead the recovery, with Vietnam's economy expected to see 7.6% growth and Singapore's to reach herd immunity by the end of 2021, with a forecasted 6.4% growth.

site_title: Asia: Shares turn subdued ahead of US inflation test
summary: Asian shares drifted off on Monday as investors awaited key inflation data and a US jobs report, despite relief over a benign US jobs report. Relief over the benign US jobs report was tempered by caution ahead of key inflation data later this week. The G-7's agreement on a minimum global corporate tax rate of at least 15% also weighed on shares, with major tech firms potentially facing a hit. Meanwhile, a coronavirus outbreak in Taiwan took a toll on chip makers, with Taiwan stocks losing 0.6% and Chinese blue chips falling 0.5%.

site_title: Toshiba to buy back 6% of shares, pay special dividend
summary: Toshiba Corp plans to buy back up to 6% of its shares worth around $1.21 billion and pay a special dividend of about $500 million to boost shareholder returns. The move comes as the company has been under pressure from activist shareholders. Toshiba aims to return a surplus of 150 billion yen to shareholders once it reaches an appropriate equity level. The company's decision follows its previous promise to return surplus funds to shareholders.

site_title: Some on Wall Street try options trade to bet against AMC without getting burned
summary: Some Wall Street traders are betting against AMC Entertainment's massive rally in the options market, using a strategy known as a bear put spread to limit their losses if retail investors continue to drive up the stock price. This strategy, favored by professional traders, allows investors to buy put contracts with a higher strike price and sell lower-strike contracts, offsetting most of the upfront cost. As AMC's stock has surged 2,160% this year, institutional investors are seeking ways to profit from the trend while minimizing their risk, with some using put spreads to bet against the stock.

site_title: Four EH-Reit Chapter 11 properties sold for US$117.2m; rest to be sold by end-June
summary: Eagle Hospitality Real Estate Investment Trust (EH-Reit) sold four Chapter 11 properties for US$117.2 million, with the remaining properties expected to be sold by end-June. The sale proceeds will be used to repay debtor-in-possession financing, with an estimated US$153.44 million in net proceeds. Four properties were sold, including Sheraton Denver Tech Center and Four Points by Sheraton San Jose Airport. The sale of the remaining properties, excluding the Queen Mary Long Beach, is expected to conclude by the end of June.

site_title: Air Canada executives to return bonuses after government aid outcry
summary: Air Canada's top executives will return their bonuses and share awards, worth C$10 million, amid public outcry over executive compensation despite receiving government aid during the pandemic. The move comes after Canadian Finance Minister Chrystia Freeland called the bonuses "inappropriate." The airline, which received up to C$5.9 billion in government aid, acknowledged the step as a "right direction" to address concerns about responsible corporate behavior. The executives who will return their bonuses include the airline's CEO and former CEO.

site_title: China blocks several cryptocurrency-related social media accounts amid crackdown
summary: China has blocked several cryptocurrency-related social media accounts, including those on Weibo, amid a crackdown on bitcoin trading and mining. The move follows a previous ban on crypto-related financial and payment services and a vow by the State Council to crack down on bitcoin mining and trading. Analysts expect the government to link illegal crypto activities directly with China's criminal law, and a judicial interpretation is expected soon. The crackdown also comes as China accelerates testing of its own digital currency and increases reporting on crypto trading scams.

site_title: Australia's Victoria reports biggest rise in Covid-19 cases in a week
summary: Victoria, Australia, reported its biggest weekly rise in Covid-19 cases, with 11 locally acquired cases on Monday, surpassing the previous day's total of two. Authorities are investigating the source of the highly infectious Delta variant. This marks the latest outbreak in the state, which is the country's second-most populous.

site_title: It's time to mind the gap in Singapore's rich-poor digital divide: report
summary: Singapore's digital government services have a significant rich-poor divide, with only 42% of the lowest-income households meeting their needs, compared to 66% of higher-income households. The city-state ranks fourth globally in satisfaction with digital government services, but lags behind China, India, and Estonia. Trust in data management is also a concern, with the lowest-income group showing the least satisfaction in areas of security, transparency, and communication. The government must address these issues to bridge the gap and improve overall performance.

site_title: Hutchison Port Holdings Trust's trustee-manager names new chief executive
summary: Hutchison Port Holdings Trust's trustee-manager announced the departure of CEO Lam Hing Man, effective June 25, due to health reasons. He will be succeeded by Ivor Chow, director of corporate finance, who has been an executive since 2011. The trustee-manager expressed gratitude to Lam for his contributions during his tenure. No immediate impact on the company's counter was reported, trading flat at 23.5 US cents.

site_title: Cleaners in Singapore to enjoy higher wages from 2023 under latest PWM review
summary: Singapore's Tripartite Cluster for Cleaners (TCC) has approved a new Cleaning Progressive Wage Model (PWM) review, effective from 2023, which will provide higher wages to cleaners. The proposed wage ladder includes increments of 5-20% over six years, with the largest increase in the first year. Base wages for general cleaners will rise 19.7% to S$1,570. The TCC also recommends increasing the number of Workforce Skills Qualifications training modules to 3-4 by 2025.

site_title: Qantas seeks details on 'disturbing' criminal gang report
summary: Qantas has requested details from Australian law enforcement agencies about an intelligence report suggesting 150 employees may be linked to organized crime, including a mid-level manager allegedly recruited by a motorcycle gang to import narcotics. The airline's Chief Security Officer described the claims as "disturbing" and stated that Qantas follows government vetting procedures. The report's existence and any potential investigations into employees have not been disclosed to the airline. Qantas shares fell 1.9% following the news, citing a high threat to the Australian border.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares fall in opening trade on Monday
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.81% in opening trade on Monday, following US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen's comments that President Biden's $4 trillion spending plan should be pursued despite potential inflation and interest rate hikes. The Hang Seng Index dropped to 28,684.17.

site_title: Trial in MH17 crash to start hearing evidence
summary: Dutch judges begin hearing evidence against three Russian suspects and a Ukrainian in the downing of Malaysia Airlines flight MH17, which killed 298 people in 2014. The trial, which started in March 2020, will focus on whether the Boeing 777 was shot down by a BUK missile and if the accused played a role. The hearing will last until July 9, with relatives of the victims allowed to address the court in September. An international investigation concluded that a BUK missile from the Russian army was responsible for the crash.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open higher following Wall Street gains
summary: Tokyo shares opened higher on Monday following Wall Street gains, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.89% to 29,199.50 and the Topix index firming 0.20% to 1,963.11.

site_title: S&P revises Australia outlook to stable from negative on 'swift economic recovery'
summary: S&P Global Ratings revised Australia's long-term ratings outlook to stable from negative, citing the country's swift economic recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic. The Australian government's decisive fiscal and health response led to a quicker and stronger recovery than expected. S&P affirmed Australia's 'AAA' long-term and 'A-1+' short-term sovereign credit ratings. This change reflects the country's ability to contain the pandemic and limit long-term economic scarring.

site_title: Australian job advertisements jump 7.9% in May: ANZ
summary: Australian job advertisements rose 7.9% in May, reaching their highest level since 2008 with 213,894 ads, up 220% from a year earlier. The increase suggests demand for labor can withstand the impact of a coronavirus lockdown in Victoria and the removal of government support programs. This is the 12th consecutive month of job ad growth, indicating labor demand remains strong despite recent lockdowns.

site_title: New poll finds half of Japanese back Olympics this summer
summary: A new poll by the Yomiuri Shimbun daily in Japan found that 50% of respondents favor holding the Tokyo Olympics this summer, while 48% are in favor of cancellation. This represents a significant increase from early May, when 59% wanted the Games scrapped. The poll also showed Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga's approval rating has fallen to 37%, while the government's disapproval rating has risen to 50%. Olympic organizers are set to decide on spectator attendance later this month.

site_title: ComfortDelGro forms new private mobility group for its transport, lifestyle businesses
summary: ComfortDelGro has formed a new Private Mobility Group (PMG) to unify its transport, lifestyle businesses, including taxi and car rental services, amid a strategic review. The move aims to leverage core strengths in land transport solutions and develop novel mobility solutions using digital technology and clean energy. This re-organisation will allow for a more focused approach to customer access and sustainable mobility solutions.

site_title: Star Entertainment investigated for money laundering breaches in Sydney
summary: Star Entertainment Group's casino in Sydney is under investigation by Australia's AUSTRAC financial regulator for potential breaches of anti-money laundering laws. The regulator found concerns about ongoing customer due diligence and program maintenance. The company stated it will fully cooperate with the investigation.

site_title: Cromwell E-Reit acquires Czech Republic logistics asset for 10.1m euros
summary: Cromwell European Real Estate Investment Trust (Cromwell E-Reit) has acquired a Czech Republic logistics asset for 10.1 million euros (S$16.4 million), funded from its cash reserves. The freehold building spans 8,382 sq m with a 6.4% NOI yield and a 6.5-year WALE profile. The asset is 97.3% leased to quality tenants with an average lease of 6.5 years. This acquisition aims to rebalance Cromwell E-Reit's portfolio towards 50% exposure to quality light industrial/logistics assets.

site_title: Spain opens borders to all vaccinated travellers
summary: Spain has reopened its borders to all vaccinated travelers from around the world, aiming to boost its tourism sector. Health Minister Carolina Darias emphasized that Spain is a safe destination, and the move is part of the country's efforts to reclaim its global tourism leadership. Non-vaccinated Europeans can now take a cheaper antigen test instead of a negative PCR test. This change is effective immediately.

site_title: Steam rises as India and Pakistan take basmati battle to EU
summary: India has applied for a trademark for basmati rice, potentially granting it sole ownership in the European Union, sparking a dispute with Pakistan, the other global exporter of basmati. Pakistan, which now fills two-thirds of the EU's demand, opposes the move, claiming Pakistani basmati is of higher quality. The EU must try to negotiate a resolution by September, with Pakistan suggesting a joint application could resolve the issue. If an agreement cannot be reached, Pakistan may appeal to the European courts, potentially affecting its rice industry.

site_title: Utico CEO makes offer for Hyflux 2 days after winding-up application
summary: Utico CEO Richard Menezes has made a rescue offer for Hyflux, just two days after the company's judicial managers filed for liquidation. The proposal includes Hyflux's unsecured senior creditors receiving 5 cents on the dollar and retail investors getting 4 cents. Menezes has pledged S$50 million of his personal shares and S$50 million in cash to guarantee the deal. However, the judicial managers have declined to comment on the chances of the deal succeeding, citing failed investor talks.

site_title: China's meat giant WH Group jumps on HK$15b buyback plan
summary: WH Group Ltd, China's largest pork company, announced a HK$15 billion (S$2.52 billion) buyback plan, buying back and canceling about 13% of its issued shares at HK$7.80 each. The move aims to support the stock price and return profits to shareholders, with analysts predicting a 15% increase in earnings per share. The buyback plan comes as shares of hog companies have retreated amid concerns over pork prices and feed costs.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise at Monday's open; STI up 0.6%
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.6% at Monday's open, with the Straits Times Index reaching 3,168.69 points. Gainers outnumbered losers 134 to 27, and Mercurius was the most actively traded counter by volume. The STI has now gained 0.6% for the week, marking a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Aspen says financial impact of restrictions on business operations unknown
summary: Aspen Holdings, a Singapore-based conglomerate, has updated on its business operations following the imposition of restrictions in Singapore and Malaysia. The restrictions, which include a full movement control order in Malaysia, have affected its property, healthcare, and food and beverage sectors. While the financial impact is unknown, Aspen has taken measures to minimize disruptions, including closing galleries and ceasing construction works. Subsidiaries Aspen Glove and Kanada-Ya SG continue operations with restrictions, and Aspen expects no material adverse effect on its contractual obligations. Shares were trading 2.9% lower on Monday.

site_title: Taxi for hire! Bangkok cabbie hopes to capitalise on his Covid-19 shot
summary: A Thai taxi driver, Sombat Subin, has created a sign in his cab with vaccination information in three languages to reassure passengers. The sign, which reads "Vaccine" and "Covid" with a tick, has helped increase his income during the pandemic. Authorities have prioritized frontline workers, including taxi drivers, to speed up vaccinations. Only 2.7 million Thais have received a first vaccine dose, with the government scrambling to source more. A passenger in Mr. Subin's taxi expressed confidence in using public transportation after seeing the vaccination sign.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Lendlease Reit, Cromwell E-Reit, ComfortDelGro, Hutchison Port Holdings Trust, Q&M
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article:

Several Singaporean stocks saw developments that may impact trading on Monday. Lendlease Reit and Cromwell E-Reit are to watch due to potential changes in their investment strategies. ComfortDelGro and Hutchison Port Holdings Trust will focus on novel mobility solutions. Q&M posted a significant net profit of $9.4 million for the first quarter, while MXNU aims to list its UK Reit subsidiary. Hong Lai Huat will dispose of its equity interest in a research arm, and Riverstone faced COVID-19 cases among factory workers. Meanwhile, 1D8 appointed a new independent director and chairman. Shares of various companies closed with varying changes.

site_title: Yemen's unique 'dragon's blood' island under threat
summary: Yemen's Socotra island, known for its unique "dragon's blood" trees, is facing an environmental crisis due to intense storms, overgrazing, and invasive species. The trees, which provide water and medicinal sap, are being decimated, and replacement saplings are being eaten by goats. Scientists warn that the trees will largely die out within decades if action is not taken. UNESCO has described Socotra as one of the world's most biodiversity-rich islands, but climate change and human activities are putting this ecosystem at risk. Islanders are taking steps to protect the island, including replanting trees and enforcing fishing bans, but more support is needed to prevent the loss of this unique ecosystem.

site_title: Tesla won't make souped-up Model S Plaid: Musk
summary: Tesla CEO Elon Musk stated that the company won't produce a souped-up version of its Model S Plaid, citing that the original iteration is "so good." The Model S Plaid is the "quickest production car ever made," capable of accelerating from zero to 96.6km/h in under two seconds.

site_title: World's third-biggest wealth fund grows team with new hire
summary: The Abu Dhabi Investment Authority (ADIA), the world's third-biggest wealth fund, has hired Alexander Davidovich, a veteran software developer, to its in-house data analysis and artificial intelligence team. Davidovich will join the quantitative research & development department and build a technology platform from scratch for ADIA. This move follows the creation of ADIA's "science lab" to develop methods to digest large amounts of data and adopt a more science-driven approach to investment strategies.

site_title: Macquarie infrastructure nears US$4.5b deal to sell Atlantic Aviation
summary: Macquarie Infrastructure Corp is close to selling its Atlantic Aviation private aviation services network to KKR & Co Inc for around US$4.5 billion, according to a source. This deal comes as US business jet flights surge, drawing investor interest in the niche industry. Fixed base operators, which provide services ranging from hangars to fueling, have seen increased demand. A deal has not yet been signed, with Macquarie Infrastructure declining to comment. The sale would be one of the largest in the fixed base operator network.

site_title: NAB says Australian regulator probing bank's compliance with anti-money laundering laws
summary: Australia's financial regulator, AUSTRAC, has launched an investigation into National Australia Bank (NAB) over concerns with its compliance with anti-money laundering and counter-terrorism laws. NAB had self-reported shortcomings in its systems and was working to strengthen its processes. AUSTRAC has not indicated whether enforcement action will be taken, citing the lender's efforts to improve its performance. NAB CEO Ross McEwan acknowledged the need for further improvement, stating the bank takes its financial crime obligations seriously.

images.alt_text: National Australia Bank on Monday said Australia's financial crime regulator has begun an investigation after it identified serious concerns with the bank's compliance with anti-money laundering and counter-terrorism laws.

site_title: Merkel party wins big in last German state poll before general election
summary: Angela Merkel's CDU party won a convincing 37% of the vote in Saxony-Anhalt, ahead of the far-right AfD on 21%, in the final regional vote before Germany's general election. The result is seen as a major boost to CDU's conservative successor, Armin Laschet. Merkel, who is stepping down as chancellor, has not indicated her intention to run for office. The outcome suggests the CDU may be in a strong position for the upcoming general election.

site_title: Kamala Harris's plane forced to turn around due to technical fault
summary: US Vice-President Kamala Harris's plane was forced to turn back after take-off due to a technical issue on its way to Guatemala for her first international trip. The issue was resolved without major delays, and Harris will still visit Guatemala and Mexico this week. The technical fault was described as an unusual noise from the landing gear, but no safety concerns were raised. Harris will focus on tackling the root causes of migration from the region during her trip.

site_title: Harry and Meghan announce daughter's birth after tumultous year
summary: Prince Harry and Meghan Markle announced the birth of their daughter, Lilibet Diana, named after Queen Elizabeth II and Meghan's late grandmother, Princess Diana. Born healthy on Friday in Santa Barbara, California, Lilibet weighed 7 lbs 11 oz and is now at home with Meghan. The couple's second child comes after a tumultuous year marked by strained ties with the British royal family and a bombshell interview with Oprah Winfrey, where they discussed racism and their decision to quit frontline royal duties.

site_title: Spain captain Busquets tests positive for Covid-19, leaves Euro training camp
summary: Spain captain Sergio Busquets has left the country's Euro 2020 training camp after testing positive for Covid-19. The rest of the squad tested negative, and those in close contact with Busquets will remain isolated as a precaution. The squad will continue with individual training programs ahead of the tournament, which begins on June 14. Coach Luis Enrique has until Saturday to make changes to his squad. Busquets, 32, has played over 120 times for Spain and has won numerous titles with Barcelona.

site_title: Sri Lanka recovers black box from sinking ship
summary: Sri Lanka's authorities have recovered a black box from the MV X-Press Pearl, a Singapore-registered ship that sank off the coast after a fire that raged for nearly two weeks. The Voyage Data Recorder, or VDR, is expected to provide details of the ship's movements and communications with the harbour in Colombo. An investigation is underway, and police have seized the passports of the ship's crew members. The ship was carrying 25 tonnes of nitric acid and a large amount of plastic raw materials, which may have sparked the blaze.

site_title: Bitcoin falls amid Weibo crypto suspensions, Goldman CIO survey
summary: Bitcoin fell amid concerns of a further crackdown on the cryptocurrency industry in China, as Chinese social-media service Weibo suspended crypto-related accounts. The cryptocurrency also struggled with technical levels, falling below its 20-day and 200-day moving averages. A Goldman Sachs note suggested that institutional adoption of Bitcoin may be a long process, with only 25% of CIOs from various long-only and hedge funds expressing interest in the cryptocurrency.

site_title: Thai oil giant invests in plant protein to power new growth
summary: Thai state-controlled oil giant PTT Pcl has invested 300 million baht (S$12.71 million) in a plant-based protein venture with NR Instant Produce, aiming to reduce its dependence on fossil fuels. The partnership, set to start commercial operations by 2022, will produce protein from local crops like mung beans and mushrooms. PTT expects non-traditional businesses to generate a fifth of its revenue within a decade, driven by growing demand for health- and environmentally-conscious consumers.

site_title: UK businesses raise fears of future lockdowns as cases rise
summary: UK businesses are warning of potential lockdowns threatening their recovery from the pandemic. Despite optimism about near-term prospects, 40% of surveyed businesses say future lockdowns are holding them back from fully reopening. The government faces pressure to keep its June 21 timeline for lifting lockdown restrictions, which is under threat due to the delta variant's spread. Access to finance and concerns over demand, staff recruitment, and inflation are also hindering businesses. The British Chambers of Commerce urges the government to clarify safety measures and provide support for businesses in case of further restrictions.

site_title: Hot housing market creating risk to UK economy
summary: The UK housing market is experiencing a rapid surge in demand, with mortgage approvals reaching a three-year high and prices growing by 11% year-on-year. However, affordability is becoming increasingly stretched, with lenders easing loan requirements and critics warning of an unsustainable bubble. The government's temporary stamp-duty cut is set to expire, potentially creating a cliff edge and slowing the market. Authorities are watching the market closely, with some warning of the risk of price declines, particularly in London, where regional hotspots are emerging.

site_title: Strategically located Sri Lanka harbours big maritime ambitions
summary: Sri Lanka's ambitions to become a major maritime transport hub are hindered by its lack of skills and equipment to handle pollution from sinking ships. The recent fire on the MV X-Press Pearl highlighted this issue, releasing chemicals and plastics into the Indian Ocean. The ship's nearly 300 tonnes of fuel oil may leak into the ocean, posing environmental risks. Sri Lanka's limited port capacity also exacerbates the problem, making it challenging for the country to effectively manage maritime traffic and mitigate the consequences of such incidents.

site_title: Lendlease Global Reit proposes to raise stake in Jem to up to 31.8%
summary: Lendlease Global Reit proposes to raise its stake in Jem mall to up to 31.8% for a purchase consideration of S$204.1 million to S$337.3 million. The Reit currently holds an indirect interest in Jem through its 5% interest in Lendlease Asian Retail Investment Fund 3 Limited. The trustee has entered into sale-and-purchase agreements with vendors to acquire stakes in two private funds, Lendlease Jem Partners Fund Limited and Lendlease Asian Retail Investment Fund 3 Limited, which own 25% and 75% of Jem, respectively.

site_title: Singapore listcos ride recovery wave in Q1
summary: Singapore-listed companies saw a significant recovery in Q1, with nearly 70% in the black, and more than half earning better than they did over the same period last year. Combined earnings reached almost S$7.99 billion, more than doubling the collective net profit of S$3.72 billion in Q1 last year. However, some sectors, including travel and tourism, continue to face hard times, and near-term uncertainties, such as tightened measures due to a spike in Covid-19 cases, may dampen the rebound.

site_title: China electric vehicle maker betting on cult status to sell a million cars
summary: A Chinese automaker, SAIC-GM-Wuling Automobile, has dominated China's electric car market by selling 270,000 of its Hongguang Mini EVs in nine months, outselling bigger players and even Tesla. The affordable EV, priced at $4,500, has achieved cult status, with the company aiming to sell a million cars. This is part of its larger ambitions for the future, driven by its joint venture with state-backed automakers and US giant General Motors.

site_title: Euro/US dollar rally unlikely to persist
summary: The euro/US dollar pair is unlikely to sustain its recent rally, with a mean reversion expected in the near to middle term. The pair has been on a steady decline since peaking in 2018, with a strong reversal in late May 2020. Current indications of resistance at 1.2243 and an overbought signal from the stochastic oscillator suggest a potential reversal. A weakening momentum, as indicated by the Moving Average Divergence (MACD) indicator, may also lead to a price drop, with support levels at 1.1755 and potentially lower.

site_title: What can Singapore companies learn from the latest rally in US-listed meme stocks?
summary: Singapore companies can learn from the recent rally of US-listed meme stocks, such as AMC Entertainment and GameStop, by cultivating a large following of small investors to boost market value. Companies like AMC have successfully engaged with retail investors, offering loyalty benefits and direct communication. Singapore companies, particularly consumer-facing ones, can benefit from developing retail investor communication initiatives, similar to AMC's "AMC Investor Connect" platform. This could lead to a positive impact on market valuation and create a win-win situation for both the company and its owners.

site_title: China's new birth policy: Not as simple as one, two, three
summary: China's new policy allowing couples to have up to three children aims to boost the country's low fertility rate, currently at 1.3 children per woman. Experts predict minimal impact, citing history of failed social policies and changing aspirations among young couples. A more comprehensive approach, including pro-birth policies, benefits, and infrastructure, is needed to shift the needle. The policy may slow China's declining population issue but won't reverse it, as most young couples don't want kids due to financial considerations and changing values. China's aging population poses significant economic challenges, and a more sustainable solution is needed.

site_title: Logistics woes under the spotlight
summary: E-commerce platforms in South-east Asia are experiencing a surge in business due to the pandemic, but this has also led to increased problems in logistics and delivery manpower. A report by Parcel Monitor and iPrice Group found that delivery times in Malaysia increased from 2.1 days to 4.6 days during the pandemic. The issue is exacerbated by safe distancing measures, customs clearance delays, and reduced customs personnel. To address this, companies such as JD.com are partnering with local taxi companies to deliver parcels, and smart technologies like self-service parcel lockers are being implemented to increase flexibility and reduce physical contact.

site_title: Bicycle prices in US reflect inflationary pressures in broader economy
summary: US bicycle prices have risen 10% due to inflationary pressures, with some models increasing by as much as 27% in the past year. Supply chain issues, including raw material shortages and shipping costs, are driving the price hikes. Despite the surge in demand, driven by a new wave of popularity and increased bike-friendliness in cities, supply is expected to remain tight until at least next year. Industry executives foresee further price increases, which could impact the economy and potentially affect President Biden's re-election prospects.

site_title: Collectors of digital NFTs see a 'Wild West' market worth the risk
summary: Collectors of digital NFTs are embracing the "Wild West" market, driven by the unique ability to verify ownership through blockchain technology. Enthusiasts, like Brandon Kang, who owns over 500 NFTs, are willing to take risks due to the potential for huge returns. NFT sales have generated nearly $2.5 billion in the first five months of 2021, with big auction houses like Sotheby's now selling them. The market's accessibility and innovation are drawing in collectors, who see NFTs as a new frontier in digital ownership.

site_title: Second annual survey begins on Singapore's best law firms
summary: Singapore's second annual survey to identify the best law firms has been launched by The Straits Times and German-based research firm Statista. The survey, open until July 26, will compile a list of the 100 top law firms in various practice areas, including Technology, Media, Telecommunication (TMT) Law and Best Offshore Law Firm. Last year's survey received over 10,000 recommendations and 4,716 respondents. The results will be published in November, with industry players anticipating how recent legal developments will impact the survey results.

site_title: Cruise ships' return to Venice reignites tensions
summary: The MSC Orchestra, a cruise ship, returned to Venice after a nearly 1.5-year suspension due to the pandemic, rekindling tensions between supporters and opponents of massive floating hotels. Opponents, concerned for the environment and cultural heritage, argue that cruise ships cause damage to the city's foundations and ecosystem. However, supporters claim that stopoffs create jobs in a city reliant on tourism. The ship's crew took on supplies and tightened safety protocols, with only half of its 3,000 places filled for its tour.

site_title: Lian Beng aims to stay conservative as pandemic hits construction sector
summary: Construction company Lian Beng Group is taking a conservative approach amid the pandemic's impact on the construction sector. The company is focusing on fulfilling existing projects in its order book of S$1.5 billion while keeping a firm hand on costs. With a workforce 30% fewer than before due to labor shortages and safety restrictions, Lian Beng aims to diversify its revenue streams through its dormitory business, property development, and investment holdings. The company's chairman, Ong Pang Aik, believes that cash flow is king and that the industry's dependence on foreign workers is a major concern, with technological innovations not yet catching up.

site_title: Taiwan lifts toughest water curbs after rain eases drought
summary: Taiwan lifted its toughest water restrictions after heavy rain eased a severe drought. The restrictions, imposed in April, limited water supplies to parts of Taichung, Changhua, and Miaoli to no water for two days a week. The drought, Taiwan's worst on record, was exacerbated by a lack of typhoons. The lifted restrictions will allow residents to resume normal water use.

site_title: Universal Music turns dominant roster of stars into US$42b smash
summary: Universal Music Group has become the world's unchallenged hit machine, with nearly half of the top 10 acts in Bloomberg's Pop Star Power Rankings signed to its labels. The company's valuation has soared to around $42 billion, including debt, and is expected to go public later this year. UMG's success can be attributed to its ability to adapt to industry changes, such as the rise of streaming services, and its strategic expansion into emerging markets like Asia. The company's scale and diverse roster of artists, including Taylor Swift, Billie Eilish, and Lady Gaga, have cemented its position as the dominant force in the music industry.

site_title: PE consortium to buy majority stake in Medline
summary: A consortium of private equity firms, including Blackstone Group, Carlyle Group, and Hellman & Friedman, has agreed to buy a majority stake in Medline Industries, a medical supply company. Singapore's GIC will also invest in the partnership. This deal would be one of the largest leveraged buyouts in history. The terms of the agreement were announced on June 5, 2021.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: KrisEnergy, a troubled oil and gas group, has submitted a winding-up petition to the Cayman Islands' Grand Court due to inability to pay debts. The company's liabilities exceed asset value, with no acceptable alternative restructuring options and limited near-term funding.

site_title: With Covid cases dropping, Singapore heading in right direction: Ong Ye Kung
summary: Singapore reported 20 Covid-19 cases, with six in the community and 14 imported, on June 6, 2021. The number of community cases has been declining, with the lowest since May 10. Health Minister Ong Ye Kung said Singapore is heading in the right direction, with a rise in the percentage of infected people detected during quarantine. Unlinked cases have also fallen, and the Tan Tock Seng Hospital and Pasir Panjang clusters have been closed. The total number of cases in Singapore has reached 62,196, with 22 more patients discharged from hospital and 207 remaining hospitalised.

site_title: Central banks face new balancing act with their huge asset piles
summary: Central banks worldwide are reassessing their massive bond-buying programs in a post-pandemic world, with many owning over $7 trillion in debt. Despite efforts to reduce asset piles, officials face pressure to maintain borrowing costs low, fight inequality and climate change, and maintain independence. A "fiscal dominance" regime, where central banks prioritize government finances over inflation, is a concern, with some calling for cancellation or perpetual bonds. Reducing debt holdings quickly could create market turmoil, and central bankers are wary of tapering programs, citing the need for progress on employment and inflation goals.

site_title: Sacked JPMorgan exec ends up becoming its CFO
summary: Jeremy Barnum, a former JPMorgan executive, has been promoted to chief financial officer (CFO) despite being fired over a trading mishap and having another market blunder at a hedge fund. Barnum, 48, was given a second chance by JPMorgan in 2007 and has since risen through the ranks, helping the firm navigate the financial crisis and overseeing the London Whale trading scandal. His unorthodox background, including time spent in a bohemian neighborhood in Barcelona, has been noted by colleagues, who describe him as a unique and articulate individual.

images.alt_text: Jeremy Barnum is known to love a good debate, and is rarely at a loss for words. Some are keen to see how he interacts with analysts and investors.

site_title: China e-commerce players tap Asean market for growth
summary: Chinese e-commerce players are expanding into Southeast Asia, but face challenges in understanding local dialects, such as Singlish, which is prevalent in Singapore. A lack of fluency in English and unfamiliarity with local expressions, such as acronyms and colloquialisms, lead to poor customer service experiences. This hinders growth plans in the region.

site_title: Two days, 100 florists, one million flowers: A festival blooms in New York City
summary: The L.E.A.F Festival of Flowers in New York City is a two-day event featuring over 100 florists, one million flowers, and 25 large-scale installations in the Meatpacking District. The festival, inspired by European events like the RHS Chelsea Flower Show, aims to celebrate New York's florists after a tough year. The event, free to the public, will also provide a platform for florists to connect with retailers and promote their work. Organizers hope to turn the festival into a for-profit event in the future, with ticketed lectures and master classes.

site_title: Thailand calls for end to Myanmar violence, implementation of 5-point Asean consensus
summary: Thailand has expressed concern over the violence in Myanmar, calling for the implementation of the 5-point Asean consensus to help end the turmoil. The consensus, agreed in April, includes an end to violence, political talks, and the naming of a regional special envoy. Thailand's government, led by a former army chief, fears the conflict could bring a flood of refugees and has been engaged in quiet diplomacy. The country has urged the Myanmar junta to release detainees, end violence, and implement the consensus, with at least 847 people killed since the coup.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for June 4, 2021, reveals a mixed week for the tanker and dry bulk market. The Capesize market slid, with the 5TC rate dropping $4,681 to $20,933, while the Transatlantic C8 rate fell to $16,875. However, the fronthaul C9 rate saw some higher-paying fixtures, offering hope for owners. The Transpacific C10 remains the best-paying region. Despite the downwards influence from Capesize, the timecharter average and BPI improved, supported by grains from east coast South America.

site_title: G-7's global minimum tax deal may nullify any tax advantage Singapore offers
summary: The G-7 countries have agreed on a global minimum tax rate of at least 15% for multinational corporations (MNCs), which could nullify any tax advantage Singapore offers to MNCs. The deal would require companies to pay taxes to countries where sales are generated, regardless of where their headquarters are located. Countries with large domestic markets, such as Indonesia, may benefit from the agreement, while smaller economies may face limited policy options to attract investments. The impact on Singapore's tax incentives and MNCs' investment decisions is uncertain, with tax experts warning that the rules will need to be clarified before implementation.

site_title: Developers, contractors battle labour crunch, supply shortage to meet deadlines
summary: Singapore's construction industry is facing disruptions due to a labor shortage, with developers and contractors battling to meet project deadlines. The shortage, exacerbated by COVID-19 cases in India and tightened border controls, has forced some workers to return to their home countries. The government has introduced measures to alleviate the labor crunch, but some developers are still experiencing delays. Several projects, including Unison Construction's Meyer House and CapitaLand's Rochester Commons, have adjusted their completion timelines. Despite these challenges, most developers say they are on track to meet their individual TOP (topping out) schedules.

site_title: Aspen says no further developments with Honeywell; glovemaking unit in talks to sell production capacity
summary: Aspen Holdings' glove-making unit, Aspen Glove, is in talks to sell its Phase 1(b) production capacity, originally meant for Honeywell International, due to lack of further developments. The US$210 million supply agreement with Honeywell was announced in April but not consummated. Aspen confirmed that the resignations of its divisional director and chief operating officer are unrelated to the Honeywell deal. The company is exploring other options for the sale of its production capacity.

site_title: In New York, buildings with sections that seem to float in midair
summary: In New York, innovative building designs are incorporating cantilevers to create unique, space-efficient structures. By extending building sections into the air, developers can maximize square footage, create more apartments with better views, and sidestep zoning restrictions. Architects praise cantilevers for their architectural drama and potential financial benefits, as the value of space increases with height. Examples of cantilevered buildings, such as The Emerson and Era, showcase the creative solutions being used to build more homes in a crowded cityscape, where land is scarce.

site_title: Young entrepreneurs pivot towards recovery
summary: Young entrepreneurs in the Asia-Pacific region have adapted to the COVID-19 pandemic by changing and developing new business strategies. 92% of youth-led enterprises have been negatively impacted, with 85% shrinking or limiting their businesses, but 87% demonstrated resilience by pivoting. 86% developed new products and services, and 86% transformed their operating models. The Asia-Pacific region is home to 660 million young people, with worsening youth unemployment due to the pandemic, highlighting the need for social entrepreneurship to drive inclusive growth and sustainable development.

site_title: Canadian dollar recoups weekly loss as investors shrug off jobs decline
summary: The Canadian dollar strengthened 0.3% against the US dollar, recovering from its weakest level in over a week, as oil prices rose and investors weighed US and Canadian employment data. Canada lost 68,000 jobs in May, but analysts say the number is "below the surface" and the Canadian dollar won't be flustered. The loonie has been bolstered by higher commodity prices and the Bank of Canada's more hawkish stance, with interest rate decisions due on Wednesday.

site_title: The evolution of cross-border e-commerce merchants
summary: E-commerce in South-east Asia is evolving, shifting from traditional e-commerce platforms to social commerce. Industry insiders say that selling through influencers and live streaming is gaining popularity, with platforms like Facebook, Instagram, and TikTok becoming key channels for attracting buyers. This model reduces the transactional aspect and increases "stickiness" through interactive social elements, leading to impulse buying and increased sales. Social commerce now accounts for 44% of South-east Asia's e-commerce sector, generating $48 billion in sales, and many cross-border vendors employ a dual-channel strategy to reach customers.

site_title: Look beyond data for human biases to gain an edge in the market
summary: Investors often focus on data to gain an edge in the market, but this approach has become commoditized due to the abundance of accessible data. To succeed, one must look beyond data and seek truths that data devotees shun, taking into account human biases such as confirmation bias. This involves analyzing historical trends and causal relationships that data alone cannot reveal. By doing so, investors can identify unique findings and gain an edge in the market, as seen in the example of the price-to-sales ratio (PSR) which was initially successful but has lost its power due to widespread adoption.

site_title: S-Reits' YTD asset acquisitions exceed S$5 billion
summary: S-Reits in Singapore have seen significant asset acquisitions in 2021, with 15 deals valued over S$5 billion. Industrial and logistics-related properties accounted for 11 of these acquisitions, with notable deals by Mapletree Industrial Trust, Ascendas Reit, and Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust. These acquisitions aim to diversify portfolios and increase assets under management.

site_title: How the best law firms list is compiled
summary: Singapore's Best Law Firms are identified through a peer-to-peer survey of lawyers, in-house lawyers, and clients, conducted by Statista. The survey, open from June 7 to July 26, 2021, collects recommendations on 17 law practice categories. Participants must provide a personalized email address for validation. The results are analyzed to rank law firms, with 100 firms expected to be listed, and many firms expected to appear in multiple categories. Self-recommendations are not allowed, and participants can submit optional questions for a deeper understanding of Singapore's legal landscape.

site_title: With travel off the cards, cashback takes off instead
summary: Consumers are shifting from travel rewards to cashback credit cards as international travel remains uncertain. This trend is driven by the need to stretch everyday expenses. The rise in cashback sign-ups is a response to consumers' desire for flexibility and value from their credit cards. As a result, cashback credit cards are becoming increasingly popular, allowing consumers to convert points into cash.

site_title: One dead, seven missing after accident at central China coal plant
summary: One person died and seven are missing after an accident at a coal mine in central China. The incident occurred at a mine run by Henan Hebi Coal and Electricity Co in Henan province on Friday. The authorities have launched an emergency response plan. This accident comes amid China's efforts to stabilize rising commodity prices and boost coal production to meet global demand. The incident is the latest in a series of safety concerns at China's coal mines, which have been carrying out safety inspections.

site_title: KrisEnergy submits winding-up petition
summary: KrisEnergy, a troubled oil and gas group, has submitted a winding-up petition to the Grand Court of the Cayman Islands due to its inability to pay debts. The company's liabilities exceed asset value, with no acceptable alternative restructuring options. This decision comes after its restructuring plan was shelved due to lower oil prices and sales. As of June 30, 2019, KrisEnergy's total debt was US$476.8 million. The company's shares were suspended in August 2019 at S$0.03. Liquidation proceedings are expected to proceed.

site_title: Hong Lai Huat Group unit disposes Singapore farm resort business to focus on Cambodia operations
summary: Hong Lai Huat Group's wholly owned subsidiary HLH Agri International is disposing of its entire equity interest in HLH Agri R&D for S$4.8 million, focusing on its business in Cambodia. HLH Agri R&D owns a 20-year leasehold agri-tainment farm resort, Gallop Kranji Farm Resort, set to be leased by Blue Dolphin from July 1, 2021. The sale aims to strengthen the group's financial position as it shifts focus to its operations in Cambodia.

site_title: Riverstone confirms Covid-19 infections at Malaysia manufacturing facilities
summary: Riverstone Holdings, a Malaysian glove maker, has confirmed 75 positive Covid-19 cases among its factory workers at facilities in Perak, resulting in temporary closures and a 60% workforce capacity limit. This will lead to a 2% loss of annual production capacity. The company has taken immediate action, conducted PCR tests, and isolated affected workers and those in close contact. Riverstone will continue to adhere to stringent safety measures, prioritizing employee health and well-being.

site_title: Vaccinated Europeans book their holiday while Brits decry U-turn
summary: The UK government's sudden policy U-turn on travel has caught many UK vacationers off guard, forcing them to seek rapid retreats or face lengthy quarantines and more tests upon re-entry. In contrast, European countries such as Germany, Italy, Spain, and France are seeing a rise in holiday bookings, with 52% more bookings in the past month, as vaccination drives and loosening of border restrictions gain momentum. The UK's decision to remove Portugal from its travel list has been criticized, with airline executives accusing the government of mismanaging the Covid recovery.

site_title: Implementation of G-7 agenda challenging
summary: The G-7 summit in Cornwall, England, aims to end the Covid-19 pandemic and secure a global economic recovery. However, implementation of the agenda will be challenging due to inequitable vaccine distribution, which has left millions vulnerable to the virus. The G-7 leaders will promise to help developing nations' vaccination programs, but economists are skeptical about the feasibility of a proposed 15% global minimum corporate tax, which may generate $100 billion. The finance ministers have agreed to support climate change and environmental policies, proposing $100 billion a year to help third-world nations.

site_title: Director ups stake as MNACT pursues portfolio expansion
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) remained unchanged at 3,165.00 through May 28 to June 3, maintaining a total return of 13.1% for the 2021 year. OCBC, Genting Singapore, CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust, Mapletree Industrial Trust, and UOB received the highest institutional inflows. Nine primary-listed stocks conducted share buybacks, with OCBC, Singapore Exchange, and Singapore Telecommunications leading the consideration tally. Several director and substantial shareholder transactions were reported, including the sale of shares by Jiutian Chemical Group executive director Lee Chee Seng and the acquisition of shares by Healthway Medical Corporation executive director Abram Melkyzedeck Suhardiman.

site_title: North Korea's Kim appears in public for the first time in month
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un made his first public appearance in about a month, wearing his signature black Mao suit, during a Party meeting that discussed ways to improve the country's deteriorating economy. The meeting reviewed major policy tasks and came after his longest absence from public view in six weeks, sparking speculation about his health. The meeting also highlighted North Korea's ongoing struggles with the pandemic, US sanctions, and a lack of trade with China, which has shown little sign of growth this year.

site_title: UK says all state contract bidders must commit to 2050 net zero goal
summary: The UK government has announced that companies bidding for state contracts must commit to net zero emissions by 2050 and publish their carbon reduction plans. The rules, set to take effect by September, aim to transform the economy to net-zero without overly burdening businesses, particularly small and medium-sized enterprises. Anyone failing to comply will be excluded from the contest, with the government's purchasing power expected to help drive this change, spending over £290 billion annually on procurement.

site_title: Autonomous vehicle startup Aurora in talks to merge with Reid Hoffman's SPAC
summary: Aurora, an autonomous vehicle startup, is in talks to merge with Reinvent Technology Partners Y, backed by Silicon Valley heavyweights Reid Hoffman, Mark Pincus, and Michael Thompson. The deal's valuation has decreased from US$20 billion to around US$12 billion. The merger is expected to be announced as early as next week.

site_title: In rural India, fear of testing and vaccines hampers Covid-19 fight
summary: In rural India, the COVID-19 pandemic is spreading rapidly despite vaccination efforts being hindered by fear and ignorance. Health workers face resistance when attempting to administer vaccines, with some villagers fleeing or refusing to receive shots due to misconceptions about their safety. This issue is particularly pronounced in poverty-stricken areas where access to information is limited.

site_title: Tencent-backed Kanzhun seeks up to US$912m in US IPO
summary: Kanzhun, a Tencent-backed Chinese online recruitment platform, is set to raise up to $912 million in its US IPO, offering 48 million American depositary shares at $17-$19 each. The company aims to use the funds for technology infrastructure and research and development, despite a challenging market with many Chinese firms putting US listing plans on hold. Kanzhun's net loss narrowed to $36.5 million in the first quarter, with revenue surging almost threefold to $788.5 million. The IPO is led by Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley, and UBS Group AG.

site_title: Biden rejects higher GOP infrastructure offer from Capito
summary: President Joe Biden rejected a $928 billion infrastructure proposal from Senate Republicans led by Shelley Moore Capito, which offered $50 billion more in spending than their previous proposal. The offer, which included $257 billion in new net spending, fell short of Biden's objectives to grow the economy, tackle the climate crisis, and create new jobs. Biden agreed to continue engaging with senators from both parties to achieve a more substantial package, with the next call scheduled for Monday.

site_title: Microsoft says error led to no matching Bing images for Tiananmen 'tank man'
summary: Microsoft blames an "accidental human error" for not displaying image results for the query "tank man" on Bing in the US and elsewhere, sparking concerns of possible censorship around the Tiananmen Square crackdown anniversary. The issue was resolved after hours, with the search returning results of tanks elsewhere in the world. The incident has raised questions about content moderation and potential state involvement, with some experts suggesting it could be a case of purposeful suppression. Microsoft acknowledged the error and is working to resolve the issue.

site_title: China blasts US and EU consulates in Hong Kong for Tiananmen candles
summary: China has condemned the US and EU consulates in Hong Kong for displaying candles to commemorate the 1989 Tiananmen crackdown, calling it a "clumsy political show" to destabilize the city. The move comes as Hong Kongers hold candlelit vigils on June 4, banned by authorities this year amid a crackdown on dissent. China's foreign ministry spokesperson said the actions crossed a "red line" and urged the consulates to stop meddling in Hong Kong affairs. The display of candles is a rare act of defiance in a city under increasing Beijing control.

site_title: Oil gains for second week on signs summer travel rush underway
summary: Oil futures rose nearly 5% this week, marking their second consecutive weekly gain, as summer travel demand in the US and Europe picks up. Global benchmark Brent surpassed the $70-a-barrel mark for the first time in over two years. Opec+ is expected to keep adding barrels to the market in August or September to meet the recovery, while traders anticipate higher prices in the coming months due to muted financial flows and low speculative positioning.

site_title: Philippines files criminal complaint against Wirecard's former COO
summary: Philippine authorities have filed criminal complaints against Wirecard's former COO, Tan Teck Long, and others in connection with the German payment firm's multi-billion dollar fraud. Wirecard collapsed last June, owing creditors almost $4 billion, and was accused of a sophisticated global fraud. The Philippines had claimed it held $2 billion in two local banks, a claim denied by the country's central bank and lenders. The move is part of ongoing investigations into the scandal.

site_title: Mexico mine collapse leaves seven workers trapped
summary: Rescuers in northern Mexico are attempting to free seven mine workers trapped after a collapse at a coal-producing mine in the municipality of Muzquiz, Coahuila state. Initial investigations suggest the collapse was due to a flood at the mine. The labor department stated that some workers were trapped inside the mine, but no further details have been released. The rescue efforts are ongoing, but no update on the status of the trapped workers has been provided.

site_title: China to make climate information disclosure mandatory
summary: China aims to make climate and carbon emission information disclosure mandatory, following successful testing with commercial banks and listed companies. The move is part of China's goal to become carbon neutral by 2060 and requires an estimated 2.2 trillion yuan in investment annually by 2030. The People's Bank of China is developing green finance and addressing related financial risks, including conducting stress tests and assessing policy incentives for green projects.

site_title: My family contracted Covid-19 and this is what I learned
summary: A writer shares their personal experience contracting Covid-19, which led them to reflect on statistical anomalies, including the unpredictability of markets. They cite the MSCI All Country World Index, which has had four drawdowns greater than minus 40% in over 30 years, despite its long-term annualized return of 7.16%. This highlights the need for investors to be mentally and emotionally prepared for market fluctuations and to maintain a rational investment strategy. The writer emphasizes the importance of empathy for those who experience anomalies, both positive and negative, in their lives.

site_title: Prudential's Goh Theng Kiat is running for his life
summary: Prudential Singapore's Chief Customer Officer, Goh Theng Kiat, is running to stay healthy and fit. A lifelong runner, he incorporates daily workouts, weekly fitness sessions, and a balanced diet into his routine. He also runs with an inclusive group, Runninghour, which teaches him lessons in gratitude and positivity. Goh believes in the importance of preventative actions to care for one's mind and body, aiming to maintain good health throughout his life.

site_title: Flight diverted to Albuquerque, New Mexico after passenger tries to breach cockpit
summary: A Delta flight from Los Angeles to Nashville was diverted to Albuquerque, New Mexico after a passenger attempted to breach the cockpit. Authorities removed the passenger and took them into custody, with no injuries reported. The Federal Bureau of Investigation confirmed it was responding to the incident, stating there was "no threat to the public at this time." The flight resumed its trip to Nashville after the incident.

images.alt_text: A Delta flight headed to Nashville from Los Angeles was forced to land in Albuquerque, New Mexico on Friday after a passenger attempted to break into the cockpit.

site_title: Goldman, HSBC to open Hong Kong offices fully as virus wanes
summary: Goldman Sachs and HSBC are reopening their Hong Kong offices fully as the city's fourth wave of infections is contained. The US investment bank, which employs 1,700 people in Hong Kong, said half of its staff are now vaccinated and encouraged those who haven't to get shots. HSBC also plans to get all its staff back at their desks by the end of the month. The move comes as the city's administration seeks to encourage vaccination, with cash payouts and extra time off offered to those who get vaccinated.

site_title: Biden's electric vehicle plan includes battery recycling push
summary: President Joe Biden's electric vehicle plan includes boosting domestic battery recycling to reuse lithium and other metals, aiming to reduce metal usage in new battery chemistries and secure enough raw materials. The administration will review gaps in supply chains, including those for cobalt, lithium, and other minerals, and consider direct investment in projects and scientific research to spur domestic recycling. This push is part of a broader effort to make the US a leader in electric vehicles and reduce reliance on mining, with estimates suggesting recycling could cut the need for new sources of metals by 55% by 2040.

site_title: Boom or bust: my one week roller coaster with AMC
summary: A writer shares their experience investing in AMC Entertainment, a "meme" stock, after being influenced by Reddit discussions. They initially bought 20 shares at $19.56, but sold at cost price after the stock surged 160% in a short period. The writer notes the importance of discipline and risk management in investing, and now plans to learn from credible sources and consider exchange-traded funds (ETFs) for a more stable investment approach.

site_title: Regulators are trying to get Elon Musk to run his tweets by lawyers. It's not working.
summary: Regulators are struggling to hold Elon Musk accountable for his tweets, which have moved Tesla's stock price without consulting the company's lawyers. Despite a $40 million fine and loss of chairmanship, Musk continues to tweet, citing the need for "wholly aspirational" statements. The Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has not taken further action, with some experts suggesting that the SEC may be hesitant to revisit the issue due to concerns about the propriety of the earlier settlement and the potential for a lengthy court battle.

site_title: Trump's former counsel Don McGahn testifies to House panel
summary: Former White House counsel Donald McGahn testified for hours to the House Judiciary Committee about the 2016 presidential election and whether then-President Donald Trump tried to obstruct the Mueller investigation. McGahn's appearance marked the end of a two-year legal standoff, with the committee limited in what it could ask him under an agreement in principle. Despite restrictions, McGahn testified about President Trump's attempts to obstruct the investigation and shed new light on several troubling events. A transcript of the testimony is expected to be released within seven days.

site_title: CIMB Singapore pulls out as Catalist sponsor for SGX-listed firms
summary: CIMB Bank Singapore announced its intention to cease acting as a Catalist sponsor for SGX-listed firms to focus on clients listed on the mainboard of the Singapore Exchange. The bank stated it will ensure existing Catalist clients continue to receive support from another Catalist sponsor. This move allows the bank to concentrate on its mainboard clients, providing a smoother transition for its existing clients.

site_title: Visible carbon price, harmonised laws needed to drive sustainable finance: panel
summary: A visible carbon price in a liquid market and harmonized regulations are crucial for driving sustainable finance, according to a panel discussion at the Asia Securities Industry & Financial Markets Association ESG & Sustainable Finance Week. Experts emphasized the need for a credible and effective carbon market to direct sustainable financing towards green targets. Harmonization of standards and regulations globally is also essential to make efforts comparable and credible, with the Singapore Exchange and London Stock Exchange Group highlighting their roles in promoting disclosure and comparability.

site_title: China rebukes Biden for 'suppressing' Chinese firms
summary: China has accused the US of "suppressing" Chinese firms after US President Joe Biden expanded a blacklist of 59 Chinese companies that are off-limits to American investors. The list includes subsidiaries of companies already included, and Beijing has issued veiled threats of retaliation. The move is part of Biden's campaign to pressure China's "military-industrial complex." The blacklist was previously narrowed down after legal challenges but was expanded after a review. China's reaction comes as the US maintains pressure on the Asian superpower.

site_title: Ant faces dent in profitability with new consumer finance unit
summary: Ant Group's consumer finance unit has been approved with a capital base of 8 billion yuan (S$1.65 billion), but this approval limits its ability to lend on its own and in partnership with banks. As a result, the company's most lucrative business of consumer lending is likely to become less profitable due to regulatory crackdowns. The approval marks the end of a six-month regulatory period aimed at curbing Ant's influence.

site_title: CFM Holdings fields slew of SGX queries over pharma startup acquisition
summary: CFM Holdings has seen its shares surge following its announcement to acquire a 51% stake in SING-SWE MM Biotechnology for up to S$6.1 million. The acquisition was reportedly facilitated by a mutual business associate who introduced the CEO to Fang Huasheng and Gao Hong, who then arranged for the distribution and sale of viral test kits in Singapore. The Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) has questioned the origin of the deal, prompting CFM Holdings to clarify its involvement.

site_title: Audi Q5 review: Still an orderly Q
summary: The Audi Q5 has undergone a facelift, introducing smoother looks and new features such as OLED tail-lights and a mild hybrid drive system. The updated car also boasts a more modern design, with a slimmer grille, new bumper, and satin chrome accents. The infotainment system has been improved, featuring a larger touchscreen and Audi's new tiled-based user interface. The Q5 remains a refined and capable SUV, with a comfortable cabin and responsive handling. Its price starts at S$268,524, making it a premium option in the market.

site_title: Asean, EU conclude negotiations on air transport agreement
summary: ASEAN and the European Union have concluded negotiations for the world's first bloc-to-bloc air transport agreement, liberalising aviation between the two regions. The deal aims to facilitate travel between Southeast Asia and Europe, but industry watchers warn it may take several years to assess the impact due to ongoing pandemic restrictions. The agreement is seen as a significant step towards promoting air travel between the two regions.

site_title: Gold rebounds as US non-farm payrolls fall short of expectations
summary: Gold prices rebounded 1% to US$1,889.27 per ounce after US nonfarm payrolls fell short of expectations, with 559,000 jobs created instead of the forecasted 650,000. The dollar index eased, making gold more affordable for holders of other currencies. Analysts attribute the rally to inflation expectations and stronger economic data. Gold prices are expected to trade between US$1,855 and US$1,920 per ounce, with silver gaining 1%, while palladium fell 0.1% and platinum rose 0.5%.

site_title: Gold retreats as strong US data raises bets on Fed tapering
summary: Gold prices retreated below US$1,900 an ounce as the week closed, after reaching a five-month high earlier in the week due to strengthening economic optimism. Strong US data and a rise in bond yields, particularly after the Federal Reserve announced it would begin liquidating its corporate credit portfolio, contributed to the decline. The US Dollar Index rose to a 2.5-week high, while yields on 10-year Treasury Notes and German bunds also increased, making gold less attractive as a store of value.

site_title: Facebook suspends Trump until 2023, shifts rules for world leaders
summary: Facebook suspended former US President Donald Trump until at least January 2023, citing a severe violation of its rules following the January 6 Capitol Hill riot. The two-year suspension will be lifted if public safety risk subsides. This decision marks a shift in Facebook's policy, which now weighs violative content from politicians against the potential risk of harm, and removes the presumption that speech from politicians is inherently of public interest. The move has sparked criticism from Trump and some free-expression advocates, while others see it as a necessary step to prevent harm.

site_title: 7 new Covid-19 community cases in Singapore, lowest since May 10
summary: Singapore reported 7 new Covid-19 community cases, the lowest since May 10, with 2 unlinked cases. 5 linked cases were already in quarantine, and 6 imported cases were placed on stay-home notice. The total cases now stand at 62,158. Education Minister Chan Chun Sing announced extra checks for the Moderna vaccine to prevent errors, following a case of a 16-year-old boy receiving the wrong dose.

site_title: Two Southernpec (Singapore) entities face winding-up applications
summary: Two Southernpec (Singapore) entities, Southernpec (Singapore) and Southernpec (Singapore) Shipping, may be wound up if Goodwood Associates is successful in liquidating them for non-payment of approximately US$1.5 million for fuel oil trades. Southernpec placed a 2015 order for 3,200 metric tonnes of fuel oil. The outcome of the liquidation application could affect both companies, which operate in the ship bunkering and petrochemical sales sectors in Singapore.

site_title: Olympics could be 'show window' for Tokyo's booming real estate
summary: Tokyo's real estate sector is expected to benefit from hosting the Olympics, with an analyst predicting a "show window" effect that could fuel gains in the Reit indexes for two years. The upcoming Games, combined with Japan's increasing Covid-19 vaccination campaign, has boosted expectations for the country's real estate investment trusts. Historically, countries hosting the Olympics have seen their Reit indexes gain for two years, and analysts believe the same outcome could occur in Japan. The Tokyo Stock Exchange Reit Index has already seen significant gains in 2021, rising 18% year-to-date.

site_title: Indian airlines will lose US$8 billion due to Covid-19
summary: Indian airlines are expected to incur a loss of US$8 billion by 2022 due to the second Covid-19 wave, with IndiGo and Air India accounting for US$4.5 billion of losses. The industry needs US$5 billion to survive but has only US$1.1 billion in available funds. The country's air travel industry has been paralyzed by the spike in infections, and domestic traffic is expected to drop to 80 million passengers from 140 million in 2020. The industry is calling for government intervention, including relaxing Air India's sale terms and implementing a Plan B for the state-run carrier.

site_title: US: Wall Street ends with solid gains after tepid jobs report
summary: US stocks closed the holiday-shortened week with solid gains, despite a tepid jobs report that fell short of expectations. The US added 559,000 jobs last month, with the unemployment rate falling and average hourly wage rising more than expected. The data eased concerns about the economy forcing the Federal Reserve to pull back on stimulus, with investors instead focusing on the Fed's tapering debate. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.5%, the S&P 500 gained 0.9%, and the Nasdaq Composite jumped 1.5%.

site_title: Carpark space sells for HK$10 million in Hong Kong
summary: A luxury car park space in Hong Kong's Peak area has been sold for HK$10 million (S$1.7 million), setting a new record for the city's pricey real estate. The 135 square foot parking spot is part of a high-end apartment complex, reflecting the area's high property prices. In contrast, many residents in Hong Kong struggle to afford affordable housing, with a 2019 report stating that a skilled worker needs 22 years of income to afford a 60 sq m flat.

site_title: Higher freight costs pushing up food prices in Singapore
summary: Higher freight costs and commodity prices are driving up food prices in Singapore, with some hawker suppliers passing on the costs to customers. The price surge has been significant, with oil costs doubling in some cases. Anthony Low, chairman of the Federation of Merchants' Associations hawker division, notes that some hawkers are increasing prices by 50 cents or a dollar. The price increase is attributed to higher freight costs and commodity prices, affecting smaller food ingredient suppliers.

site_title: US: Stocks rise after mixed jobs data
summary: US stocks rose after a mixed jobs report, with 559,000 jobs added in May, below expectations, but unemployment fell and average hourly wages rose more than expected. The Dow Jones, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite Index gained 0.4%, 0.6%, and 0.9% respectively. Analysts say the report suggests the economy still has room for improvement, supporting the Federal Reserve's patient policy approach.

site_title: US job growth picks up steam in May after disappointing April
summary: US job growth accelerated in May, with payrolls increasing by 559,000, beating economists' expectations. The unemployment rate fell to 5.8%, signaling progress in filling record job openings. The labor market remains 7.6 million jobs short of pre-pandemic levels, with service providers, such as the leisure and hospitality industry, still recovering from the health crisis. The Federal Reserve is expected to hold its ultra-easy monetary policy due to temporary inflationary pressures and a strong economic momentum.

site_title: Corporate digest
