Ginsburg, a veteran banker, will become global co-head of advisory and investment banking, joining Adam Bagshaw. The move comes as HSBC continues to build out its leadership ranks in Asia, which is crucial for the bank's growth. Ginsburg has been based in Hong Kong since 1992 and has previous experience at Morgan Stanley and Barclays.

site_title: Singapore stocks back in the black; STI up 0.13%
summary: Singapore stocks ended in positive territory, with the Straits Times Index (STI) up 0.13% or 3.96 points to 3,165, following a 50.7 PMI reading for May, marking the 11th straight month of expansion. UOB economist Barnabas Gan expects the manufacturing sector to drive growth, with export-oriented industries benefiting from global trade growth. Top gainers included D01 and CDL, while transport counters declined.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's resident and citizen unemployment rates continue to decline, with improvements seen since September's peak. The latest data shows a decline in unemployment rates, indicating a positive trend in the job market.

site_title: AMC, BlackBerry shares jump as Reddit rally powers on
summary: Shares of AMC Entertainment and BlackBerry surged, with AMC rising 14.5% to $71.60 and BlackBerry jumping 29.1% after a Reddit-fueled rally. The rally, driven by amateur investors, has forced bearish investors to unwind their bets at a loss, with estimated losses of $2.75 billion for short-sellers. The rally, similar to the January GameStop surge, is seen as a flawed strategy by some, with most short-sellers holding onto losses in hopes of retail investors backing out.

site_title: ESG can drive out-performance, and is not just a feel-good factor: Credit Suisse director
summary: A Credit Suisse director, Clement Florentin, stated that incorporating environmental, social, and governance (ESG) metrics into investments can drive out-performance in a portfolio, rather than being seen as a "feel-good factor." This is due to ESG-compliant companies having access to more financing options and ESG-related products attracting large inflows, resulting in out-performance of stocks seen as ESG-compliant.

site_title: US jobless claims dip below 400,000 for first time in pandemic
summary: US jobless claims dropped below 400,000 for the first time during the pandemic, falling to 385,000 in the week ended May 29, according to Labor Department data. This decline is attributed to accelerating hiring and a strengthening economy as pandemic restrictions ease. The US added 978,000 private payroll jobs in May, the most in nearly a year. Despite being elevated compared to pre-pandemic levels, Thursday's figure is the lowest since mid-March 2020.

site_title: No change to Straits Times Index components after June review
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) has undergone no changes to its constituents after the June 2021 quarterly review. The STI reserve list, consisting of five non-constituents by market capitalisation, will remain unchanged. Stocks on the reserve list will replace any ineligible constituents due to corporate actions before the next review, scheduled for September 2021. The index is jointly calculated by FTSE Russell, Singapore Press Holdings, and the Singapore Exchange to ensure accurate representation of the investable universe for benchmarking purposes.

site_title: More than two billion Covid vaccines given worldwide
summary: More than two billion Covid-19 vaccines have been administered worldwide, surpassing the 2,109,696,022 mark, according to an AFP tally. This milestone comes six months after the first vaccination campaigns began. The top five countries for vaccination rates are Israel, Canada, the UK, Chile, and the US, with six out of 10 injections administered in China, the US, and India. Only six countries remain unvaccinated, including North Korea, Haiti, and Tanzania.

site_title: China, US aim for common ground in trade talks to resolve issues: ministry
summary: China and the US have resumed trade discussions, aiming to find common ground and pragmatically solve concrete issues for producers and consumers. The talks come after a nearly two-year trade war and mark the first formal engagement under the Biden administration. China's Vice-Premier Liu He held video calls with US Trade Representative Katherine Tai and Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen, discussing trade, economic issues, and domestic policies. The two sides agreed to work together to resolve specific issues, promoting healthy Sino-US trade and economic relations.

site_title: Tengah EC plot tender awarded to Taurus Properties for S$400.3m
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) has awarded a tender to Taurus Properties for a land parcel at Tengah Garden Walk, a 22,020.8 sq m site for a 99-year lease, with a maximum gross floor area of 61,659 sq m and estimated to accommodate 615 units. The tender, which drew seven bids, was awarded for S$400.3 million, with a project completion period of 60 months.

site_title: Netanyahu, battling for political life, attacks deal to unseat him
summary: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is fighting back against a potential deal to unseat him, after centrist politician Yair Lapid announced a coalition agreement with left-wing, centrist, and right-wing parties. Netanyahu, facing a 12-year term limit, has accused the new coalition of being "left-wing" and has targeted historic Arab participation. The coalition, led by Naftali Bennett, aims to form a government that includes Arab representation for the first time in Israeli history. A parliamentary session to approve the government is expected in about 12 days, with Netanyahu potentially using the time to try to twist arms.

site_title: Queen Elizabeth to meet Joe Biden in person after G-7
summary: Queen Elizabeth will meet US President Joe Biden in person on June 13 at Windsor Castle, west of London, after he attends a G-7 summit in Britain. The 95-year-old monarch, who has been holding virtual meetings, has received her Covid-19 vaccination and will meet First Lady Jill Biden. This will be the Queen's first in-person meeting with a head of state since the pandemic began in March 2020.

site_title: Hong Kong parking spot sells for US$1.3m, setting record
summary: A luxury parking spot at Mount Nicholson residential project in Hong Kong's Peak area has sold for a record-breaking US$1.3 million, surpassing the previous record of HK$7.6 million set in 2019. This sale marks the latest in a string of record-breaking transactions in Hong Kong's luxury home market, driven by buyers' confidence. The sale comes as Mount Nicholson, a high-end project, previously held the title for the most expensive apartment in Asia, now surpassed by a different project.

site_title: Garuda Indonesia to seek suspension of debt payments to avoid bankruptcy
summary: Garuda Indonesia, Indonesia's national flag carrier, is seeking a "standstill agreement" to suspend debt payments to creditors and lessors, aiming to avoid bankruptcy. The airline faces a negative cashflow of $100 million a month due to the coronavirus pandemic and has a ballooning debt of $4.5 billion. To continue as a going concern, the carrier needs to reduce its debt to $1-1.5 billion through a "fundamental restructuring".

site_title: 35 new Covid-19 community cases in Singapore, including 22 from MINDSville@Napiri cluster
summary: Singapore reported 45 new COVID-19 cases, bringing the total to 62,145. 35 new community cases were confirmed, with 22 linked to the MINDSville@Napiri cluster. 11 linked cases were placed on quarantine, and 10 imported cases were isolated. No new cases were reported from workers' dormitories. The Ministry of Health will provide more details on Thursday night.

site_title: Hundreds of Myanmar activists hold flash mob protest against military rule
summary: Hundreds of Myanmar activists staged a flash mob protest in Yangon against military rule, despite a heavy security presence. The protest, which drew around 400 pro-democracy supporters, lasted around five minutes before dispersing. The military, which seized power in February, has killed 842 people since the coup, according to activist figures. Demonstrators vowed to continue protests, but acknowledged the increased risk of arrest and violence. The unrest has also affected the countryside, displacing tens of thousands of people.

site_title: World's coal producers now planning more than 400 new mines: research
summary: The world's coal producers plan to build 432 new mines with 2.28 billion tonnes of annual output capacity, surpassing previous targets for slowing global climate change. China, Australia, India, and Russia account for over three-quarters of the new projects. China alone plans to increase production capacity by 452 million tonnes annually, despite its pledge to peak emissions by 2030 and reach net zero by 2060. The plans jeopardize efforts to combat global warming and risk $91 billion in stranded assets for companies.

site_title: Australia: Shares scale record high on financials boost
summary: Australian shares reached a record high, with the S&P/ASX 200 index climbing 0.6% to 7,260.1, driven by gains in financials and energy stocks. The sector rose 1% after data showed the economy returned to pre-pandemic levels, with consumers and businesses spending freely. Energy stocks, fueled by rising oil prices, added 3.3% and miners advanced for a sixth straight session. Technology stocks also saw gains, with Afterpay rising 3.3%.

site_title: Sri Lanka prepares for worst oil spill as weather hits ship salvage
summary: Sri Lanka prepares for a possible major oil leak from the MV X-Press Pearl, a cargo ship that caught fire two weeks ago, leaving 350 tonnes of fuel oil on board. The ship has already caused the island's worst maritime environmental disaster, littering beaches with plastic pellets. The Marine Environment Protection Authority has prepared oil dispersants and skimmers in case of a leak. Worsening weather has stalled salvage efforts, heightening concerns about a potential oil spill.

images.alt_text: Sri Lanka was preparing Thursday for a possible major oil leak from the burnt-out cargo ship sinking off Colombo's main harbour, as worsening weather stalled salvage efforts.

site_title: GLP C-Reit to begin trading on the Shanghai Stock Exchange in late-June 2021
summary: GLP C-Reit, a Chinese property investment firm, is set to start trading on the Shanghai Stock Exchange in late-June 2021. The Reit's portfolio comprises seven logistics assets valued at 5.3 billion yuan, with a 98.7% lease ratio. This is part of GLP's expansion into the Chinese market, following the success of its Tokyo-listed GLP J-Reit, which has a market capitalization of 703.7 billion yen. The announcement comes after GLP sold the world's largest US-dollar green subordinated perpetual offering at US$850 million last month.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end near record high on chip boost, foreign buying
summary: South Korean shares closed near a record high on Thursday, driven by chip heavyweights and strong foreign buying. The Kospi index rose 0.72% to 3,247.43, its highest since May 10, with Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix leading the gains. Foreigners bought 232.2 billion won worth of shares on the main board. The won remained flat, while the benchmark bond yield fell. Investors await US jobs data for cues on the global economy's recovery path.

site_title: Microsoft to unveil new Windows June 24, likely for fall debut
summary: Microsoft will unveil a new version of its Windows software on June 24, with CEO Satya Nadella describing it as one of the "most significant" overhauls to the operating system in a decade. The update includes design changes, opportunities for creators and developers, and improved community connections. The new software will be available to Windows Insiders and is expected to be released widely this fall.

site_title: Australia's Victoria state Covid-19 outbreak eases
summary: Australia's Victoria state reported just three new Covid-19 cases on Thursday, its lowest single-day rise in over a week, amid a seven-day hard lockdown in Melbourne. The lockdown, initially set to end on June 10, may be extended. The government announced a plan to pay up to US$387 a week to people in lockdown, but criticism mounts over the slow vaccine rollout and refusal to build quarantine centers. Victoria's daily cases have remained in the single digits for a week, with officials warning of the highly contagious variant of the virus spreading out of control.

site_title: HPL's Hilton Singapore along Orchard Road to be rebranded voco under IHG
summary: Hilton Singapore, a 423-room hotel along Orchard Road, will be rebranded as voco Orchard Singapore under IHG Hotels & Resorts. The hotel is set to open in January 2022. This marks IHG's 12th hotel in Singapore and its seventh brand in the country. The voco brand, launched in 2018, aims to have 200 hotels globally within 10 years, with existing properties in Australia, China, and other countries. The voco Orchard Singapore will be the first in South-east Asia.

site_title: Europe: Stocks slip ahead of data deluge
summary: European stocks slipped 0.1% on Thursday ahead of data releases on US jobs and euro zone services sector activity. Investors are cautious about an early tightening of monetary policy, with the US jobs data set to provide fresh clues on the pace of recovery. Swiss drugmaker Roche fell 1% after a downgrade, while French spirits group Remy Cointreau rose 3.9% after beating earnings expectations.

site_title: UK, Australia hold further talks in bid to strike trade deal within weeks
summary: Britain and Australia held talks to progress a free trade deal, aiming to strike an agreement in mid-June. The deal, which could add £500 million to British economic output, is part of the UK's post-Brexit strategy to strengthen ties in the Indo-Pacific region. Despite some sticking points remaining, British Trade Minister Liz Truss and her Australian counterpart Dan Tehan held talks, with a bilateral agreement between Prime Ministers Johnson and Morrison expected on June 15. This deal is the most advanced of several pursued by London.

site_title: Taiwan says too early to talk of lockdown, but 'no optimism' over Covid-19 trends
summary: Taiwan's health minister, Chen Shih-chung, expressed concern over the rising Covid-19 infections, with 583 domestic cases reported, including 219 added to recent totals due to delays in reporting. The government has limited gatherings and closed entertainment venues, but has not raised the alert level to the highest level, citing it's "too early." The government is also dealing with vaccine delivery issues, having vaccinated only 3% of Taiwan's 23.5 million people, and is advising people not to travel for non-urgent reasons. There is no cause for optimism over the trend in infections.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed 1.13% lower on Thursday, with the Hang Seng Index falling to 28,966.03, amid investor caution ahead of US jobs data. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined, easing 0.36% and 0.34% respectively. The decline follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a strong performance in the US market, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reached fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: South-east Asia headed for equities, earnings recovery, but economic growth is patchy
summary: Southeast Asian equity markets are expected to experience a "broad earnings recovery" in 2021, with regional corporate earnings projected to recover 30-50% year-on-year. Analysts predict significant upsides for markets like Indonesia, the Philippines, and Vietnam, driven by tax cuts, supply chain shifts, and tech companies. However, some markets, such as Malaysia and Thailand, are expected to underperform due to challenges like political uncertainties and pandemic-related border closures. The recovery will be uneven, with services sectors dragging down growth until border controls are relaxed.

site_title: Cashless payments catching on in South-east Asia: Visa survey
summary: Visa's latest study reveals cashless payments are gaining ground in South-east Asia, accelerating by 3-5 years due to the pandemic. In markets like Malaysia, Singapore, and Thailand, 46% of consumers use card payments, and 63% use contactless payments. The shift towards digital payments is attributed to the pandemic's disruption of traditional consumer habits.

site_title: Global home prices rise most since 2006, fuelling bubble concerns
summary: Global home prices rose 7.3% in the 12 months to March, the fastest pace since 2006, according to Knight Frank's Global House Price Index report. Turkey topped the list with a 32% growth, while the US saw a 13.2% increase. The surge is attributed to massive fiscal and monetary stimulus during the pandemic, fuelling concerns of bubbles. Several countries, including New Zealand and China, have taken action to cool the market, with some expecting home price inflation to slow in the coming year.

site_title: Pacquiao emerges as obstacle to Duterte's succession plans
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte's succession plans are complicated by the emergence of boxer-turned-politician Manny Pacquiao as a potential obstacle. Pacquiao, a loyal ally to Duterte since 2016, has rankled loyalists by urging party members to ignore a rival meeting that called for Duterte to pick a presidential candidate. This move complicates Pacquiao's own presidential ambitions and may lead to a split in the vote between his and Duterte's camps. Pacquiao faces stiff competition from other candidates, including Duterte's daughter Sara and Senator Christopher "Bong" Go, in the 2022 elections.

site_title: Hiap Seng to sell entire 80% stake in UAE subsidiary for 2.7m dirham
summary: Hiap Seng Engg agreed to sell its 80% stake in UAE subsidiary Hiap Seng Engineering FCZ (HS FCZ) for 2.7 million dirham (S$1 million) to an existing 20% shareholder. The sale is expected to be completed by Sept 14 this year and will be used for working capital and covering professional fees. The group considers HS FCZ a loss-making non-core asset, and selling it will improve its financial position.

site_title: Apple co-founder Steve Wozniak can't sue YouTube over Bitcoin scam
summary: Apple co-founder Steve Wozniak lost his lawsuit against YouTube over videos promoting a bogus bitcoin scam. A California state judge ruled that YouTube is protected by Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act, which shields internet platforms from responsibility for user-posted content. The judge found that YouTube's actions, including selling targeted ads, did not overcome the immunity provided by the law. Wozniak had argued that YouTube "materially contributed" to the scam, but the judge rejected this claim. Wozniak has 30 days to revise his complaint.

site_title: Global chip shortage extends to more sectors, to last till 2022: Bain & Company
summary: The global chip shortage, expected to last until 2022, has extended to the tech industry, with consumer electronics such as PCs, smartphones, and others being impacted. The shortage, caused by a surge in demand during the pandemic and complex supply chain issues, has affected various industries beyond the automotive sector. To address the issue, industry players are focusing on adding capacity, with major companies such as Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co and Intel investing heavily in new manufacturing facilities. However, this process is expected to take months to years, and structural changes to supply chains are recommended to mitigate future shortages.

site_title: A see-through pool opens 10 storeys above London
summary: A see-through pool, 82 feet long and 10 storeys above London, has opened in the Embassy Gardens residential complex. The 61-tonne pool, made of transparent polymer, took four years to construct and was shipped from Colorado after three weeks. It offers residents and their guests exclusive access, but lower-income residents do not have access due to a lack of payment. The pool's use is seen as a unique amenity, but its exclusivity has raised criticism about the allocation of units and amenities in the development.

site_title: Sinostar PEC appoints ex-MP John Chen as lead independent director
summary: Sinostar PEC Holdings announced the appointment of former member of Parliament John Chen as lead independent director and non-executive independent director. Chen, 67, served in Parliament from 1988 to 2006 and held various ministerial positions. His appointment aims to bring expertise and independence to the company's board.

site_title: Hot stock: CFM rises 43.9% amid heavy trading after proposed acquisition
summary: CFM Holdings' shares rose 43.9% on June 3, amid heavy trading, following a proposed acquisition of 51% of SING-SWE MM Biotechnology for up to S$6.1 million. The acquisition aims to provide CFM with additional and recurrent revenue streams through the distribution of pharmaceutical products and viral test kits. The shares initially surged to 9.5 cents before easing to 9.3 cents, with a final close at 11.9 cents.

site_title: Malaysia gets Deloitte's US$80m 1MDB settlement payout
summary: Malaysia has received US$80 million from Deloitte in a settlement over the firm's audit of 1MDB and its former unit SRC International between 2011-2014. The government also expects to receive RM2.83 billion from local lender AMMB Holdings. The recovered funds will be used to repay 1MDB's debts, with the current balance sufficient to service debt obligations for 2021 and 2022. The settlements are part of Malaysia's efforts to recover billions of dollars allegedly siphoned from 1MDB by people connected to the country's former prime minister.

site_title: Singapore IoT service provider opens Tokyo office in regional expansion
summary: Singapore-based IoT service provider UnaBiz has opened its Tokyo office to support its growing strategic alliance and explore new collaborations. Pascal Gerbert-Gaillard, the new managing director, brings experience in retail, food, energy, and technology to the company. UnaBiz aims to increase global competitiveness and accelerate IoT infrastructure growth through its connection with Japan's vibrant innovation ecosystem. The move follows the company's Series A funding round led by KDDI in 2018 and its participation in the "Invest Tokyo" program.

site_title: VC firm Good Startup hits US$25m first close of alternative protein fund
summary: Good Startup, a Singapore-based venture capital firm focused on alternative protein, has raised US$25 million in its first close of the Good Protein Fund I. The fund will back 32 companies globally, with 80% allocated to early-stage investments. The fund's total size remains undisclosed, but it will support companies in intellectual property protection, scaling, hiring, and fundraising. This marks the firm's sixth investment in startups such as Eat Just and Avant Meats, with a focus on reducing environmental impact in the global food ecosystem.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares end higher as train operators, beer makers jump on vaccine hopes
summary: Japanese shares closed higher on Thursday, with the Topix index reaching a six-week high, as the country's vaccination drive gains momentum. The Nikkei share average rose 0.39% to 29,058.11, while the broader Topix gained 0.84% to 1,958.70. Analysts attribute the boost to vaccination hopes, saying they are moving faster than expected and boosting hopes of reopenings.

site_title: Gold edges lower as dollar firms; focus on US economic data
summary: Gold prices fell 0.2% to $1,904.36 per ounce, as a stronger US dollar offset lower Treasury yields. Investors await US economic data, including jobless claims and payroll numbers, to gauge monetary policy. The US 10-year Treasury yield dropped below 1.6%, reducing the opportunity cost of holding non-interest bearing gold, but the dollar index edged higher, making gold less appealing. The US economic recovery accelerated despite supply chain troubles and rising prices, with Fed officials expecting price pressures to be transitory.

site_title: BlackRock CEO Larry Fink sees potential for 'big shock' from inflation
summary: BlackRock CEO Larry Fink warned that investors may underestimate the potential for a spike in inflation, citing his 40-plus years of experience. Fink believes that central banks may reassess their policies if higher prices become a concern, which could conflict with the US government's fiscal stimulus plans. He also noted that climate change adaptation efforts could lead to higher inflation, as companies invest in green technologies without yet having the necessary technology. Fink's comments come as concern about inflation has already begun to seep into US markets, with rising costs of goods such as lumber and steel.

site_title: Olympics chief says cancellation unlikely as 10,000 volunteers quit
summary: Tokyo Olympics chief Seiko Hashimoto stated that the Games would only be cancelled in extreme circumstances, with 10,000 volunteers quitting due to coronavirus fears, scheduling problems, and sexism concerns. The event has been scaled back, and overseas fans are barred, with domestic spectators' attendance expected to be decided after a state of emergency ends on June 20. Despite low public support, Hashimoto believes public opinion may be turning in favour of the Games, and the first Olympic athletes, Australia's softball team, have arrived in Japan.

site_title: Credit Suisse's RenTech fund holds back some client cash
summary: Credit Suisse has temporarily barred clients from withdrawing all their cash from a fund that invests in Renaissance Technologies, citing poor performance. The CS Renaissance Alternative Access Fund's assets under management have slumped to $250 million, down from $700 million in 2020. The fund, which invests in the Renaissance Institutional Diversified Alpha Fund International, has lost 32% last year, triggering a hold back clause that will delay 5% of client funds until January. This is the first time the hold back mechanism has been invoked.

site_title: Facebook pitches new tools for businesses at developer event
summary: Facebook has introduced new tools for businesses to power digital commerce, including programming updates for WhatsApp and Instagram. The company aims to help businesses lure new customers and keep existing ones using the messaging and photo-sharing apps. Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg said the new tools will create value for everyone, whether it's social experiences or new ways for businesses to stay afloat. The changes include access to Instagram's application programming interface and automated messaging tools for businesses, with 175 million people messaging a business on WhatsApp every day.

site_title: Global big banks plot back-to-office plans as vaccines roll out
summary: Global big banks are planning to reopen their offices as vaccination rates rise, with most adopting hybrid working models. Key banks, including Wells Fargo, Goldman Sachs, and JPMorgan, plan to bring employees back to the office on a rotational basis or with 50% occupancy caps. Others, such as Citigroup and Barclays, will maintain a hybrid model with reduced office space. The return-to-office plans vary by region, with some banks, like HSBC, cutting 40% of their global office footprint.

site_title: Australia: Shares hit record high on economic growth cheer
summary: Australian shares hit a record high, climbing 0.6% to 7,261.00, driven by strong economic growth data and high commodity prices. The energy index rose 2% and gold stocks advanced 0.8% as oil prices reached a 1-year high. Financial stocks and miners also gained, with the "big four" banks rising between 0.7% and 1%. The ASX 200 index surpassed its previous record high set in April.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise at Thursday's open; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.3% to 3,171.96, driven by gains from CFM Holdings, ThaiBev, and local banks. The STI has now notched a 5-day rally ahead of key US jobs data. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 also advanced, while European stocks remained near record levels.

site_title: Biden says 'looking' at Russia retaliation over cyberattack
summary: US President Joe Biden stated he is "looking" at possible retaliation against Russia following a cyberattack on global meat processing giant JBS. The attack, attributed to the REvil and Sodinokibi hacking group with ties to Russia, prompted accusations that Russia is harbouring cybercriminals. Biden will discuss US concerns, including the issue, with President Vladimir Putin during their summit in Geneva later this month. The White House expects the topic to be a point of discussion throughout the trip, with Biden saying "responsible states do not harbour" cybercriminals.

site_title: CFM to acquire 51% stake in firm distributing and selling pharma products
summary: CFM Holdings has agreed to acquire 51% of SING-SWE MM Biotechnology for up to S$6.1 million. The company, which distributes and sells pharmaceutical products, will become a subsidiary of CFM upon completion. SING-SWE MM Biotechnology's share capital will be reduced to S$100, with NEIS retaining 49%. The acquisition is part of CFM's expansion into the healthcare sector.

site_title: Jack Ma's Ant builds government relations team for Asia push
summary: Ant Group, a fintech giant led by Jack Ma, is building a team to strengthen its government relations in Asian markets, including South-east Asia, Hong Kong, and Macau, as it seeks to expand its international business. The team, led by senior vice-president Chen Leiming, aims to promote transparency and mutual understanding with regulators. Ant's international push comes as the company faces increased scrutiny and slowing growth at home, and it aims to revitalize its stalled initial public offering.

site_title: Avengers ready to welcome Marvel fans at new Disneyland campus
summary: Disneyland Resort's new Avengers Campus in Anaheim, California, is set to welcome the public on Friday. The 2.43-hectare campus features Spider-Man attractions, including an aerial robot and a ride called Web Slingers. Physical sets and virtual environments blend to create an immersive experience. Fan favorites from Marvel movies, such as Black Widow and Captain America, will roam the area and interact with guests. The campus, initially set to open in July 2020, was delayed due to the pandemic and is currently accepting guests only from California until June 15.

site_title: Singapore unemployment situation keeps improving in April for citizens, residents
summary: Singapore's unemployment rates for residents and citizens continued to decrease in April, with resident unemployment falling to 3.9% and citizen unemployment at 4.1%. The overall unemployment rate remained unchanged at 2.9%. A total of 92,100 residents were unemployed, down from 95,500 in March. Manpower Minister Tan See Leng expressed gratitude for collective efforts to boost job matches but noted that unemployment rates remain elevated, particularly in sectors affected by the recent tightening of measures.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares rise in opening trade on Thursday
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.23% on Thursday, driven by a positive Wall Street lead, ahead of key US data reports. The Hang Seng Index reached 29,365.32, while the benchmark Shanghai Composite Index dipped 0.05%. The rally follows a 5-day streak of gains in Singapore stocks and comes as investors remain optimistic despite US tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: Australians splash out big on autos, keep economy ticking
summary: Australian auto sales reached a record high in May, with 100,809 new vehicles sold, a 68% increase from last year. This surge in spending suggests the economy maintained momentum despite a Covid-19 lockdown in Victoria. Strong employment, rising employment, and record-low interest rates are supporting consumption. Household wealth is boosted by surging home prices, with national home prices climbing 9% in the three months to May. The data indicates a resilient economy, with consumers continuing to spend despite concerns about Covid-19.

site_title: Singapore's iGlobe starts US$100m fund for fintech, biotech
summary: Singapore's IGlobe Partners has launched a US$100 million fund to invest in fintech, biotech, and smart city technologies. The fourth fund, IGlobe Platinum Fund III, will back 15-20 startups across the US, Europe, and Southeast Asia over the next three years. The firm, led by founder Koh Soo Boon, focuses on cross-border deep tech investments and has a history of delivering strong returns, including a 33% net internal rate of return. The fund will support startups in emerging trends such as synthetic biology, cancer diagnostics, and digital banking.

site_title: Tesla steps up senior recruitment in India amid push into nation
summary: Tesla is recruiting for senior leadership roles in India, including a head of sales and marketing and a head of human resources, as it prepares to enter the country's large emerging car market. The company has also hired a senior legal counsel. This move comes after Tesla's formal India entry marked with a launch event in Mumbai in July 2025. The recruitment drive is part of Tesla's efforts to expand its presence in the Indian market, which is expected to be a key growth area for the electric vehicle manufacturer.

site_title: HDB resale prices climb for 11th straight month in May: SRX
summary: HDB resale prices rose 1.2% in May 2021, marking the 11th consecutive month of upward trajectory, according to SRX Property. Year-on-year, prices grew 12%, with matured estates seeing a 11.6% increase and non-mature estates a 12.4% hike. Transaction volumes decreased 16% from April but increased 440.1% year-over-year, with the majority of sales coming from four-room flats. The highest transacted price was a five-room unit at S$1.2 million, and 13 flats were sold for at least S$1 million, surpassing the 2020 total of 82 million-dollar flats.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's stock market opened flat on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.20 points, or 0.01%, to 1,597.74. Volume was 521.23 million lots worth RM228.44 million. Gainers beat losers 297 to 130.

site_title: Sembcorp prices S$400m green bonds due 2031 at 2.45%
summary: Sembcorp Industries priced its S$400 million green bond offering at a 2.45% coupon rate, due 2031, with 90% of the bonds sold to institutional investors in the Asia-Pacific region. The bonds are expected to be listed on the Singapore Exchange and will be used to finance or refinance eligible green projects. This marks the first certified green bond under the Climate Bonds Standard by a Singapore-based energy company, with proceeds to be used in a low-carbon economy.

site_title: Biden to amend Trump's China blacklist, target key industries: sources
summary: US President Joe Biden plans to amend a ban on investments in companies linked to China's military, targeting key industries such as defense and surveillance technology. The revised policy will create a list of companies that could face financial penalties, shifting responsibility from the Defense Department to the Treasury Department. The change aims to clarify the criteria for blacklisting entities and keep a large number of previously listed entities, while adding new ones. The move comes after two Chinese companies successfully challenged the Trump-era policy in court.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Thursday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.12% higher on Thursday, driven by subdued trade on Wall Street, ahead of key US jobs data this week. The Nikkei 225 index rose 33.43 points to 28,979.57, while the Topix index increased 7.08 points to 1,949.41. Investors await the US jobs data, with traders brushing off new Trump threats to extend the stocks rally.

site_title: Tesla engineer says Musk overstated the capability of Autopilot
summary: A Tesla engineer, CJ Moore, stated that CEO Elon Musk overestimated the capabilities of Autopilot, the company's driver-assistance system, in a March memo to California DMV officials. Musk had claimed Teslas could achieve full autonomy by the end of the year, but the engineer described this as "not engineering reality." The California DMV concluded that Tesla's Autopilot is currently at Level 2, not Level 5, as Musk claimed, and the company needs to provide clearer communication about its features and limitations.

site_title: China makes desalination push to ease water scarcity
summary: China plans to invest in new desalination plants over 2021-2025, aiming to boost water supplies and raise capacity to 2.9 million tonnes a day. The country will commission 1.25 million tonnes of new capacity, mainly in coastal cities and island regions. This move aims to alleviate water scarcity, particularly in the north, where underground water tables are at risk due to excessive extraction. Desalinated water will become a major back-up source of municipal supplies in water-scarce regions.

site_title: UMS' offer for JEP closes with 71.66% valid acceptances
summary: UMS Holdings' mandatory unconditional cash offer for Catalist-listed JEP Holdings closed with 71.66% valid acceptances, exceeding the required threshold. The offer price of S$0.20 per share valued JEP at S$82.4 million. UMS aims to diversify its business and broaden earnings streams, with plans to preserve JEP's listing status and assess further options if the public float falls below 10%. The deal is seen as a strategic move to expand UMS' presence in new markets.

site_title: Japan PM Suga seen calling snap election after Tokyo Games: Asahi
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga is likely to call a snap election after the Tokyo Olympic and Paralympic Games, despite the country's ongoing Covid-19 pandemic. The government plans to use nearly 4 trillion yen in reserves to pay for immediate spending to combat the pandemic. Suga has stated his resolve to proceed with the Games under strict virus-protection measures, despite low public support and declining support ratings. A snap election is expected after the Games' conclusion on September 5.

site_title: Japan's service sector shrinks for 16th month as health crisis hits demand: PMI
summary: Japan's services sector contracted for the 16th consecutive month in May due to coronavirus emergency curbs and stricter restrictions in key Asian markets. The au Jibun Bank Japan Services Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) fell to 46.5, below the 50.0 threshold, as demand declined. The sector's contraction dragged overall private-sector activity into contraction, hindering the country's economic recovery. The survey also showed faster contractions in outstanding and new export business, highlighting strain from lacklustre demand. Businesses remain optimistic about the year ahead, but to their lowest in four months.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sembcorp Industries, UMS, Mapletree Industrial Trust, CFM, Sabana Reit
summary: Sembcorp Industries priced its S$400 million green bond offering, with 90% of bonds placed to institutional investors. UMS's offer for Catalist-listed JEP closed with 71.66% valid acceptances, while Mapletree Industrial Trust and CFM announced new developments, including the issuance of new units and a sale and purchase agreement. Sabana Reit appointed a new independent non-executive director, Chan Wai Kheong.

site_title: AMC now worth more than half the companies in the S&P 500
summary: AMC Entertainment has surged in value, becoming more valuable than half of the companies in the S&P 500 Index with a market capitalization of $31.3 billion. The company's shares have risen 95% amid a retail-trading frenzy, surpassing companies like Tyson Foods and Delta Air Lines despite lower projected revenues. AMC's market value has increased from under $500 million in the midst of the COVID-19 crisis. The company has raised $230 million in new funding and plans to reward retail investors with special screenings and free popcorn.

site_title: Apple touts App Store economy as its clout challenged
summary: Apple reported a 24% surge in App Store billings and sales in 2020 to $643 billion, fueled by pandemic-driven demand for digital goods and services. The growth was driven by independent developers, with 90% of total billings occurring outside the App Store. This comes as Apple faces a US District Court trial with Epic Games, seeking to break the company's grip on the App Store and potentially disrupt the mobile ecosystem. Apple CEO Tim Cook highlighted the App Store's role in creating jobs, innovation, and economic opportunities.

site_title: Oil hits over one-year high on Opec+ supply discipline, demand prospects
summary: Oil prices surged on Wednesday, reaching their highest in over a year, due to Opec's decision to stick to supply restoration plans and slow nuclear talks between Iran and the US. Brent crude rose 1.6% to $71.35 a barrel, its highest since January 2020, while US WTI crude rose 1.6% to $68.83 a barrel, its highest since October 2018. The price increase is attributed to concerns over global demand prospects.

site_title: Citi hires new head of family office advisory in Singapore
summary: Citi has appointed Faye Ong, a former head of wealth planning for South Asia at Union Bancaire Privee (UBP), as the new head of family office advisory in Singapore. Ong, who has 16 years of experience in private banking, will oversee the bank's family office advisory unit in Singapore. The move comes as Citi gears up to capture more wealth flows in the region, with over 400 single family offices set up in recent years. Citi aims to triple its assets under management in Singapore by 2025.

site_title: Europe: Shares hold near record highs as energy, consumer stocks bounce
summary: European stocks held near record highs on Wednesday, driven by gains in energy and consumer stocks. The Stoxx 600 index rose 0.3%, staying below its all-time high. Strong US and European factory data lifted world shares to fresh highs, awaiting US jobs data for confirmation of a solid recovery.

site_title: US supply bottlenecks, labour shortage hitting production: Federal Reserve
summary: The US economy continues to recover from the pandemic, with American businesses remaining optimistic despite supply disruptions and labour shortages. The Federal Reserve's "beige book" survey found significant supply chain challenges disrupting production, while hiring increased in most regions but failed to fill open positions, leading to reduced output in some cases. The report may intensify concerns about the Fed's response to rising prices, which are expected to be temporary but may prompt policy adjustments.

site_title: China's concrete jungles make room for green space
summary: China is transforming its cities by building urban parks, aiming to improve daily life for its citizens. Since 2001, the country has nearly quintupled public green space in cities, with Suzhou, Kaifeng, and Shanghai leading the way. The nationwide programme, approved in 2021, calls for 1,000 large parks to promote physical fitness and addresses the growing issue of obesity. While construction costs are high, with an estimated US$15 billion per year, officials can quickly seize and bulldoze homes to clear land, offering compensation to residents.

site_title: Lonza plans new production line for Moderna Covid vaccine ingredients
summary: Lonza, a Swiss contract drug manufacturer, is building a new production line in the Netherlands to produce ingredients for Moderna's Covid-19 vaccine. The new line will have a capacity to make ingredients for up to 300 million doses annually at 50 micrograms per dose, half the current 100 mcg dose. This move aims to significantly increase vaccine output, with Moderna targeting 3 billion doses in 2022. The lower dose vaccine could be used as booster shots or for children requiring a reduced dose.

site_title: US global vaccine distribution plan could be announced on Thursday: Blinken
summary: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken announced that President Joe Biden may reveal a plan to distribute 80 million coronavirus vaccines globally as early as Thursday. The plan aims to push out vaccines worldwide.

site_title: Raising land supply may aggravate housing issues
summary: Singapore's housing market may face increased pressure due to a potential surge in land supply, which could lead to higher construction costs and prices. The government has proposed adjusting the buyer's stamp duty (ABSD) remission deadline for government land sales (GLS) sites and allowing changes of use for hospitality properties to ease the labor shortage. However, releasing more GLS sites could further heat up competition for labor and materials, adding to upward pressure on housing prices. The construction sector is already facing a labor shortage, with the number of foreign workers declining due to border restrictions and competition for workers.

site_title: Britain hosts G-7 health summit amid pressure to broaden Covid-19 vaccine access
summary: Britain is hosting a G-7 health summit in Oxford, focusing on broadening Covid-19 vaccine access worldwide. British Foreign Minister Dominic Raab stated equitable access will be the top agenda item. Charities are pushing for Britain to support a temporary waiver on intellectual property rights for pharmaceutical firms to increase vaccine distribution. The summit comes as the world struggles to distribute vaccines to those in need, with the UK facing criticism for not doing enough to support global access.

site_title: Putin to host flagship investor forum in Russia despite Covid-19 risk, political strife
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin is set to host the St Petersburg International Economic Forum, despite ongoing Covid-19 risks and western sanctions. The forum, which opens on Thursday, aims to demonstrate Russia's economy is back to business as usual. The event comes as the country faces economic challenges and increasing tensions with the West. Putin's hosting of the forum is seen as an attempt to showcase Russia's resilience and attract investors.

site_title: UK's Sunak says US plan to break global tax deadlock could work
summary: British finance minister Rishi Sunak said a US proposal to focus on the world's 100 biggest and most profitable firms as part of a global tax deal could work, with big tech firms expected to pay more tax in countries where they operate. The Group of Seven is making progress on the reform, with finance ministers set to meet in London for talks on Friday and Saturday, marking the first face-to-face encounter since the Covid-19 pandemic. This meeting raises hopes for increased cooperation between the US and other rich economies under the new US administration.

site_title: Diana's iconic wedding dress is star of royal fashion exhibit
summary: Princess Diana's iconic 1981 wedding dress, designed by David and Elizabeth Emanuel, is on display at the Royal Style in the Making exhibition at Kensington Palace. The ivory silk gown, with a 7.6m long train, was one of the best-kept secrets in fashion history, with the designers using tactics to keep it hidden from prying eyes. The exhibition, which runs until January 2, also showcases Diana's growing sense of personal style, her relationship with designers, and her influence on British fashion. Her sons, Prince William and Prince Harry, have loaned the dresses to the exhibition.

site_title: Prosecutors seek 30-year sentence in George Floyd murder case
summary: Prosecutors in the US seek a 30-year sentence for Derek Chauvin, the former police officer convicted of murdering George Floyd. Chauvin's attorneys argue for a sentence of time served and probation, claiming he was guilty of an "error made in good faith." Prosecutors describe Chauvin's actions as an "egregious abuse" of his position, sparking nationwide protests last year. The sentencing hearing is set for June 25.

images.alt_text: Attorneys for the Minneapolis officer, Derek Chauvin, countered with a far different request - a sentence of time served and probation, claiming that their client was guilty of "an error made in good faith."

site_title: Aramco said to plan bond sale to help fund US$75b dividend
summary: Saudi Aramco is planning to issue Islamic debt, or sukuk, to help fund a US$75 billion dividend commitment. The state-controlled energy company has selected around 15 banks to manage the sale, which could happen this month. The company may seek to raise around US$5 billion from the bond sale, which would be one of the largest sukuk issuances globally.

site_title: A 50-year bond from Sweden's government is about to test inflation anxiety
summary: Sweden is set to issue its longest-ever bond, a 50-year government bond worth 10 billion kronor (S$1.6 billion), in a sale aimed at gauging investor appetite for inflation and higher interest rates. The bond, which will have a fixed rate of 1.5%, is part of a broader trend of ultra-long bonds being issued globally. However, some experts, such as Alexander Onica, question the viability of the 50-year bond in the current low-yielding environment, citing concerns about the potential for European interest rates to drift higher in the coming months.

site_title: Covid vaccines and the US national interest
summary: The US national interest in exporting Covid-19 vaccines to poor countries is driven by four key reasons. Firstly, it protects Americans' medical interest by preventing the spread of mutated variants that could evade US vaccines. Secondly, it upholds US values by showing empathy and solidarity with suffering populations worldwide. Thirdly, it enhances US soft power by demonstrating a commitment to global health and cooperation. Finally, it counters China's growing soft power and influence in the global health arena, particularly in regions where the pandemic originated.

site_title: US: Stocks edge up as AMC soars
summary: US stocks finished marginally higher on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 0.1% at 34,600.38. Oil-linked equities continued to rally, driven by US oil prices at their highest level since October 2018. AMC Entertainment surged 95.2% after a buying spree by retail investors, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also advanced 0.1%. Investors weigh positive news on the reopening economy against lingering worries over inflation.

site_title: Big oil's green-spending boost isn't enough, IEA says
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) expects the oil and gas industry to boost investments in clean energy to at least 4% of capital spending this year, but still falls short of the goal to limit global temperature increases. The IEA expects 70% of new power generation capacity to come from renewable sources, but only 45% of global investment in the sector will go towards clean energy. To maintain the possibility of limiting warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius, investments in clean energy need to more than triple this decade.

site_title: Taper tantrum haven may be found in emerging markets
summary: Bank of America's London-based strategist Andrew MacFarlane predicts a potential surge in US Treasury 10-year yields to 2.15% by the end of the year, potentially fueling a jump in yields for euro-denominated bonds. However, emerging-market euro-denominated bonds may offer investors a refuge, as they outperformed dollar peers during the 2013 "taper tantrum". Emerging-market sovereign dollar bonds have returned 2.3% this quarter, compared to 0.2% for euro-denominated debt, making them a relative haven from a potential US rate hike.

site_title: Activist fund poised to take three seats on ExxonMobil board
summary: Activist investor Engine No. 1 is poised to fill three seats on ExxonMobil's board after a shareholder vote, with nominees Alexander Karsner, Gregory Goff, and Kaisa Hietala set to join the board. The outcome, which must be certified, marks a victory for Engine No. 1, which has pushed ExxonMobil to address climate change. ExxonMobil defended its policies, but the company's CEO, Darren Woods, welcomed the new directors, who will work to position the company for a lower-carbon future. The vote reflects the growing mainstream recognition of climate change as an investor issue.

site_title: Insurance industry to reduce par policies' illustrative rates of return
summary: The Life Insurance Association (LIA) in Singapore has reduced the illustrative rates of return for participating (or "par") policies from 4.75% to 4.25% and from 3.25% to 3% to reflect persistently low interest rates. The changes take effect on July 1 and do not impact actual par policies' returns, but may prompt insurers to reprice or redesign their product offerings. Despite strong recent performance, insurers still face challenges due to low yields and a mismatch between assets and liabilities.

site_title: Vietnam's election was freer, more transparent than portrayal
summary: Vietnam's recently concluded election to the National Assembly saw 92% of candidates affiliated with the Communist Party of Vietnam (CPV), down from 97% in the previous election. The CPV's efforts to tighten control over national politics appear to be a response to criticism from non-party assemblymen and women. The election process has been described as "flawed" by foreign media, but scholars argue that it is more open and active than in other communist countries. The CPV's move to silence criticism is reminiscent of China's Hundred Flowers Campaign, where criticism was briefly allowed to flourish before being suppressed.

site_title: Creative capital
summary: A group of designers have successfully transitioned into new disciplines, leveraging their creative skills. Gabriel Tan, a product designer, now designs interiors for restaurants like Bella Pasta and Burger King. Cherin Tan, a principal in an interior architecture firm, started an upcycled furniture collection. These individuals, along with four others, are featured in a BTLifestyle article. Meanwhile, British stage actress Helen McCrory's death at 52 has been mourned by theatre lovers, and articles on home dining, zero-waste living, and corporate purpose are also covered.

site_title: Engaging children with arts and crafts
summary: Charity arts organisation TRCL has partnered with the Zhenghua community to launch the #Engage 3.0 programme, providing arts activities to over 250 under-served children. The initiative, which runs until June 24, includes surprise packs with craft materials and "nutritious meals" for the children. The programme aims to keep children occupied during the holidays and inspire confidence through creative activities. The #Engage 3.0 initiative is the third instalment of TRCL's #Engage series, which has previously engaged over 1,000 school children in arts and culture activities.

site_title: Biden's US$6t budget: Start of an economic boom or inflationary ruin?
summary: US President Joe Biden's proposed $6 trillion budget aims to boost economic growth through increased government spending on education, infrastructure, and healthcare. However, critics argue that this could ignite inflation and hinder the economic recovery. The administration expects a 2% annual growth rate and full employment, with inflation around 2.3%, but economists warn that massive government spending could cause inflation and trigger a recession. The budget's impact on inflation and the economy remains uncertain, with the Biden administration and critics debating the potential consequences of the proposed spending plan.

site_title: Serba Dinamik shareholder PNB has 'deep concern' after audit issues raised
summary: Malaysia's largest fund manager, Permodalan Nasional Bhd (PNB), expressed deep concern over developments at Serba Dinamik Holdings Bhd, which is under investigation by the country's securities regulator. The concern follows revelations that Serba's auditor, KPMG, was unable to verify RM3.5 billion worth of contracts with 11 customers. Serba rejected these concerns and plans to appoint an independent firm to review the issues. Shares of Serba Dinamik have lost 46% of their value this week, trading up 3.6% on Wednesday.

site_title: Investors criticise Australia's proposed proxy adviser rules
summary: International and local investors have criticized Australia's proposed rules targeting proxy advisory firms, which issue voting recommendations to investors. The proposed rules, introduced by the centre-right government, aim to reduce uninformed voting and make it harder for investors to be heard. Critics argue the rules will lead to uninformed voting and stifle investor voices, sparking concerns about the impact on the market and corporate governance. The proposals have not yet been finalized, but investors have already expressed strong opposition to the plan.

site_title: Volvo owners to get bumper payout from UD Trucks sale
summary: Volvo Group shareholders are set to receive a 19 billion Swedish kronor ($3 billion) payout from the sale of a Japanese business unit to Isuzu Motors. The company plans to distribute the entire amount to investors, resulting in a 3.6% share price increase. The sale was completed earlier this year, with Volvo receiving the funds from the transaction.

site_title: US: Stocks rise as investors eye bond yields
summary: US stocks rose modestly early Wednesday as investors weighed economic recovery against inflation concerns. The 10-year Treasury yield pulled back after rising on Tuesday, alleviating worries over inflation. Analysts, including IHS Markit, believe a potential inflation spike will be temporary due to increased supply. The Dow Jones, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite indexes all gained, with the Dow up 0.2%, the S&P 500 up 0.2%, and the Nasdaq up 0.3%.

site_title: Why China's hated tech titan decided to play nice
summary: China's tech giant Tencent has managed to rebrand itself as a benevolent industry leader, despite being accused of being a brazen copycat and limiting competition. The company has invested heavily in smaller businesses, including Meituan, and has a significant stake in many companies, including Tesla and Snap. However, critics argue that Tencent's cozy relationships with industry players may harm innovation and efficiency, and that the company still wields significant influence in China. Despite being the subject of antitrust scrutiny, Tencent remains one of the country's most powerful technology companies.

site_title: Genting Singapore rises 1.2% on heavy trading, after firm qualifies for Yokohama IR RFP
summary: Genting Singapore shares rose 1.2% on heavy trading after the company qualified for Yokohama's integrated resort RFP. The stock reached a high of 88 cents before closing at 86.5 cents. Maybank Kim Eng upgraded its call on the stock from "hold" to "buy" and raised its target price to S$1.16 from S$0.86. The move follows the company's selection as one of the two qualifying parties for the Yokohama IR RFP.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Singapore Reinsurance has extended its closing date for Fairfax Asia's cash offer to June 17, with the offer unchanged. As of June 1, Fairfax Asia had acquired 92.09% of shares, exceeding the 50% threshold. Acceptances of an additional 9.17 million shares would allow Fairfax Asia to exercise its compulsory acquisition right. Meanwhile, Sabana Reit appointed Chan Wai Kheong as an independent non-executive director, with roles in audit, risk, and remuneration committees.

site_title: Wages of workers in unpopular jobs could stay up for good, observers say
summary: Singapore's labor market shows signs of recovery as wages in unpopular jobs rise due to a foreign manpower shortage and elevated local unemployment. Employers are offering higher wages to locals, up to 20% more, in service roles, while migrant workers command higher pay. The median monthly salary for service crew increased to S$2,000 from S$1,800. However, questions remain on how long wages for mid-skilled jobs and non-PMETs will stay up and how much resident workers will benefit, with some players expecting a retreat in salaries when the pandemic-related crunch eases.

images.alt_text: Employers are offering up to 20 per cent more for locals who take on service jobs, as they save on foreign-worker levies and can enjoy wage support, says Andrew Tan from recruiter Wantedly.

site_title: 'Greenium' shrinks as climate bond sales swell
summary: Record issuance of green bonds has led to a significant decline in the "greenium," the premium investors pay for environmentally-beneficial projects. In April, investors paid virtually no premium for holding green corporate bonds, down from an average 9 basis points in 2020. The surge in green bond supply, with companies raising nearly as much through green bonds this year as in 2020, has reduced the pricing benefit for borrowers. However, social and sustainability bonds remain scarce, offering a premium of 20-36 basis points at issuance.

site_title: Opening borders and living with Covid-19 as a new normal in Singapore
summary: Singapore must balance safety and costs as it prepares to open up from Covid-19 restrictions. The country's priority is to get as many people vaccinated as possible, with the latest measures showing success in stemming the viral spread. Experts recommend a long-term strategy of co-existence with Covid-19, including vaccinations and booster shots, and Singapore's Prime Minister has unveiled a three-pronged approach to testing, tracing, and vaccination. With the virus unlikely to be eradicated, Singapore must be prepared to live with Covid-19 as a bad flu, prioritizing health and safety for all, including visitors, to convince businesses it can balance these.

site_title: Lendlease Reit's perp issue signals potential acquisition: CGS-CIMB
summary: Lendlease Global Commercial Real Estate Investment Trust (LReit) issued S$200 million in perpetual securities at 4.2% per annum, with the issue being upsized from S$150 million due to strong demand. This could signal an acquisition, according to brokerage CGS-CIMB. The oversubscribed issue may indicate investors' confidence in the company's prospects, potentially paving the way for a strategic takeover.

site_title: Athens opens Olympics museum ahead of Tokyo Games
summary: Athens has opened its long-awaited Olympic museum ahead of the Tokyo Games, marking 3,000 years since the origins of the Greek athletic contests. The museum, housed in the renovated 2004 Olympic TV centre, features a mix of ancient and modern displays, including items donated by Greek sportspeople and historical pieces charting the modern foundation of the Games. The museum, part of a network in nearly 30 countries, opened on May 14 after several postponements due to the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: GRP Limited director Mahtani Bhagwandas assisting with CAD probe
summary: GRP Limited's independent director Mahtani Bhagwandas was interviewed by the Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) on May 17 over an investigation involving certain private companies he is a nominee director of. He stated he is not the subject of the investigation and is assisting in it. No charges have been made, and there are no restrictions on his role. The nominating committee will reassess its suitability assessment upon further information. Mahtani has sought legal advice on the investigation, which is still ongoing.

site_title: Strong leasing interest for part of StanChart space in MBFC
summary: Hongkong Land's asset manager for the Marina Bay Financial Centre (MBFC) has received strong interest from tech firms, media, and financial services companies for 200,000 sq ft of office space in Tower 1. The space, which occupies nine-and-a-half floors, is part of the roughly 400,000 sq ft leased by Standard Chartered. Rents are expected to range between S$11 and S$12 per square foot per month, with the final lease terms still uncertain. The move is part of the larger trend of banks and financial institutions rationalizing their office footprints in the wake of the Global Financial Crisis and the pandemic.

site_title: 24 Covid-19 community cases here, including 5 unlinked
summary: Singapore reported 24 community Covid-19 cases, including 5 unlinked cases, on Wednesday. The cases include a nursing home staff, massage therapist, and NTUC Fairprice employee, with the unlinked cases identified as a 61-year-old woman and a 43-year-old Changi Prison Complex employee. Free testing is being offered to those who visited a Sengkang shop from May 12-30. The new cases bring the total number of open clusters to 44, and the total number of cases in Singapore to 62,100.

site_title: Broadway plans to reopen doors in August
summary: Broadway plans to reopen with the play "Pass Over" on August 4, nearly a month ahead of the previously announced September 14 restart date. The show, directed by Danya Taymor and starring a cast of three actors, will have an intermission-free 85-minute run and is expected to perform to full-capacity audiences. Producers cited improving public health and a desire to be part of the industry's resurgence as reasons for the early reopening.

site_title: Cummings' testimony won't sink Boris Johnson, but his biggest test is yet to come
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson faces his biggest test as he navigates the aftermath of the COVID-19 pandemic and Britain's European Union exit, amidst global tensions with the US, China, and Russia. Despite Dominic Cummings' criticism, Johnson is unlikely to be toppled, but his economic management will be his greatest challenge. Cummings' testimony highlights issues of confidentiality and transparency in government, but a wealth tax could be a key solution to address UK inequality and economic imbalances.

site_title: Nvidia CEO 'confident' of getting regulators' OK for Arm deal
summary: NVIDIA CEO Jensen Huang expressed confidence that regulators will approve the US$40 billion acquisition of SoftBank's Arm Ltd, despite growing concerns. He stated that the process may take 18 months, with potential approval in China and the UK later this year or in 2022. Huang emphasized that the companies are complementary, bringing innovations and customer choices. The deal faces challenges from regulators in China and the UK, with Arm involved in a legal battle in China.

images.alt_text: Nvidia is committed to paying Arm owner SoftBank US$2 billion whether the deal goes through or not.

site_title: A closer look at Frasers Property's green push
summary: Frasers Property, a Singapore-listed real estate company, aims to achieve net-zero carbon emissions by 2050. The company has secured its 17th green and sustainability-linked financing, totaling S$5.4 billion, and will work towards four new sustainability goals over the next three decades. This commitment makes Frasers Property the first Singapore-listed real estate company to set a net-zero target.

site_title: Greenback holds gains as US manufacturing picks up
summary: The US dollar maintained minor gains, hovering near a five-month trough against major peers, as a rise in US manufacturing kept bets alive for a quicker Federal Reserve policy normalization. The dollar index hovered just below 90, while the euro traded at US$1.22 after pulling back from a multi-month top. Investors are also watching China's yuan, which remained little changed, and the Canadian dollar, which rallied to a fresh six-year peak as oil prices rose.

site_title: Danish housing rally needs no intervention, says advisory body
summary: Denmark's housing prices have reached record levels, sparking concerns from the central bank and IMF. Despite the risks, the Danish Economic Councils advise against intervention, citing stable annual housing costs as a percentage of income. The council suggests measures such as higher down-payment requirements and amortisation conditions for indebted homeowners. The IMF urges Denmark to tighten debt-to-income ratios and require highly leveraged households to pay back loan principal. The council's chairman notes similarities with the years leading up to the financial crisis, but does not deem immediate intervention necessary.

site_title: TSMC begins construction at its Arizona chip factory site
summary: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co (TSMC) has begun construction at a US$12 billion chip factory site in Arizona, with plans to start volume production in 2024. The factory will use TSMC's five-nanometre production technology and is part of a larger investment plan to increase capacity at its factories. The move comes as TSMC faces increasing competition from Intel and Samsung Electronics for US$54 billion in subsidies for the chip industry. The factory is expected to support the growth of clients in the automotive and consumer electronics industries.

site_title: Singapore Reinsurance further extends closing date for Fairfax Asia's cash offer
summary: Singapore Reinsurance Corp has extended the closing date for Fairfax Asia's cash offer to June 17, 5.30pm, unchanged from other terms. The offer aims to acquire 71.82% of Singapore Reinsurance's stakes not owned by Fairfax Asia and its concert parties, conditional on a 50% stake threshold. As of June 1, Fairfax Asia and its affiliates held 92.09% of shares, including 63.10% through public acceptances. The extension gives Fairfax Asia more time to meet the 50% stake requirement.

site_title: How the B Corp movement is redefining success in business
summary: The B Corp movement is redefining success in business by using profits and growth as a means to a greater end, focusing on social and environmental impact. Since its launch in 2007, over 4,000 Certified B Corps have been certified globally, including major companies like The Guardian and Patagonia. These companies meet high standards of verified social and environmental performance, accountability, and transparency. The B Corp certification process evaluates a company's entire operation, not just a single product, and provides a benchmark for businesses to measure and improve their positive impacts.

site_title: Nintendo announces plans for Japan museum
summary: Nintendo plans to open a "Nintendo Gallery" museum in Kyoto, Japan by spring 2024, repurposing an old factory site. The museum will showcase the company's history and beloved gaming products. This follows the recent opening of Nintendo's first-ever theme park in March 2021. The exact details of the museum's design and content have not been released, but it is expected to be a significant addition to Nintendo's brand and a destination for fans.

site_title: Korea's business leaders call on Moon to free jailed Samsung boss Lee
summary: South Korean business leaders, including Samsung, Hyundai, and LG executives, urged President Moon Jae-in to pardon Jay Y Lee, the jailed Samsung Electronics vice-chairman, to maintain the country's edge in the chip industry. Lee was sentenced to 30 months in prison for bribery, embezzlement, and other offenses. Legal experts believe Lee is eligible for parole, and business leaders emphasized the need for his release to retain South Korea's leading position in the chip industry amid global shortages.

site_title: Australia's economy booms to pre-pandemic levels as consumers, businesses spend
summary: Australia's economy has rebounded to pre-pandemic levels, expanding 1.8% in the first quarter of 2021, driven by private investment and household spending. The country's $2 trillion economy has surpassed its pre-pandemic size, with annual output reaching $525.7 billion. This marks a rare achievement among rich-world peers, with only five countries boasting an economy larger than before the pandemic. The recovery is attributed to strict social distancing measures, timely monetary and fiscal stimulus, and a low-interest-rate environment.

site_title: AirAsia X gets shareholder go-ahead for restructuring plan
summary: AirAsia X, the long-haul affiliate of the AirAsia Group, has secured shareholder approval for its debt restructuring plan, allowing it to pursue a rights issue and share subscription to raise RM500 million. The airline had proposed restructuring its RM64.15 billion debt into a principal amount of RM200 million, with the rest waived. The approvals were obtained with a 99.8% margin, marking a major milestone in the airline's restructuring efforts, which are expected to be finalized in late July or August.

site_title: Access to Sinovac shot welcomed by frequent travellers to China
summary: Singapore's Health Ministry has announced that it will open access to the Sinovac Covid-19 vaccine for frequent business travellers to China, allowing them to enter China more easily in the future. The vaccine will be available via private healthcare providers under the Special Access Route, but the government will not subsidise the vaccine or provide financial assistance for those vaccinated under this route. This move is seen as a relief for businessmen and residents from China who have been waiting for months to get vaccinated.

site_title: Japan leads pledges to bridge US$1.7b Covax vaccine gap
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga pledged US$800 million to close a US$1.7 billion funding gap for the Covax vaccine initiative, aiming to inoculate 30% of populations in 92 low-and-middle-income countries by the end of 2021. Other nations, including Australia, Canada, and the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, also pledged over US$800 million. The move comes as the pandemic continues to rage in Asia and scientists emphasize the need for global vaccination efforts to end the pandemic.

site_title: AstraZeneca commits to 1.8 million Thai vaccine doses amid supply anxiety
summary: AstraZeneca has committed to delivering 1.8 million doses of locally manufactured COVID-19 vaccines to Thailand, the first of multiple batches this month, amid public anxiety about vaccine supplies. The move comes as Thailand launches its mass immunization drive, which relies on 61 million doses of AstraZeneca vaccine. The Thai government has promised 6 million doses this month, with the remaining doses to be sourced from Siam Bioscience, a firm owned by Thailand's king, and other suppliers.

site_title: Jakarta start-up offers cleaning products without the plastic packaging
summary: A Jakarta start-up, Siklus, is offering cleaning products without plastic packaging by delivering direct refills into customers' kitchens. This move aims to reduce single-use sachets of detergents and help cut Indonesia's plastic pollution, the second-largest ocean polluter in the world.

site_title: Chips shortage: Musk blames panic buying like toilet paper rush
summary: Elon Musk blames the global chip shortage on panic buying, similar to the toilet paper rush during the pandemic, citing over-ordering by companies and consumers. The shortage is affecting Tesla's supply chain, with chip companies and automakers warning of tight supplies until next year. A consulting firm estimates automakers will lose $110 billion in sales due to the shortage. Chip manufacturers plan to increase production, but supplies are expected to remain tight, impacting the automotive industry.

site_title: Singtel shareholders should not count on a fat payout from plan to unlock asset value
summary: Singtel's plan to "unlock value" from its regional infrastructure portfolio may lead to a significant shake-up of its legacy assets. However, investors should not expect a substantial payout, unlike the sale of a majority stake in NetLink Trust. The move could revive Singtel's stock, but it's essential to consider the potential consequences of asset realignment. The company's decision may impact its long-term value, and shareholders should be cautious of the potential outcomes.

site_title: Japan may see inflation perk up in post-Covid era: BOJ board member
summary: Japan may see inflation increase in the post-pandemic era, according to Bank of Japan board member Seiji Adachi. The central bank's massive stimulus may not be enough to achieve its 2% inflation target, and firms may be able to raise prices for value-added services. Adachi cited a post-pandemic world as an opportunity for firms to charge more for higher-quality services, potentially helping the BOJ achieve its inflation target. The BOJ's current asset-buying program may not be enough to prop up inflation, and a potential yen spike could prompt a response from the central bank.

site_title: UK's Johnson under pressure to stick to lockdown easing plan
summary: The UK government is under pressure to stick to its lockdown easing plan, despite no new Covid-19 deaths being recorded for the first time since the pandemic began. The positive news has bolstered calls from business and Conservative Party members for the final stage of unlocking the economy to proceed on June 21, with Health Secretary Matt Hancock urging caution and warning that Britain has not "beaten this virus yet." Ministers will analyze data on hospitalizations and deaths before making a decision, focusing on the impact of the Delta virus variant.

site_title: Global economic growth set for strongest pace in 50 years, expected to expand 6.1%: BOS
summary: The world economy is expected to expand 6.1% this year, its strongest pace in 50 years, according to Bank of Singapore's chief economist Mansoor Mohi-uddin. China's growth is expected to slow to 8.7%, while the US and UK are expected to grow 6.8% and 6% respectively. Despite fresh virus waves in some countries, restrictions are targeted and less impactful than last year, supporting the global growth outlook. Central banks are expected to remain dovish, and governments' large budget deficits are boosting risk assets.

site_title: Nursing home staff, massage therapist among 24 Covid-19 community cases
summary: A nursing home staff, massage therapist, and NTUC Fairprice employee are among 24 community Covid-19 cases reported in Singapore. The cases include five unlinked cases, with the first being a 61-year-old woman who worked at NTUC Fairprice in Clementi Avenue 3. The Ministry of Health is investigating the cases to determine the source of the outbreak.

site_title: Gaming company Razer mulls entering cryptocurrency space
summary: Razer, a Hong Kong-listed gaming company, is "carefully evaluating" a potential entry into the cryptocurrency space, according to its CEO Tan Min-Liang. The company has a global reach of hundreds of millions of gamers and a significant presence in fintech, making it a potential player in the industry. While Tan ruled out issuing its own cryptocurrency, Razer may accept cryptocurrencies for its hardware and services. This move comes as the company rolls out a 10-year sustainability roadmap, including investing in environmental and sustainability initiatives.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong

site_title: Sinovac approved under Special Access Route: MOH
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Health (MOH) has approved Sinovac's Covid-19 vaccine under the Special Access Route (SAR), following the World Health Organisation's (WHO) approval for emergency use listing. The vaccine will not be part of the national vaccine programme, and those who choose it will not be eligible for compensation. Private healthcare institutions can apply to be licensed providers, with MOH working out details on pricing, consent, and safety.
