This move may allow more people with known anaphylaxis history to be vaccinated with mRNA vaccines, currently approved for use.

site_title: Australia: Shares hit record peak as economic data boosts risk appetite
summary: Australia's shares hit a record high, closing 1.1% higher at 7,217.8, as economic data showed a 1.8% increase in gross domestic product, beating expectations. The surge was driven by increased consumer and business spending, as well as firmer commodity prices. The boost was despite concerns over fresh Covid-19 cases in Victoria.

site_title: Malaysia reports record 126 Covid-19 deaths
summary: Malaysia reported a record 126 COVID-19 deaths on Wednesday, surpassing the previous high of 98 fatalities announced on Saturday. The country has seen a surge in cases due to more infectious variants, prompting stricter lockdown measures. Authorities reported 7,703 new cases, bringing the total infections to 587,165 and fatalities to 2,993. Malaysian Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin recently announced a $9.7 billion aid package to combat the pandemic.

site_title: Lonza plans new production line to make Moderna Covid-19 vaccine ingredients
summary: Lonza plans to build a new production line in the Netherlands to produce ingredients for Moderna's Covid-19 vaccine, with the capacity to make 300 million doses annually at 50 micrograms per dose. This is half the dose Moderna has been delivering, and the move is part of the company's plan to significantly increase output to 3 billion doses in 2022. Lower dose vaccines could be used as booster shots or for children who may not require a full dose, addressing potential coronavirus variants.

site_title: Burnt-out Singapore containership off Sri Lanka at risk of sinking, says MPA
summary: A Singapore-registered containership, X-Press Pearl, is at risk of sinking off Sri Lanka after a nearly two-week fire was extinguished. The vessel's stern is submerged, and all crew members have been evacuated. The Maritime Port Authority (MPA) of Singapore is working with the ship operator to continue salvage operations, while also investigating the cause of the incident. The MPA has also opened its own investigation and is cooperating with the Sri Lankan authorities, who are also investigating the incident. The ship was carrying 1,486 containers, including chemicals, when the fire started on May 20.

site_title: HSBC offers vaccinated staff in Hong Kong two days of extra leave
summary: HSBC Holdings is offering all Hong Kong-based staff two days paid vaccination leave after the city government's efforts to boost inoculation rates. Vaccinated employees will receive one day off for each vaccination dose, while those who received their vaccine prior to the announcement will also be eligible. The move comes as Hong Kong authorities urge financial institutions to support vaccination efforts, with the Hong Kong Monetary Authority encouraging staff in client-facing roles to get vaccinated.

site_title: Sinopharm can provide more than 1b Covid-19 shots beyond China
summary: Sinopharm chairman Liu Jingzhen announced the company's capacity to provide over 1 billion Covid-19 vaccine doses globally beyond China in the second half of 2021. This assumes China meets its vaccination demand. Sinopharm's annual production capacity exceeds 5 billion doses, with two of its vaccines gaining emergency use approval from the World Health Organization. The company is planning a third vaccine manufacturing facility. China has also pledged 10 million doses to the Covax initiative, and Gavi is in talks with Sinovac Biotech to expand the Covax portfolio.

images.alt_text: China National Pharmaceutical Group (Sinopharm) has the capacity to provide more than 1 billion Covid-19 vaccine doses to the world beyond China in the second half of this year, the firm's chairman Liu Jingzhen said late on Wednesday.

site_title: Sabana Reit appoints hedge fund chief as non-executive director
summary: Sabana Reit appointed Singapore-based hedge fund founder Chan Wai Kheong as a non-executive director, subject to independent unitholders' approval. Chan has over 35 years of experience in the financial sector and previously worked at Credit Suisse. He holds a 0.4% stake in the company and will join the audit and risk committee, as well as the nominating and remuneration committee. The appointment follows a 1.2% increase in the company's units to 42 cents on the day of the announcement.

site_title: Elon Musk's 'Baby Shark' tweet sends shares soaring
summary: Elon Musk's tweet about the viral song "Baby Shark" sent shares of Samsung Publishing, a shareholder in the song's producer SmartStudy, soaring by up to 10% to their highest level since May 7. The company's shares have more than quadrupled since 2018 due to the song's massive popularity. The tweet's influence on assets, including cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin and meme stocks, highlights Musk's significant impact on the market. The song has been viewed nearly 8.7 billion times and has reached the Billboard Hot 100 chart multiple times.

site_title: 24 new Covid-19 community cases in Singapore, including five unlinked
summary: Singapore reported 31 new COVID-19 cases, including 24 community cases, bringing the total to 62,100. Five cases are unlinked, while 19 linked cases are under quarantine. Seven imported cases are on stay-home notice. No new cases from workers' dormitories were reported.

site_title: Singapore stocks reverse gains; STI down 0.8%
summary: Singapore stocks reversed gains, closing down 0.82% or 26.19 points at 3,161.04, following a negative start. The decline was attributed to selling pressure ahead of the US jobs report. Among constituents, banks O39, D05, and U11 fell 1.51%, 1.42%, and 0.68% respectively. This marks a reversal of the 5-day rally seen ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Olympics: As unpredictable Games looms, Japan's sponsors struggle to adapt
summary: Japan's sponsors of the Tokyo Olympics are struggling to adapt to the uncertainty surrounding the event due to the COVID-19 pandemic and slow vaccine rollout. With no domestic spectators allowed and foreign spectators banned, many sponsors are uncertain how to proceed with advertising campaigns or marketing events. Global sponsors have scaled down Tokyo promotions, while domestic sponsors are committed to seeing the event through despite concerns about reputation risk. The Tokyo government has no plans to allow alcohol at public viewing sites outside venues, further complicating sponsorship efforts.

site_title: Deutsche Bank's Postbank to charge new fees to compensate for negative rates
summary: Deutsche Bank's retail unit Postbank will begin charging new customers fees to compensate for negative interest rates. Fees will be charged on cheques over 50,000 euros and savings accounts over 25,000 euros. This move aims to generate revenues to offset the fees the European Central Bank demands to keep bank deposits.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end on negative note
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended on a negative note, closing down 0.58% with a 170.38-point loss. The Hang Seng Index fell to 29,297.62, while the Shanghai Composite Index dropped 0.76% to 3,597.14. Investors are cautious ahead of US jobs data release later this week.

site_title: Taiwan unveils mass vaccination plan as Covid-19 cases edge up
summary: Taiwan reported 549 new COVID-19 cases, with 177 added from recent days, amid a rise in community infections. The country has unveiled a mass vaccination plan aiming to cover 1.7 million people per week, as it battles a spike in cases and places curbs on gatherings and entertainment venues. The trend is considered stable, but not falling. Taiwan's Health Minister Chen Shih-chung attributed the rise to delays in reporting positive tests.

site_title: Germany says has been helping on Taiwan's BioNTech vaccine deal
summary: Germany's top diplomat in Taipei, Thomas Prinz, stated that his government has been assisting in talks between Taiwan and BioNTech to supply Covid-19 vaccines, amid a controversy over Chinese "intervention" in vaccine acquisition. Taiwan rejected Beijing's offer to supply shots made by Shanghai Fosun Pharmaceutical Group, which holds a contract to sell them in Greater China. China denied the accusation, escalating a war of words.

site_title: GIC enters joint venture with India-based mall developer-operator
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC has entered a joint venture with Phoenix Mills, an India-based mall developer, to invest in retail-led mixed-use assets in India. GIC will acquire a significant minority stake in Phoenix Mills' US$733 million portfolio, comprising 3.4 million square feet of leasable space in Mumbai and Pune. This move aims to capitalize on the growing demand for retail and mixed-use developments in India, despite the ongoing global crisis.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund, GIC, has entered a joint venture with Phoenix Mills, acquiring a significant minority stake in the US$733 million portfolio of retail-led mixed-use developments. A new Professional Conversion Programme for interior fit-out specialists was launched, and a UOL-led group won a housing site in Ang Mo Kio for S$381.4m. iX Biopharma expanded its wafer production capacity, aiming for its first commercial batch in July. Mapletree Investments reported a 4% growth in FY21 net profit to S$1.85b, but Singapore stocks reversed gains, closing 0.8% lower.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares rally as reopening hopes boosts travel; real estate firms surge
summary: Japanese shares rose 0.46% to 28,946.14, driven by gains in the hospitality sector as vaccination drives boost economic reopening hopes. The real estate sector also surged, with railway companies and airlines experiencing significant gains. Automakers like Honda and Toyota reached new highs on stronger global demand, while investors rotated out of pandemic-benefited shares.

site_title: Indonesia ends salvage efforts for sunken submarine
summary: Indonesia's navy has ended efforts to salvage the sunken KRI Nanggala-402 submarine, which sank in April off Bali island, resulting in the deaths of all 53 on board. The submarine was discovered in three parts at a depth of 840 meters, with some parts remaining on the sea floor. The salvage effort, assisted by countries including China, Australia, and Malaysia, was deemed too difficult to retrieve the vessel. The incident sparked a desperate international search and rescue effort before the oxygen supplies were exhausted.

site_title: Volvo owners to get US$2.3b payout from UD trucks sale
summary: Volvo Group shareholders are set to receive a $2.3 billion payout from the sale of its Japanese business unit, UD Trucks, to Isuzu Motors. The payout will be distributed to investors, resulting in a 3.6% increase in shares. The sale is part of Volvo's efforts to cut costs and increase service sales, which are less sensitive to demand swings. Despite pandemic-affected sales last year, Volvo posted an 8.4% operating margin, close to its target of 10% over a business cycle.

site_title: Brokers' take: Maybank KE upgrades Genting to 'buy' on Yokohama IR hopes
summary: Maybank KE upgrades Genting Singapore to "buy" with a target price of S$1.16, citing hopes that Genting's joint venture with Sega Sammy Holdings will win the Yokohama integrated resort bid, potentially adding S$1.8 billion to earnings. The analyst views Genting's strong ESG credentials and Singapore's highly-regulated casino industry as advantages in bidding for a Japanese casino license.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 12.04 points to 1,597.94, closing higher on Wednesday. The index saw 711 gainers compared to 362 losers, with a trading volume of 7.439 billion lots worth RM4.099 billion.

site_title: Europe: Stocks hover near record high as oil shares bounce
summary: European stocks rose 0.4% near record highs, driven by energy and consumer stocks, as strong US and European factory activity lifted investor sentiment. Oil shares led sectoral gains after OPEC maintained its plan to increase oil supply in June and July. Volvo and Bang & Olufsen also saw significant gains, with Volvo's board proposing to distribute sale proceeds to shareholders and Bang & Olufsen providing an upbeat earnings forecast.

site_title: EHT unitholder KP Poh says he didn't keep US$1.9m from Urban Commons' founders
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT) unitholder KP Poh has denied claims that he and his company, Poh Altan Resources Company (PARC), received US$1.9 million from Urban Commons Queensway (UCQ) under the US Cares Act's Paycheck Protection Programme (PPP). Poh stated that the funds were transferred in May 2020 for a contemplated business transaction, but the transaction did not proceed, and the funds were ultimately returned. A US judge denied UCQ's motion to freeze sufficient funds to recover US$2.4 million. Poh termed the claims "recklessly false" and portrayed himself as a victim of "purported PPP-related fraud".

site_title: Mapletree Investments FY21 net profit grows 4% to S$1.85b
summary: Mapletree Investments reported a 4% increase in net profit to S$1.85 billion for FY21, driven by significant investments in global logistics and data centers. The company recycled S$3.1 billion in capital and recorded revaluation gains. Revenue fell 29.4% year-over-year to S$2.74 billion, but assets under management increased 9.6% to S$66.3 billion. The group's CEO, Hiew Yoon Khong, attributed the performance to a focus on managing and improving asset operating performances and prudent capital management.

site_title: Virus outbreak to boost Thai healthcare operators' revenue until end-2021 at least
summary: A new government stimulus package in Thailand is unlikely to boost the consumer sector, but analysts expect the Covid-19 pandemic to sustain the fortunes of hospital operators until at least the end of 2021. Alternative-vaccination roll-outs in the private healthcare sector are seen as a major revenue driver, with operators like Bangkok Dusit Medical Services and Bumrungrad Hospital expected to see strong earnings growth in 2022. The pandemic is expected to improve in the second half of the year, but the distribution of alternative vaccinations could provide a long-term boost to healthcare operators.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks extend rally; US jobs data in focus
summary: South Korean stocks rose for a fourth consecutive day, closing 2.36 points higher or 0.07% at 3,224.23. The rally was tempered by a selloff from institutional investors, while the won weakened and bond yields rose. Consumer inflation accelerated to a nine-year high in May, supporting calls for monetary tightening. Investor focus shifted to US payrolls data due on Friday, which may impact monetary policy. Foreigners were net buyers of 32.4 billion won worth of shares, and the benchmark bond yield rose 1.4 basis points to 2.199%.

site_title: Hot stock: MFG Integration rises 26.7% amid heavy trading, prompting SGX query
summary: Manufacturing Integration Technology (MFG Integration) shares surged 26.7% amid heavy trading on June 2, prompting a Singapore Exchange (SGX) query about "unusual volume movements". The stock price jumped 1.6 cents to 7.6 cents, with 6.3 million shares changing hands, before easing to 6.9 cents, up 15% or 0.9 cents. No married deals were recorded in early trade, according to ShareInvestor data.

site_title: China watchdog disapproves of stock index target setting: report
summary: China's regulators have disapproved of analysts forecasting specific levels for the Shanghai Composite Index, citing concerns that such predictions can be "whimsical" and "arbitrary." The move aims to quell speculative behavior in financial markets, following recent efforts to talk down commodity prices and the yuan. Regulators prefer a "slow bull" rather than a frenzied rally, and have previously sought to cool the market via state media and issued window guidance to brokerages.

site_title: China's Guangdong tightens coronavirus measures as cases persist
summary: China's Guangdong province has tightened coronavirus measures amid persistent cases, with cities locking down compounds and requiring negative test results for travelers. The province reported 10 locally confirmed cases on June 1, all in Guangzhou and Foshan, and has suspended individual appointments for COVID-19 vaccine shots to prioritize medical staff. Travel restrictions have been imposed, and asymptomatic cases have been reported in Shenzhen. The recent infections are linked to fast-spreading virus strains first detected in India and Britain. China's death toll remains unchanged at 4,636.

site_title: Telkom, Astra among beneficiaries of Indonesia's new index weighting method: Citi
summary: Indonesia's IDX Composite Index is set to benefit companies with higher free float, including Telkom and Astra International, due to changes in the index's weighting method. The new method will use free float-adjusted market capitalization and cap each stock's weighting at 9%. Telkom's weight is expected to rise by 3.1%, while Astra's weight will increase by 1.7%. Other beneficiaries include Bank Mandiri, Bank Rakyat Indonesia, and Merdeka Copper Gold, with smaller increases for Merdeka Copper Gold and Charoen Pokphand Indonesia. The changes are set to be implemented in stages from October 1, 2021 to April 1, 2022.

site_title: How the world ran out of everything
summary: A global shortage of goods, including electronics, lumber, and clothing, has highlighted the limitations of the "Just In Time" manufacturing approach, pioneered by Toyota. This method, which minimizes inventory storage to reduce costs, has been adopted by various industries, but the current crisis has exposed its vulnerabilities. Disruptions to global shipping, manufacturing, and supply chains have led to shortages, with companies such as Nike, construction companies, and pharmaceuticals struggling to meet demand. Experts warn that the pursuit of cost savings has led to an over-reliance on Just In Time, leaving companies unprepared for disruptions.

site_title: Asia: Crude extends gains as recovery picks up but equities mixed
summary: Oil prices extended their rally in Asia, driven by growing expectations for demand as the global economy recovers. The Opec+ group agreed to continue lifting output in July, citing improved demand signs. However, the International Energy Agency warned of a potential gap between demand and supplies, which could push prices higher. Despite this, WTI and Brent prices rose to their highest levels since 2018, supporting energy firms. Broader Asian markets, however, were mixed, with some countries rising and others dipping.

site_title: TPP members agree to start process for UK to join, Japan says
summary: Members of the Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP) agreed to allow the UK to start the process of joining the trade deal, with Japan's economy minister saying it would strengthen economic ties between the UK and Japan, and make the zone equal to the European Union in terms of economic size. The UK made its formal application to join CPTPP in February, which is expected to accelerate its growth in export trade with Asian economies. This move comes after the UK's exit from the EU and Japan's support for the UK's efforts to seal global trade deals.

site_title: New Professional Conversion Programme launched for interior fit-out specialists
summary: Singapore has launched a Professional Conversion Programme (PCP) for interior fit-out specialists, aiming to enhance their skills and career prospects. The 9-month training programme, starting in July, will equip participants with knowledge and practical skills in assembly technology and client management. The programme is part of the government's efforts to support mid-career professionals and managers in the furniture sector, with the goal of moving them into higher-value tasks and increasing their salary potential to S$2,500 to S$4,000 per month.

site_title: Ang Mo Kio housing site awarded to UOL-led group for S$381.4m
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) awarded a private housing site at Ang Mo Kio Avenue 1 to United Venture Development (2021), a 60:20:20 joint venture between UOL Group, Singapore Land Group, and Kheng Leong Company, for S$381.4 million. The site, spanning 12,679.4 square meters, was offered on a 99-year lease term and drew 15 bids. The winning bid was 6.3% higher than the second-highest bid of S$358.89 million.

site_title: Chinese central bank's digital yuan given trial by lottery
summary: China's capital Beijing will launch a lottery in June to distribute 200 digital yuan (S$41.45) to 200,000 winners, who must download an app to use their prizes at designated merchants. This trial follows previous trials in Shenzhen and Shanghai, as China aims to become the first major central bank to issue a central bank digital currency (CBDC). The e-CNY could potentially erode the dominance of Alipay and WeChat Pay in online payments, and is part of China's push to internationalize the yuan and reduce dependence on the dollar-dominated global banking system.

site_title: AirAsia X gets shareholder go-ahead for restructuring plan
summary: AirAsia X shareholders approved the airline's debt restructuring plan, allowing it to pursue a scheme viewed as key to survival. The plan involves raising RM500 million through a rights issue and share subscription, with a principal debt amount of RM200 million and the rest waived. The airline has obtained 99.8% approval from shareholders and is in active talks with creditors, including lessors. A court granted the airline leave to convene separate meetings with its creditors within six months to vote on the scheme, which is scheduled for late July or August.

site_title: As Covid-19 cases rose, so did hospital hacks in France
summary: In February 2021, the Dax hospital in southwestern France was hit by a ransomware hack, disrupting hospital operations and forcing a return to paper records. This incident is part of a growing trend of ransomware attacks on French public hospitals, with at least half a dozen others affected since the start of the COVID-19 pandemic. The attacks have highlighted the vulnerability of the healthcare system and prompted the French government to announce an extra billion euros for cybersecurity in the health sector. The attacks also underscore the lucrative nature of ransomware hacking, with victims making an estimated $350 million in cryptocurrency payments in 2020.

site_title: Hot stock: Genting sees heavy trading, rises 2.3% after qualifying for Yokohama RFP
summary: Genting Singapore shares rose 2.3% on Wednesday amid heavy trading following the operator's qualification for the Yokohama integrated resort request for proposal (RFP). The counter surged to 87.5 cents before easing to close at 86.5 cents. Genting Singapore, along with a joint venture with Sega Sammy Holdings, was one of the two accepted parties for the RFP.

site_title: Japan may see inflation perk up in post-Covid era, says BOJ board member
summary: Japan may see inflation increase in the post-pandemic era, according to Bank of Japan board member Seiji Adachi. Adachi suggests that consumers may become more willing to pay more for value-added services, allowing firms to raise prices. The BOJ aims to achieve a 2% inflation target, and Adachi believes that a post-pandemic world could offer an opportunity to achieve this goal. The central bank must maintain its ultra-loose policy to support the economy and prepare for potential funding issues for companies.

site_title: US to detail plan for global distribution of 80m vaccine doses
summary: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken announced plans to distribute 80 million Covid-19 vaccine doses globally, with a focus on equitable distribution. The US will send at least 20 million doses of Pfizer/BioNTech, Moderna, and Johnson & Johnson vaccines, on top of 60 million AstraZeneca doses already planned.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel Infra Trust, Boustead Projects, iX Biopharma, Raffles Medical, Wee Hur
summary: Keppel Infra Trust plans to issue S$300 million subordinated perpetual securities. Boustead Projects signed an option agreement with Khai Toan Joint Stock Company for a potential 49% stake in Boustead Industrial Logistics Joint Stock Company. iX Biopharma installed new equipment to expand wafer production capacity six times. Raffles Medical partnered with China Life Insurance to boost healthcare collaborations in China. Wee Hur Construction secured a new project worth S$176.7 million from the Housing and Development Board. Lim Swee Say joined Singtel as a non-executive independent director.

site_title: Brokers' take: CGS-CIMB positive on Lendlease Reit on potential acquisition
summary: CGS-CIMB analysts have expressed positive views on Lendlease Global Commercial Real Estate Investment Trust (LReit) due to its recent issuance of S$200 million in perpetual securities. The analysts believe the funds will be used for accretive acquisitions, with a potential target being a second stake in integrated office and retail development Jem. They have maintained an "add" rating and raised the target price to 86.9 Singapore cents. Despite challenges such as a drop in shopper traffic and tenant sales, the analysts do not expect the impact on LReit's overall financial performance to be substantial.

site_title: Montenegro learns true cost of China-backed US$1b road to nowhere
summary: Montenegro has spent $944 million on a $1 billion road project backed by China, with the remaining 130km expected to cost at least $1.59 billion. The road, which is intended to connect the Adriatic port of Bar with the Serbian border, has been criticized for its high cost, environmental damage, and potential for corruption. Locals have seen some economic benefits, but critics question how the rest of the road will be paid for and highlight concerns over the project's impact on the country's economy and debt. Montenegro's government is now seeking help from the European Union to rescue the project.

site_title: Australian banks, led by CBA, set to return record US$15b cash to investors
summary: Australian banks, led by Commonwealth Bank of Australia (CBA), are set to return a record $15 billion or more in cash to investors over the next two years. The banks have made a remarkable recovery from the Covid-19 crisis, with investors expecting share buybacks and dividends. CBA's shares have hit a record high, and analysts predict the bank will announce an off-market buyback of between $5 billion and $5.5 billion and hike its dividend payment in August. Other banks, including ANZ, NAB, and Westpac, are also expected to follow with similar capital return programs, totaling around $15 billion.

site_title: Macquarie-backed Keypath Education IPO tumbles 5% in Australian debut
summary: Keypath Education International, a US-based online programme maker backed by Macquarie, made its Australian IPO debut with shares tumbling 5% to A$3.52, down from its IPO price of A$3.71. The company raised A$212.1 million to fund expansion, particularly in the healthcare sector and Southeast Asia. This marks the second Macquarie-backed IPO to underperform, following Nuix's shares, which have more than halved in value this year.

site_title: Australia's Victoria state extends Covid-19 lockdown in Melbourne by a week
summary: Australia's Victoria state extended a Covid-19 lockdown in Melbourne by a week, citing a decrease in new cases, to end on June 10. The lockdown, initially set to end on June 3, was imposed on May 27 after the state reported its first locally acquired cases. The total infections in the latest outbreak have reached 60. In other news, the US announced new tariffs on Vietnam, Malaysia's agency plans to seize RM3 billion of assets, China's GDP growth is expected to slow, and the UK economy contracted for the second month.

site_title: Australia: Shares climb ahead of GDP data; miners rally
summary: Australian shares rose 0.4% to 7,169.5 ahead of GDP data showing a 0.6% expansion in the first quarter, maintaining a steady recovery pace. Mining stocks, led by iron ore's surge, rose 1.7% for a fifth straight day, with heavyweights Rio Tinto, BHP, and Fortescue gaining 3-5%. Energy stocks also rose 2.7% as oil prices hit their highest since March.

site_title: Vietnam resumes incoming international flights to largest cities
summary: Vietnam has resumed incoming international flights to Hanoi's Noi Bai airport and Ho Chi Minh City's Tan Son Nhat airport, effective immediately, after a brief suspension due to Covid-19. The decision comes as most of the current outbreak cases are locally transmitted, not from international passengers. The resumption of flights is seen as a positive move for the country's aviation industry, which has been impacted by the pandemic.

site_title: Australia's economy booms to pre-pandemic levels as consumers, businesses spend
summary: Australia's economy has rebounded to pre-pandemic levels, expanding by 1.8% in the first quarter of 2021, driven by private investment and household spending. The country's annual output has climbed 1.1% to A$525.7 billion, surpassing the five other countries that have seen their economies grow larger since the pandemic. Despite this growth, economists caution that the outlook remains cautious due to ongoing lockdowns and slow vaccine rollout, with the Reserve Bank of Australia warning that it will not raise interest rates until inflation reaches its target band.

site_title: SPH unit lists £83.2m unsecured loan notes on TISE
summary: SPH unit Privilege Midco issued 83.2 million British pounds in unsecured loan notes on The International Stock Exchange (TISE) at a 3.27% coupon rate, payable quarterly. The notes are direct, unconditional, and repayable on demand. They were issued to Straits Ten, a wholly-owned indirect subsidiary of SPH, at a 100% issue price. The move allows Privilege Midco to raise funds without affecting its credit rating.

site_title: Tyson Foods to launch plant-based food in Asia-Pacific
summary: Tyson Foods plans to launch plant-based food in select Asia-Pacific markets starting this month, capitalizing on the growing demand for meat substitutes in the region. The company will initially roll out plant-based nuggets, strips, and bites in Malaysia under its First Pride brand, with plans to expand into other markets. The move follows rival companies Impossible Foods, Nestle, and Beyond Meat, which have already entered the Asian market with their plant-based meat products. Retail sales of meat substitutes in Asia-Pacific reached $16.3 billion in 2020 and are expected to exceed $20 billion by 2025.

site_title: South Korea's inflation hits nine-year high on higher commodity prices
summary: South Korea's inflation accelerated to a nine-year high in May, with consumer prices rising 2.6% from a year earlier, driven mainly by a low base effect and increases in oil and agricultural prices. The finance minister stated the government will prepare against inflation risk and prevent excessive expectations to stabilize living costs. Core CPI, excluding energy and food prices, rose 1.2% year-on-year, the sharpest increase since November 2018. The central bank has upgraded its economic outlook and is considering pulling back on pandemic-era stimulus due to accelerating inflation.

site_title: Xi seeks 'lovable' image for China in sign of diplomatic rethink
summary: President Xi Jinping urged Chinese officials to create a "trustworthy, lovable and respectable" image for China, signaling a potential rethink of the country's hard-edged diplomatic approach. Xi emphasized the need for "open and confident" communication while being "modest and humble." This comes as China's assertive diplomacy has been criticized for diplomatic setbacks with partners such as the EU and the Philippines. Xi's remarks may aim to address deteriorating public perception of China in the West, which has turned sharply negative in 14 countries surveyed by the Pew Research Centre.

site_title: Oil settles up after hitting 15-month highs on demand prospects
summary: Oil prices rose after hitting 15-month highs, with Brent crude futures settling at $70.25 a barrel, its highest since March. Demand prospects for the US summer driving season, combined with Chinese factory activity growth, drove the gains. However, Opec+ agreed to continue easing supply curbs, and expectations of increased Iranian output may cap further gains. US crude stockpiles are expected to fall, and US petrol demand jumped 9.6% on the Memorial Day weekend, its highest since 2019.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei opens lower on Wednesday
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index opened lower on Wednesday, down 0.34% or 98.24 points at 28,716.10, as investors evaluated US data and awaited key jobs numbers. The broader Topix index rose 0.23% or 4.47 points.

site_title: iX Biopharma expands wafer production capacity, on track for 1st commercial batch in July
summary: iX Biopharma has installed new freeze-dry equipment, expanding its wafer production capacity by up to six times. The company expects to produce its first commercial batch of wafers in July 2021, benefiting from improved operational efficiency and economies of scale. The expansion will enable iX Biopharma to pursue commercial partnerships, invest in marketing, and enter new markets. The company's shares rose 2.1% following the announcement.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall at Wednesday's open; STI down 0.3%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.3% at Wednesday's open, with the Straits Times Index (STI) dropping 8.13 points to 3,179.10. Despite the decline, 80 gainers outnumbered 51 losers, with 86.7 million securities changing hands. Index stocks Genting Singapore and Jiutian Chemical saw significant trading, with shares rising 1.2% and falling 3.1%, respectively.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks down at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks began the day with a 0.18% decline, falling 53.36 points to 29,414.64, following a two-day run-up. The Shanghai Composite Index rose 1.61 points to 3,626.33, while the Shenzhen Composite Index gained 1.09 points to 2,430.66. The US market provided a tepid lead, with energy firms benefiting from another surge in oil prices.

site_title: Gold retreats from near five-month peak on firmer yields, equities
summary: Gold prices retreated 0.1% to $1,898.58 per ounce, as higher US bond yields and strong economic data shifted investors back into riskier assets. The US 10-year Treasury yield rose to a one-week high, increasing the opportunity cost of holding non-interest bearing gold. Meanwhile, the euro zone inflation surged past the European Central Bank's target, heightening a challenge for policymakers to respond with interest rate hikes. Market participants await US payrolls data due on Friday for further clarity on economic recovery and near-term Federal Reserve policy action.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Wednesday, rising 5.35 points or 0.34% to 1,591.25. Volume reached 518.89 million lots worth RM253.14 million. Gainers beat losers 281 to 186.

site_title: Boustead Projects signs option agreement to acquire 49% interest in holding company
summary: Boustead Projects signed an option agreement to acquire a 49% interest in holding company KBJSC, which will give the company a 49% stake in KBIL, a joint-stock company holding 100% of KBIL. The deal aims to expand Boustead Projects' presence in Vietnam and grow its income-yielding leasehold portfolio. The option agreement, worth S$16.6 million, has an expiration period of 18 months and will be exercised if either party decides to proceed with a share purchase agreement.

site_title: Zoom tops sales, profit estimates on large customer additions
summary: Zoom Video Communications has topped sales and profit estimates for the current quarter, signaling its ability to retain and add large customers despite easing pandemic demand. The company expects revenue of up to $990 million and profit of $1.14 to $1.15 per share. This tops analysts' average estimates, with Zoom also reporting a 87% increase in customers with over 10 employees and 1,999 large clients generating over $100,000 in revenue. The company's diversification efforts, including premium products, appear to be paying off.

site_title: Nintendo to open gallery on Japan factory site
summary: Nintendo plans to open a gallery on a renovated factory site south of Kyoto, Japan, showcasing its products and other exhibits. The facility, set to be completed by March 2024, was previously used for manufacturing playing cards and customer service. The gallery will be part of Nintendo's efforts to diversify beyond its core console business, following recent expansions such as a Super Mario themed area at Osaka's Universal Studios Japan and a Tokyo shop opening two years ago. Details of the gallery's exhibits and experiences have not been disclosed.

site_title: US agency not doing its job to halt tech to China's military: congressional report
summary: A US congressional advisory report has found that the US Commerce Department is not fulfilling its duties to protect national security by keeping sensitive technology out of China's military hands. The report, released in June 2021, cited a two-year delay in developing a list of emerging and foundational technologies that should be scrutinized before export to China. The Commerce Department has published some rules and added companies to its entity list, but critics argue it has not done enough to address national security risks.

site_title: Even with 20 million Covid-19 shots a day, China chooses isolation
summary: China administers 20 million daily Covid-19 vaccine doses, with over 40% of the population having received at least one shot, but the country remains cautious, refusing to signal an end to its Covid playbook of closed borders and strict quarantine measures despite low case numbers and growing protection from inoculations. Despite international pressure, China's top officials maintain aggressive rhetoric, prioritizing control over reopening, citing the risk of uncontrolled outbreaks outside the country.

site_title: Heads of WHO, WTO, IMF and World Bank issue joint call for vaccine equality
summary: World leaders from the World Health Organization, World Trade Organization, International Monetary Fund, and World Bank have issued a joint call for increased vaccine distribution to combat the global COVID-19 pandemic. They urge wealthy nations to provide $50 billion in funding to support vaccine equity and accelerate the end of the pandemic. The goal is to vaccinate at least 40% of the global population by the end of the year and 60% by the end of next year to enable a lasting economic recovery.

site_title: WHO approves China's Sinovac Covid jab
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has approved China's Sinovac Covid-19 vaccine for emergency use, marking the second Chinese vaccine to receive the WHO's green light. The two-dose vaccine, already being deployed in several countries, has been validated for safety, efficacy, and manufacturing. The approval paves the way for countries to quickly import and distribute the vaccine, particularly in poorer countries, and opens the door for it to enter the Covax global vaccine-sharing scheme. The WHO recommends the vaccine for adults 18 years and older, with efficacy results showing 51% prevention of symptomatic disease and 100% prevention of severe Covid-19 and hospitalization.

site_title: Europe: Commodity rally, record factory growth lift shares to new peak
summary: European stocks reached new highs, driven by a commodity rally and record factory growth in the euro zone. The Stoxx 600 index rose 0.8%, with UK, German, and French indices also gaining ground. Manufacturing activity expanded to 63.1 in May, a record high since 1997, despite supply bottlenecks. Investors are optimistic about economic reopening, but worry about higher inflation and potential ECB stimulus measures.

site_title: WHO narrows in on Covid-19 Delta variant
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has narrowed down the Covid-19 Delta variant to only one strain, B.1.617.2, considered "of concern" due to increased transmissibility. Two other strains, B.1.617.1 (Kappa) and B.1.617.3, have been downgraded to "variant of interest" and "not of interest," respectively. The WHO continues to monitor the variant's impact and recommends further studies.

images.alt_text: The WHO said on Tuesday that only one strain of the Covid-19 Delta variant first detected in India was now considered "of concern", while two other strains had been downgraded.

site_title: Strengthening global efforts to deal with climate change impact
summary: Global efforts to combat climate change are gaining momentum, with countries and businesses committing to reduce carbon emissions. The transition to a low-carbon future requires international cooperation, trust, and the use of market mechanisms to coordinate resources and drive change. The International Financial Reporting Standards foundation is working to establish sustainability standards, and Singapore is launching a carbon services and trading hub to support Asia's decarbonization challenge. A purpose-led marketplace can pioneer pathways to achieve sustainability commitments and co-opt active citizenry through products, platforms, and technology.

site_title: Huge sinkhole threatens to swallow Mexican home
summary: A massive sinkhole in central Mexico's Puebla state is rapidly expanding, threatening to swallow a house. The hole, initially 30m wide, grew to 80m by Tuesday, forcing the Sanchez family to evacuate. Authorities are considering geological fault and soil water content as possible causes. The sinkhole has broken away large chunks of earth, scaring onlookers, and the governor has assured public safety, stating the authorities will compensate those affected. The sinkhole's growth is expected to continue until nature decides, when the water's pressure is no longer exerted.

images.alt_text: A giant sinkhole that was expanding by dozens of metres each day has alarmed residents in a rural area of central Mexico where it was threatening to swallow a house.

site_title: China considers new holding company for Huarong and three other bad-debt managers
summary: China's finance ministry is considering transferring its shares in China Huarong Asset Management and three other bad-debt managers to a new holding company modelled after the government's stakes in state-run banks. The move aims to separate the government's roles as regulator and shareholder, streamlining oversight and instilling a more professional management culture. Authorities are also discussing reducing the finance ministry's controlling stakes and bringing in external investors to address Huarong's debt challenges.

site_title: Flash Group becomes Thailand's first unicorn
summary: Flash Group, a Thailand-based e-commerce logistics startup, has become the country's first unicorn after raising $150 million in Series D+ and E funding. Founded by 29-year-old Komsan Lee just three years ago, the company aims to rank among the top three logistics firms in South-east Asia within five years, positioning Thailand as a regional logistics hub. Flash Express handles a daily peak parcel volume of two million items and plans to expand services, increase employee numbers to 40,000, and launch a financial service, with ambitions to go beyond the domestic market and initiate joint ventures.

site_title: EU agrees new tax transparency rules for multinationals
summary: The European Union has agreed on new tax transparency rules for multinationals with annual turnovers over $1.21 billion. The directive requires companies to declare profits, employees, and tax payments in each EU country where they operate, as well as on the EU's tax haven black list. The measure aims to increase scrutiny of major companies amid growing international pressure for greater transparency. The deal must still be formally approved by the EU parliament and council, with campaigners arguing the measures do not go far enough to combat tax avoidance.

images.alt_text: European Union member states and MEPs reached a deal on Tuesday on tougher tax transparency measures for multinationals as international pressure grows for greater scrutiny of major companies.

site_title: Spectre of data-driven 007 haunts MGM deal
summary: Amazon's acquisition of MGM, including the 50% stake in the James Bond franchise, has sparked concerns among screenwriters and industry experts about the potential impact on artistic control and the franchise's enduring quality. Writer John Logan, who worked on Bond films Skyfall and Spectre, warns that corporate partners may try to water down the franchise's edgy elements to appeal to a broader audience, leading to a loss of originality and uniqueness. He advocates for the Broccoli/Wilson family's continued protection of the franchise, which has allowed Bond to endure despite changing public tastes and corporate influences.

site_title: US: Stocks end little changed as oil shares surge
summary: US stocks ended Tuesday unchanged, despite a strong manufacturing report, as concerns over higher interest rates offset gains. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.1%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Indexes slipped 0.1%. Petroleum-linked shares surged, with Apache up 10% and Chevron 2.7% higher, as investors anticipate a reopening economy. Banking stocks also gained, with JPMorgan Chase, Citigroup, and Bank of America rising over 1%. Despite a rally in petroleum shares, markets remain cautious about inflation and potential interest rate hikes.

site_title: Europe's factory activity racing but supply squeeze dims outlook
summary: Europe's factory activity surged in May, with the Eurozone manufacturing PMI reaching 63.1, the highest since 1997, and Britain's PMI hitting a record 65.6. Despite the growth, supply chain disruptions and rising raw material costs pose a challenge, particularly in Asia where factory activity expanded at the fastest pace this year. China's PMI rose to 52.0, while Japan and South Korea's moderate growth underscores the fragile nature of their recoveries.

site_title: Biden suspends Trump-era oil and gas leases in Alaska refuge
summary: US President Joe Biden's administration suspended oil and gas leases in an Alaska wildlife refuge pending an environmental review, reversing a Trump-era effort to expand fossil fuel development. The decision, made on June 1, 2021, was welcomed by environmentalists and indigenous groups, who had sued to stop the lease sale. The leases, sold in January, received limited interest from the oil and gas industry and generated $14.4 million in high bids. A review will determine whether the leases stand, be voided, or be subject to mitigation measures, preserving the 19.6 million-acre habitat for polar bears and migratory birds.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure Trust to issue S$300m 4.3% perps
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust (KIT) plans to issue S$300 million 4.3% subordinated perpetual securities, with the coupon fixed at 4.3% until 2031, then resetting to the prevailing 10-year Singapore dollar Swap Offer Rate plus a 2.735% spread. The issue, under KIT's S$2 billion multicurrency debt program, will be led by DBS, HSBC, OCBC, and Standard Chartered. Net proceeds will refinance borrowings and fund working capital, capital expenditure, and investments. The Series 002 perps are expected to be issued on June 9.

site_title: China forces banks to hold more foreign currencies in reserve
summary: China's central bank has forced banks to hold 7% of their foreign exchange reserves, a 2 percentage point increase, effective June 15, to curb the surging yuan. The move aims to reduce the supply of dollars and other currencies, putting pressure on the yuan to weaken. Analysts say the direct impact may be small, but the move is a clear signal by the People's Bank of China that it is unhappy about the yuan's surge to a three-year high against the greenback.

site_title: SGX RegCo should require Aspen to provide regular updates on status of Honeywell deal
summary: Aspen's glove unit secured a US$210 million supply agreement with Honeywell International on April 13, but retracted the announcement on April 24 after discovering the deal had not been "consummated". The delay in retraction was attributed to a 24-hour communication turnaround between Aspen and Honeywell due to a time difference. SGX RegCo should require Aspen to provide regular updates on the deal's status to ensure investors are not blindsided by new developments. The deal's future remains uncertain, with Aspen stating that the ball is now in Honeywell's court.

site_title: Singtel, Sembcorp appoint new non-executive directors
summary: Singtel and Sembcorp Industries appointed new non-executive directors, Lim Swee Say and Tow Heng Tan, respectively. Lim, a former Singapore minister for manpower, joins Singtel's board, while Tow, current CEO of Pavilion Capital, joins Sembcorp's board as a non-executive, non-independent director. The appointments aim to enhance the boards' expertise and governance.

site_title: Monde Nissin ends first trading day flat, sets sights on US markets
summary: Monde Nissin, a Philippine food maker, listed on the stock market with a 48.6 billion pesos (S$1.3 billion) IPO, the country's largest. The company's shares ended trading at 13.48 pesos, flat with the IPO price. Monde Nissin aims to expand its presence in the US market, leveraging its market-leading position in the Philippines with popular brands like Lucky Me! instant noodles and SkyFlakes biscuits.

site_title: With limited fiscal power, Malaysia's latest stimulus package offers 'only slight relief'
summary: Malaysia's RM40 billion stimulus package, announced to combat the economic impact of the pandemic, is deemed insufficient by experts. Only RM5 billion is direct fiscal spending, which may not provide adequate relief to the hardest-hit groups. The package includes measures to support public hospitals, businesses, and poor households, but critics argue that daily Covid-19 infection numbers need to decrease for consumer confidence to return. The government aims to maintain a fiscal deficit in check while implementing the stimulus measures, which have been criticized for being insufficient.

site_title: Bitcoin's easing volatility sends bullish signal for some
summary: Bitcoin's recent price swings have eased, with the cryptocurrency rising 3.3% on Tuesday, its third straight day of gains. The 10-day volatility has fallen to 106% from a high of nearly 162% on May 24, leading some to view this as a tentative sign of recovery. Analysts, including Tom Lee of Fundstrat Global Advisors, see this as a positive sign that Bitcoin has bottomed, with some predicting it could exceed $125,000 by the end of the year.

site_title: Using data analytics to boost port industry connectivity in APAC
summary: Asia-Pacific's ports are crucial to the global economy, with the region contributing significantly to maritime trade. To operate effectively, ports must adopt smart technologies and improve data management, addressing challenges such as congestion, cyberattack risks, and supply chain resilience. Advanced ports, like the Port of Rotterdam and Port of Antwerp, are using technologies like drones and API platforms to enhance efficiency and collaboration. By embracing data analytics and smart technologies, ports can process cargo faster, reduce costs, and improve sustainability, ultimately transforming the region's port industry.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Lendlease Global Reit announced that its chairman Anthony Lombardo is stepping down to become CEO, with Ng Hsueh Ling taking his place. Ng, a Singapore managing director and Asia chief investment officer, will also serve as key executive officer of Lendlease Retail. Meanwhile, Keppel Land secured a S$150 million sustainability-linked loan from DBS, referencing the Singapore Overnight Rate Average. Wee Hur Holdings secured a S$176.7 million project from the Housing Development Board, with a 44-month construction period.

site_title: Growth in China home prices to sustain momentum in 2021: poll
summary: China's home prices are expected to grow 5% in 2021, exceeding previous forecasts, driven by strong demand in major cities despite Beijing's cooling measures. Authorities have implemented policies to curb speculation and financial risks. Home prices are expected to slow to 3% in the first half of 2022, and climbing land prices will continue to support housing prices. Despite this, analysts predict a long time before China enacts broad property tax reforms.

site_title: Towards ensuring all countries get a fair portion of multinationals' taxes
summary: The US has proposed a global minimum tax rate of 15% on corporations to combat a "race to the bottom" among countries offering tax incentives to attract business. This move is aimed at funding President Joe Biden's multi-trillion dollar infrastructure proposals. The proposal has been met with resistance from countries like Ireland, which has a corporate tax rate of 12.5%. The OECD has agreed to lower the target figure from 21% to 15% to facilitate international tax negotiations.

site_title: Australia central bank maintains policy as bond target looms
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) maintained its policy settings, keeping the cash rate and three-year yield target at 0.10% as it prepares to decide on extending its yield target and quantitative easing programs. A weeklong lockdown in Sydney complicates the outlook, but the RBA remains committed to supporting a return to full employment and inflation consistent with its 2-3% target. The decision will be made in July, and the RBA may extend its bond programs if the outbreak worsens, to maintain maximum support for the economy.

site_title: The short, the index, and the private markets
summary: Massimiliano Saccone, a CFA, argues that short positions and representative benchmarks are necessary for private market investments. He critiques the current lack of objective benchmarks for private equity, citing the subjective nature of past and future returns. Saccone proposes building benchmark indices that represent the physical allocation to unlisted private funds, with a short trade challenge as the objective criteria. This would provide a reference price in the market, contributing to democratization and product suitability. The creation of such benchmarks would benefit both general partners and investors, driving growth in the private equity asset class.

site_title: Olympic anxiety leaves Japanese sponsors counting the costs
summary: Around 60 Japanese companies, including Toyota, Bridgestone, and Panasonic, have invested a record $3.3 billion in the Tokyo Olympics, despite public opposition and concerns over the COVID-19 pandemic. Sponsors face challenges with Games-linked advertising and potential spectator bans, which could impact local firms' ticket and hospitality sales. Some business leaders, including Rakuten's CEO, have called the event a "suicide mission," but big sponsors may still benefit from the global audience. Local sponsors may be worst hit, but a mass defection is unlikely.

site_title: Covid war's many fronts: funding, sharing technology, adapting solutions
summary: The US is still battling the COVID-19 pandemic, with a focus on getting vaccine doses to as many people as possible. Key takeaways include the importance of rapid and accurate testing in nursing homes and schools, and the need for a global health system capable of monitoring infectious diseases and improving access to therapeutics. The pandemic will likely continue to hit in waves, and sharing technology and adapting practical solutions to local circumstances is crucial for saving lives and livelihoods.

site_title: Macau's gaming revenue beats May expectations as tourists return
summary: Macau's gaming revenue surged 492% in May, beating analyst expectations, as mainland Chinese tourists returned during the Labour Day Golden Week holiday. Revenue rose to 10.4 billion patacas (S$1.72 billion), a 24% increase from the previous month, but still down 60% from 2019. Daily visitor arrivals increased 158% during the holiday period, with 93% coming from China. However, gaming revenue dropped to 250 million patacas a day after the holiday, indicating a weak demand for the rest of the quarter.

site_title: Australian home prices surge in May as sales race past supply
summary: Australian home prices surged 2.2% in May, driven by super-low interest rates and strong demand, despite a general shortage of supply. Major cities like Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane, and Adelaide saw significant gains, with Sydney prices rising 3% and Melbourne adding 1.8%. This marks a 10.6% increase in national home prices over the past year, with consumer confidence boosted by improving economic conditions and low interest rates.

site_title: Singapore equities: Recovering, restructuring, rebalancing
summary: The Singapore equity market is expected to continue its ascent, driven by attractive stock valuations, a fast-recovering economy, and the country's safe haven status. The economy is recovering to pre-Covid-19 levels, with GDP growth forecast to reach 8% in 2021, and companies are restructuring to better suit the new economy. The MSCI Singapore Index is set to rebalance towards new economy sectors, including tech companies, which could raise tech exposure and improve the market's overall profile. Recent Covid-19 flare-ups are seen as a temporary speed bump, not a permanent roadblock to the growth path of the economy.

site_title: Shaken by Covid-19, some Americans try 'manifesting' a positive result
summary: Some Americans, shaken by Covid-19, are turning to "manifesting" - a mix of positive thinking and magical practices - to achieve their goals. The trend, popularized on TikTok, involves focusing one's thoughts and using materials like crystals and water to bring desired outcomes. A 19-year-old user, Baila Salifou, has shared a video on the app with nearly 500,000 views, detailing a simple method using Post-It notes and imagination. While the effectiveness of manifesting is unclear, it reflects a growing interest in alternative approaches to achieving success and well-being during the pandemic.

site_title: Asian refiners face a double blow to profits from Iran and Covid
summary: Asian refineries face a double blow to profits due to a resurgence of COVID-19 in India and other nations, reducing consumption of gasoline and jet fuel. This coincides with a likely surge in oil-product exports from Iran, if a nuclear deal is revived. Refining margins in Singapore have fallen to as low as three US cents a barrel, but are expected to rebound in the third quarter as vaccination rates aid demand.

site_title: China's increasing use of digital currency may speed use of yuan in cross-border trade
summary: China's increasing use of digital currency may accelerate the use of yuan in cross-border trade. The country's Digital Currency Electronic Payment (DCEP) trial has been launched in four major cities, with major financial institutions such as Ant Group and Tencent's WeBank participating. The e-yuan has the potential to boost international capital flows by reducing intermediation costs and increase financial inclusion. China's recent decision to participate in a multiple-CBDC project with other central banks could further promote the use of yuan in regional cross-border transactions. This development could potentially increase the yuan's influence on a regional basis, particularly with its major trading partners in Asia and the Belt and Road Initiative.

site_title: Empty streets and malls as Malaysia locks down for two weeks
summary: Malaysia has implemented a two-week national lockdown to combat a surge in COVID-19 cases, with Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin describing it as a "total lockdown" with essential services allowed. The lockdown is expected to impact the country's economic growth forecast, which may be revised downward due to the closure of major economic sectors. The government has announced an additional RM40 billion stimulus package to mitigate the effects, but some experts warn of a widening fiscal deficit and potential impact on the bond market.

site_title: Omni-channel retail is key to survival, but retailers may not be ready
summary: Traditional retailers are struggling to adapt to the shift to omni-channel retailing, which requires integrating physical and online formats to achieve business goals. Despite the annual Great Singapore Sale taking on an omni-channel format, few retailers are well-prepared to deliver seamless customer experiences. To survive, retailers must invest in infrastructure, retrain employees, and streamline supply-chain management systems. However, the shift to omni-channel also requires significant cost-cutting measures, with retailers potentially facing up to 50% cost reductions. Embracing partnerships, tax planning, and innovative supply-chain arrangements can help retailers thrive in the long term and mitigate the risks of the pandemic's impact on consumer behavior.

site_title: Push-pull factors driving deals for telco assets amid global boom
summary: The global telecommunications market has experienced a surge in mergers and acquisitions (M&A) deals, with 629 deals announced in 2020, valued at $263.42 billion. Sellers are looking for cash, while buyers seek yield, driven in part by the pandemic's increased online activities. Investors are attracted to telecoms assets due to their relatively stable cash flows and lower business risk profile. Deals involve various sectors, including tower infrastructure, data centers, and fiber networks. Experts expect sustained interest in telco investments, as the global digital economy continues to drive growth.

site_title: PE fund backed by rich Thais seeks distressed investments in South-east Asia
summary: 9 Basil, a private equity fund backed by Thailand's Chiaravanont family, is seeking distressed investments in South-east Asia to grow its portfolio. The fund has a pipeline of 30 potential investments, with 20 in real estate and the rest in consumer products, restaurants, and financial services. Founded by Schwin Chiaravanont and Kris Panijpan, 9 Basil aims to leverage its network and existing portfolio companies to capitalize on distressed opportunities in the region.

site_title: US dollar steadies, yuan slips on central bank's orders
summary: The US dollar hovered near five-month lows on Tuesday, losing to commodity currencies, as investors awaited economic data. The dollar index fell below 90, while the euro remained steady. Commodity currencies, such as the Australian and Norwegian dollars, rose against the dollar. China's yuan slipped despite a central bank move to limit its appreciation. The pound hit a three-year high, and the Canadian dollar was close to a six-year high.

site_title: International schools in Singapore feeling upbeat
summary: International schools in Singapore are optimistic about the upcoming academic year, despite tightened border restrictions. Student and staff intake numbers are looking encouraging, with some schools expecting a smooth start to the new year. Schools have developed virtual learning systems and implemented staff redeployment measures to mitigate the impact of the pandemic. Demand for international schools education remains unchanged, with parents viewing Singapore as a safe country due to its efficient handling of the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: All well in the galley?
summary: The International Chamber of Shipping (ICS) has released a new record book for ships' cooks, providing a global resource to track career progression, demonstrate competency, and record training and experience. The book is based on the International Labour Organization's guidelines and covers practical and safety skills, including cooking techniques and handling allergies and food intolerances. The ICS emphasizes the importance of good nutrition for seafarers, citing its impact on crew welfare, health, and morale, and notes that the quality of food on board is essential for efficient ship operation.

site_title: Active engagement is key to unlocking alpha in China
summary: Chinese companies are increasingly valuing engagement on environment, social, and governance (ESG) issues, creating opportunities for investors to generate alpha. Active shareholders can drive investment returns by constructively engaging with companies, assessing risk, and encouraging improvement. Proactive engagement involves suggesting ESG improvements, while remedial efforts address negative events. Chinese firms need improvement in disclosure, particularly on social factors, and investors should engage on talent attraction, supply chain management, and health and safety policies. Improved ESG disclosures can lead to better company quality, attracting investors and increasing share prices.

site_title: Hamptons boom creates a new world of luxury problems
summary: The Hamptons, a summer playground for New Yorkers, is experiencing a luxury boom, with home sales increasing 48% in the first quarter of 2021. The area is filled with wealthy visitors and locals, who are enjoying upscale boutiques, art galleries, and restaurants. However, this surge in tourism has also brought issues, such as overcrowding, noise, and concerns over data privacy. Residents are rallying around local businesses, but the area's high cost of living and lack of affordable housing remain significant problems.

site_title: WHO approves Sinovac Covid vaccine, the second Chinese-made dose listed
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has approved Sinovac's Covid-19 vaccine for emergency use listing, making it the second Chinese-made vaccine to receive the designation. The vaccine, branded CoronaVac, has been shown to be 51% effective in preventing symptomatic disease and 100% effective in preventing severe Covid-19 and hospitalization. The approval paves the way for the vaccine to be included in the Covax program, which aims to provide vaccines mainly for poor countries.

site_title: Top Glove's US$1 billion HK listing stalls in latest blow from US import ban: sources
summary: Top Glove Corporation's planned US$1 billion Hong Kong listing has stalled due to a US import ban on its products, which was imposed in July citing forced labour practices. The company had hoped to complete the listing by Q2, but now awaits word from US customs on whether the ban will be lifted. This delay is another setback for the Malaysian company, which has already faced a near four-fold gain in shares last year and a subsequent 17.3% loss in 2021.

site_title: Retail investors snap up China's first batch of Reits
summary: China's first batch of real estate investment trusts (Reits) were oversubscribed by retail investors, with over 30 billion yuan in subscriptions, exceeding 10 times the available amount. The nine Reits, worth 2 billion yuan, will invest in infrastructure projects and are initially not backed by commercial properties. Fund managers have suspended taking new subscriptions. The move is part of China's effort to channel private money into infrastructure projects to ease debt burdens on local governments, and investors expect premiums to the net assets of the Reits.

site_title: US manufacturing expands at faster pace on stronger orders
summary: US manufacturing expanded at a faster pace in May, with a gauge of factory activity rising to 61.2, indicating expansion. The increase in new orders and longest delivery times since 1974 suggests manufacturers continue to struggle with supply shortages, shipping delays, and difficulty finding skilled labor. Production expanded at the slowest pace in nearly a year, and the employment gauge dropped to 50.9, indicating labor obstacles are constraining factories.

site_title: 'Womenomics' author Matsui seeks to bring ESG to Japan startups
summary: Former Goldman Sachs vice-chair Kathy Matsui is launching a US$150 million venture fund, MPower Partners Fund, to invest in Japanese startups with environmental, social, and governance (ESG) values. Matsui, known for her "Womenomics" research, aims to integrate ESG into startups' business strategies to help them scale globally. The fund will target growth-stage startups in Japan and abroad, with a focus on influencing ESG principles from an early stage. The launch comes as ESG investment in Japan grows, with assets under management rising to US$35 billion.

site_title: Cannes gears up for film festival
summary: Cannes, France is gearing up for its film festival, which will take place from July 6-17, after being delayed from May due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The festival is expected to announce its lineup of Palme d'Or contenders on Thursday, with industry insiders speculating on a pick rich in big names. However, bookings for hotels and restaurants remain slow due to ongoing travel restrictions, with some hotels reporting only 10% occupancy in June. The festival is expected to bring in 20,000 attendees, down from 40,000 in pre-pandemic years, but is still a major economic driver for the city.

site_title: All 26 Hua Zai food outlets closed until June 14 due to likely Covid-19 transmission
summary: The Singapore Ministry of Health has closed all 26 Hua Zai food outlets until June 14 due to a likely Covid-19 transmission among staff and customers. Nine cases are linked to the NTUC Foodfare outlet, with seven unlinked cases reported, including a delivery rider and a resident with intellectual disabilities. The outlets will undergo deep cleaning to break the transmission chain. The closures are part of the ministry's efforts to contain the outbreak.

site_title: Opec+ set to sign off on July increase as market tightens
summary: Opec+ is set to stick to its plan to increase oil production in July, following hikes in May and June, amid a tight market. Saudi Arabia's energy minister, Prince Abdulaziz Salman, expressed a bullish tone about the global recovery, citing improved demand. However, the group is cautious due to concerns over the impact of new Covid-19 variants and Iran's potential return to international markets. The alliance plans to add 841,000 barrels in July, with a scheduled increase until April 2022 to rescue producers from a price war.

site_title: 26 Hua Zai food outlets to close till June 14 over likely Covid transmission
summary: The Ministry of Health in Singapore is investigating Covid-19 cases among Hua Zai food outlet staff, leading to the closure of all 26 outlets from June 1 to June 14 to prevent transmission. The closures will allow for deep cleaning of the premises. This move comes as Singapore continues to navigate the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: Sympathy for Osaka in Japan over French Open withdrawal
summary: Japanese fans and public figures rallied in support of tennis star Naomi Osaka after she withdrew from the French Open due to mental health concerns. Osaka, a four-time Grand Slam winner, revealed she has "suffered long bouts of depression" and will take time away from the court. Her decision follows controversy over her refusal to attend press conferences. Sympathy and understanding for Osaka's mental health issues were expressed, with some calling for a change in the tennis system to prioritize athlete well-being.

site_title: Thailand approves 140 billion baht in stimulus that includes cash handouts
summary: Thailand's government approved a 140 billion baht ($5.9 billion) economic stimulus package to counter the impact of its largest coronavirus outbreak, which has over 130,000 cases. The package includes cash handouts, co-payments, and cash rebates to target 51 million people, injecting 473 billion baht into the economy. The measures aim to support the economy, which is expected to grow 1.5-2.5% in 2021, but may experience an uneven K-shaped recovery, with exports supporting growth while tourism lags.

site_title: Taking the oil giants to court - and winning
summary: A group of rebels, including an environmental lawyer, pension fund executives, and the world's largest asset manager, won a series of victories against major fossil fuel companies, forcing them to address their role in the climate crisis. The lawsuits, filed in shareholder meetings and courtrooms, target companies to diversify and cut emissions. Despite differing perspectives, the rebels delivered a common message: the time to retreat from fossil fuels is now, not in the future. This marks a significant shift in the effort to hold oil and gas companies accountable for their impact on the climate crisis.

site_title: UK businesses implore Johnson to ease rules on June 21
summary: UK businesses, including the hospitality and nightlife industries, are urging Prime Minister Boris Johnson to ease coronavirus rules on June 21, citing concerns about a potential fresh wave of infections and job losses. Industry groups warn that a delay could push businesses to the brink of collapse, with 95% of businesses already committing funds to the reopening. The UK is hosting major events this year, including the Group of Seven and climate summits, and a delay could impact the economy and global reputation.

site_title: WHO, World Bank endorse IMF call for US$50b to fight virus
summary: The World Health Organization, World Bank, and World Trade Organization have endorsed the International Monetary Fund's call for a US$50 billion investment to combat COVID-19. The plan aims to immunize at least 40% of the global population by the end of 2021 and 60% by mid-2022, with a focus on low- and middle-income countries. The investment will boost vaccine production, testing, and tracing, and public health measures, potentially saving lives and delivering a US$9 trillion economic boost by 2025.

site_title: UK house prices jump by 10.9%, set to climb more
summary: UK house prices surged 10.9% in the past year, the largest annual increase in nearly seven years, driven by people seeking new homes post-pandemic. A survey by Nationwide found 70% of homeowners considering a move would proceed without a tax incentive extension. Economists warn of a risk of inflationary pressure if demand outstrips supply, while Nationwide expects further acceleration in house price growth in the coming months.

site_title: Thai delivery startup Flash raises US$150m, becomes 'unicorn'
summary: Thai logistics startup Flash Group has raised US$150 million in a recent fundraising round, pushing its overall value beyond US$1 billion, making it the first "unicorn" in Thailand. The company, founded in 2017, has 7,000 delivery points and 27,000 employees, with plans to expand in Southeast Asia and introduce payments services. The new investment comes amid strong e-commerce growth in Thailand, driven by prolonged coronavirus outbreaks and social restrictions.

site_title: J&J to pay US$2.1b talc award as top court rejects appeal
summary: The US Supreme Court has upheld a $2.1 billion verdict against Johnson & Johnson, requiring the company to pay damages to women who claimed its baby powder was contaminated with cancer-causing asbestos. The verdict, which was the largest in the company's almost decade-long litigation, was awarded to 20 women after a St Louis jury found the product helped cause ovarian cancer. The decision comes after J&J announced it was setting aside $4 billion to cover the verdict, and the company still faces over 25,000 lawsuits blaming baby powder for causing cancers.

site_title: EU to raise US$100b in bonds this year to finance stimulus
summary: The European Union plans to raise around $100 billion in long-term bonds and "tens of billions" in short-term bills this year to finance a landmark stimulus programme. EU member states have agreed to allow the Commission to raise up to $1.29 trillion in debt by 2026 to fund investments in green and digital policies. The stimulus fund sales will make the EU's executive arm the world's biggest issuer of social and green debt, with the goal of convincing hawkish countries to agree on a more permanent instrument.

site_title: Raffles Medical partners China Life unit to boost expansion in China
summary: Raffles Medical Group has partnered China Life Healthcare Investment Company to boost its expansion in China's healthcare market. The partnership, signed as part of a memorandum of understanding, aims to collaborate on initiatives in medical services, healthcare management, training, and financing. This marks Raffles Medical's continued investment in China, where it has established several hospitals, including Raffles Hospital Chongqing and Raffles Hospital Beijing. The partnership is expected to support ageing populations and bring quality and compassionate healthcare, along with financing solutions, to China.

site_title: Pope revises Church law, expands rules on sexual abuse
summary: Pope Francis has revised Catholic Church law, expanding rules on sexual abuse and introducing new categories, such as "grooming" minors or vulnerable adults for abuse and possessing child pornography. The revised section, involving about 80 articles, aims to "reduce the number of cases in which the imposition of a penalty was left to the discretion of authorities." The changes, which have been in the works since 2009, also include tougher regulations for clerics who commit fraud or ordain women.

site_title: StanChart offers digital tool for consumers to track climate impact of their card purchases
summary: Standard Chartered has partnered with fintech Doconomy to launch a digital tool that tracks the carbon and freshwater impact of customers' purchases through their credit and debit card transactions. The tool uses the Aland Index, which calculates the carbon and water footprints for each transaction. Customers can view their monthly and individual transaction impact across various lifestyle categories, enabling them to make informed choices to reduce their environmental impact. The tool will be piloted for customers in Pakistan later this year.

site_title: US: Optimism on reopening economy boosts stocks
summary: US stocks rose on Tuesday, boosted by optimism over the reopening of the US economy ahead of key government data, including the May jobs report. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.4% to 34,681.00, while the S&P 500 advanced 0.4% to 4,221.31. Analysts attribute the gain to "reopening enthusiasm" and a "sense of normalcy" as Americans return to crowded public spaces after the Memorial Day holiday. However, lingering worries about inflation and the uncertainty surrounding President Biden's infrastructure package may limit the upside for stocks.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's flag carrier Singapore Airlines (SIA) expects its $6.2 billion cash reserve to last until early 2023. The investor watchdog questioned SIA about potential privatisation and the issuance of convertible bonds. Meanwhile, SingPost group CEO Paul Coutts has resigned to pursue other opportunities. Heritas Capital has raised $150 million for its third growth fund. The STI rose 0.73% to 3,187.23 points, following a similar trend in Asian markets.
