The Fair Tenancy Industry Committee has been established to ensure compliance with a new code of conduct for retail tenancies in Singapore.

images.alt_text: SIA sees the S$6.2 billion to be raised from the issuance of mandatory convertible bonds (MCBs) will last it through to the financial year ending March 2023.

site_title: Zenyum secures US$40m in Series B funds led by L Catterton
summary: Zenyum, a cosmetic dental startup, has secured US$40 million in Series B funding led by L Catterton. The round was also joined by existing investors, bringing the company's valuation to US$53.7 million. The funds will be used to accelerate expansion across Asia, deepen product offerings, and develop technology. L Catterton sees Zenyum as a potential regional champion in the growing affordable dental cosmetics market, fueled by aesthetic-conscious millennials in Asia.

site_title: More property firms secure green, sustainable finance
summary: Keppel Land, the property arm of Keppel, secured a S$150 million, five-year sustainability-linked loan from DBS, referencing the Singapore Overnight Rate Average (Sora). The loan incorporates interest rate reductions linked to environmental, social, and governance targets. This is Keppel's second green loan facility, following a 2019 S$176 million loan for the development of Seasons City in China. The loan proceeds will be used for general corporate purposes, including refinancing debt and new development projects.

site_title: STI up 0.73%, in line with most Asian markets
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.73% to 3,187.23 points, tracking Asian peers. Gainers outpaced losers 311 to 202, with Oceanus Group being the most active stock, closing 5.26% higher. Most Asian markets also reported gains, while Australia's S&P/ASX 200 Index and Japan's Nikkei 225 Index declined for the second consecutive day.

site_title: Trading starts under Shanghai-Hong Kong ETF Connect
summary: Shanghai's exchange-traded fund (ETF) market has exceeded 1 trillion yuan (S$207.1 billion) in capitalization, making it the world's sixth largest. Trading started under the Shanghai-Hong Kong ETF Connect, with the first pair of ETFs listed on Tuesday. This move solidifies Shanghai's ETF market as Asia's second-largest by market cap, but largest by trading volume.

site_title: Myanmar junta moves Aung San Suu Kyi to 'unknown location'
summary: Myanmar's junta has relocated Aung San Suu Kyi and ex-president Win Myint to an unknown location, sparking concerns for their safety. The two leaders were held by the military since the coup on February 1. Suu Kyi faces six criminal charges, including violating state secrets and incitement, while Win Myint is charged with incitement and breaching Covid-19 restrictions. The National Unity Government, led by Suu Kyi's party, has urged the junta to take responsibility for their actions and ensure accountability. Suu Kyi's lawyers reported no contact with her after a court appearance on May 24.

images.alt_text: Myanmar's junta has moved the nation's civilian leader Aung San Suu Kyi and ex-president Win Myint from their residences in the capital to an "unknown location," according to allies who've expressed serious concerns for their safety.

site_title: Malaysia says Chinese military planes came close to violating airspace
summary: Malaysia's air force reported that 16 Chinese military transport planes flew close to its airspace over the South China Sea, prompting a scramble of jets for visual confirmation. The planes, which did not contact air traffic control, were detected 60 nautical miles off the coast of Sarawak state. The incident occurred on June 1, 2021.

site_title: Wee Hur bags S$176.7m construction project from HDB
summary: Wee Hur Holdings secured an S$176.7 million construction project from the Housing and Development Board, covering building and contingency works in Bidadari, with a 44-month construction period. The project is expected to have a minimal impact on the company's financials. Shares of Wee Hur closed flat at S$0.205 on the day of the announcement.

site_title: Australia: Shares weighed by banks amid coronavirus lockdowns
summary: Australia's shares fell 0.4% on the first day of the new financial year due to lockdowns to curb the Delta variant of coronavirus. The S&P/ASX 200 index dropped to 7,285.1 points, with Commonwealth Bank and ANZ Banking Corp shedding 0.7% and 0.6% respectively. Gold stocks rose 1%, while technology stocks fell 0.1%. New Zealand's benchmark index remained flat.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end on a healthy note
summary: Hong Kong stocks finished Tuesday on a healthy note, with the Hang Seng Index rising 1.08% to 29,468.00, following a rally across most Asian markets. Optimism over the global recovery and upcoming US jobs data fueled the gains. Meanwhile, the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw increases of 0.26% and 0.41%, respectively.

site_title: Twitter's website back up after being down for several users
summary: Twitter's website experienced an outage affecting over 6,000 users, with 93% of reports related to the website. The issue was resolved late on Wednesday, with profile tweets not loading for some users. Twitter acknowledged the problem but didn't specify the cause, working on a fix. The outage was tracked by Downdetector, a website that collates status reports from users.

site_title: 15 new Covid-19 community cases in Singapore, including seven unlinked
summary: Singapore reported 15 new Covid-19 community cases, including seven unlinked, bringing the total to 62,069. Of the 15 community cases, 8 linked cases were detected, with 6 already on quarantine and 2 through surveillance. 3 imported cases were also reported, with 2 being Singaporeans or permanent residents. No new cases were reported from within workers' dormitories. The Ministry of Health will provide more details on Tuesday night.

site_title: BHP union says work schedules too punishing for train drivers
summary: BHP's new train driver roster, requiring 2 weeks on and 1 week off, has been criticized by the CFMEU Mining & Energy Division as damaging to mental health and family relationships. The roster, which will be in effect until at least August 2022, is seen as a temporary measure to address a skills shortage. The union argues that drivers will only have 5 days to see their families due to travel time. BHP attributes the roster to the skills shortage and is recruiting more drivers.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 2.35 points to 1,585.90 on Tuesday, driven by a 587-525 gain/loss ratio. The index closed higher despite global market uncertainty, following a 5-day rally in Singapore and a 0.4% gain in the STI index. US stocks, including the S&P 500 and Nasdaq, reached fresh records, while investors await US-EU trade talks and tariff developments.

site_title: Greenback set for best month in 4½ years
summary: The US dollar is on track for its largest monthly gain in 4.5 years, rising 2.5% against a basket of currencies in June, driven by the Federal Reserve's hawkish shift in rates outlook and concerns over the Delta coronavirus variant. The US dollar index is steady at 92.041, with the euro at $1.1900 and the yen at 110.49 per dollar. The next major test of the US dollar outlook is US labour data, due this week, which could influence the timeline for rate hikes and inflationary pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Alexandra Hospital ward re-opens 14 days after staff tests positive for Covid-19
summary: A ward at Alexandra Hospital in Singapore has reopened 14 days after staff tested positive for Covid-19. The hospital banned visitors and placed staff and patients on quarantine after a staff member tested positive on May 18. Nineteen staff and nine patients have since been cleared, and the hospital has stepped up routine swab testing. The hospital expressed gratitude to those who showed support, including a former patient who bought food for staff and others who donated hawker food and bento sets. The hospital's CEO emphasized the need to stay vigilant in the ongoing battle with Covid-19.

site_title: China wants more babies but some men choose vasectomies
summary: In China, a growing trend of "Double Income, No Kids" (DINK) lifestyle is leading some men to opt for vasectomies to avoid parenthood. Despite the government's new three-child policy, many young people are choosing to remain childless due to economic concerns and a desire for personal freedom. Insurance companies, matchmaking agencies, and housing agents are catering to this demographic, with some men even posting about their vasectomy experiences online to change societal perceptions. Experts attribute this shift to the country's shrinking population and the rising cost of raising a child, with some estimating the direct economic cost of raising a child to be seven times the annual salary of the average Chinese citizen.

site_title: Malaysia's king seeks special parliamentary sitting before Aug 1
summary: Malaysia's King has requested a special parliamentary sitting before August 1 due to the ongoing COVID-19 surge and lockdown. The request comes after Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin was hospitalized with diarrhea. The King's decree, relayed to the prime minister, aims to discuss steps taken to address the health and economic crises caused by the pandemic. The parliament is expected to reconvene by September, once the daily new coronavirus infections fall to under 2,000 cases.

site_title: Lazada president Jessica Liu to leave e-commerce company
summary: Lazada president Jessica Liu is leaving the e-commerce company after a year and a half, citing a desire to spend more time with her family. Liu led LazMall, the online marketplace on Lazada, and was also CEO of Thailand operations. Current CEO James Dong has taken on the additional role of CEO of Thailand. Liu joined Lazada in 2020 from Alibaba, where she was general manager of Tmall Fashion and Luxury. This is the third change in Lazada's senior management since 2018.

site_title: JustCo signs agreement with Ho Bee Land to manage space at The Metropolis
summary: JustCo, a coworking operator, has signed an agreement with Ho Bee Land to manage approximately 35,000 square feet of office space in The Metropolis in Singapore. The space, set to open in 2022, will feature flexible space solutions and optimise the sharing of assets and amenities. This marks JustCo's second collaboration with Ho Bee Land, following their previous partnership in 2021. JustCo has shifted towards an "asset-light" model, focusing on managing space for landlords rather than taking on long-term leases.

site_title: Cutting down trees can help save climate in forest industry maths
summary: Sweden's forest industry has released a study suggesting that cutting trees can help combat climate change by displacing fossil materials, resulting in smaller carbon dioxide emissions. The industry argues that a "carbon debt" calculation is nonsensical in sustainably managed forests like Sweden, where trees are replanted. The study's findings contradict climate activists' concerns that forestry accumulates a carbon debt due to trees taking decades to grow back. Industry leaders claim that harvesting trees and replacing fossil materials with bio-products is the most effective way to reduce emissions.

site_title: Global tax rules will need to come as a package deal
summary: The Group of Seven (G-7) has endorsed a minimum corporate tax rate of at least 15%, rekindling hopes for a global consensus on new international tax rules. The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) Inclusive Framework is negotiating the proposals, with a key meeting on July 1. A package of rules, including sector exclusions and pre-existing tax incentives, is expected to be agreed upon, with a global minimum tax rate linked to sector exclusions. Pillar One will apply to the largest 100 companies with a US$20 billion revenue threshold, while Pillar Two will target companies with a US$1 billion revenue threshold, subject to a 15% global minimum tax rate.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks fall on virus variant woes, firm dollar; focus on US data
summary: South Korean stocks fell 0.44% on Thursday, closing at 3,282.06, due to concerns over the spread of the Covid-19 Delta variant and a strengthening US dollar ahead of a US jobs report. The won weakened, and foreigners sold 407.4 billion won worth of shares. Despite this, South Korean exports marked a fourth consecutive month of double-digit growth in June, and factory activity continued to grow.

site_title: Telcos must convince clients that they can be trusted and successful vendors for the 5G journey
summary: Singapore's telcos, Singtel and StarHub, must convince small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to adopt 5G technology, as the returns on infrastructure are expected to come from industry rather than consumer spending. Despite launching standalone 5G networks, telcos still need to present themselves as compelling partners for enterprises, offering end-to-end solutions and a clear roadmap for implementation. With SMEs holding 18% of businesses seeing telcos as digital transformation experts, telcos must demonstrate their capabilities beyond providing mere connectivity.

site_title: Shanghai: Stocks open higher
summary: Mainland Chinese stocks rose on Thursday as investors monitor the spread of the Delta virus variant. The Shanghai Composite Index increased 0.26% to 3,600.55, while the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.23% to 2,471.79. Hong Kong stocks remained closed due to a public holiday.

site_title: Australian regulator may authorise media group talks with Google, Facebook
summary: Australia's competition watchdog has issued draft proposals to authorise regional newspaper industry group Country Press Australia to negotiate with Google and Facebook for payments for news content on their platforms. The group, which represents 81 news publishers, seeks to address the bargaining power imbalance between digital giants and local news outlets. The proposed 10-year authorisation follows an interim authorisation granted in April, and comes after Australia passed a law mandating the US tech giants to pay media companies for news content.

site_title: Hot stock: Singtel up 0.9%, iFast surges 2.5% after digital bank licence applications
summary: Shares of Singtel and iFast rose after both companies announced their applications for a digital bank license in Malaysia. Singtel gained 0.9% to S$2.31, while iFast surged 2.5% to S$8.35. iFast will take a 40% stake in the digital bank if the application is successful. No merger and acquisition deals were recorded for either company in early trade. The news comes ahead of GDP data, which may impact market sentiment.

site_title: Italians aghast as notorious mafia killer released
summary: Italy is outraged over the release of notorious mafia killer Giovanni Brusca, who was freed from prison after serving a 25-year sentence. Brusca, 64, was released on probation after becoming a state's witness, despite being a key figure in the Cosa Nostra and responsible for the 1992 assassination of prosecutor Giovanni Falcone and the gruesome murder of a 12-year-old boy, Giuseppe Di Matteo, whose body was dissolved in acid. The move has sparked widespread dismay, with politicians and families of the victims condemning Brusca's release.

site_title: China confirms first human case of bird flu strain
summary: China has reported the world's first human infection of the H10N3 bird flu strain, a 41-year-old man admitted to hospital with fever symptoms in April. The risk of large-scale spread is considered extremely low, according to the National Health Commission, which described the strain as low pathogenic in birds. This is the first reported human case of H10N3 globally, and mass outbreaks in humans are rare. China has experienced outbreaks of bird flu in the past, but human cases have been limited, with the last outbreak occurring in 2016-2017.

site_title: German unemployment falls as economy starts to shrug off virus
summary: Germany's unemployment rate fell to 6% in May, with 2.74 million people out of work, as the economy starts to recover from the pandemic. The decline of 15,000 jobs was lower than expected, with economists attributing it to supply-chain disruptions. Germany's vaccination campaign has led to the loosening of restrictions, allowing shops and cultural venues to reopen. The labor market shows signs of improvement, but economists predict a slow recovery for the euro area, where unemployment remains higher than before the pandemic.

site_title: Thai Cabinet approves S$5.95b stimulus package amid new outbreak
summary: Thailand's government approved a S$5.95 billion (140 billion baht) economic stimulus package to counter the impact of its biggest coronavirus outbreak yet, which has totaled over 130,000 cases since April. The measures include cash handouts, co-payments, and cash rebates, set to be implemented from July. The package is on top of an 85.5-billion baht package last month, and the government is also considering a further US$16 billion borrowing plan to finance relief measures. The stimulus aims to support the economy, which is expected to grow 1.5-2.5% in 2021, down from initial forecasts of 2.5-3.5%.

site_title: CapitaLand sells 2 malls for 42b yen; to invest 7.5b yen in 2nd Japan logistics asset
summary: CapitaLand has sold two retail malls in the Greater Tokyo area for approximately 42 billion yen (S$520 million), marking the group's exit from retail in Japan. The proceeds will be reinvested in new economy assets, including a 7.5 billion yen investment in a logistics asset in Ibaraki City, Osaka. This transaction follows the divestment of the group's five malls in Japan, with the total expected gain nearing 9 billion yen.

site_title: Water futures market fails to make a splash with California farmers
summary: The world's first water futures contract launched in California in December 2021, but it has failed to attract significant interest from farmers, despite efforts by the CME Group to promote it. The contract is based on an index tracking water rights leases and sales, but trades settle in money, not water, making it useless for solving real-world shortages. Farmers say the contract is too illiquid and cannot be used without impacting prices, limiting its usefulness.

site_title: Shinvest to record S$2.8m gain from further disposal of Espressif Systems shares
summary: Shinvest, a precision manufacturer, has disposed of 245,491 shares of Espressif Systems, a China-based fabless semiconductor firm, generating net cash proceeds of S$11.5 million. The disposal is expected to result in a gain before tax of S$2.8 million. The company's pro forma net tangible assets per share and earnings per share are expected to increase. Proceeds from the disposal will be used for general working capital purposes and investment opportunities.

site_title: Finian Tan, top lawyers Thio Shen Yi, Sunil Sudheesan, among alleged victims in S$1b nickel scam
summary: Singaporean businessman Ng Yu Zhi, 34, is alleged to have swindled investors into putting at least S$1 billion into non-existent nickel deals. He faces 31 charges, including 13 new ones, and is accused of a S$200 million breach of trust. Notable victims include Thio Shen Yi, Sunil Sudheesan, and Finian Tan, who lost S$5.5 million, S$1 million, and S$87,000 respectively. Ng is out on S$1.5 million bail and is expected to appear in court on July 5 for a bail review.

site_title: Australian job vacancies surge to record, firms struggle to find workers
summary: Job vacancies in Australia reached record highs in the May quarter, with 57% above pre-pandemic levels. Vacancies surged 23.4% to 362,500, 132,000 higher than in February 2020. Businesses across all sectors reported difficulties in filling vacancies, with 22% of businesses reporting at least one vacancy. The private sector led the charge, with positions rising by almost a quarter, while the public sector vacancies grew 10%. This boost in employment has driven the jobless rate down to 5.1%, far from the top of 7.5% hit last July.

site_title: United Airlines unveils huge jet order in bet on travel recovery
summary: United Airlines has ordered 270 new planes, including 200 Boeing aircraft and 70 Airbus jets, valued at $35.4 billion. The order is the largest in the airline's history and represents a bet on a travel industry recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic. Despite the order, United and other major airlines are expected to report another quarterly loss due to the ongoing travel crisis. Business travel volumes remain down 60% and international travel is off even more, according to CEO Scott Kirby.

site_title: Dollar-cost averaging and compounding: low-risk, easy strategies for new investors
summary: Investors can achieve a $1-million portfolio through dollar-cost averaging and compounding, two low-risk strategies. Dollar-cost averaging involves investing a fixed sum at regular intervals, regardless of market price, to smooth out volatility and limit losses. Compounding generates additional returns from prior returns, leading to faster portfolio growth. By investing $300 monthly for 40 years at an 8% annual rate, starting with $300, one can reach $1 million, with a total investment of $144,000.

site_title: Sudan rejects Ethiopian plan to fill giant dam a second time: senior official
summary: Sudan has rejected an Ethiopian proposal to fill the reservoir behind the Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam for a second time, deepening a regional dispute over the project. The proposal, which would involve the second filling of the reservoir, is opposed by both Sudan and Egypt, which fear impacts on their water supplies. Sudan considers the proposal "not real" and "a way to buy time," and has indicated a willingness to consider a partial interim agreement before the second filling, but only under the auspices of AU mediators and involving all parties.

site_title: Taiwan's Covid-19 cases fall to month-and-a-half low
summary: Taiwan reported its lowest daily rise in domestic Covid-19 infections in 1-1/2 months, with 60 new cases on Monday, down from 88 the previous day. Health Minister Chen Shih-chung attributed the decline to curbs imposed on gatherings and urged caution, as the highly contagious Delta variant remains a concern. Mass testing continues in Pingtung, and the government is hastening its vaccination programme, which has been hampered by global shortages.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei ends flat as investors cautious ahead of US data
summary: Japan's benchmark Nikkei index ended flat at 28,084.02 on Monday, weighed down by chip-related stocks due to muted Nasdaq trade and investors' caution ahead of key US economic data. The Topix edged up 0.15% despite a 0.05% decline in the Topix Growth Index and a 0.35% gain in the Topix Value Index. US economic reports, including jobs data, will influence investor sentiment later this week.

site_title: China dismisses concern for Hong Kong freedom after tabloid closure
summary: China's foreign ministry dismissed US President Joe Biden's concerns about Hong Kong's repression after the closure of Apple Daily newspaper, stating it was a normal business decision. China also approved promotions for officials, including Hong Kong's security secretary John Lee to chief secretary, seen as tightening Beijing's grip. The moves were criticized by critics, who say they further restrict Hong Kong's autonomy.

site_title: New chairmen for SingHealth, NHG
summary: The Minister for Health has appointed Cheng Wai Keung as the new chairman of Singapore Health Services (SingHealth) for a three-year term starting July 1, 2021, replacing Peter Seah Lim Huat. Tan Tee How will assume the role of chairman of National Healthcare Group (NHG) until April 14, 2024, replacing Kay Kuok Oon Kwong. Both new chairmen aim to enhance clinical outcomes, provide value-driven care, and lead key infrastructure projects, while deepening strategic partnerships and collaborations.

site_title: Athena to install 1,500 cryptocurrency ATMs in El Salvador
summary: Athena Bitcoin plans to install 1,500 cryptocurrency ATMs in El Salvador, particularly in areas where residents receive remittances from abroad. The company will invest over $1 million and expects to start with dozens of machines, testing the business model before expanding. This follows El Salvador's adoption of bitcoin as legal tender in June, with President Nayib Bukele promoting its use as a remittance currency. The move aims to support the country's bitcoin economy and follows Athena's previous installation of a cryptocurrency ATM in El Zonte beach, El Salvador.

site_title: More intervention, support needed for Singapore infrastructure sector: report
summary: A joint report by the Singapore Business Federation and KPMG has recommended that more intervention and support are needed for Singapore's infrastructure sector to grow at home and succeed overseas. The report suggests providing subsidized access to shared services, help in forming consortiums, and an export-import bank to boost local participation in infrastructure projects. Recommendations also include setting up a national infrastructure development unit, developing local talent, and providing grants for research and development. The report aims to help local firms focus on key business activities and capture global market share in strategic sectors.

site_title: NTUC Income offering usage-based coverage for electric vehicles
summary: NTUC Income will offer usage-based motor insurance (UBI) for electric vehicles (EVs) in Singapore, allowing drivers to pay premiums pegged to their mileage. The move aims to accelerate EV adoption amid the Singapore Green Plan 2030, which includes reducing carbon emissions by transitioning to EVs. Three UBI plans will be available, catering to different lifestyles, and customers can track and monitor their mileage and premiums on a new self-service platform. The insurance cooperative will partner with Carro to integrate its pricing system with in-vehicle telematics technology.

site_title: Singapore shares close flat on Thursday as regional markets struggle for direction
summary: Singapore shares closed flat on Thursday, with the benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) rising 0.03% to 3,119.62. Markets in the region struggled for direction, with Asia-wide gains ranging from 0.2% to 1.3%. DBS Group Research sees potential benefits from domestic reopening, including public transportation and retail Reits. Analysts predict a return to more directional moves next week, driven by US Federal Reserve speaker headlines.

site_title: It's half-time at a breathtaking Euro 2020
summary: The Euro 2020 tournament has reached its halfway mark, with 16 teams advancing to the knockout stage. Italy, Belgium, and the Netherlands are the top teams with a perfect winning record in the group stage. The Czech Republic's Patrik Schick scored a record-breaking 45-meter goal, while Austria has pulled off a surprise by qualifying for the knockout phase for the first time. Conversely, Turkey has been eliminated after a dismal performance, and Denmark's Christian Eriksen has overcome a cardiac arrest to continue playing. The knockout stage is set to produce more thrilling matches, including a potential showdown between Austria and Italy.

site_title: EQC is an electric car with star quality
summary: Mercedes has launched the EQC, its first mainstream pure-electric car for Singapore, marking the debut of its new label Mercedes-EQ. The five-door, five-seat EQC has a 80kWh battery, all-wheel drive, and 408 horsepower, and costs S$298,888, including a Certificate Of Entitlement. The company aims to have a carbon-neutral fleet by 2039 and will consider carbon emissions by suppliers. Mercedes plans to launch a six-model lineup by the end of 2022, including the EQA and EQS, and will offer plug-in hybrids and 48V mild hybrid technology to cater to different customer needs.

site_title: ByteDance founder donates 500m yuan amid China billionaires' charity rush
summary: ByteDance founder Zhang Yiming has donated 500 million yuan (S$104.1 million) to Longyan, China, to support education and vocational training, particularly in rural areas. This move follows a charity rush by Chinese tech billionaires, including Meituan's Wang Xing and Alibaba's Jack Ma, amid China's crackdown on the tech sector. Zhang's donation will establish the "Meifang Foundation," which aims to assist teachers with advanced education and promote vocational education.

site_title: Settlement reached over ship that blocked Suez Canal
summary: A settlement has been reached between the owner and insurers of the Ever Given, the container ship that blocked the Suez Canal in March, and the Egyptian authorities. The terms of the agreement were not disclosed, but the ship is expected to complete its journey through the canal after nearly three months of negotiations. The Suez Canal Authority had sought up to $1 billion in compensation, but the settlement will allow the ship to proceed without paying the full amount. The ship's crew, who were stuck in limbo for months, will be able to disembark once the agreement is finalized.

site_title: Yangzijiang rises on building deals for 14 vessels worth US$715m
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding secured agreements to build and deliver 14 vessels worth US$715 million, resulting in a 0.73% increase in its stock price to S$1.39. The vessels include 40,000 cu m liquefied petroleum gas carriers, marking a breakthrough for the company and recognition of its strengths in clean-energy vessel design. The new orders bring the group's total contract value for this year to US$4.72 billion, its largest number of order wins since 2008, with deliveries set to take place between 2022 and 2024.

site_title: The Games must go on - at what cost?
summary: The 2021 Tokyo Olympics are set to proceed despite cost overruns, reduced spectatorship due to pandemic rules, and rising COVID-19 infections in the city. The estimated price tag for the Games has ballooned to $15.4 billion, a 22% increase from the previous year's estimate, with $900 million allocated for COVID-19 counter-measures. Foreign spectators have been banned, limiting local spectators to 50% capacity, and athletes will be restricted in movement. Despite concerns, International Olympic Committee (IOC) officials and sponsors remain committed to the event, citing the potential economic benefits and the privilege of participation for athletes.

site_title: Future-focused: Michael Dell, founder and CEO of Dell Technologies
summary: Michael Dell, founder and CEO of Dell Technologies, remains optimistic about the post-pandemic future, envisioning a digital wave that will shape the future of businesses. Despite the devastating effects of Covid-19, Dell sees opportunities in digital transformation, work-from-home, and multi-cloud adoption. The company is benefiting from the shift to digitalization, with Dell Technologies Capital investing in over 124 companies since 2012, valued at over $140 billion. Dell plans to spin off VMware, unlocking significant value for stakeholders, and maintain its investment-grade status. He believes that the future will be driven by technologies like 5G, AI, and edge computing, and that organizations must adapt to these changes to remain competitive.

site_title: Local data centre provider Digital Edge acquires Indonesia's Indonet for US$165m
summary: Digital Edge, a Singapore-based data centre provider, has acquired a controlling interest in Indonesian digital infrastructure service provider Indonet for $165 million. The acquisition enables Digital Edge to expand its presence in South-east Asia and offers Indonesian firms a regional platform to expand globally. Indonet, founded in 1994, owns self-built fibre assets and offers internet connectivity services. The deal is expected to capitalize on Indonesia's growing market, with a projected co-location market value of $625 million by 2025.

site_title: Double joy as Tokyo panda gives birth to twins
summary: A panda at Tokyo's Ueno Zoo gave birth to twins, a first for the facility, weeks after news of Shin Shin's pregnancy sparked a surge in stocks of nearby restaurants. The mother panda is in good health, and both cubs are receiving care. Zookeepers will be swapping the babies to simulate natural feeding, and the birth has been welcomed by the Japanese government, with a spokesperson calling it "cheerful news."

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 1.78 points to 1,574.02. Volume reached 5.903 billion lots worth RM3.075 billion, with 528 gainers outnumbering 481 losers.

site_title: World's most bubbly housing markets flash 2008 style warnings
summary: Real estate prices worldwide are flashing warning signs similar to the 2008 financial crisis, according to Bloomberg Economics. New Zealand, Canada, and Sweden are among the world's most frothy housing markets, with the UK and US also near the top of the risk rankings. Record low interest rates, fiscal stimulus, and limited housing stock are contributing to the unprecedented price growth. The risk of a correction is higher, but economists believe a cooling rather than collapse is more likely, with synchronized booms in house prices posing the greatest risk.

site_title: Messaging maestro David Gurle, Symphony founder
summary: David Gurle, founder of the Symphony communications platform, has retired after six and a half years at the helm. Gurle, who spent over a decade in the industry before becoming a technopreneur, built Symphony into a US$1.4 billion company with over 500 clients globally. He envisioned a future where communication networks become the "new operating system of work," complemented by artificial intelligence, and will continue to be involved with the company as a board member. Gurle plans to focus on writing a book and spending time with his family in the south of France.

site_title: US: S&P 500 ends at record as ECB holds steady on monetary policy
summary: The S&P 500 closed at a record high on Thursday as investors largely shrugged off higher-than-expected US inflation data, which rose to 5% in May. The European Central Bank held steady on monetary policy, contributing to a decline in European equities. Despite concerns over US inflation, the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records, with the S&P 500 finishing at an all-time high.

site_title: Navigating the data centre boom
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

The global data centre market is booming, with 130 deals worth US$32.4 billion in 2020. Emerging markets such as China, India, and Indonesia are leading the growth story, with Asia-Pacific expected to reach US$45.8 billion by 2025. However, data centres are significant energy guzzlers, accounting for 2% of global greenhouse-gas emissions and expected to rise to 14% by 2040. Stakeholders are exploring sustainable solutions, such as renewable energy and green power procurement, to mitigate the environmental impact. Despite challenges, the data centre sector is expected to continue growing, driven by increasing demand for cloud computing and digital services.

site_title: Palm oil futures tumble 10% on cheaper soya bean oil, but prices to stay elevated
summary: Palm oil futures plummeted 10% on Monday due to a decline in soya bean oil prices, caused by concerns over US biofuel blending requirements and Midwest rain. Despite some market watchers predicting prices will recover, most expect prices to remain elevated, with Fitch Solutions forecasting palm oil to average RM3,400 per tonne this year, the highest level since 2000.

site_title: Covid debt restructuring push not advanced enough, IMF chief cautions
summary: IMF chief Kristalina Georgieva cautions that efforts to restructure unsustainable debt burdens in poor countries have not made enough progress. The "Common Framework" debt relief plan, which involves private sector banks and governments agreeing to writeoff or postpone repayments, has only been utilized by three countries so far. Georgieva emphasizes the need for continued work to address concerns about defaulting on debt and its impact on international borrowing markets.

site_title: Effort of internationalising yuan cannot be rushed
summary: China's efforts to internationalize its yuan cannot be rushed, requiring a phased approach in tandem with capital account liberalization. The country must address domestic financial market development, global support and cooperation, and technological advancements to make the yuan a viable international currency. China has adopted a gradual approach, prioritizing stable economic growth and implementing a managed floating exchange rate regime. The internationalization of the yuan also faces controversy, with concerns over the flaws of using a sovereign currency as a reserve currency or for international transactions, and the potential for digital currencies to replace traditional currencies.

site_title: Jho Low, Fugees member charged with bid to get Trump administration to drop 1MDB probe
summary: A federal grand jury has indicted Malaysian financier Jho Low and former Fugees member Prakazrel "Pras" Michel on charges of money-laundering conspiracy and witness tampering. They allegedly lobbied the Trump administration to drop the 1MDB investigation and extradite a Chinese dissident. Michel's lawyer claims the case is a selective prosecution targeting Michel, and Michel intends to defend himself vigorously. The two men previously faced charges of funneling millions of dollars into the US presidential election as legitimate campaign contributions.

site_title: ECB in hot seat over easy money as economy strengthens
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is under pressure to maintain its easy monetary policies as the eurozone economy strengthens. The ECB is expected to hold interest rates at historic lows and continue its massive bond purchasing schemes, despite inflation surging past its target. The bank's president, Christine Lagarde, will face questions about how to wean the economy off crisis support. Economists expect the ECB to maintain its pace of bond purchases until the economy shows signs of overheating, with some predicting a potential tapering of support as early as September.

images.alt_text: Markets will be looking for clues on Thursday on when the European Central Bank might start winding down monetary stimulus, as the economic rebound from the pandemic accelerates and eurozone inflation surges past the bank's target.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens little changed
summary: US stocks opened flat on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones and S&P 500 indices gaining 0.1% each. Investors are assessing the threat of inflation to the recovery, with the 10-year US Treasury yield slipping. Meanwhile, President Joe Biden and Senate Republicans ended negotiations on an infrastructure package, and meme stocks like AMC Entertainment and Clover Health Investment saw significant price swings.

site_title: Asia: Markets rise ahead of jobs data but Federal Reserve taper talk builds
summary: Asian markets rose ahead of US jobs data, with oil prices also gaining as investors expect a surge in activity and demand. The Federal Reserve's ultra-loose monetary policies are being reassessed amid a robust economic recovery and increasing inflation concerns. Expectations for a potential taper of the Fed's bond-buying program have increased, causing traders to remain cautious. The recovery in the jobs market is seen as not as smooth as hoped, with some choosing not to return to work due to lingering virus fears and government handouts.

site_title: OCBC gets nod from covered bondholders to transition to Sonia from sterling Libor
summary: OCBC has secured approval from covered bondholders to transition its £250 million sterling floating-rate covered bonds from sterling Libor to Sterling Overnight Index Average (Sonia). This move follows the cessation of sterling Libor by the end of 2021 and is the first bank in Asia to complete this transition. The change will provide certainty for investors and pave the way for other bond issuers to follow suit, with the sterling Libor vs Sonia interpolated basis set at 0.078%. The Sonia rate will be effective from June 14, 2021.

site_title: Prolonged JBS meat shutdown could hit China hardest
summary: A prolonged shutdown at JBS meat supplier due to a cyberattack could disproportionately affect China, the world's largest beef buyer and a significant market for JBS. China's reliance on JBS for beef shipments, combined with already record-high beef prices, could lead to further food inflation and shortages. The shutdown affects JBS plants in the US, Canada, and Australia, with Beijing taking food security concerns seriously ahead of the 100th anniversary of the founding of the communist party. The impact on China's food supply and prices remains uncertain.

site_title: Prime US Reit acquiring two office assets for US$245.5m, to be part funded by placement
summary: Prime US Reit has agreed to acquire two office assets, Sorrento Towers in San Diego, California, and One Town Center in Boca Raton, Florida, for US$245.5 million. The acquisitions will be partially funded by a private placement exercise to raise at least US$80 million. The properties have strong tenancies, with occupancy rates of 95.6% and 94.7% respectively, and weighted average lease expiry (WALE) of 6.6 years and 6.2 years. The deal is expected to boost Prime US Reit's free-float market capitalisation by 24% and is seen as accretive to the Reit's assets under management (AUM) growth profile.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu

site_title: Singapore PMI stays in expansion in May, though slowing from Apr on Covid-19 curbs
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector remains in expansion, with the Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) at 50.7 in May, down from 50.9 in April. The sector has now experienced 11 consecutive months of growth, albeit at a slower pace. The slowdown is attributed to Covid-19 restrictions, with the electronics sector also showing a decline in expansion. Despite this, economists expect the sector to grow 5.5% this year, driven by global trade growth, and forecast full-year manufacturing growth at 6%.

site_title: Huawei launches new operating system for phones, eyes 'Internet-of-Things' market
summary: Huawei has launched HarmonyOS, a new operating system for smartphones, aiming to recover from US sanctions that have hindered its handset business. The system is designed to be an 'Internet-of-Things' platform, connecting devices such as laptops, smartwatches, and appliances. Huawei plans to have HarmonyOS on 200 million smartphones and 100 million third-party smart devices by the end of the year. The company views HarmonyOS as a way to bridge the gap between devices, enabling easy connection and file sharing.

site_title: UBS ramps up 'Netflix' of banking to tap into stream of millionaires
summary: UBS has launched a hybrid digital wealth management platform, MyWay, to target a broader range of clients, including those with $250,000, in an effort to tap into the growing pool of millionaires. The platform, which has attracted $3.7 billion in assets in its first year, offers personalized recommendations and digital tools to help clients manage their investments. This shift marks a major change in the private banking industry, where human connections have traditionally been key. UBS aims to capture 50% of the market for private clients outside of its billionaire core client base, with the potential to pull in $30 billion in assets within the next 12 months.

site_title: Bond traders glimpse taper-talk roadmap that revives volatility
summary: Bonds are experiencing renewed volatility as investors anticipate the US Federal Reserve's discussion on tapering its massive bond-buying program. Despite no policy move expected in June, traders are betting on an August shift, which could lead to a climb in 10-year yields to 2% by year-end. A strong May job growth report and consumer price acceleration in May have reinforced expectations of a potential taper. The Fed's current asset purchases of $120 billion per month are expected to continue until substantial progress is made towards employment and price goals, with September as a potential base case for reducing bond buying.

site_title: Tesla to buy more than US$1b of Australian battery minerals a year
summary: Tesla plans to spend over US$1 billion annually on Australian battery minerals, such as lithium and nickel, due to the country's reliable mining industry and responsible production practices. The company, which already sources three-quarters of its lithium from Australia, expects to increase its spend in the coming years. This decision aligns with the US Administration's strategy to rely on allies for electric vehicle metal supplies, and Australia is among the countries expected to benefit, alongside Canada and Brazil.

site_title: Temasek-linked directors of One Championship resign
summary: Two Temasek-linked directors, Derek Lau and Fock Wai Hoong, have resigned from One Championship's board, citing the company's plans for a public listing. The move comes as One Championship tries to recover from the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. The company recently raised US$70 million and axed a fifth of its staff, and its financial performance has been affected by high marketing and administration expenses. One Championship president Teh Hua Fung stated that Temasek and Heliconia remain supportive of the company's strategic direction.

site_title: StanChart halves maximum cashback earned on Spree credit card to S$30
summary: Standard Chartered has announced that it will cap the maximum cashback amount on its Spree Credit Card to S$30 per month from July 12, down from the current cap of S$60. The change applies to eligible transactions posted in a statement starting from July 12, while transactions from July 11 to August 10 will still qualify for the current maximum cashback.

site_title: China's third-child policy boosts shares in toy, diaper makers
summary: China's new three-child policy has boosted shares in toy, diaper makers, and infant food companies, with shares in companies like Goldlok Holdings, Jinfa Labi Maternity & Baby Articles, and Beingmate rising sharply. Despite concerns that the policy won't have a significant impact on China's declining birth rate, analysts see potential benefits in companies related to childcare and infant products. However, hedge fund manager Hu Yunlong notes that the gains are largely due to short-term speculation and may not reflect long-term changes in corporate fundamentals.

site_title: Dow Chemical's Asia-Pac president on the circular economy
summary: Dow Chemical's Asia-Pacific president, Jon Penrice, emphasizes the need for industry action to address climate change and plastic waste. The company has set targets to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 15% over the next 15 years and to remove one million tonnes of plastic waste from the environment by 2030. Penrice advocates for a circular economy, where materials are reused or recycled, and notes that partnerships with governments and recycling companies are crucial to implementing this model. He highlights Dow's efforts in innovation, such as turning rubberised sports shoe soles into sports surfaces and managing plastic waste collection through smart sorting machines.

site_title: Fewer viewings drive 11.4% fall in condo resale volumes in May after four-month climb
summary: Singapore condominium resale volumes fell 11.4% in May after four months of growth, driven by fewer viewings during the heightened alert period. Approximately 1,722 units were resold, with prices rising 0.9% month-over-month, 6.9% year-over-year. Despite the decline, prices remain higher than the five-year average, with the highest transacted price reaching S$13.3 million for a unit at The Marq on Paterson Hill. Experts predict a bounce back in property sales volume after Phase 2 is lifted, with potential price increases unless government intervention occurs.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei closes up more than 3.1% on US bounceback
summary: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei index surged 3.12% on Tuesday, rebounding from the previous day's 3% drop, driven by a US stock market bounceback. The Nikkei 225 index closed at 28,884.13, with major shares including Fast Retailing, Sony, Toyota, and Nissan also rising. Investors were monitoring Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's testimony and the dollar's appreciation to 110.45 yen. The broader Topix index jumped 3.16% to 1,959.53, with Pharmaceutical firm Eisai and Advertising giant Dentsu also gaining.

site_title: Tokyo governor extends time off on doctor's advice before Games
summary: Tokyo Governor Yuriko Koike will extend her absence from public duties for a few more days due to doctor's advice, just three weeks before the Olympics. She had been expected to return on Monday but will now take a few more days off. Koike, 68, has led Tokyo's response to the coronavirus crisis and has maintained strong public backing, with 57% of respondents supporting her handling of the virus. The decision comes at a critical time, with local elections in Tokyo on July 4 and controversy surrounding the Olympics.

site_title: Biogen soars as Alzheimer's approval cheers investors
summary: Biogen's Alzheimer's disease therapy has been approved by the FDA, marking the first clearance since 2003. The stock surged 64% after the news, with a 38% gain, its largest single-day gain since November. The approval, despite mixed results in clinical trials, is expected to dramatically change treatment for the debilitating brain condition.

site_title: Huawei aims to reach driverless car technology in 2025
summary: Huawei aims to develop driverless passenger car technology by 2025, according to Wang Jun, a senior executive at Huawei's smart vehicle unit. This move diversifies the company's business amid US sanctions, as dozens of startups, automakers, and tech firms are also working on self-driving systems. The development is expected to bring significant changes to the transportation industry, but no further details on Huawei's plans have been disclosed.

images.alt_text: China's Huawei Technologies aims to develop driverless passenger car technology by 2025, an executive said on Thursday, as the world's largest telecommunications equipment maker diversifies its business in the face of US sanctions.

site_title: Credit Suisse scraps plan to back trader's fund amid crises
summary: Credit Suisse has scrapped its plan to back Hamza Lemssouguer's credit fund, Arini European Credit, amid the bank's risk assessment following the collapse of Archegos Capital Management and Greensill Capital. The Swiss lender will not invest money or retain ownership in the fund, which was initially set to target $500 million in assets. The decision comes as Credit Suisse cuts risk across various businesses, including its prime brokerage unit, following a series of sweeping changes led by CEO Thomas Gottstein.

images.alt_text: Credit Suisse Group cancelled a plan to back star trader Hamza Lemssouguer's credit fund in a stunning about-face as it dials back risk after the implosion of Archegos Capital Management and Greensill Capital.

site_title: Hopes for 'historic' global corporate tax deal as G-7 meets
summary: Finance ministers from the G-7 nations are expected to announce support for a minimum global corporate tax rate of 15%, aimed at getting multinationals, especially tech giants, to pay more into government coffers. The move is seen as a historic step forward, with US President Joe Biden set to attend a G-7 summit in Cornwall, England, on June 11. The proposal has gained broad support from countries such as France and Germany, and a deal is considered "within sight." However, Ireland has expressed significant reservations about the proposal, citing its low 12.5-per cent tax rate.

site_title: Business protector
summary: QBE Asia CEO Jason Hammond discusses the low take-up of cyber insurance, which he attributes to a lack of awareness and the perception that the risk can be absorbed by businesses themselves. Hammond aims to improve the industry's digital capabilities and educate SMEs about cyber risks. QBE's digital strategy focuses on building a platform for partnerships and enabling end-to-end transactions, with a goal of creating capacity and improving customer experience. The company is also investing in sustainability efforts, including its Premiums4Good impact investment program, which channels a portion of customer premiums into social and environmental investments.

images.alt_text: "It's about giving people more time to be able to do things that add greater value, whether it's stronger engagement with partners, with customers, or thinking about products, or spending more time to get the pricing right." - Jason Hammond.

site_title: Singapore-headquartered DigibankASIA set to operate digital bank in Philippines
summary: DigibankASIA, a Singapore-headquartered fintech company, has received approval from the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP) to operate a digital bank in the Philippines. The digital bank, UNObank, aims to address financial inclusion in the country by offering products and services through partnerships with industry leaders. This move is seen as a step towards aligning the Philippines as a modern banking center for the region, with an estimated 71% of unbanked Filipino adults in 2019.

images.alt_text: UNObank will be helmed by Manish Bhai as CEO, a career banker and tech entrepreneur.

site_title: EH-Reit receives US$153.9m in net proceeds from sale of five Chapter 11 assets
summary: EAGLE Hospitality Real Estate Investment Trust (EH-Reit) has received US$153.9 million in net proceeds from the sale of five Chapter 11 properties. The funds will be used to repay debts, including a debtor-in-possession facility and pre-petition creditors, with US$109.7 million remaining for ongoing expenses and pre-petition creditors. The sale follows Chapter 11 proceedings by the properties, which will help EH-Reit reduce its liabilities.
